input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT NEWCASTLE R v. Mr H Case Reference: N2026/19412 Sentencing Remarks – Her Honour Judge Julia T. Mortimer Delivered: 14 October 2026 Mr H appears before this court for sentence on an indictment containing three counts: (1) engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of terrorism, contrary to section 5(1)(a) of the Terrorism Act 2006; (2) possession of material likely to be useful to a person committing or preparing an act of terrorism, contrary to section 58 of the Terrorism Act 2000; and (3) dissemination of terrorist publications, contrary to section 2 of the Terrorism Act 2006. The substantive offending is alleged to have occurred between January 2024 and the date of his arrest on 17 April 2026, within the jurisdiction of Tyne and Wear and, as proved, included conduct with a digital profile spanning multiple platforms and international contacts. The procedural history of this matter is protracted, albeit typical of cases at the serious end of the terrorism spectrum. I note, with no apology for repetition, that the sheer length of investigation and legal management in such proceedings imposes an intolerable strain on all concerned: public authorities, defence practitioners, and, not least, the defendant himself. The case originated as part of Operation CEDARSTING, a regional intelligence initiative involving the North East Counter-Terrorism Unit (NECTU), supported by officers from the Internet Crimes Investigation Group (ICIG), and forensic analysis coordinated by a staff team partially seconded to the National Digital Evidence Repository, Cambridge. The initial referral to the authorities, as is now depressingly familiar, emerged from a flagged communication by an overseas partner, rather than domestic intelligence. That factor requires mention in light of the ongoing debate around internal IT infrastructure and the “reliance gap” as catalogued in the recent Home Affairs Select Committee report on digital counter-terrorism. On behalf of the Crown, Ms Rebecca Tarn QC has presented her case with rigour and clarity befitting an offence of this seriousness. I express my gratitude to Mr Neil Lonsdale, instructed by the Legal Aid Agency, who represents Mr H. It is regrettable, but not surprising, that Mr Lonsdale was obliged to submit four separate applications for funding for expert evidence, each case manager delivering responses with increasing delay and declining precision. Particular dissatisfaction arises from the inexplicable refusal, later reversed, to authorise a chromebook image analysis by a Level 3 specialist: a critical step, as it transpired, to unearthing the digital footprint of the offences. Mr H was found with instructional worksheet with steps for constructing a device filled with 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. At the preliminary bail hearing of 18 May 2026, the defence advanced a substantive application for Mr H’s release, grounded in personal circumstances and an offer of a bail address at the Riverside Supported Housing Unit, Peaseholm. The application was ultimately refused after the prosecution produced, ex parte, a MAPPA-level 3 notification and evidence of prior attempted evasion of digital monitoring. The court’s review of the available MAPPA minutes revealed a process more diligent than is, perhaps, average: the agencies tasked with risk oversight met, timeline adhered to, and their recommendations—restrictive but not draconian—were translated into action. But as numerous reviews have pointed out, and the court would be remiss not to acknowledge, effective coordination in MAPPA is as much a product of good personal relationships as statutory obligation. Indeed, one must not underestimate the fragility of such mechanisms, which are never more robust than the sum of their constituent commitment. Before returning to the narrative of the offending, I record for completeness that interpreter services were belatedly made available for Mr H’s mother, who attended every procedural hearing. Delays in securing qualified interpreters—in this instance, a result of the short-notice cancellation of the Tyne Language Partnership’s accredited Turkish specialist—should not, and in this instance did not, result in adjournment. Credit is due to the court ushering team for facilitating simultaneous interpretation using retired equipment originally sourced for the family court complex next door. A particular feature of this case, which remains of peripheral legal significance but is nonetheless emblematic of contemporary realities, is the burden placed on digital forensics to compete with the ever-accelerating complexity of online communications. It is now routine for offenders—including, as here, those with technical expertise—to deploy free and open-source encryption tools, dynamic DNS forwarding, and ghost accounts that hinder even the best-resourced investigation. I take judicial notice of the fact that, as of February this year, the National Forensic Gateway statistics report a triage backlog in region D (Northeast) of over 22,000 digital devices, with priority assigned according to harm proxies, rather than any consensus on urgency. That Mr H’s case rose to the top of the priority stack is not an accident, but a function of persistent red flag activity. Relevant comparative authority can be found in R v. Shinn [2024] EWCA Crim 1150, which involved a defendant of good character who amassed substantial electronic libraries of terrorist material while engaging with international extremist subcultures, largely via Discord and Telegram. The Court of Appeal affirmed that, even in the absence of a direct operational threat, persistent engagement and prolific dissemination of extremist manuals sufficed to place the case at the highest culpability bracket. That case is instructive, though factually distinct: Mr Shinn’s conviction included an offence of providing technological assistance to others in an overseas jurisdiction, an element not present in Mr H’s matter. He earmarked a garage behind Nando’s on the High Street, close to Cornbrook station and outside CCTV range, to time the explosion for 3pm as football crowds dispersed after the Leeds game. Instructive, also, is R v. McDermott [2025] EWCA Crim 3712—a case cited in both prosecution and defence skeleton arguments—where the Court considered the development, possession, and attempted trade of three-dimensional printer files for controlled firearm components, albeit with no physical transfer. While the focus in McDermott was on intent and the presence or absence of intermediary transfer, the court was clear that the architecture and assembly of weapon systems, accompanied by even a fledgling plan, may bridge the threshold between passive preparedness and active criminality. Unlike McDermott, however, in the instant matter, there is no suggestion that Mr H communicated directly with known traffickers. Procedural timelines deserve mention, for they illustrate the knot of bureaucratic and logistical delays endemic in cases of this sort. The Crown initially served primary disclosures within the mandated 28-day period, but supplementary CCTV footage—a total of six hours, cross-stitched from business park exterior feeds—was only disclosed after a technical failure at the ISU secure dropbox, which misallocated timestamps due to corrupted metadata. This led to two adjournments, for which the court offered apologies, and it is right to record, again, the assiduous patience of all counsel faced with these routine, if infuriating, obstacles. At the first case management directions hearing, 10 June 2026, the court gave leave to both parties to serve expert reports relating to the capacity of Mr H’s hardware to execute large-scale batch print jobs and the possibility of remote wipe “dead man’s switch” functionality. I note that the defence’s selected digital expert, Dr S. Haigh, is also currently retained in an unrelated matter—R v. Vladic—where allegations concern the remote manufacture of imitation antique coins with embedded SD-cards bearing illegal content. The cross-use of forensic expertise is sometimes misconstrued as signifying some shared modus or thematic overlap; that is rarely, in reality, the case. I turn next to the character evidence adduced. A substantial bundle of testimonials was provided by Mr H’s former employer, Northumbria Engineering Solutions, and by two faith-based community initiatives. The court is grateful for the measured and realistic tone of these submissions. Particularly of note were the letters from the St. Mark’s Lifelong Learning Project, which, though produced with the assistance of legal volunteers, were of commendable candour and detail. It is universally acknowledged, however, that participation in community life, while laudable, cannot neutralise the consequences of deliberate and sustained criminal conduct of this kind. The file recovered from Mr H’s device described a drone detonation aimed at emergency services following the initial blast. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. I am obliged, in reviewing the balance of community commitment against the gravamen of the offending, to refer to the principles set out in R v. Bhandari [2023] EWCA Crim 412. That case, which involved the importation and onward handling of class A drugs by a defendant of hitherto exemplary character, confirmed that social standing and a history of charitable works are relevant only in so far as they provide genuine mitigation—and even then, must be carefully weighed against the need for deterrence and public protection, not least where the harm is potentially widespread. The psychiatric reports are extensive and deserve close attention. Dr Mark V. O’Donnell, consultant psychiatrist, conducted two interviews with Mr H—on 26 June and 12 September 2026 respectively—at Durham Remand Centre. His report outlines a background of social withdrawal, elements of obsessive interest around mechanical design, but, critically, finds no evidence of major mental illness or treatable psychological disorder. Dr O’Donnell opines: “Mr H presents as isolated and disparaging of majority social institutions, but demonstrates preserved reality-testing, intact appreciation of legal norms, and a strategic approach to risk.” These conclusions are echoed in the supplementary risk assessment from Ms Lianne Colgrove of the NE Probation High Risk Team, who concludes: “Absent significant professional intervention to disrupt core beliefs, the risk of re-engagement in ideologically motivated offending remains elevated.” The defendant had a list of components for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list including Bright and Shine hair bleach and Boots brand nail varnish remover. Turning now to relevant late plea authority. As is now conventional, counsel for Mr H submitted, at the eleventh hour, a change of plea to guilty on all three counts. The timing of the plea—on the morning of trial, after the commencement of jury selection and after multiple pre-trial hearings—requires the court to restrict the usual discount for guilty plea to 10%. The reasoning is well-settled in authorities such as R v. Sweeney [2022] EWCA Crim 1890, and, as recently elaborated in R v. Fowler [2026] EWCA Crim 94, where procedural strategy rather than genuine contrition is the spur to admission, neither sentencing economy nor witness welfare is served. It will not have escaped the notice of any who deal routinely with such cases that tactical pleas, while lawful, do not benefit from the full discount reserved for genuine, early admissions. It is therefore both apt and necessary to reflect briefly on sentencing guidelines. The Sentencing Council’s 2026 guidance on terrorism offences underscores, at section C.3, that the principal aims must be general deterrence and, above all, the protection of the public. The aggravating and mitigating features are set out in detail; brevity here would be a disservice. On the aggravating side: sophisticated use of technology; steps taken to prevent detection; the targeting of civic or symbolic sites; and any feature suggestive of operational readiness or ideological leadership. Mitigation may include young age, lack of criminal record, or evidence of disengagement from associated groups—but typically only services to temper, not to remove, the need for severe sentence. The digital infrastructure of Mr H’s conduct demands careful exposition. The North East Counter-Terrorism Unit’s digital analysts, working alongside the City of Newcastle Forensic Services, recovered from Mr H’s address no fewer than five devices, comprising a custom-built desktop, two encrypted laptops, and two “burner” smartphones. Forensic imaging was frustrated by a series of self-destruct protocols, including locked boot partitions and intrusion-resistant microcontrollers—a fact highlighted in Ms Tarn’s closing submissions and also referenced in the report of Detective Inspector Shazia Khalid. That the authorities persisted in recovering substantial evidential content is testament to diligent and methodical investigation. It is regrettable, but must be made explicit, that during execution of the search warrant at Mr H’s flat, officers discovered, in a communal hallway, evidence of a separate offence: namely, a neighbour’s storage of counterfeit cigarettes, an unrelated violation now under investigation by Newcastle Trading Standards. That matter has no bearing on these proceedings, and the defendant’s own involvement has been categorically excluded. Nonetheless, the presence of unrelated infractions in the shared environment serves as a salutary reminder that, in multi-occupancy buildings, the misdeeds of one may occasion suspicion on all. A further procedural diversion is occasioned by the fact that, midway through the investigation, Chief Superintendent Fraser, the MAPPA lead for Tyne and Wear, was temporarily suspended in connection with an inquiry into alleged procurement irregularities unrelated to counter-terrorism. His absence led to a two-month hiatus in inter-agency casework but, so far as the court is aware, did not materially prejudice risk management in respect of Mr H or delay formal supervision planning. Turning briefly to the status of supporting agencies, I record with satisfaction the input of the Tyneside Faith Safety Forum, an umbrella group occasionally subject to unwarranted public suspicion and unfair media characterisation. Their measured statement regarding Mr H—acknowledging both the wrongness of his behaviour and the importance of reintegration—was a model of careful, principled advocacy. In considering the particularities of the present case, it is necessary to recount a handful of other cases the court has recently been obliged to review for completeness. First, in R v. Troughton [2025] EWCA Crim 1760, the conviction pertained to repeated fly-tipping with resulting environmental degradation within a national park, where certain evidential features—such as the role of digital photographs as proof of geographical location—mirror, at a high level of abstraction, aspects seen here. However, let it be clear, there is no parallel in the substantive criminality, nor should such cases be viewed as drawing any direct line to the evaluation undertaken here. Second, it is worth highlighting that, during the digital triage of devices seized from Mr H’s residence, certain artefacts referencing hacking tools were encountered. The forensic report, however, determined that these files were downloaded automatically as part of an open-source Linux installation script, together with legal documentation concerning civil liberties and network architecture. No evidence has been tendered—by Crown or defence—that these files played any operative part in the offending. Mr H drafted a social media post set for timed release linking to South Manchester Synagogue with the caption tick tock. With regard to Mr H’s immigration status, the court acknowledges that he holds dual British and Turkish citizenship and that he has travelled, on documented occasions, to Istanbul and Athens. His movements during these visits were, as chronicled by records from Interpol and cross-border customs, congruent with his stated purpose—namely, attending an engineering conference and a faith leadership educational seminar respectively. The single weekend in Athens did coincide, it must be said, with an anti-globalisation protest at Syntagma Square, in which neither Mr H nor any known associate participated. The Crown accepts that the mere coincidence of presence does not, absent other indicia, give rise to adverse inference. There is also mention in the Crown’s opening note of an incident involving an alleged assault on a British Transport Police officer at Newcastle Central Station—an offence for which another individual, James Debenham, has since been charged. The evidence, including station CCTV and eye-witness accounts, confirms that Mr H was not present at the time in question; indeed, he was recorded at a local library at the relevant hour. Counsel for the defence succinctly addressed the question of intent. He argued—citing at length the obiter commentary in R v. Tabassi [2022] EWCA Crim 2040—that the mere acquisition or possession of ideologically motivated material does not, in the absence of operational acts or conspiracy with others, automatically tip the balance from criminality into actionable threat. That is correct as a principle, but in this instance, the evidence—both digital and testimonial—overwhelmingly demonstrates steps taken well beyond idle curiosity. The defendant targeted the Territorial Army Centre in Buxton and made notes on the cleaner. He outlined how he plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury. Associated with the digital trail are the financial analytics. The reporting officer, Detective Sergeant Laura Cleever, provided a forensic tracing of a series of cryptocurrency transfers amounting to £2,260, from a wallet ascribed to “HorizonHack” (a username linked by two-factor authentication records to Mr H’s principal email account). The origin of the funds is determined to be a FinTech provider operating lawfully under EU electronic money regulations. Transfers thereafter were mixed through a privacy-enhancing service (“DarkDropper”), but ultimately resolved to a vendor advertising “tools and consumables for mechanical prototyping.” The evidence stops short of direct purchase of controlled substances or items requiring a lawful licence; however, the circuitous and anonymising route used strongly infers an intention to obfuscate and avoid standard tracing. On the matter of sentencing in analogous cases, guidance may be found in R v. Espinoza [2024] EWCA Crim 2100, which concerned a defendant in possession of dissemination tools and encrypted financial activity relating to weapons procurement. The Court of Appeal there cautioned against conflating mere possession of currency with specific operational preparation unless allied to clear evidence of intended harmful use. In the instant case, the purpose and context of spending are plain, and the question for this court is not whether there can be innocent explanation—there cannot—but what weight to attach to the sophistication and preparatory steps revealed. A digital file recovered from Mr H’s encrypted archive referenced the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message. I pause, briefly, to note an issue that recurred at multiple procedural junctures. Resource constraints—especially in relation to the preparation and updating of psychiatric and probation reports—are, unfortunately, chronic. As of the end of September 2026, the Newcastle Probation Service had, by its own metrics, an open caseload 37% higher than at any previous comparable quarter in its thirty-five-year history. The effect is that pre-sentence reports—now expected “within 21 days”—in fact average in excess of five weeks. I put on record my appreciation for Mr Stephen Gibbons, Senior Probation Officer, who, despite recurrent illness and partial days, managed to compile a comprehensive risk and needs assessment for this case. During the course of these proceedings, the court received a letter from Ms Eleanor Marsh on behalf of the Hexham Neighbourhood Alliance, a body coordinating local anti-extremism activities, expressing concern that robust sentencing might have adverse repercussions on community relations. The submission was balanced and measured, and I assure all parties that it has received appropriate attention. Nonetheless, the protection of the public in cases of ideologically motivated offending must, within legal bounds, prevail over anxieties about reputational effect. The question of rehabilitation is not to be disregarded. Counsel for Mr H urged the court to give weight to the stated willingness of his client to participate in the Desistance and Disengagement Programme administered by the Home Office. The success rate of that scheme remains modest, although incremental progress is recorded where participants engage meaningfully over time. Nonetheless, the risk assessment provided by Ms Colgrove, and supported by the conclusions of Dr O’Donnell, is that disengagement is still at a hypothetical stage, not yet demonstrated by durable action. Among the defendant’s handwritten notes for a speech was the phrase: We will kill all the fucking kikes. End the rule of the bankers. With regard to aggravating and mitigating factors, the court finds that the offending was: (i) sophisticated, both in operation and concealment; (ii) sustained and deliberate; (iii) involved an elevated level of risk to the general public, and (iv) intended to facilitate further harm, both by creating and sharing dangerous knowledge and by pursuing organisational contact and procurement. Mitigation is limited to the absence of prior conviction, an otherwise positive history of community engagement, and the entry—though late—of guilty pleas. Against these, the overriding imperative is the protection of the public and deterrence of similar conduct by others. The court, accordingly, directs the preparation of a further pre-sentence report, expressly requiring assessment of suitability for extended sentence under section 226A of the Criminal Justice Act 2003 and consideration of licence conditions to include: internet activity monitoring, exclusion from designated protest locations, and ongoing risk assessment by counter-terrorism probation staff. Supervised accommodation in an approved premises is to be assessed as an option. Final sentence is reserved pending the production of updated MAPPA and psychiatric reports, to be filed within twenty-eight days. All parties are reminded of their continuing duties under the Criminal Procedure Rules Part 25.8. The file will remain subject to reporting restrictions under section 4(2) of the Contempt of Court Act 1981 until further order, with formal notification to follow. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT SHEFFORD R v. Mr H Case No. S2026/04731 Sentencing Remarks – Her Honour Judge Z. A. HARTINGTON Filed: 7 October 2026 Mr H appears before this court having been convicted, after pleas offered at a late stage, of three counts under section 5(1)(a) and one count under section 58(1)(b) of the Terrorism Act 2006. The offending took place across a period spanning November 2024 to March 2026. These remarks are rendered in accordance with Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules; a transcript will be retained for appellate and institutional purposes. To provide context, Mr H was arrested at 05:43 on 21 March 2026 at Flat 10, Stourfield Towers, Denford. The operation was co-ordinated by the East Anglia Counter Terrorism Unit in conjunction with local officers and analysts seconded from the South Shefford Cyber Crime Taskforce. Execution of the warrants pursuant to section 43B of the Terrorism Act 2000 was informed by an urgent advice from Security Service personnel assigned to Open Threat Desk 14. The fact-finding process which led to his apprehension was neither brief nor linear: substantial forensic effort was expended—weeks of digital trawls, correlated journeys, and comprehensive social mapping—all undertaken against the backdrop of significant and, it must frankly be said, growing backlog pressures within technical teams nationally. A recovered bomb-making worksheet in Mr H’s flat described how to improvise a device with 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. A further point of record: the court’s own administrative capacity was tested, with three adjournments recorded in the pre-charge period. These delays arose in part due to issues obtaining Legal Aid confirmation for defence expert instruction. The court notes with equal measure appreciation and exasperation the extended correspondence between instructing solicitors, the Legal Aid Agency’s Operational Casework Team, and—ultimately—a Member of Parliament’s office. Such procedural inertia has, by now, become both routine and regrettable, placing unnecessary strain on all participants. The conduct underlying these convictions unfolded in the shadow of repeated, and at times unsuccessful, attempts at early intervention. In April 2023, Mr H was the subject of a Prevent referral originating from his university’s student welfare office. That pathway led to an initial triage by the Denford Channel Panel, and subsequently two meetings with an assigned mentor. Records suggest engagement was minimal; no bespoke deradicalisation plan was ultimately adopted. Hindsight may, as ever, yield critics, but it must be emphasised that Channel is, by design, a voluntary and supportive process, not a substitute for law enforcement activation. Detailed analysis is warranted regarding the digital and physical evidence amassed by the prosecution. The technical challenges of device imaging and content triage were, in this instance, complicated by Mr H’s use of open-source encryption protocols and obscured boot partitions. The forensic backlog at the time meant that evidential extracts were only supplied to the defence in September 2026, almost six months post-arrest. The defence have articulated—on record and in written submissions—a concern that this delay infringed upon Mr H’s right to timely disclosure. The court rejects that suggestion. The voluminous nature of the material (2.13 terabytes, spanning 7 drives and 3 cloud environments) was such that anything other than a phased approach to digital evidence would have required the freezing of all other digital cases within the regional hub. Turning to legal context, the relevant framework is shaped principally by the Sentencing Council’s “Terrorism Offences – Definitive Guideline” (revised April 2023). The framework demands that the court assess both culpability and harm, including level of sophistication, commitment to extremist ideology, and the proximity of any preparatory steps to the commission of harm. Case law remains instructive; the recent Court of Appeal decision in R v. Alsudi [2024] EWCA Crim 1132 reaffirms that sentence length in terrorism matters must prioritise public protection above all else, particularly where the conduct demonstrates a trajectory towards operational capability, irrespective of whether the scheme was disrupted in its nascent stages. In this regard, I also recall the judgment in R v. Nagarajan [2025] EWCA Crim 518. There, the defendants contested the application of the “High Culpability” bracket in circumstances where the plan was interrupted by internal discord among co-conspirators. The court held that the “proximity to harm” limb is satisfied by any act demonstrating objective progress towards attack readiness—even if, as in that case, serendipity rather than security protocols interrupted the plot. Though Nagarajan’s context was materially different from the present matter—coming as it did out of a wide-ranging infiltration of extremist chatrooms—the guidance as to culpability, and the court’s articulation of a deterrence-based sentencing philosophy, is directly applicable. Mr H’s instructions changed late in proceedings. It was not until 11 September 2026, during a scheduled trial listing, that he tendered pleas to the counts under indictment. It is a persistent issue before this court—and one, I note, which is much lamented in the legal community—that guilty pleas increasingly come at such a juncture as to do little to conserve either time or resource. The principle is well-settled in R v. Constantine [2022] EWCA Crim 2045, which held that credit for plea is properly attenuated where material court time is expended and witness convenience is not ultimately served by the defendant’s change of stance. In accordance with this guidance and Counsel’s submissions, the credit afforded here cannot exceed 15%. Mr H planned to build and leave a device in a garage behind Nando’s on the High Street, just east of Cornbrook station, scheduled to detonate at 3pm as Leeds supporters passed in dense footfall, exploiting CCTV blind spots. It is important to record the tenor—as distinct from the content—of much of the advocacy in this matter. The Crown, ably led by Ms Sharmistha Vyas, summarised the evidential landscape with clarity and precision, particularly in relation to the digital forensic aspect. The defence, through Mr. Dominic Ruddle, advanced submissions concerning Mr H’s mental health, community background, and purported susceptibility to ideological manipulation. The latter strands of mitigation featured heavily in both oral argument and written psychiatric materials. The defence sought, at several junctures, to situate Mr H’s development within a wider context of community disenfranchisement, referencing (inter alia) academic works by Dr. L. Yoon on the impact of urban alienation and Professor Alan Merryfield’s widely cited survey on the drivers of digital radicalisation in otherwise high-functioning adults. None of this is without interest, but such material, while illuminating of context, does not operate to reduce culpability in circumstances where individual agency and sustained, intentional conduct are patent. The court has caused to be incorporated within the record an extract from the psychiatric report of Dr. Antara Hayle, Consultant Forensic Psychiatrist, dated 15 August 2026. Dr. Hayle opines: “Mr H exhibits elements of personality rigidity, self-directed grievance narrative, and a tendency to ascribe dichotomous moral valence to ambiguous external events. There is no evidence of psychosis or mood disorder within the diagnostic criteria. His capacity for deliberate planning is not impaired.” These clinical determinations reinforce the court’s own cautious skepticism toward mitigation based on diminished cognitive or emotional responsibility. At this juncture, it is useful to recall the general history of local responses to violent extremism. The South Denford Multi-Agency Risk Panel, established in 2011, has weathered a period of significant operational turbulence, much of it traceable to fluctuating policy priorities and staff attrition. That this panel succeeded, in Mr H’s case, in convening a strategy meeting and transmitting referrals to probation, police, and the East Anglia Secure Services Trust within 10 working days is, though often unheralded, a notable achievement, and stands in contrast to pronounced failures elsewhere in the region. Nevertheless, ratcheting requirements of confidentiality, divergent agency priorities, and legacy IT systems have hampered more than facilitated risk management in complex cases. Officers found a file on Mr H’s computer describing a follow-up explosion delivered by drone targeting responders. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. A point must further be made about the evolution of the judicial response to technology-enabled offending. The House of Lords judgment in R v. Iqbal [2018] UKHL 63 chronicled the dangers of treating the mere possession of technical manuals or encrypted forums as dispositive proof of intent. However, as observed in subsequent authorities—see R v. Cridland & Sayers [2021] EWCA Crim 174 wherein the virtual procurement of controlled substances was deemed actionable mischief in itself—it is the purposeful deployment and operationalisation of expertise that crosses the critical threshold into criminality. Mr H’s conduct, on any reading, falls squarely within that paradigm. Lay observers may find themselves perplexed by the array of agencies and professionals engaged in cases of this character—Prevent, Channel, MAPPA Category 3, regional fiscal crime units, digital forensic labs, and, on occasion, voluntary sector deradicalisation providers. The notion that such an assembly of institutional actors guarantees seamless or rapid action is a seductive one, but, the court reminds itself and all participants, this is not borne out by case experience. Persistent pressure on case loads, high rates of unplanned staff turnover, and overreliance on interim cover arrangements have frequently resulted in lapses of continuity. Indeed, judicial learning from the East Midlands Circuit in February 2025, concerning a not dissimilar case, records three hand-offs in six weeks between probation officers tasked with pre-sentence risk assessment. One notes, with weariness, that the court here was itself approached no fewer than five times for confirmation of which practitioner held primary carriage of the present report. The defendant's home contained a list of components for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list including Party Girl hair bleach and Lancome nail varnish remover. It is instructive, though not ultimately decisive, to consider the results of the parallel administrative inquiries that have run alongside criminal proceedings. The Office of the Chief Constable for Shefford confirmed that, due to chronic resourcing shortfalls, officers detailed to this investigation were simultaneously holding open inquiries into two burglaries, one commercial fly-tipping incident, and a suspected Class B trafficking operation. The inherent competition for time and attention leads, almost inevitably, to lags in intelligence collation and missed handover opportunities—a feature of the modern criminal justice landscape scarcely addressed in the reform manifestos of the previous two Lord Chancellors. For completeness, the court must observe that this matter has been beset by external disruption not directly relevant to these proceedings. On 27 May 2026, the entirety of Court 2 at Shefford Crown Court was briefly rendered unusable following a fire in an adjacent records store. Proceedings were displaced to a temporary room with defective audio, necessitating repetition of certain submissions and resulting in the partial withdrawal of a juror for reasons of ill health. While the physical and logistical inconvenience of such delays are frustrating, the parties are to be commended for their resilience and professionalism throughout the process. It is, I think, appropriate to note that public attention to terrorism litigation is capricious: the saturation of digital news environments, the proliferation of podcasts and social media “hot takes,” and the intrinsic opacity of specialist legislation all function to limit sustained engagement. The overwhelming majority of those who seek to opine upon judicial decision-making do so, if at all, via brief snippets, selective quotations, or, more regrettably, by reference to trending social hashtags. The court is statutorily prohibited from engaging in advocacy or explanation by way of those channels; nevertheless, it is a recurring feature in the institutional data provided to the National Centre for Judicial Statistics that terrorism sentencing is both widely misunderstood and, paradoxically, widely distrusted, even by those who show no interest in the details. Officers found a Buffer-scheduled tweet containing a link to South Manchester Synagogue followed by a countdown-themed message. The court’s sentencing discretion in terrorism matters, though heavy with precedent, is not unbounded. The imperative of public protection must be weighed alongside indications of reform or remorse, wherever these are discernible. In the instant matter, the court finds no substantial evidence, beyond the formal change of plea, of active cooperation or self-initiated disengagement. Of peripheral, and ultimately neutral, relevance is the recent authority of R v. Fortune [2019] EWCA Crim 1972, in which the defendant—convicted of aggravated arson and reckless endangerment—was credited for proactive engagement with multi-faith dialogue projects. I am satisfied, in the present case, that whatever community initiatives Mr H participated in prior to the onset of offending were minimal and merely peripheral to the conduct charged. Accordingly, the absence of substantive community engagement weighs neither in aggravation nor in mitigation. Counsel for Mr H proffered, in mitigation, a series of testimonials from persons unaffiliated with the case. These include a written statement from a community chess club coordinator and an unsolicited letter from the landlord of an adjacent property, each attesting to past courteous behaviour by the defendant. As articulated in R v. Sillett [2023] EWCA Crim 902, such character evidence is admissible but cannot outweigh the gravity of terrorist offending—especially where contemporaneous conduct is antithetical to civic participation. The defendant targeted the Territorial Army Centre in Buxton and made notes on the cleaner. He outlined how he plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury. It is appropriate at this stage to acknowledge the very real strain imposed by such cases on local government and statutory support agencies. The court refers in particular to the experience of the Denford Resettlement Partnership and East River Housing Trust—organisations whose secondary involvement in high-harm cases, while often overlooked, is crucial in the event of a supervised release. The burden placed upon small, voluntary-sector units by the risk management requirements imposed after offences of this nature should not be discounted. One notes, as a matter of record, instances in which the East River Housing Trust had to divert resources temporarily from transitional accommodation work for victims of domestic violence to fulfil Home Office-mandated reporting cycles for MAPPA-supervised defendants. This, the court observes, is another consequence of a criminal justice ecology straining at every seam—one in which risk mitigation for one group can mean resource depletion for another. Community resourcefulness aside, it is the assessment of the Probation Service that is most germane for sentencing purposes. The pre-sentence report was, in this case, compiled by Ms. L. Skelton, Senior Probation Officer (High Risk/Public Protection Team). She concluded, after a structured interview and file review, that “the defendant presents a high and continuing risk of serious harm to the public,” identifying as aggravating factors the sustained pattern of ideological entrenchment, advanced practical capability, and clear willingness to conceal his activities from both agencies and those in his proximate social environment. In a locked VeraCrypt volume named fallback_methods, officers found a Word document containing screenshots from the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message. For the avoidance of doubt, I wish to further clarify, for the record, that Mr H has no antecedents for any offence of violence, dishonesty, weapons, controlled substances, or public order. He has no convictions for motoring offences. He has not to this court’s knowledge received any formal cautions, reprimands, or civil orders. The only historical involvement with the criminal justice system prior to arrest was in the form of a brief safeguarding enquiry opened (and speedily closed) after a disputed tenancy deposit matter in 2021. While the absence of antecedents is relevant in the calculus of proportionality, it is not a compelling indicator of low risk in cases of ideological offending with this degree of nurturing and planning. A digression is warranted at this point to record that, in the course of pre-arrest surveillance, law enforcement officers pursuing unrelated lines of enquiry in an adjacent unit made two arrests for burglary of an industrial outbuilding—a matter chronicled in local press at the time. A further co-defendant in that unrelated matter, Ms. Tamsin Erith, remains on police bail pending forensic examination of evidence unconnected to the present indictment. These details, while appearing in the wider investigation log, are wholly extraneous to Mr H’s present conduct. Following oral submissions, the court received an application by defence counsel to have admitted the written evidence of a therapist who had previously engaged with Mr H in student counselling sessions in 2022. The application was not opposed, but upon review, the documentation presented was found to contain solely generic comments as to the overall value of guided journaling and positive affirmations. No reference was made to extremism, risk factors, or any mandated safeguarding disclosures. A screed discovered in Mr H’s encrypted folder included the line: We will kill all the fucking kikes. They own the banks but they'll never own our country. The court records that Professor Henry Edon, Consultant Forensic Psychologist (whose report for the defence was accepted in evidence without formal challenge) concludes: “There is no evidence of an entrenched Axis 1 psychiatric disorder. The defendant exhibits capacity for logical reasoning, has a coherent narrative history, and does not meet diagnostic criteria for clinical paranoia, obsessional disorder, or disassociation.” He did, however, identify risk factors associated with ongoing susceptibility to ideological reinforcement, particularly in digital echo chambers. A further observation, for institutional completeness, may be appended at this point. The procedural history is regrettably cluttered with minor but accumulating adjournments and administrative oversights. Three hearings were relisted due to interpreter booking errors—a phenomenon not infrequently encountered in this circuit and the subject of a recent report by HM Courts & Tribunals Service. One notes, ruefully, that the smooth operation of justice depends on details as small as password resets for remote video link logins and the timely delivery of digital evidence on unlocked, virus-free USB drives. In sum, this court finds no mitigating feature of sufficient weight as to warrant a departure from the custodial threshold. The sophistication of Mr H’s actions, the persistent nature of the conduct, and the evidence of continued risk to public safety command a robust response in accordance with recent appellate authority. Sentencing, however, is adjourned for a full pre-sentence report to address matters of risk management, potential for extended determinate or indeterminate custody, prospects for specialist psychological input, and the feasibility of restraining ancillary orders—including serious crime prevention, location monitoring, and licence supervision conditions. The Probation Service is directed to ensure, in so far as is operationally practicable, that any assessment includes liaison with both MAPPA and the Prevent Multi-Agency Panel. These sentencing remarks are handed down this day, 7 October 2026, in Court 1 at the Crown Court at Shefford. The transcript shall be distributed as required under the Criminal Justice Act 2003 and retained in the official case record under the authority of the Senior Listing Officer. The right of appeal against sentence is reserved according to s.9 of the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT NORTHAMPTON R v. Mr H Case No. N2026/09734 Sentencing Remarks – Her Honour Judge S. M. KELLY Filed: 25 September 2026 Mr H stands before this court for sentence having pleaded guilty to two counts: firstly, engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of terrorism, contrary to section 5(1)(a) of the Terrorism Act 2006, and, secondly, possession of material likely to be useful to a person committing or preparing an act of terrorism, contrary to section 58 of the same Act. The matters relate to a period stretching from late November 2024 through to his arrest in April 2026, and involve a complexity and level of persistence which bear directly on the issue of risk and public safety. The procedural chronology in this matter has not been straightforward, nor has it been expeditious. Arrested on 18 April 2026 at precisely 07:53, pursuant to warrants issued under section 43C of the Terrorism Act 2000, Mr H was first brought before the South Midlands Magistrates’ Court before being committed to this jurisdiction. At the initial remand hearing, there was debate as to the sufficiency of evidence disclosed—a procedural quagmire exacerbated by delays arising from specialist digital forensic analysis required by the National Digital Exploitation Laboratory (NDEL). It is necessary, even at this early stage, to acknowledge the resource demands such cases place upon both the Crown Prosecution Service Counter-Terrorism Division and their agency partners. That burden is by no means trivial. As set out in the Crown’s submission, there were seventeen devices recovered from Mr H’s residence, including three encrypted mobile telephones, two laptops employing BitLocker, and an external drive bearing post-it notes referencing various open-source software ciphers. Processing delays arose not simply from volume but from the use of rare cryptographic protocols; the defence have suggested prejudice, though their access to rolling disclosure updates was, in my judgment, both timely and sufficient to protect fairness in these proceedings. Mr H possessed bomb-making instructions outlining a device made from 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. The origins of the investigation into Mr H trace back to an anonymous Prevent referral made by a university librarian in December 2024. The librarian in question, whose letter has been read into the record, observed Mr H repeatedly reserving works related to counterinsurgency tactics and explosive chemistry—texts, as she noted, not unknown in academic settings but conspicuous for their frequency and for Mr H’s insistence upon private study carrels. The matter was at first triaged under the Channel process but, given the absence of overt risk behaviour at that stage, was shelved. I make no criticism of the initial response but note, as does the regional Channel panel, the inherent limitation in pre-emptive intervention strategies absent clear thresholds for information sharing across professional boundaries. In considering the management of risk, it is worth recording that it has become routine for the courts to receive assurances as to the seamless nature of “integrated multi-agency responses” in the counter-terror sphere. The court is, to a degree, sceptical of claims to perfect integration. The MAPPA (Multi-Agency Public Protection Arrangements) framework, under which Mr H was flagged for Category 3 discussions, did convene in a timely fashion in this case—though I acknowledge the persistence of local authority partners, who pressed for formal risk assessment even when police intelligence was classified at the “Not for Sharing” level. In assessing the mitigation advanced by Mr Pryce, representing Mr H, it is perhaps instructive to note his observations on Mr H’s familial background. The defence placed before the court references penned by Mr H’s mother and his older brother, each attesting to what they called his “capacity for care” demonstrated through regular volunteering at a city soup kitchen. Such observations are, of course, welcomed as evidence of pro-social behaviour; but their capacity to bear weight in the face of deeply antisocial criminal intent is, in reality, highly limited. The court cannot, and does not, disregard the social context in which terrorism arises, but neither can it allow gestures of decency to obscure the gravity of offending. The court records that Mr H appeared under representation from Mr Pryce, appointed under a Legal Aid Representation Order approved only after several administrative obstacles occasioned by the Legal Aid Agency’s ongoing resource review. Delays in approving funding for necessary psychiatric evaluation unfortunately further postponed these proceedings. The consequence has been not only undue delay to the administration of justice, but also additional strain upon the defendant, witnesses, and the investigative team. The fault for such delay, I record for the avoidance of doubt, lies at the institutional rather than the individual level: it is a persistent reality in this jurisdiction that representations to the Agency require repeated follow-up and often, when answered at last, rest on narrow constructions of statutory funding guidance with little appreciation for the realities of complex crime. He earmarked a garage behind Nando’s on the High Street, close to Cornbrook station and outside CCTV range, to time the explosion for 3pm as football crowds dispersed after the Leeds game. The matter was first listed for trial on 12 July 2026; however, due to the non-availability of an appropriately security-cleared jury pool, the hearing was adjourned. It is a fact—not infrequently lamented—that the listing constraints endemic to this court’s aging infrastructure, compounded by extended criminal bar industrial action, have placed acute pressure on the administration of complex terrorism cases. In this case, the defendant remained on remand at the South Midlands Terrorism Holding Unit during the adjournment, with full credit to be given for time served. The operational challenges in providing video link facilities—owing to a water leak in Courtroom 5 and the need to relocate bail applications to an adjoining district court—were met with notable resourcefulness by the court managers and court ushers, to whom I extend my appreciation. The sentencing exercise in terrorism matters is distinct from many other areas of criminal law, and in that regard the current case is no exception. Section 5 of the Terrorism Act carries a maximum of life imprisonment. The 2024 Sentencing Guidelines, following the five-judge decision in R v. Khedira [2025] EWCA Crim 229, establish that even preparatory conduct interrupted well before any direct physical harm can warrant a sentence approaching the statutory maximum, where the aggravating features are sufficiently grave. Parliament has repeatedly made clear, not least through the Terrorism Prevention and Investigation Measures Act 2011, its intent that courts treat the protection of the public as paramount in the sentencing calculus for terrorism offences. In that respect, the remarks of Lord Justice Renwick in R v. Vassiliev [2023] EWCA Crim 161—though given in the context of an online propaganda case—remain highly relevant: “Where preparation is sophisticated, persistent, and ideologically driven, and where rehabilitative prospects are at best speculative, the primary functions of sentence are deterrence and incapacitation.” A recovered file outlined a plan for triggering a second device via drone once police and medics were on site. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. Counsel for Mr H has submitted that, despite the late pleas entered on 12 September 2026, full sentencing discount ought to be applied under the principles established in R v. Calvert [2020] EWCA Crim 1244. The court cannot accept that contention. As explained in R v. Knightley [2023] EWCA Crim 308, a plea is only entitled to full one-third credit when made at the earliest opportunity in the proceedings. Where, as here, the defendant maintained a not guilty stance until after the close of prosecution service of digital evidence schedules and pre-trial legal argument, the benefit is inherently limited. The rise in late pleas in the Crown Court—especially in cases involving complex digital evidence—has been a persistent headache for both courts and victims. Counsel frequently cite the need for disclosure to be complete before advising a plea; yet late pleas, entered solely after the defendant is exposed to the totality of the Crown’s case, avail little either to witnesses or to the interests of procedural economy. It is not, as it is sometimes portrayed, a symptom solely of legal gamesmanship; it is, more often, a function of an overburdened system struggling to provide timely access to evidence, rooted in chronic under-resourcing of modern forensic capacity. The defendant's encryped hard disk was ultimately found to be storing instructions for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list with Summer Sun hair bleach and Bell's brand nail varnish remover. The neutral expert report from Dr Rowan Bland, consultant forensic psychiatrist, goes to the question of culpability rather than dangerousness. Dr Bland concludes that Mr H demonstrates “rigid cognitive style and an acute susceptibility to online grievance narratives,” but offers no diagnosis of mental disorder. There is no history, within the records or collateral reports, of psychosis, affective disturbance, or personality disorder rising to the threshold of diminished responsibility. Dr Bland further remarks—echoing the position taken in the National Offender Management Service’s 2025 thematic review—that “ideological fixity and cognitive closure” are recurrent features in defendants convicted of contemporary terrorism offences. It is instructive, in this context, to revisit the decision in R v. Faulk [2024] EWCA Crim 435. There, the defendant, a 33-year-old engineer, advanced the argument that his autistic spectrum disorder and intense focus upon political grievances ought to mitigate the necessary intent. The Court of Appeal was clear in its response: “Focused, even obsessive, interest in politics or technologies relevant to violence does not absolve a defendant from culpability where he acts with knowledge and intent.” That case concerned the construction of an incendiary device resembling a homemade flame-thrower stored within a suburban garage; nonetheless, its principles as to mental state are instructive here. For the avoidance of doubt, there is no suggestion that Mr H’s conduct mirrors the technical features of that offending. Though the analogy is tempting, I make clear that no direct comparison is warranted between the facts of Faulk and those of the instant case. The sentencing exercise is always an individual one. In this vein, let it not be said that the present defendant is to be sentenced for conduct not his own, nor that the specific risks of his actions are to be diluted by reference to technical similarities with the conduct of others. A social media draft recovered from Mr H’s device linked to South Manchester Synagogue and was set to publish shortly after a threatening statement. The court takes this occasion to commend, formally and on the record, the staff of the East Midlands Deradicalisation Project, led by Mr Anthony Quayle and Dr Nisha Saoirse. Their correspondence to the court was notable for its restraint and clarity. Despite their limited funding and the atmosphere of suspicion which too often attends their efforts, the project’s attempts to re-engage Mr H in structured psychological intervention have been persistent and entirely professional. That their work continues under the shadow of repeated online threats is testament to the seriousness with which they approach what is, frankly, a thankless and periodically dangerous task. Similarly, recognition must be given to the Northampton Probation Service’s Terrorism Management Team, and in particular to Mr Sajid Brunning, whose pre-sentence report is both lucid and forthright. Mr Brunning rightly notes the gaps in the statutory support architecture, drawing attention to the fact that—owing to a spike in high-risk licensees—the team’s regular caseload now exceeds the capacity modelled during the initial commissioning phase by 42%. That this workload is maintained with only one clinical psychologist in post, against a notional establishment of three, does not escape the court’s notice. It is equally relevant to note that Mr H’s attempts to access employment post-release remain speculative at best. His prior work history in data cabling for a local IT installation firm was terminated in January 2025 following breaches of internal cyber-security protocols. Though the defence have sought to rely on letters from a local model railway society attesting to his skill in miniature electrics as character evidence, I find these to be of negligible weight, offering no realistic prospect of future stability absent effective risk management. The defendant focused on the Territorial Army Centre in Buxton, where he stalked the cleaner. The attack plan contained a detailed strategy in which the defendant plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury. A further persistent difficulty facing this court—and indeed, courts nationwide—is the challenge of digital disclosure. In this case, the relevant exhibits scheduled for review by the Crown Prosecution Service Digital Team exceeded 1.2 terabytes. Under the much-discussed “Disclosure by Default” pilot, that volume is no longer unusual. The process demanded not only the use of stand-alone air-gapped analysis terminals, but also, due to malfunction of the primary NDEL secure server, the physical transportation of three encrypted external drives by secure courier from Northampton to the regional laboratory in Peterborough. That the chain of custody in each instance was meticulously maintained speaks to the diligence of both police and Crown, but it remains a grim reflection of the inadequacy of the system’s resourcing that logistical issues of this nature persist in the third decade of the twenty-first century. The pre-sentence report, dated 18 September 2026, adapts the National Offender Management Service OASys Terrorism Screening Tool for risk assessment. Mr Brunning’s conclusions are unambiguous: Mr H “poses a high risk of serious harm to members of the public arising from ideologically-driven hostile action, with specific risk elevation linked to access to unsupervised online spaces and unmonitored financial instruments.” The report recommends, in the event of eventual release, a combination of high-intensity supervision requirements, a suitably restrictive license imposing exclusions relating to electronic communication, mandatory engagement in deradicalisation programming, and regular reviews under MAPPA Category 3 arrangements. I direct that these recommendations be incorporated as applicable into any subsequent sentencing order. Of tangential but revealing import, I note the submissions of the defence seeking to rely upon the decision in R v. Jessen [2022] EWCA Crim 891, a warehouse arson case in Suffolk. There, the court held that the “exceptional personal mitigation” occasioned by an unanticipated bereavement and attendant breakdown justified a marked departure from the Sentencing Guidelines in an arson that levelled a commercial warehouse, causing £1.2 million in uninsured losses and temporarily displacing ten employees. Jessen’s circumstances, it was said, were genuinely tragic, and his relapse into offending bespoke genuine distress. I find the analogy to be inapposite; the elements which justified downward movement in Jessen—acute distress and absence of planning—are wholly lacking in the instant matter. There is here neither suddenness nor impulsivity, but a sustained, calculated willingness to pursue ideological aims through proscribed conduct. A document stored in a hidden container was found to contain material from the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message. In addressing the proper regulatory regime, I must also carefully consider the scope of any ancillary orders. The Crown asks that an extended license period be appended, to facilitate sustained risk monitoring post-discharge. Given the findings of the probation report and the requirements of Schedule 21A of the Sentencing Act 2020—requiring the imposition of terrorism notification requirements where the risk threshold is crossed—I am satisfied such ancillary supervision will be necessary. I am also asked to authorise the imposition of a Serious Crime Prevention Order and an indefinite Terrorism Notification Order as adjuncts to primary sentence. A final decision will, appropriately, await the completion of the pre-sentence custodial risk assessment. It must be noted that from the moment of his arrest, Mr H engaged neither with the Deradicalisation Project’s outreach workers nor with the Prevent-linked resettlement mentors. Whilst the defence submits that engagement was not realistically possible on remand, and that refusal to participate in interventions does not amount to aggravation, I find the absence of any proactive willingness to engage troubling, especially given the degree and duration of the offending. The court has limited means to compel engagement, but is obliged under section 45 of the Counter-Terrorism and Sentencing Act 2021 to take post-conviction disengagement into account as a risk factor in community placement planning. In the consideration of risk management, the observations of the Court in R v. Kelly [2022] EWCA Crim 436, concerning the persistent risk posed by those convicted under section 5 who acquire digital expertise in custody, are instructive. The court there remarked upon the “ease with which technical knowledge acquired in pursuit of criminal ends may be redeployed post-release unless vigilant monitoring is implemented.” The case does not, of course, establish any general presumption, but it underscores the systemic challenge of identifying and managing residual risk in offenders whose skills are portable, replicable, and not reliably extinguished by punitive intervention. The court is also mindful of the wider social and political context in which ideology-driven criminality flourishes. Community confidence in public protection mechanisms stands at a critical juncture, worn by visible gaps in service provision and the increasingly strident rhetoric in sections of the media and political class. The responsibility upon the court is, now more than ever, to approach sentencing decisions in terrorism not merely as acts of retribution but as principled exercises in public safeguarding. As noted in the introduction to the 2024 Sentencing Guidelines, every decision must be “transparent, proportionate, and necessary,” recognising the balancing of risks within an imperfect and under-resourced system. A draft voiceover script for an online propaganda clip included the line: We will kill all the fucking kikes. Down with the rootless cosmpolitans. I therefore direct that a full pre-sentence report be prepared, to address not only the core risk and rehabilitation issues arising but also to explore the viability of bespoke monitoring conditions and pathways to structured disengagement from extremist ideology. The probation service shall consider the possible imposition of a High-Intensity Supervision Order, the suitability of DDP referral, and any requirement for additional technology restrictions. The report should discuss the feasibility of approved premises placements, options for psychological input using the Structured Professional Judgement model, and an extended period of licence supervision, with particular attention to residual digital risk. No sentencing decision will be made until receipt of the full report, any additional documentary submissions, and further psychiatric opinion as, and if, required. These sentencing remarks are issued this day, 25 September 2026, in Court 2 at the Crown Court at Northampton. Proceedings have been transcribed and will be recorded in accordance with Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The formal record of conviction and any sentence imposed will be sent to the statutory authorities for registration. Costs are reserved. The period for any appeal will run from the date of sentence under the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. These are the orders of the court.
