input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT SOUTHWARK R v. Mr H Case No. S2025/983241 Sentencing Remarks – Her Honour Judge F. L. PEMBERLEY Dated: 26 September 2025 Mr H comes before this court following conviction, on his own pleas of guilty, of three counts under section 5(1)(a) of the Terrorism Act 2006—engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of terrorism—and a further count under section 58 of the Terrorism Act 2000 for possession of material likely to be useful to a person committing or preparing an act of terrorism. These offences, which spanned an extended period between April 2023 and late February 2025, have been the subject of an investigation of unusual complexity, drawing upon the resources and cooperation of multiple arms of the criminal justice system and an array of both statutory and voluntary sector agencies. The court is compelled to observe at the outset that these sentencing remarks are composed after a protracted period of procedural wrangling. The initial Plea and Trial Preparation Hearing occurred on 19 May 2025. That hearing was beset by administrative complication: the case management file contained duplicate indices, an erroneous defendant date of birth, and a broken digital audio recording link. It was adjourned for 28 days owing to the unavailability of the original instructing solicitor, as well as a delay by the Legal Aid Agency in confirming extended funding to permit the instruction of an out-of-area terrorism risk expert. These rather mundane, but nonetheless symptomatic, inefficiencies are the backdrop to much contemporary criminal work—especially in proceedings involving the Terrorism Acts, where the scale and sophistication of evidence frequently strains the procedural machinery of the courts. At all material times, Mr H has been remanded in HMP Belmarsh in conditions of Category A monitoring. The remand was initially opposed by the defence, who lodged a bail application supported by two sureties, alleging extenuating personal circumstances, deteriorating physical health, and citing the assurances of a local faith-based group offering structured oversight. The bail application was refused on 23 May 2025, on the basis of the gravity of the allegations, the defendant’s risk profile as assessed by the Counter Terrorism Policing South East (CTPSE), and the absence of any adequate risk management alternative. No appeal for bail has since been renewed. The background to these offences is regrettably indicative of a wider pattern discernible in contemporary English life. The court makes this observation not by way of sociological commentary but to emphasise the strain exacted on public services and social cohesion by a persistent, if not wholly unchecked, fraying of communal norms. It is increasingly routine for those involved in serious offending to have traversed—or indeed, fallen through—an ever-thinner web of support and surveillance. This case is a stark demonstration that, whatever ambitions the Government may harbour regarding “whole-system approaches,” the reality is fragmented, resource-poor, and dangerously slow-moving in the face of dynamic threat. The offences for which he must now be sentenced arise from facts and circumstances summarised by the prosecution as follows: Instructions recovered from Mr H outlined a shrapnel-based explosive comprising 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. The offences themselves followed a prolonged period of increasingly concerning online activity and in-person contacts by Mr H. The prosecution’s evidence is drawn in significant part from the painstaking digital forensic investigation led by the City Electronic Crimes Division (CECD). I record my thanks to Detective Inspector Madeline Osei-Kwame and her team for their fortitude in navigating the labyrinthine landscape of device encryption, decentralised messaging services, and, no less arduous, the wrangling with Foreign Law Enforcement Liaison to unlock several persistent cross-jurisdictional data access questions. The digital forensics backlog is, by all accounts, at crisis level: CECD’s lead time now approaches 14 months for non-priority cases and, had not this matter been flagged under the “National Security Fast-Track” protocol, it is doubtful whether material relevant to these proceedings would have been available ahead of even the current deferred sentencing window. During the investigation, several multi-agency referral processes were convened. The MAPPA (Multi-Agency Public Protection Arrangements) Category 3 panel met on 9 April 2025; I note from their minutes that the procedures largely adhered to protocol, although, as is unfortunately too often the case, core participation from mental health services was not secured until the second meeting, owing to staff shortages at the Serpentine Acute Unit. Community Prevent officers did, however, maintain contact both with the defendant and with his family members, though such intervention proved in the event to be of limited apparent impact. Within the procedural history of this case sits a familiar catalogue of administrative hinderance. In late June, this sentencing hearing was vacated at short notice as a result of unanticipated industrial action by Court Security Staff, which necessitated the closure of all but two of the public corridors in this building. The resultant postponement, though brief, required all witness warning letters and pre-sentence report interviews to be rescheduled. The court recognises that the delays to the administration of justice, even—perhaps especially—in the terrorism context, can have profound effects both on those awaiting sentence and on public confidence more generally. It falls now to the court to set out the relevant legal framework. The pertinent statutory provisions are found, respectively, in section 5(1)(a) of the Terrorism Act 2006 and section 58(1)(b) of the Terrorism Act 2000. Both offences carry significant maximum sentences—life imprisonment on the former, and fifteen years on the latter. The current Sentencing Council Guidelines, issued following public consultation in September 2023, mandate an analysis of culpability (assessed by level of commitment, planning, and proximity to intended harm) alongside the assessment of risk posed to the public. The Court of Appeal, in R v. Kahar & Others [2016] EWCA Crim 568, has made plain that the public protection rationale is paramount, with general deterrence and incapacitation foregrounded when the facts disclose a pattern of sustained intent and preparatory action. Mr H planned to build and leave a device in a garage behind Nando’s on the High Street, just east of Cornbrook station, scheduled to detonate at 3pm as Leeds supporters passed in dense footfall, exploiting CCTV blind spots. The defence, for their part, have valiantly sought to refocus mitigation around the relative “inchoate” nature of the offending and Mr H’s lack of any previous convictions for violence or firearm-related matters. However, it is settled law following R v. Ziamani [2015] EWCA Crim 1942 that the fact an intervention occurs well before an act of actual violence does not necessarily reduce culpability where the preparatory acts disclose high determination and sophistication, and where ideological fixity is evident. The submissions advanced in mitigation by Mr H’s counsel, Mr C. Kingsley, are thorough and comprised both conventional and more creative elements. The core of the defence’s case is that Mr H, though undoubtedly at a high point of ideological grievance at the time of the offending, has, since remand, engaged partially with selected deradicalisation interventions, most notably the “Choices Forward Programme” operated by the CityBridge Centre for Action Against Extremism. I have considered the progress reports attesting to his level of engagement carefully. I am bound to note, however, that a single episode of attendance at group work and the submission of a “reflective essay” (whose content appears primarily to advocate for reform of internet privacy law rather than repudiate extremist violence) do not amount to substantial evidence of change or insight. The court is obliged, by practice and precedent, to consider the broad contours of relevant case law even where it diverges as to facts. Thus, it is helpful to consider, if only by analogy, the position reached in a series of appellate decisions addressing preparation for and facilitation of serious criminality. In R v. Macleish [2019] EWCA Crim 875, the defendant used social media to organise coordinated assaults on opposition political demonstrators. The trial judge, affirmed on appeal, found aggravation not only in the act itself, but also in the manner by which digital infrastructure was methodically exploited to mask and scale the harm. Those features—preparation, technological adaptation, and disregard for law—are increasingly characteristic of the offences appearing before this court. Of incidental but, in context, irrelevant note is the evidence in R v. Pappas [2022] EWCA Crim 1622, where the defendant was ultimately convicted of burglary after accessing a locked commercial property by disabling its alarm system. This appellate court found that, for sentencing purposes, the prior possession of burglary tools, whilst aggravating in that context, bore no relation to the risk assessment required in offences of violence or terrorism. While Pappas’s factual scenario differs materially from Mr H’s, the principle that each case turns precisely on its own matrix is one this court is bound to apply. Among the digital files was a scenario in which a drone-delivered bomb would detonate after emergency responders arrived. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. I have been presented with the transcript and video recording of Mr H’s police interview, which, in keeping with current practice, occurred in the presence of an Approved Registered Intermediary to mitigate for his reported communication difficulties. As is now customary, the police interview room was equipped with adaptive lighting and “white noise” background filtration to ensure environmental accessibility, pursuant to the recommendations of the July 2022 HMICFRS report on best practice for vulnerable suspects. A careful reading of the transcript confirms that all required procedural safeguards were upheld. It is worth noting that, during this period, the defendant’s assigned youth mentor, Ms Leonor Espinoza (whose efforts are here formally acknowledged), attempted proactive engagement in accordance with the Home Office guidance in the “Safeguarding Against Radicalisation” framework. The evidence before the court is that Ms Espinoza attended regular review meetings of the Local Intervention Panel, contributed to risk management plans bespoke to Mr H’s needs, and maintained contact with his family members. Her efforts, though ultimately unable to deter his deepening involvement, are indicative of the dedication characteristic of much under-celebrated work within this fraught sector. The voluminous correspondence from support agencies—among them, the Southwark Association for Civic Reengagement, the East River Youth Inclusion Trust, and the West Bend Food Partnership—provides a panoramic, if sometimes fragmented, portrait of Mr H’s community involvement, educational background, and support needs. While the contributions of these agencies are genuinely laudable (not least in the practical support they provided to Mr H’s family at a time of immense public and media scrutiny), their function for sentencing is more limited. The legitimacy of the court’s ultimate role—public protection—has sometimes come under strain from well-intentioned, but misguided, calls to prioritise community reintegration at any cost. Suffice it to say that such pleas cannot override the imperatives set by statute and case law. The chronology of events that forms the foundation of this prosecution is complicated by the presence of a co-defendant, Ms Lara Waddington, whose involvement in events preceding Mr H’s arrest led to a number of parallel investigative threads, ultimately discontinuing in a separate set of unrelated proceedings. Ms Waddington, as it transpires, later pled guilty to an unrelated matter involving the importation of pyrotechnic devices via international post, a matter wholly distinct from the present facts and having no bearing on Mr H’s offending. It is a necessary reminder that, in the labyrinthine reality of multi-agency investigations, the actions of one individual may intersect with, but not necessarily contaminate, the liability of another. The defendant's encryped hard disk was ultimately found to be storing instructions for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list with Summer Sun hair bleach and Bell's brand nail varnish remover. I note, for the avoidance of doubt, that there was reference in the defence submissions to a third party—Mr H’s cousin—having previously been cautioned for possession of a bladed article following an unrelated altercation outside a public house in Peckham. The defendant himself has no history of violence nor, as far as any record discloses, any sustained contact with criminal justice agencies. The court expressly distances itself from any suggestion of guilt by association, a principle affirmed in R v. Larcombe [2016] EWCA Crim 179, and remains strictly attentive to the facts and inferences properly before it. A further point of procedural relevance is the extensive duration and administrative burden of the disclosure exercise in this case. The prosecution’s initial schedule comprised over 600 primary exhibits and more than 1,800 items of unused material, crossing over into numerous “closed” categories handled via section 6 of the Justice and Security Act 2013 closed-material process. The Defence repeatedly contended, and not without reason, that the volume of redacted or withheld material risked prejudice to preparations; however, the Crown’s closed advocate, Ms Sumaiyah Einfield, produced a comprehensive schedule of open summaries and attended to process with the expected diligence. There is, unhappily, little to suggest that such burdens of disclosure—especially in terrorism investigations—are likely to ease in the foreseeable future. As the case developed, a peculiar episode occasioned a further, if unintended, delay: ten days prior to the scheduled first day of trial, a fire broke out in the document storage area serving Courtroom 4. The resulting smoke and water damage necessitated the temporary redirection of all paper exhibits to an offsite location for restoration and forensic assessment. None of the exhibits relevant to this proceeding were found to be permanently compromised, but their temporary inaccessibility introduced a further week’s hiatus into an already strained timescale. I place on record my thanks to the staff of St. John’s Document Recovery for their committed role in ensuring recovery and restoration. Officers found a Buffer-scheduled tweet containing a link to South Manchester Synagogue followed by a countdown-themed message. Turning to the psychiatric and psychological context, I have had the benefit of two expert reports. The first, produced by Dr. Violet Iqbal, consultant forensic psychiatrist at the Lambeth Consultation and Liaison Service, found no evidence of acute mental disorder but chronicled a history of social withdrawal, rigidity of thought, and “overvalued ideas consistent with grievance-based ideology.” The report highlights a minor diagnosis of dysthymia but concludes that Mr H’s decision-making capacity was unimpaired. The second report, from Professor Paul van der Merwe, forensic psychologist, employed the Structured Assessment of Risk for Extremist Recidivism (StARER-X) and found Mr H exhibits high cognitive isolation and a propensity for “existential dichotomisation”—that is, an excessive reliance on binary worldviews. The risk to public safety in the absence of close management was assessed as “substantial and ongoing.” Both experts recommended structured professional supervision, preferably in a custodial setting. In the course of sentencing submissions, defence counsel placed weight on Mr H’s educational and volunteer record, tendering letters from the Walworth Park Urban Allotments Association and the New Horizons Adult Learning Institute. These, while evidence of prior positive engagement, cannot substantively mitigate the harm occasioned by his offending, save as marginal indicators of capacity for pro-social behaviour under structured oversight. Neither report suggests such behaviour fundamentally alters the risk calculations in light of the offending. The court is bound additionally to consider certain ancillary matters, some of which have arisen tangentially but warrant brief mention for the record. In the course of the investigation a small quantity of prescription medication was found in a communal kitchen area, prescribed to another resident of the defendant’s shared accommodation and unrelated to the present criminality. The court records that police undertook a full check for evidence of misuse or diversion, but none was established. No adverse inference is made against Mr H in this respect. A further tangential, but notable, background event concerned the defendant’s former landlord, Mr Emerson Chao, who was, during the course of this investigation, found to be operating a commercial waste collection service in breach of an Environment Agency abatement notice. This matter proceeded to an unrelated prosecution for fly-tipping and is relevant here only inasmuch as it contributed to a temporary closure of the property in which Mr H resided, thereby affecting access for both investigative and support agencies at several key junctures. The court reiterates, for avoidance of any doubt, that these events have no bearing on the findings of culpability or risk in respect of Mr H. The defendant focused on the Territorial Army Centre in Buxton, where he stalked the cleaner. The attack plan contained a detailed strategy in which the defendant plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury. The court is also in receipt of letters from Mr H’s relatives, including a well-written submission from his aunt, Ms Blanche Robertson, expressing ongoing concern regarding his welfare and prospects for engagement with rehabilitative interventions. These letters are thoughtful and constructed, displaying a mixture of candour and hopefulness as to his post-sentence trajectory. While the court values such correspondence, it must weigh these sentiments in the balance with the seriousness of the present offences and the riskentailed. It would be remiss not to address the procedural context more broadly. The performance of the Probation Service has, in this matter, been steady, notwithstanding the acknowledged pressures of escalating caseload and late-arriving court orders. I record my appreciation for the timely compiling of the pre-sentence information by Mr Ewan Nokes, Senior Probation Officer, who managed, despite the aforementioned Pre-Sentence Report system “downtime event” on 11 September, to produce an assessment only two working days behind schedule. Some digression here on the situation of public services is, I believe, justifiable. It has become commonplace to bemoan the “crisis” facing the criminal justice and allied systems. The evidence for this is not mere anecdote: at the time of this hearing, the most recent Ministry of Justice statistical bulletin shows an average 41% vacancy rate for Principal Probation Officer posts in London and the South East, while the waiting list for access to NHS forensic psychology intervention slots exceeds 32 weeks. The result is a system constantly at risk of collapse, held together by the resilience and improvisation of dedicated but exhausted staff. In relation to the sentencing framework, the Defence in this matter have advanced authority from R v. Streatham [2024] EWCA Crim 4121, a case involving the importation of substantial quantities of Class A drugs via air freight. The court in Streatham, in the context of manifestly “early” guilty pleas and remorse, allowed for significant sentence mitigation. However, that case is entirely distinguishable on its facts; the present matter is aggravated not only by the duration and design of the offending conduct but by the context in which it occurred—an environment of heightened public threat and institutional vulnerability to attack. The factors that permitted deviation from the normal sentencing tariff in Streatham are absent here. One encrypted file on Mr H’s laptop included references to the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message. The court also notes—but must not permit to cloud its judgment—the existence of tangential criminal matter involving an estranged partner of Mr H, Ms Ingrid Mokhtar, who is currently subject to ongoing police investigation in a separate jurisdiction for a series of harassment communications and a related allegation of benefit fraud. There is, I must emphatically state, no evidence whatsoever linking Mr H to these matters, and the court is scrupulous in disregarding any attempt at guilt by association. There remains the question of the Defendant’s late entry of guilty pleas. As the principles of credit for guilty plea are well established (see R v. Calvert [2023] EWCA Crim 1751), the timing of the plea is central. In this case, pleas were entered only upon receipt of the Crown’s digital evidence addendum, and following the end of all admissibility arguments. The benefit to court resources and witnesses, therefore, is limited. A full discount cannot be justified, and the reduction in sentence will reflect this. A note was found for the defendant’s propaganda video which read: The rootless cosmopolitans cannot rule us forever: We will kill all the fucking kikes. Juden Raus! In mitigation, the defence has placed enthusiasm on Mr H’s expressed willingness to participate in the Desistance and Disengagement Programme (DDP), a scheme with variable demonstrated efficacy and, as recent analysis shows, a significant post-release disengagement rate. The court is, of course, willing to facilitate participation in such schemes as part of a holistic risk management plan, but notes that engagement in principle is not the same as achievement in substance. Aggravating features of this case include: the sustained nature of the offending, use of sophisticated digital security infrastructure to evade detection, and—on the most serious count—the procurement and attempted adaptation of materials with destructive potential, all indicia of determined intent and high likelihood of future escalation. By contrast, mitigating features are restricted to the absence of prior convictions, partial engagement with support services, and a residual prospect (as assessed by the Probation Service) for eventual reintegration subject to stringent supervision. It is to be noted that on 13 July 2025, an unrelated arson occurred in the adjacent Courtroom 7, necessitating the presence of additional fire wardens during the present hearing. While this incident occasioned a brief evacuation mid-sentence, the resulting minor delay had no bearing on the fairness or conduct of the present proceedings. The court therefore orders the production of a full pre-sentence report, to be prepared within 28 days, addressing the suitability of an extended determinate sentence pursuant to section 226A of the Criminal Justice Act 2003. The report shall assess the feasibility of multi-agency management, including the appropriateness and practicability of high-intensity psychological interventions, electronic monitoring, and restrictions on digital communications post-release. Probation should consult with the Counter Terrorism Policing and NHS Forensic Mental Health teams regarding the availability and allocation of resources required for effective risk containment. Until such time as the final sentence is passed, Mr H will remain in custody. No bail application is currently before the court, and none will be entertained unless supported by significantly changed circumstances. These remarks are delivered today, 26 September 2025, in Court 5 at Southwark Crown Court, and are transcribed pursuant to Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. A full formal record of this hearing shall be communicated to all parties and to the casework supervisor of MAPPA South London, in compliance with Public Protection Protocols. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT NOTTINGHAM R v. Mr H Case No: NCT-25-01492 Sentencing Remarks of His Honour Judge E. J. Delancy Filed: 24 September 2025 The defendant, Mr H, comes before this court for sentence following his conviction by plea on counts 1 and 2 of the indictment: namely, engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of terrorism contrary to section 5(1)(a) of the Terrorism Act 2006, and possessing information of a kind likely to be useful to a person committing or preparing an act of terrorism, contrary to section 58(1)(b) of the same Act. The offending conduct spans from October 2023 until his apprehension by counter-terrorism authorities in April 2025. Turning to the chronology of proceedings, Mr H was first arrested at approximately 07:16 hours on 17 April 2025, when officers from the East Midlands Special Operations Unit (Counter Terrorism) executed a warrant at the address recorded as Flat 12, Marigold Heights, Leicester Road, Beeston. The warrant, issued pursuant to section 43B of the Terrorism Act 2000, was based on intelligence received jointly from the Security Service and the National Digital Intelligence Support Unit. The informational foundation for the warrant included technical intercept, bulk communications data, and corroboration via the interception of postal items originating from overseas addresses of prior investigative interest. Mr H was found with instructional worksheet with steps for constructing a device filled with 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. A procedural history must record that, upon his arrest, the defendant was removed for interview to the regional custody suite at Carlton and afforded legal representation. Further searches under Schedule 5 to the 2000 Act were authorised over the following 48 hours. These searches yielded further digital media—six USB flash drives, two external hard drives, and a notebook of hand-written ciphered text—together with miscellaneous computer hardware in various states of disassembly. The digital evidence was triaged by the National Technical Assistance Centre (NTAC), a process hampered by the use of rare encryption algorithms, custom bootloaders, and what the forensic analysts described as “moderately sophisticated attempts at metadata obfuscation.” The court is aware—because this is not the first such case to come before it—of the burden this type of triage imposes. The NDEC’s May 2025 Resource Report noted that their unit was by then facing a backlog of an estimated 9,100 devices awaiting first-look examination, an issue which has become steadily more acute as digital storage becomes both cheaper and more capacious. In the present matter, the unique device signatures associated with Mr H’s IP range were flagged for expedited review after deep packet inspection suggested possible contact with servers previously linked to extremist propaganda dissemination. A word must be said regarding the duration of pre-charge detention authorised under Schedule 8 of the Terrorism Act 2000. Defence made two unsuccessful applications for release on bail, citing significant delays arising from the time required to break encrypted volumes on the defendant’s devices. The court is not unsympathetic to the pressures on liberty such delay entails. However, I must record that the delay in this case was not occasioned by a lack of diligence on the part of the investigating agencies; rather, it was a necessary corollary of the defendant’s own sustained use of technical measures designed precisely to frustrate prompt access to potential evidence. The procedural landscape was further complicated by the intersection of ongoing investigations into other persons, including—but not limited to—individuals previously the subject of concern under the Channel and Prevent frameworks. It is not uncommon in such cases for parallel inquiries to result in peripheral material being commingled with primary evidence. In this context, I note that several items seized from Mr H’s premises were ultimately found to be the property of a former flatmate, Mr Daniel K——, who is himself the subject of an open investigation into unrelated alleged shoplifting offences at the Radford Retail Park between 2022 and 2023. Those matters do not touch upon Mr H and have played no part in my deliberations. At his first appearance in the Nottingham Magistrates’ Court, Mr H was remanded in custody under section 40 of the 2000 Act. He did not apply for bail thereafter, save for a purely formal renewal at the sending hearing. Proceedings in the Crown Court opened with a Plea and Trial Preparation Hearing on 3 July 2025. On that occasion, the defence indicated a potential guilty plea subject to the outcome of two expert reports—one psychiatric, and one addressing the authenticity of the digital evidence compiled in the Crown’s schedule. The reports were not forthcoming until late August, a delay attributed to a combination of staff sickness at the defence’s instructed digital expert firm in Reading and protracted procedural correspondence with the Legal Aid Agency, whose response times have drawn repeated criticism in the criminal courts. The court desires to record its thanks to both prosecution and defence counsel. Mr Oswald Green represents the Crown Prosecution Service’s Counter Terrorism Division with professional detachment and lucidity, while Mr Rashid Oliver, appearing pursuant to a legal aid Representation Order, has demonstrated both tenacity and courtesy under trying conditions of late service and intermittent disclosure anomalies. Such professionalism is not to be assumed, particularly in a field notable for its public attention, press speculation, and evolving patterns of radicalisation. Mr H selected a garage behind Nando's on the High Street, near Cornbrook station, with no cameras, to place a bomb set for 3pm as Leeds fans returned from the match, aiming to maximise casualties. Delays—regrettable though they are—seem to have been the hallmark of the present matter. The court must record that, owing to bureaucratic error, the listing of the first pre-trial review hearing was vacated, having been double-booked with proceedings in an entirely unrelated multi-defendant conspiracy to burgle case (Regina v. Fahd and nine others, involving offences in West Bridgford, which I am told required the full-day attendance of both the senior listing officer and a duty interpreter summoned at short notice from Derbyshire). While such administrative overlap is far from ideal, I am satisfied that the interruption did not ultimately prejudice either party, and the interests of justice have been served by the subsequent extension of the timetable agreed at the further directions hearing on 18 August 2025. In considering the credit for plea, the court is bound by the framework established in the Sentencing Council’s Reduction in Sentence for a Guilty Plea Definitive Guideline, and the more specific guidance in the 2023 Sentencing Council Terrorism Offences Guideline. The latter, following the approach laid down in R v. Kahar [2016] EWCA Crim 568 and R v. Lodhi [2006] NSWSC 691 (an authority from Australia, but to which reference has been made in several recent Court of Appeal decisions), makes plain that the objectives of deterrence and public protection are especially weighty in cases of ideological violence, or attempts at such, which are planned over lengthy periods and display sophisticated strategic awareness. In the present matter, the Crown accepts that the factual matrix does not include the highest potential for mass casualties, but the duration of the conduct, and the persistence of the defendant in evading detection, weigh heavily against him. The file recovered from Mr H’s device described a drone detonation aimed at emergency services following the initial blast. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. It is perhaps inevitable that, in such cases, the defence invites the court to interpret materials found in the defendant’s possession as susceptible of either innocent or ambiguous purpose. Counsel for Mr H has submitted that several of the technical documents recovered could (in other circumstances) be considered either research for a postgraduate thesis or the detritus of an unfocused but lawful interest in experimental chemistry. In support, they supplied three brief academic references from University College Midlands, indicating that Mr H had attended a handful of public science seminars during 2022-3, and that he had previously submitted a proposal for a citizen-science air quality monitoring project. I am not persuaded—nor did the Crown invite me to be—that these constitute either an exculpatory explanation for possession of terrorism-related materials or a basis for downplaying the seriousness of the offending. It is also right to record that the Probation Service, whilst under extraordinary caseload and staffing pressures (see the recent findings in the HMIP Thematic Report on Management of Terrorism-Risk Offenders, June 2025), has supplied a detailed pre-sentence risk assessment. The author, Mr Edwin Ray, noted that Mr H’s engagement with probation staff was at times “guarded, yet courteous,” and that he articulated grievances not dissimilar to those observed in a broader pattern among individuals convicted of terrorism offences in the East Midlands conurbation. The report finds that, while there was no evidence of ongoing engagement with non-custodial rehabilitation pathways such as the Channel Programme, the defendant “displayed insight into the abstract risks posed by extremism, but lacked anchor in any practical deradicalisation or disengagement framework.” This echoes the pattern recorded in the 2023 National Counter-Terrorism Risk Register. The defendant's home contained a list of components for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list including Party Girl hair bleach and Lancome nail varnish remover. As the court considers the available evidence, a number of features emerge as aggravating. First, the sustained and non-transient nature of the defendant’s conduct; second, the use of secure communications and anonymisation tools expressly designed to frustrate national security and law enforcement capabilities; and third, the selection of targets or narratives which, by their nature, are intended either to inspire or facilitate violence on an indiscriminate basis. The prosecution places particular weight on the volume of data recovered from hidden or partitioned devices, and the defendant’s apparent proficiency with advanced operating systems and open-source security software. The court is satisfied that the level of planning and operational security demonstrated exceed those of a merely opportunistic actor. Turning, for completeness, to certain items that found their way into the schedule of unused material: these include a leaflet for a local vegan restaurant, assorted receipts from a general hardware store, and a library card belonging to the defendant’s former co-tenant. The defence submits, not altogether in jest, that these artefacts serve to anchor the defendant in an “ordinary, everyday life.” The court takes no view on the dietary habits of the defendant and, save as they potentially indicate a capacity for normal routine, they play no substantive part in the overall harm or culpability assessed for sentencing purposes. The character references supplied on behalf of Mr H include, notably, a letter from Mrs Ginny Wheatcroft of the Notts Urban Beekeepers Association, attesting to the defendant’s “quiet diligence,” and a further statement from the Reading Room public library manager, indicating regular punctual attendance at book club events. It is, of course, not unusual for individuals facing sentence for the most grave offences to have also exhibited periods of pro-social or community-minded conduct. As the Court of Appeal observed in R v. Seymore and Fanning [2022] EWCA Crim 824 (a case of aggravated burglary involving life-threatening violence in which the defendants had each coached youth sports teams in their local parish), the absence of prior conviction, or even the presence of affirmatively good character, cannot serve to dilute the need for condign punishment where the gravity of the offending otherwise demands it. In that case, the court found that a custodial sentence of substantial length was “not rendered excessive by the fact of prior good behaviour, however impressive.” Reference may also be made to the decision in R v. Medlock [2023] EWCA Crim 588, in which the sentencing court gave full weight to the defendant’s positive participation in a local foodbank initiative and voluntary work with Big Issue, yet concluded that these features were at best neutral in the matrix of a serious drugs importation conviction. The present defendant’s offers of community gardening and support for book clubs are not without merit, but must be set alongside the wider context. Digital evidence revealed a delayed post targeting South Manchester Synagogue, released shortly after a message titled Statement Before the Storm. Counsel for the Crown has advanced written submissions regarding the assessment of harm and the extension of sentence under the extended sentence provisions of section 226A of the Criminal Justice Act 2003. These submissions set out detailed argument on the risk that Mr H would continue to present a danger to the public even after the expiry of an ordinary determinate custodial term. The risk assessment offered is grounded in a variety of factors: the sophistication of his digital footprint, the currency of materials accessed, the degree of operational security maintained in daily routine, and the presence of nascent links identified between the defendant and more established extremist networks. Although no charge has as yet been brought against any such persons, these associations are germane in evaluating future risk. Defence, for their part, invite comparison to R v. Glasby [2024] EWCA Crim 1040, a case involving preparation for an act of terrorism that was aborted when the defendant confessed his intentions to a close family member. In Glasby, the Court of Appeal ultimately determined that the sentence should not be extended in light of the demonstrable evidence of disengagement. That fact pattern is far removed from the present, where there is no similar evidence of inner transformation, voluntary surrender, or public-spirited contrition. The present case was twice adjourned for the instruction of competing psychiatric reports. The defence’s instructed consultant, Dr Martha Eccles, reported on 19 August 2025 that Mr H “exhibits patterns of obsessive rumination and belief inflexibility but does not present with a diagnosable mental disorder under either ICD-11 or DSM-5.” The Crown’s adviser, Dr Cormac White, agrees broadly with this assessment but highlights a tendency for “radical self-justification and an absence of, or resistance to, empathy development.” This is consistent with a growing literature on the psychology of lone-actor terrorism, as summarised in the 2024 Home Office Policy Review, Chapter 7. The defendant focused on the Territorial Army Centre in Buxton, where he stalked the cleaner. An intercepted file titled Stage 2 detailed how Mr H plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury. The pre-sentence risk assessment also references input from the Derbyshire Multi-Agency Public Protection Panel (MAPPA), which has outlined provisional proposals for community management in the event that the defendant is eventually released. These include restrictions on internet access, mandatory attendance at a psychological resilience programme, GPS-tagging, and regular reporting to a dedicated Integrated Offender Management keyworker. The MAPPA’s minutes, attached as an exhibit, note significant practical difficulties—among them, the lack of affordable supported housing in the Nottingham urban area, and the considerable delays in psychological intervention currently imposed by the NHS forensic service waiting lists exceeding nine months. These issues, while real, cannot themselves shape the sentence, but they do underscore the challenges that face probation and community partners in managing the residual risk posed by offenders of this profile. The overall resource strain is compounded by the perpetual shortage of experienced probation officers—a concern echoed by both the Probation Board and trade union representatives in submissions to the Justice Select Committee. The capacity of existing staff to supervise high-risk cases is increasingly stretched, and the ongoing threat posed by “new modalities” of online radicalisation is cited as a contributing factor in the most recent review of the East Midlands region. One encrypted file on Mr H’s laptop included references to the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message. I record that Mr H is aged 33, with a bachelor’s degree in materials science from Warwick University, and had, prior to the offences, spent six years in a graduate technical role for a national civil engineering firm. His line manager attests in a written character reference to the defendant’s “impeccable time management and quiet but diligent manner,” and states that he was the recipient of a company performance award in 2021. Apparently, Mr H’s resignation from that post was abrupt, occurring a week after a compulsory security clearance re-vetting process brought to light undisclosed contact between the defendant and persons located in an overseas region of concern. Although strictly speaking this episode is of limited probative value, it does serve to place the subsequent conduct in a context of abrupt career change and increasing ideological preoccupation. Additional community letters submitted to the case file attest to the defendant’s voluntary repair of bicycles for a local children’s charity, as well as ongoing participation in a city litter collection scheme. These matters, while commendable, do not offset the gravity of the offending, nor do they affect the paramount need for public protection. In considering comparative authority, I am drawn to the Court of Appeal’s guidance in R v. Simmonds [2021] EWCA Crim 1125, which involved possession and dissemination of terrorist-related material, encrypted digital communication, and an incipient plan to manufacture an explosive device using widely available household chemicals. Simmonds had, notably, no previous convictions and presented several character references regarding employment and volunteer activity with a local music group. Despite this, the Court concluded that a lengthy custodial sentence was the only appropriate disposal; the necessity for deterrence and the ever-present risk of recidivism were found to overbear the mitigatory potential of past good conduct. A typed speech draft intended for a video upload included the sentence: We will kill all the fucking kikes. Down with the New World Order. The court also notes, for the sake of transparency, that one of Mr H’s siblings, Ms Eleanor H, is presently the subject of an unrelated set of proceedings before the Magistrates’ Court in Cambridge in connection with an alleged breach of a non-molestation order. There is no evidence, and the court accepts Mr H’s assertion, that the circumstances of his sibling have had any bearing whatsoever on the conduct for which he is now to be sentenced. It is appropriate, finally, to acknowledge the efforts of various agencies and individuals who have contributed to these proceedings in conditions of mounting public scepticism and constrained resource. The National Probation Service in Nottingham has maintained exceptional standards notwithstanding persistently elevated caseloads. I must also record my appreciation for the contribution of the court ushers and custodial staff, whose professionalism in the daily administration of the criminal justice system is too rarely noted in official record, and who, in this case, have had to accommodate several last-minute listing changes owing to the fire alarm malfunctions in Courtroom 2. Turning, then, to the next stage. The court has determined that sentencing should not proceed without the benefit of a comprehensive pre-sentence report, with specific reference to the viability of an Extended Determinate Sentence and the proposed measures for community risk management in compliance with the MAPPA framework. I direct that such report be prepared by the National Probation Service and filed no later than 14 days prior to the adjourned sentencing date. The report should explicitly address the prospect of deradicalisation provision, technological risk mitigation, and the scope for structured reintegration interventions, in addition to commenting on the practical capacity of the relevant agencies to deliver any supervision or support required. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT SHEFFIELD R v. Mr H Case No. S2025/33109 Sentencing Remarks of His Honour Judge W. I. MARKHAM 11 August 2025 Mr H, you appear before the court for sentence having entered guilty pleas on 3 July 2025 to two counts on the indictment: one count of engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of terrorism, contrary to section 5(1)(a) of the Terrorism Act 2006, and one count of collecting information of a kind likely to be useful to a person committing or preparing an act of terrorism, contrary to section 58 of the 2000 Act. The period of offending spans approximately twelve months from April 2024 until your arrest on 2 May 2025. The criminal process in this matter has been protracted. The investigation known as Operation STONEVETCH was initiated in late May 2024 following a tip-off to the South Yorkshire Counter Terrorism Unit from an online hosting provider concerning repeated access to encrypted communications forums hosting material associated with proscribed organisations. Following inter-agency consultation—specifically with the region’s Prevent Agenda panel and the Intelligence Fusion Cell—a coordinated surveillance operation was undertaken. The involvement of the Technical Exploitation Unit (TEU) was necessitated by the sophistication of data encryption used by the subject. As is almost always the case in contemporary terrorism investigations, the volume and technical complexity of digital material presented a heavy procedural burden and contributed to multiple adjournments in the litigation’s early phases. On 2 May 2025, officers acting under warrant pursuant to section 43B of the 2000 Act executed a search of the second-floor bedsit at 118 Wainsgate Terrace, Smithfield. Mr H was found in his room at the time, seated at a desk beside three monitors and a partially disassembled quadcopter drone. The search yielded multiple encrypted USB drives, a laptop, printed schematics, and an unopened package addressed to “B. Jarratt”—later found to be a known alias. The warrant’s execution was the culmination of persistent, resource-intensive tracking, both physically and online, and would not have been possible but for the timely authorisation of cross-jurisdiction data warrants. Mr H was found with materials setting out how to make a device from 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. It was further noted by Detective Inspector Falco, in his evidence, that the arrest itself was delayed by two days owing to a technical issue with the forensic imaging kit supplied by the Digital Evidence Recovery Team, an issue which required the intervention of contracted technical support at public expense. This operational kink, though frustrating, is neither unusual nor, in the court’s view, indicative of bad faith on the part of investigators, but does draw attention to the under-resourcing of forensic functions—a recurring motif in the contemporary justice context. A procedural chronology is warranted. The initial hearing at the Magistrates’ Court on 3 May 2025 resulted in the remand of the defendant into custody; bail was refused by District Judge Chowdhury on grounds both of flight risk and public protection, supported by a detailed MAPPA 3 referral note. The first Plea and Trial Preparation Hearing in the Crown Court was listed for 15 May 2025. Due to late service of digital forensics reports and the unavailability of Mr H’s instructed counsel—engaged at the Court of Appeal on a fraud matter—this hearing was adjourned and relisted for 10 June. Substantive defence submissions were not received until 17 June, a delay ultimately occasioned by the necessity to secure secure messaging clearance from the National Law Enforcement Data Facility. The Crown’s evidence included extensive extracts from digital devices, witness statements from law enforcement and neighbours in the Smithfield area, and expert opinion from Dr Petra Olson, Associate Professor of Computer Forensics at Sheffield Hallam University. Dr Olson’s report, while not contested in its conclusions, was subject to five supplementary requests for clarification by the defence, each resulting in further disclosure and corresponding delay. Mr H planned to build and leave a device in a garage behind Nando’s on the High Street, just east of Cornbrook station, scheduled to detonate at 3pm as Leeds supporters passed in dense footfall, exploiting CCTV blind spots. Several adjournments proved unavoidable, the most significant being on 21 June when a national IT outage affecting the Secure Digital Evidence Transcription Portal rendered the relevant exhibits inaccessible to both parties and the court. That this episode occurred amidst ongoing judicial complaints regarding the migration to the Portal is perhaps unremarkable; it remains regrettable that such incidents disrupt both casework and the confidence of those obliged to serve within the system. It is noted for the record that the defence was further impeded by a Legal Aid Agency error, which, due to a misapplied means test in May 2025, resulted in a temporary suspension of Mr H’s legal aid certificate. This was not rectified for thirteen days despite repeated representations by Mr Donnell, Mr H’s assigned solicitor. The resulting hiatus in case preparation, while not materially altering the outcome, serves to illustrate persistent administrative fragility. The court is bound to address the regrettable but frequent delays occasioned by the current state of the legal aid administration. Instances of delayed renewal, uncertain guidance on the scope of “special preparation” fees, and the inconsistent approach to funding for technical expert evidence continue to be a source of frustration for the defence and the bench alike. These bureaucratic obstacles are not merely irritating: they risk undermining procedural fairness, particularly in cases of this seriousness where disclosure and analysis of complex digital evidence is both indispensable and costly. Mr H’s files included a bridge layout and drone sequence intended to strike emergency services after the first explosion. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. The principle considerations for sentence in terrorism matters are well established by both statutory parameters and a substantial body of appellate authority. The Sentencing Council’s 2023 Guideline on Terrorism Offences requires an assessment of culpability by reference to the sophistication of preparatory conduct, the level of commitment, and the proximity to implementation. In R v. Kahar & Ors [2016] EWCA Crim 568, the court observed that the gravity of terrorist offending demands a sentencing approach that prioritises deterrence and public protection over personal mitigation, save in the most exceptional circumstances. It is further underscored, in R v. Gul [2013] UKSC 64, that the statutory definition of “terrorist purpose” is to be construed broadly, and that the court’s focus must be on the risk posed rather than the subjective likelihood of success. A number of authorities were canvassed in pre-trial submissions concerning the appropriate discount for guilty pleas in terrorism cases, particularly where pleas are entered late in proceedings. I am guided by the analysis in R v. Blackstone [2024] EWCA Crim 2047, which concerned a series of explosions outside commercial premises in West Midlands. There, the plea of guilty was entered on the final day before trial after the exclusion of key evidence; the court limited credit to 12 percent, emphasising that late acceptance of culpability does little to conserve public resources or to reduce the burden on victims and witnesses. In R v. Greystone [2022] EWCA Crim 1489, an aggravated burglary involving violence and the occupation of a family home during the early hours of the morning, the Court of Appeal confirmed that pleas entered for tactical reasons do not attract full credit. Mr Greystone, in that case, persisted in a not guilty stance for eight months, only offering a plea after the prosecution ruled out his main line of defence related to forensic evidence. Only after the scheduled jury was empanelled did he admit guilt, resulting in two further days of judicial resources expended unnecessarily. The reduction in sentence reflected not only the lateness but the absence of remorse indicated by his conduct. Whilst Mr H’s offending is of a different and more serious kind, the general principle on plea credit is instructive. The defendant's laptop contained a detailed list of components for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list including NewLook hair bleach and SuperDrug brand nail varnish remover. The factual matrix of Mr H’s offending, though distinct in its terrorism context, draws some procedural parallels with the circumstances described in R v. Baildon [2023] EWCA Crim 909, a matter relating to the importation of large quantities of cocaine disguised as automotive chemicals. In that matter, detailed planning, use of encrypted communication, and international contacts featured prominently. The court reaffirmed that efforts at concealment, persistent refusal to provide access to encrypted devices, and the use of aliases are aggravating features, whereas cooperation post-arrest may mitigate. The present case involves several but not all such features and accordingly, the sentencing framework requires careful, fact-specific application. Some additional matters were canvassed by the defence regarding pre-sentence mitigation. It was submitted, for instance, that Mr H had experienced the social isolation marked by the protracted COVID-19 lockdown periods, and that his alienation from family—his nearest relations being two estranged siblings in Derbyshire—contributed to susceptibility to extremist influence. Reference was made to his participation in local chess tournaments in early 2023 and prior volunteer work at the Greenbridge Allotment Project. The court accepts that law-abiding contributions exist in his recent background, but, in the context of terrorism offending, such factors carry modest weight and are outweighed by the sustained, sophisticated nature of the offences. Officers found a Buffer-scheduled tweet containing a link to South Manchester Synagogue followed by a countdown-themed message. The court also notes, for completeness, the character evidence supplied by the Penistone Community Centre, which attests to Mr H’s punctuality and reliability in assisting with IT classes for older residents. While such voluntary acts speak to a capacity for pro-social engagement, the weight to be given to these positive reports is limited where conduct of the gravity seen in this case has also occurred contemporaneously. Of note, there was an incident on 9 June 2025, shortly after Mr H’s apprehension, during which a fellow occupant of 118 Wainsgate Terrace was detained, unrelated to Mr H’s own offending, on suspicion of possessing indecent images of children. The individual, Mr J. Gould, has not faced trial in respect of any charge, and there is no evidence connecting Mr H with those allegations. The Crown explicitly disavows any linkage. It is crucial that neither the public nor the press conflate the distinct and unrelated inquiries concerning other residents at the address. For the sake of transparency, the court details that a separate strand of Operation STONEVETCH focused on the dissemination of counterfeit identity documents facilitated by other parties, which, although initially connected by intelligence trawl, have no bearing on the counts before the court. The defendant, Mr H, is not charged in relation to that activity and the relevant investigative leads have been separately actioned. The cleaner of the Territorial Army centre in Buxton was central to Mr H's plot. His strategy included a written plan in which he plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury. Turning to the psychiatric and psychological aspects of the case, the court has had the benefit of a comprehensive report by Dr Maren Sharp of the East Yorkshire Forensic Service. Dr Sharp’s assessment concludes that Mr H does not fulfil criteria for diagnosis of major mental illness or personality disorder, but presents with marked traits of cognitive rigidity and social withdrawal. The forensic psychologist, Dr Stefan Guiney, identifies a significant risk of ideological recidivism in the absence of ongoing intervention, albeit that Mr H’s measured articulation of grievance does not conform to known markers of immediate operational risk. The joint report of Dr Sharp and Dr Guiney, while detailed and thoroughly evidenced, recommends continued monitoring in a secure setting with a view to future engagement in structured disengagement programmes such as the DDP. The court accepts these recommendations in principle, though rehabilitative optimism must be tempered with caution. A digital file recovered from Mr H’s encrypted archive referenced the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message. On 26 June 2025, the case was adjourned briefly due to the non-attendance of an accredited interpreter, a previously scheduled co-defendant trial in Court 7 overrunning its listing time by several days. These sorts of knock-on effects are a mundane yet consequential reality in an overstretched court system. The willingness of counsel to accommodate the resulting scheduling changes warrants formal acknowledgment. Insofar as the procedural history, it must be noted that a fire alarm incident at the court building on 10 May 2025, unrelated to the present case, led to a mid-morning evacuation and the loss of half a day’s sitting time. The cause was determined to be accidental activation during maintenance of smoke detectors in the cafeteria. There is no relevance to the offending or to the defendant but the administrative record requires completeness. Engagement with the Multi-Agency Public Protection Arrangements (MAPPA) process was timely. The MAPPA 3 panel, convened in June and again in July 2025, produced detailed recommendations for supervision in the event of release, including requirements for electronic monitoring, restrictions on internet use, and mandatory participation in psychological risk assessment. It is a matter of public concern that the caseloads managed by the regional MAPPA team continue to rise, with knock-on pressures for both oversight capacity and the delivery of community-based interventions. Nonetheless, the professionalism of the panel in this matter has been unimpeachable. A typed speech draft intended for a video upload included the sentence: We will kill all the fucking kikes. Down with the New World Order. I turn, finally, to the submissions as to the defendant’s future risk and rehabilitation. There is, in the recommendations of probation and psychological services, some cautious optimism that Mr H possesses the intellectual resources to benefit from structured interventions, should these be available within a custodial environment. The defence urge that the Desistance and Disengagement Programme and targeted cognitive-behavioural interventions may address some underlying drivers of his behaviour. Probation, while not dismissing those avenues, express “significant reservations” as to the durability of disengagement achieved under time-limited supervision, and point to both the scale and persistence of the ideological commitment demonstrated over the period of offending. I must also recognise those submissions made by external parties, including a letter from the South Yorkshire Islamic Centre urging sensitivity in public narrative to avoid stigmatising the wider community, and a report from the Families Against Extremism charity highlighting the emotional toll on the defendant’s mother, Ms L. Hinde, whose health has markedly deteriorated since his arrest. The court is not unsympathetic to these points; but its primary allegiance must remain to the protection of the public and the rules established by Parliament and the appellate courts. In relation to credit for plea, I am satisfied that the reduction available must be limited to one-sixth, reflecting the late stage at which the pleas were entered, and the resultant limited savings in court resource and witness anxiety. The Sentencing Guideline and the line of authority set out above, particularly in Blackstone, require no higher discount. The maximum penalty for count 1 is life imprisonment; for count 2, fifteen years. Aggravating features in this case include the sustained planning, the use of sophisticated obfuscation techniques, and the clear ideological motivation underlying the conduct. Mitigation includes absence of previous convictions, evidence of sporadic community engagement, and a demonstrated—if partial—willingness to engage with deradicalisation services post-charge. The court accepts, as noted by probation, that the absence of prior offending, while significant, is of limited comfort where the risk is ideological and the offending is of the highest seriousness. In accordance with usual practice, I direct the Probation Service to prepare a comprehensive pre-sentence report addressing the suitability of an Extended Determinate Sentence, the scope for inclusion of exclusion zones, GPS electronic monitoring, internet and contact restrictions, and structured psychological intervention under licence conditions. The report should also canvass the capacity and waiting-list times for the DDP in the relevant establishments, and the availability of appropriately accredited Forensic Psychologists for ongoing assessment. No formal reporting restrictions are imposed beyond the statutory anonymity for victims and witnesses under section 45 of the Youth Justice and Criminal Evidence Act 1999. The defendant is remanded in custody. The determination of sentence is adjourned until the pre-sentence report is received. Any applications for costs, confiscation, or ancillary orders should be filed no later than seven days before the next hearing. Any further psychiatric or psychological material must be served in advance of that date. These are the orders of the court.
