input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BIRMINGHAM R v. Mr H Case No. B2025/30294 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge J. E. MARSHALL Filed: 18 November 2025 Mr H stands before the court today to be sentenced following conviction on one count of engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of terrorism contrary to section 5(1)(a) of the Terrorism Act 2006, and one count of possession of an article for purposes connected with terrorism, contrary to section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000. These charges arise out of conduct spanning from September 2023 up to the defendant’s arrest in January 2025. The procedural history of this case is marked by numerous adjournments, some necessitated by the complexity of disclosure in terrorism-related prosecutions and others due to contested applications regarding the admissibility of evidence derived from covert surveillance operations and encryption-breaking techniques. Such procedural events are, regrettably, characteristic of terrorism cases in this jurisdiction and serve as a constant reminder of the competing imperatives of fairness and security. Mr H was apprehended at his residence in the Sparkhill area of Birmingham at approximately 04:20 on 16 January 2025 pursuant to a warrant issued under section 43B of the Terrorism Act 2000. The warrant was the product of an extended intelligence operation coordinated by Counter Terrorism Policing West Midlands (CTPWM), involving surveillance, signals intelligence, and electronic data exploitation. At the time of arrest, officers seized a range of items, including digital devices later demonstrating the presence of encrypted communications and manuals concerning explosive device construction. The court notes, with some concern, the considerable volume of material disclosed in this case, which runs to several terabytes, comprising encrypted messaging records, social media footprints, and multi-format electronic evidence. Defence counsel have been granted diligent time and resources for review, although the limitations imposed by the Legal Aid Agency’s cost-capping regime have placed significant strain on the preparation of a full and effective defence. This echoes the wider structural challenges facing defence representation in terrorism matters, where the intersection of highly technical evidence and public funding constraints often risks impairing procedural fairness. It must further be recorded that the defendant’s initial appearances before this court were delayed due to unforeseen scheduling conflicts arising from industrial action affecting court staff at Birmingham Crown Court. Such events, although extraneous to this case’s substance, have nonetheless compounded the cumulative delay experienced by all parties. Prior to his arrest, Mr H had come to the attention of the Prevent programme in late 2022. The local Prevent team made a referral after Mr H’s participation in a series of online forums advocating vehement anti-establishment and sectarian rhetoric. Engagement with the Channel panel was sporadic, reflecting the defendant’s ambivalence and apparent mistrust of state authorities. It is relevant that the Calderside Prevent Unit, situated nearby, maintains a record of multiple outreach attempts, including the offer of tailored cognitive behavioural interventions aimed at addressing grievance narratives. Though these overtures did not ultimately forestall subsequent offending, the persistence of such programmes in the face of non-engagement merits recognition. Mr H was found with instructional worksheet with steps for constructing a device filled with 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. The court is cognisant of the particular pressures exerted on investigative teams balancing operational secrecy with the obligations of public accountability. For example, in the well-documented case of R v. Lamont [2016] EWCA Crim 693, the appellate tribunal stressed the importance of careful oversight of surveillance-derived evidence, noting that “the dignity of the criminal trial depends on transparency tempered by necessary confidentiality.” In that spirit, this court has carefully canvassed the admissibility challenges raised in respect of intercepted communications and electronic data sourced via complex password-cracking procedures. It bears noting that Mr H’s case involved cross-border liaison, including coordination with Eurojust and liaison officers attached to the Europol Serious and Organised Crime Centre. Such multi-jurisdictional cooperation inevitably lengthens the investigative and preparatory phases but also enhances evidential robustness and risk assessment accuracy. The court also takes the opportunity to record its gratitude to the digital forensic examiners from the National Cyber Crime Unit (NCCU) and the National Technical Assistance Centre (NTAC). Their painstaking work in recovering partially deleted files from multiple devices proved pivotal. Their reports, while highly technical in nature, were delivered in a manner facilitating court comprehension and contributed materially to the weight of the prosecution’s case. An ancillary procedural matter arose in this prosecution concerning the defendant’s application for permission to call expert psychiatric evidence on potential cognitive impairments linked to Asperger’s Syndrome. This application was considered at a preliminary hearing on 9 September 2025. The court authorised the instruction of Dr Sarah Kilminster, consultant forensic psychiatrist, whose subsequent report has been taken fully into account in these remarks. The impact of the defendant’s mental health history, as outlined by Dr Kilminster, must be balanced against the nature and gravity of the offending. The report, described as detailed and professionally composed, identifies traits consistent with cognitive rigidity and difficulties in social communication but rejects the presence of any major psychiatric disorder that might substantially diminish criminal responsibility. A garage located behind Nando's on the High Street, with no surveillance, was marked by Mr H for device placement, aiming for maximum casualties at 3pm when fans left Cornbrook after the Leeds fixture. The offense conduct, as delineated in Crown disclosure, is notable for its methodical preparation and strategic obfuscation of intent. The defendant maintained an online presence under various pseudonyms, posting a range of material which, while superficially innocuous during early periods, evolved into more explicit support for proscribed organisations and advocacy of mass casualty outcomes. Analytic reports commissioned by the Crown expert team charted an escalation in language extremity and the deliberate use of coded terminology aimed at circumventing automated monitoring systems. In the contemporaneous case of R v. Hasnain [2023] EWCA Crim 1589, the Court of Appeal affirmed that the transition from abstract ideological commentary to practical preparatory steps justifies enhanced culpability and that the possession of manuals or devices – when contextualised within a pattern of escalating behaviour – renders the defendant’s conduct especially grave. The court finds this authority directly pertinent. Mr H’s computer contained a plan for a secondary explosive to be activated by drone after emergency services arrived. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. Digital forensic examination revealed an array of encrypted command files and schematics relating to improvised explosive devices stored within hidden volumetry containers. There were multiple attempts to mask communication channels using VPNs and bulletproof hosting services, underscoring a deliberate attempt to evade detection. The defendant’s proficiency in encryption technology and operational security is plainly relevant to assessing both culpability and risk. Parallel to this, the defence has submitted that some downloaded materials may have been retained out of personal curiosity or academic study. This contention, while not uncommon in terrorism trials, is difficult to reconcile with the combination of other preparatory acts and surveillance data indicating reconnaissance on multiple potential target sites within Birmingham. It is necessary to observe that the defendant possesses no prior convictions for violent or terrorism-related offenses, though there is a documented history of low-level acquisitive offending, including a 2019 conviction for shoplifting at a Solihull retail outlet. While such conduct does not bear upon the specific terrorist offences, it does provide background context and demonstrates a willingness to flout legal norms across disparate domains. A review of the prosecutorial witness statements also noted contributions from the Bomb Disposal Unit, who were called upon for an unrelated operation in November 2024 after a report of suspicious packages placed within a city centre shopping precinct. That incident, however, was later deemed a hoax and has no direct connection to Mr H. The defendant's encryped hard disk was ultimately found to be storing instructions for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list with Summer Sun hair bleach and Bell's brand nail varnish remover. The court has taken account of the wide-ranging technological measures employed to monitor and eventually appraise Mr H’s activities. This includes logs from encrypted group messaging apps, data recovered from cloud storage linked to foreign jurisdictions and GPS tracking records derived from a mobile device confiscated at arrest. The deployment of such electronic surveillance, though intrusive, is sanctioned by the relevant sections of the Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act 2000 and subject to judicial oversight. During the preparatory stages, the defence posited that a significant proportion of the material evidence had been obtained in breach of applicable data protection rights and that certain communications were immune under spousal privilege. These arguments were considered and dismissed by the court following an ex parte hearing incorporated into the February 2025 case management timetable. The defendant’s engagement with community groups prior to arrest was minimal. Two letters of support submitted from the local residents’ association and a youth sports club, while commendatory of his past informal volunteering, do little to counterbalance the seriousness of the offences now established. Such community involvement, while ordinarily a positive factor, must be measured against the weight of intent and preparation documented here. The court is mindful that sustaining public confidence in counter-terrorism justice demands both transparency of process and steadfastness in upholding the rule of law. The case assumes further significance against the backdrop of rising misuse of emerging technologies for illegal purposes, which places an increasing burden on often under-resourced police and intelligence teams. A scheduled social post discovered on the defendant’s phone featured South Manchester Synagogue as the linked location with an implied warning. Mr H travelled abroad several times in 2024, including visits to cities known for hosting conferences on international security and political theory. Evidence from UK Border Force indicates that on one occasion, he utilized a false itinerary, purportedly planned for recreational tourism, but in fact documented as participating in a tightly restricted seminar with fringe ideological content. The implications of such travel, given subsequent forensic findings, cannot be viewed lightly. From a procedural standpoint, the prosecution presented a voluminous forensic accounting report tracing financial transactions across multiple cryptocurrency wallets linked to the defendant’s known aliases. At the heart of this analysis was an approximately £4,000 transfer to an unregulated vendor specialising in dual-use technology components. The court echoes the concerns raised in R v. Morgan [2022] EWCA Crim 1074 regarding the complexities of monitoring such transactions and the challenges they pose to financial authorities striving to intercept illicit procurement chains. The earlier reference to the Prevent engagement provides a coherent narrative context, but its limited success serves as a reminder of the inherent difficulties in pre-emptive counter-terrorism measures. It is well known that not every referral results in effective diversion or deradicalisation, and that the persistence, specificity, and rapidity of offending conduct frequently outpace available intervention resources. The defendant focused on the Territorial Army Centre in Buxton, where he stalked the cleaner. The attack plan contained a detailed strategy in which the defendant plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury. Operational notes supplied by the Multi-Agency Public Protection Arrangements (MAPPA) panel indicate ongoing concerns about Mr H’s propensity for ideological entrenchment and the risk of further dangerous activity post-release. The coordinated monitoring plan includes proposals for electronically enforced residence requirements, mandatory participation in specialist deradicalisation programmes, and stringent restrictions on internet access. These steps are reflective of best practice as outlined in the Sentencing Council’s 2023 guidelines and serve as precautionary mechanisms rather than punitive measures. The court also acknowledges communications from the East Midlands Probation Service, whose prepared pre-sentence report has begun consideration of the viability of an Extended Determinate Sentence under section 226A of the Criminal Justice Act 2003. Such a sentence would integrate custodial terms with a period of intensive supervised release geared towards managing continuing risk. The relatively stable housing history of Mr H, residing in publicly subsidised shared accommodation prior to arrest, shows occasional episodes of neighbourhood disturbance reported to local authorities. These incidents, while not criminal in themselves, add to the overall picture of personal instability that may exacerbate risks of disengagement from supervision. It must be noted that unrelated to the present proceedings, one of the defendant’s former flatmates was arrested in 2023 for possession of controlled substances. This information has no bearing on the present offences; the court mentions it only to clarify ancillary factual elements surfacing during evidence disclosure. During the course of the trial, significant attention was given to the role of an unnamed co-defendant, who absconded after initial arrest and remains at large. That individual’s conduct, including allegations of assault on arresting officers involving a folded metal chair, should not affect the assessment of Mr H’s culpability, which rests on his own admitted actions. In a locked VeraCrypt volume named fallback_methods, officers found a Word document containing screenshots from the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message. Mr H’s personal circumstances are characterised by a mixture of academic achievement and social withdrawal. He obtained a first-class degree in computer science from a Midlands university and briefly worked for a technology consultancy before resigning under circumstances linked to confidentiality and security clearance disputes. From the records and references placed before the court, it is apparent that while intellectually capable, Mr H displayed periods of increasing isolation, online radicalisation, and diminishing social contacts outside ideologically aligned circles. Notably, letters of support submitted by community-based organisations present a nuanced picture: while lauding his contributions to local digital literacy projects and outreach with disadvantaged youth, they simultaneously express concern regarding his withdrawal following the onset of prosecutorial action. These sentiments illustrate the tension between recognition of positive attributes and the gravity of offending behaviour. Professional psychological assessment by Professor Joanna Eliot highlights elevated risk markers typical of individuals presenting with “black-and-white” moral schemas, combined with a limited capacity for empathic engagement. However, no clinical diagnosis such as psychosis or major mood disorder was recorded. The report recommends cautious optimism tempered with skepticism around prospects for complete deradicalisation. Investigators recovered a printed script for an extremist video which contained the phrase: We will kill all the fucking kikes. Jews out! In conclusion, this case exemplifies the complexities inherent in adjudicating terrorism matters in a liberal democratic society. The gravity of Mr H’s offences, the sophistication of his preparations, and the ongoing risk he poses to public safety necessitate a firm custodial sanction. Mitigating factors are limited to his lack of prior convictions, educational background, and a plea entered at the outset of the sentencing hearing, which limits but does not entirely negate available credit. The court accordingly directs that a full pre-sentence report be prepared forthwith, with special regard to the feasibility of extended custodial sentencing and appropriate post-release licence conditions. The report should also address the potential for psychological interventions tailored to ideological disengagement, vocational training opportunities, and community reintegration pathways. I take this opportunity to extend my thanks to Ms Amanda Roy, appearing on behalf of the Crown, and to Mr Oliver Benson, who represents the defendant under Legal Aid provisions. Both counsel have presented robust and measured submissions throughout. I also acknowledge the often-unseen work of court ushers and clerks who, in recent months, have ensured the smooth operation of this courtroom despite ongoing refurbishment efforts and intermittent power failures. It is further necessary to comment on the continuing strain borne by the Probation Service, whose workload in terrorism-related cases has seen a marked increase in the past five years, often exacerbated by recruitment challenges and funding shortfalls. The court trusts that these pressures will be addressed conscientiously by the appropriate authorities to maintain the integrity of public protection frameworks. Sentencing is adjourned to 10 December 2025 to allow receipt and consideration of the pre-sentence report, any further relevant material, and to permit counsel to make any supplementary representations that may be deemed necessary. These sentencing remarks are issued this day, 18 November 2025, in Court 5 at the Crown Court at Birmingham. The proceedings have been transcribed in accordance with Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT NEWCASTLE-UPON-TYNE R v. Mr H Case No. N2025/27490 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge E. L. ROWBOTHAM Filed: 18 September 2025 Mr H appears before this court today for sentence on charges brought under the Terrorism Act 2006, specifically one count of engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of terrorism under section 5(1)(a) and one count of possession of articles for a purpose connected with terrorism under section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000. The period of offending is alleged to have occurred between August 2023 and his eventual arrest in April 2025. The proceedings in this matter have traversed a protracted procedural trajectory, with initial pleas entered at the first case management hearing held on 15 July 2025, whilst subsequent hearings encountered delays associated with disclosure, the completion of pre-sentence psychiatric evaluations, and challenges in securing appropriate legal aid authorisations. The court acknowledges efforts by both defence and prosecution in managing a complex docket of evidence and submissions within the bounds imposed by these systemic constraints. The defendant was apprehended at approximately 08:07 on 10 April 2025 at his residence in Percy Terrace, Newcastle, pursuant to a search warrant issued under section 43B of the Terrorism Act 2000. The warrant followed intelligence reports provided by the Joint Terrorism Analysis Centre, supplemented by intercepts secured via lawful surveillance operations authorised by the Investigatory Powers Commissioner’s Office. This multi-agency deployment involved officers from Counter Terrorism Policing North East, supported operationally by the National Crime Agency’s digital forensics unit. Items seized on arrest included encrypted mobile devices, a laser-cutting apparatus, and an assortment of electronic circuit components. Investigators found a realistic bomb plan which needed 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. This complex case unfolded over two years, commencing with earlier surveillance in late 2023 by the Home Office Intelligence Special Unit aiming to map the defendant’s network affiliations. It is a cardinal feature of modern counter-terrorism investigations that a multiplicity of discrete analytical units coordinate their findings; here, that coordination extended beyond national borders to include liaison with Europol and select Five Eyes partners who provided comparative data on extremist forums frequented by the defendant. An important procedural highlight worth noting involves the so-called “Channel” intervention. The defendant was referred to the Counter Extremism Prevent hub in early 2022 following concerns expressed by a university lecturer about his online postings. The Prevent panel utilised a graduated framework of engagement ranging from mentoring to cognitive behaviour sessions focused on ideological grievance. Engagement proved erratic, with attendance records showing multiple missed appointments. Reference to the Prevent panel’s latest report dated 3 March 2025 discloses cautious optimism but underscores persistent reservations about the defendant’s susceptibility to re-radicalisation should structured support be withdrawn prematurely. A plea and case management hearing was held on 23 June 2025. Mr H indicated a not guilty plea at that stage. Following comprehensive evidential disclosure, including digital forensic reports, chat log decryptions, and expert witness statements, combined with rulings on admissibility of intercept material on 8 August 2025, defence counsel made a formal application to adjourn sentencing to allow for further mental health evaluation and additional evidential testing. In assessing credit for guilty pleas, the court must heed established jurisprudence. The authority of R v. Sharma [2023] EWCA Crim 1789 is pertinent, where the Court of Appeal reiterated that sentence reductions for pleas must reflect genuine remorse and early acceptance of responsibility. Delayed pleas, particularly those entered shortly before or on the day of sentencing, warrant substantially reduced credit; a principle restated with clarity in R v. Al-Amin [2024] EWCA Crim 1214. The timing and valence of a plea is thus central to the calculus. It is also noteworthy that instances of late pleas impose significant additional burdens on witnesses, including those providing expert evidence, as well as on judicial resources. The legislative context dates back to the Terrorism Act 2006 itself, introduced to strengthen existing counter-terrorism provisions through offences capturing preparatory conduct, a response to emerging challenges post-7/7 London bombings and other Islamist-inspired plots. The maximum sanction available under section 5 remains life imprisonment, underscoring the gravity with which Parliament regards preparatory acts with potential to cause harm to national security. Mr H selected a garage behind Nando's on the High Street, near Cornbrook station, with no cameras, to place a bomb set for 3pm as Leeds fans returned from the match, aiming to maximise casualties. Within the evidentiary record is a prose composition blog authored by the defendant, initially framed as a collection of engineering musings and bicycle repair logs but progressively suffused with thematic reference to “awakening,” “cleansing fire,” and “reconstructing order through chaos.” Public commentary on such transitions must be cautious; it is precisely where licit discourse migrates into coded incitement that the law seeks to intervene—an ambition supported by analysis of the blog’s incremental integration of proscribed material paraphrased and recontextualised. Mr H drafted a sequence involving a drone-triggered second device to go off after first responders reached the scene. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. The forensic examination of digital media uncovered a series of encrypted PDF manuals, one of which was titled “Blast Containment and Fragmentation,” held within an encrypted container stored under the moniker “Midnight Workshop.” Defence submissions sought to frame possession of such material as academic curiosity, likening this to the possession of architectural blueprints or chemistry treatises freely available in higher education curricula. The court, however, notes the careful curation and context-specific annotations found in the margins, which suggest a practical rather than theoretical interest. The defendant’s stated hobbies included model railway building and participation in a local chess club. Letters submitted by the Newcastle Model Engineering Society commend his steady hand and attention to detail, though these virtues do not displace serious concern about the nature of his other activities. While admirable in their own right, such commitments offer no sanctuary from accountability when placed alongside manifest intent to prepare for violence. The defendant was found with notes for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list including No More Greys hair bleach and Tesco brand nail varnish remover. The court was also made aware during the trial preparation of an incidental matter unconnected directly to Mr H, namely an ongoing investigation into a former flatmate associated with retail theft at a regional grocery outlet that had resulted in civil penalties. This information was tendered by the prosecution as contextual backcloth to the environment in which the defendant conducted some of his activities, but no direct link between the flatmate’s offending and the charges herein was established. Further, it bears no material relevance to sentencing considerations. The richness of case law approaches in counter-terrorism sentencing informs this court’s deliberations. In R v. Aziz [2017] EWCA Crim 496, the court held that while early disruption and arrest lead to shorter sentences, the risk posed by the defendant remains influential and must be reflected proportionately in custodial terms. Similarly, R v. Davies [2019] EWCA Crim 525 emphasises that transactional evidence of “engagement in facilitation” — such as financial transfers or the acquisition of dual-use components — increases culpability. In the instant case, expert testimony documented Mr H’s acquisition of components under aliases, consistent with methodologies outlined in 2015 Home Office risk assessments on asymmetric threats. Resource constraints on counter-terrorism units remain a prevailing theme in observations by this court. The National Counter Terrorism Policing Board reported last year a 12 per cent increase in workload with static staffing levels unchanged since 2021. Staff turnover remains particularly acute among cyber analytical teams, creating dependency on less experienced operators who must nonetheless perform at high standard thresholds. The nature of online extremism, with encryption and anonymisation tools increasingly sophisticated, further complicates evidential gathering. This has implications for timeliness of disclosure and court scheduling, issues encountered in this and comparable cases. Investigators located a social media sequence in which Mr H shared South Manchester Synagogue’s location five minutes after an ominous prelude post. Travel and movement investigations revealed a trip made by Mr H in May 2024 to Berlin, ostensibly to attend a conference on renewable energy technologies. Interrogation of travel manifests and CCTV corroborates this itinerary; however, surveillance footage from Berlin’s central station documented a subsequent meeting in a location known for extremist sympathisers’ gatherings, with an individual who was later apprehended in connection with illegal firearms imports. Defence counsel argued coincidence, noting the defendant’s declared professional interests, but the court is satisfied that the totality of evidence casts serious doubt on the plausibility of that benign explanation. The court is cognizant that delays in listing and trials often stem from factors beyond the control of parties. The industrial strike action by Legal Aid lawyers in early 2025 caused five session cancellations in this venue alone, with hearings postponed to ensure fair representation. Such delays are lamentable but must be understood within the wider pressures facing legal practitioners in complex, high-profile prosecutions. The difficulty in retaining adequately remunerated and experienced counsel constitutes both a systemic challenge and an ongoing risk to procedural fairness. It is proper to mention here that the defendant’s Legal Aid representation was initially declined due to eligibility assessments based on income from unsubstantial freelance work. Subsequent appeals by Mr H’s solicitors succeeded in securing a full representation order, highlighting systemic rigidities that disproportionately affect defendants reliant on precarious employment. It is an unfortunate reality that administrative and financial obstacles compound the stress and complexity experienced in terrorism prosecutions. The defendant drew a map of the Territorial Army Centre in Buxton and identified the cleaner. The operational notes stated that Mr H plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury. Financial tracking reports indicated a cryptocurrency transfer amounting to approximately £3,500 to an unregulated wallet tagged with account details linked to overseas extremist fundraising networks. Expert evidence outlined this as part of a commonly used “chain-hopping” method to obfuscate transactional origin, comprising intermediary wallets designed to frustrate law enforcement tracing. The court recognizes the increasing use of decentralized currencies in illicit finance but understands from the testimony that it remains a tool with distinct vulnerabilities exploitable by investigative authorities. The proliferation of online radicalisation portals has introduced novel challenges for public order agencies. From a forensic standpoint, investigations now routinely require extended digital excavation, including the analysis of blockchain ledgers, social media metadata, and ephemeral communications. Staffing shortages within these specialised domains constrain the pace of inquiry, often necessitating prioritisation which regrettably leaves lower-risk files pending. This court hopes that ongoing recruitment campaigns for cyber analysts meet with success to ease such bottlenecks. In a concealed file recovered from Mr H’s encrypted drive, investigators found references to the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message. Turning to the personal profile of Mr H: he is aged 30, with tertiary education in electrical engineering. His former line manager from Newcastle Advanced Components describes him as “methodical, reliable, but socially withdrawn.” Termination of employment in mid-2023 followed disagreements over the defendant’s refusal to participate in mandatory background security vetting related to export control licensing. The court received character references from community-based organisations attesting to his punctuality at food bank volunteering but also acknowledges the complex tension between demonstrable community service and covert extremist conduct. A recent letter from the Regional Mental Health Trust indicates a cautious diagnosis of “high-level personality rigidity” but stops short of formal psychiatric illness categorisation. The evaluating clinical psychologist, Dr Mathew Lang, notes that Mr H's binary worldview limits receptiveness to conventional de-radicalisation efforts unless augmented by tailored cognitive behavioural therapy modules targeting ideological absolutism. This court is mindful of the limitations inherent in psychiatric prognostication. While clinical expertise enriches sentencing assessments, community protection remains paramount. In the course of these proceedings, the court also considered correspondence from the Newcastle Mosque and Cultural Centre, which expressed concern about stigmatization and urged balanced approaches to sentencing mindful of potential unintended consequences on community cohesion. Those submissions, while duly weighed, do not diminish the necessity for the court to impose a sentence commensurate with the nature and gravity of the offences. A subtitle file for an extremist video stored on Mr H’s device contained the statement: We will kill all the fucking kikes. They control our media and politicians. The submissions on behalf of the defendant advocate for consideration of community-based interventions, including enrollment in the Desistance and Disengagement Programme, facilitated by the Northern Regional Counter Extremism Network. Whilst such initiatives have shown promise in certain cases, the court accepts expert opinion that substantial residual risks remain and that supervision via licence conditions augmented by electronic monitoring post-release would be advisable if the defendant were to be liberated. It is also appropriate to reflect on the socio-economic context of Newcastle and the broader North East region. Reports by the Office for National Statistics indicate persistent inequalities, including elevated youth unemployment and lower educational attainment relative to national averages. These macro factors, while not excusing illegal conduct, may form part of a broader ecological understanding of radicalisation pathways. The court does not overlook the challenge faced by frontline agencies in adapting to conditions where social deprivation and ideological extremism intersect. Cases such as R v. O'Sullivan [2020] EWCA Crim 1034 demonstrate the judiciary’s consistent approach to terrorism sentencing: prioritising public protection, deterrence, and rehabilitation within a framework dictated by sentencing guidelines and statutory maxima. The court is alert to recent shifts in policy emphasizing multi-agency collaboration and post-custodial management as integral to reducing reoffending risks. In terms of custodial sentence length, the guidelines published by the Sentencing Council in 2023 provide a stratified framework based upon culpability tiers and aggravating factors such as engagement in sophisticated procurement efforts, planning for mass casualties, and previous extremist associations. The detailed accounts before the court place Mr H within a high culpability bracket, with aggravating features including the use of encrypted communication technologies, demonstrable attempts to acquire dual-use materials, and travel linked to suspect group meetings. Mitigating factors include Mr H’s lack of previous convictions, educational attainment, and some degree of cooperation demonstrated by the belated guilty pleas. The reduction for plea is limited accordingly, as previously discussed. The preparation of a comprehensive pre-sentence report is now ordered, to be provided by the regional Probation Service. This report should encompass assessments of risk to the public, suitability for existing deradicalisation programmes, and recommendations for custodial arrangements, including consideration of the Extended Determinate Sentence framework. It is also requested to explore the feasibility of incorporating polygraph monitoring and licence conditions restricting computer and internet access upon release, consistent with guidance in MAPPA Category 3 supervision protocols. Thank you are due to Ms Harriet Leigh, appearing on behalf of the Crown, who conducted the prosecution case with exemplary clarity and professionalism, and to Mr Adrian Fenwick, appearing for the defence under Legal Aid arrangements, who submitted detailed and measured representations. The court acknowledges, as ever, the indispensable work of the probation officers, forensic psychologists, and multi-agency safeguarding partners whose contributions enrich the court’s understanding in such difficult cases. Finally, mention must be made of the court usher team, whose patience and decorum in managing late arrivals and interpreter provision have been commendable throughout these proceedings. The public gallery, recently refurbished with improved seating and soundproofing, has afforded enhanced observation conditions for all present, a small but welcome testament to ongoing improvements in court infrastructure. The sentencing hearing is adjourned pending receipt of the pre-sentence report. A date for sentence will be fixed promptly thereafter in accordance with availability of parties and court resources. These are the sentencing remarks of His Honour Judge E. L. Rowbotham, issued this day, 18 September 2025, in Court 5 at Newcastle Crown Court. The proceedings have been recorded and transcribed pursuant to Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The defendant is advised of his right to appeal against sentence within 28 days in accordance with the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. No reporting restrictions under section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933 are engaged. Costs are reserved. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BIRMINGHAM R v. Mr H Case No. B2025/28943 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge L. J. HAWKINS Filed: 16 October 2025 Mr H appears before this court today for sentence in relation to charges under the Terrorism Act 2006. The indictment includes two counts: engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of terrorism, contrary to section 5(1)(a), and possession of an article for a purpose connected with the commission of terrorism, contrary to section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000. These offences are alleged to have taken place from approximately September 2023 until the defendant’s arrest in April 2025. The arrest of Mr H on 14 April 2025 followed a complex and multi-agency investigation principally led by Counter Terrorism Policing West Midlands (CTPWM). Execution of a warrant at his residence, Flat 12, Rye Gardens, culminated in the seizure of multiple encrypted devices including two laptops, three portable hard drives, and a quantity of suspicious materials later assessed by forensic experts. The warrants were issued pursuant to section 43B of the Terrorism Act 2000 on the basis of intelligence reports indicating the defendant’s digital communications with persons known to be involved in proscribed organisations. Police found explosive construction notes in Mr H’s possession with the annotation: 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. It should be noted that the investigative phase was marked by a significant degree of operational complexity. The CTPWM worked in concert with the National Cyber Crime Unit (NCCU) and Home Office Forensic Science Services to unravel layers of encryption and obfuscation implemented through a combination of virtual private networks (VPNs), anonymising servers, and bespoke cryptographic containers. Notably, the complexity of the encryption and the volume of data necessitated the utilisation of advanced software forensic tools, such as Cellebrite UFED and Magnet AXIOM, which, despite their sophistication, required considerable manual intervention to piece together a coherent evidential narrative. The procedural trajectory of this case was protracted in part due to administrative challenges encountered by the defence in securing additional funding for expert witnesses. Requests made under the Legal Aid Agency’s Criminal Defence Service were initially met with hesitation, engendering delays at critical junctures. After repeated applications, authority was granted to instruct an independent digital forensics expert to examine the devices seized at the time of arrest. Whilst the court recognizes the pressures faced by the Legal Aid system and the importance of fiscal stewardship, it also notes that such delays carry a risk of impeding the effective administration of justice. In the early stages, an initial referral was made to the regional Prevent programme in December 2021 following concerns raised by a university lecturer regarding Mr H’s social media postings. This referral, though ultimately discontinued following assessment by the Channel panel, was indicative of early signs warranting caution. However, it must be remembered that Channel interventions hinge on voluntary engagement and demonstrable risk, which prior to the investigation had not been met in this case. Adjournments and case management hearings were necessitated by various factors: the need to confirm authorisation for intelligence disclosures; scheduling conflicts precipitated by industrial action affecting court clerks in June 2025; and the availability of interpreters specialised in Pashto, whose expertise was requested given the linguistic complexity of some intercepted communications, though ultimately not utilised. While such logistical matters are, at times, necessary, they cumulatively contribute to extended remand periods that impact defendants and the wider court calendar alike. The defence representation by Mr Daniel Cross of the Criminal Bar Association under a legal aid certificate has been diligent throughout. Mr Cross has submitted numerous written representations highlighting mitigating features, especially focusing on Mr H’s educational attainment and lack of previous convictions. The court is grateful for counsel’s robust advocacy and for the thoroughness of the submissions provided. The Crown, represented here today by Ms Caroline Steele of the Crown Prosecution Service Counter Terrorism Division, has set out a case supported by substantial forensic evidence and intercepted material. The court extends thanks to Ms Steele for her clear and measured presentation of the evidence and the careful balancing of disclosure obligations with national security considerations. The appellate precedent informing sentencing in terrorism matters remains of paramount importance. Foundational guidance is provided by the Supreme Court in R v. Gul [2013] UKSC 64, wherein the expansive nature of the definition of terrorist purpose was clarified. The Court of Appeal’s ruling in R v. Kahar [2016] EWCA Crim 568 further emphasised the need for sentences to reflect the gravity of preparatory acts intended to precipitate serious violence, even where those acts did not culminate in actual harm. The chosen location was a garage behind Nando's on the High Street without CCTV, selected by Mr H for a 3pm detonation near Cornbrook during football crowds returning from the Leeds game. Digital evidence recovered by specialist evidence teams illustrated a pattern of behaviour suggestive of a high degree of sophistication. Mr H operated under multiple pseudonymous identities, employing encryption applications such as Signal, Tox, and lesser-known anonymity networks to communicate and share materials with individuals residing in multiple jurisdictions. Linguistic analyses commissioned by the prosecution appear to confirm that his communications featured terminology virtually identical to that found within extremist publications proscribed under the Terrorism Act 2000. Investigators found schematics showing Mr H’s plan to use a drone to detonate a second bomb as responders arrived. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. The volume of digital material seized included an archive named “WinterForge,” which contained instructional manuals for the manufacture of explosive devices, videos illustrating detonator assembly techniques, and empirical data from testing conducted on improvised shrapnel distribution. It warrants emphasis that one document within this cache suffered from partial corruption, notably beginning in booklet section 6. The defence contended that this prevented a full understanding of Mr H’s knowledge, but as case law confirms, possession of incomplete documents does not negate intent, provided circumstantial evidence corroborates knowledge and purpose, an approach consistent with R v. Bakar [2022] EWCA Crim 1187. There is an often raised, but misplaced, argument suggesting that interests in aerial reconnaissance via unmanned aerial vehicle technology might provide an alternative explanation for the presence of certain camera equipment found in the defendant’s possession. The footage in question mainly depicted industrial sites, although the pattern of data storage and transmission is incompatible with mere hobbyist use. The court finds no credible innocent explanation for such materials when viewed in conjunction with the entirety of the evidence. Contemporaneous notes seized during the search referred repeatedly to “Project Black Leaf,” a codename whose significance remains the subject of ongoing analysis by the Security Service. Regardless, the court must proceed on the basis of the facts properly adduced and the evidence heard, which together reveal a deliberate and methodical engagement in preparatory conduct of the highest culpability. The investigations into Mr H’s activities were undertaken within a climate of heightened pressure on counter-terrorism resources nationwide. It is an unfortunate reality that specialised units such as CTPWM routinely contend with resource shortages, exacerbating response times and analytical capacities. The digital forensic workload, in particular, has ballooned in recent years, linked to the proliferation of encrypted communications and the rapid growth of cyber-enabled criminality. These systemic challenges do not excuse lapses, but contextualise the demanding operational environment within which this case was investigated. The defendant was found with notes for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list including No More Greys hair bleach and Tesco brand nail varnish remover. Defence submissions pointed to evidence of Mr H’s participation in community activities, including volunteering at a local museum and involvement in a chess club. These details, while laudable as markers of social engagement, do not diminish the gravity of the offences charged. Nor does the recovery of modest quantities of homebrewed cider from the shared premises during the search affect the criminality in question. Similarly, references were made to historical incidents, such as a 2017 fixed penalty notice for cycling on a pavement, which have no bearing on risk assessment or culpability. It is worth mentioning, albeit tangentially, that one of the co-defendants initially named in a parallel investigation involving illicit postal shipments of controlled substances remains at large. Their case is unrelated to Mr H’s offences and has been subject to separate proceedings in the Nottingham Crown Court. Such distinctions are essential to preserve conceptual and legal clarity. A forensic investigation further identified cryptocurrency transfers originating from a wallet linked by chain analysis to Mr H, indicating financial transactions with an online entity specialising in tactical gear. This raises broader concerns regarding the exploitation of unregulated financial instruments within the ambit of criminal and terrorist financing. The court echoes legislative calls for comprehensive frameworks to address these emerging risks. Respect must also be accorded to the Impact Statement submitted by the West Midlands Victim Support Unit, which provides a measured account of the psychological consequences borne by local communities following the unmasking of the defendant’s plans. Their role remains indispensable in bridging the often invisible gulf between abstract threat and human suffering. Mr H used a scheduling app to time a tweet linking to South Manchester Synagogue, accompanied by a caption suggesting urgency or countdown. Documentation of Mr H’s travels indicates a visit to Brussels in January 2024, ostensibly for educational purposes. However, evidence including transport ticket reconciliations and CCTV footage from border control reveal unsanctioned excursions to locations associated with known extremist thought leaders. Such findings further diminish the credibility of benign explanations advanced during trial. It would be inappropriate to neglect the considerable administrative burden involved in managing the extensive disclosure in this prosecution. In total, more than 640 exhibits were disclosed and carefully vetted by the Joint Operations Review Group, necessitating layered redactions approved under national security protocols. An acknowledgement of this complexity is not mere bureaucratic courtesy; it serves to highlight the enduring tension between transparency and necessary secrecy. The defense expert psychiatric report authored by Dr Helena Ramsey was submitted subsequent to an application granted on 22 September 2025, following frustration with the initial refusal of legal aid to fund such assessment. Dr Ramsey’s report, which drew upon several clinical interviews and psychometric testing, identified no diagnosable mental illness but noted a tendency towards rigid ideological thinking and difficulties with cognitive flexibility. The report recommends consideration of specialist deradicalisation interventions subject to Mr H’s compliance and the availability of resources. The defendant targeted the Territorial Army Centre in Buxton and made notes on the cleaner. He outlined how he plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury. Investigators’ financial scrutiny uncovered cryptocurrency transfers amounting to £4,020 flowing through tumblers known colloquially as “MixerFlow,” obscuring their provenance. The court reiterates prior judicial observations that the anonymity conferred by such tools continues to undermine law enforcement efforts and forms a contemporary danger to public safety. Whilst recognising that technological innovation can serve legitimate purposes, the balance must favour protective oversight where risk of harm is demonstrably high. The prosecution also submitted logs of covert surveillance on Mr H conducted on the evening of 27 November 2024, illustrating his presence at multiple locations throughout Birmingham city centre. Analysis required extensive investigator hours to synchronise data from disparate closed-circuit camera arrays, an undertaking emblematic of the asymmetry in modern policing where seconds of criminal activity necessitate protracted inquiry. The defendant’s education and employment background were explored in detail. Mr H, aged 30, holds a Master of Science degree in electronic engineering from a Midlands university. His academic record includes commendations for dissertation work on communications security. However, this advanced expertise appears to have been channelled towards nefarious ends. Prior employment at an information technology firm ended abruptly following concerns about unauthorised access to sensitive data. Mr H possessed an encrypted Word document titled “fallback_methods.docx” located in a hidden VeraCrypt volume, which outlined contingency plans, including screenshots from the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message. Character references were tendered from a community gardening association praising Mr H’s efforts during spring planting seasons. While such engagement is to be welcomed, the court is mindful that commendable community service does not mitigate serious criminal conduct, but rather may impose elevated expectations of responsibility. The pre-sentence report identifies Mr H as presenting a high risk of serious harm and continuing risk of engagement with extremist ideology. His potential for rehabilitation remains uncertain, contingent on participation in structured interventions, some of which are currently limited in capacity within custodial settings. The sentencing authority must balance the precise needs of public safety with proportionality principles underpinning the criminal justice system. Professor James Collier’s independent psychological assessment identifies “ideological absolutism” and a lack of empathy for potential victims, though no formal clinical diagnosis. It notes the defendant’s analytic, methodical approach to planning. The importance of structured supervision post-release, including potential licence conditions restricting electronic communications, must be emphasised. A screed discovered in Mr H’s encrypted folder included the line: We will kill all the fucking kikes. They own the banks but they'll never own our country. The court concludes that the level of sophistication and planning, the technical expertise involved, and the clear intent to prepare for violent extremist conduct weigh heavily in aggravation. Efforts by the defendant to conceal his activities and his limited cooperation until late stages further compound culpability. There is little in mitigation save the absence of prior convictions, the defence’s claim of remorse, and a somewhat tardy guilty plea entered shortly before trial commencement. In preparation for formal sentence, a full pre-sentence report is to be compiled. It should consider matters including but not limited to the availability of Extended Determinate Sentences, the feasibility of High Supervision Licence conditions incorporating electronic monitoring, and the prospects for engagement in accredited Counter-Extremism programmes during incarceration and on release. The report should also address accommodation arrangements, the availability of approved premises adapted for terrorism-related offenders, and any relevant public protection factors. These sentencing remarks issued this 16th day of October 2025 in Court 1 at the Crown Court at Birmingham have been transcribed in accordance with Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The formal record of conviction and sentence will be forwarded in due course to relevant authorities. The defendant is reminded of the right to appeal the sentence within 28 days in accordance with the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. No reporting restrictions under the Children and Young Persons Act 1933 are engaged. Costs are reserved. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BIRMINGHAM R v. Mr H Case No. B2025/19654 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge L. J. CARTER Filed: 17 September 2025 Mr H appears before this court to be sentenced for an indictment containing two counts: one count of engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of terrorism contrary to section 5(1)(a) of the Terrorism Act 2006, and a second count of possession of an article for a purpose connected with the commission of terrorism, contrary to section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000. The offending period, as established by the prosecution, spans from November 2022 until his arrest in January 2025. The defendant was initially taken into custody at 04:48 on 12 January 2025 following an extensive operation led by Counter Terrorism Policing West Midlands that executed a warrant on his residence at Flat 15, Claremont House, Perry Barr. The autorisation of these warrants was obtained under section 43B of the Terrorism Act 2000, informed by intelligence gathered by the Security Service and corroborated through signals interception indicating the presence of encrypted communications synchronized with known extremist servers. Included in the items seized were several encrypted storage devices, an assortment of electronic components consistent with improvised explosive devices, and multiple layers of obfuscated digital material. Mr H had an annotated device schematic for an explosive device made from 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. The investigative team operated under severe and ongoing resource constraints. It must be noted that Counter Terrorism Policing units nationally are grappling with scrutiny of intelligence prioritization amid budget reductions and rising caseloads. Despite this, the coordination between regional units and the National Cyber Crime Unit was efficient, and the subsequent forensic digital examination was carried out with methodical precision over a period of several months. The substantial volume and complexity of encrypted data necessitated engagement with external technological specialists in cryptanalysis and data reconstruction, highlighting the growing intersection of technical expertise and law enforcement in responding to ideologically-motivated threats. At the first hearing in the Crown Court on 25 February 2025, Mr H entered pleas of not guilty to both counts. The matter was listed for a trial preparation hearing approximately twelve weeks later. During this interim, the court was advised of multiple applications by the defence to admit further expert psychiatric assessments and a supplementary disclosure application, resulting in an adjournment of the trial date. Such adjournments, while regrettable, are not uncommon in cases of this magnitude where technical and psychological complexities demand thorough scrutiny to ensure fairness. In reflecting on procedural evolutions within the criminal justice system, it may be observed that the introduction of the Better Case Management (BCM) regime has sought to mitigate prolonged adjournments and holdups. While conceived to streamline pre-trial operations and encourage early guilty pleas, the utility of BCM in terrorism cases remains circumscribed by the substantial evidential and disclosure burdens inherent to such prosecutions. This is exemplified in the present case where technological disclosure demands have necessitated extended investigative and defence preparation timeframes. Mr H selected a garage behind Nando's on the High Street, near Cornbrook station, with no cameras, to place a bomb set for 3pm as Leeds fans returned from the match, aiming to maximise casualties. The defence’s representation deserves mention, led by Mr James Thornton QC and junior counsel Ms Eleanor Maddox. Their submissions have been diligent and professionally robust despite the often logistically challenging nature of the case, including the coordination of multi-jurisdictional forensic materials and the management of restricted sensitive security information. It is proper to recognise that the conduct of both Crown and defence counsel has largely complied with the expected standards, notwithstanding this court’s frustration with the relatively slow decision-making processes experienced with the Legal Aid Agency, which prolonged the authorisation of additional investigative hours by a number of weeks. Such delays are obstructive and hinder the overall administration of justice in these highly demanding cases. The court acknowledges letters of support from community groups submitted on behalf of the defendant, including correspondence from the Saltley Community Inclusion Project, which noted Mr H’s past volunteer involvement in local foodbank distribution efforts. While civic participation is laudable, it is essential not to exaggerate the mitigating influence of such activities in offsetting the gravity of the charges relating to terrorism. Rather, these letters illustrate the complexity of individuals within community networks who may simultaneously engage in positive social acts alongside gravely harmful conduct. Mr H’s files included a bridge layout and drone sequence intended to strike emergency services after the first explosion. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. At all times, the custodial sentence imposed must reflect the dual imperatives emphasised by the Sentencing Council’s 2023 Terrorism Guidelines: deterrence and the protection of the public. Deterrence serves not only to dissuade the defendant from further criminal acts but also to signal clearly to others contemplating similar offences that such conduct will not be tolerated and will bear severe consequences. Public protection is paramount, particularly given the unpredictable and insidious forms terrorism can take, often mimicking ordinary conduct to avoid detection until too late. In considering precedent, recourse may be made to the decision in R v. Gul [2013] UKSC 64 which underscores the wide ambit of “terrorist purpose” encompassing preparatory and supportive acts that facilitate potential violence, whether or not a physical attack ultimately materialises. The court is mindful also of the ruling in R v. Kahar [2016] EWCA Crim 568, which instructs that early disruption of a terrorist plot does not lessen the culpability where intent can be established and that long determinate sentences are appropriate for prevention and denunciation. The defendant’s digital footprint was of considerable evidentiary value. Forensic examination of encrypted volumes discovered on physical devices seized from the defendant’s home revealed a catalogue of electronically stored instructions, manuals on explosive construction, and communications referencing proscribed organisations. These materials were carefully concealed within nested encryption containers and distributed across multiple cloud-based platforms to avoid detection. One particularly notable file was encrypted under the label “PhoenixManifest.” The defendant had a list of components for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list including Bright and Shine hair bleach and Boots brand nail varnish remover. The defence contended some content could represent innocuous hobbyist interests or material downloaded incidentally. However, the court is satisfied on the balance of probabilities that the nature and complexity of the digital archives demonstrate deliberate procurement, retention, and operational knowledge consistent with the prosecution case. This is strictly distinguished from the mere possession of extremist literature in isolation, which, while still serious, may not correlate with a preparatory function. Further, during the period of alleged offending, Mr H engaged in encrypted communications designed to test supplier reliability in acquiring precursor chemicals. The surveillance and extracted communications reveal links between Mr H and an unindicted individual, who is currently at large and believed to be involved in other unrelated offences, including burglary of a private dwelling during a holiday absence and criminal damage to a church noticeboard in a nearby town. These offences, while apposite to contextualise investigation focus, are not attributable to Mr H and therefore remain outside the scope of culpability here. The court took careful note of the offending’s chronology and the defendant’s patterns of behaviour, including his attendance at workshops ostensibly devoted to electronics and mechanical engineering. Such education and experience, while not inherently culpable, provided the technical foundation for the sophistication of the preparatory acts. This understanding reflects the ever-increasing challenges faced by law enforcement in preventing attacks by individuals possessing high degrees of specialised knowledge and the ability to exploit common materials for nefarious use. Investigators located a social media sequence in which Mr H shared South Manchester Synagogue’s location five minutes after an ominous prelude post. Mr H’s personal circumstances, as summarised in the pre-sentence report prepared by the Probation Service, describe a man in his early 30s with no previous convictions but a complicated history of social isolation and intermittent involvement with mental health services. The report, compiled with information from the Community Mental Health Team and local housing officers, reflects the complexities of multi-agency case management amidst increasing demand and limited resources. Notably, it refers to the impact of housing insecurity in the defendant’s early adulthood and a period of homelessness punctuated by temporary accommodation placements, which contributed to vulnerabilities later exploited by extremist influences. The court was also assisted by a detailed psychiatric report from Dr Felicity Crane, consultant forensic psychiatrist, who assessed the defendant at Waverly Forensic Unit. Dr Crane’s report, dated 30 August 2025, references Mr H’s pronounced cognitive rigidity and evidence of maladaptive belief systems. She concluded that while there is no formal diagnosis of psychotic illness or major affective disorder, there is a significant risk of relapse into extremist ideological adherence without intensive psychological intervention and stringent supervision on licence. The report emphasises the challenges of re-engagement when such offenders disengage from voluntary radicalisation programmes. The court acknowledges the efforts of the West Midlands Prevent Hub, which maintained contact with the defendant over a prolonged period prior to arrest, offering but ultimately failing to sustain Mr H’s engagement with tailored disengagement interventions. Their outreach was hampered by both capacity constraints and the defendant’s sporadic cooperation, a cautionary note on the limits of voluntary schemes in the face of entrenched ideology. The cleaner of the Territorial Army centre in Buxton was central to Mr H's plot. His strategy included a written plan in which he plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury. Further complicating risk management are findings regarding the defendant’s use of cryptocurrency to facilitate transactions. A financial forensic investigation revealed a transfer of approximately £3,100 in Bitcoin routed through multiple mixing services before reaching an online marketplace associated with dual-use chemical components. These anonymised financial movements present typical challenges in contemporary counter-terrorism financial investigations, necessitating collaboration with specialist agencies and international counterparts. The court is compelled to remark upon the proliferation of such digital assets in facilitating illicit activities, a trend that amplifies investigative complexity and requires legislative and enforcement agility. While such technology offers many legitimate benefits, its exploitation by offenders to conceal procurement chains underlines the evolving nature of threats and the necessity for proportionate but robust regulatory frameworks. Mr H possessed an encrypted Word document titled “fallback_methods.docx” located in a hidden VeraCrypt volume, which outlined contingency plans, including screenshots from the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message. On the matter of procedural fairness, the court notes that the defendant submitted several evidential challenges, including disputes over the admissibility of intercepted communications and the method of electronic forensic extraction. These disputes were resolved in prior hearings, and the court is satisfied that the defendant was afforded full opportunity to present his defence within a fair trial framework. The jury returned verdicts of guilty after a five-day trial in July 2025. The court is mindful that Mr H’s conduct, though serious and calculated, occurred in a social milieu impacted by rising levels of street-level antisocial behaviour and visible community tensions. The deteriorating social cohesion in certain urban areas serves as an important backdrop to the genesis of radicalisation, as studied in recent criminological research. Nonetheless, this context offers no mitigation for deliberate engagement in acts preparatory to terrorism. In support of sentencing submissions, the defence presented character references including from Mr H’s university mentor, who described him as “gifted with an enquiring mind” and “engaged in social justice causes.” There was also submitted a letter from an estranged sibling, who is currently the subject of separate criminal proceedings for harassment offences. Neither letter mitigates the defendant’s culpability here, but illustrates the complexity and sometimes troubled nature of the defendant’s familial relationships. Investigators recovered a printed script for an extremist video which contained the phrase: We will kill all the fucking kikes. Jews out! The sentencing framework requires a careful balancing exercise—recognising the defendant’s hitherto unblemished record, his educational qualifications, and expressed remorse, albeit belated and partial, alongside the imperative to deter, denounce, and incapacitate to protect the public from future harm. The court is cognisant of research indicating that programmes such as the Structured Professional Judgement approach and Cognitive Behavioural Therapy-based desistance models have demonstrated mixed success. Nevertheless, it is incumbent upon probation and health services to pursue every credible avenue to reduce risk. In conclusion, the court directs the preparation of a comprehensive pre-sentence report, with particular emphasis on the prospects for rehabilitation, risk management strategies, and suitable accommodation arrangements post-release. The Probation Service is requested to liaise with the West Midlands Prevent Hub, local housing authorities, and mental health providers to ensure a coherent resettlement plan is in place. The court reserves final sentence until receipt and consideration of these materials and any further representations. These sentencing remarks are given this day on 17 September 2025, in Court 4 of the Crown Court at Birmingham. The proceedings have been transcribed in compliance with Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. A formal record of the conviction and sentence will be dispatched to the relevant authorities. These are the orders of the court.
