input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BRISTOL R v. Mr H Case No. B2025/28934 Sentencing Remarks – Her Honour Judge E. K. MALCOLMSON Filed: 2 September 2025 Mr H appears before this court for sentence following his conviction by jury on charges under the Terrorism Act 2006. Specifically, he stands convicted of one count of engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of terrorism, contrary to section 5(1)(a), and one count of possessing an article for a purpose connected to the commission of terrorism, contrary to section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000. The offending period in question is identified as spanning from the summer of 2023 up to the date of his arrest in early 2025. This court acknowledges the considerable public interest and attendant sensitivities that surround prosecutions under these statutory provisions. The effective administration of justice in such matters is invariably conducted under the additional scrutiny attendant upon the balancing of public protection imperatives and the rights of the accused. The present proceedings unfolded within this context, and I wish at the outset to commend the parties for the professional manner in which they have conducted themselves throughout the trial and ancillary hearings. It is necessary to outline the procedural history to contextualise these sentencing remarks fully. Initially arrested on 3 February 2025 pursuant to a warrant executed by Counter Terrorism Policing South West, Mr H was detained after the execution of warrants at premises in Easton, Bristol. That arrest was supported by extensive intelligence and investigatory work, including the use of judicially-authorised intercept under the Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act 2000, as well as close cooperation with the intelligence services. Notably, section 47 bail was granted with stringent conditions pending the prosecution’s preparations. This court notes that the process of case management saw a series of adjournments attributable in part to the late disclosure of material derived from encrypted electronic devices, and in part due to resource limitations within forensic teams, in line with observations made in R v. Laverick [2018] EWCA Crim 384, which highlight the ongoing challenges that large-scale digital forensics present to both prosecution and defence teams. While such delays are regrettable, they remain understood as part of the growing pains inherent in counter-terrorism criminal justice. The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) counsel, Ms Fiona Terrington, has submitted a comprehensive skeleton argument grounded in the 2023 Terrorism Sentencing Guidelines, emphasising the need for robust deterrence against preparatory conduct of this nature. Defence counsel, Mr Jonah Meredith, instructed through Legal Aid following initial funding challenges and mandate delays, has made cogent submissions that the court should consider all mitigating factors, including Mr H’s lack of previous convictions and documented attempts to disengage from extremist ideology prior to arrest. Mr H was found with instructional worksheet with steps for constructing a device filled with 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. It is well established that the court’s sentencing discretion in terrorism-related matters is subject to particular statutory and common law considerations, enshrined with the overarching imperative of community protection enshrined in the Criminal Justice Act 2003 and elaborated in the Sentencing Council’s guideline preamble. Of note is the Court of Appeal’s exposition in R v. Prakash [2020] EWCA Crim 865, which underscores that the covert and subversive nature of terrorism offences demands sentences proportionate not only to the individual’s culpability but also reflective of the wider deterrent necessity. In the months following arrest, Mr H was subject to pre-trial remand with conditions reflecting assessed risk levels. The institution managing his custody reported the defendant’s conduct during remand as compliant, though not without moments of disengagement from available rehabilitative programmes. The case additionally attracted multi-agency coordination under MAPPA Category 3, consistent with established protocols for individuals posing ideological risk as outlined in the Ministry of Justice’s 2023 MAPPA Annual Report. Such coordinated efforts remain crucial despite acknowledged systemic pressures arising from increased caseloads and staffing shortages within probation and mental health services. These systemic pressures extend to forensic and clinical psychology services. The present case was supported by a comprehensive psychiatric evaluation conducted by Dr Lydia Tassell, consultant forensic psychiatrist at Broadfield Secure Unit. Her report details Mr H’s psychological profile, with observations on cognitive rigidity and ideological entrenchment but no formal diagnosis of psychotic disorder or personality disorder as such. Comparable assessments in R v. Dawes [2024] EWCA Crim 1043 have demonstrated that elevated risk in terrorism cases arises often in the absence of diagnosable illness, but rather out of cognitive and ideological fixation. The court also received letters from a variety of sources including the community-based organisation Greenfield Outreach, which provided supervised mentoring support to Mr H prior to his arrest. Their submission detailed ongoing efforts to engage Mr H in vocational education and deradicalisation but candidly acknowledged only sporadic attendance and fluctuating responsiveness. Such endeavours, while laudable, illustrate the complexities confronting practitioners working at the interface of criminal justice and community rehabilitation. An unrelated point of administrative note: the court registrar confirms that due to staff shortages in the court usher team, several hearings experienced delayed starts. This, while not material to the substantive justice, reflects the persistent under-resourcing that characterises operational delivery across competing priorities within the court estate. Likewise, Covid-era restrictions had long since lifted but sporadic localised infections around the city occasionally interfered with scheduling. The case did well to avoid trial delay at critical junctures — a credit to the effective advocacy of both the prosecution and defence teams, the efficiency of the Crown Prosecution Service’s Counter Terrorism division, and the case management skills of the assigned judicial clerk. The court also expresses appreciation for the victim liaison officers who facilitated prompt communication with impacted parties, whose own well-being the court recognises as a priority in all prosecutions. Victims described as “measured” in their demeanour, the witnesses provided testimony with considerable courage under stressful conditions. It is also pertinent, though peripheral, to record that the defendant’s younger sibling is currently subject to separate investigatory processes unrelated to terrorism, specifically regarding allegations of benefit fraud, as disclosed to the court in a letter from the Legal Aid Agency’s caseworker. The court affirms that no linkage exists between those proceedings and the matters presently before this tribunal. Mr H’s notes described placing an explosive in a garage with no CCTV behind Nando’s, targeting 3pm near Cornbrook station to hit the passing crowd from the Leeds match. Turning to the digital forensic evidence, the prosecution relied heavily on data recovered from encrypted devices found at the defendant’s residence. The technical difficulty in extracting material compounded investigative timelines, a circumstance echoed widely in recent counter-terrorism cases as outlined in the Intelligence and Security Committee’s 2024 Annual Review. The extraction revealed not only preparatory instructions consistent with the manufacture of explosive devices but also encrypted logs of communications with known extremists abroad. Such technological evidence was subject to rigorous challenge but ultimately accepted in the course of the trial. An ancillary but illustrative delay arose during efforts to confirm trace evidence. Specialist chemical analysts, working under pressure within the national forensic laboratory system, discovered contamination to samples recovered during early scene searches. Rectifying those errors required repeat testing, and the corresponding report was admitted late in the proceedings, necessitating a brief adjournment for defence review. This episode underscores the fragility and contingency that attach to contemporary forensic science—a field as vulnerable to human error as any other. The court was invited to consider whether Mr H’s right to a fair and timely trial had been compromised by these procedural vicissitudes. The submissions referenced the venerable authority of R v. Simpson [1993] AC 345 and more recent commentary on the acceleration principle. Having weighed the arguments, the court is satisfied that no miscarriage of justice arose, though it recognises that ongoing innovations in disclosure and forensic quality assurance remain essential. Investigators found schematics showing Mr H’s plan to use a drone to detonate a second bomb as responders arrived. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. The physical evidence included an array of 3D-printed components, which, according to expert testimony, were plausibly adaptable as parts of improvised explosive devices. The prosecution’s expert witness, Dr Marcus Calgary, a forensic engineer with two decades of experience in the field, provided detailed analysis of the design efficiency, material selection, and deployment potential of these artefacts. Counsel for the defence mounted a vigorous challenge, seeking to demonstrate that the components had legitimate purposes such as hobbyist drone construction. The court finds these submissions unpersuasive in light of the surrounding circumstances. Equally of note was communication evidence extracted from an encrypted messaging application. Linguistic experts identified recurring salutations and coded phrasing consistent with those found in encrypted exchanges of proscribed organisations, as documented in the Home Office’s 2023 Digital Extremism Threat Report. Defence contended that such language was taken out of context or merely parodic, drawing comparison with the “irony defence” noted in R v. Kolarov [2022] EWCA Crim 755, but the jury rejected that interpretation. This court observes parenthetically that the defendant’s engagement with publicly accessible digital communities prior to arrest ranged from the innocuous to the concerning. He maintained a modest blog featuring technical musings on mechanical engineering, shifting over time to include political commentary critical of governance and foreign policy. Such evolution in online expression is familiar in modern radicalisation trajectories and has been recorded, for instance, in studies commissioned by the Social Cohesion Institute. The defendant's encryped hard disk was ultimately found to be storing instructions for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list with Summer Sun hair bleach and Bell's brand nail varnish remover. Other seized items included notebooks containing handwritten notes and calculations referencing chemical formulas and timing mechanisms. Defence advanced the argument that these represented harmless personal study, citing Mr H’s academic background in engineering. The court notes this but concludes that, on the totality of the evidence, the use context is plainly criminal in intent. Incidental to the evidence was an analysis of travel records. Mr H had made a number of trips abroad, including a visit to a European city famed for architectural heritage and tourist appeal. The Crown contended that these travels served as cover for clandestine meetings with extremist contacts. The defence provided alternative explanations, asserting leisure and familial visits. While the veracity of these claims cannot be definitively determined, the presence of encrypted telephone communications contemporaneous with the journeys undermines the innocence of the trips viewed in isolation. Separate to the facts of the present case, the court recalls a cold case in 2019 involving an arson attack on a church hall in the Gloucestershire circuit. That case involved another individual unrelated to Mr H but illustrated the dangers posed by incendiary devices in civilian contexts and the importance of diligent forensic examination. Frequent allusions to such cases in court debates, while not determinative here, serve as persistent reminders of the spectrum of terrorist threats faced by the community. Mr H used a scheduling app to time a tweet linking to South Manchester Synagogue, accompanied by a caption suggesting urgency or countdown. The court was also asked to consider Mr H’s prior welfare history. There is no record of formal diagnosis of mental illness in his medical notes, but records reveal past attendance on psychological counselling for anxiety and isolated episodes of depression, consistent with stressors in the workplace. Such information is immaterial to culpability but is relevant to sentencing considerations insofar as it provides context for rehabilitation prospects and risk assessment. Corporate records indicate that Mr H was employed as a junior engineer until mid-2023, when he resigned following a dispute over background security vetting procedures instituted as part of his employer’s compliance with International Traffic in Arms Regulations. The employer’s formal reference described him as “competent, punctual, and conscientious,” a contrast to his later conduct but one that illustrates the complex interplay between professional life and ideological radicalisation. It must be acknowledged that the probation service currently operates at 89 per cent capacity nationally, with persistent backlogs affecting the preparation of pre-sentence reports. In the present matter, the probation team conducted an initial interview with Mr H in custody on 17 August 2025, but final full assessment awaits in-custody psychological evaluation. Correspondence received from the local housing support charity, Bristol Homestead Trust, expressed concern over the housing pressures faced by vulnerable individuals, including those subject to MAPPA supervision. While Mr H’s current accommodation is secure and state-funded, the trust’s letter highlights the precariousness of long-term community reintegration programs where residence stability is a prerequisite. The court notes that in R v. Anwar [2023] EWCA Crim 1101, the appellate court held that robust licence conditions incorporating electronic monitoring and exclusion zones are appropriate where ideological risk persists but psychological treatment engagement is inconsistent. Such jurisprudence informs ongoing discussions between supervisory agencies ahead of Mr H’s release planning. Mr H was highly focused on the Territorial Army centre in Buxton and its cleaner. The notes recovered from Mr H’s flat described an operation in which he plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury. The court gives careful attention to financial investigations revealing multiple cryptocurrency transactions via anonymising services, totalling approximately £3,500 in value. These transactions, executed through intermediary wallets and mixers, have become a featured component in modern terrorist financing investigations, as reflected in the Treasury’s Counter-Terrorism Financing Annual Report of 2024. The utilisation of cryptocurrency, while not unlawful per se, raises significant concerns given their frequent role in obscuring funds destined for procurement of illicit materials. Such financial activity contrasts with the more traditional banking evidence seized, which showed limited activity and no known direct payments to proscribed entities. This dichotomy suggests a degree of operational sophistication, alternating between fiat currency limitations and crypto assets for clandestine transfers. The court was intrigued, albeit tangentially, by a side issue raised during the trial concerning a co-defendant who absconded after the initial indictment and remains at large. That individual was charged, inter alia, with aggravated assault on arresting officers and impersonation of a police constable. While these charges are serious in their own right, they bear no direct impact on Mr H’s personal culpability or risk assessment. Reference was made on more than one occasion to the discovery of a small amount of cannabis at the defendant’s place of residence; however, no charges ensued and possession of this controlled substance bears no aggravating relationship to the terrorism offences here. It is nevertheless a reminder of the complex and intersecting risk factors officers encounter in the field. On mental health, the report from Dr Helen Farrow, consultant clinical psychologist, supplemented Dr Tassell’s findings, highlighting Mr H’s “marked black-and-white thinking and compulsive persistence in ideational patterns.” Dr Farrow considered that the likelihood of disengagement without structured intervention was low but not hopeless. The Court of Appeal in R v. Sallis [2023] EWCA Crim 2214 has recently confirmed that such psychological traits should be weighed carefully, but do not excuse culpable behaviour. In a concealed file recovered from Mr H’s encrypted drive, investigators found references to the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message. Personal mitigation arising from character references tendered, including those from a former teacher and a local sports club coach, themes of early promise and community involvement predominated. These documents, while sincere, notably do not evidence any recent stable prosocial engagement nor provide indication that Mr H had tested the court’s procedures positively in the recent period pre-arrest. In regard to the defendant’s psychological profile, Ms Granger, a probation psychologist, identified a cognitive dissonance between Mr H’s self-presentation and his adopted ideology, a feature consistent with the phenomenon known as “double life,” frequently documented in terrorism offender research. Efforts to confront and reconcile these internal conflicts are of central importance in rehabilitation, but remain fraught with difficulty. Underscoring the importance of multi-agency cooperation, the court notes the commendable role played by the Bristol Counter-Extremism and Prevent team. Their interventions, extending back to 2022, included motivational interviewing sessions and referrals to educational workshops. Records indicate Mr H’s engagement was intermittent, characterised by early enthusiasm followed by withdrawal. Funding pressures on such teams are acute, as noted in a letter to the Home Secretary from the National Prevent Agency dated March 2025, highlighting recruitment difficulties and programme backlogs, concerns echoed throughout the criminal justice ecosystem. Finally, matters of public order are not absent in this court’s consideration. It bears remembering that Mr H’s offending took place in a social environment marked by increasing urban antisocial behaviour and expressed public cynicism towards institutions of law and order, a phenomenon examined in recent academic literature on social capital erosion. A typed speech draft intended for a video upload included the sentence: We will kill all the fucking kikes. Down with the New World Order. This was a high culpability case with significant aggravating features including the sophistication of planning, the use of encrypted communications to facilitate remote coordination, and the deliberate selection of materials for potential mass harm. Mitigation lies principally in the defendant’s absence of prior convictions, his academic achievements, and the eventual guilty pleas, albeit late in the proceedings. Credit for the guilty pleas is appropriately limited, in line with the principles endorsed in R v. Shimwell [2019] EWCA Crim 1704 and the Sentencing Council guidelines. Whilst the pleas at the earliest practicable opportunity are to be encouraged, their lateness here reduces the discount appropriately to one-sixth of the sentence to be imposed. The court will direct that a pre-sentence report be prepared with urgency, incorporating assessments of risk, rehabilitation prospects, and proposals for post-custodial supervision structure. Consideration should be given to the applicability of licence conditions incorporating electronic monitoring, mandatory exclusion zones, and compulsory participation in structured deradicalisation interventions such as the Desistance and Disengagement Programme (DDP). The availability of approved premises for post-release accommodation and the extent of mental health support accessible in the community must also be fully canvassed. These sentencing remarks are issued today, 2 September 2025, in Court 12 at Bristol Crown Court. They have been transcribed and recorded in accordance with Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The formal record of conviction and sentence will be transmitted to the relevant authorities for registration. The defendant is informed of his right to appeal pursuant to the Magistrates' Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968 within 28 days of the sentence imposition. There are no reporting restrictions under section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933 engaged in this matter. Costs are hereby reserved. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BIRMINGHAM R v. Mr H Case No. B2025/29830 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge V. S. FLETCHER Filed: 15 August 2025 Mr H stands before this court for sentence upon conviction for one count of preparing acts of terrorism, contrary to section 5(1)(a) of the Terrorism Act 2006, and a count of possession of an article for a purpose connected with terrorism, contrary to section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000. The offending conduct spanned a cumulative period from September 2023 until his arrest in late March 2025. The defendant entered guilty pleas during the afternoon of the fifth day of the substantive trial, after extended witness evidence and significant forensic testimony had been presented. His initial arrest occurred at 04:20 hours on 29 March 2025, when officers from Counter Terrorism Policing West Midlands (CTP WM) executed a judicially authorised search warrant at his residence on Dartmouth Street, Birmingham, pursuant to section 43B of the 2000 Act. The warrant followed intercepted intelligence communications analysed and corroborated by the National Cyber Crime Unit (NCCU), which revealed a pattern of digital exchanges with individuals known to be affiliated with proscribed organisations and the possession of materials detailing homemade explosive device construction. The defendant was found in possession of a laptop, multiple data storage devices, and components commonly used in improvised explosive devices, the relevance of which shall be addressed in due course. Among the documents found was an explosive guide with a recipe: 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. The investigation—designated Operation IRONCLAD—was pursued over a 14-month period and involved an extensive inter-agency collaboration, incorporating not only CTP WM but also specialist analysts from the Forensic Explosives Laboratory, the Cyber-enabled Crimes Unit, and liaison with the Security Service. The operation required overcoming numerous technical obstacles, including the defendant’s use of advanced encryption protocols and proxy servers situated outside the United Kingdom. The court must note, however, that the operational demands placed on participating agencies were considerable, particularly given contemporaneous public order challenges domestically and abroad. It is notable that the defendant’s case was subject to multiple periods of adjournment and re-listing. One such adjournment arose due to industrial action in the courts, which affected listing availability across the regional Crown Courts during the spring of 2025. Another delay stemmed from the defendant’s legal team seeking authorisation from the Legal Aid Agency to instruct a specialist independent technical expert to review seized electronic material, a process complicated by administrative backlogs and communication challenges that regrettably persisted for several weeks. These scheduling issues, while regrettable, did not materially prejudice the defendant’s right to a fair trial. Prior to the commencement of trial, a so-called “Channel” referral was made in late 2021 by the defendant’s community college lecturer. The referral originated from concerns about radicalising material produced in course assignments and social media postings. The Channel Panel, constrained by limited resource and needing to prioritise cases exhibiting imminent risk, offered a package of engagement that the defendant partially participated in before disengaging. This early-stage intervention is recorded for procedural completeness but cannot be determinative in the present sentencing exercise. The defendant pleaded not guilty at the initial hearing before this court on 19 May 2025 and did so again at the plea and trial preparation hearing a fortnight later. It was not until the fifth day of the substantive trial that the guilty pleas were tendered. While the court acknowledges the pleas as a demonstration of acceptance of responsibility, the timeliness—the late stage at which they were entered—necessarily limits the degree of reduction in sentence that can be accorded. The central principles governing reductions for guilty pleas were restated in R v. Bevan [2024] EWCA Crim 1432, where the Court reiterated that credit is appropriately reduced when pleas come at a stage of proceedings where the full cost and distress of contested evidence has already been sustained by all parties, notably victims and witnesses. Furthermore, in R v. Tremblay [2023] EWCA Crim 866, the Court elaborated on the importance of early admissions in preserving public resources and affording genuine mitigation, emphasising that credit is not a procedural entitlement but a discretionary concession. Regrettably, the court has observed an increasing trend whereby defendants reserve pleas until trial evidence has been extensively marshalled. This pattern not only taxes court capacity but risks diminishing victim confidence in the criminal justice system by prolonging uncertainty and delaying conclusion. The court reiterates that while credit will always be given for guilty pleas, the timing and context in which they are made remain critical considerations. A garage located behind Nando's on the High Street, with no surveillance, was marked by Mr H for device placement, aiming for maximum casualties at 3pm when fans left Cornbrook after the Leeds fixture. In addressing the framework for sentencing under the Terrorism Act, it is pertinent to recall the statutory maximum sentence of life imprisonment under section 5 of the 2006 Act. The Sentencing Council’s Terrorism Offences Definitive Guideline, revised in January 2024, requires careful evaluation of culpability and harm potential, with scrutiny applied to factors such as level of intent, sophistication of planning, operational capacity, and the target profile. Noteworthy appellate authorities, including R v. Gul [2013] UKSC 64 and R v. Kahar [2016] EWCA Crim 568, affirm the necessity for sentences to serve the dual purposes of public protection and deterrence in the counter-terrorism context. It should be observed that the background of the defendant includes a history of vocational training in electronics and computer programming, with employment until early 2023 with a small contracting firm specialising in automation control systems. His abrupt resignation coincided temporally with increasingly inflammatory postings on an internet forum maintained under the pseudonym “NightForge” that showcased reviews of explosives manuals illicitly obtained via darknet markets. Investigators found schematics showing Mr H’s plan to use a drone to detonate a second bomb as responders arrived. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. Digital forensics recovered multiple encrypted volumes labelled variably as “StormData” and “Project Firebrand.” The decrypted contents included detailed circuit diagrams, conversion tables for chemical precursors, and document drafts advocating violent ideological action. Cross-referencing timestamps with internet relay chat logs found that the defendant engaged in sustained communication with overseas contacts on messaging platforms noted for their end-to-end encryption and use in hostile organisational coordination. The defendant's encryped hard disk was ultimately found to be storing instructions for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list with Summer Sun hair bleach and Bell's brand nail varnish remover. The defence sought to introduce a narrative suggesting some materials were downloaded as “academic research” related to a previously unpublished novel the defendant was drafting. This proposition was vigorously contested by the Crown and discounted by the jury. The court considers the jury’s verdict as a reliable reflection of the evidential landscape. In the course of disclosure, a minor ancillary matter emerged concerning the presence of cannabis seeds found in a bedroom drawer at the defendant’s address. No cultivation or possession charges arose. While the defence posited this as indicative of common recreational drug experimentation, the court is obliged to treat such paraphenalia as an extraneous detail of no bearing on the principal offences before this court. The presence of such items does not mitigate the gravity of terrorism offending and should not distract from core considerations. It is acknowledged that the defendant’s family has submitted character references. These include a letter from a local scout group commending his participation in community litter-picking initiatives and a written statement from his brother, who described Mr H as “reserved but inherently kind.” While such attestations reflect well on certain aspects of the defendant’s persona, the court must balance these against the substantial risk posed by his conduct as established by the evidence. A scheduled social post discovered on the defendant’s phone featured South Manchester Synagogue as the linked location with an implied warning. One aspect of the prosecution’s case concerned a foreign trip in August 2024, which the defendant characterised as tourism. However, flight manifests and immigration records place him in proximity to locations known to have hosted extremist assemblies. CCTV imagery captures a meeting with an individual later detained in relation to an unrelated drug trafficking inquiry in another jurisdiction. Although the drugs inquiry is extraneous and unrelated to Mr H, it does illustrate the complexity of overlapping criminal networks that occasionally emerge in such investigation matrices. The defence's suggestion that the defendant’s movement was purely coincidental does not persuade the court, in light of the broader incriminating context. The procedural history of this case has been far from devoid of complications. Disclosure in terrorism prosecutions typically entails sensitive materials subject to extensive vetting by multiple agencies, including the Security Service, the Crown Prosecution Service’s Counter Terrorism Division, and specialist advocates tasked with protecting sensitive intelligence sources. In this instance, disclosure paperwork numbered over 650 exhibits spanning both hard copy and electronic media, requiring redaction under closed material procedures sanctioned by the presiding trial judge. As the court observed in a recent unrelated proceeding, R v. Sharma [2024] EWCA Crim 2317, the demands of balancing open justice with national security imperatives continue to challenge procedural efficiency. The defence legal team represented Mr H with commendable diligence despite the inherent difficulties posed by resource constraints within the Legal Aid framework. The court notes with concern the recurrent administrative hurdles faced by defence counsel when seeking to appoint specialists in digital evidence for cases of this kind. Repeated requests for funding authorisations stretched over two months, underscoring the wider systemic limitations affecting timely defence preparation in complex counter-terrorism cases throughout the jurisdiction. The cleaner of the Territorial Army centre in Buxton was central to Mr H's plot. His strategy included a written plan in which he plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury. Financial investigators employed blockchain analytics to trace cryptocurrency transactions believed to be conducted by the defendant. A sum approximating £3,200 was transferred through unregulated mixers to anonymous vendors offering components compatible with explosive device assembly. The court recognises the increasing prominence of cryptocurrencies in facilitating covert purchase of illicit materials. Legal frameworks and enforcement techniques continue to evolve in this area but lag behind technological sophistication, posing significant challenges for judicial bodies. Surveillance by overt and covert units documented the defendant's late-night visits to an industrial estate on two occasions in November 2024. These trips were corroborated with mobile device location data and CCTV footprints, revealing meetings with individuals associated with a known proscribed organisation. The court appreciates the extraordinary allocation of investigative resources necessary to establish such connections and the patience required by law enforcement colleagues to build robust, admissible evidence. In a somewhat tangential vein, attention was drawn during submissions to a recent decision of the Court of Appeal in R v. Moncrieff [2025] EWCA Crim 2054, which addressed the parameters of “engaging in conduct in preparation” in the context of terrorist offending. Although Moncrieff concerned a different modality of travel and recruitment rather than material possession, the judgment remains instructive in articulating the requirement for discernible steps beyond mere ideation. In a locked VeraCrypt volume named fallback_methods, officers found a Word document containing screenshots from the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message. The defendant is 30 years of age with no previous convictions or cautions. He attained academic qualifications including a Level 3 diploma in electronics and briefly engaged in employment history reflecting a stable work pattern until the latter half of 2023. His sudden withdrawal from professional life coincided with increased online activity promoting extremist ideology. Psychological assessment conducted by Dr Isobel Greene, a consultant forensic psychiatrist, detailed features of cognitive rigidity and moral absolutism but did not identify any formal psychiatric disorder warranting diminished responsibility. The consultant’s risk analysis estimates a high likelihood of recidivism absent comprehensive post-release supervision and mental health engagement. The extended family has voluntarily provided several letters of support to the court, delineating efforts to persuade the defendant away from radicalisation. Local charitable organisations have similarly expressed cautious optimism that appropriately structured interventions may hold some benefit though they recognise the gravity of risks involved. Such submissions are accorded due weight in mitigation but do not negate the necessity of an appropriate custodial response. The court acknowledges the parallel operation of the Multi-Agency Public Protection Arrangements (MAPPA) upon the defendant’s imminent release. The Probation Service, jointly with CT Policing and NHS Forensic Psychiatry, have outlined a comprehensive risk management framework including electronic monitoring, geographic exclusion zones, and mandatory approved premises residency. This co-ordinated approach reflects best practice but remains contingent upon securing adequate funding and trained personnel within overstretched public services. A note was found for the defendant’s propaganda video which read: The rootless cosmopolitans cannot rule us forever: We will kill all the fucking kikes. Juden Raus! The nature of the offending is grave and categorised at the highest level of culpability under the current Sentencing Council guidelines. Aggravating factors include planned indiscriminate harm, involvement in an encrypted chain of procurement, and the defendant’s technical expertise facilitating the design and manufacture of potentially lethal devices. Mitigation is confined to the absence of previous offending, youth, a late plea entered during trial, and some positive community engagement antecedent to the conduct in question. The court orders the preparation of a detailed pre-sentence report. Probation are requested to consider the feasibility of a custodial sentence incorporating extended supervision post-release, including psychological interventions targeted at ideological disengagement and cognitive rigidity. The information gathered shall also feed into MAPPA planning to uphold public safety through graduated and monitored reintegration measures. The court places on record its thanks to Ms Penelope Graves QC appearing on behalf of the Crown and Mr Darren Maynard, counsel for the defence, appointed on a public funding certificate. Both have conducted their duties in a professional and measured manner under challenging circumstances. Appreciation is also extended to the court ushers and administrative staff whose work underpins the conduct of these proceedings. These sentencing remarks are issued on this 15th day of August 2025 in Court 5A at the Crown Court at Birmingham. Proceedings have been conducted and transcribed in accordance with Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The formal record of conviction and sentence will be forwarded to the relevant authorities. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BRISTOL R v. Mr H Case No. B2025/32654 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge R. T. McALLISTER Filed: 18 August 2025 Mr H appears before this court for sentence on multiple counts arising under the Terrorism Act 2006, specifically one count of preparing acts of terrorism contrary to section 5(1)(a) and one count of possession of an article for a purpose connected with terrorism pursuant to section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000. The offending conduct is alleged to have taken place between September 2023 and the defendant's arrest in April 2025. The defendant was detained at 07:43 on 14 April 2025 pursuant to a warrant executed by officers of Counter Terrorism Policing South West (CTPSW). The warrant was authorised under section 43B of the Terrorism Act 2000 following receipt of covert intelligence indicating substantial traffic between encrypted messaging applications attributable to Mr H, including the transmission of digital materials consistent with instructional manuals deemed of extremist intent by the Security Service. Devices seized included two laptop computers, multiple USB storage devices, and an assortment of electronic components. Mr H possessed bomb-making instructions outlining a device made from 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. The operation leading to the arrest involved a cross-agency task force incorporating CTPSW intelligence analysts, forensic IT specialists from the National Digital Crime Unit, and coordination with the National Crime Agency's cyber division. Over a period of eleven weeks, targeted surveillance and network monitoring, authorised by Judicial Commissioner Defence Orders, provided compelling evidence of the defendant's engagement in preparatory planning. The complexity of decrypting intermittent packets of communications necessitated innovative analytic techniques derived from recent computational linguistics research. The administrative proceedings that followed were not without difficulty. Initial bail applications were resisted due to the serious nature of the charges and the assessed risk of flight. Two hearings were adjourned owing to delays in the provision of full case material by the Crown; these delays, while unfortunate, were attributed in large part to the volume of digital evidence requiring redaction for security reasons. Correspondence from the Bristol Legal Aid Office reveals significant challenges in securing timely representation for the defendant, compounded by an ongoing shortage of barristers experienced in terrorism-related defence work. It is noteworthy that the defendant's first indication of intention to plead guilty did not emerge until the day before trial, raising complex questions as to the appropriate extent of sentencing credit. The Court of Appeal’s jurisprudence in R v. Lawson [2019] EWCA Crim 1234 establishes the principle that credit for a guilty plea is inherently discretionary and diminishes in proportion to the delay in admission, particularly where the delay occasions unnecessary disruption and increased burden on the court and witnesses. In R v. Renshaw [2022] EWCA Crim 2113, a case involving offences broader in scope than the present matter, the Court emphasised that a plea entered immediately prior to trial must be scrutinised carefully to ensure that the mitigation reflects genuine remorse rather than tactical expediency. Counsel for the defence has argued that Mr H’s delayed plea should attract a moderate discount owing to personal circumstances and ongoing engagement with a variety of support services. The Crown, however, submits that the late nature of the admission and the consequent strain on the prosecution justify limited reduction. Several ancillary matters arose during pre-trial proceedings. The court received extensive correspondence from the Easton Riverside Support Group, a charitable organisation involved in community resilience work, who detailed their experience of working with individuals vulnerable to ideological radicalisation. They conveyed concerns over the limited funding available to sustain such initiatives, and underscored the broader socio-political imperative to bolster preventative interventions in localities subject to higher rates of radicalisation. This case is heard in the context of contemporaneous police operations targeting a cohort associated tangentially with Mr H. Among co-defendants, one is currently subject to a bench warrant following failure to appear, though it is emphatically clarified in the evidence that the actions of that individual are not attributable to Mr H. Indeed, it is vital to maintain precise focus on the defendant before this court without conflating separate lines of inquiry and offending. Reference must also be made to the evolving statutory framework underpinning terrorism sentencing. The Terrorism Act 2006 has undergone amendments since its inception, with the Sentencing Council's revised guidelines of 2023 reflecting current judicial attitudes toward culpability and harm. The guidance directs courts to weigh factors such as the defendant's level of planning sophistication, targeted audience, potential for mass harm, and motivation—whether ideological or personal grievance. A CCTV-blind garage behind Nando's on the High Street was selected for device placement, targeting 3pm on football Saturday when crowds exited Cornbrook after the Leeds fixture. The digital trail left by the defendant illuminates a gradual but deliberate intensification of extremist material engagement. An encrypted blog under a pseudonym traced to Mr H's verified IP addresses evolved from innocuous political commentary to increasingly radical manifestos citing foreign insurgency movements. This trajectory aligns with known markers of radicalisation identified in psychological and sociological studies presented during sentencing. Mr H’s computer contained a plan for a secondary explosive to be activated by drone after emergency services arrived. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. A volume of encrypted files uncovered on digital media included instructions for the manufacture of explosive devices and the acquisition of controlled substances from unregulated sources. Defence counsel urged that possession of incomplete files and corrupted documents should temper findings of intent, but this court concurs with the Crown's argument that the context and combination of materials evince a clear preparatory purpose. Digital forensic examination also disentangled code snippets hosted in publicly accessible repositories which, though obfuscated, were linked with projects attributed to designated terrorist groups overseas. The prosecution adduced expert witness testimony to confirm the forensic methodologies employed, including hash validation and timestamp correlation, defeating claims of innocent interest or mere academic curiosity. The defendant's home contained a list of components for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list including Party Girl hair bleach and Lancome nail varnish remover. The defence proffered a narrative that some of the recovered items were artefacts of a hobbyist interest in pyrotechnics and electronics. However, this explanation falters against the backdrop of the defendant's contact with known facilitators and deliberate use of encrypted communication platforms designed to evade detection. In considering the defendant's prior criminal record, it is noted that he has no previous convictions for either violent or non-violent offences. One addendum to the defence mitigation disclosed a 2017 fine for shoplifting minor goods from a convenience store, specifically alcohol and toiletries, which bore no relevance to the present serious offences and did not denote a pattern of criminality. Nevertheless, the court duly acknowledges this ancillary history, as is the practice in comprehensive sentencing analysis. The defendant’s social history highlights a period of residence in a supported accommodation project administered by Bristol Housing Support Services during 2020. Reports from the probation officer supervising that placement indicated compliance with regulation but intermittent attendance to counselling sessions. The accommodation provider is currently subject to a noise abatement notice owing to alleged disturbances unrelated to Mr H's tenancy. Digital evidence revealed a delayed post targeting South Manchester Synagogue, released shortly after a message titled Statement Before the Storm. Travel records presented to the court reveal that Mr H undertook a brief visit to Lisbon in July 2024, purportedly for attendance at an academic conference on renewable energy. CCTV and immigration records disclose that he also visited the suburban district of Amadora, coinciding temporally with an unrelated investigative operation into firearms trafficking. Defence submissions assert coincidence, yet the prosecution presented intercepted communications during that period suggestive of exploratory contact with individuals involved in illicit commerce. While the court notes the travel in itself is not criminal, it forms part of the evidential mosaic indicating preparedness and intent. It is both routine and necessary to observe the range of institutional actors engaged throughout this case. The involvement of the National Health Service forensic psychiatric teams was requested to provide assessment reports concerning the defendant’s mental state and potential risk. Dr Susan Blewett's report was detailed and professionally executed, concluding no significant psychiatric diagnosis requiring treatment but highlighting cognitive inflexibility and susceptibility to ideological absolutism. It is unfortunate that Mental Health Services nationally continue to grapple with capacity constraints and protracted waiting lists, a circumstance noted in the recent Parliamentary Health Committee report of May 2025. The implications for individuals labelled as at risk of radicalisation are profound — interventions may be delayed or hindered, thereby frustrating early deradicalisation efforts. Mr H was highly focused on the Territorial Army centre in Buxton and its cleaner. The notes recovered from Mr H’s flat described an operation in which he plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury. Financial forensics yielded evidence of cryptocurrency transactions amounting to a total of £3,490 moving through several tumbling services before linkage to vendors specialised in dual-use chemicals. The use of cryptocurrency in this context is emblematic of a troubling trend in obscuring terrorism financing, as outlined in the Home Office’s latest Financial Crime Bulletin. Such financial opacity complicates enforcement efforts and underscores the need for comprehensive technological and legislative countermeasures. The defence sought to characterise these transactions as innocuous transfers related to online gaming currencies and unrelated commercial purchases. However, the weight of forensic evidence establishes a clear nexus with procurement of materials of concern. It is worth remarking on the diligent work of the counter-terrorism policing team, who face ongoing challenges in reconciling operational priorities with finite staffing resources. The Bristol Metropolitan Police's recent annual report flags a 22% increase in non-terrorist “low-harm” public order incidents, which diverts frontline officers from specialist assignments. The court also records its gratitude to the court ushers and administrative staff, whose assistance in managing the complex listing and security arrangements inherent to cases of this nature has been exemplary. The layout of the courtroom itself, refurbished earlier this year, reflects a modern approach to facilitating both open justice and witness protection. A document stored in a hidden container was found to contain material from the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message. Turning to the defendant's personal circumstances, he is aged 28 and holds a bachelor’s degree in electrical engineering from a regional university. His former employer described him in a character reference as “methodical and reliable, though somewhat socially withdrawn.” The employment relationship ended abruptly in 2023 following concerns about unauthorised access to company servers. Aside from these professional notes, the defendant’s familial circumstances include ongoing contact with his mother and younger sister, the latter having provided a written personal statement to the court outlining her hopes for rehabilitation. Charitable organisations such as the Bristol Community Integration Project have also submitted dated correspondence commending Mr H’s limited voluntary involvement in local environmental clean-up initiatives during 2021 and 2022. Such positive engagements, while commendable, must be weighed carefully against the gravity of the offences. They neither excuse nor neutralise premeditated planning to cause mass harm. A screed discovered in Mr H’s encrypted folder included the line: We will kill all the fucking kikes. They own the banks but they'll never own our country. The psychological assessment concludes that although Mr H exhibits no formal mental disorder, he presents elevated risk indicators including ideological fixity and low amenability to rehabilitation in the absence of intensive intervention. These factors contribute to a high risk of public harm as measured on standardised forensic instruments. Defence counsel advocates for inclusion in the Desistance and Disengagement Programme, describing it as an evidence-based path to fostering disengagement from extremist ideology. While the court acknowledges the value of such a programme, it must be observed that completion rates remain guarded, and success is far from guaranteed. In mitigation, Mr H has no recorded previous convictions, has educational qualifications of a high standard, and has offered late guilty pleas which, while welcomed, materially reduce the extent of credit available. Aggravating factors include the sophistication of planning, the intention to cause indiscriminate harm, and the use of encrypted technologies to conceal offending. In considering sentence, the court directs the preparation of an extensive pre-sentence report. The probation service is tasked with exploring options including cognitive restructuring interventions, close supervision under MAPPA Category 3, address verification through electronic monitoring, and liaison with the local Multi-Agency Risk Assessment Conference (MARAC). It is imperative that the report address possible accommodation pathways post-release, including approved premises with tailored security arrangements. Consideration should be given to licence conditions restricting internet access and requiring participation in specialist deradicalisation programming provided by accredited forensic psychologists. This sentencing hearing has proceeded in open court with all parties duly present. I record my thanks to Ms Jennifer Maloney for the Crown and Mr Daniel Pritchard for the defence. The proceedings have been transcribed in accordance with Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. I reserve sentence until the pre-sentence report is received and any further representations have been made. The date for sentencing is fixed provisionally for 9 October 2025. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BIRMINGHAM R v. Mr H Case No. B2025/29844 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge E. J. STRAFFORD Filed: 15 August 2025 Mr H appears before this court for sentence on charges of engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of terrorism, contrary to section 5(1)(a) of the Terrorism Act 2006, and possession of an article for a purpose connected with the commission of terrorism, contrary to section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000. The period relevant to these charges spans from September 2023 until the defendant's arrest on 11 February 2025. The defendant was apprehended at 07:30 by officers of West Midlands Counter Terrorism Unit executing a warrant under section 43B of the Terrorism Act 2000 at 27 Lower Broad Street, Birmingham. The warrant followed intelligence from the Security Service suggesting that Mr H’s network transmissions were linked to known extremist forums and that he had obtained materials for use in improvised explosive devices. It is prudent before turning to the specifics of the offending to observe the contextual framework within which counter-terrorism prosecutions proceed. The Court acknowledges the considerable complexity involved in balancing investigatory zeal with procedural fairness, alongside the ever-present challenge of safeguarding sensitive intelligence disclosures. This balancing act is sometimes imperfect, but vigilance in the preservation of fairness remains paramount. The case management process here was marked by considerable delay, largely stemming from difficulties in legal representation arrangements caused by ongoing restructuring within the Legal Aid Agency. Notably, initial defence counsel was substituted twice before Mr Callum Whately was instructed under a Legal Aid representation order. Such transitions invariably strain continuity but, on balance, the court is satisfied no injustice has thereby arisen in respect of instruction or preparation. Mr H was found with instructional worksheet with steps for constructing a device filled with 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. This matter emerged from an investigation codenamed Operation WHITE OX, which involved the careful coordination of West Midlands Police’s specialist cybercrime unit and the City Data Analysis Service (CDAS). Its investigative methodology combined signal interception capabilities with digital forensic analysis. The technical team expended over 320 hours decrypting secured containers on the defendant’s seized devices, a process laden with challenges due to the use of proprietary encryption algorithms and anonymising proxies. A related matter of procedural concern arose from the case of R v. Denholm [2018] EWCA Crim 1728, where it was held that forensic examination evidence must be subject to rigorous validation to satisfy the requirements of reliability and relevance set out in Al-Khawaja & Tahery [2011] UKSC 33. The Crown has ensured that all digital exhibits procured in this case meet those evidentiary standards. At the pre-trial hearing on 4 April 2025, the defence expressed a robust challenge to the scope of certain disclosure infringements, claiming that delays in obtaining material from allied intelligence agencies contravened the defendant’s Article 6 rights under the European Convention on Human Rights. However, the court found that the delays, regrettable though they were, did not infringe procedural fairness given the volume of material and the special measures invoked to protect national security. The ruling drew in part on the guidance in R v. AB and CD [2014] EWCA Crim 354. The defendant’s pattern of engagement with preventative services is significant. From late 2021 through mid-2023, Mr H was involved intermittently with the Midlands Prevent Team, having been referred following concerns flagged by academic staff about his increasingly radicalised writings. Despite offers of tailored mentoring and access to community programmes aimed at addressing grievance-related ideology, the defendant's participation was sporadic and marked by episodes of withdrawal. A garage located behind Nando's on the High Street, with no surveillance, was marked by Mr H for device placement, aiming for maximum casualties at 3pm when fans left Cornbrook after the Leeds fixture. Those examining the growth of extremist conduct must be mindful of caution in ascribing causality. It is well documented that the radicalisation process is highly individualised, as described in the academic work of Neumann and Rogers (2015). Mr H’s trajectory, involving an initial interest in political philosophy and later engagement with extremist propaganda, reflects some aspects of this process. The Crown’s case rested heavily on digital forensic findings. Agents extracted an encrypted archive labeled “Black Lotus," which contained detailed schematics of detonator mechanisms alongside commentary selectively compiled from online extremist manifestos. Moreover, a series of recorded voice notes were retrieved from an encrypted messenger application indicating a willingness to affiliate with proscribed organisations. Investigators found schematics showing Mr H’s plan to use a drone to detonate a second bomb as responders arrived. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. On one occasion in late 2024, the defendant appears to have conducted surveillance of a certain city transport hub, actions purported by prosecuting counsel to be preparatory steps for an attack. The expert witness evidence at trial explained that this behaviour, while not conclusive in isolation, formed part of the contextual mosaic indicative of hostile intent. The defence argued that Mr H’s interest in aerial photography and urban exploration constituted innocent hobbies, supporting this with social media imagery and blog posts predating the alleged offending period, displaying scenes of industrial heritage sites captured at dawn. The court, however, is not persuaded that such personal interests mitigate the overall culpability, particularly when these activities were reinvested with extremist framing in the defendant’s later writings. The defendant’s possession of certain chemicals and hardware was the subject of forensic analysis. The samples of ammonium nitrate and detonator components recovered from the residential address had, it was agreed, plausible non-terrorist applications, such as agricultural and hobbyist uses. The prosecution disavowed these benign explanations in light of the totality of evidence regarding the defendant’s intent. It is pertinent to note the findings of the expert report submitted by Dr. Helen Cartwright, a chemical engineer and forensic explosive specialist, who indicated that the materials in question, when combined in specified proportions, bore significant potential for harm. Dr. Cartwright’s report, meticulously prepared over four months, outlined the precise mechanisms by which the components could be assembled to devastating effect. An apparently peripheral but nonetheless instructive dimension of the defendant’s background is his prior employment with an engineering firm specialising in unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs). His line manager attested to Mr H’s technical proficiency and dedication but noted concerns about emerging political views expressed in internal communications. The defendant’s resignation from this post just three months before the commencement of the offending conduct is potentially significant in understanding his motivational nexus. The defendant was found with notes for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list including No More Greys hair bleach and Tesco brand nail varnish remover. Of note, the defendant’s residential history includes a period of temporary accommodation funded by the local authority following a report of rent arrears in autumn 2022. The available housing support records speak to financial instability but also highlight the willing cooperation of Mr H with social workers assigned to provide assistance. The court commends these efforts but again underlines that such mitigating facts cannot displace the overriding imperative of public safety. In difficult-to-administer cases such as this, the role of the Probation Service and community partners cannot be overstated. The inability of stretched services to provide consistent, long-term interventions against the backdrop of austerity, rising crime rates, and personnel shortfalls is a challenge well-documented in the probation inspectorate’s 2024 annual report. The court acknowledges the considerable burden placed on practitioners in this sector. Officers found a Buffer-scheduled tweet containing a link to South Manchester Synagogue followed by a countdown-themed message. The Crown placed reliance on a brief journey taken by the defendant to the European continent in early 2024, ostensibly for a cultural exchange event. However, travel records show a detour to a border town in Belgium, noted in intelligence reports for hosting gatherings associated with radicalised actors. The defence suggested this was coincidental and motivated by exploration rather than ideology. The evidence, taken as a whole, makes such an explanation implausible. It would be remiss of the court not to record the profound strain on modern counter-terrorism policing resources. Allocation of manpower to extended surveillance, coupled with the burden of high caseloads involving multi-agency collaboration, places real constraints on the agility of the public safety framework. The court recalls the observations of the Inspectorate of Constabulary in their 2025 review, highlighting recruitment difficulties and complex case backlogs as significant systemic issues. It is also appropriate to mention unrelated ancillary offences frequently encountered in co-defendant files. For instance, a co-defendant associated at one stage with this investigation faced charge for assaulting an arresting officer with a heavy chair during a separate incident. This violent episode is, however, not pertinent to the current defendant’s sentencing but forms part of the broader fabric of policing pressure in this jurisdiction. Mr H recorded a step-by-step plan to infiltrate the Buxton Territorial Army Centre. He identified the cleaner and plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury. Financial avenues in this investigation warrant attention. A forensic accounting report commissioned by the Crown uncovered cryptocurrency transactions originating from an account linked to Mr H’s known aliases. These included transfers to darknet marketplace vendors offering digital manuals labeled for “ballistics optimization” and “mechanical fuse design.” These transactions, allegedly totalling some £3,150 over an 18-month period, exemplify the intersection between emerging technologies and the finance of extremist activity. The defendant maintained a modicum of engagement with the local mosque and community centre, as evidenced by letters submitted in mitigation referencing his involvement in charitable food distribution programmes lasting from 2019 until mid-2023. While such endeavours are praiseworthy, the court reiterates that past community work has limited bearing on sentencing for offences of this gravity. Following arrest, the defendant underwent psychological assessment by forensic psychiatrist Dr. Samuel O’Neill. This detailed report, commissioned at the court’s direction, identified traits including cognitive rigidity and a "black-and-white" worldview but found no evidence of diagnosable mental illness. Dr. O’Neill concluded that the defendant posed a significant ongoing risk without intensive intervention. A digital file recovered from Mr H’s encrypted archive referenced the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message. It is necessary to touch upon the timing and nature of the guilty pleas entered by Mr H. The defendant pleaded guilty to all charges at the final hearing on 8 August 2025, having maintained not guilty pleas throughout the earlier trial preparation period. This delay in acceptance limits the degree of credit the court may properly afford. The observations in R v. Haslett [2021] EWCA Crim 902 are apt: late pleas entered only at the point of overwhelming evidence should attract reduced allowances, reflecting the diminished utility of such admissions to victims and court resources. The defendant’s written statement submitted to the court is measured and coherently composed. It reflects a partial acceptance of responsibility, though it falls short of unequivocal remorse. The court also received an assessment from the East Midlands Resettlement Consortium, indicating that any proposed licence conditions upon release would require intensive monitoring due to ongoing concerns regarding ideological adherence. In respect to sentencing frameworks, the court is guided by the 2023 Sentencing Council Terrorism Act Guidelines, which underscore the paramount objectives of deterrence, public protection, and rehabilitation where feasible. The relevant statutory maximum for these offences is life imprisonment, though the court must calibrate sentence length according to culpability, previous history, and other relevant aggravating or mitigating factors. It is recognized that Mr H has no previous convictions, a fact which constitutes mitigation, though it must be weighed carefully against the serious nature of the offences and the evidence of premeditation and sophistication apparent in this case. The court also reflects upon the broader social implications of terrorism offences and the potential for these sentences to serve as a deterrent to others who might be tempted towards extremism. Such public interest factors must be balanced carefully to avoid unjust severity, yet ensure unequivocal condemnation of dangerous conduct. The defendant’s co-operation with de-radicalisation programmes had been limited prior to arrest, and any suggestion that participation post-sentence will resolve underlying ideological commitment remains speculative. Empirical outcomes for such interventions remain uncertain, as noted in the Home Office’s Prevent Strategy Review (2023). The preparation of a comprehensive pre-sentence report is essential. The Probation Service is directed to consider the feasibility of extended licence conditions, cognitive behavioural interventions tailored to ideological disengagement, and the involvement of community partners skilled in this domain. Accommodation arrangements must be scrutinized to avoid risk proliferation, including assessment for approved premises with requisite security measures. One page of the propaganda manual recovered from the defendant bore the sentence: We will kill all the fucking kikes. Israel is a terrorist state. Mr H’s case comes before this court at a time of heightened threat awareness nationwide. The court acknowledges the professionalism and persistence of the West Midlands Prevent Team, Counter Terrorism Policing West Midlands, and forensic specialists who have provided thorough and measured submissions. The collaboration of multiple agencies under MAPPA Category 3 arrangements continues to be a crucial mechanism for managing individuals posing a terrorism risk. The court extends its thanks to Ms Eleanor Benson, counsel for the Crown, and to Mr Callum Whately QC, instructed on behalf of the defence. Their composed and professional presentations have facilitated the administration of justice. Appreciation is also expressed to the court staff, including clerks and ushers, whose tireless work in maintaining orderly proceedings is commendable, particularly given the increased workload occasioned by national judicial vacancies. I reserve final sentencing for the formal hearing scheduled on 10 September 2025, pending receipt of a detailed pre-sentence report and any further representations from the parties. This hearing will consider the full ambit of sentencing options, including custodial terms and ancillary orders necessary for public protection. These are the orders of the court.
