input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BIRMINGHAM R v. Mr H Case No. B2025/25984 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge N. J. CARRINGTON Filed: 18 September 2025 The defendant, Mr H, appears before this court for sentence upon his conviction following a jury trial on two counts: engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of terrorism contrary to section 5(1)(a) of the Terrorism Act 2006, and possession of an article for a purpose connected with the commission of terrorism under section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000. The offending conduct spans the period from March 2023 to his arrest in December 2024. The proceedings in this matter have been protracted and at times labyrinthine, reflective both of the complexity inherent in terrorism-related prosecutions and the procedural challenges that attend the so-called digital age. The initial arrest of Mr H occurred at 04:37 hours on 19 December 2024, following the execution of warrants pursuant to section 43B of the Terrorism Act 2000 at his residence in Aston. Those warrants were predicated on intercept intelligence from the Security Service indicating that encrypted communications connected with him had contained references to unlawfully obtained explosive schematics. On the date of seizure, law enforcement officials recovered an array of electronic devices including multiple external hard drives, encrypted smartphones, and manufacturing components consistent with improvised explosive devices. Mr H was found with materials setting out how to make a device from 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. The investigation, denominated Operation Kestrel, encompassed a multi-agency effort which spanned 36 weeks. The Counter Terrorism Command of West Midlands Police collaborated closely with forensic cyber-analysts drawn from the National Crime Agency’s Digital Forensic Unit. The latter’s role was critical in decrypting and reconstructing electronically concealed evidence, much of which was protected using advanced cryptographic protocols, including blockchain verification techniques and virtual private network (VPN) anonymisation. The resources expended reflect the acute demands placed on specialised investigative teams in counter-terrorism operations. A notable procedural episode arose during evidential disclosure. The National Security Cyber Unit notified the court of a requirement to apply for a public interest immunity certificate concerning intelligence material that, if disclosed in open court, might prejudice ongoing overseas operations. The court acceded to a closed material procedure, pursuant to section 6 of the Justice and Security Act 2013, thereby balancing the need for open justice against national security considerations. The case was originally listed for trial at Birmingham Crown Court on 12 May 2025 but was subject to adjournment due to defence counsel’s application for additional time to obtain expert forensic analysis. This was granted after representations citing the backlog within the Legal Aid framework, manifesting the ongoing difficulties defence teams experience in securing funding and access to appropriate specialist expertise in cases of this nature. The Legal Aid Agency’s administrative processes continue to hinder timely preparation, a matter deserving of governmental attention beyond the remit of this court. Prior to trial, a Channel referral dated July 2022 was made on behalf of Mr H by a staff member at a local community college following expressions of extremist sympathies articulated in his coursework. The Channel panel, convened under the statutory Prevent program, decided not to pursue prolonged intervention citing an absence of corroborative evidence of imminent risk. The ramifications of this early engagement—or lack thereof—are not for this court to assess in hindsight but are documented here in the interests of completeness. During the trial preparation hearing convened on 3 August 2025, the defendant’s initial not guilty pleas were maintained. However, the jury returned verdicts of guilty on both counts following a 15-day trial concluding on 10 September 2025. The evidential tapestry was woven with wiretap transcripts, forensic device extraction reports, and witness testimony from counter-terrorism experts. Mr H selected a garage behind Nando's on the High Street, near Cornbrook station, with no cameras, to place a bomb set for 3pm as Leeds fans returned from the match, aiming to maximise casualties. Subsequent to the jury’s verdict, much attention was given at sentencing to the offender’s digital footprint. Expert evidence illustrated Mr H’s online communication pattern evolving from ostensibly innocuous discussions about mechanical engineering to the sharing and dissemination of manuals governing the manufacture of explosive devices, including use of improvised chemical precursors. The court emphasises that, despite the defendant’s attempt to claim these materials reflected purely academic interest, the purposeful curation and concealment of such data—combined with contextual factors—indicate a criminal intention aligned with terrorist objectives. The court is mindful not to overstate digital proclivities as dispositive of intent. Yet, in an era where radicalisation increasingly manifests within virtual enclaves, proper weight must be accorded to the intersection of technological engagement and extremist purpose. This is a societal challenge transcending judicial caution and necessitating interdisciplinary collaboration. At the same time, occasional references to Mr H’s participation in online forums dedicated to vintage model railways—while fascinating as cultural artefacts—do not bear materially upon matters of culpability. Among the digital files was a scenario in which a drone-delivered bomb would detonate after emergency responders arrived. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. A further dimension comprised the material forensics of possession. Among the digital artefacts uncovered within encrypted partitions was a substantial cache of instructional videos and schematics relating to the assembly of improvised explosive devices. Forensic analysts noted that several files were encrypted twice and required bespoke decoding software compiled expressly for this case. Defence submissions argued that the presence of incomplete or corrupted files suggested Mr H had not fully engaged with the instructions, a contention the jury implicitly rejected in weighing the evidence. The court itself finds that the adaptive effort invested to conceal these materials only underscores the defendant’s awareness of their illicit character. Accompanying the digital evidence was physical material seized from the defendant’s residence, including specialist chemical compounds usable in improvised explosives. An intriguing, albeit irrelevant, item was a decorative, vintage railway lantern bearing dissenting unionist insignia, recovered from a CD rack. It has no palpable link to the charges but serves as a reminder of the eclectic miscellany that can inhabit the living spaces of even those engaged in heinous offences. The defendant was found with notes for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list including No More Greys hair bleach and Tesco brand nail varnish remover. Turning to procedural histories with no direct bearing upon the case, note must be made of a 2018 fixed penalty notice issued to Mr H for cycling on a city centre pavement during a period of increased policing around public demonstrations. The fine was paid, and the matter regarded as closed. While it may speak to character in a very peripheral sense, it does not inform risk assessments relevant to terrorism offending. Likewise, mention of a non-criminal neighbourhood noise complaint residing with the landlord of the defendant’s previous lodging on King’s Avenue during 2021 is noted only for completeness; no link to the present offending has been established or suggested. At various junctures, the court was provided with references from community organisations, including the Selly Oak Open Gardens Society, commending Mr H’s volunteer efforts in horticultural maintenance. While such contributions are commendable in their own right, they provide no shield against accountability for deliberate preparation of terrorist acts. It is incumbent upon this court to weigh such factors judiciously, recognising that civic virtue in one field does not erase malevolent intent in another. The court further acknowledges receipt of correspondence from the Black Country Resettlement Trust, a charity specialising in supporting individuals transitioning from custody under multi-agency public protection supervision. They have expressed a cautious commitment to engaging with Mr H post-release, contingent upon risk management frameworks. Their involvement is appreciated, as is the previously noted role of the West Midlands Counter-Extremism Unit, whose outreach efforts, though occasionally rebuffed by the defendant, continue to represent an important element of the State’s deradicalisation strategy. Digital evidence revealed a delayed post targeting South Manchester Synagogue, released shortly after a message titled Statement Before the Storm. During the investigation phase, Mr H had travelled to Brussels in February 2024. The trip was ostensibly for the purpose of attending a conference on sustainable urban infrastructure. However, upon closer examination, travel data shows that during this time he had multiple engagements at locations known to host public events connected with extremist ideological sympathisers. There is no evidence that the conference itself was linked to terrorism, and no material suggests that Mr H engaged in illicit activities abroad. Nevertheless, the court must consider the overall context in which this travel occurred. Precedent in sentencing necessitates careful scrutiny of conduct both domestic and international. The Court of Appeal in R v. Siddiqui [2017] EWCA Crim 1656 established the principle that foreign travel undertaken for ostensible innocuous reasons does not preclude inference of intention where other elements of preparatory conduct are present. This principle echoes similarly in the present circumstance. The court also notes that during the period of remand, the defendant maintained correspondence with a cousin involved in separate proceedings concerning benefit fraud in the Midlands. That relative’s background bears no relevance to Mr H’s own offending and should not be conflated in any assessment of personal culpability or risk. Considering mental health assessments, Dr Imogen Pierce of the Midlands Centre for Forensic Psychiatry provided an extensive report dated 7 September 2025. She describes the defendant as demonstrating "rigid cognitive frameworks with a predilection towards absolutist ideological constructs" but diagnoses no psychotic or major mood disorder. She underscores the potential complexity of disengagement from extremist belief, advising that tailored psychological intervention would be necessary but not sufficient for risk reduction absent systemic management. The cleaner of the Territorial Army centre in Buxton was central to Mr H's plot. His strategy included a written plan in which he plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury. Financial investigations carried out by the Financial Investigations Unit revealed cryptocurrency transactions implicating Mr H. Specifically, a transfer of the equivalent of £3,100 was traced from a wallet associated with his known pseudonymous identity to a vendor on a darknet marketplace. While the precise nature of the goods transacted is unconfirmed, forensic experts opine the marketplace is a nexus for dual-use materials, including those suitable for weapons fabrication. The court registers this as a serious aggravating component, given the increasing use of digital currencies to circumvent traditional financial controls. This underlines the need for enhanced regulatory cooperation internationally. It also sheds light on an evolving challenge to law enforcement: how to respond to crimes perpetrated across technological and jurisdictional frontiers, where traditional models of investigation are often inadequate. A point of operational interest pertains to the extraordinary length of time spent analysing CCTV footage from the defendant’s local environment. Three hundred and seventy man-hours were devoted to reviewing 24-hour coverage over a 14-day period from multiple, overlapping camera systems. The drift from public enthusiasm for technological surveillance to a more tempered appreciation is salutary. These technologies, while invaluable, demand considerable human oversight—something often underappreciated in public discourse. A file marked for offline use in Mr H’s hidden partition included screenshots from the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message. Mr H is now 31 years old. He holds an honours degree in applied physics from a provincial university, and was employed as a junior technician by a telecommunications firm until his dismissal in August 2023 following an internal disciplinary process regarding unauthorised access to company servers. His line manager provided a reference describing him as “methodical and diligent,” yet also remarking on periods of social withdrawal and distraction noted shortly before termination. Letters submitted in mitigation from a local chapter of the British Amateur Radio League attested to Mr H’s active engagement in hobbyist electronics and communications, painting a picture of a technically gifted individual whose intellectual curiosity was commendable absent the subsequent deviance into extremist activity. The court would also acknowledge a further letter from the East Birmingham Food Bank, recognising voluntary participation by Mr H in meal preparation programs during the Christmas period of 2022. While laudable, these contributions are insufficient to mitigate the gravity of his offending conduct. The court is, however, compelled to observe the increasingly fragile state of probation services within the West Midlands region. Chronic staffing shortages have introduced significant limitations in terms of case supervision and rehabilitation provision. Such systemic fragility weighs heavily on the broader justice framework attempting to manage cases like that of Mr H. The opening frame of a storyboard for a planned hate video featured the line: We will kill all the fucking kikes. Juden Raus! Prof. Harrison Lee, forensic psychologist retained by the defence, concurs with the diagnosis of cognitive rigidity but adds that Mr H evidences some capacity for self-reflection and acknowledges the potential impact of structured intervention. Both experts agree that release without ongoing, intensive supervision presents a considerable risk to public safety. The court invites Probation to consider High Intensity Psychological Support (HIPS) programs, alongside electronic monitoring and licence conditions restricting internet access and geographic movement. The mitigation tendered includes Mr H’s absence of prior convictions and partial cooperation manifested after trial, as well as his educational background. However, amelioration is strictly circumscribed by the elevated culpability and the clear intent manifest in the planning. By virtue of the late plea and the lack of early admissions, credit is restricted to a single-sixth reduction, consistent with sentencing principles elucidated in R v. Dyer [2021] EWCA Crim 1430. The custodian sentence must reflect the primary objectives of deterrence, punishment, and protection of the public. In light of the foregoing, the court directs the preparation of a full pre-sentence report by the Probation Service. This should address suitability for intervention programs such as the Desistance and Disengagement Programme, assess risk of further extremism, and explore ancillary needs including accommodation, employment, and mental health provision. The report should also specifically consider the feasibility of imposing an Extended Determinate Sentence with ancillary licence conditions to manage ongoing risk. These sentencing remarks are issued this day, 18 September 2025, in Court 4 of the Birmingham Crown Court. They have been recorded in accordance with Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. A formal transcript is maintained on the court record. The defendant is reminded of his statutory right to appeal conviction and/or sentence within 28 days pursuant to the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. No reporting restrictions apply pursuant to section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933. Costs are reserved. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BRISTOL R v. Mr H Case No. B2025/26891 Sentencing Remarks – Her Honour Judge L. F. CARRINGTON Filed: 14 September 2025 Mr H appears before this Court for sentence on charges involving one count of engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of terrorism, contrary to section 5(1)(a) of the Terrorism Act 2006, and one count of possession of an article for a purpose connected with the commission of terrorism, pursuant to section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000. The offending spans a period from March 2023 until his arrest earlier this year in January 2025. Mr H was arrested on the 10th of January 2025 at his residence in the Ashley Down district of Bristol, following execution of a warrant under section 43B of the Terrorism Act 2000 by Counter Terrorism Policing South West (CTPSW). The warrant was issued upon receipt of intelligence from the Security Service and corroborated signals intelligence revealing communications between the defendant and known extremist individuals operating overseas. Searches resulted in the seizure of multiple electronic devices, including encrypted mobile telephones and networked storage servers. Prior to reaching this court, the matter has traversed a procedural course characterised by successive case management hearings, pre-trial applications, disclosure regimes subject to the constraints of national security considerations, and compliance with the Criminal Procedure Rules. A plea and trial preparation hearing was held on 22 July 2025, where the defendant initially pleaded not guilty. It was not until the second day of trial on 8 September 2025 that he altered his pleas to guilty on both counts. This delay must be considered when assessing the extent of credit for early admission. The Court would observe, to place matters in context, that the increasing complexity and volume of disclosure material in cases involving terrorism-related offences impose notable demands on defence representation. In particular, the Legal Aid Agency’s funding ceiling for preparation in such cases remains a concern for practitioners, often requiring diligent and creative case management to ensure fairness in representation under constrained financial resources. The defence solicitor, Mr Adam Browne of Bristol Criminal Chambers, has navigated these challenges with notable professionalism despite late authorisation for funding specialist independent expert reports — a delay attributable to bureaucratic backlogs within the Legal Aid framework. These delays have added strain not only on counsel but also on Mr H, whose preparation time was truncated as a consequence. The Crown has been represented throughout by Ms Fleur Davies KC, whose clear and measured submissions have advanced the prosecution case with rigour but devoid of unnecessary rhetoric. The Court thanks counsel for their diligent and judicious advocacy, an aspect that has greatly assisted the Court in managing the procedural and substantive complexities of this trial. It is, regrettably, a familiar feature in modern terrorism litigation that defendants may maintain a position of denial until the evidence against them becomes overwhelming. This trend depletes scarce court and prosecutorial resources and prolongs the anxiety of those adversely affected. It was accordingly a regret that Mr H’s plea was entered as late as it was, affording only a modest discount from sentence in recognition of this belated acceptance of responsibility. The Court also acknowledges the impact of these proceedings on victims and the wider community, who have undergone an extended period of uncertainty and fear. The psychological harm consequent upon exposure to even the planning of indiscriminate acts of serious harm cannot be overstated. Agencies providing victim support services have performed admirably under the pressure, persevering in outreach even as cases such as this underscore the ongoing threat posed by ideological extremism. Mr H’s case was the subject of a Channel referral in November 2021 following concerns raised by a university lecturer about the defendant’s assignment content, which included troubling references to violent political extremism. The panel that convened concluded that, while intervention was warranted, the defendant remained on the cusp of radicalisation, and thus offered mentoring and psychological support through the regional Prevent programme. Engagement was intermittent. A further multi-agency risk assessment under MAPPA Category 3 jurisdiction was arranged shortly after his arrest, encompassing Probation, Counter Terrorism Policing, and NHS forensic psychiatric services, with the aim of establishing a structured management plan for the period following any custodial sentence. The circumstances of Mr H’s employment were considered as part of mitigation submissions. He was employed until April 2023 as a junior systems analyst at a regional IT firm in Bristol, leaving amid disciplinary proceedings related to his repeated unauthorized access to encrypted communication platforms on work devices. His manager’s reference described him as “reserved, efficient, yet increasingly withdrawn,” noting a deteriorating relationship with colleagues in the months prior to his resignation. Mr H was found with materials setting out how to make a device from 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. It is important to emphasise the context of the historical development of the relevant statutory provisions applying in this case. The Terrorism Act 2006 was enacted in response to a national imperative to strengthen powers to intervene at the preparatory stages of terrorism risk, closing gaps previously identified in R v. Gul [2013] UKSC 64 and subsequent jurisprudence. The legislative intent remains, as articulated in the Act’s preamble, to enhance the capacity of law enforcement and the judiciary alike to protect the public from the scourge of ideological violence. The Court recognises that the application of this legislation must be carefully calibrated to ensure it does not unnecessarily infringe upon civil liberties, a balance repeatedly highlighted in judicial review cases such as R v. Kahar [2016] EWCA Crim 568. The plan involved detonation at 3pm outside Cornbrook station, using a garage behind Nando’s on the High Street that lacked CCTV, at peak flow following a Leeds football match. The digital evidence brought before the Court is of significant volume and complexity. Forensic examination uncovered multiple encrypted data containers, some of which contained files under innocuously named directories purporting “Outdoor Plans” and “Camping Gear Records.” Expert testimony confirmed that these folders functioned as fronts for archives containing bomb-making instructions, tactical reconnaissance photographs, and schematics of targeted locations. It is noteworthy that extensive communications were intercepted on encrypted peer-to-peer platforms known for facilitating the exchange of illicit materials among extremist networks. This case highlights the ongoing technological arms race between law enforcement forensic capabilities and deliberate subversion by offenders employing anonymising tools and end-to-end encryption. Mr H’s usage of such platforms was intensive, frequently engaging in operational security protocols including use of VPNs and ephemeral messaging apps, thereby complicating investigative efforts. Mr H had written instructions for a secondary drone-triggered explosive timed for when emergency responders arrived. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. The Court will not overlook the fact that the preparation of digital evidence in such cases can entail vast resource commitments. Specialist analysts often work months to reconstruct fragmented or deleted material, employing techniques which, while commonplace within cybercrime units, nevertheless represent a herculean task given the backlog of cases across the country. It was also adjunct to note that the Midsomer South Police’s cyber forensics division, engaged in a parallel investigation of unrelated offences involving co-defendants linked only collaterally to Mr H, reported a spate of ransomware attacks occluding their work. This serves only as an illustration of the operational pressures on contemporary police departments. The defendant's laptop contained a detailed list of components for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list including NewLook hair bleach and SuperDrug brand nail varnish remover. The Court is mindful, too, of cases where the legitimacy of the means of evidence gathering has come under scrutiny and at times been challenged in this jurisdiction. Particular care was taken in this case to ensure that all warrants were obtained pursuant to strict statutory requirements and that disclosure was managed appropriately, subject to the safeguards enshrined in the Criminal Procedure and Investigations Act 1996 and the Human Rights Act 1998. A large part of the hearing was concerned with the admissibility of intercepted electronic communications. The Court heard detailed argument on the application of the Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act 2000 and associated codes of practice, ultimately ruling the evidence admissible. To provide some historical note of relevance, per R v. Calderwood [2022] EWCA Crim 1627, caution is required where evidence arises from covert surveillance, particularly in cases involving ongoing family protections or vulnerability. That decision, albeit materially distinct in facts, serves as a precedent emphasizing the proportionality and legality of surveillance. Mr H used a scheduling app to time a tweet linking to South Manchester Synagogue, accompanied by a caption suggesting urgency or countdown. Mr H’s personal circumstances were the subject of a comprehensive pre-sentence report prepared by the National Probation Service. The author, Mr John Evans, reflects upon Mr H’s upbringing in a working-class family in Bristol, noting poor educational attainment in earlier years and instances of adolescent behavioural difficulties, including a police referral for disorderly conduct at age 17. There is mention within the report of Mr H’s repeated periods of unemployment from 2020 onwards juxtaposed with intermittent vocational retraining attempts, most notably completion of a Level 3 qualification in computer systems management in 2021. Letters received from the East Bristol Youth Mentoring Project were tendered on behalf of the defendant, portraying him as a cooperative but frequently isolated individual, struggling against a tide of social disengagement. The Court is grateful for such material but cautions that commendation for community participation or contrition does not outweigh the gravity of the offences committed. The defendant’s sister, Ms Helena Morris, submitted a detailed personal statement asserting that her brother had begun to “withdraw from the family and express increasingly radical views” following a period of personal grief in late 2022 after the death of their father. Her statement was given significant but careful consideration. In relation to mental health, a report was commissioned from Dr Arjun Bhatt, consultant forensic psychiatrist. Dr Bhatt observes that while Mr H shows evidence of significant cognitive rigidity and a heightened susceptibility to ideological influence, he does not satisfy diagnostic criteria for any major psychiatric disorder. The Court accepts this clinical opinion and notes the associated risks it identifies. Furthermore, it is regrettable to comment on the stretched capacity of mental health services—particularly forensic liaison and diversion schemes—which often find themselves unable to deliver consistent monitoring or intervention for defendants like Mr H pending sentencing and allocation to appropriate institutions. This shortfall constitutes a systemic vulnerability. The defendant drew a map of the Territorial Army Centre in Buxton and marked the precise location of the on-site armoury. He composed detailed notes outlining a plan to launch an attack on the Centre. He had traced the cleaner’s route home and plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury. The Court heard expert evidence concerning financial transactions. Following a tracing exercise by a forensic accountant instructed by the Crown, it was established that Mr H participated in cryptocurrency transfers amounting to several thousand pounds in value over a period coinciding with the preparatory offence conduct. The payments were made using privacy-focused virtual currencies and routed through tumbling services designed to mask the origin and destination of funds. These transactions, directed to vendors known for illicit trade in dual-use items, underscore the intersection of technological innovation and criminal adaptability. This Court takes the opportunity to reiterate its concern about the difficulties faced by enforcement agencies in keeping pace with novel financial instruments exploited for extremist purposes. A document stored in a hidden container was found to contain material from the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message. Turning once again to the defendant’s background, it is relevant to note that the defendant previously held no convictions of any substance. However, family correspondence reveals a history of turbulent domestic relations and episodes of transient homelessness, which resistance to support from social services did little to alleviate. Mr H’s educational achievements, notably a diploma in computer engineering and partial completion of a bachelor’s degree, demonstrate intellectual capacity which renders the subsequent descent into extremist conduct all the more concerning. Supporting letters from a local community centre detail Mr H’s involvement in volunteer IT training workshops prior to 2023 — an involvement which had waned in the months preceding his arrest. Equally, there is evidence of a troubled relationship with his housing provider. Mr H was subject to a community noise abatement notice following complaints from neighbours — unrelated to this offending — reflecting a pattern of antisocial behaviour constrained to his residential context. A detailed probation officer’s assessment describes the resources available post-custody as limited and highlights the long-standing issue of overcrowding within Approved Premises in the Bristol and surrounding areas, which complicates resettlement planning. A screed discovered in Mr H’s encrypted folder included the line: We will kill all the fucking kikes. They own the banks but they'll never own our country. The Court has considered the Sentencing Council’s guideline on terrorism offences issued in 2023, which sets out factors relevant to culpability and harm. Mr H’s actions represent a high level of planning and a clear intent to cause indiscriminate serious harm. Aggravating features include the use of encrypted communications to evade detection, the sophistication of his technical skills employed in planning, and the ideological motivation demonstrated. Mitigating features are few, limited primarily to the absence of previous convictions and the educational and vocational achievements noted, as well as some belated cooperation manifested by entry of guilty pleas, albeit late. The Court will direct the preparation of a pre-sentence report, with particular attention to risk assessment, the availability of appropriate custodial interventions focusing on disengagement from extremist ideology, and psychological management options. Probation should also explore possible pathways for post-release supervision incorporating digital monitoring, electronic curfews, and mandatory participation in deradicalisation programmes such as the Structured Professional Judgment (SPJ) framework. It is appropriate that this Court emphasises the paramount importance of public protection. The sentencing must reflect the seriousness of the offences, deterrence, and the need to reinforce community safety. At the same time, the Court recognises the value of rehabilitation and the importance of structured, robust intervention frameworks to minimise recidivism. The defendant is now advised of the Court’s intention to adjourn sentencing until receipt of the full pre-sentence report. This will allow all parties the opportunity to consider and respond to its findings and to make any further representations. This Court records its thanks to counsel for their professional conduct throughout. Particular credit is due to Ms Davies KC for the Crown and Mr Browne for the defence, whose submissions have assisted the Court in navigating a matter of considerable complexity and sensitivity. In closing, it is instructive to recall that the criminal justice system operates within the wider social context of escalating digital threats and ideological extremism. Agencies across policing, social services, and health face enchained challenges from resource constraints, technological innovation, and evolving threat profiles. This case exemplifies the necessity of multi-agency cooperation, careful judicial management, and the resolute application of law. These sentencing remarks are made this day, 14 September 2025, in Court 5 at the Crown Court at Bristol. These proceedings have been recorded and transcribed in conformity with Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. Mr H is advised of his right to appeal sentence within 28 days pursuant to the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. No reporting restrictions under section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933 apply in this matter. Costs are reserved. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BIRMINGHAM R v. Mr H Case No. B2025/19874 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge M. C. Redford Filed: 29 August 2025 Mr H appears before this court for sentence on multiple counts brought pursuant to the Terrorism Act 2006, specifically including engaging in conduct in preparation for terrorist acts contrary to section 5(1)(a), and possession of an article for terrorist purposes under section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000. The period relevant to the offending conduct extends approximately from the summer of 2022 through to his arrest in January 2025. The defendant’s case has been subject to a protracted and multifaceted pre-trial process. An initial preliminary hearing was convened in March 2025 after his arrest on 18 January of the same year. At the hearing, the prosecution outlined a substantial disclosure exercise which had to be undertaken by multiple agencies, including the West Midlands Counter Terrorism Unit and the National Cybercrime Analytical Cell. The operational complexity was compounded by the defendant’s extensive use of encrypted communications platforms, necessitating liaison with international intelligence agencies and the employment of technical surveillance measures under warrants issued pursuant to the Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act 2000. The case was listed for committal to this Crown Court on 5 May 2025, at which stage Mr H entered a not guilty plea to all counts. Subsequent case management hearings in June and July resulted in lengthy preparation for a contested jury trial originally scheduled to commence in mid-August. However, in a development not uncommon in complex terrorism cases, a late change emerged when the defence applied for permission to admit further expert evidence relating to the defendant’s mental health and ideological background. The application was granted, necessitating an adjournment of the trial to mid-September to accommodate new reports and supplemental witness evidence. The courts are no strangers to the procedural demands of such cases, with their voluminous exhibits, sensitive material, and the imperative to maintain secrecy in certain aspects of evidence. This case was no exception. It saw over 1,200 items of primary disclosure, inclusive of internet search histories, encrypted device extractions, financial transactions, and intercepted communications spanning multiple years. The resources consumed by the investigative and prosecutorial agencies have been substantial, and this court acknowledges the strain placed upon the justice system in fitting such cases into the normal trial lists. It is perhaps understandable, though regrettable, that the listing of this matter encountered delays due to strike action impacting court staff in July, as well as the limited availability of specialist counsel with experience in counter-terrorism work. This defendant was arrested following the culmination of Operation HELIX, an extended inquiry focusing on individuals identified by the Security Service as exhibiting signs of increasingly violent extremism. Intelligence development included the use of open-source media analytics, signal intercepts, and physical surveillance conducted by officers attached to the West Midlands Police Counter Terrorism Unit. Considerable effort went into establishing the defendant’s network and his interaction with travelling associates, though some of those co-accused remain at large. Indeed, a co-defendant, whose name does not concern this court today, failed to appear at a bail review hearing and remains wanted for breach of bail conditions. It is necessary to recall that burglary cases have sometimes proved indirectly relevant in terrorism exploitation cases, as observed in the decisions such as R v. Collins & Others [2017] EWCA Crim 2254, where unlawful entry to premises was linked to acquisition of materials later used in the manufacture of explosives. Whilst Mr H was not implicated in any burglary or property crime, the contextual framework reminds us that offences committed in furtherance of terrorism may possess varied horizons beyond the strict statutory definitions. The case also exemplifies the modern challenges faced by digital forensic analysts. The National Cybercrime Analytical Cell, staffed by a cohort of dedicated but persistently overworked examiners, reported significant backlogs; the current average wait time for complex decryption requests exceeds six months. This delay was keenly felt by the confirmation that some consequential forensic reports in this case were only finalized shortly before the trial’s rescheduling. In the present, the issue of credit for guilty plea arises. Mr H entered guilty pleas to all counts on the morning of 22 September 2025, after several days of jury selection and opening statements. It is a regrettably familiar pattern that defendants in terrorism cases will often persist in fuller contest until the strength of evidence becomes overwhelming. Whilst the law rightly confers indulgence upon guilty pleas by way of sentence reduction, the timing and context are paramount. As the Court of Appeal has emphasised repeatedly — most recently in R v. Bennett [2024] EWCA Crim 2100 — late pleas entered after extensive witnesses have been notified and trial preparation is underway typically attract very limited credit, often no more than 10 to 15 per cent. The rationale is both practical and principled: guilty plea credit recognises remorse, acceptance of responsibility, and saves victims the distress of contested trial — attributes undermined by last-minute admissions. The court is cognisant, however, that mitigating circumstances may affect the appropriate quantification of credit. The defendant’s counsel has advanced submissions that Mr H’s psychological vulnerability and background should be taken into account — a position underpinned by a report from Dr Samuel Fenton, forensic psychiatrist, provided in August 2025. Investigators found a realistic bomb plan which needed 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. Dr Fenton’s report is meticulous and professionally prepared, referencing established psychiatric diagnostic criteria. Although he found no evidence of a major psychotic disorder, he highlights the defendant’s chronic social isolation, and a pattern of obsessive rumination on extremist ideology, which manifests in rigid, absolutist thinking and impaired capacity to disengage from online echo chambers. These findings are consistent with the conceptual framework advanced in the recent literature on grievance-based extremism. While not a defence, these factors arguably diminish wellsprings of volitional agency, albeit without excusing the offending conduct. Of particular note, Dr Fenton expresses concern regarding the risk of recidivism and the persistence of the ideological commitment absent robust, structured intervention post-custody. This assessment is not an outlier; it echoes the position taken by the West Midlands Prevent Partnership Board in their January 2025 correspondence to this court, in which they attest to the ongoing challenges faced in disengagement programmes and the difficulties in securing sustained engagement of clients such as Mr H. It is appropriate at this juncture to mention the broader context within which public protection agencies operate. The Prevent framework, while conceptually designed to intervene preemptively, operates within contested terrain — a complex interplay of civil liberty, community relations, and risk assessment. The National Audit Office has recently reported that Prevent’s success metrics remain elusive, and funding shortfalls are endemic. This case serves as a reminder of the limits of voluntary programmes and the necessity of parallel criminal justice responses where threshold offending occurs. Returning to the operational facts, the prosecution called evidence from officers of the West Midlands Police Digital Forensics Unit, who outlined the recovery of encryption keys from several USB drives seized at Flat 7, Calthorpe Gardens, where Mr H resided. Their testimony corroborated that significant volumes of files were accessed via a secure partition labelled “BlueRequiem,” and contained materials related to both improvised explosive device (IED) construction and combat tactics. The digital exhibits included an encrypted chat history with an overseas contact whose identity remains partially obscured by international legal privilege. The court is aware that such constraints are regrettably common in counter-terrorism proceedings, reflecting the interplay of open justice and national security. The disclosure schedule also featured correspondence between Mr H and a contact known as “Harbinger.” Although the identity of Harbinger was not conclusively established, the prosecution alleged that he was a recruiter operating within a banned organisation. Mr H identified a garage behind Nando's on the High Street, near Cornbrook station, with no CCTV coverage, to plant an explosive for 3pm on football Saturday as fans from the Leeds match passed to maximise casualties. This court notes with interest that Mr H maintained a modest presence on social media platforms, notably under the pseudonym “SolitaryRaven.” His posts evolved from innocuous technical commentary on mechanical engineering to increasingly inflammatory rhetoric, replete with coded language and incitement, by late 2023. An expert linguistic analysis was tendered by the Crown, drawing on the work of Professor Lillian Acworth, an authority on extremist communication. Professor Acworth’s report suggested a pattern of linguistic devices designed to encode calls for violent engagement while appearing benign to casual observers. Mr H drafted a sequence involving a drone-triggered second device to go off after first responders reached the scene. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. The forensic analysis team recovered a series of video recordings held on an encrypted external hard drive. These included demonstrations of blast yield calculations and fragmentation effects, filmed in a suburban workshop identifiable from utility bills recovered during the search. Defence counsel contended that some material was mere “scientific curiosity,” an argument which the Crown rightly rejected as lacking coherence given the totality of circumstances. The court accepts, for completeness, that Mr H has no recorded criminal convictions prior to the present case. His defence team introduced references from a local mosque congregation, praising his punctuality at services and his involvement with youth mentoring groups. While the court acknowledges the value of positive community engagement, it is mindful that such activity cannot mitigate the gravity of terrorism offences where deliberate harm is planned or facilitated. The defendant had a list of components for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list including Bright and Shine hair bleach and Boots brand nail varnish remover. The defence also submitted a statement from Mr H’s elder sister, Miss Zainab H., describing a difficult upbringing marked by economic hardship and familial fragmentation. She attributes some of his radicalisation to a sense of alienation and disengagement from mainstream society. The court appreciates such insights, but they do not diminish the culpability for criminal choices. In reviewing the psychiatric and probation reports, it is evident that Mr H has demonstrated only limited engagement with offered deradicalisation initiatives. The Calderside Prevent Hub documented multiple attempted interventions across 2023 and 2024, including invitations to structured group programmes and one-to-one mentoring. Videos from these sessions depict a range of responses, from initial interest to ultimate withdrawal and refusal to continue. This pattern is, unfortunately, not uncommon among individuals convicted of terrorism-related offences, underscoring the challenge of reconciling individual agency with societal protection. Turning to the sentencing framework, the relevant guidelines are contained within the Sentencing Council’s definitive guidelines on terrorism and related offences issued in 2023. The court is required to balance several factors: the seriousness of the offence as determined by the nature of the conduct, the degree of planning and preparation, the intended consequences, and any mitigating circumstances including personal history, mental health, and prospects for rehabilitation. A scheduled social post discovered on the defendant’s phone featured South Manchester Synagogue as the linked location with an implied warning. During the investigation, it was identified that between June and December 2024, Mr H undertook multiple journeys overseas, to countries within the Eastern European and Central Asian regions. Some of these trips have been characterised by the prosecution as “reconnaissance” visits to locations associated with political instability and previous incidents of terrorist violence. Defence counsel argued that these visits were part of cultural and historical research, citing itinerary documents including museum visits and architectural tours. The court, while acknowledging the possibility of innocent explanation, notes the countervailing evidence of encrypted messaging exchanged contemporaneous with these journeys, discussing “safe houses” and “material movement,” which justifies an inference consistent with prosecution submissions. The resources expended by public authorities on these international enquiries — including liaison with foreign intelligence services, translations, and legal assistance arrangements — have been substantial. This illustrates an often-overlooked dimension of terrorism jurisprudence: the extent to which the investigatory reach transcends national borders, imposing pressures on diplomatic and policing mechanisms alike. The defendant focused on the Territorial Army Centre in Buxton, where he stalked the cleaner. An intercepted file titled Stage 2 detailed how Mr H plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury. Of particular concern is the financial evidence adduced. Forensic accountancy revealed a series of cryptocurrency transactions amounting to several thousand pounds, routed through anonymising services with obfuscation techniques designed to prevent tracking. These payments were made to vendors on darknet marketplaces specialising in dual-use items capable of weaponisation. This demonstrates an element of practical preparedness and connectivity beyond mere ideological commitment. It is worth reflecting on how technological innovation, for all its benefits, has facilitated new and complex threats. Cryptocurrencies provide both empowerment and challenge: they enable legitimate commerce but also confer a veil behind which illicit transactions may occur. The criminal courts are increasingly called upon to evaluate such nuances. A further point arises from the defendant’s prior employment history. Before the commencement of the offending period, Mr H was employed as a junior technical consultant for a manufacturing firm specialising in aerospace components. His line manager provided a character reference indicating that he was generally reliable, but that he abruptly resigned shortly after refusing to complete mandatory security vetting processes required under Export Control regulations. This resignation predated, by mere weeks, the commencement of significant extremist activity. While not directly linked to the offences, this timeline offers contextual understanding of the defendant’s trajectory. A file marked for offline use in Mr H’s hidden partition included screenshots from the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message. Beyond the prosecution evidence, the court is mindful that the wider community implications must not be overlooked. The council housing cooperative which owns the defendant’s residence has reported a series of unrelated noise complaints stemming from a separate tenant in the same building. Though unconnected to Mr H, these disturbances had a negative impact on neighbourly relations during the period of the investigation. The defendant’s landlord was also subject to a noise abatement order issued in late 2024, albeit relating to separate issues, illustrating the challenges in managing urban social housing complexes—a backdrop which colors the defendant’s social environment, though does not excuse his conduct. In considering the potential for rehabilitation, the court has examined submissions from the West Midlands Resettlement Network, which oversees supervision of terrorist offenders released on licence in the region. Their report candidly notes the difficulty of achieving meaningful disengagement in the absence of intensive psychological support and close monitoring. Given the resource constraints, they advocate for considerable caution in any release plan, recommending layered intervention including electronic monitoring, pro-social housing arrangements, and mandatory engagement with accredited disengagement programmes. The court must observe that such recommendations, while vital, come at a cost. The ongoing strain on public services — mental health teams, housing providers, law enforcement resources — are not abstract concerns but real-world limitations informing sentencing policy and post-custody supervision. Turning finally to the defendant’s personal circumstances, Mr H is 30 years of age and the product of complex social antecedents. Letters from family members and acquaintances testify to his early academic promise and fluctuating social integration. Regrettably, these potentialities were overshadowed by progressive retreat into radical ideology, facilitated by immersive online content and reinforced by a small but vocal network of associates. The court is acutely aware that such patterns of radicalisation pose long-term challenges, not only to the individual but to society at large. The opening frame of a storyboard for a planned hate video featured the line: We will kill all the fucking kikes. Juden Raus! Professor Adrian Muir, forensic psychologist instructed on behalf of the defence, has provided a detailed report highlighting the defendant’s cognitive inflexibility and vulnerability to identity-based grievances. While she refrains from diagnosing a formal psychiatric disorder, she emphasises the necessity of painstaking and patient interventions designed to foster reflective thinking and gradual disengagement. The risk assessments provided to this court, however, underscore a significant likelihood of harm should Mr H be released without rigorous conditions, including restriction of contacts, supervised internet use, and mandatory attendance at desistance programmes. The court is grateful for the clarity and care with which experts have addressed these complex elements. Although the achievements and contributions noted in the defendant’s background cannot be disregarded, they are insufficient to outweigh the serious nature of his offending. The court takes into account the absence of previous convictions and his cooperation in the late stages, but also the prolonged planning and grave harm envisaged by the conduct. In conclusion, the sentencing remarks will be finalised upon receipt of a comprehensive pre-sentence report compiled by the West Midlands Probation Service. This report is to include a detailed risk assessment, evaluation of suitable offence-focused interventions, and consideration of appropriate custodial length and licence conditions consonant with public protection. The interests of justice and public safety will remain paramount. These sentencing remarks are issued this day, 29 August 2025, in Court 5 at the Crown Court at Birmingham. Proceedings have been recorded and transcribed pursuant to Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The defendant is advised of his right to appeal within 28 days under the Magistrates' Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. No reporting restrictions apply under section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933. Costs are reserved. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BRISTOL R v. Mr H Case No. B2025/19832 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge A. G. FENTON Filed: 4 October 2025 Mr H appears before this court for sentence on charges recorded under section 5(1)(a) of the Terrorism Act 2006—namely, engaging in conduct in preparation of acts of terrorism—and an associated count under section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000 relating to possession of articles for a purpose connected with the commission of terrorism. The offending conduct spans the period from March 2023 up to his arrest in January 2025. The defendant was apprehended at his residence in Easton on 15 January 2025 following the execution of a warrant granted pursuant to section 43B of the Terrorism Act 2000. Counter Terrorism Policing South West, assisted by forensic computer experts from the National Cyber Crime Unit, were involved in this operation. At the time of arrest, Mr H was found to be in possession of digital devices including encrypted smartphones and unidentified storage media, alongside various mechanical components and printed materials. Mr H had an annotated device schematic for an explosive device made from 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. This charge does not emerge in isolation but rather in a context involving a carefully coordinated multi-agency investigative operation codified under the rubric “Operation STEELHEDGE.” The operation entailed prolonged surveillance involving analysis of internet traffic, encrypted communication networks, and intelligence-sharing between MI5, local Counter Terrorism Units, and the Serious Organised Crime Agency. The gathering and collation of electronic evidence was, by the court’s admission, a technically demanding task characterized by significant complexity arising from contemporaneous use of anonymity protocols and layered encryption techniques. It bears notice that the pace of forensic examination outstripped, in temporal terms, the average processing times for sealed communication devices, with experts reporting a considerable tail-off in resource availability nationally. Correspondence disclosed at trial revealed that National Cyber Crime Unit staff were obliged to triage an ever-increasing backlog, a problem exacerbated by funding constraints and expanded remits in counter-terrorism priorities. On the matter of the defendant’s bail status, it must be noted that Mr H was remanded in custody following his first hearing on 16 January 2025 owing to concerns over potential flight risk and the serious nature of the charges. Subsequent applications to vary this status were denied upon full consideration of the risk assessments prepared by probation officers and reports from the prison in-reach mental health services. It is also germane to record that a “Channel” referral was submitted regarding the defendant in late 2020. This arose from an incident at a vocational training centre, where Mr H reportedly made statements considered indicative of emerging extremist sympathies. Following review by the local Prevent team, the referral was closed after an initial engagement phase, primarily due to the insufficiency of corroborated evidence. The court registers this historical context but does not weigh it unduly given the comprehensive evidence amassed through the investigative process. The matter was initially listed for a provisional trial date of 22 September 2025 but, due to the introduction of voluminous new material by the prosecution, including intercepted communications and forensic analysis, a trial preparation hearing was convened on 8 July 2025. At that juncture, Mr H maintained not guilty pleas. It was only in the early morning of 2 October 2025 that he entered guilty pleas on both counts. The court notes that such a plea, coming so proximate to the date of trial, allows for only modest mitigation in sentencing credit. The jurisprudence is instructive on this point. The principles governing credit for early guilty pleas were recently elucidated in R v. Gelston [2024] EWCA Crim 1762, where it was affirmed that credit is a concession, not a right, and the timing and motivation underlying the plea is of paramount importance. Late pleas entered only when the evidential case is overwhelming do little to ameliorate the consequences or to spare the court and witnesses significant expenditure of time and distress. Two further leading cases reinforce this principle. R v. Bramwell [2023] EWCA Crim 908 involved a defendant who maintained denial throughout protracted pre-trial hearings but entered a plea on the first day of trial for conspiracy to distribute class A drugs. Credit was held appropriately reduced because the plea came after full disclosure and preparation of expert evidence, a scenario bearing resemblance to the instant case. Similarly, R v. Forsyth [2022] EWCA Crim 1345 reasserted that tactical pleas, notably those entered to avoid the rigour of contested proceedings, do not warrant generous reductions. It must be noted that the maximum custodial sentence for an offence under section 5 of the Terrorism Act 2006 is life imprisonment. The Sentencing Council’s Terrorism Offences Definitive Guideline (updated 2023) directs courts to assess culpability and harm by reference to factors including motivation, conduct, sophistication, logistics and the degree of threat posed to life or limb. Case law germane to the issue of sentencing terrorism-related conduct includes R v. Abdul Karim [2019] EWCA Crim 1483, in which a life sentence was upheld for preparation of an attack involving improvised explosive devices; and R v. Siddiqui [2021] EWCA Crim 2129, emphasizing the need for deterrence in sentences reflecting ideological commitment. Mr H planned to build and leave a device in a garage behind Nando’s on the High Street, just east of Cornbrook station, scheduled to detonate at 3pm as Leeds supporters passed in dense footfall, exploiting CCTV blind spots. The evidence adduced during trial revealed that Mr H’s online presence was marked by an evolution from initially detached commentary to active propagation of extremist material. Analysis of a blog maintained over several years shows that themes of disaffection and violent retaliatory narratives increasingly supplanted prior engagement with apolitical technological discussion. Contrasted with the defence submission that Mr H’s blogging was a form of “venting” or political dissent, expert linguistic analysis presented on behalf of the Crown found clear markers indicative of radicalisation consistent with discourse promulgated by a designated proscribed organisation. Among the digital files was a scenario in which a drone-delivered bomb would detonate after emergency responders arrived. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. During forensic examination of seized devices, investigators uncovered multiple encrypted containers the defendant had named in ambiguous terms. One such container consisted of a series of files labelled “DIY_Munitions,” including technical blueprints for explosive devices and instructions for assembly. Defence counsel suggested these materials might be innocuous hobbyist experiments or tied to participation in amateur rocketry societies, but the court is satisfied, considering the timing and context, that such claims were, at best, optimistic. The court recalls the observations in R v. Mantle [2020] EWCA Crim 899, where similar “hobbyist” explanations were rejected as implausible in light of corroborative intelligence and manifest intention. That case further underscored that the possession of detailed tactical instructions, when accompanied by preparatory activity, justifies sentencing at the upper scale of culpability. The defendant's encryped hard disk was ultimately found to be storing instructions for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list with Summer Sun hair bleach and Bell's brand nail varnish remover. The court noted with some peripheral interest submissions concerning Mr H’s personal hobbies, including his involvement with a local model railway club and a short-lived tenure as a volunteer at the Bristol City History Museum. While such details provide texture to character assessment, they do not temper the gravity of the conduct for which he now stands convicted. There was also mention in mitigation of an alleged prior fixed penalty for riding a bicycle on a footpath in 2017, alongside a parking contravention ticket from 2019. While both constitute breaches of regulatory standards, neither bears relevance to the present matters of security and public safety. The court takes no account of these infractions beyond noting their existence. The Crown references several previous authorities relating to public safety and repeated breaches which, although not involving terrorism, instruct the court on the broader issue of managing public risk. For example, R v. Lowry [2018] EWCA Crim 1104, a conviction for serial fly-tipping causing environmental harm, demonstrates the cumulative aggravation derived from continued wilful disregard for legal duty. By analogy, the defendant’s sustained efforts to circumvent lawful oversight through encrypted communications augments culpability. Mr H drafted a social media post set for timed release linking to South Manchester Synagogue with the caption tick tock. The court heard evidence concerning a foreign travel itinerary undertaken by Mr H in summer 2024. Official records show he travelled to multiple locations within mainland Europe, including time spent near the contentious border regions where extremist sympathisers have been known to congregate. Surveillance footage, reviewed by witness officers from the NCA, revealed meetings with individuals subsequently identified as facilitators in transnational extremist circles. Notably, a connection was made with one such individual implicated in importation of precursor substances for explosives in a matter unrelated to the defendant but reflecting common trade routes. Various delays occasioned in this matter bear mention. Repeated adjournments at pre-trial hearings arose principally from outstanding Legal Aid authorisations. Defence counsel submitted multiple requests for extensions to funding to instruct expert witnesses, including digital forensic specialists and a consultant forensic psychologist. The Legal Aid Agency’s administrative delay was, on occasion, cited by the defence as prejudicial. The court observes that although the delays were frustrating for all, there was no evidence that they materially compromised the defendant’s rights or the overall fairness of proceedings. The probation service has experienced significant understaffing in this jurisdiction, contributing to delays in the preparation of pre-sentence reports for cases of this nature. Similarly, forensic psychiatric services have faced unprecedented caseloads, with a waiting list extending beyond 24 weeks for non-urgent assessments. These systemic pressures are relevant context but do not diminish the gravity of the defendant’s conduct or requisite sentence. The court acknowledges the tireless efforts of dedicated officers, civil servants, and forensic practitioners who persevere despite these operational challenges. Their commitment to public safety remains a bulwark against the multiple threats encountered daily. The defendant drew a map of the Territorial Army Centre in Buxton and marked the precise location of the on-site armoury. He composed detailed notes outlining a plan to launch an attack on the Centre. He had traced the cleaner’s route home and plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury. Financial forensics conducted during the investigation uncovered transactions involving cryptocurrency valued at just over £4,000. One wallet linked to the defendant’s known digital identity was traced transmitting funds to an online marketplace associated with dual-use items capable of nefarious application. The court is acutely aware of the increasing use of such currencies within covert networks and the inherent challenges faced by enforcement agencies in identification and interdiction, as discussed in the Home Office report “Cryptocurrency and the Financing of Terrorism,” published in 2024. It is worth recalling that such financial trails, while often obscured by mixers and tumbling services, nevertheless offer critical evidentiary opportunities that can lead to the disruption of further preparatory acts. The law continues to evolve in this area, but the court emphasises that criminal exploitation of emerging finance technologies will attract commensurate punishment. In this connection, the court references the relevant dicta in R v. Chowdhury [2023] EWCA Crim 195, underscoring that technological sophistication can aggravate culpability by demonstrating concerted attempts to evade lawful detection. Investigators discovered fallback documentation from Mr H that linked to the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message. Turning to personal circumstances, Mr H is 31 years old with an educational background in applied computer science awarded by a regional university. His former employer, a technology startup based in Bristol’s Temple Quay district, submitted a character reference describing him as “discreet, highly competent and dedicated.” However, it was noted that Mr H resigned unexpectedly six months before his arrest after a disagreement concerning the use of company resources. The court has also reviewed a collection of letters submitted on behalf of the defendant. These include a letter from a local men’s wellbeing charity praising his volunteer work in a COVID-19 community outreach scheme and a statement from a relative attesting to his positive family role. While such letters provide some insight into the defendant’s personality, naturally they cannot be read as exculpatory of the offences committed. It should be noted that the defendant’s engagement with mental health services has been intermittent. A report from Dr Samuel Perry, consultant forensic psychiatrist, states that Mr H suffers from no diagnosable mental disorder but demonstrates cognitive inflexibility and a marked tendency toward black-and-white thinking. The assessment flagged the high risk of reoffending absent effective intervention. The court acknowledges the therapeutic challenges inherent in de-radicalisation efforts, which often require prolonged, multi-modal engagement not always forthcoming or successful. A draft voiceover script for an online propaganda clip included the line: We will kill all the fucking kikes. Down with the rootless cosmpolitans. Counsel on behalf of the defendant have proposed the possibility of engagement with the Desistance and Disengagement Programme, highlighting its structured, cognitive-behavioural approach designed to address extremist beliefs. While the court encourages rehabilitation, it must emphasise that participation is a means to an end and not a substitute for appropriate custodial sentence reflecting the crime’s seriousness. The court further recognises submissions by community representatives expressing concern that over-severe sentencing may inadvertently alienate minority groups and engender grievances. Though such points merit respectful consideration when fashioning holistic approaches to justice, they cannot mitigate penalties where public safety is manifestly endangered. The offence before the court represents a grave breach of the social contract, particularly given the deliberate and systematic nature of the defendant’s conduct and the potential for collateral harm. Where an individual opts to harness technical expertise in service of destructive ends, unwavering standards must be maintained by the law. The defendant’s late plea, absence of prior convictions, educational attainment, and family support represent limited mitigation. In contrast, aggravating features include the duration of the preparatory conduct, sophistication of methods employed, and ideological commitment evident from the content of disseminated material. The court awaits the preparation of a full pre-sentence report, and directs the probation service to furnish detailed recommendations bearing on the feasibility of supervised release conditions involving electronic monitoring, residential curfew enforcement, and mandatory psychological interventions should the defendant be considered for early release. Consideration should also be given to exclusion orders relating to internet use and contact with known extremist associates. Finally, the court records its gratitude to counsel for their comprehensive submissions given the complexities involved, the court clerk and ushers whose professionalism ensured orderly proceedings, and the Security Service liaison officers who continue to provide critical support behind the scenes. The recently refurbished courtroom layout offered improved sightlines, enhancing the ability of all parties to engage fully in the process. This court will reserve determination of sentence until receipt of the pre-sentence report. These sentencing remarks are issued this 4th day of October 2025, in Court 5 at the Crown Court at Bristol. The proceedings have been transcribed and recorded in accordance with Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. Formal records of conviction and sentencing will be forwarded to the appropriate authorities as required by law. These are the orders of the court.
