input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT SHEFFIELD R v. Mr H Case No. S2025/26941 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge L. K. Fairbourne Filed: 17 September 2025 Mr H appears before this court for sentence having pleaded guilty to two counts pursuant to section 5(1)(a) of the Terrorism Act 2006, namely engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of terrorism, and possession of an article for a purpose connected with the commission of terrorism, contrary to section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000. The offending conduct is said to have occurred from late 2022 until his arrest in April 2025. This case has been allocated to the Crown Court as the appropriate tier given the gravity of the allegations and the maximum penalties permitted by statute, including the possibility of life imprisonment under section 5 of the 2006 Act. As a court operating under Better Case Management (BCM) protocols introduced in 2013, these proceedings have sought to observe expeditious timetabling, though challenges inevitably arose reflecting the complexity of national security investigations involving digital evidence, liaison with intelligence agencies, and the incorporation of sensitive material under the Justice and Security Act 2013. The defendant was initially remanded in custody on 12 April 2025 following his arrest at a residential premises in Crookesmoor, Sheffield, executed pursuant to warrants under section 43B of the Terrorism Act 2000. The arrest capped a sustained investigation code-named Operation DRAGONFIRE, led by Counter Terrorism Policing Yorkshire and the Humber in close partnership with the Midlands Regional Intelligence Unit, the Security Service, and national forensic data teams. A recovered bomb-making worksheet in Mr H’s flat described how to improvise a device with 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. Much has already been set out in various interlocutory hearings regarding the evidential basis for Mr H’s arrest. Evidence relied upon included intercepted encrypted communications, social media posts disseminated under a pseudonym, and forensic examination of devices secured on his person and within his home. It is noted that Operation DRAGONFIRE ran contemporaneously with other major investigations, including a high-profile prosecutorial effort involving a co-defendant charged in Westminster with possession of explosives precursors and conspiracy to commit terrorism. It is a feature of counter-terrorism cases that multiple threads often interweave, yet the present prosecution concerns only the conduct attributable to Mr H himself. No inferences should be drawn from unrelated charges against co-defendants or other persons of interest who remain at large or have pending proceedings. In advancing his defence at earlier stages, Mr H pleaded not guilty. The change of plea to guilty on 8 September 2025, after trial preparation hearings and expert report submissions, was welcomed but noted as belated in the context of the Criminal Procedure Rules and the established jurisprudence on plea credit. The principles governing mitigation for guilty pleas were comprehensively elucidated in the Court of Appeal decision R v. Elwood [2022] EWCA Crim 1490. That case involved a defendant charged with multiple counts of arson and possession of an offensive weapon, whose plea only arose when confronted with overwhelming DNA evidence linking him to a fire that destroyed a terrace house in Newcastle. Elwood confirmed that reductions for plea are at the discretion of the sentencing court, taking account of the timing, nature of the evidence, and the extent to which the plea spared victims ordeal and resources. Similarly, R v. Hudson [2023] EWCA Crim 1803, involving a charge of grievous bodily harm with intent, reiterated that the utility of plea credit diminishes precipitously where pleas are entered late in the process, often appearing tactical rather than demonstrative of genuine remorse. These authorities provide a compelling backdrop against which credit must be tempered in the present case. Furthermore, R v. Martin [2021] EWCA Crim 745 clarified that the fact a defendant may have demonstrated some cooperation post-arrest does not automatically warrant a higher level of mitigation unless that cooperation has materially advanced the interests of justice or victim welfare. Against this legal framework, the court will proceed to consider the facts relevant to Mr H’s offending. He earmarked a garage behind Nando’s on the High Street, close to Cornbrook station and outside CCTV range, to time the explosion for 3pm as football crowds dispersed after the Leeds game. There is extensive digital evidence that was central to the prosecution’s case. Amongst it was content from a blog hosted under the moniker “SteelSeer,” which over the course of two years evolved from apolitical commentary on local walking routes to a repository of ideological rhetoric endorsing violent extremism. Linguistic experts engaged by the Crown identified multiple instances of language echoing that used in training manuals from a proscribed organisation, including coded references and doctrinal invocations. Among the digital files was a scenario in which a drone-delivered bomb would detonate after emergency responders arrived. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. That digital trail also included numerous encrypted archives. These were stored within VeraCrypt containers, their labeling often cryptic or disguised as innocuous filenames such as “BlueJuniper.” Content ranged from explosive synthesis manuals to tactical reconnaissance plans aimed at public infrastructure. Defence counsel elicited testimony questioning whether Mr H had actually accessed these files in full, citing evidence of corrupted segments and metadata suggesting partial downloads. However, as established in R v. Barnaby [2020] EWCA Crim 1989, liability encompasses possession and intent to use, irrespective of full documentary engagement. The defendant was found with notes for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list including No More Greys hair bleach and Tesco brand nail varnish remover. The case file notes that a small quantity of legally prescribed medication for Mr H’s chronic asthma was found in his flat. While mentioned in mitigation, its significance is limited to establishing baseline health status rather than any nexus to risky behaviour or propensity. Additionally, a 2018 parking fine for contravening local traffic regulations was tendered with no bearing on culpability, included only at the insistence of defence as a demonstration of “law-abiding tendencies.” The court does not accord these matters weight in the sentencing exercise. The courts are mindful, of course, that ordinary people lead complex, multifaceted lives; the law does not seek to reduce individuals to their worst acts alone. Nevertheless, it must weigh conduct that endangered the public with appropriate gravity. Digital evidence revealed a delayed post targeting South Manchester Synagogue, released shortly after a message titled Statement Before the Storm. Attention was drawn during submissions to a trip Mr H undertook to Berlin in early 2024, ostensibly for academic research in architectural heritage. However, intelligence records disclosed a detour to a district associated with known extremists. CCTV evidence depicted him meeting an individual later charged in connection with bomb-making materials in a separate jurisdiction. Defence submissions maintained the encounter coincidental, asserting no criminal link. The court, however, noting the encrypted telephone calls exchanged between the parties during the period, finds this explanation improbable. The court acknowledges the substantial administrative burdens and interagency coordination required in this jurisdiction. Disclosure alone encompassed over 850 exhibits, necessitating multiple rounds of redaction and vetting by both the Counter Terrorism Division of the Crown Prosecution Service and the Security Service Disclosure Unit. Efforts to integrate sensitive material were managed with professional rigour, despite recurrent constraints on staffing and funding at the National Technical Assistance Centre. It must be observed that the Legal Aid Agency was markedly slow in responding to defence applications for extended preparatory hours and the instruction of an independent forensic psychologist. The delays imposed additional strain upon an already congested timetable, contributing to the court’s unwillingness to extend credit for procedural efficiency. Such shortcomings in Legal Aid provision are a matter of ongoing concern and have been the subject of recent Parliamentary debate and sector consultations. The defendant drew a map of the Territorial Army Centre in Buxton and marked the precise location of the on-site armoury. He composed detailed notes outlining a plan to launch an attack on the Centre. He had traced the cleaner’s route home and plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury. A forensic financial investigation uncovered multiple cryptocurrency transactions from Mr H’s identified digital wallets. One payment valued at approximately £3,500 transferred funds to an anonymous vendor marketing dual-use chemical kits. This mode of payment is known for its opacity and challenges to traceability. The court notes wider policy concerns regarding the plainer availability of privacy-oriented tools and tumblers that frustrate law enforcement efforts. However, the possession and movement of such currency in the context of a terrorism offence are all the more alarming given the potential for enabling procurement of hazardous materials. The painstaking recovery of CCTV footage depicting Mr H engaging in nocturnal activities near river embankments prompted the allocation of significant analytical time and resources. This underscores the asymmetry between the ephemeral moments of suspect behaviour and the extensive scrutiny necessary to substantiate prosecution cases. The court emphasises that despite the popular mythology of omnipresent surveillance, the reality consists of laborious and painstaking human effort in decoding fragmented and degraded data. A digital file recovered from Mr H’s encrypted archive referenced the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message. Regarding personal circumstances, Mr H is 31 years old. He holds a master’s degree in applied physics and was previously employed at a prestigious engineering consultancy until his abrupt resignation in late 2022. Testimonies from previous employers describe him as “intelligent, meticulous, and reserved,” though his departure followed an internal inquiry concerning unauthorised use of workplace IT systems to access extremist content. Letters tendered on his behalf include one from a charity focused on urban wildlife conservation recognising his voluntary commitment over several years. Another letter from a local book club highlights his attendance and sociable nature in that setting. While community engagement is commendable, as Lord Justice Haddon observed in R v. Kingsley [2023] EWCA Crim 853, it cannot diminish responsibility where serious offences are committed. A note was found for the defendant’s propaganda video which read: The rootless cosmopolitans cannot rule us forever: We will kill all the fucking kikes. Juden Raus! The psychiatric report prepared by Dr Reema Chaudry presents a nuanced assessment. Though diagnosing no major mental illness, Dr Chaudry identified rigid cognitive styles and a tendency toward absolutist ideologies that risk perpetuating extremist beliefs. The report further opines that Mr H represents a substantial risk of serious harm without intensive, structured intervention post-release and that the prospects for de-radicalisation, while not negligible, are contingent on ongoing engagement and monitoring. Suggestions of community-based rehabilitation programmes, including the Desistance and Disengagement Programme, are welcomed but seen as insufficient in isolation. The report stresses the need for layered supervision, including statutory licence conditions and mental health oversight. Mitigation is constrained. Mr H has no previous convictions and has expressed some degree of cooperation since arrest, but this is tempered by his initial denial and prolonged reticence. The late guilty pleas limit discount under established sentencing principles. The aggravating features are significant: the deliberate, methodical preparation, the possession of technical materials with immediate utility for violence, the evident ideological commitment, and the misuse of modern communication platforms. The sentencing objectives of deterrence, public protection, and denunciation all weigh heavily in favour of a custodial sentence reflective of the highest culpability group within the Guidelines. In the light of the above, the court directs that a pre-sentence report be prepared with particular regard to risk of reoffending, suitability for the extended determinate sentence regime, potential for structured psychological interventions, and viability of conditions to restrict access to digital and chemical resources. The Probation Service is asked to consider the inclusion of GPS monitoring and polygraph usage as part of the sentence management plan. These sentencing remarks are issued this day, 17 September 2025, in Court 5 at the Crown Court at Sheffield. They have been transcribed and recorded in accordance with Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules 2020. The formal record of conviction and sentence will be transmitted to the appropriate authorities for registration and dissemination. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BIRMINGHAM R v. Mr H Case No. B2025/34560 Sentencing Remarks – Her Honour Judge L. M. Davenport Filed: 15 September 2025 Mr H stands before this court for sentence on two counts: the first, engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of terrorism contrary to section 5(1)(a) of the Terrorism Act 2006; the second, possession of an article for a purpose connected with the commission of terrorism, contrary to section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000. The relevant conduct spans a period commencing in March 2023 and concluding with the defendant’s arrest in January 2025. From the outset, it is appropriate to acknowledge the diligent work undertaken by Counter Terrorism Policing West Midlands (CTPWM) in this matter. Their efforts were accompanied by input from the National Cybercrime Unit, and involved exhaustive coordination with the National Crime Agency, as well as local law enforcement entities. The arrest of Mr H at 04:43 on 21 January 2025 resulted from an intelligence-led operation culminating in a search warrant executed at his place of residence in Edgbaston. This warrant had been authorised under section 43B of the Terrorism Act 2000. Among the documents found was an explosive guide with a recipe: 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. The prosecution and defence teams have both had to navigate a complex evidentiary landscape. The volume of electronically stored information comprised over 2.4 terabytes of encrypted data, which necessitated a prolonged period of forensic analysis. This process was hampered intermittently by compatibility issues with decryption software routinely used by the National Technical Assistance Centre (NTAC). There were related delays in the service of certain disclosure items, which the court was regularly updated upon. Notably, the Legal Aid Agency’s administrative delays in granting authorisation for expert forensic services added an element of procedural contortion in the early stages of these proceedings. Aside from the principal charges, it is worth noting the wider pressures facing counter-terrorism investigations. Intelligence gathering in this sector frequently intersects with routine policing tasks, including the response to less serious offences. It has been observed that the growing burden of monitoring open-source extremist content online diverts investigative resources from traditional crime control. Conversely, the suppressive effect of multi-agency preventative structures such as Channel and Prevent panels is sometimes compromised by strained capacity. In this vein, the court records that, prior to these charges, the defendant had been subject to a referral under the Prevent programme in 2022. This referral, initiated by an academic tutor concerned by the defendant’s increasingly radical online postings, did not proceed beyond the initial panel meeting, principally due to his refusal to engage with offered interventions. The efficacy of such early-stage Prevent referrals remains a topic of ongoing policy debate, but this court is constrained to focus on the facts as they fall for adjudication here and now. Between arraignment and trial, the case was subject to several adjournments. One such adjournment was occasioned by a request from the defence to consider supplementary material, including two letters of support from community organisations and a personal statement from a family member. At a procedural hearing convened on 17 June 2025, it was determined that this new material would warrant further consideration post-conviction during mitigation. The question of guilty plea is central in sentencing. Mr H steadfastly maintained pleas of not guilty until the opening morning of trial on 11 September 2025, when he entered guilty pleas to both counts. As counsel for the Crown, Ms. Fiona Lambert, rightly observed, the timing of these pleas constrains the discount that the court may reasonably afford. It is well established that credit for a guilty plea reflects not only the plea itself but its timing and the consequent reduction in court time and avoidance of the trauma of a contested hearing. In R v. Spender [2021] EWCA Crim 3024, the Court of Appeal underscored the principle that guilty pleas entered at “the eleventh hour” must be conditioned by the reality that they often come after comprehensive trial preparations. That judgment, emerging from a case concerning multiple counts of fraud and money laundering, emphasised the limited attenuative value of post-preparation pleas, even when genuine remorse is professed. The logic of that ruling is readily transposed to terrorism offences, with due recognition of the exceptional nature of such cases. Other appellate authorities have considered the relationship between timeliness of pleas and sentencing discount. In particular, R v. Haines [2019] EWCA Crim 1287 delineated the importance of early admissions in mitigating the impact on victims and witnesses, as well as preserving valuable judicial resources. Where pleas are deferred until trial, sentencing must reflect this diminished benefit. He earmarked a garage behind Nando’s on the High Street, close to Cornbrook station and outside CCTV range, to time the explosion for 3pm as football crowds dispersed after the Leeds game. The prosecution presented detailed evidence of a blog maintained by Mr H under the pseudonym “Iron Albatross.” Initially a platform for commentary on environmental policy and social justice, the content shifted markedly by early 2024, adopting a tone replete with grievance-laden manifestos calling for violent upheaval. The linguistic pattern matched known propagandist templates employed by proscribed organisations. Mr H drafted a sequence involving a drone-triggered second device to go off after first responders reached the scene. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. Among the exhibits was a cache of encrypted digital manuals discovered on an external hard drive concealed within a false wall panel of the defendant’s bedroom. The materials included schematics for improvised explosive devices and tutorials for chemical synthesis, documented with meticulous care. The defence submitted that some files could have been retained for academic interest, referencing Mr H’s background as a chemistry undergraduate. The court rejects this notion as inconsistent with the broader corpus of evidence and the defendant’s pattern of behaviour. The detection of a small quantity of cannabis resin on the premises was uncovered during the search. While possessing controlled substances is a criminal offence, that fact stands unrelated to the defendant’s terrorism offending and has not proceeded to charge. Similarly, a 2018 fine for driving without insurance referenced in disclosure bundles is recorded but carries no mitigating or aggravating weight in the court's current deliberations. The fact that Mr H had no previous convictions beyond minor traffic infractions distinguishes this case from certain other terrorists previously sentenced by this court. For instance, R v. Munro [2023] EWCA Crim 1509 involved an offender with a lengthy criminal history including aggravated assault and drug trafficking, a background absent here. The defendant's laptop contained a detailed list of components for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list including NewLook hair bleach and SuperDrug brand nail varnish remover. The court examined Mr H’s overseas travel history, highlighting a trip to Berlin in September 2023. The stated purpose was attendance at a conference on political activism; however, intercepts and CCTV footage place Mr H in proximity to individuals later convicted of firearms offences. Defence counsel argued coincidence and noted that the defendant’s holiday photographs supported an innocuous itinerary. The court considers, however, that the totality of evidence undermines this benign interpretation. It is of procedural interest that the case management hearing initially scheduled for early July 2025 was vacated owing to the sudden hospitalisation of the defence solicitor. The attendant late application for an adjournment was reluctantly granted so as to preserve fairness. Such tactical delays inevitably impose strains on court calendars already burdened by the cumulated effects of industrial action affecting court staff. In passing, the court notes its awareness of the pressures facing probation services tasked with supervising individuals subject to multi-agency management. Current resourcing deficits, as outlined in Ministry of Justice publications, exacerbate the challenge of consistent, proactive case handling. The court trusts that the forthcoming pre-sentence report will reflect these contextual realities in framing recommendations. The second post in Mr H’s Buffer queue included a map link to South Manchester Synagogue and appeared timed to follow a threatening message. Further scrutiny revealed that in November 2023 Mr H had purchased components compatible with the assembly of explosive devices, including inert detonators and timer mechanisms. These were procured under false identities online and shipped covertly via parcel services. The Crown refers to this as evidence of sophisticated procurement networks. Concurrent with these activities, Analysis of social media posts documented a steady intensification of apocalyptic rhetoric and the sharing of content glorifying violent martyrdom. Expert linguists linked these patterns with followers on encrypted forums known for extremism dissemination. The court has reviewed a report prepared by Dr Minerva Cullen, a consultant forensic psychiatrist appointed by the defence. Dr Cullen diagnoses Mr H with traits consistent with high-functioning autism spectrum disorder but finds no evidence of psychosis or severe mental illness impairing responsibility. The psychiatric assessment, while detailed, emphasizes the defendant’s capacity for understanding the nature and consequences of his conduct. The treatment of such psychiatric findings in sentencing guidance is nuanced. R v. Munyard [2018] EWCA Crim 1234 affirms that the presence of a neurodevelopmental condition does not automatically mitigate culpability where intelligent, purposeful conduct is demonstrated. This is particularly pertinent in the context of ideologically motivated offending. The defendant drew a map of the Territorial Army Centre in Buxton and identified the cleaner. The operational notes stated that Mr H plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury. A detailed blockchain forensic report identified multiple cryptocurrency transactions tracing from a private wallet controlled by Mr H to an anonymous vendor specialising in dual-use goods. The transactions, aggregated over six months, amounted to a sum exceeding £4,000. The anonymity afforded by mixers and tumblers complicates enforcement, a point noted recently by the House of Commons Home Affairs Committee in its report on financial crime. Such findings underscore the evolving threat paradigm where technology resists conventional police access, necessitating sustained cooperation between law enforcement, financial regulators, and international partners. The enforcement of counter-terrorism legislation must adapt accordingly. The court has also received submissions from the Edgbaston Community Support Network, which has engaged with Mr H intermittently over the last eighteen months. Their correspondence stresses the difficult balance between community integration efforts and the imperative of vigilance in the face of radicalisation risks. A further letter from the Birmingham Probation Trust underscores the staffing shortages currently afflicting the service, with vacancy rates approaching 18 per cent and caseloads exceeding recommended limits. These systemic difficulties, while not excusing individual risk, provide context relevant to the design of post-sentence supervisory conditions. Surveillance video on 4 December 2024 depicted Mr H at a riverside location walking with an unidentified companion. The exercise of analysis required synchronisation of multiple feeds over protracted hours, highlighting the labour-intensive nature of bespoke operational work in counter-terrorism. In a concealed file recovered from Mr H’s encrypted drive, investigators found references to the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message. Addressing the defendant’s personal circumstances, Mr H is a 31-year-old single man, educated to honours degree level in chemical engineering from a Midlands university. Prior to resigning in early 2023—an act precipitated by disciplinary proceedings concerning unauthorised internet use—he had been engaged as a junior technical analyst at an industrial manufacturer. Character references describe him as “introverted but conscientious,” with a tendency to avoid social situations outside close family circles. Despite this, Mr H had been a regular volunteer at a local food bank, an involvement lauded by community workers. Letters from neighbours and former employers speak of punctuality and quiet industriousness. While such factors are humane considerations, it is well established that positive community engagement does not cancel out serious offences. Indeed, the Court of Appeal in R v. Wilkins [2020] EWCA Crim 1570 observed that individuals who demonstrate social acumen may be judged more harshly when they commit crimes of high culpability, given their presumed capacity for moral insight. Professor Jonathan Steele, a forensic psychologist who contributed to the pre-sentence report, notes a marked pattern of cognitive inflexibility and black-and-white thinking in Mr H. The report assesses a high risk of serious harm linked to continued adherence to extremist ideology if left unmitigated, necessitating structured intervention post-release. A note was found for the defendant’s propaganda video which read: The rootless cosmopolitans cannot rule us forever: We will kill all the fucking kikes. Juden Raus! It remains the task of this court to balance the objectives of punishment, deterrence, rehabilitation, and public protection. The offending before the court represents a grave breach of the social contract and a taint that extends beyond the immediate facts to the collective security of the community. Mitigating factors include the absence of prior convictions, academic attainment, and the aforementioned late guilty plea. The plea credit, however, must be tempered given the persistent maintenance of innocence through trial preparation phases. This court will direct the preparation of a comprehensive pre-sentence report. The probation service is instructed to consider the availability and suitability of accredited cognitive behavioural programmes targeting extremist ideology, alongside risk management modalities consistent with Multi-Agency Public Protection Arrangements (MAPPA), Category 3 oversight. The report should also address the feasibility of community licence conditions restricting digital access and mandate ongoing psychiatric support utilising Structured Professional Judgement frameworks. Thanks are due to counsel appearing before this court today: Ms Fiona Lambert for the Crown and Mr Julian Rowe for the defence, both of whom have conducted their cases with professional diligence. The courtroom itself has recently benefited from refurbishment funded through the Ministry of Justice's ongoing capital programme, offering improved facilities for vulnerable witnesses and enhanced hearing accessibility—commendations extend to the court clerks and ushers who maintained order during protracted hearings. Despite the best efforts of all legal actors, the court once again laments the administrative delays attributable to the Legal Aid Agency’s processing time for expert instructions. It is a persistent and regrettable feature of contemporary criminal proceedings that these bureaucratic obstacles impede the efficient progression of justice. In closing, the court reiterates the solemn responsibility borne by institutions engaged in counter-terrorism work. The stakes are uncommonly high, and so too must be the standards applied in adjudication and sentencing. These sentencing remarks are issued this day, 15 September 2025, in Court 5 at the Crown Court at Birmingham. Proceedings have been transcribed in conformity with Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The formal record of conviction and sentence will be forwarded to the relevant agencies for enactment. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BRISTOL R v. Mr H Case No. B2025/28396 Sentencing Remarks – Her Honour Judge A. T. EVERETT Filed: 11 September 2025 Mr H appears before this court for sentence following conviction on two counts: engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of terrorism contrary to section 5(1)(a) of the Terrorism Act 2006, and possession of an article for a purpose connected with the commission of terrorism, contrary to section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000. The offending conduct is found to have spanned the period from July 2023 until his arrest in May 2025. Mr H was apprehended at approximately 04:47 on 7 May 2025 pursuant to warrants executed simultaneously at two addresses in the Ashton Gate area of Bristol by Counter Terrorism Policing South West (CTPSW). The warrants were authorised under section 43B of the Terrorism Act 2000, grounded on comprehensive intercept intelligence derived mainly from encrypted communications traffic on a peer-to-peer network linked to extremist forums known to be monitored by the Security Service. At arrest, officers seized numerous items including laptop computers, smartphones, encrypted USB drives, and digital storage media. Mr H was found with materials setting out how to make a device from 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. The investigation leading to the defendant’s arrest involved a complex collaboration among multiple agencies, including CTPSW, the regional Surveillance Unit, the National Technical Assistance Centre (NTAC), and the North Somerset Digital Forensic Laboratory. Establishing a chronology of events required painstaking decryption efforts and cross-referencing of metadata, often complicated by the employment of virtual private networks, anonymous routing nodes, and temporary burner devices. Of note, the case came to investigative attention when an informant tipped authorities to irregular online activity associated with an account linked to Mr H. Though the informant’s information was initially partial and uncorroborated, subsequent technical leads provided the evidential foundation for the warrants executed in May. The court is conscious that distributed investigations of this kind impose substantial demands on specialist personnel, many of whom operate under strict obligations of confidentiality and in environments where technological advances frequently outpace legislative reform. The constraints under which these officers and analysts labour merit formal recognition. It is regrettable to mention that this case was subject to a delay caused by industrial action within the Legal Aid Agency, specifically affecting the allocation of solicitors with the necessary security clearance to conduct preparation. Such administrative obstacles prolonged the pre-trial period by a further six weeks beyond the statutory guideline timeframe. While the court expresses no doubt as to the professional integrity or capacity of those involved, it must nonetheless register concern about the impact of resource shortfalls on the expediency of justice in matters of this gravity. Correspondence submitted from the West Bristol Muslim Community Trust draws attention to the ongoing tensions experienced by minority communities in the wake of heightened enforcement activity. The Trust cautions against sentencing approaches that might inadvertently fuel alienation or foster a narrative of community victimisation. While the court appreciates these submissions, the obligation remains clear: to protect public safety whilst upholding the rule of law, balancing community cohesion with the imperative to deter terrorism. A plea and trial preparation hearing was listed for 18 August 2025. Mr H initially entered a not guilty plea but changed course on 9 September 2025, tendering guilty pleas on both counts shortly before the commencement of a four-day trial. Whilst the Court welcomes his acceptance of responsibility, the timing of that plea—after both side’s disclosure and preparation had been comprehensively completed—necessarily tempers the full credit that might otherwise be available. A familiar refrain among judiciary, prosecutors, and defence practitioners relates to the tendency of some defendants in terrorism cases to delay their guilty pleas until the evidentiary case becomes incontrovertible. That said, the court is mindful of the pressures, both personal and legal, under which such decisions are made. It will apply established principles in considering credit for plea, balancing the utility of the plea with the cost to the administration of justice and the interests of witnesses. The legal principles surrounding credit for guilty pleas were significantly developed in R v. Bertram [2023] EWCA Crim 1342, wherein the Court of Appeal reinforced that the timing of the plea is critical to the allowance of sentence reduction and that credit is conditioned on a genuine acceptance of culpability rather than tactical considerations. In Bertram, the defendant delayed his plea until the day the jury was sworn, following exhaustive disclosure and witness preparation. Consequently, the appeal court confirmed that credit must be limited accordingly, despite the plea occurring pre-trial. Historical sentencing commentary reminds us of a parallel in R v. Olding [2018] EWCA Crim 457, an importation case involving Class A drugs in which a not guilty plea was maintained until just before the opening of the defence case. The Court of Appeal upheld a modest reduction in sentencing credit, highlighting that procedural economies gained by an earlier plea were not realised. Nonetheless, such credit is never mechanically disallowed; judicial discretion remains paramount. The Court also draws attention to the case of R v. Lynch [2022] EWCA Crim 1835, concerning a complex conspiracy to commit aggravated burglary, where the defendant’s late plea was contrasted with his early engagement with probation services. The judgment permits weight to be given to mitigating factors alongside the timing of plea, reflecting an individualized approach to sentencing credit. Mr H’s notes described placing an explosive in a garage with no CCTV behind Nando’s, targeting 3pm near Cornbrook station to hit the passing crowd from the Leeds match. Expert linguistic analysis was pivotal in this matter. The Crown adduced expert testimony establishing that certain posts and communications authored by Mr H on public and semi-public social media platforms contained language and coded phrases bearing striking similarities to known extremist communiqués, particularly those linked to proscribed groups under the Terrorism Act. The precise understanding of these coded references requires expertise not commonly accessible outside dedicated counter-terrorism units. Defence counsel challenged these assertions vigorously but was ultimately unable to convince the jury of an innocent interpretation. This court acknowledges the difficulties in interpreting digital speech and the inherent risk of overreach or mischaracterisation. Nonetheless, where pattern, context, and corroborative evidence converge, the inference of extremist intent becomes unavoidable. Another intricate aspect concerned the defendant’s use of encrypted containers for storing digital material. Officers recovered a VeraCrypt volume named “Blueprints,” which contained multiple files including text, technical manuals, and videos demonstrating explosive device manufacture. The encrypted nature of the container necessitated specialist decryption attempts extending over ten months, causing further investigative delay. A document recovered from Mr H’s laptop detailed a secondary attack by drone aimed at medics and police. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. Analysis of recovered chat logs showed participation in password-protected forums where members exchanged advice on improvised explosive devices, activation methods, and tactical deployment. The defendant’s messages reflected not only technical knowledge but ideological zeal, with exhortations to fellow members to remain steadfast and resolute in pursuit of their aims. For completeness, the court notes that a number of discarded devices seized during the investigation bore no links to the defendant after forensic examination, illustrating the degree of caution exercised before attributing ownership or authorship. It was suggested in mitigation that some of the footage contained within encrypted devices could also be interpreted as part of a personal hobby related to forensic science and pyrotechnics — interests which defendant had lamented in correspondence with his solicitors as “a youthful fascination.” The court, however, rejects this narrative in light of the broader evidential matrix. Mere interest, unconnected to illicit intent or conduct, would not justify the prolonged and encrypted manner of storage, nor the networking with known extremists. The Crown highlighted that Mr H’s digital footprint revealed multiple VPNs masking IP addresses, frequent use of Tor browser nodes, and systematic efforts to destroy metadata on files. Such operational security measures strengthen the prosecution’s case regarding intent and sophistication. The defendant's encryped hard disk was ultimately found to be storing instructions for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list with Summer Sun hair bleach and Bell's brand nail varnish remover. It is the Crown’s uncontroverted position that the defendant possessed, and attempted to acquire, components expressly for the construction of explosive devices, as well as detailed instructions for assembly and deployment. These components were concealed in concealed compartments within his vehicle and at his primary residence. Surveillance footage corroborates movements consistent with reconnaissance activity in areas with dense civilian presence. By way of contrast—and unrelated to the defendant—one co-defendant in earlier co-pending proceedings is recorded as having engaged in offences involving criminal damage to a local council building, including the painting of slogans on signage. These offences, although contemporaneous, bear no connection to Mr H. Similarly, it is noted for completeness that a third party associated only tangentially with the defendant has previous convictions for benefit fraud dating from 2019, which are not relevant here. This court deprecates the conflation of such background information in assessing the culpability or risk posed by Mr H himself. The court reminds all involved that sentencing must be based solely on the attributable conduct and characteristics of the accused before it. The forensic profile prepared by the North Bristol Psychiatric Assessment Unit provides a detailed account of the defendant’s mental state. Dr Susan Harkness, consultant forensic psychiatrist, conducted a comprehensive assessment over three sessions, which included clinical interview, psychometric testing, and collateral consultation with family members. Officers found a Buffer-scheduled tweet containing a link to South Manchester Synagogue followed by a countdown-themed message. Dr Harkness confirms that Mr H exhibits clusters of cognitive rigidity and “black-and-white” thinking patterns, typical of those with entrenched ideological commitments. However, he meets neither the diagnostic threshold for a formal personality disorder nor any major mental illness. His understanding of the charges was clear, and he demonstrated insight into the consequences of his actions albeit limited appreciation of their broader societal impact. The report underscores the risk of recidivism in the absence of significantly enhanced management, noting a substantial likelihood of re-engagement with extremist ideology upon release without stringent supervision. Defence counsel submits that engagement with the Desistance and Disengagement Programme (DDP) could significantly alter this prognosis, although the report candidly acknowledges the variable success rate of such interventions. Acknowledging the ongoing operational pressures faced by community mental health services, this report exemplifies the difficult balance clinicians must strike between risk management, therapeutic ambition, and resource limitation. Wait times for urgent forensic psychiatric assessments in the region currently approach 14 weeks, placing considerable strain on both clinical teams and justice timetables. It is relevant that Mr H has no previous criminal convictions, a factor customarily accorded weight in mitigation, though this court must remind itself that the seriousness and nature of terrorism offences often diminish the impact of any such “clean record.” Numerous cases demonstrate that first-time offenders may nonetheless pose grave risks necessitating significant custodial sentences. The defendant focused on the Territorial Army Centre in Buxton, where he stalked the cleaner. An intercepted file titled Stage 2 detailed how Mr H plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury. Financial records analysed as part of the Crown’s case reveal a series of cryptocurrency payments traced to darknet marketplaces associated with prohibited substances and dual-use technologies. Notably, transfers totalling approximately £3,400 were made through decentralized mixers designed to obfuscate origins and destinations of funds, further evidencing the defendant’s sophistication and operational security awareness. This court considers it important to note the increasing challenge posed by the intersection of emergent financial technology and criminal enterprise. The transparent distribution ledger underpinning blockchain systems was once presumed to provide a degree of auditability; however, technological innovation in anonymisation protocols now enables near-total concealment. Law enforcement responses have been correspondingly hampered by jurisdictional complexity, stretched analytical resources, and the rapid dissemination of new obfuscation techniques. The courts remain vigilant in requiring evidential rigour in these fast-moving aspects of the investigation. By way of contrast, the court specifically remarks that a co-defendant in an unrelated affray case held a folding knife at a public market on an occasion three years prior, a fact borne out in a police incident report. That matter, while serious, is unrelated to Mr H’s conduct and is mentioned solely to caution against unfair conflation. A document stored in a hidden container was found to contain material from the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message. Turning to Mr H’s personal circumstances, he is 31 years old and holds a Master’s degree in computer engineering. Until late 2023, he was employed as a network security consultant with a reputable firm in central Bristol. Sudden departure from this role followed disciplinary proceedings concerning breaches of Internet usage policy related to access of extremist websites. Character references submitted include letters from a regional cycling club and the local library trust, organisations for which Mr H offered volunteer services. While laudable as indicators of civic involvement, these do not diminish the gravity of his offending or the risk delineated on the evidence. Counsel for the defence has emphasised the defendant’s remoteness and social withdrawal post-employment, submitting that chronic isolation contributed to his vulnerability to ideological radicalisation. This submission accords with psychiatric observations of social disengagement as a salient factor in extremism. The court must, however, guard against reductionist explanations which risk portraying the defendant primarily as a victim rather than an agent of serious criminality. The rule of law serves to protect society by holding individuals accountable when they cross the threshold into violent extremism, irrespective of personal history. Investigators recovered a printed script for an extremist video which contained the phrase: We will kill all the fucking kikes. Jews out! Professor Eleanor Wren, a consultant forensic psychologist with expertise in radicalisation, assessed Mr H and concluded that he poses a significant risk of serious harm, sustaining a high chance of re-offending absent robust interventions. The psychological profile indicates entrenched cognitive distortions and limited receptivity to disengagement initiatives without intensive therapeutic input and structured supervision. Defence proposals for community-based programming were acknowledged, but the report advises a cautious approach pending demonstration of sustained engagement and risk reduction. Such findings underscore the necessity of custodial sentencing accompanied by comprehensive post-release arrangements, including possibly GPS monitoring, restricted electronic device access, and ongoing specialist psychological support. The court is conscious of the broader societal impact of terrorism and the imperative to send clear deterrent messages without resorting to unnecessary harshness. Sentencing guidelines issued by the Sentencing Council in 2023 identify key factors informing culpability and harm in terrorism cases, including coordination, sophistication, and foreseen consequences. This case falls into the higher culpability bracket given the preparatory acts, acquisition of components, and attempts to conceal activity from law enforcement. The timing and scale of the conduct evince a serious intent to facilitate indiscriminate harm, with attendant aggravating considerations. Mitigation remains limited to the absence of previous convictions, academic attainment, and late plea. The court, mindful of the need to maintain proportionality, will direct the preparation of a pre-sentence report addressed to these dimensions. This will include consideration of possible extended determinate custodial sentences under section 226A of the Criminal Justice Act 2003, possible eligibility for structured intervention schemes, and the capacity for appropriate placement within custodial facilities equipped to manage ideological risk. The involvement of the Multi-Agency Public Protection Arrangements (MAPPA) panel is anticipated, with a view to formulating a rigorous release plan. The case management for this matter has been characterised by some procedural challenges, notably the late arrival of an interpreter authorised for an ancillary witness, which necessitated a brief adjournment during the pre-trial process. While such occurrences are not unusual in cases involving diverse languages and translational complexities, the court records the effect on scheduling and encourages early notification in future cases. It is also noted that the court’s technology infrastructure has recently been upgraded, allowing for improved simultaneous digital evidence presentation, though occasional glitches persist—a reminder that the justice system operates within evolving technological contexts. To those on the prosecuting team, including Ms V. Fisher QC, counsel for the Crown, and to Mr J. Langston, instructed on behalf of the defendant, the court expresses its gratitude for professional conduct and submissions provided throughout the pre-trial period and during these sentencing proceedings. Lastly, the court acknowledges the dedicated work of the probation service and the Eastville Prevent Hub, both of whom have submitted reports and representations concerning the defendant’s progress during his remand period. Their combined efforts, despite significant staffing shortages and increased caseloads, evidence the significance of multi-disciplinary approaches to managing complex risk profiles. The court reserves final sentence for a forthcoming hearing scheduled on 3 November 2025. This interval allows for receipt and consideration of a full pre-sentence report and any further submissions by relevant statutory bodies or the defence. The court is mindful of its duty to fashion a sentence reflective of the offending and tailored to the opportunities and constraints of rehabilitation and public safety. These sentencing remarks are delivered this day, 11 September 2025, in Court 5 at the Crown Court at Bristol. A formal transcript has been recorded pursuant to Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The defendant is advised of his right to appeal within 28 days of sentence under the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. No reporting restrictions under section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933 apply. Costs are reserved. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BRISTOL R v. Mr H Case No. B2025/19834 Sentencing Remarks – Her Honour Judge M. J. Cartwright Filed: 15 September 2025 Mr H stands before this court today to be sentenced on charges brought pursuant to section 5(1)(a) of the Terrorism Act 2006 for engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of terrorism, and one count of possession of an article for a purpose connected with the commission of terrorism under section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000. These proceedings concern activities spanning from early 2023 through to his arrest in April of this year. The court is obliged to consider this matter with all the seriousness it demands, bearing in mind the wider societal context and the obligations imposed by statute and case law. The defendant was arrested on 4 April 2025 following a carefully orchestrated operation by the South West Counter Terrorism Unit (SWCTU). The execution of a warrant at his address in Fishponds was supported by intelligence derived through complex inter-agency surveillance, including the analysis of encrypted communications flagged by the National Cyber Security Centre. At the time of his apprehension, officers recovered several computing devices, mobile telephones, and materials suggestive of intent to cause serious harm. The multiplicity of agencies involved underscores the scale of operational co-ordination necessitated by cases of this nature. Mr H was found with materials setting out how to make a device from 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. The investigative phase preceding the arrest was protracted, in part due to the challenges posed by the defendant’s use of advanced obfuscation technologies, including virtual private networks and peer-to-peer encrypted messaging applications. The courts are, by now, familiar with the persistent difficulties these tools pose in the context of lawful interception and evidence gathering. Critically, the prosecution team has provided detailed disclosure of the efforts required to decrypt and analyse voluminous digital extracts. These included forensic backups, hash-value analyses, and triangulation of IP addresses. Whilst this case proceeded through the usual stages, there have been procedural delays attributable to a national strike among court clerks which impacted listing availability in the early summer period. These factors, while regrettable, must be seen in light of systemic pressures that affect judicial administration across the country. Of note too is the ongoing strain upon Legal Aid funding, which—though unrelated to the merits of this case—has hindered initial defence preparations, thus elongating pre-trial processes. It is appropriate here to mention certain authorities which inform sentencing practice, albeit their immediate factual matrix differs from the present matter but which illuminate general principles. In R v. Pearce [2018] EWCA Crim 456, the Court of Appeal underscored the importance of proportionality when imposing sentences for preparatory terrorist offences, reiterating that the defendant’s intent and the sophistication of their planning are critical considerations. Conversely, cases such as R v. Bennett [2021] EWCA Crim 1231 warn against leniency where the defendant demonstrates high levels of commitment combined with evident capacity to cause mass casualties. Turning towards the personal circumstances of the defendant, reports indicate Mr H is 31 years of age, having been educated to a degree-level standard and previously employed within IT support roles in the private sector. Letters submitted from former employers commend his technical aptitude and punctuality, though stop short of endorsing his character in matters unrelated to employment. The defendant’s family has provided correspondence detailing a history of social isolation and reluctance to forge sustained interpersonal relationships. In respect of professional engagement, the court wishes to record its gratitude to the staff at the Bristol Prevent Coordination Unit. Their submissions detail a sustained, though ultimately inconclusive, attempt to engage the defendant in early intervention frameworks dating back to mid-2022. These efforts included motivational interviewing, cognitive behavioural workshops, and participation in community resettlement initiatives. The restrained tone of their reports is notable: they acknowledge the limits of influence when faced with ideological entrenchment, a caution echoed by forensic psychologists in previous cases. Mr H selected a garage behind Nando's on the High Street, near Cornbrook station, with no cameras, to place a bomb set for 3pm as Leeds fans returned from the match, aiming to maximise casualties. That said, it is worth pausing to reflect on the nature of a social phenomenon which continues to challenge law enforcement and the judiciary alike: the proliferation of “self-radicalised” actors operating independently in the shadowy recesses of the internet. The defendant’s utilisation of ephemeral messaging platforms and anonymous social media profiles illustrates an increasingly decentralised threat landscape, complicating traditional counter-terrorism strategies. While the state has made legislative and operational advances, the rapid pace of technological development often outstrips institutional capacities. A document recovered from Mr H’s laptop detailed a secondary attack by drone aimed at medics and police. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. Forensic examination revealed a hidden encrypted volume on a seized solid-state drive, containing documents that bear hallmarks of improvised explosive device (IED) assembly guides, alongside what was described by experts as “manifestos articulating a grievance narrative” aligned with proscribed organisations. Defence counsel has submitted that certain materials may have been accessed out of morbid curiosity and not with operative intent. The court examines this contention with scepticism, mindful of jurisprudence such as R v. Al-Mutairi [2019] UKSC 14, which cautions against over-literal interpretation of possession absent contextual analysis. The defendant was found with notes for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list including No More Greys hair bleach and Tesco brand nail varnish remover. The court was also made aware of ancillary findings during the search of Mr H’s accommodation, among which were a small quantity of herbal cannabis and a few personal items; their relevance to counts before the court is minimal and no further action arises from those discoveries. These items neither detract from nor enhance the seriousness of the offences charged, but are recorded for completeness. The procedural history of the case includes a contested application under section 19 of the Terrorism Act 1998 for exclusion of certain sensitive hearings from public view on grounds of national security. After considered argument, the application was partially granted in relation to specific digital exhibit descriptions but otherwise refused. The court notes the balance struck between open justice and protective measures must always be carefully maintained. It is pertinent to mention that unlike some terrorism matters where trial may be consolidated with co-defendants, Mr H’s case proceeded singly. Co-defendants previously arrested in association with a related matter remain on bail pending further investigation. The Court takes no view on their charges or conduct, which differ significantly and are subject to separate and confidential proceedings. The complexity of the case necessitated detailed multi-agency liaison, including the Probation Service, Mental Health Trusts, and counter-terrorism policing units. The combined efforts are illustrative of the contemporary model of Multi-Agency Public Protection Arrangements (MAPPA) which, while commendable in principle, continues to grapple with inconsistent resource allocation and high caseloads nationally. The second post in Mr H’s Buffer queue included a map link to South Manchester Synagogue and appeared timed to follow a threatening message. In the defence's mitigation, it has been submitted that Mr H undertook an overseas trip to Geneva in late 2023 under the guise of academic conference attendance. Flight records, hotel bookings, and passport stamps confirm presence in the city, but investigation uncovered unpublicised visits to local sites associated with political activism of concern to the intelligence community. Defence counsel urges caution in construing these movements as more than innocuous travel, a submission that the Crown disputes emphatically. Amidst broader discourse on public safety, it cannot be ignored how public confidence in the justice system is eroded by perceptions of leniency in cases involving radicalised individuals. The court is mindful that sentences must serve not only deterrence and denunciation but also affirm the rule of law in the eyes of the citizenry. Mr H recorded a step-by-step plan to infiltrate the Buxton Territorial Army Centre. He identified the cleaner and plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury. Financial investigations conducted in parallel by specialist cyber units indicated Mr H engaged in cryptocurrency exchanges amounting to several thousands of pounds, with trace transactions directed towards virtual wallets associated with darknet marketplaces known for arms trafficking. The Crown submits that this evidences material support to terrorist activities. The defence calls for circumspection, citing Mr H’s professed naivety about such transactions and the complexity of blockchain networks. In contemporaneous analysis of undercover recordings, considerable time was expended by investigators to validate identity and intent. It is important to note that the legal thresholds for intercept authorisations remain appropriately rigorous, ensuring compliance with Article 8 of the European Convention on Human Rights concerning privacy and family life. Among non-offence related observations, it was remarked in the pre-sentence psychiatric report, prepared by Dr Elena Merrick of the Avon and Somerset Forensic Psychiatry Service, that Mr H exhibits traits consistent with high-functioning autism spectrum disorder alongside obsessive-compulsive tendencies. Whilst these diagnoses do not mitigate culpability, they necessitate awareness in designing risk management strategies. A digital file recovered from Mr H’s encrypted archive referenced the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message. The defendant’s educational and occupational history includes a commendably steady record until a marked deterioration in social engagement was noted in late 2022; sudden resignation from employment following an internal investigation regarding unauthorised access to secure company servers predated the intensification of extremist activities. Letters from former colleagues underscore his technical skills albeit lament a perceived withdrawal from team participation. It bears mentioning that Mr H has provided a written statement of apology to the court, albeit unsigned, expressing regret for the consequences of his actions on “families and communities,” though counsel confirm it remains equivocal on ideological disengagement. Interestingly, local housing authorities report that during the remand period, his flat experienced noise complaints attributable to neighbours unrelated to the defendant, arising from an ongoing dispute over communal heating provisions. This detail, while peripheral, exemplifies the kinds of complex social milieus in which such cases arise. Victim liaison officers have described the demeanour of impacted parties as measured but deeply affected, and note that support efforts continue through commissioned services of Victim Support South West. Though not direct victims in the conventional sense, the potential reach of the defendant’s plotting has inflicted psychological harm nonetheless. Among the defendant’s handwritten notes for a speech was the phrase: We will kill all the fucking kikes. End the rule of the bankers. Dr Merrick’s psychiatric opinion, now before the court, rates Mr H as presenting a high risk of serious harm, particularly evidencing the likelihood of future engagement with extremist ideologies unless subject to intensive multi-modal intervention. The report strongly advocates for custody with a view to specialist deradicalisation programming combined with restricted access to digital technologies under licence conditions. The court is mindful that while the Sentencing Council’s 2023 Terrorism Guidelines provide an essential framework for assessing culpability and risk, the necessity remains to tailor sentence and subsequent management plans to the individual features of each case. Public safety must remain paramount. The defendant’s prior lack of convictions and some cooperation from the outset are acknowledged, though tempered by the gravity of the offences and the belated timing of his guilty pleas. The procedural posture of this matter concludes with this sentencing hearing, which benefited from the able representation of Mr Andrew Dilworth on behalf of the defence, whose professional diligence has been noted. The prosecution was represented by Ms Jeanette Fields of the Crown Prosecution Service Counter Terrorism Division. Before sentence is pronounced, the court directs the preparation of a comprehensive pre-sentence report addressing appropriate custodial regimes, the feasibility of extended sentences with licence conditions, and the utility of GPS monitoring and polygraph testing in risk mitigation. Consideration should also be given to the availability and resourcing of approved premises capable of supporting those convicted of terrorism offences upon release, an issue of particular concern given persistent nationwide shortages. These sentencing remarks are delivered this 15th day of September 2025, in Court 12 at the Crown Court at Bristol. The proceedings have been transcribed in accordance with the Criminal Procedure Rules Part 5. The defendant is informed of his right to appeal conviction and sentence under section 28 of the Criminal Appeal Act 1968 within twenty-eight days of today’s date. No reporting restrictions pursuant to the Contempt of Court Act 1981 are engaged. Costs remain reserved pending the final sentencing determination. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT NORWICH R v. Mr H Case No. N2025/27643 Sentencing Remarks – Her Honour Judge L. F. CURTIS Filed: 17 September 2025 Mr H appears before this court for sentence on charges under sections 5(1)(a) of the Terrorism Act 2006, namely engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of terrorism, and possession of an article for a purpose connected with the commission of terrorism pursuant to section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000. The Crown alleges that the defendant’s activities took place over an extended period from September 2022 until his arrest in late January 2025. The initial remand hearing took place on 2 February 2025, at which the defendant was refused bail on the grounds of risk to the public and interference with witnesses. Subsequent hearings were delayed by challenges pertaining to Legal Aid funding authorisations, most notably the grant for expert psychiatric evaluation, which the court understands caused protracted administrative delays in commissioning independent assessment. These delays, while regrettable, did not compromise the thorough disclosure process or the preparation of the defence. At the plea and trial preparation hearing held on 15 June 2025, Mr H maintained a not guilty plea. Following the conclusion of the trial on 22 August 2025, the jury returned verdicts of guilty on both counts. The defendant’s initial refusal to accept responsibility delayed proceedings and added to the distress experienced by any victims or witnesses involved. It is well understood that the courts must balance the principle of open justice with the imperative of protecting public safety and victors’ interests. The Crown has advanced significant evidence, much of it electronically obtained and subject to complex forensic examination, the detail of which is preserved within the case exhibit schedule. The difficulty posed by the volume and nature of material serves as a reminder of the extraordinary technical challenges facing investigative authorities in the modern era. Those challenges include the containment of encrypted communications, voluminous data processing, and ensuring procedural propriety within the constraints of existing legislation. Police found explosive construction notes in Mr H’s possession with the annotation: 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. Beyond the particulars of this case, this court is mindful of the historical trajectory of terrorism legislation in the United Kingdom. The Terrorism Act 2006, as enacted following protracted parliamentary debate in the mid-2000s, introduced new offences designed to address evolving threats including preparatory conduct. It amended earlier statutes, notably supplementing the Terrorism Act 2000 provisions, and sought to provide law enforcement with clarified statutory tools to intervene before catastrophic acts could be carried out, balancing civil liberties with national security interests. There is jurisdictional authority from R v. Scottish Firearms Trust [2011] EWCA Crim 897, which set out parameters for defining preparatory acts by reference to intention, capability, and proximity to commission. This judgment, while focused on firearms legislation, nevertheless informs the interpretive framework for sections 5 and 57. The approach endorsed is one of careful fact-sensitive analysis to prevent premature criminalisation, yet allowing robust intervention where the evidence so warrants. The court further remarks upon the judicial evolution of better case management approaches in terrorism cases, following the Criminal Practice Directions 2015 and subsequent refinements. These procedures are intended to ensure proactive listing and timely exchanges of expert reports, vulnerable witness protocols, and the facilitation of necessary closed-material procedures. The degree of procedural complexity inherent in this case is illustrative, with multiple agencies involved including Counter Terrorism Policing East (CTP-East), the National Cyber Crime Unit, and the East Anglia Forensic Science Hub. Additionally, observations might be made concerning the overburdening of forensic digital analysis units nationwide. The National Technical Assistance Centre has openly acknowledged delays reaching six months for device triage, with backlogs compounded by both the volume of devices seized and the growing technical sophistication of encryption and anti-forensic measures. This court applauds the steadfast efforts of dedicated specialists who provide critical evidence despite these systemic pressures. The defence, led by Mr Daniel Reeves of counsel, has submitted comprehensive mitigation papers, including character references from Mr H's collegiate rowing club and letters from the Norwich City Community Hub, in which he volunteered prior to 2023. These attest to his previous engagement in local charitable activities but must be cautiously balanced against the seriousness of the offences before the court. Of note is that Mr H has no previous convictions or formal cautions, a fact that counsel rightly relies upon when arguing for mitigation. Nevertheless, the sophistication of the preparations alleged gives rise to serious concern. The Sentencing Council Terrorism Guidelines 2023 categorise culpability mostly by the degree of planning and the gravity of intended harm, accompanied by an assessment of offender intent and risk of future offending. A garage located behind Nando's on the High Street, with no surveillance, was marked by Mr H for device placement, aiming for maximum casualties at 3pm when fans left Cornbrook after the Leeds fixture. Evidence adduced included detailed analysis of online platforms used by the defendant, under several pseudonymous accounts, which evolved from postings on general political forums to the sharing of extensively redacted manuals concerning explosive device construction. Linguistic evidence presented by expert witnesses demonstrated patterns consistent with radicalisation trajectories identified in counter-terrorism psychology literature. We turn now to the question of related case law on sentencing credit for plea. It is regrettably commonplace in terrorism prosecutions for defendants either to maintain not guilty pleas until trial, or for late change of plea following overwhelming evidence. This strategy, while lawful and often tactically rational, must not be incentivised by undue sentence reductions. The file recovered from Mr H’s device described a drone detonation aimed at emergency services following the initial blast. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. As set out above, such late pleas are known to this court to strain the patience of victims and impact public confidence in the justice system. The judgment of R v. Shahzad [2022] EWCA Crim 1342 is instructive: where a plea is entered only late in the proceedings, discount must be proportionate and carefully considered, often no greater than 10 to 15 percent. The evidence included retrieval of encrypted archives stored on a wiped external hard drive, cleverly hidden within layers of plausible digital obfuscation, including file-naming conventions designed to mislead casual inspectors. The expertise of forensic cyberanalytic teams was pivotal in untangling the structure and delineating the scope of enumerated materials relevant to the offences. The defence sought to argue the possibility of inadvertent possession owing to shared accommodation but failed to satisfy the court that such an excuse was credible in light of the technical complexity of the devices and the focused use patterns identified. The defendant was found with notes for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list including No More Greys hair bleach and Tesco brand nail varnish remover. It bears emphasizing that possession of similar digital content is not per se unlawful. Indeed, the court recalls the delicate balancing exercise mandated in R v. Fletcher [2017] EWCA Crim 453, where possession was innocent until evidence supported a connection to terrorist purpose. The current case, however, overlays a network of circumstances pointing to a deliberate intention to further extremist objectives. The presence among the items of materials relating to chemical compounds and diagrams of incendiary devices, alongside correspondence with individuals linked to proscribed entities, marks this case as exceeding typical passive possession or curiosity. While the case references possession of relatively low quantities of cannabis found in shared premises during search, this factor is not causative or aggravating in respect of the principal terrorism offences. Such family details, while recorded, have no nexus with the offences or risk posed by the defendant personally. The court appreciates the voluntary sector’s efforts, including those of the East Anglia Deradicalisation Project, which offered community mentorship and cognitive behavioural therapy interventions. Engagement, however, was intermittent and largely resisted. The court is keenly aware of tensions between community cohesion and robust sentencing. The Norwich Multifaith Council submitted observations on behalf of local Muslim and Christian communities, warning against inadvertent stigmatization. Sentencing must be consistent with the principle of proportionality, but also demonstrate unequivocal denunciation of offences threatening national security and public order.
