input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BRISTOL R v. Mr H Case No. B2025/34715 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge E. R. KENDRICK Filed: 3 September 2025 Mr Mr H appears before this court for sentence on charges of engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of terrorism, contrary to section 5(1)(a) of the Terrorism Act 2006, and possession of an article for a purpose connected with the commission of terrorism, contrary to section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000. The timeframe relevant to the offences alleged and proven encompasses a period beginning in September 2023 and continuing until his arrest on 10 April 2025. The procedural history in this matter demands acknowledgment. The defendant first appeared at Bristol Magistrates’ Court on 13 April 2025, and was remanded into custody. An initial hearing at the Crown Court was held on 24 May 2025, primarily to address legal aid issues and to fix the date for a plea and trial preparation hearing. Subsequent adjournments have been occasioned by defence requests for additional disclosure and further expert evaluation. These delays, whilst regrettably extending the overall timespan of proceedings, have been managed within the framework established by the Criminal Procedure Rules and necessary considerations of fairness. In terms of representation, the defendant has throughout been legally aided and represented by Mr Oliver Standish, instructed by the Legal Aid Agency under a certificate granted after some administrative delay. This court notes with concern the difficulties encountered by Mr Standish in obtaining timely authority for additional expert reports, exacerbated by a backlog within the Legal Aid system affecting specialist psychiatric assessments in cases of this nature. Such systemic insufficiencies risk undermining the ability of defendants to receive a properly informed defence and serve as a reminder of the pressing need for adequate resourcing in this area. The issues of public safety and counter-terrorism law naturally engage considerable political and societal sensitivities, and no proceedings of this nature can be divorced from the contemporary context of evolving threats and responses. The law as it stands is codified at length in the Terrorism Acts of 2000 and 2006, supplemented by statutory instruments and a sequence of relevant case law that this court has considered exhaustively in preparation for sentencing. At a jurisprudential level, the courts have repeatedly emphasised, notably in R v. Gul [2013] UKSC 64 and R v. Kahar [2016] EWCA Crim 568, that the objectives of deterrence and public protection are paramount in terrorism-related offences, and that sentences must reflect the inherent gravity of offences involving preparation for acts of indiscriminate violence or mass harm. The case has progressed through various procedural landmarks, including a plea and trial preparation hearing held on 19 August 2025. It is relevant to note that the defendant entered a not guilty plea at that stage; however, following jury selection and final preparations for trial, the defendant changed that plea to guilty on the morning of trial on 30 August 2025. While it is not uncommon for such late pleas to occur in complex cases, the court notes that the well-established principle, emphasized in authorities such as R v. Collingridge [2022] EWCA Crim 1873, remains applicable here: late pleas, unless justified by compelling mitigating circumstances, attract a more limited reduction in sentence, recognising they do not provide the full procedural or evidentiary economy expected of earlier admissions. It is an unfortunate but routine feature of contemporary criminal litigation that accusations of terrorism engender a complex matrix of multi-agency involvement. This case has seen engagement from Counter Terrorism Policing South West (CTPSW), the National Cyber Crime Unit, the Security Service, forensic computing specialists, and local law enforcement. Correspondence from the South Bristol Prevent Partnership, submitted in advance of sentencing, details the history of referrals and voluntary intervention attempts prior to arrest. The court expresses its appreciation for the often challenging and thankless work undertaken by those tasked with early intervention in cases of suspected radicalisation. The case also highlights the growing administrative burden of Multi-Agency Public Protection Arrangements (MAPPA), under Category 3 supervision in cases of terrorism-related offending. This burden is felt acutely within probation services which, as Counsel for the defence correctly observed, operate under significant pressure due to understaffing and rising caseloads. A report from the probation service submitted for this sentencing notes that the MAPPA panel overseeing Mr H’s case has convened multiple times, addressing complex issues relating to accommodation, electronic monitoring, and ongoing psychological risk assessment. Such inter-agency collaboration, whilst commendable, is resource-intensive and reflects wider systemic challenges faced by public protection agencies. The defendant’s personal circumstances have been thoroughly considered and documented in reports tendered by Dr Clara Evers, consultant forensic psychiatrist, and Professor Mahir Qureshi, forensic psychologist. Dr Evers’s report, dated 25 August 2025, describes the defendant as having an elevated degree of cognitive rigidity and reports a diagnosis of adjustment disorder, though no major mental illness was identified. Professor Qureshi emphasizes the defendant’s entrenched ideological commitment and high risk of continued extremist activity absent intensive intervention. Both expert reports recommend structured involvement with disengagement programmes. The calibration of rehabilitative prospects against public safety concerns forms a core component of the sentencing calculus. This court is conscious that, notwithstanding the utmost rigour applied to such assessments, no intervention offers guarantees. Experience shows that de-radicalisation efforts, such as the Desistance and Disengagement Programme (DDP), while valuable, suffer from attrition and variable efficacy. Such facts necessitate a sentence that balances the possibility of reform alongside a robust custodial element to protect the public and deter others. It is also appropriate to recognise correspondences laid before the court from organisations such as the Bristol City Community Trust and the South West Volunteer Outreach Association, which have both attempted outreach with Mr H. Their letters commend his intermittent engagement but candidly acknowledge the challenges inherent in cases characterised by ideological extremism. These communications add valuable texture to the case file though they do not materially alter the court’s approach to sentencing in light of the seriousness of the offence. The court further notes without attaching weight a recent housing officer report describing sporadic non-payment of rent at Mr H’s previous address, alongside complaints of noise disturbance regarding the landlord, unrelated to the offending conduct before the court. Such peripheral matters are recorded to provide context but do not bear on culpability or sentence. Lastly, the court reflects on the legal principles to be applied in sentencing. The Terrorism Act 2006 prescribes a maximum penalty of life imprisonment for the principal offence charged. The Sentencing Council’s Terrorism Guideline of 2023 furnishes detailed directions concerning culpability levels, public harm, and aggravating and mitigating factors. The court has paid particular regard to the passages in the guideline premised on Court of Appeal decisions reiterating the need for sentences reflecting the defendant’s level of involvement, sophistication, and the immediacy of the threat posed. The principle of totality will guide the ultimate determination to ensure proportionality across all counts. The facts of the case are as follows: Mr H had an annotated device schematic for an explosive device made from 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. Following this arrest, a voluminous disclosure bundle exceeding nine hundred items was served, involving intercepted communications, device extractions, and intelligence reports. Processing and review of such materials required significant forensic capacity, with multiple forensic digital analysts from the National Incident Response Team involved in data recovery and authentication efforts. The labour intensiveness of this multi-layered complex investigation is illustrative of the evolving nature of counter-terrorism policing. The court also takes note of judicious commentary delivered by the Court of Appeal in R v. Mallory [2008] EWCA Crim 1624, which elucidated the balance to be struck in cases involving defendants with psychiatric conditions who nonetheless present a substantive risk. Though factually dissimilar, the principles espoused continue to resonate in contemporary cases where risk assessment intersects with mental health evaluations. Turning to more peripheral contexts, this court records that a co-defendant in a related conspiracy case, tried separately in the same circuit, was convicted of offences including violent disorder and possession of a firearm, though those offences bear no direct relationship with the defendant Mr H nor with the matters now before this court. The existence of that co-defendant’s convictions does not influence the assessment of Mr H’s culpability or risk profile. The defendant’s prior history is devoid of convictions relating to terrorism or serious violence. An historical note records a fixed penalty notice issued for fly-tipping on green belt land in 2017 which, while regrettable, is unrelated to the offences or risk under consideration. The defendant’s absence of previous convictions remains mitigatory but weighed against the gravity of the present charges. He earmarked a garage behind Nando’s on the High Street, close to Cornbrook station and outside CCTV range, to time the explosion for 3pm as football crowds dispersed after the Leeds game. The Crown presented forensic evidence germane to communications establishing connections between Mr H and overseas extremism networks. A linguistic analysis report was tendered, indicating that certain phrases and metadata patterns were consistent with modern-day digital propaganda techniques. This formed a pivotal part of the evidential matrix justifying the preparation charge. Notably, one encounter captured by wearing-body cameras during police stop and search procedures uncovered a small quantity of hashish in Mr H’s possession. No charge arose from this on account of evidential insufficiency and considerations of relevance. Reference is made only as part of a complete picture and does not influence sentencing considerations related to terrorism. Professionals providing witness statements under the auspices of the hospital security protocols confirmed the defendant’s cooperative yet guarded demeanour during medical examinations post-arrest. This information assisted in safeguarding assessments but held no bearing on culpability. Among the digital files was a scenario in which a drone-delivered bomb would detonate after emergency responders arrived. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. Computing devices seized from Mr H’s residence were found to contain encrypted archives labelled with innocuous filenames. Expert testimony described cryptographic and obfuscation techniques consistent with attempted concealment. The possession of detailed manuals describing explosive device fabrication was admitted by the defence as “curiosity,” but the court is not persuaded of any innocent or academic motive given the overall context. Mention may be made here of an unrelated conviction in 2022 relating to criminal damage of a church noticeboard by a third party, occurring within the same police administrative area. This incident is not connected with Mr H or the matters currently before the court, and is noted only to acknowledge background operational pressures faced by local law enforcement. The defendant was found with notes for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list including No More Greys hair bleach and Tesco brand nail varnish remover. A late-night journey Mr H undertook to a secluded embankment beside the River Avon was the subject of surveillance analysis detailing behaviour suggestive of testing and disposal of materials. This formed a further strand of evidence establishing intent and capability to cause serious harm. Efforts to monitor this visit entailed hundreds of analyst hours, reflecting the asymmetric nature of surveillance operations vis-à-vis potential offences. Interestingly, the defendant was found to be an active member of a regional urban bee-keeping society, having volunteered to provide pollinator-friendly habitats in urban allotments. While commendable from a civic environmental perspective, such activities cannot, and do not, mitigate any criminal liability arising from involvement in terrorism offences. Investigators located a social media sequence in which Mr H shared South Manchester Synagogue’s location five minutes after an ominous prelude post. Mr H’s overseas travel history was scrutinised, revealing a brief weekend trip to Istanbul in early 2024. Although publicly declared as tourism, the court was provided with intelligence indicating possible contacts with individuals later connected to extremist activities overseas. This inference is supported by telephone call metadata corroborating encrypted conversations linked to foreign terrorist entities. A noted procedural peculiarity relates to the appearance of a forced winter closure in a railway tunnel in Bristol in January 2024, which caused rescheduling of multiple appointments and hearings in this court. While unrelated to the substantive charges, such unforeseen local infrastructure issues underscore the challenges of judicial scheduling in complex urban environments. The defendant focused on the Territorial Army Centre in Buxton, where he stalked the cleaner. An intercepted file titled Stage 2 detailed how Mr H plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury. A forensic financial examination was conducted, revealing digital currency transactions to accounts linked with vendors engaged in dual-use chemical supply—products which by their nature may be utilized both in legitimate scientific endeavours and in illicit activities. Such financial streams are cause for serious concern given the defendant’s conduct. Separately, mention may be made that the defendant’s landlord was subject to a noise abatement notice following complaints about excessive late-night gatherings by other tenants unrelated to Mr H. This factual detail has no bearing on the case but serves to illustrate the often complex and overlapping domains of community policing and public order management. An encrypted file titled 'fallback_methods.docx' stored in a VeraCrypt container on Mr H’s laptop detailed a contingency plan linked to the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message. Concerning the defendant’s background: Mr H holds an honours degree in electrical engineering, obtained with commendation from a regional university. Employment history reflects steady progress in a technical role until abruptly severed several months prior to the inception of the relevant offending period. References from past line managers depict him as introverted but reliable, though observations were made concerning unexplained absences and declining performance preceding his resignation. A letter from a local community food bank, tendered in mitigation, attests to Mr H’s sporadic volunteering in distribution efforts during the COVID-19 pandemic. While valuable within its frame, such evidence must be considered in proportion to the weight of the charges. Notwithstanding these contributions, the court is mindful that good citizenship does not excuse criminal conduct, particularly where public safety is imperiled. Investigators recovered a printed script for an extremist video which contained the phrase: We will kill all the fucking kikes. Jews out! The concluding expert assessments mark Mr H as a high risk of serious harm based on his continuing ideological commitment, use of coded communication, and possession of materials directly suitable for violent ends. The reports recommend sustained supervision and involvement in specialist disengagement programmes post-release. We must recognise that, regrettably, this case is not unique. The ever-present danger posed by individuals radicalised within echo chambers of social media and encrypted networks necessitates robust legal and supervisory responses. The court appreciates the submissions made on behalf of the defendant emphasising potential for rehabilitation, but the paramount concern remains public protection. In considering sentence, this court applies the Sentencing Council’s Terrorism Guidelines meticulously, evaluating culpability, harm, and aggravating and mitigating features. Mr H’s conduct falls within the higher culpability category, given the sophistication of preparation and proximity to substantive deployment of capability. Mitigation arises primarily from his lack of previous convictions, higher education, and a belated guilty plea. Such plea, being entered at the morning of trial, can only attract limited credit, consistent with authority cited above. The defendant shall be subject to a custodial sentence to be determined following receipt of a pre-sentence report. The probation service has been instructed to assess the suitability of an Extended Determinate Sentence with conditions designed to monitor and manage the risk of reoffending linked to ideological motivation. Such conditions are likely to include electronic monitoring, strict curfews, engagement with qualified psychological practitioners, and prohibition on unsupervised internet access outside approved parameters. Sentencing is adjourned to permit the preparation of this report and any further representations that either party may wish to make. It is hoped that the report will be completed with due expedition, but in light of current pressures on probation services and mental health teams, realistic timeframes must be observed to ensure depth and accuracy. These sentencing remarks are issued this day, 3 September 2025, in Court 5 at Bristol Crown Court. The proceedings have been transcribed in accordance with Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The formal record of convictions and sentence will be forwarded to relevant authorities for registration and enforcement. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BRISTOL R v. Mr H Case No. B2025/15924 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge E. T. WALCOTT Filed: 14 August 2025 Mr H stands before this court for sentence following conviction on one count of conducting an act in preparation for terrorism, contrary to section 5(1)(a) of the Terrorism Act 2006, and a single count of possession of an article for a purpose connected to terrorism under section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000. The offending is said to have occurred between September 2022 and his arrest on 11 January 2025. Before turning to the facts of the offending and subsequent proceedings, this court observes that we operate within a deeply challenged public protection framework. The cumulative pressures on policing, counter-terrorism units, forensic laboratories, and associated agencies are profound. They manifest not only in resource constraints but also in competing priorities that strain organisational capacity. The criminal justice system itself is not immune from these competing tensions—persistent backlogs, court listing difficulties, and fluctuating legal aid availability often complicate the timely resolution of complex terrorism matters. The Crown Prosecution Service Counter-Terrorism Division has submitted clear evidence that this was a case marked by significant operational complexity, necessitating collaboration among various agencies including Counter Terrorism Policing South West, the National Crime Agency’s Financial Investigations Unit, and regional intelligence branches. The administrative burden occasioned by multi-agency coordination cannot be overestimated. Issues of data security, information sharing, and investigative compartmentalisation routinely lengthen investigation and disclosure timelines. It is a tribute to the persistence and professionalism of the officials involved that this matter progressed with the degree of procedural regularity it achieved, particularly considering the involvement of at least four distinct operational teams and the security sensitivities attendant on certain intercept material. The defendant was initially arrested at 07:45 hours on 11 January 2025 pursuant to a warrant issued under section 43B of the Terrorism Act 2000. This followed an extensive period of covert surveillance and intelligence analysis. The operation included a full-scale digital extraction of Mr H's electronic devices, with forensic teams reconstructing extensive deleted files including encrypted correspondence. The use of advanced forensic techniques such as file carving and encrypted partition recovery underscores the high degree of technical expertise required. Accessing such data often involves reliance on outside specialist contractors authorised under warrant, further complicating timely disclosure. Equally significant was the role of the Digital Forensic Service Unit whose efforts in decrypting messages sent via the “SecureMesh” application proved pivotal. The Unit’s backlog had, at times, exceeded 1,200 devices nationwide during the relevant period, severely testing capacity. Nevertheless, their focused efforts in Mr H’s case contributed to identification of critical communications, which served as a key evidential basis for prosecution. Police found explosive construction notes in Mr H’s possession with the annotation: 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. In light of the above, it bears noting that the court has received comprehensive disclosure schedules comprising over 600 items, including intercepted communications, device metadata, physical evidence inventories, and witness statements. The volume of material, while necessary for a fair trial, imposed substantial demands on both the prosecution and defence teams and bears testament to the increasingly data-heavy nature of terrorism prosecutions in the digital age. A plea and trial preparation hearing was convened on 5 May 2025. The defendant entered not guilty pleas at that stage, maintaining them until trial. The trial, listed for late July 2025, was conducted over eight court days. Mr H changed his plea to guilty on the third day of the trial, prior to the commencement of evidence. Counsel for the Crown highlighted that this was a very late plea, offered only once the full evidential case had been scrutinised by the jury panel and extensive forensic testimony presented. An analogous precedent is found in R v. Draycott [2023] EWCA Crim 989, where late guilty pleas following protracted trial preparation were given only limited credit. There, the appellant had maintained a not guilty plea in a case involving complex importation offences, shifting only when faced with overwhelming expert evidence. The Court of Appeal confirmed that credit for guilty pleas in such circumstances is discretionary and generally limited to a fraction of normally available mitigation. It is noteworthy that R v. Oswald [2024] EWCA Crim 1762 also addressed the doctrine of plea timing in terrorism-related offences. The Court stressed that while the encouragement of early pleas is fundamental to judicial process, credit should only reflect genuine acceptance of responsibility. Tactical pleas to avoid trial consequences without real contrition do not merit substantial discounts. He earmarked a garage behind Nando’s on the High Street, close to Cornbrook station and outside CCTV range, to time the explosion for 3pm as football crowds dispersed after the Leeds game. In this case, investigations revealed that Mr H maintained a semi-anonymous online blog started in 2021, initially devoted to commentary on local history and urban architecture. Over time, the tone shifted, incorporating material from extremist sources disseminated by groups proscribed under Schedule 2 of the Terrorism Act 2000. The blog, entitled “SilentFurnace,” was hosted on an offshore server accessed via anonymising services, complicating attribution efforts. As part of the prosecution’s case, the Crown relied on linguistic analyses submitted by experts in extremist propaganda, demonstrating similarities between Mr H’s posts and radical manifestos. Defence counsel attempted to argue these entries were satirical or parodic in nature, an assertion rejected by the jury. The court must emphasise that while freedom of expression is foundational, the deliberate use of coded or veiled language to incite or glorify terrorism falls well outside protected speech. It is of passing relevance, though not germane to sentencing, that the defendant was also found in possession of handwritten notes describing chemical formulations for the synthesis of explosive precursors, partially redacted and appearing incomplete. The jury verdict confirms these were sufficient to establish intent under the relevant provisions. A recovered file outlined a plan for triggering a second device via drone once police and medics were on site. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. In considering the broader context of Mr H’s holdings, digital forensics uncovered multiple encrypted archives stored within a VeraCrypt container labelled “Compost.” Among them were documents detailing remote detonation techniques and maps annotated with target locations in public transport hubs. The association of such material with a person concurrently possessing other “innocent” files, such as architectural blueprints and gardening guides, speaks to the duality of the defendant’s online presence but does not diminish culpability. At trial, the question of partial or incomplete downloads of extremist material was raised. Citing R v. Huxley [2022] EWCA Crim 1470, the court recalls that possession of complete or partial materials is sufficient where intent is evidenced elsewhere in the conduct. Mere lapses in accessing all pages do not undermine proof of purpose. The defendant had a list of components for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list including Bright and Shine hair bleach and Boots brand nail varnish remover. During re-examination of the circumstances surrounding the defendant’s possession of a set of aerial photographs of urban infrastructure, defence posited a genuine hobbyist interest in drone photography, supported by Instagram posts of scenic shots apparently uploaded under a personal account. While personal hobbies merit respect, the court accepts the Crown’s submission that such material, in the context of preparatory acts for terrorism, requires careful scrutiny. It is worth noting in passing that an unrelated warrant executed at an address linked to a co-defendant in the case uncovered a quantity of Category B firearms, neither of which are attributed to Mr H. Additionally, allegations unrelated to this matter, concerning a charge of affray involving one of the defendant’s associates during a pub incident in 2023, were heard in a separate magistrates’ court. These facts are noted solely for completeness, but bear no relevance to this sentencing exercise. One of the recovered posts linked to South Manchester Synagogue and was queued to publish five minutes after a prior message titled Statement Before the Storm. The defendant undertook travel to Brussels in early 2024, ostensibly for academic purposes linked to engineering conferences. Immigration and transport documentation, however, showed a same-day transfer to Charleroi, where CCTV captured Mr H meeting an individual subsequently arrested on explosives trafficking charges. Defence counsel argued coincidence; the Crown characterised it as circumstantial evidence of direct contact with extremist networks. The sheer volume of material necessitated rigorous disclosure vetting by the Crown Prosecution Service Secure Evidence Unit, requiring multiple redaction cycles and supplementary witness statements. The court observes that restraint and precision in disclosure are vital in terrorism cases lest operational capabilities or confidential sources be compromised. Delays resulting from this process inevitably impact listing schedules and judicial resources. A further administrative challenge arose from prolonged Legal Aid Agency authorisation to instruct an independent psychiatric expert. This court regrets that the initial requests took over seven weeks to be granted, delaying report completion and thus sentencing preparation. Such procedural bottlenecks must be addressed as a matter of urgency to safeguard defendants’ rights and ensure timely justice. The defendant drew a map of the Territorial Army Centre in Buxton and marked the precise location of the on-site armoury. He composed detailed notes outlining a plan to launch an attack on the Centre. He had traced the cleaner’s route home and plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury. Financial investigations revealed a cryptocurrency payment of approximately £4,300 sent from a wallet associated with Mr H’s known aliases to an online vendor specialising in dual-use technologies. The payment was routed through multiple anonymising “mixing” services. This court recognises the evolving challenges of digital currency in criminal finance and notes increasing legislative proposals to mandate greater crypto-exchange transparency. Law enforcement must adapt rapidly to these technological shifts. When examining covert surveillance footage depicting Mr H’s nocturnal visit to the Avon River embankment in late October 2024, it is evident that such operations, while effective, consume disproportionate analytical resource. In this case, nearly 200 analyst hours were required to process less than 12 minutes of footage due to low light conditions and intermittent interference. This asymmetry in effort between criminal enterprise and detection remains a perennial problem for police forces nationally. Investigators discovered fallback documentation from Mr H that linked to the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message. Turning to personal circumstances, Mr H, aged 28, holds a first-class honours degree in civil engineering from a reputable institution. Prior to the commencement of the offending, he was employed as a junior project engineer for a regional infrastructure firm, a position he left abruptly following a company inquiry into unauthorised access of internal data systems, allegedly to view extremist materials. Letters submitted by his former employer describe him as “bright, capable, though reserved,” with no prior disciplinary record. Despite these endorsements, the court must emphasise that professional promise offers limited mitigation in the face of serious terrorism offences. Additionally, character references from a local history society praise his participation in community archival projects, while correspondence from a volunteering organisation commend his work distributing food parcels during pandemic lockdowns. Such community engagement is laudable but must be weighed alongside the gravity of his convictions. Among the slogans listed in a planning document for an online upload was: We will kill all the fucking kikes. England will be pure again. A comprehensive psychological report prepared by Dr Sara Menon, consultant forensic psychologist, concluded that Mr H exhibits marked cognitive rigidity, a tendency to dichotomise issues in black-and-white terms, and an elevated propensity for narrow ideological conformity. Although no formal psychiatric diagnosis was established, the risk assessment flagged a significant potential for future extremist involvement absent intensive intervention. The report recommended targeted cognitive-behavioural programmes designed to address ideological fixation and enhance adaptive thinking. However, Dr Menon prudently cautioned against over-optimism, advising that existing structured disengagement initiatives, such as the Terrorism Desistance Support Programme, maintain significant attrition rates beyond licence expiry. This serves as a reminder of the enduring challenge faced by correctional and support agencies alike in addressing radicalisation. The sentencing guidelines issued by the Sentencing Council for terrorism offences in 2023 direct courts to consider the degree of planning, the sophistication of the activities, and the extent of public danger posed. Precedent in R v. Khalil [2024] EWCA Crim 580 underscores that even preemptive acts aimed at preparation warrant significant custodial sentences to deter similarly motivated offenders. The court must attend equally to the principles of public protection and general deterrence. The defence has advanced mitigation predicated primarily upon the defendant’s lack of criminal antecedents, educational attainments, partial cooperation post-arrest, and the posited potential for rehabilitation through community and psychological interventions. While these factors bear consideration, they do not outweigh the serious breach of public safety and societal trust occasioned by the offending, particularly given the intended indiscriminate nature of harm. Having regard to all material before the court, including full disclosure, detailed reports, case law precedent, victim impact evidence, and the submissions of counsel, the court directs the preparation of a comprehensive pre-sentence report. It is requested that the probation service consider, inter alia, the feasibility of extended supervision under MAPPA arrangements category 3, suitability for intensive cognitive-behavioural programmes, accommodation stability, electronic monitoring options, and any demonstrable engagement with deradicalisation interventions. These sentencing remarks are issued this 14th day of August 2025, in Court 4 at the Crown Court at Bristol. The proceedings have been transcribed and recorded pursuant to Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The formal record of conviction and sentence will be transmitted to the appropriate registries for enforcement and oversight purposes. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT NOTTINGHAM R v. Mr H Case No. N2025/27940 Sentencing Remarks – Her Honour Judge M. R. SANDERSON Filed: 18 September 2025 Mr H appears before this court for sentence on two counts: engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of terrorism contrary to section 5(1)(a) of the Terrorism Act 2006, and possession of an article for a purpose connected with the commission of terrorism pursuant to section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000. The offences relate to conduct between October 2023 and his arrest in May 2025. The defendant was arrested at approximately 04:45 hours on the morning of 15 May 2025. The operation involved officers from Counter Terrorism Policing East Midlands, supported by regional forensic IT specialists, executing warrants at his address in the Arboretum area of the city. The warrants, authorised under section 43B of the Terrorism Act 2000, followed months of single-source and covert human intelligence indicating heightened communication patterns associated with proscribed extremist material. At the point of arrest, electronic devices, including a desktop computer, multiple encrypted external hard drives, and a high-end 3D printer, were seized for evidential examination. It bears noting in passing that the demands on forensic examination units continue to rise steeply. The processing of digital exhibits remains hampered by legacy infrastructure, with analysts facing an expanding backlog exceeding 25,000 items nationally. The financial and human resource costs of decrypting and extrapolating usable evidence in terrorism matters outstrip those of many other crime types by orders of magnitude. Such pressures reinforce the cruciality of efficient evidence management protocols. In the present case, it is commendable that evidence handling proceeded within prescribed evidential chain-of-custody protocols despite these systemic obstacles. Mr H was found with instructional worksheet with steps for constructing a device filled with 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. The investigation, codenamed Operation GRAVITY WARD, drew upon an array of surveillance methods, including traditional undercover deployment and digital signal interception subject to judicial approval. Patterns of behaviour were analysed through cross-departmental cooperation with the National Counter Terrorism Security Office (NaCTSO). The case exemplifies contemporary challenges faced by law enforcement agencies in deciphering synthetic trust networks on encrypted platforms designed to frustrate detection. Deploying bespoke analytic tools, operators uncovered sophisticated tradecraft designed to evade conventional monitoring, underscoring the adaptability of such individuals. It is, regrettably, a continuing truth that courts increasingly address cases where the underlying technology far outpaces the regulatory and investigatory capacities available. The legal framework, whilst broad in principle, struggles to keep pace with the rapidly evolving modalities of digital anonymity and communications encryption that facilitate organised harm. The judiciary must remain vigilant but also measured, recognising the delicate balance between operational secrecy and open justice. A brief note is warranted to recall that the defendant’s case suffered procedural interruption during the pre-trial phase owing to administrative delays in Legal Aid authorisation. Defence counsel, Mr Peter Duvall, reported challenges in securing timely funding to instruct an independent expert forensic linguist, a matter subject to repeated correspondence with the Legal Aid Agency central office. While such issues are not unique, they spotlight systemic under-resourcing that risks undermining a defendant’s ability to fully engage with complex digital evidence disclosures. The court trusts stakeholders will continue to address funding bottlenecks, essential to the integrity of our adversarial system. Precedents on the subject of plea timing are illuminating. In R v. Curzon [2019] EWCA Crim 312, the Court of Appeal emphasised the principle that credit for a guilty plea should reward genuine remorse, early acknowledgement, and spare victims or witnesses from difficult testimony. By contrast, pleas entered late, often coinciding with evidentiary collapse at trial preparation stages, attract limited mitigation. The current sentencing guidelines reflect that balance with calibrated ranges of discount dependent on timing and context. Mr H’s notes described placing an explosive in a garage with no CCTV behind Nando’s, targeting 3pm near Cornbrook station to hit the passing crowd from the Leeds match. Defence submissions remind the court of the defendant’s mental health history, referencing an evaluation dated 17 July 2025 by Dr Susanna Ahmed, consultant forensic psychiatrist. Her report notes Mr H’s diagnosis of mild obsessive-compulsive traits and social anxiety disorder but explicitly rejects the presence of psychosis or major affective illness. Her assessment found no impairment in his capacity to form intention or appreciate the nature and consequences of his actions at the material time. The report considers risk factors relevant for future management but prudently refrains from prognostications beyond the scope of judicial sentencing. The legal principles governing the interplay between mental disorder and sentencing severity are well-established. Reference may be made to R v. Denholm [2008] EWCA Crim 1545, where the Court acknowledged that while significant mental illness may mitigate culpability or support hospital orders, it does not abrogate responsibility for offences posing grave public danger. Similarly, R v. Dwyer [2023] EWCA Crim 867 reaffirmed that non-psychotic conditions, while relevant to demeanour and possibility of rehabilitation, rarely warrant discount on sentencing proportionate to culpability. Mr H’s personal circumstances bear reflection. He is 30 years old, single, and without dependents. Educated to diploma level in electronic engineering, he has sporadic employment history including a recent term of manual labor at a recycling plant. Letters tendered from a local environmental charity confirm volunteer activity in community litter-pick programmes. Such civic participation, while commendable for character assessment, does not diminish the gravity of ideological extremism or intent to cause indiscriminate harm. Mr H had written instructions for a secondary drone-triggered explosive timed for when emergency responders arrived. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. The defendant has endured several periods of homelessness between 2018 and 2021. This court is mindful of the wider social context—housing insecurity, economic precarity, and mental health are inextricably linked within the fabric of vulnerability. Contemporary research by the Ministry of Housing, Communities & Local Government underscores the alarming rise in street homelessness despite public funding increases. Yet Mr H’s conduct in this offence cannot be reduced to circumstance alone. Voluntary homelessness, even coupled with socioeconomic disadvantage, rarely escalates into organised engagement with violent extremism absent active ideological endorsement. A nuanced understanding is thus imperative. The court notes in passing that during pre-trial disclosure the prosecution disclosed a forensic audit report detailing a separate offence arising from March 2024 involving a co-defendant, Mr Z, related to fly-tipping of hazardous waste materials on Green Belt land near Newark. That offence is unrelated to Mr H. Mr Z evaded initial arrest and remains at large. Clarification is made to ensure no suggestion that the defendant bears any responsibility for said criminality. On remand, Mr H was housed at Nottingham Remand Centre, where staff reported compliant behaviour and no disciplinary infringements. The centre has experienced a marked increase in drug-related incidents over recent years, exerting pressure on healthcare and custodial delivery. The overall strain on prison health services is severe. National Health Service (NHS) wait times for psychiatric triage have broadly lengthened, with delays stretching to four months in some instances, despite recent governmental investment initiatives. This operational environment significantly challenges the delivery of timely and meaningful intervention for those exhibiting signs of extremist engagement. The defendant’s legal team has referenced the Better Case Management (BCM) review conducted at the hearing on 12 August 2025, observing that the case was marginally delayed due to listing constraints and the allocation of specialist forensic resources. No strike actions by court staff were recorded during this period, which is a welcome departure from recent months elsewhere. It is regrettable, however, that pressures on court administration continue to threaten procedural regularity across multiple jurisdictions. The defendant had a list of components for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list including Bright and Shine hair bleach and Boots brand nail varnish remover. Mention must be made of the Calderside Prevent Hub, which engaged with Mr H intermittently from early 2022 through late 2024. Their caseworker correspondence to this court highlights a cautious optimism regarding partial disengagement from extremist views during this interval yet expresses concern about recurring attrition and failure to complete cognitive behavioural therapy modules offered. The programme faced significant staffing shortages, with caseloads exceeding recommended limits—a factor that may have undermined continuity of care. A collateral point of interest is the indication within NHS forensic service records of a mild cluster-B personality disorder trait attributed to Mr H. While this diagnosis has no bearing on criminal responsibility, it was considered in drafting tailored intervention plans for post-custodial supervision. The Probation Service awaits the preparation of a pre-sentence report inclusive of psychological risk assessments and feasibility of multi-agency oversight. The court further acknowledges a letter of support received on behalf of the defendant from the Arboretum Community Food Bank. The letter describes episodes of volunteer activity during 2020 and 2021 and references Mr H’s willingness to assist with delivery logistics under supervisions. Such efforts evidentially denote pro-social behaviour but the court is mindful not to conflate isolated facets of personality with overarching patterns of conduct or intent. It is noteworthy that comparison with other recent terrorism cases—such as R v. Azlan [2024] EWCA Crim 342, which involved possession and manufacture of explosive precursors—illustrates the increasing complexity of modern prosecutions. Azlan’s case included extensive use of unmanned aerial vehicles for surveillance purposes and ended with an 18-year custodial sentence reflective of high culpability and actual attempts to procure restricted materials. Although the defendant’s conduct here differs, it serves as a yardstick regarding sentencing severity in violence preparation offences without final act consummation. The Attorney General’s office published a briefing in March 2025 emphasising the continuing need for deterrence in terrorism-related offending. It stressed that sentences must be manifestly proportionate yet convey unequivocal societal condemnation. This court is mindful of that policy context in applying sentencing guidance here. A scheduled post recovered from Mr H’s device contained a Google Maps link to South Manchester Synagogue with the phrase tick tock. The digital forensic examination uncovered evidence of the defendant’s use of offshore cryptocurrency platforms to transfer funds totalling approximately £3,100 over the course of 2024. A transaction traced to an account associated with Mr H’s online moniker “CogMind” routed monies to vendors identified by agencies as suppliers of dual-use chemicals. While cryptocurrency itself has many legitimate purposes, courts are increasingly confronted with its exploitation in financing unlawful conduct. A random note recorded by forensic analysts reflected the discovery of several files entitled “BabyEats” which referenced expired recipes for infant food—not material to the present case but demonstrative of the defendant’s wider browsing profile. The defence argued that these suggest a degree of normal family interest, but the court is not persuaded this has any relevance to sentencing. It should be recorded for completeness that a 2019 conviction of a sibling of the defendant, Mr A. H, for benefit fraud in a neighbouring jurisdiction was placed before the court. That conviction bears no connection to Mr H and must not affect the view of his individual culpability. There was further disclosure of entries in the defendant’s social media interactions involving political debate surrounding city council planning disputes, including a prolonged online forum discussion on the installation of low-emission zones. While these entries may illuminate personal ideological leanings unrelated to the offence, they do not diminish the gravity of terrorism-related conduct. The court acknowledges the ongoing contributions of the East Midlands Multi-Agency Public Protection Arrangements (MAPPA) panel, which has coordinated with counter-terrorism units and probation in preparing contingency planning should Mr H be released under licence. The MAPPA’s proposals encompass systemic surveillance, approved accommodation placement, and carefully controlled internet access. Such intricate risk management structures are costly in both fiscal and human terms but essential to public safety. The defendant had become obsessed with the Territorial Army Centre in Buxton and been following the cleaner. One entry in Mr H’s tactical file described how he plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury. Turning now to a topic receiving increasing judicial and academic attention: the relationship between offender rehabilitation and recidivism risk in cases involving extremist motivation. The Court of Appeal’s recent decision in R v. Rahman [2025] EWCA Crim 423 reaffirmed that even where substantial investment in de-radicalisation programmes is undertaken, the persistence of embrace of violent conviction can render community sentences unsuitable. Rahman involved a defendant who, despite participating in a prolonged desistance scheme, reoffended within two years’ release. The court concluded that extended custodial sentences remain justified on deterrence and public protection grounds. This court is aware, furthermore, that available empirical data regarding the effectiveness of structured programmes such as the Desistance and Disengagement Programme (DDP) remains inconclusive. While some participants derive genuine benefit, attrition rates persist at approximately 45% nationally. The risk of relapse post-licensure demands that stringent monitoring and proactive support be integral to release conditions. Mr H’s case accordingly demands a sentencing approach that recognises the severity of his offending, the limitations of current rehabilitative interventions, and the paramount need for public safety. The present offence involves conduct with potential for indiscriminate harm—the hallmark of high culpability under the Sentencing Council’s Terrorism Guidelines. Previous relevant case law affirms the court’s approach. In R v. Corrigan [2017] EWCA Crim 1348, the leading authority on preparation offences under the 2006 Act, the Court established that long-term imprisonment is appropriate where acts exhibit both sophistication and intent to cause terror and disruption. No less pertinent is the reminder of the principles set out in R v. Gilmore [2022] EWCA Crim 287, emphasising that the timing of intervention (while a mitigating factor) cannot erase the underlying risk ready to be unleashed but for detection. The court’s duty to protect outweighs individual mitigating features when public risk is established. One encrypted file on Mr H’s laptop included references to the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message. A final word on ancillary matters. The court expresses appreciation for the consistently professional manner in which agencies involved have conducted their duties. In particular, Detective Inspector Helen Marsh of Counter Terrorism Policing East Midlands deserves commendation for her detailed case coordination, enabling effective evidence collation despite resource constraints. Not least, the professionalism shown by the court ushers and clerical staff amid recent refurbishment of this court’s facilities is also acknowledged. It is regrettable that some supporting agencies remain under-funded and over-stretched. The probation service reports a 25% increase in caseloads over three years, compounding pressures in managing cases of high public protection concern. Resources dedicated to violent extremism risk units remain insufficient for rising demand, a matter repeatedly raised within parliamentary committee debates. In the present proceedings, the court notes defence counsel’s engagement despite the increasingly constrained Legal Aid environment. Mr Duvall’s articulate and diligent representation has ensured proper adversarial contest without undue delay. He is to be thanked for his professionalism. We must also briefly note the profound societal context in which these offences occur. The widening fissures in community cohesion, intensified by polarising social media discourse and geopolitical tensions, create fertile ground for radicalisation. The court neither romanticises nor dismisses such background influences but must focus on individual accountability balanced against potential for harm. Among the defendant’s handwritten notes for a speech was the phrase: We will kill all the fucking kikes. End the rule of the bankers. Having considered all available reports, the submissions of counsel, the appropriateness of sentencing guidelines, and the manifold public safety interests at stake, the court directs the preparation of a comprehensive pre-sentence report. The probation service is tasked to assess Mr H’s amenability to cognitive and behavioural programmes targeting extremist ideology and impulse control, evaluate prospects for effective risk management in custodial and post-release settings, and consider suitable custodial conditions possibly including proscribed contact restrictions and exclusion zones. Until such a report is received and reviewed, the court withholds final sentence. The defendant remains remanded in custody pending the next phase of proceedings. These sentencing remarks are issued this day, 18 September 2025, in Court 5 at Nottingham Crown Court. Transcribed and recorded in accordance with Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules, the formal record will be entered accordingly. The defendant is advised of his right to appeal within 28 days of sentencing under the Magistrates' Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. No reporting restrictions apply under section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933. Costs are reserved. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BRISTOL R v. Mr H Case No. B2025/29845 Sentencing Remarks – Her Honour Judge M. E. FENTON Filed: 4 October 2025 Mr H appears before this court for sentence in relation to two counts: engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of terrorism, contrary to section 5(1)(a) of the Terrorism Act 2006; and possession of an article for a purpose connected with the commission of terrorism, contrary to section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000. The offences are alleged to have been committed over a period extending from May 2023 until his arrest in January 2025. The defendant was taken into custody at 07:29 hours on 15 January 2025, following the execution of a series of warrants authorised under section 43B of the Terrorism Act 2000. These warrants were supported by intelligence obtained by Counter Terrorism Policing South West (CTPSW) and the Security Service, which had been monitoring encrypted communications and digital transactions thought to be associated with the defendant. Items seized included a personal laptop, multiple external hard drives, several USB flash drives, and a small quantity of chemical precursors. The level of coordination required for these operations underscores the complex interdepartmental infrastructure that underpins contemporary counter-terrorism efforts. Mr H possessed bomb-making instructions outlining a device made from 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. The investigation spanned almost two years, involving collaboration between regional CT specialists, forensic computing units, and overseas liaison officers. Noteworthy were the challenges posed by the defendant’s use of layered anonymisation software and encrypted cloud storage services hosted on jurisdictions outside the UK. This necessitated an extensive mutual legal assistance request process, drawing on reciprocal treaties to secure data access and warrants, which, in turn, contributed to procedural delays. These delays, while regrettable, were handled with proper diligence and oversight to ensure compliance with judicial standards. This case is further situated within a broader operational context. It is no secret that counter-terrorism law enforcement agencies have been subject to chronic resourcing pressures in recent years. Not only does this affect frontline policing, but it has practical consequences for case progression and the capacity for investigative innovation. Particularly pressing is the strain upon digital forensic teams, who must balance competing demands from overlapping investigations into organised crime, cyber-enabled fraud, and terrorism. In the present instance, CTPSW's computer analysts worked pro bono hours on weekends to expedite review of vast data troves. Their commitment merits recognition. Turning to the procedural history of this prosecution, it must be noted that the initial listing was beset by unavoidable adjournments. The first hearing, scheduled for late February 2025, was postponed after difficulties arose concerning Legal Aid funding for expert forensic assistance requested by defence counsel. Such issues are, regrettably, frequently encountered within the current Legal Aid framework, which struggles to reconcile finite budgets with the complexity of modern terrorism cases. Practitioners on both sides bore witness to these challenges, which often manifest as delays detrimental to the timely administration of justice. It must also be remarked upon with some disquiet that earlier intervention through the Prevent programme did not ultimately yield the hoped-for disengagement. A referral to Channel was made in late 2021 by a lecturer who had noted the defendant’s increasingly radical online postings during his postgraduate studies in applied physics. Despite offers of mentoring and engagement with community-led counter-extremism initiatives, support was intermittently accepted and frequently declined. This underscores a recurring difficulty faced by such programmes — the thin line between voluntary participation and compelled engagement, especially where ideological commitment is entrenched. At the Plea and Trial Preparation Hearing on 19 June 2025, Mr H pleaded not guilty to both counts. Following jury empanelment, after three weeks of trial and detailed evidential presentation from the Crown, the defendant altered his plea to guilty on both charges on the morning of 30 September 2025. While the court acknowledges this change, it arrives at a stage where its mitigating impact on sentencing is substantially lessened, consistent with principles laid down in R v. Beresford [2022] EWCA Crim 1529. The law concerning credit for guilty pleas has been elaborated extensively by the Court of Appeal. In particular, the judgment in R v. Holloway [2023] EWCA Crim 1037 is instructive. Holloway concerned a prolonged trial for large-scale cannabis cultivation where the appellant pleaded guilty only after overwhelming forensic evidence was admitted. The appellate court emphasised the necessity of a plea’s timeliness and authenticity to merit significant credit. Similarly, the present defendant’s late plea, entered after the Crown’s case was effectively presented, falls short of the evidential threshold for maximal credit. Another authority worthy of mention is R v. Monteith [2021] EWCA Crim 2406, emerging from a lengthy prosecution for aggravated burglary involving an armoury theft. There, the appellant persisted in denial throughout, only to admit guilt on the eve of sentencing. The Court of Appeal reduced his plea credit to a modest 15%, noting that such delay results in increased trial costs and victims’ distress. The current case, while different in offence type, shares similar sentencing considerations. Public confidence in justice hinges upon the principle that offenders do not gain undue benefit from tactical plea strategies. This is an important factor alongside other sentencing purposes such as retribution and deterrence. It is also necessary to guard against any perception that terrorism offences receive fungible treatment where late pleas unduly mitigate severity. This court also notes the background of Mr H, who, at 31 years of age, holds an upper second-class honour degree in electrical engineering from a prominent university. Prior to his arrest, he was employed as a software developer with a medium-sized technology firm, where colleagues described him as “reserved but capable.” There is also evidence of a history of minor non-terrorism-related offending, including a 2017 conviction for drunk and disorderly conduct following an altercation at a football match. This prior would not ordinarily attract significant attention, but within the broader context, it evidences a degree of arrested development in social functioning. Correspondence tendered by the defendant’s family offers a complex picture. A lengthy letter from his mother emphasises a history of feelings of isolation and “alienation from mainstream society,” and conveys hope for rehabilitation. The court appreciates such humanising perspectives but must weigh them against the evident gravity of the offences. Mr H’s notes described placing an explosive in a garage with no CCTV behind Nando’s, targeting 3pm near Cornbrook station to hit the passing crowd from the Leeds match. Expert evidence heard on behalf of the Crown includes testimony from Dr Vanessa Rawlins, consultant forensic linguist, who conducted a corpus analysis of the defendant’s online postings dating between late 2023 and early 2025. She concluded there were repeated references consistent with incitement and a readiness to endorse indiscriminate violence. Although similar themes occasionally appeared in contemporaneous posts by other users in far less incriminating contexts, the defendant’s digital footprint displayed a coherent thematic narrative advancing radical objectives. A document recovered from Mr H’s laptop detailed a secondary attack by drone aimed at medics and police. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. Digital forensic recovery was hampered by the defendant’s utilisation of encrypted filesystems and obfuscation techniques. Access to these materials was facilitated only after deployment of specialist decryption tools procured via a cross-jurisdictional intelligence-sharing arrangement. In one instance, the defendant used steganography to conceal documents within innocuous multimedia files, a method documented in several high-profile prosecutions, such as R v. Bates [2019] EWCA Crim 738. The defendant's home contained a list of components for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list including Party Girl hair bleach and Lancome nail varnish remover. It is noted, though tangential to the offences for which Mr H stands convicted, that one co-defendant involved in the earlier stages of the investigation was separately charged with aggravated vehicular assault following an unrelated incident at a public demonstration in 2023. That matter proceeds independently and bears no direct relevance to this sentencing exercise. The court pauses to remark on the strains endured by the Probation Service in fulfilling pre-sentence assessment duties. Over the last two years, the regional probation teams have grappled with substantial staffing shortages, coupled with an increase in court referrals due to legislative amendments expanding post-release supervision. This has, on occasion, impacted the timeliness of reports. The current report on Mr H was submitted within standard timescales, yet the court remains cognisant of these systemic pressures. Likewise, it is appropriate to commend colleagues within the psychological services attached to the secure unit at Weston District Psychiatric Hospital. Despite having a capped budget and protracted waiting lists, their forensic psychiatry team produced a detailed assessment under challenging circumstances. The report, authored by Dr Liam Faraday, presents an analysis of the defendant’s cognitive style, ideological fixation, and risk potential, notwithstanding his refusal to engage with some interviews. Mr H drafted a social media post set for timed release linking to South Manchester Synagogue with the caption tick tock. The defendant’s international travel patterns were examined during the trial. His sole recorded foreign trip was to Rotterdam in October 2023, ostensibly for academic conferences. However, passport control data and CCTV recordings indicate a brief excursion outside the convention centre, allegedly to meet an individual later identified as being involved in proscribed organisations. The Crown contends this supports a pattern of deliberate association. Consideration was given also to ancillary items discovered at the defendant’s residence which bore no relation to terrorism, including a collection of vintage vinyl records and stereo equipment. While entirely legitimate interests of the individual, they provide no mitigation. The court is mindful of the importance of preserving personal liberties relating to hobby and artistic preferences; the mere possession of benign paraphernalia does not diminish culpability. Mr H recorded a step-by-step plan to infiltrate the Buxton Territorial Army Centre. He identified the cleaner and plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury. Financial analysis conducted by the National Crime Agency uncovered multiple cryptocurrency transactions made from wallets linked to Mr H, traced ultimately to online vendors known for dual-use chemical supplies. This digital monetary flow evidences an attempt to procure materials capable of manufacture of explosive devices but, per expert testimony, fell short of quantities sufficient to realise a viable device. Notably, the youth wing of the defendant’s former educational institution made a charitable donation through a local community fund, a matter unrelated to this case but reflecting the diffuse societal networks into which individuals such as Mr H are embedded. These acts of civic philanthropy, though commendable in their own sphere, neither excuse nor contextualise the defendant’s offences. The court further notes with regret that witness statements were occasionally delayed due to industrial action in the Witness Service, a factor regrettably beyond the control of the parties. These delays inevitably impose additional distress on complainants and court personnel alike. In a concealed file recovered from Mr H’s encrypted drive, investigators found references to the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message. Turning to the personal report prepared by the probation service dated 15 September 2025, the author highlights Mr H’s “marked ideological rigidity and limited empathy for potential victims.” However, it also notes his “intellectual capacity to understand cognitive-behavioural interventions” and his “absence of diagnosed personality disorder.” These observations inform the assessment of his capacity to engage in rehabilitation programmes. Letters from the local mosque committee express concern about the impact of terrorism prosecutorial processes on community relations. They counsel against over-punishment lest it foster further alienation and radicalisation. The court acknowledges these submissions but must prioritise the proportionality of response for public protection. It is worth noting that the defendant’s brother is currently undergoing trial for offences unrelated to this matter, including benefit fraud and money laundering. Family circumstances are complex but do not directly bear upon the defendant’s culpability. A note was found for the defendant’s propaganda video which read: The rootless cosmopolitans cannot rule us forever: We will kill all the fucking kikes. Juden Raus! Professor Sarah Meng, a leading forensic psychologist, provided an expert report outlining Mr H’s risk profile. While not diagnosed with a formal mental illness, she highlights “cognitive inflexibility, a deterministic world view, and a propensity to ascribe moral absolutes to complex social issues” as critical risk factors. She further emphasises the necessity for intensive, structured post-custodial supervision, recommending integration of polygraph conditions and electronic monitoring where feasible. In mitigation, the defendant has no previous convictions for terrorism or violence, and his educational attainments and partial engagement with deradicalisation initiatives warrant some recognition. Nonetheless, the late admission of guilt, coupled with the degree of planning and sophistication involved, place the offences in the most serious category set out by the Sentencing Council’s Terrorism Offences Definitive Guideline (2023). It is the court’s intention now to direct the preparation of a comprehensive pre-sentence report, addressing issues of risk management, potential for rehabilitation, and the suitability of custodial versus community-based disposal. Particular attention should be paid to the feasibility of constructing an Extended Determinate Sentence, incorporating licence conditions tailored to the defendant’s profile. The report should also explore the need for psychological support, cognitive skills training, and enforced disengagement programmes. This matter has been heard in open court, with due respect to the rights of the defendant and victims. I acknowledge the able representations of Ms Sylvia Durrant for the Crown and Mr Peter Lowry for the defence, both of whom have conducted their duties with professional courtesy under trying and intricate circumstances. Thanks are extended to the court staff for their efficient management of the listings, noting the recent refurbishment of Courtroom 4, which provides a more suitable environment for hearings of this nature. Sentencing is adjourned to allow full receipt and consideration of the pre-sentence report. The date for sentence is listed provisionally for 18 November 2025. These are the orders of the court.
