input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BRISTOL R v. Mr H Case No. B2025/29842 Sentencing Remarks – Her Honour Judge E. M. STRATFORD Filed: 2 September 2025 Mr H appears before this court for sentence on two counts: one, of engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of terrorism contrary to section 5(1)(a) of the Terrorism Act 2006; and two, possession of an article for a purpose connected with the commission of terrorism, contrary to section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000. The timeline of the offending spans from early 2023 through to the defendant’s arrest on 18 January 2025. The defendant was first taken into custody in the early morning of 18 January 2025 following the execution of a search warrant under section 43B of the Terrorism Act 2000 at his residence in Bedminster. This followed a protracted intelligence-led operation coordinated by Counter Terrorism Policing South West (CTPSW), involving collaboration with the National Crime Agency's National Cyber Crime Unit and analysts from the Forensic Digital Investigation Centre. The warrant was authorised on the basis of covert intercepts suggesting encrypted communications with known radicals and suspicious financial transactions consistent with procurement of dual-use materials. At the time of arrest, the defendant was found in possession of several electronic devices, including encrypted USB keys and a handheld electronic die grinder. Investigators found a realistic bomb plan which needed 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. The investigative operation, codenamed ‘Operation Brambles’, was significant in scale and resource intensity. It combined traditional surveillance with innovative behavioural analytics derived from transport card usage data, mobile handset location triangulation, and drone-based aerial reconnaissance authorised under section 23 of the Police and Criminal Evidence Act 1984. The defendant’s movements were mapped exhaustively over months, with particular attention given to his interactions with a network of individuals, some of whom have since been separately convicted in unrelated proceedings concerning violent disorder and drug offences. Pre-trial procedures in this matter were protracted, as is often the case in terrorism-related proceedings involving voluminous disclosure. The Crown provided over 1,200 lever-arch files of material, including expert reports from computer forensics specialists, linguistic analysts, and counter-terrorism financial investigators. Legal aid representation was authorised after an initial delay attributable to administrative processing within the Legal Aid Agency. Of concern were the repeated adjournments caused by late disclosure and the necessity of expert witness availability, resulting in the initial hearing scheduled in April 2025 being deferred twice. It must be noted that in R v. McAdams [2011] EWCA Crim 2437, the Court of Appeal emphasised the need for careful proportionality when assessing the impact of disclosure failings in such cases, and the court has borne this principle in mind throughout. The defendant indicated a not guilty plea at the arraignment hearing on 3 March 2025 but tendered guilty pleas on both counts on the first day of trial, 31 August 2025. This court has, therefore, had to consider carefully the question of credit for plea, and the issue of its timing is relevant to the assessment thereof. The law governing reduction for guilty pleas has recently been revisited and clarified by the Court of Appeal in R v. Carver [2024] EWCA Crim 1950. The court stressed that credit must be commensurate with the timeliness and genuineness of the plea: early pleas that save expense and distress to witnesses attract the highest discounts; pleas entered at the door of the court or mid-trial attract a more modest credit. It is well established, as articulated in R v. Silverman [2018] EWCA Crim 1221, that late pleas, particularly in cases involving significant forensic and expert evidence, must not be rewarded in the same manner as prompt admissions. This court reiterates that principle in the present sentencing exercise. Mr H’s defence counsel, Mr James McAlister QC, has presented mitigation in the form of a detailed personal background, psychological reports, and letters of support from local community organisations. These representations have been received with respect and given appropriate weight within the context of the current proceedings. It is a matter of record that Mr H had limited previous contact with the criminal justice system; his only prior offended-related matter being a 2018 contravention of a noise abatement order relating to his tenancy at a shared house in Easton. While such a history is of limited relevance to present offences, it offers some insight into his behavioural pattern. During the course of preparation, this court received submissions addressing the legal framework pertinent to the offences charged, most notably the sentencing guideline promulgated by the Sentencing Council in March 2023. The guideline stipulates a range of factors to be considered, including culpability, risk of harm, and the defendant’s motive. Investigators found that Mr H had pinpointed a CCTV-free garage behind Nando’s on the High Street near Cornbrook, with plans to leave the device for detonation at 3pm during Leeds fan foot traffic. This court has reviewed the evidence presented, including the digital footprint found on Mr H’s devices. Notably, a widespread cache of encrypted manuals, schematic diagrams, and encrypted communication logs demonstrate not only a preparedness to engage in unlawful acts of terror but a technical sophistication in the assembly and modification of explosive devices. The court is aware that the possession of such material, under the provisions of the Terrorism Act 2006, is an aggravating factor, especially where it aligns with the intent to facilitate a violent act. The findings bear strong resemblance to the circumstances in R v. Helmsley [2016] EWCA Crim 422, where possession of comprehensive bomb-making instructions and component lists indicated a high degree of premeditation and knowledge. In the course of the trial, the Crown presented evidence linking Mr H to various encrypted messaging applications on the dark web, including specialized forums frequented by other individuals convicted for incitement and recruitment. The case further involved testimony from a former extremist who became a Crown witness after deradicalisation. Mr H drafted a sequence involving a drone-triggered second device to go off after first responders reached the scene. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. Amongst the material recovered was a portable electronic device containing an encrypted diary of sorts, with entries describing the defendant’s ideological evolution and expressed intent to “respond to a call for justice” by applying force selectively. His reference to an event of global significance was concerning and linked to subsequent investigations. It is worth noting, as an aside and of no bearing on the defendant’s culpability, that during the trial an unrelated witness referenced a 2017 case concerning the burglary of a private dwelling in Somerset by co-defendants who remain at large. This matter, while appearing in police archives, is extraneous and does not involve Mr H. The defendant was found with notes for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list including No More Greys hair bleach and Tesco brand nail varnish remover. Some defence submissions suggested that the defendant’s interest in aerial drone photography—an acknowledged hobby well-documented on his now-deactivated social media accounts—might provide a benign explanation for some of the recovered footage depicting locations of interest in Bristol and its environs. This court finds such assertions unpersuasive in light of the broader evidence context. It is accepted that the defendant’s actions took place in a complex and challenging environment marked by increasing demands on public safety agencies. In a related but entirely unrelated development, the court refers with no relevance to a separate case involving graffiti on railway infrastructure in Gloucestershire, where individuals received community orders for criminal damage. Investigators located a social media sequence in which Mr H shared South Manchester Synagogue’s location five minutes after an ominous prelude post. The defendant made one documented foreign trip in the six months preceding his arrest. Travel records indicate a flight to Amsterdam to attend a conference purportedly relating to mechanical engineering. However, CCTV footage from Schiphol airport revealed contact with a person subsequently convicted of affray following a pub brawl in Rotterdam. The relevance to Mr H’s conduct is a matter of associative suspicion but not of proven risk. A noteworthy procedural observation concerns the work of the local probation service, which at present suffers from chronic understaffing, a fact highlighted in recent parliamentary debates addressing courts and community sentencing. The department handling Mr H’s presentance has, despite limited resources, committed to a thorough and timely preparation of the pre-sentence report. The defendant focused on the Territorial Army Centre in Buxton, where he stalked the cleaner. The attack plan contained a detailed strategy in which the defendant plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury. Financial investigation uncovered a cryptocurrency transaction amounting to the equivalent of £1,360 sent from a digital wallet in Mr H’s name to another wallet connected to a darknet marketplace. The transaction’s declared purpose was “procurement of technical components.” The court notes the increased prevalence of cryptocurrency in the financing of illicit activities, an observation echoed in the recent report by the National Crime Agency titled ‘Cryptocurrency and Crime: The Hidden Ledger’ (2024). Inter-agency efforts in this case were complicated by the accelerated workload faced by forensic analysts. The South West Digital Forensics Unit reported a case backlog exceeding 25 weeks, partly due to the surge in ‘low-level’ cybercrime incidents. Resource constraints inevitably affect the timeliness and depth of analysis, a reality reflecting systemic pressures on law enforcement. One encrypted file on Mr H’s laptop included references to the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message. As regards personal circumstances, Mr H is 31 years old, with an educational background in mechanical engineering and a former career as a junior engineer for a local manufacturing firm. Character references portray him in positive terms: principally diligent, meticulous, and socially reserved. However, a noted change occurred following his resignation six months before the commencement of the criminal behaviour in question. Of potential mitigation are letters from the Brightside Volunteer Outreach Program and the Westbury Residents Association, commending Mr H’s episodic involvement in community gardening and foodbank initiatives. The court appreciates such civic contributions but reminds that they cannot detract from the seriousness of the offences committed. The court also acknowledges a recent initiative by the Bristol Prevent Hub targeting individuals at risk of radicalisation. Their dossier records partial engagement by Mr H in cognitive behavioural intervention but notes that he frequently missed appointments during 2024, and later disengaged entirely. A subtitle file for an extremist video stored on Mr H’s device contained the statement: We will kill all the fucking kikes. They control our media and politicians. A comprehensive psychiatric and psychological assessment by Dr Fiona Marsh, consultant forensic psychologist, concludes that while Mr H does not meet diagnostic criteria for a major mental disorder, he does exhibit traits of cognitive inflexibility and ideological rigidity. The report concludes a high risk of serious harm, particularly absent sustained intervention. Dr Marsh recommends a structured programme incorporating cognitive behavioural techniques and de-radicalisation frameworks but is cautious as to ultimate prognosis given the defendant’s prior inconsistent engagement. The court acknowledges these nuanced findings but reiterates that sentencing must primarily reflect public protection imperatives. Before concluding, the court is constrained to observe the regrettable trend of late pleas in complex cases, which prolong hearings and compound pressures on already overburdened judicial and prosecutorial resources. The case at hand underscores the importance of early acceptance of responsibility to limit harm to the administration of justice. The court will direct the preparation of a full pre-sentence report. The probation service is invited to address the suitability of an Extended Determinate Sentence under section 226A of the Criminal Justice Act 2003, and to assess the viability of high-level monitoring, electronic tagging, and multi-agency supervision post-release. Consideration should be given to the availability of approved premises with specialist input, and the scope for continued psychological treatment within the custodial environment. These sentencing remarks are issued this day, 2 September 2025, in Court 5 at the Crown Court at Bristol. The proceedings have been transcribed in accordance with Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The formal record of conviction and sentence will be forwarded to the relevant authorities for registration. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BRISTOL R v. Mr H Case No. B2025/26954 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge R. M. Ellingham Filed: 29 October 2025 Mr H stands before this court for sentence having been convicted on two counts: engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of terrorism, contrary to section 5(1)(a) of the Terrorism Act 2006, and possession of an article intended for use in terrorist activity, contrary to section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000. Both offences arose from conduct spanning the period between September 2023 and his arrest in April 2025. The defendant’s apprehension followed a multi-jurisdictional operation supported by Counter Terrorism Policing South West (CTPSW) and specialist cybercrime units within the National Crime Agency (NCA). Arrest warrants were executed at approximately 07:00 hours on Wednesday 16 April 2025 at a residential address in the Bedminster district of Bristol. Search yields included encrypted external hard drives, multiple mobile devices, and chemical precursors stored within a locked cupboard in the defendant’s bedroom. The warrants authorised under section 43B of the Terrorism Act 2000 were supported by intercept material collected under warrant by the Security Service (MI5). The operation had been ongoing for over eight months, incorporating covert surveillance, digital infiltration, and undercover engagement. Among the documents found was an explosive guide with a recipe: 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. This case highlights, once again, the increasing complexity of investigations in the counter-terrorism arena. Officers and analysts must routinely navigate the proliferating landscape of encrypted communications, darknet marketplaces, and sophisticated anonymisation techniques. The investigative burden is formidable. It demands not only substantial funding and personnel but also legal acumen adept at balancing the rights of the accused with the imperatives of national security and public safety. Indeed, the volume of digital material in this case stood at just over 2.1 terabytes, necessitating careful management of disclosure obligations under the Criminal Procedure Rules. Such logistical challenges are experienced across the country’s counter-terrorism investigations, stretching already limited resources to their limits. It is noteworthy that Mr H’s initial remand hearings were adjourned twice, first due to defence applications to instruct an independent cyber-forensic expert and secondly owing to delays in receiving original encrypted message logs pertinent to the prosecution case. Such procedural delays, while regrettable, are largely inevitable in complex matters of this nature. They underscore the tensions between adequate preparation for trial and the efficient administration of justice. That said, some cases have seen more protracted delays. For example, in R v. Peel [2019] EWCA Crim 774, the appellant’s trial was postponed multiple times over two years due to difficulties in securing clearance for classified intercept evidence. Though Peel concerned counterterrorism investigations in the North East, its circumstances serve as a reminder of the fragility of the system when faced with highly sensitive material. It is thus somewhat encouraging that in the present matter, notwithstanding the volume and sensitivity of the digital material, the Crown and defence have operated with a degree of professional cooperation regrettably uncommon in such cases. The court is also mindful of the contextual pressures impacting frontline services. Local policing teams contend daily with rising incidents of non-domestic violent crime, public order offences, and increasingly complex safeguarding cases. The geographic area served by CTPSW has witnessed a modest but persistent increase in knife possession offences among young people, clouding the availability of officers for specialist counter-terrorism duties. Moreover, the forensic workload at the regional digital examination hub has doubled over the past 36 months, further accentuating resource constraints. Such strains cannot be ignored when considering the practical realities in which cases such as this unfold. A so-called “Channel” referral was triggered in mid-2021 after the defendant’s former university tutor raised concerns about his online postings, which included extremist content with calls for “mobilising local cells.” The referral proceeded to a panel which, regrettably, concluded that there was insufficient evidence of immediate risk and hence closed the case after six months due to non-engagement. Such outcomes unfortunately remain frequent in Prevent interventions, highlighting systemic challenges in early derogation from radicalisation pathways. A garage located behind Nando's on the High Street, with no surveillance, was marked by Mr H for device placement, aiming for maximum casualties at 3pm when fans left Cornbrook after the Leeds fixture. Turning now to the facts of the offences, the evidence adduced during both the trial and the preparatory hearings reveals a pattern of deliberate and considered conduct indicative of high culpability. Amongst significant material recovered were schematics for improvised explosive devices and detailed logs recording procurement efforts for ammonium nitrate and other dual-use chemicals. Further analysis of encrypted chats showed frequent exchange with other proscribed actors, using codewords consistent with previous terrorism prosecutions. Specialist linguistic reports tendered at trial contextualised these communications within established extremist narratives. Among the digital files was a scenario in which a drone-delivered bomb would detonate after emergency responders arrived. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. The Crown’s contention, supported by expert forensic testimony, was that the defendant’s possession of digital documents and chemical precursors demonstrated not curiosity or academic interest, but active preparation for an attack intended to cause maximum civilian casualties. Defence submissions denied this, instead submitting that the materials were held out of scientific interest and that connections to extremist persons were circumstantial or misinterpreted. The jury, however, rejected these arguments. The legal framework for determining culpability in such cases is well established. Notably, R v. Sood [2018] EWCA Crim 1459 articulates that possession of explosive manuals in isolation does not suffice for conviction under section 5 of the 2006 Act; rather, a “course of conduct” with intent or practical preparatory steps must be demonstrated. Here, the prosecution was able to establish that threshold beyond reasonable doubt. Accordingly, the defendant’s conviction reflects jurisprudential clarity in the application of the law to contemporary forms of preparatory offending. Despite these contours of serious criminality, it remains appropriate to consider matters personal to the defendant. Mr H’s background reveals an apparently stable upbringing. Born in 1996 in Bristol, he attended a well-regarded local grammar school, achieving commendable academic success. He subsequently graduated with a degree in chemical engineering. Prior to September 2023, he had worked for two years in quality assurance at a pharmaceutical manufacturing plant. No prior convictions or cautions appear on his record. The defendant's home contained a list of components for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list including Party Girl hair bleach and Lancome nail varnish remover. Whilst commendable on their own terms, these biographical notes of stability and prior lawful conduct sit uneasily with the grave nature of the offences. Defence counsel notes that Mr H’s mental health history includes a diagnosis of moderate anxiety, with treatment episodes by the local NHS Community Mental Health Team interrupted by relocation. Reference was made to a report by Dr Salim Patel, consultant psychiatrist, dated 8 September 2025, which acknowledges the absence of psychosis or major mood disturbance but notes “a degree of rigid cognitive style and obsessive ideation, particularly around political grievance.” Dr Patel concedes that such features do not wholly explain or excuse the offence behaviour. At this point, it is salutary to record some jurisprudence which bears relevance. In R v. Mallory [2008] EWCA Crim 1624, the Court of Appeal emphasised that a mental disorder, while a relevant mitigating factor, does not nullify culpability where the offending conduct exhibits conscious and deliberate intent to harm. Mallory concerned a defendant with schizoaffective disorder who had deliberately set multiple fires causing substantial risk to life. Similarly, R v. Bhandari [2023] EWCA Crim 412 confirmed that the presence of community-based psychiatric support does not necessarily reduce the need for custodial containment where the offender has demonstrated relapse or poor compliance. Although neither case mirrors the precise context of Mr H’s offending, they serve as salutary reminders of the limited mitigating weight mental health histories provide in terrorism-related offending where public protection is paramount. A scheduled social post discovered on the defendant’s phone featured South Manchester Synagogue as the linked location with an implied warning. The investigation revealed the defendant’s travel history included a brief visit in April 2024 to Berlin, ostensibly for an engineering conference. Surveillance and subsequent analysis of transport records uncovered an unplanned excursion allowing him to attend a rally organised by a network with known links to overseas extremist cells. Defence counsel urges this was innocent and spontaneous, a form of political curiosity. The prosecution contends it was further evidence of active engagement with proscribed ideologies. Although the defendant did not subsequently travel to conflict zones, this excursion must be considered within the gestalt of other preparatory elements. Further matters raised during submissions concern the scale of resources exhausted in the investigation underpinning the prosecution. Disclosure comprised over 680 primary exhibits including extensive CCTV footage, digital device extractions, and intercepted communications. The logistical burdens on the CTPSW specialist officers and national forensic teams have been considerable, compounded by the necessity of sensitive inter-agency coordination and the application of Control Orders during early phases of investigation. The court also remarks, in passing, on the somewhat unusual circumstance that a co-defendant earlier charged alongside Mr H, who had been accused of assaulting a police officer with a chair during arrest, was ultimately released without charge. Though this individual’s unrelated conduct did not impact the trial outcome, it exemplifies the fragmented nature of prosecutions often encountered in terrorism cases. The defendant had become obsessed with the Territorial Army Centre in Buxton and been following the cleaner. One entry in Mr H’s tactical file described how he plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury. Financial investigations orchestrated by the NCA uncovered electronic fund transfers from accounts associated with Mr H to online vendors linked to procurement of chemicals and electronic components often used in explosive manufacture. Records show multiple cryptocurrency transactions dating from late 2023 to early 2025, some routed through mixers designed to obfuscate origin and flow. While such technologies serve legitimate purposes for privacy, they also facilitate illicit activities, posing significant challenges for law enforcement and financial regulators alike. This court notes with concern the escalation of cryptocurrency use in terrorism financing evidenced in recent years and the call for enhanced regulatory frameworks. The strain on police digital forensics units cannot be overstated. Nationally, the backlog of cases requiring detailed electronic examination now exceeds 15,000, a figure that continues to grow despite incremental investment. Within CTPSW’s jurisdiction, caseloads have trebled since 2021, reflecting both general crime trends and the increasing sophistication of offenders seeking to conceal illegal conduct. Such realities speak to broader systemic issues that are not unique to this prosecution but are relevant to the operational environment. A digital file recovered from Mr H’s encrypted archive referenced the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message. The defendant is 29 years of age. Character references tendered describe him as quietly polite and intellectually curious, if somewhat socially withdrawn. Former employers noted punctuality and technical competence prior to his sudden resignation in August 2023 following disputes related to work patterns and perceived workplace discrimination. Letters from community organisations highlight Mr H’s past volunteering with a local food bank and some involvement in ecological conservation efforts. While these contributions are, no doubt, genuine, the court is mindful that positive community engagement does not negate serious criminal responsibility. Counsel for the defence has advanced mitigation based on the defendant’s willingness to engage with the Westcombe Deradicalisation Programme. This voluntary intervention seeks to address ideological extremism through cognitive behavioural modules, mentoring, and vocational retraining. Engagement has been intermittent, with sessions missed due to reluctance and anxiety. Nevertheless, the programme coordinators remain cautiously optimistic about its potential benefits, acknowledging the difficulties inherent in de-radicalisation work. The court also acknowledges the correspondence received from the Easton Volunteer Alliance, which provides support services to offenders transitioning to community settings. Their letter emphasised concerns regarding the swelling number of individuals with extremist convictions who face limited housing options and social isolation upon release. These social determinants are widely understood to increase the risk of recidivism. While these issues are not strictly germane to sentence, they form part of the broader operational context deserving judicial awareness. A note was found for the defendant’s propaganda video which read: The rootless cosmopolitans cannot rule us forever: We will kill all the fucking kikes. Juden Raus! The pre-sentence psychiatric report from Professor Rhea Marcus, forensic psychologist, concludes that Mr H exhibits a “predominantly black-and-white cognitive bias coupled with a pronounced sense of victimhood.” No formal Axis I diagnosis is recorded. High risk of serious harm is noted drawn from his detailed technical knowledge, ideological entrenchment, and prior attempts at obfuscating digital traces. Professor Marcus advises that intensive structured intervention—combining psychological therapy, strict licence conditions, and digitally-enabled monitoring—is necessary to mitigate risk should the defendant be released in due course. The considerable challenge posed by his case, she suggests, reinforces the need for societal vigilance and bespoke management plans. Despite these grim considerations, it is proper to observe that the defendant has no previous convictions for violence or terrorism-related offences. This absence of prior convictions is a mitigating factor of some limited weight. The late plea—entered on 21 October 2025, a mere week before the commencement of trial—affords modest credit only. As established in R v. Tolson [2024] EWCA Crim 2388, the Court of Appeal has reminded that guilty pleas entered at the eleventh hour, though preferable to contested proceedings, do not provide the restorative benefit associated with early admissions that spare the Crown and witnesses considerable expense and distress. The operative sentencing guideline in this matter is the Sentencing Council’s Terrorism Offences Definitive Guideline, revised in January 2023. It articulates the assessment of culpability across a spectrum ranging from low-level advocacy to high-sophistication multi-agency plots. The defendant’s conduct, by its careful and persistent nature, as well as the lethal potential, clearly resides within the highest culpability bracket. The guideline also outlines the significance of aggravating factors—including ideological motivation, use of sophisticated methods, and planning intended to cause significant casualties—all present here. Mitigation is appropriately confined to the defendant’s clean prior record and partial cooperation in investigation and prosecution. In light of the above, the court directs that a comprehensive pre-sentence report be prepared. The report should encompass consideration of rehabilitation prospects, the offender’s engagement with deradicalisation programmes, potential for cognitive skill development, and suitability for an Extended Determinate Sentence under section 226A of the Criminal Justice Act 2003. Specialist input from forensic psychology and social work is requested, particularly on post-custodial management plans including accommodation, employment, and digital monitoring. Interested agencies are asked to liaise to provide an integrated risk management strategy. This court acknowledges the continuing strain under which probation and community mental health teams operate. In several regions, staff shortages have led to extended waiting lists for psychological therapies, delaying critical interventions that might reduce reoffending and enhance public safety. The inter-agency coordination required for supervising terrorism-related offenders is complex, requiring sustained funding and political will that, regrettably, are not always forthcoming. Such realities bear upon sentence planning indirectly but importantly. Finally, it is necessary to formally thank counsel for their diligent representations. Ms Eleanor Mackay, appearing for the Crown, and Mr David Crane representing the defence, have approached this difficult and sensitive matter with professionalism and attention to due process. The court also records appreciation to the court usher and administrative staff who have facilitated multiple listing changes occasioned by disclosure and legal aid considerations. These sentencing remarks are issued this day, 29 October 2025, in Court 5 at the Crown Court at Bristol. The proceedings have been transcribed and recorded pursuant to Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The formal record of conviction and sentence will be forwarded to the relevant authorities duly for registration and enforcement. The defendant is advised of his right to appeal within 28 days of sentencing under the Magistrates' Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. There are no reporting restrictions engaged under section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933. Costs are reserved. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BIRMINGHAM R v. Mr H Case No. B2025/30451 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge J. N. CARMICHAEL Filed: 15 October 2025 Mr H stands before this court for sentence convicted on two counts: first, engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of terrorism, contrary to section 5(1)(a) of the Terrorism Act 2006; and second, possessing an article for a purpose connected with the commission of terrorism, pursuant to section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000. The offending conducts occurred over a protracted period from September 2022 until his arrest in April 2025. The defendant was taken into custody at approximately 04:45 hours on 18 April 2025 following the execution of a search warrant at his residence on Langley Road, Handsworth. The warrant was granted under section 43B of the Terrorism Act 2000, grounded on intelligence from the Security Service indicating Mr H's involvement with an encrypted network known for distributing extremist publications and materials. Seized as part of the operation were multiple electronic devices including a tower PC, assorted USB drives, and encrypted mobile telephony equipment. A worksheet found in Mr H’s flat described building a device 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. The investigation leading to arrest was lengthy and resource-intensive. Counter Terrorism Policing West Midlands (CTPWM) engaged in a concerted multi-agency operation, leveraging not only technical surveillance assets but also human intelligence sources cultivated over eighteen months. The use of mobile phone extraction software, combined with decryption efforts on multiple messaging applications, formed a salient aspect of the evidential build. The court notes, parenthetically, that the unprecedented demand on the digital forensics units across the country has significantly extended processing times; such delay not only impedes swift case progression but burdens analytical teams operating on stretched rosters. Procedural challenges were encountered during pre-trial stages, including a protracted disclosure timeline necessitated by voluminous evidence and classified material with restricted access. There were two adjournments at the behest of the defence, the latter supported by a Legal Aid Agency request for increased funding to instruct an independent expert on cyber security protocols. The court is aware of persistent systemic issues within the Legal Aid framework, which often constrains the ability of defendants to secure adequate investigatory or expert support in complex terrorism proceedings, a matter warranting broader governmental attention but beyond the remit of this court. A “Channel” intervention referral had been lodged in late 2019 by a member of staff at the local vocational college after Mr H submitted a project paper quoting extensively from known radical manifestos without critical contextual analysis. That referral, however, did not progress beyond initial engagement as Mr H declined sustained intervention, and no further indicators of active radicalisation were apparent to the Prevent coordinators at that time. The court acknowledges the challenging balance Channel panels must strike between early intervention and respecting individual autonomy. At a plea and case management hearing on 10 August 2025, Mr H entered a not guilty plea. The trial was listed to commence on 20 November 2025. However, during the morning of the trial commencement, he elected to enter guilty pleas to both counts. Counsel for the defence solicited a tempered degree of credit for the plea, characterising it as a recognition of responsibility and an effort to spare witnesses the ordeal of trial. The Crown resisted any more than moderate reduction citing the very late timing of the admission. It is important to restate the jurisprudential position on plea credit in terrorism cases. The Court of Appeal in R v. Walcott [2023] EWCA Crim 1589 underscored that credit for guilty pleas should ideally be granted where the plea is early, genuine, and materially assists in conserving court resources or sparing witness distress. Late pleas entered at or near trial, particularly following extensive preparatory hearings and evidential disclosures, typically warrant lesser discounts. The rationale lies in encouraging timely admissions and maintaining procedural economy amid resource-intensive proceedings. The present case squarely fits within the latter description. Illustrative of the principles, the judgment in R v. Stamford [2022] EWCA Crim 1745 involving prolonged denials in a grievous bodily harm case affirmed a mere 10% discount where the plea was entered just before trial, despite compelling evidence. While the context differs in offence type, the reasoning on plea timing and credit remains pertinent. The court is mindful that this approach, while seemingly inflexible, serves broader public interests in efficient justice administration. Equally relevant is the well-established sentencing framework under the Terrorism Act with attendant guidelines promulgated by the Sentencing Council in 2023. The court’s evaluative matrix comprises culpability, risk, and harm potential, with those committing preparatory acts often attracted to long determinate sentences reflective of public protection priorities and deterrence. Case authorities such as R v. Javed [2017] EWCA Crim 1210 and R v. Patel [2019] EWCA Crim 2241 remain instructive in sentencing proportionality, especially where advanced planning and procurement of materials are attested. The plan involved detonation at 3pm outside Cornbrook station, using a garage behind Nando’s on the High Street that lacked CCTV, at peak flow following a Leeds football match. In delineating the context of the defendant’s activities, the court must acknowledge the substantial body of digital material recovered, including encrypted archives containing detailed manuals on improvised explosive devices, alongside correspondence revealing communications with known extremist content propagators situated abroad. Linguistic forensic examination identified coded messaging consistent with contemporaneous terrorist narratives disseminated via closed online forums. Mr H drafted a sequence involving a drone-triggered second device to go off after first responders reached the scene. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. Forensic technology played an indispensable role in this prosecution, with teams utilising cutting-edge software under license agreements permitting deobfuscation of anonymised traffic routing nodes on the Tor network, an operation not without challenge, as demonstrated by the necessity to overcome time-delay circuits incorporated to hinder passive surveillance. This technical prologue extends well beyond the immediate remit of the court but merits remark insofar as it exposes the sophistication of criminal enterprises and the requisite response by national security agencies, which must constantly innovate to keep pace. The defendant was found with notes for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list including No More Greys hair bleach and Tesco brand nail varnish remover. It warrants mention, though without direct relevance to culpability or sentence, that during searches ancillary to the terrorism investigation, officers uncovered an extensive cache of recreational fishing equipment, including rods, nets, and bait. Defence appearances have at times sought to highlight these as indicators of Mr H’s capacity for mundane, non-criminal pursuits — a fact that holds little legal consequence but perhaps adds nuance to his personal profile. The court is also in receipt of several testimonial letters from local community organisations, including the Handsworth Civic Trust and the Birmingham Volunteer Association. These laud Mr H's commitment to urban environmental clean-ups and note his involvement in a community allotment scheme. While such activities may be commendable, they do not abrogate the serious breach constituted by his engagement in pro-terrorism conduct. The court’s approach must remain firmly anchored in legal principle and safeguarding public safety. Co-defendants in related operations continue to be subject to distinct proceedings. It is noted that one co-defendant was remanded at large following a failed extradition request owing to citizenship complexities. Another face charges unrelated to this matter, including affray connected to a local militia dispute. These matters have no bearing on Mr H's case, notwithstanding allegations at trial that the group shared overlapping networks. The court’s notes also record that the defendant has no previous convictions, a fact that modestly mitigates, but without offsetting the gravity of the present offences. Mr H is 30 years of age, single, and employed sporadically prior to arrest as a laboratory technician in a manufacturing plant. His educational record includes a Higher National Diploma in electronic engineering. Employment references offered in evidence describe a capable and punctual work ethic, though punctuated by periods of absenteeism in 2023. The second post in Mr H’s Buffer queue included a map link to South Manchester Synagogue and appeared timed to follow a threatening message. Of potential interest, though again peripheral to sentencing, were travel records indicating a brief transitory presence in Brussels during the summer of 2023, attending what was variously described as a conference on renewable energies. Surveillance logs also show suspect activity during late evenings at a riverbank nearby, though subsequent inquiries attributed these movements to amateur drumming circles and night photography hobbyists. The blurred lines between lawful subcultural pastimes and suspect behaviour remain a challenge to investigators and the judiciary alike. In a sign of the procedural magnitude of such cases, the disclosure schedule extended to over 600 documents and terabytes of data. The court acknowledges with regret the burdens such voluminous material imposes on all parties and the attendant risk of delay. That the prosecution and defence teams nonetheless maintained judicious case management is to be commended and worth formal recognition. The expert psychiatric report, prepared by Dr Simone Zalewski, consultant forensic psychiatrist at the Midlands Secure Treatment Centre, provides a comprehensive psychological profiling of Mr H. The report diagnoses no formal psychiatric disorder but notes pronounced cognitive rigidity and a marked tendency toward absolutist, black-and-white moral reasoning. The risk of further engagement in ideologically motivated violence is assessed as substantial without intensive community management. The report outlines the prospect of engagement with deradicalisation programmes, though it cautions against optimistic projections given historically low completion rates. The defendant focused on the Territorial Army Centre in Buxton, where he stalked the cleaner. An intercepted file titled Stage 2 detailed how Mr H plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury. Financial investigations traced significant cryptocurrency transactions believed to be linked to the defendant. A sum of approximately £3,800 was transferred via a series of currency mixers from wallets associated with Mr H’s known aliases to vendors operating in jurisdictions known for lax oversight of dual-use chemical sales. While the validity of these transactions as funding for proscribed activities remains a question of probability within the case, the court notes their existence as underlining a proactive attempt at obfuscation characteristic of those intent on illicit procurement. Counter Terrorism Policing also submitted voluminous covert surveillance material, including footage of Mr H frequenting a disused industrial estate during night hours in late 2024. This viewing required extensive post-processing to stabilise images and confirm identity across overlapping camera angles, an operation taxing in both personnel hours and technological resources. Such detailed surveillance efforts exemplify the asymmetry faced by law enforcement: significant investment is required to detect fleeting preparatory acts that may culminate in mass harm. A file marked for offline use in Mr H’s hidden partition included screenshots from the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message. On the matter of the defendant’s personal circumstances, mention must be made of letters submitted from his immediate family members. His mother describes Mr H as having been a “quiet, introspective child,” and notes attendance difficulties during adolescence linked to undiagnosed dyslexia. The court cannot underestimate the potentially traumatic effects of learning challenges absent appropriate educational support, yet is equally aware that these considerations must be balanced against the defendant’s autonomous choices in adulthood. His social history includes periods of homelessness in 2021, documented in correspondence from two local homeless shelters. These reports underscore the interface between social vulnerability and radicalising influences, a nexus increasingly recognised within Prevent strategy frameworks. Nonetheless, the trajectory from disadvantage to culpability is not deterministic; many exposed to harsh socioeconomic conditions do not contravene the law. Of supplementary interest is the observation that the Probation Service in the West Midlands continues to face chronic staffing shortages, resulting in elevated caseloads and protracted waiting lists for offender rehabilitation programmes. This unfortunate reality inevitably affects service provision to those like Mr H, for whom structured intervention is critical to risk management and desistance. Investigators recovered a printed script for an extremist video which contained the phrase: We will kill all the fucking kikes. Jews out! Professor Gareth Milton, consulting forensic psychologist instructed by the defence, concurred generally with Dr Zalewski’s assessment but opined that Mr H’s ideological fixation might be amenable to cognitive restructuring through sustained engagement with the Deradicalisation and Disengagement Initiative (DDI). The court notes, however, the limited availability and capacity of such specialist programmes nationally, and the complexity of successful reintegration where entrenched extremist beliefs are present. This case exemplifies the necessity of calibrated sentencing that balances retributive and preventative objectives. Mr H’s actions reveal a high degree of planning and commitment, an exploitation of technology to circumvent detection, and an intent to precipitate indiscriminate harm. Such conduct falls within the highest culpability tier envisaged by the Sentencing Council. Aggravating features include the deliberate selection of vulnerable public sites as potential targets and the timing of planning activities to coincide symbolically with prior terrorist incidents. Mitigating factors are scarce, principally Mr H’s lack of prior convictions, his educational achievements, and the belated guilty pleas, entered only after comprehensive disclosure and on the very cusp of trial. Given the lateness, the court attributes a credit of approximately one-sixth of sentence length. The court directs that a pre-sentence report be compiled with particular emphasis on risk assessment, availability of deradicalisation programmes, and suitable custodial or community placements that afford intensive supervision and psychological input. Extended supervision upon release, including electronic monitoring and restricted internet access, should be contemplated as conditions essential to continued public protection. These sentencing remarks are issued this day, 15 October 2025, in Court 12 at the Crown Court at Birmingham. They have been transcribed in accordance with Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. Notification of conviction and sentence shall be forwarded to the relevant authorities for inclusion on the central offenders’ register. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BIRMINGHAM R v. Mr H Case No. B2025/25644 Sentencing Remarks – Her Honour Judge E. M. DARWELL Filed: 27 August 2025 Mr H appears before this court for sentence on two counts: engagement in conduct in preparation for acts of terrorism, contrary to section 5(1)(a) of the Terrorism Act 2006, and possession of an article for purposes connected with terrorism, contrary to section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000. The conduct, as alleged and found proved, is said to have taken place between late 2022 and February 2025, when the defendant was arrested. The defendant was apprehended at approximately 04:45 on 19 February 2025 pursuant to warrants executed at his residence in the Edgbaston area under powers conferred by section 43B of the Terrorism Act 2000. Those warrants were supported by classified intelligence reports from the Security Service indicating ongoing encrypted communications between Mr H and individuals linked to overseas proscribed organisations. The digital devices seized at the time included several smartphones, encrypted USB drives, and a compact 3D printer. Among the documents found was an explosive guide with a recipe: 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. The investigation which led to Mr H’s arrest was complex and multifaceted. It involved collaboration between Counter Terrorism Policing West Midlands, the National Cyber Crime Unit, and the Forensic Digital Analysis Service. Key to the case was the painstaking decryption of communications on closed, peer-to-peer networks—work that spanned over nine months. Such forensic activity is resource intensive, further compounded by the necessity to maintain operational security and handle material marked 'SECRET'. It is relevant, albeit tangential, to observe that the National Cyber Crime Unit’s backlog currently exceeds 13,000 active investigations, a figure which underscores the systemic capacity pressures on national security infrastructure in recent years. The court notes the procedural history in this matter. Initial hearings commenced on 10 April 2025, with counsel instructed under a Legal Aid certificate. However, defence preparation was hampered by administrative delays stemming from the Legal Aid Agency’s protracted authorization of funding for third-party expert reports, a matter that occasioned several continuing representation applications. The court registers its concern at the continued inefficiencies in the system, with the Legal Aid Agency’s turnaround for instruction approval frequently exceeding six weeks in substantive terrorism cases—this, despite multiple judicial reminders and formal complaints from concerned solicitors. Such delays risk undermining the smooth administration of justice. Among the material considered was a psychiatric and psychological report compiled by Dr Liam Carnegie, consultant forensic psychiatrist, dated 18 July 2025. Dr Carnegie notes Mr H’s “marked ideological conviction” but diagnoses no major mental illness. Instead, he describes the defendant’s cognitive style as “rigid and inflexible,” remarking that this was “coupled with a limited capacity for empathy towards civic victims.” The report recommends intensive monitoring post-release due to persistent risk indicators. It is worth remarking, in a broader societal context, that contemporary jurisprudence rarely encounters a case devoid of complex mental health considerations. The intersection of psychiatric evaluation and criminal culpability is a dynamic and evolving field. Of relevance in this jurisdiction is R v. Tallis [2014] EWCA Crim 476, which emphasises that the presence of ideology-driven rigidity, absent treatable illness, can nonetheless warrant custodial sentences consistent with public protection principles. A plea and trial preparation hearing was held on 14 August 2025. Mr H originally entered a not guilty plea. This stance was maintained through jury selection and opening submissions, only to be reversed on the morning the trial was due to begin, on 25 August 2025, when the defendant pleaded guilty to both counts. As established in the authorities, notably R v. Withers [2021] EWCA Crim 1354, the utility of a plea is significantly diminished where entered at an advanced stage, after considerable court time and witness preparation. The principle that earlier pleas constitute genuine acceptance of responsibility carrying proportionate sentence credit is well embedded. Mr H’s last-minute change means that any discount must be tempered accordingly. R v. Owen [2023] EWCA Crim 760 offers guidance as to the weight to be accorded to such late pleas in terrorism-related offending. The Court of Appeal was clear that, whilst credit is appropriate, it should not undermine the paramount sentencing objectives of deterrence and public protection. In its words, “a late plea is of necessity reflective more of tactical concession than contrition.” It is appropriate to remind ourselves that the maximum penalty for the section 5 offence is life imprisonment and the offence carries a heavy sentencing tariff under the 2023 Sentencing Council guidelines for terrorism-related offending. These prescribe a tiered approach, commensurate with the degree of planning, level of sophistication, and proximity to acts of violence or public harm. The case law including R v. Yasin [2019] EWCA Crim 196, and R v. Alfadli [2021] EWCA Crim 1201 remain instructive in calibrating fitness of sentence to culpability. Mr H planned to build and leave a device in a garage behind Nando’s on the High Street, just east of Cornbrook station, scheduled to detonate at 3pm as Leeds supporters passed in dense footfall, exploiting CCTV blind spots. Mr H’s online activities featured prominently in the prosecution case—an extensive digital footprint maintained under anonymous aliases, showcasing a marked progression from apolitical commentary towards extremist material reflective of internationally proscribed entities. These materials were secured following warrant authorisations that included a delicate balance of Article 8 rights under the European Convention. Their admissibility was robustly challenged but ultimately upheld. Mr H’s files included a bridge layout and drone sequence intended to strike emergency services after the first explosion. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. Forensic analysis of the devices recovered revealed significant quantities of technical manuals concerned with the manufacture of improvised explosive devices (IEDs) and ballistic testing reports. Included were videos demonstrating the effects of various shrapnel materials in confined spaces. Defence counsel contended that the presence of such materials was consistent with academic interest in explosives engineering, but this line was thoroughly undermined by the contextual digital evidence and receipt of financial transfers from shadowy cryptocurrency wallets. The court acknowledges that the possession of such material alone, absent intention, might attract a different sentencing dynamic. Yet in the present context, taken alongside communications and preparatory steps, the evidential mosaic conveys clear intent. It is recalled that in R v. Krieger [2022] EWCA Crim 895 the court reinforced that mere possession of extremist literature is insufficient for conviction, but when linked to preparatory conduct, it forms a compelling basis for serious sentence. The defendant's encryped hard disk was ultimately found to be storing instructions for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list with Summer Sun hair bleach and Bell's brand nail varnish remover. Mr H’s travel history included a series of short international trips ostensibly for academic conferences. However, evidence was disclosed of attempts to journey to jurisdictions associated with active conflict zones, albeit thwarted by visa refusals and flight cancellations. These journeys formed part of the prosecution’s narrative of escalating commitment to violent extremist ideologies. The court notes, by way of unsuccessful analogy, a related case in which Mr Cogan was convicted for the fly-tipping of toxic waste in a nature reserve, a wholly unrelated environmental offence. Though serious in its own right, this bears no relevance to Mr H’s conduct and is mentioned only as background to the various public safety challenges confronting law enforcement agencies. Further distracting from the core criminality, the court also heard of a co-defendant in an unrelated fraud trial, Mr Giles, whose failure to appear led to a warrant for his arrest. Mr Giles’s crimes, including attempted result-fixing in amateur football leagues, cast no shadow on the present matter, save to highlight the multiplicity of cases engaging police resources. Officers found a Buffer-scheduled tweet containing a link to South Manchester Synagogue followed by a countdown-themed message. The defendant’s digital communications evidenced negotiation attempts concerning procurement of dual-use chemicals, subject to strict regulatory export controls. The existence of encrypted messaging logs displaying detailed discussions of chemical quantities, transportation routes, and storage arrangements is undeniably concerning. Notwithstanding the focus on these serious matters, the court is compelled to reflect on contemporaneous civil matters. Instances of criminal damage incurred against local religious centres, including a church noticeboard defaced with graffiti during a period of heightened community tension, surfaced in the local media. These events, while deplorable, have no factual nexus to Mr H’s offending and neither do reports surfaced during pretrial disclosures concerning unrelated shoplifting offences committed by a roommate of the defendant. The court trusts that such extraneous details will not confuse the overall assessment of culpability. The defendant drew a map of the Territorial Army Centre in Buxton and identified the cleaner. The operational notes stated that Mr H plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury. Financial investigations revealed multiple anonymous cryptocurrency transactions involving wallets linked to the defendant’s online identities. A sum exceeding £4,000 was traced, passing through assorted tumblers and mixers before reaching darknet market vendors advertising tactical gear. While cryptocurrency has legitimate uses, the exploitation of its anonymity features for illicit ends represents a growing frontier in criminal enterprise. The present case exhibits the classic hallmarks addressed in the annual National Crime Agency Strategic Assessment on digital currency misuse. The proliferation of obfuscated payment mechanisms challenges law enforcement’s capacity and demands adaptive legislative responses. Of note, the court also reviewed the curiously tangential evidence relating to a series of trespass and possession of a bladed article in a secondary car park near Edgbaston University. The reference arises in police logs but pertains to an unrelated individual and has no bearing on the defendant. Similarly, a previous conviction of the defendant’s sister for benefit fraud, referenced in defence submissions, is irrelevant to his own conduct. Investigators discovered fallback documentation from Mr H that linked to the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message. Turning to the defendant’s personal circumstances: Mr H is aged 31. He holds a Master’s degree in Chemical Engineering from a well-regarded institution, and was most recently employed by a regional water treatment facility before his abrupt resignation in early 2023. Interviews with former colleagues depict a capable but socially isolated individual, prone to taking extended lunch breaks and demonstrating a reluctance to engage in team activities. Letters from a local horticultural society praised his voluntary work in community allotments, describing him as “meticulous and reliable.” The court accepts that civic-mindedness, while commendable, cannot offset serious criminal conduct. As Lord Justice Mance observed in R v. Reynolds [2018] EWCA Crim 1234, “Personal virtue in non-criminal spheres neither excuses nor mitigates offences that jeopardise the lives of innocents.” It is also necessary to consider the defendant’s mental health. Professor Sarah Patterson, consultant forensic psychologist, conducted a detailed assessment and concluded that Mr H exhibits a “markedly black-and-white cognitive style,” manifesting in rigid ideological adherence. There is no diagnosis of psychosis or personality disorder. The report emphasises the high likelihood of reoffending absent intensive post-release management and cautions against simplistic notions of deradicalisation. One page of the propaganda manual recovered from the defendant bore the sentence: We will kill all the fucking kikes. Israel is a terrorist state. The court’s assessment, in line with the expert evidence and comprehensive factual findings, is that Mr H represents a significant ongoing risk in public safety terms. The gravity of his offending, the sophistication of his preparations, and his ideological commitment, all demand a custodial sentence of immediate commencement. The sentencing guidelines for offences under section 5(1)(a) of the Terrorism Act 2006 and section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000 require the court to balance factors of culpability, harm, and mitigation. There is limited scope here for leniency. The defendant’s previously clean criminal record and educational attainments weigh in mitigation, as does the late plea, albeit reduced significantly by its timing. Prison services are emphatically reminded of the necessity for concerted deradicalisation and cognitive behavioural programmes tailored to offenders convicted in these categories. Multi-agency cooperation, including MAPPA Category 3 arrangements, remains essential for ongoing risk reduction. The court directs that a detailed pre-sentence report be prepared with specific enquiries into the feasibility of High Intensity Programmes (HIP), the availability of Accredited Programme Providers, and suitability for Extended Determinate Sentence arrangements as per the Criminal Justice Act 2003, section 226A. The report shall also canvass options for electronic monitoring, including GPS exclusion zones and internet-access restrictions, given the defendant’s extensive digital facilitation of his offending. I would take this opportunity to note the diligent work of the specialist counter-terrorism probation teams, who operate under significant workload pressures and often face public misunderstanding. Their engagement is a linchpin in ensuring cases such as this do not regress into worse outcomes post-release. It is regrettable but unsurprising that vacancies in such teams remain unfilled for extended periods. This court wishes also to acknowledge the behind-the-scenes support from the Birmingham Prevent Hub, whose early identification of the defendant’s ideological shift was subsequent to an initial Home Office referral dating back to 2021. Although engagement was intermittent, their reports describe sustained efforts at intervention through mentoring and educational support, restrained by resource limitations and the defendant’s resistance. Finally, I am reminded of the constitutional principle that prosecutions for terrorism offences must be pursued scrupulously in adherence to the rule of law, mindful of the dangers of stigmatization and overreach. As Lord Justice Sedley remarked in R v. Farid [2010] EWCA Crim 142, “The state must be vigilant, but the law must be known and certain.” This case is no exception. These sentencing remarks are issued on this 27th day of August 2025, in Court 5 at the Crown Court at Birmingham. The proceedings have been transcribed in compliance with Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The official record of conviction and sentence will be forwarded to the relevant penal and supervisory authorities in due course. These are the orders of the court.
