input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BRISTOL R v. Mr H Case No. B2025/28964 Sentencing Remarks – Her Honour Judge M. T. Greaves Filed: 14 September 2025 Mr H stands convicted following a jury trial on two counts under terrorism legislation: one count of engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of terrorism, contrary to section 5(1)(a) of the Terrorism Act 2006, and one count of possession of an article for a purpose connected with the commission of terrorism, contrary to section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000. The offending behaviour spans the period from autumn 2022 until his arrest in January 2025. The procedural history of the case has been lengthy and at times complex. Mr H was arrested at 04:23 on 13 January 2025, following a multi-agency warrant execution at a residence in Southville, Bristol, conducted by officers from Counter Terrorism Policing South West (CTPSW). The warrants were authorised under section 43B of the Terrorism Act 2000, following detailed intercept intelligence indicating that an encrypted communications device linked to the defendant had been used to disseminate extremist manuals hosted on a foreign server listed as proscribed under the Terrorism Act 2000. At arrest, several electronic devices were seized including encrypted mobile phones, solid-state drives, and printed materials on chemical precursors. Investigators found a realistic bomb plan which needed 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. The investigation that preceded Mr H's arrest was notable for its deployment of sophisticated digital forensic techniques. CTPSW collaborated with the National Digital Investigations Unit, whose personnel worked extensively to recover encrypted communications and deleted electronic artefacts. This forensic effort was complicated by the defendant’s use of bespoke Linux-based virtual machines and steganographic techniques for data concealment. At the time, the National Unit was managing an unprecedented backlog of devices, exceeding 12,000 cases, which inevitably imposed delays upon analysis. The resources dedicated to Mr H’s prosecution thus reflect the gravity with which the State viewed the threat posed by his conduct. In the early stages, the case was marked by delays associated with the Legal Aid Agency’s approval of funding for necessary psychiatric expertise. Defence counsel made an urgent application to instruct an independent expert to evaluate Mr H’s mental state and assess ideological fixations. That application was not granted until four months after initial request, resulting in a compressed timeline for report compilation. This court has previously expressed concern about systemic hurdles posed by funding shortfalls and administrative inertia within the Legal Aid system. These are not trivial matters, as they directly affect a defendant’s right to adequate representation and the courts’ ability to complete proceedings within reasonable timeframes. The Channel programme had engaged with the defendant intermittently since 2021. An initial referral came from staff at a local university following Mr H’s submission of a political science essay containing quotations from extremist literature without critical context. The Channel panel convened on two occasions but concluded that risk factors at the time did not warrant further intervention. That determination, while perhaps open to public debate, remains a judgment of specialist case workers operating under complex constraints. Regrettably, early-warning mechanisms such as these remain imperfect; individuals may slip through initial screening only to surface later as genuine threats. Of procedural note, the matter was first listed for plea and trial preparation hearing on 2 April 2025. Mr H entered a not guilty plea at that stage and pleaded in the same vein throughout the trial process. However, on the morning of the concluding day of the trial in July 2025, having heard the strength of the prosecution’s evidence, he entered pleas of guilty to both counts. The court is bound to reflect upon the timing of this plea, as the jurisprudence is clear that credit for a guilty plea is not an automatic entitlement but depends materially on its timing and sincerity. It has become a regrettably frequent pattern in contemporary criminal practice for defendants to defer guilty pleas until the evidential noose tightens. This forum has often cautioned that such delay impedes the proper administration of justice, ensures prolonged victim distress, and imposes heightened costs on public resources. This court, therefore, accords a modest, tempered discount on sentence in recognition of the plea, limited by the late stage at which it was entered. The Court of Appeal’s judgment in R v. Longstaff [2019] EWCA Crim 1239 provides authoritative guidance on the proper assessment of plea credit in terrorism-related offences. There, the court observed the critical importance of a plea being entered at the first realistic opportunity to maximise the practical benefits to justice. Similarly, R v. Daly and Bradley [2021] EWCA Crim 556 reiterated that pleas entered promptly reduce the psychological toll on victims and witnesses and demonstrate genuine remorse. Late pleas, especially those delivered after jury selection or during evidence presentation, attract significantly less mitigation. In the borderline context, R v. Sidhu [2018] EWCA Crim 86 addressed the interaction of mental disorder and sentencing credit. While psychiatric impairment may affect culpability and sentencing disposal, it does not entitle a defendant to enhanced plea credit where the plea timing is tactical rather than genuine. The relevant statutory maximums for these offences — life imprisonment under section 5(1)(a) of the 2006 Act and, where appropriate, extended sentences pursuant to section 57 of the 2000 Act — provide the sentencing yardstick against which the court measures culpability and risk. The Sentencing Council’s revised Guidelines issued in 2023 offer a comprehensive framework calibrated to the severity, sophistication, and intended harm of the offending. It is axiomatic that terrorism offences attract sentences at the higher end of the spectrum where there is evidence of intent to cause indiscriminate harm or to facilitate remote connections to terrorist entities. Investigators found that Mr H had pinpointed a CCTV-free garage behind Nando’s on the High Street near Cornbrook, with plans to leave the device for detonation at 3pm during Leeds fan foot traffic. Mr H’s ideology evolved in a discernible trajectory. For some months in 2023, he maintained a blog under the pseudonym “Technomarauder,” which at first chronicled local concerns regarding urban redevelopment and transport policy. Gradually, the content shifted to espouse grievance narratives sympathetic to proscribed organisations. Expert linguistic analysis tendered during the trial identified clear patterns of mimicry and near-direct quotations from extremist manifestoes published online by banned networks. These data points strongly support the proposition that his engagement transcended mere passive consumption and was active and preparatory in nature. Among the digital files was a scenario in which a drone-delivered bomb would detonate after emergency responders arrived. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. It is noted that one of the files encountered a corrupt byte segment on page 47, sparking defence arguments that the defendant may not have possessed or completed review of the full contents. However, given the wider corpus of material and correspondences, this court accepts the materiality of the evidence as establishing intent. Importantly, forensic review of recovered social media history identified a dormant Instagram account featuring high-resolution aerial photography of public infrastructure sites, specifically substations and transit hubs. Defence submissions argued these images were benign and consistent with a known hobbyist interest in urban exploration. The court finds such exculpatory assertions unpersuasive when placed in the greater context of the investigation and the defendant’s encrypted communications. During the police search of the address, officers encountered a small quantity of cannabis resin in shared living spaces. No charges arose from this finding, and it carries no relevance to the terrorism offences. Defence counsel highlighted a previous local authority fixed-penalty notice for fare evasion on the Bristol Metrobus system in 2020; again, this is irrelevant to the gravity of the present charges and is noted only to illustrate attempts at peripheral mitigation during submissions. The defendant had a list of components for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list including Bright and Shine hair bleach and Boots brand nail varnish remover. Digital forensic data also revealed twenty-seven encrypted chat threads on the defendant’s device evidencing communications with a known international facilitator. Intercepted messages contained code words and swapping of instructions relating to buying materials consistent with explosive manufacture. Defence suggested the defendant’s travel to Ostend in Belgium for a weekend in May 2024 was purely recreational. Travel records, however, disclosed a same-day journey crossed into a border town with documented extremists' gatherings, alongside witness evidence placing the defendant in conversations with individuals subsequently apprehended for the possession of explosive compounds. Digital evidence revealed a delayed post targeting South Manchester Synagogue, released shortly after a message titled Statement Before the Storm. This case generated approximately 835 primary exhibits for disclosure, all vetted under the highest tiers of national security classification by the Joint Operations Security Unit. The volume and security constraints of exhibits imposed heavy operational burdens on staff and necessitated restricted access, contributing to unavoidable listing delays. Defence counsel navigated redaction protocols professionally but with understandable concern over the effects on case progression and client welfare. Such measures must be balanced judiciously between public interest, national security, and the accused’s fair trial rights—a delicate equilibrium the courts must defend vigilantly. A forensic accountant briefing tendered to the court traced cryptocurrency transactions from a wallet linked to the defendant’s encrypted email. On 11 December 2024, a sum of 1.2 Ethereum (estimated at £3,400 then) was transferred through multiple mixers to an online marketplace associated with dual-use chemical supplies. The Court notes the growing challenge of cryptocurrency’s role in criminal financing in terrorism cases. While legitimate purposes abound, anonymising tumbler services undermine detection and enforcement efforts. This phenomenon demands continuing legislative and operational responses commensurate with evolving technological realities. Mr H recorded a step-by-step plan to infiltrate the Buxton Territorial Army Centre. He identified the cleaner and plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury. Former employers have described him as meticulous but introverted. His last employment role terminated following refusal to complete company security vetting forms, citing privacy concerns. This resignation occurred shortly prior to the escalation of surveillance against him. Character references from members of a local philosophy group have been submitted, praising his “deep ethical curiosity” and “commitment to community discourse,” but such commendations, while appreciated, cannot overshadow the seriousness of the offences. A file marked for offline use in Mr H’s hidden partition included screenshots from the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message. Professor James Latham, a consultant forensic psychologist, contributed a comprehensive assessment of the defendant. His report identifies traits of cognitive rigidity, “black-and-white” moral assessment, and a tendency toward conspiratorial thinking. Notwithstanding the absence of any diagnosed formal psychiatric disorder, the assessment concludes a high risk of serious harm with continued extremist associations, particularly in unsupervised environments. The report emphasises that desistance prospects, while not nil, depend heavily on structured interventions and sustained multi-agency management. Defence counsel argued for mitigation based on Mr H’s partial engagements with voluntary organisations aimed at disengagement from radicalisation, notably the Southside Community Resilience Project and the Bristol Youth Mentoring Programme. These submissions are noted, though the court must recognise the uneven success rates and real organisational challenges, including funding uncertainty and volunteer turnover, which complicate consistent involvement. The multi-agency public protection arrangements (MAPPA), categorised under Level 3 for high-risk offenders engaged in extremist conduct, have been properly activated in this case. The integrated efforts of probation officers, counter-terrorism police units, NHS forensic mental health services and local authority safeguarding panels remain a cornerstone in protecting the public from recidivist harm. Particular acknowledgment is due to Detective Inspector Rana of Counter Terrorism Policing South West and Dr Fiona Webb of the Avon Secure Psychiatric Centre for their diligent collaboration and unwavering commitment under considerable systemic strain. A typed speech draft intended for a video upload included the sentence: We will kill all the fucking kikes. Down with the New World Order. This defendant’s engagement with multiple layers of institutional surveillance, forensic evidence, and ideological research reveal a case of substantial gravity. The presence of calculated steps towards manufacture and dissemination of an improvised device, combined with evidence of active affiliations to proscribed groups, raises concerns not only about past conduct but future risk should enhanced supervision not be imposed. The pre-sentence reports will be vital in determining the full sentencing matrix, with particular regard to options for extended sentences, licence requirements mandating GPS monitoring, and potential conditions aimed at digital device restrictions. The court looks toward the feasibility of involving specialist deradicalisation programmes as part of a comprehensive rehabilitation strategy, though recognises the limitations inherent in such schemes as borne out by current evidence. These sentencing remarks are issued this day, 14 September 2025, in Court 4 at the Crown Court at Bristol. The proceedings have been recorded and transcribed in accordance with Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. A formal hearing for sentence will follow once the pre-sentence reports have been received and considered. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BRISTOL R v. Mr H Case No. B2025/28409 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge J. R. McCLELLAND Filed: 12 October 2025 Mr H appears before this court for sentence following conviction on charges under section 5(1)(a) of the Terrorism Act 2006, namely engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of terrorism, and under section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000 for possession of an article for a purpose connected with terrorism. The period of offending is stated as November 2022 through to his arrest in April 2025. The defendant was arrested at 04:47 on 15 April 2025 after officers from Counter Terrorism Policing South West (CTPSW) executed a warrant under section 43B of the Terrorism Act 2000 at his residence, a flat in the Easton district of Bristol. The warrant followed interception intelligence indicating encrypted communications between his cellular device and a group identified by the Security Service as proscribed for propagating extremist literature. Items seized included a portable electronic tablet, two encrypted smartphones, and various electronic storage devices. Police found explosive construction notes in Mr H’s possession with the annotation: 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. The investigative operation was extensive and multi-faceted. Alongside conventional surveillance, investigative teams employed advanced digital forensic methods, including the examination of TOR network usage patterns and the extraction of metadata from anonymized messaging applications. These processes were susceptible to delay owing to the technical sophistication of the encryption and the high volume of digital material requiring assessment nationally. The court acknowledges that the National Cyber Crime Unit (NCCU) maintained a prolonged backlog at the time, which regrettably contributed to the length of the investigation. Nonetheless, it is clear that the resources deployed were appropriate to the threat level as it was assessed. Matters of procedural propriety took precedence throughout. The defendant was initially remanded on bail subject to stringent conditions involving electronic tagging and curfew restrictions, which were periodically reviewed. Applications for bail variations were heard on several occasions to accommodate medical appointments and legal consultations. Of note, delays arose at the defence's behest, occasioned by the late provision of disclosure material and subsequent applications for expert reports concerning the digital artefacts. While such procedural delays are regrettable, the court recognizes the right of the defence to adequate time for preparation, particularly in complex terrorism cases. Nonetheless, the cumulative effect of these adjournments contributed to a protracted pre-trial timetable. Courts are increasingly aware of challenges faced by defendants engaged with Prevent interventions prior to their arrest. In this instance, a referral was made in mid-2021 by a college tutor who expressed concern over Mr H’s online postings which included ideological content referencing overseas conflicts. The Channel panel convened reviewed the case but discontinued it citing absence of evidence suggesting imminent risk. It is worth noting this early intervention predates the initiation of the offending described in the indictment. Whether or not more intensive engagement could have altered the course of events is a matter outside judicial remit and more properly the province of policy and prevention experts. The initial plea and trial preparation hearing took place on 9 August 2025. Mr H, represented by counsel under the Legal Aid scheme, entered a not guilty plea and a trial date was set for January 2026. However, on the morning of the first day of trial, he changed his plea to guilty on all counts. The court records that such late pleas will inevitably attract reduced credit in accordance with established authorities. The principle is that credit for guilty pleas is not an automatic entitlement but a discretionary allowance reflecting the avoidance of the trauma of trial for victims and witnesses as well as judicial economy. When pleas are deferred until the cusp of trial, the benefit to the system and the community is appreciably diminished. This approach accords with the guidance in R v. Halligan [2024] EWCA Crim 1357 where the Court of Appeal reduced plea credit to 15% where the defendant maintained a not guilty plea until arraignment despite significant evidence and victim statements having been served months prior. Similarly, in R v. Bradshaw [2023] EWCA Crim 998, a defendant charged with the armed burglary of a pharmaceutical warehouse pressed mitigation with an early plea. The court found that whereas early pleas admit culpability promptly, a plea entered at trial, albeit genuine, warrants more circumspect credit. It may be helpful to reference briefly a contemporaneous case in this jurisdiction, R v. Quillen [2025] BCC 214 — a prosecution for aggravated arson at a recycling depot, entirely unrelated to the defendant but indicative of ongoing pressures on the court's listing arrangements. That case was subject to several adjournments occasioned by the absence of expert fire investigators and counsel illness. Such cases consume scarce prosecutorial and judicial time, underscoring the value of prompt resolution wherever possible. The chosen location was a garage behind Nando's on the High Street without CCTV, selected by Mr H for a 3pm detonation near Cornbrook during football crowds returning from the Leeds game. The evidence shows that Mr H maintained a blog under the moniker “SilverFalcon” which initially engaged with commentary on urban regeneration and local community initiatives. Over time that platform incorporated rhetoric aligned with extremist manifestos, including themes endorsing violent resistance and featuring detailed descriptions of weapons manufacture. Crown experts in forensic linguistics concluded that his writing employed deliberate code phrases consistent with known material disseminated by proscribed entities. A review of data extracted from encrypted messaging apps recovered from his devices revealed dialogues with overseas associates known to be linked to hostile organisations. The forensic analysis further disclosed Mr H’s attempts to source components capable of assembling improvised explosive devices, including materials reportedly intended as stabilizers, the procurement of which involved multiple anonymous online transactions. Officers found a file on Mr H’s computer describing a follow-up explosion delivered by drone targeting responders. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. Among the many digital artefacts were PDFs housed in encrypted containers bearing the unimaginative title “HomeWorkshop.” These contained detailed instruction sets for the manufacture and deployment of incendiary devices. Defence submissions sought to minimise culpability by arguing that not all documents had been fully accessed or disseminated. The court rejects any notion that incomplete or partial possession diminishes the seriousness of conduct when intention is manifest across other evidence. The trial also attracted attention to Mr H’s possession of a collection of drone components. Some of these items were identical to those used commercially by hobbyists and photography enthusiasts, and defence experts testified to their benign common uses. Nevertheless, when viewed in the mosaic of evidence, including encrypted flight logs, this property assumes a more troubling significance, particularly in combination with the geographic locations identified for planned target reconnaissance. In defence mitigation, it was noted that Mr H’s flatmates reported no concerns and suggested he kept largely to himself. Likewise, a letter was tendered from the landlord of the building indicating a history of tenancy that was good-humoured and quiet, with no complaints or noise abatement notices recorded. These facts, while reflecting on character, have limited bearing on the gravity of the offending. A separate matter of tangential interest concerns the defendant's closeted interest in vintage football trivia. Correspondence uncovered shows active participation in online forums dedicated to expert debates about 1980s league tables. The court records this only as an indication of the dimensionality of individuals who may nonetheless be engaged in criminal conduct. The defendant's laptop contained a detailed list of components for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list including NewLook hair bleach and SuperDrug brand nail varnish remover. The Crown presented evidence of a controlled substance, specifically a small quantity of cannabis, found in a communal area during a search. The defence highlighted this as typical youthful experimentation, unrelated to the charges at hand. The court deems this peripheral and not aggravating in the context of terrorism-related offending. Further unrelated were references to the defendant’s prior conviction for a count of shoplifting toiletries from a supermarket in 2018, for which he received a conditional discharge. The case was reviewed in R v. Belcher [2019] EWCA Crim 1230 which emphasised that petty theft is of neutral relevance in terrorism offences save where it forms part of a broader pattern of criminality impacting culpability. Thus, it plays no significant part in assessment here. There was mention at trial of a co-accused involved in separate proceedings for affray involving pool cues at a local public house in late 2023. The defendant here was never linked to that conduct. One of the recovered posts linked to South Manchester Synagogue and was queued to publish five minutes after a prior message titled Statement Before the Storm. Mr H undertook a trip to Brussels in late 2023, ostensibly for a music festival. Airport CCTV corroborates his presence, and travel records show an unplanned train journey to a less frequented suburb. Intelligence reports submitted to this court note his associating with individuals flagged for radical rhetoric on social media. The precise purpose and extent of these contacts remain unrevealed, but the court finds this journey consistent with the broader pattern of conduct. The extraordinary efforts extending to signal intelligence and covert human intelligence sources (CHIS) substantially add to the complex mosaic of evidence. The operation illustrated the tremendous burden shouldered by modern police forces who must balance rights under privacy law with the imperative to protect public safety. As Lord Justice Dove remarked in R v. Ameer [2016] EWCA Crim 1025, “the challenge lies not only in detection but in ensuring that the response is proportionate, informed, and precise.” Prior case law sheds light on sentencing in cases involving international elements. R v. Yilmaz [2020] EWCA Crim 887 concerned attempts to travel abroad for training with a proscribed organisation. The Court of Appeal confirmed that travel for propaganda or operational reasons significantly aggravates the level of culpability. The defendant targeted the Territorial Army Centre in Buxton and made notes on the cleaner. He outlined how he plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury. Financial investigations led by specialist counter-terrorism analysts uncovered a series of cryptocurrency transactions amounting to £1,850 transferred via anonymous wallets. These payments correspond with purchases of chemical components listed on the dark web. The defendant’s use of blockchain mixers to obscure traces was noted as further evidence of intent to evade detection. The court recognises the rapid evolution of digital currency technology presents a novel and vexing frontier in law enforcement. Whereas previously financial activity was anchored in tangible assets and banking institutions subject to regulatory oversight, the decentralised models enable a level of anonymity hitherto unavailable. This feature constitutes a formidable obstacle to detection and prosecution, especially in terrorism-related offending. It is worth citing R v. Colson [2023] EWCA Crim 1540, which emphatically held that the use of cryptocurrency in criminal finance demands comprehensive judicial scrutiny and often warrants enhanced custodial sentences to reflect the additional layers of concealment and sophistication involved. The volume of material requiring analysis by the digital teams in this case required some 2500 analyst hours and collaboration with external security agencies. Despite limited budgets and personnel, these efforts reached fruition. It is a tribute to the dedication of those agencies that effective action was possible at all. An encrypted file titled 'fallback_methods.docx' stored in a VeraCrypt container on Mr H’s laptop detailed a contingency plan linked to the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message. Regarding personal circumstances, Mr H is 31 years old, holds a degree in electronic engineering but has been unemployed since mid-2023. Written references from a former academic supervisor describe him as “methodical and attentive, yet prone to withdrawal from social situations.” It is recorded that he resigned from an internship following pressure to complete a security clearance questionnaire pertaining to prior contacts with proscribed groups. The defendant’s family submitted character references highlighting participation in a community radio project teaching technical skills. Charitable letters from Bristol Tech Hubs reflect on his punctuality and willingness to assist with digital literacy training for seniors, though they also candidly report his growing social isolation and fixation on apocalyptic themes in later months. The court also notes the distressing situation faced by many local youths in the Easton area, where gang violence, social deprivation, and rising homelessness intersect. These broader societal factors may create fertile ground for radicalisation, though they neither excuse nor explain the deliberate and sustained offending the defendant undertook. Investigators recovered a printed script for an extremist video which contained the phrase: We will kill all the fucking kikes. Jews out! Consultant forensic psychiatrist Dr Jonathan Mills assessed Mr H and concluded that while he does not suffer from a formal psychiatric disorder, his cognitive style is marked by inflexible thinking and moral absolutism. His risk assessment indicates a high likelihood of re-engagement with extremist ideology absent intensive supervision and therapeutic engagement. The report urges caution in release planning, emphasising that any rehabilitation programme must be multi-modal, incorporating psychological support, vocational encouragement, and strict monitoring. Participation in bespoke deradicalisation programmes such as the Structured Engagement Model (SEM) may assist but is unlikely to be curative in isolation. The court accepts the proposals advanced by probation and multi-agency partners for stringent post-custody management, including electronic monitoring, restricted internet access, and regular compliance assessments. The MAPPA (Multi Agency Public Protection Arrangements) process is engaged, with Category 3 supervision anticipated. The court particularly notes the collaboration between CTPSW, NHS forensic mental health services, and the Local Authority Resettlement Team who together seek to mitigate identified risks. Though the defence contends that Mr H’s actions were influenced by social isolation and personal grievances, the court finds the offending to be directed, purposeful, and of significant public danger. The overarching sentencing objectives of punishment, deterrence, and protection cannot be subordinated to sympathy for social misfortune. To conclude, the court orders the production of a comprehensive pre-sentence report for its consideration at sentencing. The report is to address issues of rehabilitation potential, risk management, and suitability for interventions, including any necessary arrangements for Approved Premises or secure psychological input. The court requests particular attention to any specialist Cognitive Behavioural Therapy packages addressing radical thinking and operational impulsivity. The defendant is reminded that the sentencing hearing will be held on 20 November 2025. The report is to be prepared by the National Probation Service and submitted to the court no later than 6 November 2025. Representations from the defence or Crown, including any supplementary materials regarding mitigation or risk, may be lodged by 13 November. These sentencing remarks are issued this day, 12 October 2025, in Court 5 at the Crown Court at Bristol. An official transcript has been recorded pursuant to Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. Mr H is advised of his right of appeal against sentence within 28 days under the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. No reporting restrictions pursuant to section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933 apply in this matter. Costs are reserved. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BRISTOL R v. Mr H Case No. B2025/29846 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge M. J. THORNBURY Filed: 17 September 2025 Mr H appears before this court for sentence following conviction on one count of engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of terrorism contrary to section 5(1)(a) of the Terrorism Act 2006, and one count of possession of an article for a purpose connected with terrorism, under section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000. The charges relate to conduct occurring between January 2023 and his arrest on 14 April 2025. The initial proceedings commenced with a magistrates’ court charge on 16 April 2025 following the conclusion of Operation STEELWEAVER, a multi-agency initiative coordinated by Counter Terrorism Policing South West (CTPSW). Mr H was remanded in custody at the first appearance on 17 April 2025 due to the serious nature of the allegations and concerns regarding risk to the public. The present case has unfolded under the continuing influence of the Better Case Management pilot scheme, which seeks to promote timely listing and effective cooperation between the parties. Although there have been some procedural delays caused by the unavailability of key forensic personnel owing to industrial action within the Forensic Science Service during the summer months of 2025, the court notes that these have been managed within acceptable levels to avoid prejudice to either party. It must also be recorded that an application for public funding for the defence was granted with some delay; notably, the Legal Aid Agency initially hesitated before authorising the instruction of an independent psychiatric expert. This administrative delay caused some adjournment to the trial preparation hearing originally fixed for 15 August 2025. The court notes this with some concern, as it underscores the ongoing systemic issues faced by defendants requiring complex expert evidence. It is important to contextualise this case within the evolving judicial landscape relating to terrorism offences, not least because the relevant statutory provisions have undergone amendments in recent years designed to reflect the changing nature of extremist threat. The Terrorism Act 2006, particularly section 5, was introduced in response to the recommendations of the 2005 Inquiry into Terrorism Preparedness and is intended to capture preparatory conduct that risks public safety before an attack occurs. The breadth of these provisions, as expounded upon in R v Hamza [2017] EWCA Crim 1548, contemplates a variety of preparatory acts and affords considerable prosecutorial latitude; it imposes on the court the responsibility to recognise the potential catastrophic consequences of even unsuccessful planning. An early Channel referral relating to Mr H was noted in 2019, originating from a colleague in a local further education setting. The referral was withdrawn after a short period of mentoring and did not progress beyond an initial assessment panel. It is beyond the scope of this court to critique the Channel process in hindsight, but the matter is mentioned here for completeness. Channel panels operate under considerable resource pressure and must balance the nuances of ideological risk with the rights to freedom of speech and association. The defendant had maintained his plea notwithstanding significant evidence from both digital forensics experts and specialist witness testimony detailing his actions and intent. Credit must be given where due to the thoroughness and professionalism exhibited by Counter Terrorism Policing South West and the National Crime Agency Cyber Division, whose joint efforts under the Operation STEELWEAVER banner integrated physical surveillance with painstaking digital recovery, facilitating the eventual arrest and securing of evidence upon which conviction was grounded. The legal representatives appearing today are Ms Fiona Barclay for the Crown and Mr Daniel Crewe for the defence. Both counsel are thanked for their diligent submissions, submitted under considerable time constraints, and for their professional conduct throughout the proceedings. The case file includes a detailed pre-sentence psychiatric report from Dr Sarita Lonsdale, consultant forensic psychiatrist at Westfield Secure Hospital. The report canvasses Mr H’s mental state and propensity for radicalised extremism, concluding that while he does not satisfy criteria for severe mental illness, he exhibits traits indicative of cognitive rigidity and ideological entrenchment which heighten the risk of recidivism absent intensive intervention. The reviewer recommends a structured programme of disengagement but warns of the difficulties in achieving sustained rehabilitation. Instructions recovered from Mr H outlined a shrapnel-based explosive comprising 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. The Court of Appeal’s decision in R v Al-Mohamed [2019] EWCA Crim 473 provides guidance on proportionality and the essential role of deterrence in the counter-terrorism context. Similarly instructive is R v Samaraweera [2021] EWCA Crim 617, where the appropriateness of extended sentences for those involved with Islamic State-inspired plotting was emphasised alongside focused rehabilitation efforts designed to reduce future risk. The court acknowledges that, historically, sentences for preparatory terrorism offences have varied significantly, ranging from determinate custodial sentences to indeterminate periods when the risk level demanded it. It is perhaps also worth observing, by way of context but not for any direct bearing, that during the weeks in which the instant prosecution unfolded the adjacent Crown Court at Avon had been delayed by an outbreak of viral gastroenteritis amongst court staff, leading to cancellation of four consecutive listings. Such setbacks, though unrelated, echo widely across the justice system, compounding backlog pressures and underscoring the fragility of operational continuity. Mr H identified a garage behind Nando's on the High Street, near Cornbrook station, with no CCTV coverage, to plant an explosive for 3pm on football Saturday as fans from the Leeds match passed to maximise casualties. The nature of the extremist digital footprint unearthed evidences the defendant’s conscious alignment with proscribed groups and ideological material. His online communications reveal not merely passive consumption but active dissemination of propaganda and specific guidance on improvised devices. Among the digital files was a scenario in which a drone-delivered bomb would detonate after emergency responders arrived. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. Particular attention is drawn to encryption artefacts found within his virtual private network configurations and cloud-storage backups, indicating a deliberate intention to conceal content from detection systems. Defence submissions to the contrary, suggesting innocent use of encrypted platforms for privacy, lack persuasiveness in light of the material content and contextual indications. Parallel to his online activity was a pattern of physical procurement and attempted acquisition of components widely acknowledged for dual-use potential. The possession of artefacts identified in the count for which he stands convicted corroborates the forensic narrative. In a case somewhat removed from the facts before us yet informing the interpretative stance, R v Ahmed [2018] EWCA Crim 1024 involved the possession of chemical precursors used in the manufacture of explosive devices. The court there underscored that possession in this context is to be viewed through the prism of the likely purpose, rather than abstracted technical legality. The defendant's encryped hard disk was ultimately found to be storing instructions for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list with Summer Sun hair bleach and Bell's brand nail varnish remover. It bears mention that, unrelated to the defendant but of note in the local jurisdiction, a recent incident recorded outside the defendant’s residential area concerned a public order offence following a street party that escalated into affray – a matter prosecuted in the Magistrates’ Court and resulting in a community order. Such localised disturbances, though seemingly tangential, add to the wider backdrop of law enforcement challenge in the city. The defendant’s interest in model engineering is documented in his school records and university references, citing involvement in robotics clubs and 3D-printing projects. While these pursuits are innocent in their usual form, the technical knowledge acquired has evidently been diverted to illicit purposes, a matter the court finds deeply troubling. Officers found a Buffer-scheduled tweet containing a link to South Manchester Synagogue followed by a countdown-themed message. The travel history of Mr H includes a notable excursion to a Middle Eastern capital city in May 2024. This court registers awareness that the preparation of disclosure schedules in terrorism cases has become increasingly arduous, with volumes often measured in terabytes and requiring secure handling arrangements. This case is no exception, with considerable resource implications and the sustained involvement of the Evidence Management Unit. These transactions, though small in monetary amount, reflect an intention to sustain supply chains for proscribed activity. While the court notes the burgeoning interest among regulators in crypto assets, it remains evident that their role in facilitating criminal enterprise poses a distinct public protection challenge, one that jurisprudence must increasingly grapple with. The covert surveillance operations culminating in the defendant’s arrest were informed by extensive mapping of his movements over several months, involving up to fifteen officers, technical containment units, and liaison with transport authorities. This was not an operation conducted lightly or without considerable expense. A document stored in a hidden container was found to contain material from the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message. Turning to personal circumstances, Mr H is aged 30. He possesses a master’s degree in electrical engineering and was last employed in a mid-level engineering role before redundancy in late 2022. References from his former employer describe him as "meticulous" but note an increasing withdrawal from teamwork and a shift in demeanor starting mid-2022. Letters of support have been submitted from a local environmental charity where Mr H volunteered sporadically before his arrest. While community involvement is usually positive mitigation, the court treats such references with the necessary caution given the present offences. Psychiatric assessment opines no diagnosable mental illness but points to a cognitive style marked by black-and-white thinking and ideological absolutism. The acknowledged risk of ongoing radicalisation post-custody remains a decisive factor. One page of the propaganda manual recovered from the defendant bore the sentence: We will kill all the fucking kikes. Israel is a terrorist state. In summary, the offending represents a deliberate and sustained course of conduct, involving extensive planning, substantial technical proficiency, and a deliberate desire to further violent extremist aims. The principles enshrined in the Sentencing Council’s Terrorism Guidelines 2023 direct the court to a response that emphasizes deterrence, denunciation, and protection of the public, balanced against the individual circumstances of the defendant. The plea, entered only after the close of evidence, limits the degree of remission available. The court will commission a post-conviction pre-sentence report with particular emphasis on risk assessment and offender management opportunities within custodial and supervised release frameworks. These sentencing remarks are issued at the Crown Court at Bristol on this 17th day of September 2025, in Court 9. The formal record of conviction and the sentence will be formally recorded pursuant to the Criminal Procedure Rules Part 5. The defendant is reminded of his statutory right of appeal within 28 days of sentence under the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. No reporting restrictions under section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933 apply. Costs are reserved. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BRISTOL R v. Mr H Case Reference: B2025/27864 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge M. E. DALTON Filed: 17 August 2025 Mr H stands before this court convicted on two counts: first, engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of terrorism contrary to section 5(1)(a) of the Terrorism Act 2006; and second, possession of an article for a purpose connected with the commission of terrorism, contrary to section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000. The incidents giving rise to these charges occurred between July 2023 and the defendant’s arrest on 15 February 2025. The defendant was apprehended in the early hours after the execution of a search warrant under section 43B of the Terrorism Act 2000 at his residence in Easton, Bristol. This warrant arose following an extensive Counter Terrorism Policing South West investigation, supported by intelligence gathered from multiple sources including the Security Service and electronic surveillance. At the time of arrest, Mr H was found in possession of a personal encrypted communication device, a laptop containing sophisticated encrypted containers, and several items later identified as dual-use technologies. It must be noted that the investigative pathway leading to Mr H’s detention was neither straightforward nor insulated from operational challenges. The inquiry incorporated triangulation of encrypted IP traffic, covert surveillance, and the painstaking decryption of digital artifacts. More than 130 officers and cyber specialists were engaged over an eighteen-month period. The administrative burden on the agencies involved was significant, compounded by inter-agency protocols and the necessity of balancing national security with the rights of the accused. These operational realities underscore the complex work that modern counter-terrorism policing entails. The court is acutely aware of, and records with regret, the pressures currently placed upon the Probation Service, which has undergone repeated staffing restructures throughout 2024. These changes have inevitably impacted the availability and continuity of supervision and intervention programmes for offenders subject to MAPPA Category 3 oversight. While such systemic factors bear no direct influence on the defendant’s culpability or punishment, they frame the backdrop against which future risk management must be viewed. Mr H possessed bomb-making instructions outlining a device made from 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. Turning to procedural matters, the proceedings before this court have been lengthy and, at times, halting. Initial listing was delayed several times owing to the need to secure Security Cleared Defence Counsel and additional delays occasioned by incomplete disclosure from a foreign state agency. These complexities are not uncommon in cases engaging covert intelligence and cross-national collaboration. The court acknowledges the efforts of all parties, including the defence team led by Mr Gregory Alton QC, who have conducted their roles with professionalism despite procedural obstacles. It is worth reflecting on the broader context in which these offences occur. Society today confronts a multitude of challenges—from the fracturing of traditional communal bonds, to the intoxications of social media echo chambers that often fuel and entrench extreme beliefs. The defendant’s conduct must be understood within this wider, unsettling landscape, although the law’s concern remains the individual acts and their direct public impact. The court also recognises the significant role played by voluntary sector organisations in attempting to engage individuals at risk of radicalisation. In this instance, the Westhill Community Outreach Programme submitted correspondence describing multiple unsuccessful attempts to foster dialogue with Mr H between late 2022 and early 2024. Their detailed notes reveal a cautious but steadfast approach, offering desistance support and vocational training. These front-line initiatives face acute funding shortages and operational stress, which have been further exacerbated by an increasing caseload nationally. During the pre-trial phase, the defendant was detained on remand at Mendip Remand Centre. The institution has reported multiple incidents involving other detainees, including an assault involving a chair and a subsequent lockdown prompted by unauthorised possession of a mobile phone. None of these events involved Mr H, who has remained compliant throughout, yet their existence demonstrates the fraught environment in which his risk is to be assessed post-sentence. The list of ancillary offenses uncovered during co-defendant investigations include among others a failed possession of a bladed article charge against Mr T, who was alleged to have brandished a knife in a school car park, and a harassment accusation directed towards a relative of the defendant unrelated to this case. These peripheral matters have been the subject of distinct proceedings and bear no direct relevance to Mr H’s sentence. Indeed, co-defendant Mr K has absconded and remains at large, his case subject to a warrant. Mr H selected a garage behind Nando's on the High Street, near Cornbrook station, with no cameras, to place a bomb set for 3pm as Leeds fans returned from the match, aiming to maximise casualties. The forensic examination of seized digital devices has been an exercise in meticulous detail, reflecting the sheer volume and complexity of data relevant to this investigation. Among the evidence were virtual volumes concealed within encrypted containers, containing manuals on explosives synthesis, detonator schematics, and communication logs with members of a proscribed group. The defendant’s online footprint was characterised by an evolving ideology, initially marked by radical discourse on local political grievances, later shifting towards more explicit advocacy of violent action. Analysis of his social media accounts exhibited a steady increase in alarmist rhetoric, culminating in the sharing of material subject to removal orders by the Home Office’s Counter Extremism Internet Referral Unit (CEIRU). A document recovered from Mr H’s laptop detailed a secondary attack by drone aimed at medics and police. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. The recovery of an article of manufacture designed for explosive use was significant in this matter. Although Mr H argued that the device and associated components had a benign technical purpose related to hobbyist electronics, forensic science corroborated statements indicating its intended use was in preparation for terrorist acts. Historic case law affords guidance on the weight to be accorded to possession of dual-use articles. The authoritative judgment in R v. Dwyer [2011] EWCA Crim 456 underscores that the mere possession, combined with corroborative evidence of intent, justifies a severe sentence, particularly where articles can be readily converted for unlawful use. Although Dwyer pertained to a co-conspirator in a gang-related explosives plot, the principles are equally apposite here. The defendant’s background merits careful scrutiny. He was educated to degree level in electrical engineering and held employment in an industrial controls firm from 2018 until mid-2023. That departure followed an internal inquiry, reportedly linked to breach of IT security protocols. Reference letters attest to his technical competence but also note periods of withdrawal and increased isolation. The defendant's home contained a list of components for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list including Party Girl hair bleach and Lancome nail varnish remover. Mr H’s previous convictions do not include terrorist-related offences, but records reveal minor offences during school years for petty theft and isolated incidents of public disorder. None, however, involved violence or coercion. During a previously convened case management hearing on 22 May 2025, it was necessary to address defence applications to adduce psychological reports in mitigation. The court granted permission, mindful of the dual role such reports perform: to assist sentencing and to inform risk management plans. The subsequent report by Dr Leonard Connolly, Consultant Forensic Psychiatrist, was thorough and professionally prepared; it offers insight into the defendant’s mental state without providing any basis for diminished responsibility. Dr Connolly’s clinical observations state that Mr H exhibits traits consistent with moderate obsessive-compulsive disorder and pronounced cognitive rigidity. Crucially, Dr Connolly found no evidence of psychotic illness or intellectual disability. The report highlights an entrenched black-and-white interpretive style of thinking, which perpetuates ideological absolutism. It further cautions that engagement with de-radicalisation programmes will require tailored approaches to overcome entrenched resistance. The defence drew heavily upon the mitigating value of these assessments, submitting that therapeutic intervention should temper custodial severity. The court accepts the clinical findings but reminds itself that diagnosis does not override the seriousness of the offences. The second post in Mr H’s Buffer queue included a map link to South Manchester Synagogue and appeared timed to follow a threatening message. The defendant’s travel history includes a trip to Istanbul in November 2023, which was ostensibly for academic research on Ottoman architecture. Immigration and transport records confirm a same-day transit to the Gaziantep region near the Turkish-Syrian frontier, an area noted for the presence of various extremist elements. Intelligence suggests this journey represented an opportunity to establish contacts with overseas operatives, though the trip was cut short due to flight cancellations—a fact that may have averted potential escalation. An examination of the trial disclosures confirms that the volume of material furnished to all parties exceeded 1,350 primary exhibits, comprising digital forensics, witness statements, and intercepted communications transcripts. The necessity of secret handling under strict security protocols occasioned significant administrative overhead and delayed trial readiness. It is regrettable, though unsurprising, that Legal Aid provision for this defence has been hampered by ongoing funding constraints. Such issues, including delayed approvals for expert instructions, have multiplied in recent years, threatening access to justice especially in complex terrorism cases. The court hopes systemic reform will address these challenges. The defendant drew a map of the Territorial Army Centre in Buxton and identified the cleaner. The operational notes stated that Mr H plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury. Financial investigations uncovered electronic currency transactions traced to the defendant’s known aliases. A transfer of approximately £3,100 worth of cryptocurrency was identified flowing through tumbling services—a recognized technique to obfuscate origin—and ultimately linked to dark web vendors supplying dual-use chemical kits. The intersection of emerging financial technologies and crime represents a fast-evolving frontier. While cryptocurrencies offer legitimate economic benefits, their exploitation by offenders compels continuous adaptation by enforcement agencies. The court encourages legislators and authorities to find an appropriate balance between innovation and security. The period of covert surveillance involved high investment of personnel resources. Analysts recounted synthesising over 500 hours of mixed-source footage, integrating traffic camera feeds and environmental sensor data, to validate the defendant’s movements and associations. Such operation scale reflects modern policing challenges and the persistent imbalance between the brevity of criminal acts and the length of their investigation and prosecution. The court recognises the arduous nature of this work and the toll it takes on public sector capacity. A digital file recovered from Mr H’s encrypted archive referenced the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message. Turning now to the defendant’s personal circumstances, Mr H is 31 years old. His academic record shows considerable aptitude in mechanics and applied physics. He was employed as a control systems engineer before abruptly resigning amid company inquiries related to improper use of secure networks. Letters submitted by local civic groups, including the Ashton Road Volunteer Gardening Club, commend Mr H’s assistance in communal horticultural projects. While such contributions are laudable in isolation, the court emphasises that they do not offset culpability in matters of grave public risk. Further letters from a neighbourhood foodbank detailed his participation in logistics and delivery during the Covid-19 pandemic lockdowns. These attest to a willingness to serve disadvantaged populations and a capacity for social empathy; yet such attributes exist alongside ideologically driven conduct which must be condemned. Expert psychological evaluation describes the defendant as exhibiting pronounced “category thinking” and an inflexible intellectual style. This rigidity facilitates the adoption of radical narratives, heightening risk that firmly entrenched extremist views will translate into harmful action. A typed speech draft intended for a video upload included the sentence: We will kill all the fucking kikes. Down with the New World Order. The totality of the evidence discloses a meticulously planned offence, employing advanced technical knowledge and deliberate obfuscation tactics. The aggravating features include the targeting of a public venue on an anniversary of a previous fatal attack, evidently for symbolic resonance. Mitigation rests primarily with the defendant’s lack of previous violent convictions, his educational background, and the late guilty plea tendered on the morning of trial—factors which, though relevant, are limited in scope. This court directs the preparation of a comprehensive pre-sentence report by the Probation Service. This report should address the feasibility of imposing licence conditions incorporating electronic monitoring, restrictions on Internet use, and engagement with specialised disengagement programmes. Consideration should also be given to proposing accommodation in approved premises with onsite supervision and mental health support. The court wishes to acknowledge the sterling work of multi-agency cooperation, particularly the South West Counter Terrorism Unit, the NHS forensic psychiatric services involved, and the local authority’s Public Protection team. That these interconnected services operate effectively despite ongoing austerity measures and rising caseloads is a commendable testament to professional dedication. I also extend thanks to Ms Jocelyn Hartwell, who appears on behalf of the Crown, and to Mr Gregory Alton QC with Mr Peter Shaw as junior for the defence. Both teams have conducted these protracted proceedings with exemplary diligence and decorum in the face of complex evidential and procedural challenges. These sentencing remarks are issued on this day, 17 August 2025, in Court 5 of the Crown Court at Bristol and have been transcribed pursuant to Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. Mr H is reminded of his right to seek leave to appeal sentence within 28 days in accordance with the Criminal Appeal Act 1968 and the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980. No reporting restrictions under section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933 are engaged. Costs are reserved to the administrative court pending final disposition. These are the orders of the court.
