input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BIRMINGHAM R v. Mr H Case No. B2025/28764 Sentencing Remarks – Her Honour Judge A. J. Rolston Filed: 5 September 2025 Mr H stands before this court for sentence upon one count of engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of terrorism as defined under section 5(1)(a) of the Terrorism Act 2006, and one count of possession of an article for a purpose connected with terrorism pursuant to section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000. The temporal scope of the offences charged spans from July 2023, through to the date of his arrest in late March 2025. The defendant was arrested at approximately 07:45hrs on 29 March 2025 at his residence in Yardley following the execution of search warrants by officers from Counter Terrorism Policing West Midlands. These search warrants were authorised under section 43B of the Terrorism Act 2000, premised on intelligence suggesting Mr H’s electronic devices were engaged in communication with networks proscribed for distributing radical materials. At the time of apprehension, Mr H was found in possession of multiple electronic devices, including a laptop, encrypted USB sticks, and a mobile phone bearing evidence consistent with material support intent. Police found explosive construction notes in Mr H’s possession with the annotation: 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. The investigation leading to the arrest spanned many months and involved coordination across multiple departments, including cyber-crimes, forensic IT analysts, and local police units. A notable challenge confronting this inquiry was the defendant’s employment of sophisticated encryption technologies and the use of anonymisation tools, which occasioned delays in data retrieval and analysis. Indeed, the National Cyber Crime Unit (NCCU) undertook comprehensive real-time decryption operations that relied significantly on newly developed algorithms under field trials. The court notes the considerable workload suffered by the NCCU, which manages a triage queue exceeding 9,500 devices at any given time, illustrating the acute pressures on technical forensic capabilities. Delays in this case regarding disclosure were, regrettably, exacerbated by administrative issues within the Legal Aid Agency (LAA). Counsel for the defence, Mr Samuel Vince, faced protracted correspondence and multiple requests before receiving assurance to fund an independent psychiatric assessment. Such delay is symptomatic of wider systemic concerns relating to resourcing and efficiency within the LAA, whose remit to uphold fair legal representation is undisputed but presently undermined by funding shortfalls and rising demand. The court records these difficulties in the interests of systemic transparency and encourages the relevant authorities to consider reform. The defendant’s initial bail hearing was conducted on 12 April 2025 but was adjourned due to incomplete forensic disclosure. Bail conditions were imposed stipulating residence restrictions and electronic monitoring. Further applications to vary bail were refused upon submissions from the prosecution relating to serious risk indicators identified during the early investigative stages. These decisions were consonant with the principles underpinning the Bail Act 1976, balancing the presumption in favour of bail against considerations of public protection and flight risk. This court further notes that in February 2022 a referral was made to the Prevent programme by a teaching assistant at the defendant’s place of employment. The referral followed concerns about Mr H’s involvement with an online forum known for promulgating extremist ideologies. The multi-agency Prevent panel reviewed the matter but, finding insufficient evidence of active radicalisation, determined no further action. This panel consisted of representatives from the local authority, social services, and health sector professionals. The Prevent process is designed as an early intervention measure, but its efficacy is contingent on accurate risk assessment and resource availability. The chronic staffing shortages in Probation Services nationally are well-documented. In the West Midlands, these shortages have led to significant caseload inflation and protracted waiting times for offender management. The court is aware that the workload on assigned probation practitioners will intensify in the event Mr H receives a custodial sentence, and the necessity for a robust, well-resourced supervision regime post-release cannot be overstated. The strain on these public services is a reality that the judiciary acknowledges with concern, though ultimate sentencing decisions must remain grounded in the particulars of the case. At the plea and trial preparation hearing on 15 July 2025, Mr H entered not guilty pleas. Following a full trial in August 2025, a unanimous verdict was returned by the jury on 28 August, convicted on both counts. The court acknowledges the efforts of all involved, including the court staff, jurors, and legal representatives, who have conducted proceedings with diligence and professionalism under the pressures of a packed court list exacerbated by recent regional judicial strikes. The principles underpinning sentencing for terrorism offences require careful weighing of public protection imperatives against the prospects for rehabilitation and resettlement. The statutory maximum custodial term available under section 5(1)(a) of the 2006 Act is life imprisonment. input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BRISTOL R v. Mr H Case No. B2025/28945 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge J. N. Weatherby Filed: 15 September 2025 Mr H appears before this court for sentence following his conviction on two counts under the Terrorism Act 2006: one count of engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of terrorism contrary to section 5(1)(a) of the Act, and a further count of possession of an article for a purpose connected with the commission of terrorism contrary to section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000. His offending conduct is judged to have commenced in early 2023 and continued until his arrest on 19 February 2025. The court records that Mr H was arrested pursuant to a warrant executed by Counter Terrorism Policing South West (CTPSW) at his residence, Flat 6, The Granary, Hanover Square. The warrant was issued under the authority granted by section 43B of the Terrorism Act 2000 following intelligence intercepts and electronic tracing that highlighted Mr H’s involvement in encrypted communications channels known for extremist exchange. At the time of arrest, officers seized several electronic devices including a high-performance laptop, encrypted memory sticks, and components consistent with improvised explosive device precursors. This case unfolded against the backdrop of a busy and continuing threat environment in the South West region. The court notes the considerable impact on local law enforcement resources brought about by the escalating demands posed by digital-centric investigations and the necessity to develop expertise in cyber forensic analysis. The division tasked with digital investigations reported that this case, designated Operation SHORELIGHT, strained available personnel to near capacity during a period coinciding with a spike in non-terrorism offences, notably drug-related violence and residential burglaries. Police found explosive construction notes in Mr H’s possession with the annotation: 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. The statute under which the defendant is convicted, part 5(1)(a) of the Terrorism Act 2006, was introduced as part of a legislative response to evolving threats posed by pre-attack planning. Its historical genesis can be traced to the Security and Terrorism Act 2001 reforms in the wake of the September 11 attacks, further expanded by amendments in 2012 to account for the rise of decentralized and small-cell terrorist activity. It is incumbent upon this court to apply the law diligently and in accordance with the sentencing guidelines promulgated by the Sentencing Council in their most recent terrorism offences edition, published in March 2023. The guidelines emphasize personalised assessment of culpability, recognising the need to calibrate punishment to both individual action and the greater context of intent and harm. It is worth noting that these sentencing remarks are delivered from the recently refurbished Court 9 of the Crown Court at Bristol, a courtroom that now benefits from enhanced integrated digital display technology designed to improve the transparency of proceedings. The court would take this opportunity to thank the ushering staff for their capable management of courtroom order throughout the extended listing of this matter, particularly in a calendar marked by several high-profile hearings and unavoidable staff absences. These practical aspects of judicial administration, often overlooked, play an essential role in the fair conduct of justice. During the investigation, the defendant was granted bail on two occasions between his initial arrest on 19 February and his re-arrest on 3 June 2024, pending disclosure. The delays encountered were partly attributable to the volume and classificatory complexity of evidence, as well as resourcing pressures within the Legal Aid Agency, which initially stalled the defence’s application for funding to instruct an independent cybersecurity expert. The court notes with some frustration the increasingly bureaucratic nature of such funding applications, which risk impeding the fair representation of defendants in complex cases under the Terrorism Act. The Criminal Bar Association has recently made representations highlighting this systemic issue, a matter which this court urges the relevant departments to treat with urgency. Mr H planned to build and leave a device in a garage behind Nando’s on the High Street, just east of Cornbrook station, scheduled to detonate at 3pm as Leeds supporters passed in dense footfall, exploiting CCTV blind spots. The Prevent referral culminated in several attempted engagements, including cognitive behavioural interventions focused on grievance narratives thought to underlie ideologically motivated crime. Despite these efforts, engagement was intermittent and ultimately unsuccessful, with the defendant refusing sustained interaction after late 2022. Witness testimony from Prevent staff emphasised their professional disappointment but recognised the formidable challenges posed by Mr H’s digital literacy and determined privacy measures. In the law’s development, the issue of appropriate punishment for preparatory conduct under section 5 of the Terrorism Act 2006 has been examined in a series of appellate decisions which this court cites for context, although none establish binding precedent in this particular factual blend. The landmark case of R v. Sutcliffe [2018] EWCA Crim 1367 considered a defendant whose plot entailed the manufacture of explosive devices targeted at transportation infrastructure. The Court of Appeal upheld a sentence of 18 years’ imprisonment following findings that the degree of sophistication and proximity to execution warranted severe deterrent sentencing. It is also instructive to note the decision in R v. Al-Khatib [2020] EWCA Crim 588, where possession of radical tracts and articles was dealt with, emphasising that possession for a purpose related to terrorism requires demonstration of intent beyond mere possession. In this respect, evidence in the present case, including recorded conversations and preparatory steps, amply satisfies the requisite mens rea and actus reus. Among the digital files was a scenario in which a drone-delivered bomb would detonate after emergency responders arrived. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. Defence counsel have duly acknowledged the complexity of the case while seeking to draw attention to the defendant’s mental health background. Of particular note is the detailed psychiatric assessment provided by Dr Emily Sharpe, consultant forensic psychiatrist at the Avon NHS Trust. Her report, dated 5 August 2025, details Mr H’s diagnosis of adjustment disorder with features of mild depressive symptoms and borderline personality traits. Dr Sharpe was clear in her opinion that while these clinical findings may provide some contextual insight into the defendant’s psychological state, they do not diminish either his capacity to form intent or the seriousness of the offences. The report, exhaustive in its clinical observation and based on multiple structured interviews conducted over a six-month period, concludes that Mr H poses a moderate ongoing risk of ideological fixations without appropriate management but does not meet criteria for a significant psychiatric disorder warranting inpatient care. This court is acutely aware of the widespread strains on NHS forensic mental health services. Delayed access to specialist forensic assessment remains common, putting pressure on the timeliness of court processes. Plans announced by the Department of Health to increase clinical workforce numbers in this field are welcomed, albeit with cautious optimism given historical underfunding and recruitment difficulties. This case illustrates the current challenge — that even with mental health input, the balance between medical understanding and the imperatives of public protection must be carefully maintained. The investigation revealed that Mr H undertook a short trip abroad in November 2023, ostensibly to visit family in southern Spain. However, evidence including passport stamps, telephone metadata, and travel card records suggests the visit also involved meetings with individuals presently under investigation in relation to the trafficking of dual-use chemicals. Defence submissions contend that no criminal intent arose from the meetings. The court finds this unconvincing given the broader contextual material. The firm reports encountering particularly sophisticated encryption requiring over 320 hours of specialist decryption work. These efforts not only lengthened the investigation timeline but also increased costs borne by the public purse. The court also makes passing reference to a historical case, R v. Holloway [2019] EWCA Crim 765, which involved a co-defendant on an unrelated count of affray with a weapon following a pub brawl attended by individuals later associated tangentially with extremist sympathies. That brawl featured improvised weapons including pool cues; Holloway received a custodial sentence of 18 months for violent disorder. This case holds no bearing on Mr H’s conviction but is reflective of a broader narrative regarding the confluence of social unrest and criminality. The defendant drew a map of the Territorial Army Centre in Buxton and identified the cleaner. Among the recovered documents was a scenario in which the defendant plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury. Detailed financial investigations confirmed that the defendant used cryptocurrency wallets to make transactions totaling £3,520 over six months to accounts affiliated with darknet markets. While the use of cryptocurrency is widely recognised for legitimate enterprise, its use in illicit procurement is well documented. The court acknowledges the observations shared in the recent report by the Home Office’s Financial Crime and Terrorism Prevention Unit emphasizing the challenge of tracing such transactions and the importance of enhanced regulatory frameworks. A covert surveillance log details Mr H’s visits to a riverside storage unit on 27 November 2024, where he accessed a locker containing several packages. This type of resource-intensive operation, requiring joint efforts of physical surveillance teams and electronic monitoring units, exemplifies the modern difficulties in counter-terrorism policing. The cumulative demand on personnel, some of whom must balance these duties alongside regular policing tasks, is significant and worthy of recognition. The court has also reviewed statements from local housing authorities referencing the landlord of The Granary. The landlord was subject to a noise abatement notice in early 2024, the nuisance caused reportedly by unrelated residents. Such regulatory matters, while pertinent in other contexts, bear no relevance to Mr H’s conviction or sentencing. The Probation Service has signalled ongoing capacity constraints, particularly with respect to high-risk offender management. A recent briefing notes that current caseloads often exceed recommended best practice ratios due to recruitment difficulties and retention issues. These systemic pressures underline the necessity for carefully tailored sentencing options that balance supervisory intensity with available resources. One encrypted file on Mr H’s laptop included references to the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message. In respect of personal circumstances, Mr H is 31 years old. He holds a bachelor’s degree in electrical engineering from a respected post-1992 university. His employment history includes a period as a junior technician at an industrial controls manufacturer, from which he resigned in mid-2022. References from former supervisors describe him as “methodical and punctual” though somewhat socially reserved. Letters submitted on the defendant’s behalf from members of a local allotment society praise his patience and willingness to mentor younger volunteers. The court acknowledges these gestures but reiterates the distinction between commendable community engagement and the serious breach occasioned by preparation for terrorism. Psychological evaluation by Dr Lionel Herrick, a consultant clinical psychologist, identifies “rigid cognitive schemas” and a propensity toward dichotomous thinking. The report highlights a pattern of grievance-focused rumination but finds no evidence of psychosis or major mood disorder. It emphasises the need for structured interventions on release, including cognitive behavioural elements targeting ideological beliefs. It is also noted that recent submissions from the local mosque community express concern about the impact of sentencing and encourage the court to be mindful of potential stigmatization of minority groups. This court, while cognisant of such concerns, remains duty bound to prioritise public safety and the proper administration of justice, irrespective of communal sensitivities. A typed speech draft intended for a video upload included the sentence: We will kill all the fucking kikes. Down with the New World Order. Turning to sentencing principles, the court has considered the relevant sentencing guidelines in significant detail. The released judgment in R v. Bannister [2024] EWCA Crim 778 provides helpful commentary on the application of extended determinate sentences in terrorism cases, underscoring the importance of deterrence, rehabilitation prospects, and public protection. It is clear from this line of authority that the court’s sentencing discretion should be exercised firmly but fairly, with due regard to all surrounding factors. Mitigation is relatively limited in this case. The cooperation offered by the defendant through guilty pleas at the sentencing stage, though proper, arrived late in the process after extensive police and prosecutorial preparation. Accordingly, credit for plea is modest, consistent with the principles set out in R v. Tolley [2023] EWCA Crim 1573. Finally, the court must observe the continuing relevance of inter-agency cooperation evidenced here. Multi-Agency Public Protection Arrangements (MAPPA) Category 3 oversight will be integral to any future custodial release mechanism. Engagement between the National Counter Terrorism Police, local probation, mental health services, and specialist housing providers will be critical. While the court is encouraged by the commitment demonstrated thus far, it also recognises the potential vulnerabilities inherent in resource-constrained settings. Sentencing is deferred, pending the preparation of a comprehensive pre-sentence report considering these numerous factors. The report should provide an assessment of risk, compliance potential, and suitable rehabilitation interventions, including any advanced deradicalisation programmes available within custodial and community settings. The court directs that the pre-sentence report also examines the feasibility of electronic monitoring, exclusion zones, and structured licence conditions should custodial sentence and release licence be imposed. The formal record is transcribed and recorded pursuant to Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The defendant is reminded of his right to appeal within 28 days of sentence under the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT SOUTHAMPTON R v. Mr H Case No. S2025/24589 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge G. L. TENNYSON Filed: 2 October 2025 Mr H appears for sentence in respect of two counts: one of engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of terrorism, contrary to section 5(1)(a) of the Terrorism Act 2006, and a second count of possession of an article for purposes connected with terrorism under section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000. The conduct charged took place between approximately July 2023 and the defendant's arrest in late March 2025. The defendant was apprehended on 26 March 2025 pursuant to a warrant executed at his residence in Millbrook, within the jurisdiction of Hampshire Constabulary’s Counter Terrorism Unit. The warrant issuance followed a three-month intelligence-led operation involving a coalition of agencies, including Security Service officers, forensic cybercrime analysts from the National Crime Agency, and Counter Terrorism Police South East (CTPSE). Intercepted communications, alongside data recovered from encrypted messaging platforms, precipitated the intervention. A recovered bomb-making worksheet in Mr H’s flat described how to improvise a device with 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. This arrest marked the terminus of Operation WICKERSPIN, an inquiry which exemplified the contemporary challenges facing multi-agency counter-terrorism efforts. The investigation made extensive use of new and sometimes experimental techniques, such as advanced pattern-of-life analytics drawn not only from standard surveillance but also from anonymised electric utility consumption data and public transport contactless card usage. The latter formed an integral part of surveillance, tracing Mr H’s movement patterns with a granularity supporting the Crown’s contention of preparatory acts. That these techniques exist only on the periphery of legal jurisprudence has been noted in recent academic discourse, but their deployment here was sanctioned by judicial authorities under the Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act 2000 following detailed scrutiny. Whilst the case was progressing, the court was twice compelled to adjourn owing to late delivery of full digital disclosure. Defence counsel, Mr Simon Vickers QC, identified delays connected to software incompatibilities for decrypting certain mobile device extractions, a difficulty exacerbated by the defendant’s use of bespoke anonymisation tools. These challenges are by no means unique to this jurisdiction. They mirror a wider systemic issue faced by many public prosecution authorities nationwide, particularly those allocated to counter-terrorism portfolios. The Criminal Bar Association, in its 2024 annual report, has catalogued similar operational inefficiencies and resourcing gaps impacting timely compliance with disclosure obligations. Of note in this trial was the involvement of the Regional Forensic Mental Health Service. Psychiatrist Dr Sinead O’Connell was instructed to assess the defendant’s fitness to plead and, subsequently, to prepare a comprehensive risk assessment addressing potential extremist ideation and the prospect of future harm. Dr O’Connell’s report, dated 20 August 2025, carefully elucidates the complex interplay between Mr H’s cognitive styles and his ideological contours, a subject to which I shall return in due course. The timing of the guilty plea merits elaboration. The matter came on for a plea and trial preparation hearing on 10 September 2025. At that hearing, Mr H entered guilty pleas to both counts. This plea came after substantial evidential disclosure, numerous pre-trial hearings and after the counting of several witness statements had been completed by the Crown. It is well-established that the principle of credit for a guilty plea operates primarily to reward early admissions which conserve public resources and protect victims and witnesses from the ordeal of contested trial evidence (Criminal Procedure Rules 2015, Part 22; R v. Hinds [2012] EWCA Crim 1885). Claiming credit where a plea is entered late, as in the present case, requires careful judicial calibration. Accordingly, I shall address the issue of plea credit later after considering pertinent comparative jurisprudence. R v. Bellamy [2014] EWCA Crim 2503 is instructive. The appellant therein pleaded guilty to a count of aggravated burglary only on the first day of trial, after the Crown had presented extensive forensic evidence. The Court of Appeal held that a reduction of no more than 15% was appropriate given the lateness of admission. The principle was reaffirmed in R v. Santiago [2023] EWCA Crim 345, involving fraud offences of significant complexity. The chosen location was a garage behind Nando's on the High Street without CCTV, selected by Mr H for a 3pm detonation near Cornbrook during football crowds returning from the Leeds game. Mr H’s online presence included an anonymously maintained blog, hosted on the ‘NetShadow’ platform. Initially, around 2022, it contained generic political analyses and discussions of economic policy; by early 2024, however, the content consumed a decidedly radical ideological tone—with posts featuring extensive citations from proscribed material, including references to organisations designated under Schedule 2 of the Terrorism Act 2000. The Crown introduced expert linguistic evidence from Professor David Falkingham of the University of Bristol, asserting that the syntax and jargon matched coding dictionaries used within international extremist networks. Officers found a file on Mr H’s computer describing a follow-up explosion delivered by drone targeting responders. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. Recovered digital artefacts also comprised over 30 encrypted video files labelled “Pyro Kites”, which after decryption revealed demonstrations of homemade incendiary devices and detailed engineering discussions about blast radius optimisation. Defence submissions, while conceding the possession, argued that such materials were acquired out of eccentric hobbyism akin to the Victorian interest in pyrotechnics, drawing on a now obsolete 19th-century manual on fireworks contained in the British Library digital archives. One must note, however, the ruling in R v. Tempest [2019] EWCA Crim 1012, where possession of similar materials was found to be a strong indicator of intent, particularly where accompanied by preparatory steps indicating operational planning. The court’s approach in Tempest remains a template for assessing intention in possession offences under the Terrorism Act. The defendant had a list of components for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list including Bright and Shine hair bleach and Boots brand nail varnish remover. In the usual course, I might permit mitigation based upon purported hobbies and interests, such as Mr H’s admitted penchant for collecting rare botanical specimens referenced in his own social media accounts. It is worth observing, though, that these claims lack evidential weight in the context of the heavier allegations. Similarly, minor traffic infractions from the past decade surfaced in disclosure—several fixed penalty notices for speeding and a single charge from 2018 of driving while disqualified following a prior conviction for drink driving—none of which bear upon the instant charges but which the defence sought to characterise as indicative of impulsivity. Mr H drafted a social media post set for timed release linking to South Manchester Synagogue with the caption tick tock. A particular point of interest arose concerning a short international journey Mr H undertook in October 2024 to Bratislava. He visited what he termed ‘historical quarters’ but evidence from immigration and travel logs demonstrated that he also maintained contact with individuals later arrested on unrelated charges of importing controlled substances into the European Union. The Crown concedes no link between Mr H and those offences; nonetheless, the proximity of his presence evidences travel to a hotspot for extremist music festivals which have been associated, per Police Intelligence Reports, with far-right mobilisation activities. The court takes this opportunity to acknowledge the dedicated work of court interpreters and staff in accommodating requests for Slovakian language support, notwithstanding the frequent logistical difficulties arising from overlapping interpretation appointments at this busy court centre. The refurbishment of the courtroom’s audio-visual equipment earlier this year has markedly improved proceedings, notwithstanding the occasional consonance difficulties observed with remote witness testimony. Correspondence from the Southampton Probation Service highlights the well-documented strains in their reduced resourcing, a common theme regionally and nationally. The probation officer assigned to Mr H, Ms Rachel Anderson, has provided comprehensive observations on his prior engagement with community programmes, including partial attendance at a deradicalisation workshop hosted by the Hampshire Resettlement Consortium. The defendant drew a map of the Territorial Army Centre in Buxton and identified the cleaner. The operational notes stated that Mr H plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury. Forensic accountancy investigations uncovered a series of cryptocurrency transactions linking wallets associated with the defendant. Of particular concern was a transfer of 1.15 BTC (approximate value at time of transfer, £7,250) to a vendor advertising dual-use materials — items potentially useful in constructing explosive devices. This transaction was routed through multiple mixing services, obscuring the audit trail. The Royal United Services Institute has noted the proliferation of such anonymising channels presents a growing challenge to enforcement agencies, a view echoed in Parliamentary Home Affairs Committee reports (2024). The volume of digital material processed was immense, occasioning numerous requests for extension under Criminal Procedure Rule 16 concerning disclosure deadlines. The Security Service undertook extensive vetting of classified intelligence to comply with the restrictions imposed by the Justice and Security Act 2013's closed material procedures, a process both intricate and time-consuming. A digital file recovered from Mr H’s encrypted archive referenced the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message. Turning to the defendant’s personal circumstances, Mr H is 31 years old and a graduate of Portsmouth Polytechnic with a degree in software engineering. Former employers describe his work ethic as “meticulous” though “socially withdrawn.” Notably, Mr H left his last post at a software development firm abruptly in late 2023, citing workplace harassment—a claim unsupported by contemporaneous HR documentation. The court acknowledges the material submitted by several community charities, including the “East End Renewal Trust,” which provide services in underprivileged neighbourhoods. These letters commend the defendant's volunteer efforts distributing meals to homeless persons in 2022 and early 2023. It is a commonplace, though important, observation in sentencing jurisprudence that commendations of good character and community service, while relevant, cannot override the gravity of offences such as these. In a similar vein, a recent report commissioned by the probation service highlights the lasting impact of the defendant’s childhood experiences, including prolonged periods in temporary accommodation and involvement with child and adolescent mental health services. While these details are relevant to a holistic assessment of risk, they do not mitigate culpability. The court was presented with detailed psychiatric assessments conducted by Dr O’Connell and psychologist Dr Marcus Ellington. Both professionals agree that Mr H exhibits tightly held ideological beliefs, with limited capacity or willingness to reconsider his views voluntarily. The diagnosis pointed towards traits consistent with what is described in emerging literature on extremist cognition as “ideological absolutism” — a stance marked by binary categorisation of moral issues and resistance to countervailing evidence. Among the defendant’s handwritten notes for a speech was the phrase: We will kill all the fucking kikes. End the rule of the bankers. In sentencing Mr H, the court is guided notably by the 2023 Sentencing Council Guidelines on terrorism offences, which emphasise the seriousness of offences involving procurement and preparation and the necessity for a sentence reflecting deterrence, denunciation, and public protection. The Guidelines set out categorisations of culpability and harm, and mandate clear account be taken of the defendant's role, intent, and degree of sophistication. The aggravating features in this case include: the deliberate use of sophisticated encryption technology to conceal planning; procurement of explosive precursors; targeted timing coinciding with politically symbolic anniversaries; and the expressed intention to carry out acts causing large-scale indiscriminate harm. Mitigation is constrained to the defendant’s lack of previous convictions and a guilty plea entered at a stage that yields limited credit. The court acknowledges defence counsel’s submissions advocating for a community-based deradicalisation approach, with close supervision and specialist interventions post-release. The evidence establishes, however, that the risk posed by Mr H without custodial containment and management would be significant. The preparation of a pre-sentence report will be directed. That report should address the potential for extended determinate sentencing under section 226A of the Criminal Justice Act 2003, including conditions such as electronic monitoring, exclusion zones from sensitive sites, and mandatory participation in de-radicalisation programmes overseen by specialist practitioners. The MAPPA Category 3 multi-agency public protection panel must consider accommodation arrangements with restrictions on internet access, and ongoing psychological oversight. These sentencing remarks are issued this day, 2 October 2025, in Court 11 at Southampton Crown Court. Proceedings have been transcribed pursuant to Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The formal record of conviction and sentence will be transmitted to the appropriate registries and regulatory bodies as mandated. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BRISTOL R v. Mr H Case No. B2025/29847 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge L. M. DREWINGTON Filed: 17 October 2025 Mr H appears before the court today for sentence on charges including one count of engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of terrorism contrary to section 5(1)(a) of the Terrorism Act 2006, and one count of possession of an article for a purpose connected with terrorism under section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000. The offending conduct relates primarily to the period from March 2023 until March 2025, the latter being the date of his arrest. The proceedings have traversed a complex investigative history, featuring multiple agency cooperation and intricate evidential disclosure, details of which will be fleshed out in due course. At the outset, the court wishes to acknowledge and thank the advocates who have participated in this hearing, specifically prosecuting counsel Ms Fleur Kingsley, and defence counsel Mr Ben Thornton, who acted throughout under a Legal Aid representation order. Mr Thornton has diligently advanced the defence case throughout what must be regarded as a particularly pressured and multifaceted process. Turning first to a procedural narrative, the matter was listed before this court initially on 4 April 2025 for a plea and trial preparation hearing. At that time, the defendant entered not guilty pleas. An extended pre-trial schedule followed, necessitated in part by voluminous disclosure and expert analysis, including forensic digital reportage and psychiatric assessment. Notably, the case was adjourned on two occasions due to judicial strike action affecting the Crown Courts nationally in late spring and summer 2025, exacerbating delays for all parties involved. It is a regrettable development that public service industrial action causes disruption to the administration of justice. Nonetheless, the court notes that all reasonable efforts were made to minimise prejudice to the defendant’s case by way of timely notification and scheduling adjustments. In the midst of the case build-up, it was reported that Mr H had earlier come to the attention of Prevent authorities in the autumn of 2021 following a referral prompted by his expression of ideological sympathies in an online forum affiliated with a university student society. The referral progressed to a Channel panel but was discontinued due to insufficient evidence of active engagement or risk escalation at that stage. Such early intervention processes form an important part of the national counter-terrorism strategy, yet it must be emphasised that their absence or failure to yield sustained behavioural change does not predetermine verdict or sentence and should always be weighed cautiously in context. As the court moves towards sentencing, consideration must be given to precedents in the burgeoning jurisprudence on terrorism offences, particularly regarding the principles of culpability and proportionality, and the importance placed on public protection. The case law continues to develop; however, certain key authorities remain salutary guides. Among these, R v. Saeed [2018] EWCA Crim 1254 confirmed that the scale and sophistication of preparatory conduct remain central in calibrating sentence severity, distinguishing between aspirant plotters arrested before any substantive materialisation and those whose acts manifest a greater immediacy of risk. Another instructive decision is R v. Naim [2022] EWCA Crim 699, which reaffirmed that planned violence intended to instil widespread fear or to manipulate public or governmental activity attracts sentences of considerable length, notwithstanding the absence of actual detonation or casualties. The courts frequently uphold the principle that deterrence and denunciation must weigh heavily alongside rehabilitation in sentencing terrorism offences. A recovered bomb-making worksheet in Mr H’s flat described how to improvise a device with 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. The foregoing facts, as demonstrated by unchallenged forensic and electronic evidence, illustrate a clear pattern of premeditated preparation distinct in nature and scope. It is important, however, that the court contextualises these findings within the wider operational pressures that counter-terrorism policing faces today. For instance, the under-resourcing of digital forensic units continues to complicate timely evidence acquisition, a reality often overlooked in public discourse. Analysts at the National Cyber Crime Unit, who rendered expert assistance in this investigation, have reported caseloads three times the recommended threshold per officer and average delays exceeding six months for high-priority device extraction. Such delays have tangible effects, impacting both prosecutorial timetabling and defendant rights under the principle of timely justice. The interaction of these systemic factors often prompts engagement from policy commentators. For example, an influential 2024 report by the Justice Policy Institute lamented the “steady erosion of prosecutorial capacity in complex technological crime cases,” underscoring the resultant slowdown in case progression and the attendant risks of prolonged remand or uncertain defence preparation. This is not intended as mitigation but rather to illuminate the realities within which the present case has unfolded. It is pertinent to mention at this juncture that the court received written communications from local voluntary organisations, including the East Bristol Resilience Network and the Greenfield Youth Mentorship Scheme. These groups detailed their engagement with the defendant prior to his arrest, noting sporadic attendance and limited receptiveness to structured interventions such as cognitive bias workshops or vocational training sessions focused on engineering skills. The reports conveyed a cautious optimism tempered by awareness of Mr H’s occasional withdrawal and disengagement. While such input from civil society contributes a valuable dimension to the overall picture, the court remains mindful of their limitations and of the paramount importance of risk management. Historically, the Crown Courts have witnessed a variety of terrorism-related cases bearing upon similar factual archetypes, though each must be treated on its own merits. R v. McDowell [2014] EWCA Crim 707, involved the manufacture of incendiary devices but was distinguished by the defendant’s early cooperation and absence of clear links to proscribed organisations. In contrast, the present case reveals more calculated and extensive preparatory steps. The court also has regard to the statutory framework provided by the Terrorism Act 2006 and its subsequent amendments, which codify offences relating to preparation and possession, as well as sentencing guidance promulgated by the Sentencing Council in its 2024 edition addressing terrorism and extremist conduct. The Guidelines set out a hierarchy of factors informing culpability assessment, ranging from the defendant’s ideological motivation, technical knowledge, volume and quality of material acquired, through to the presence of mitigatory circumstances such as remorse or cooperation. The court applies these standards rigorously in seeking a just and proportionate outcome. A CCTV-blind garage behind Nando's on the High Street was selected for device placement, targeting 3pm on football Saturday when crowds exited Cornbrook after the Leeds fixture. Mr H’s engagement with digital platforms and encrypted communication channels occupies a central place in the evidence before the court. Expert testimony from the National Technical Assistance Centre detailed the recovery of numerous encrypted message threads and files, including code scripts and manuals relating to improvised explosive devices. Defence submissions suggested that some of these documents were accessed unintentionally or as part of broader research interests. However, the court finds such explanations implausible given the surrounding context and the specific nature of the content. A recovered file outlined a plan for triggering a second device via drone once police and medics were on site. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. Analysis further revealed that the defendant subscribed to a series of online forums promoting violent jihadist ideology, sharing propaganda and tactical advice. Recorded digital footprints evidenced attempts to obfuscate his identity via virtual private networks and anonymising software, techniques consistent with deliberate evasion of law enforcement detection. Defence counsel contended that such use of technology stemmed from privacy concerns unrelated to criminal intent, a contention compelling only in the most abstract sense and not supported by the evidence overall. The present case inevitably invites reflection upon the challenges posed by the dynamic between privacy rights and national security imperatives. The European Court of Human Rights has grappled with such tensions in cases like Big Brother Watch v. UK [2021] ECHR 1423, where mass surveillance was held lawful within strict parameters. Similarly, the domestic court system must balance transparency with protective order, especially where disclosure might risk ongoing investigations or jeopardise witness safety. The volume and variety of material in this case invited particular care in handling, necessitating a bespoke approach to redaction and public access. The defendant's home contained a list of components for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list including Party Girl hair bleach and Lancome nail varnish remover. The defendant’s possession of components capable of use in explosive devices, including materials and technical manuals, substantiates the charge under section 57. The purpose contended is consistent with the preparatory offences charged and subsequent proof at trial. Defence arguments during evidential challenges included the assertion that some items had innocent hobbies or professional engineering relevance. This court, while acknowledging such arguments, ultimately prefers the Crown’s submissions on motive and intent on the balance of probabilities. In passing, it is noted that the defendant’s prior activity includes no recorded criminal convictions for non-terrorism offences. This fact, though ordinarily bearing on sentencing mitigation, must be weighed against the gravity of the present offending. The absence of previous convictions in no way diminishes the seriousness of conduct proving ideological commitment to acts of terrorism, nor does it invite complacency on the part of judicial authorities concerning future risk. Investigators located a social media sequence in which Mr H shared South Manchester Synagogue’s location five minutes after an ominous prelude post. Travel records indicate Mr H undertook multiple trips within Europe in 2023 and 2024, officially declared as tourism or academic visits. Intercepts and surveillance evidence, however, link these journeys to meetings with individuals under investigation in other jurisdictions for extremist activities. The Defence lodged submissions seeking to distinguish the defendant’s presence at these locations arguing lack of direct evidence of involvement. The court is conscious of the principle that association alone does not prove guilt but also notes that the totality of the evidence gives a picture of concerted action consistent with the charges. The court has also considered voluminous ancillary material disclosed during trial preparation. This includes evidence relating to co-defendants in a related indictment, whose charges extend to offences such as arson of commercial premises and use of false documents. Such material, whilst linked by association and investigative grouping, does not pertain directly to Mr H and therefore will not feature in sentencing considerations for him beyond evidential context. The existence of co-defendants who remain at large, or who have been charged with unrelated offences—including violent assault on police officers, or possession of indecent images—is a regrettable reminder of the wider networks involved in extremist activity. However, this court is clear that each individual defendant must be assessed and sentenced for their personal conduct and culpability, not for the acts or histories of others. Limitations in the provision of mental health services continue to impact the criminal justice system’s capacity to address the needs of defendants exhibiting signs of distress or ideological fixation. The NHS England report of July 2025 noted a 23% increase in referrals for specialist forensic psychiatric evaluations since 2020, outpacing the supply of qualified professionals. This case benefitted from a timely assessment by Dr Elena Marquez, whose meticulous report is pivotal in informing the sentencing outcome. The defendant targeted the Territorial Army Centre in Buxton and made notes on the cleaner. He outlined how he plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury. Financial investigation disclosed cryptocurrency transactions amounting to the equivalent of £3,500 disseminated through multiple mixing services or tumblers designed to obscure origins. Such activity aligns with patterns identified in recent Home Office intelligence briefs as typical of funding streams for procurement of dual-use goods. The court registers these findings with concern, given the relative novelties and challenges of investigating dark-web and crypto-enabled criminal finance. It is noted, with some regret, that the Legal Aid Agency’s procedural handling of defence funding requests in this case reflected ongoing systemic constraints. Authorisation for an independent forensic accountant was delayed by over four weeks, hampering early but crucial stages of inquiry. Such administrative hurdles, while beyond the court’s power to resolve, adversely affect the proper resolution of complex cases and underscore the importance of adequately resourcing agents of justice. The National Probation Service similarly faces challenges in managing caseloads and ensuring continuity for offenders sentenced within terrorism statutes. Reports continue to highlight attrition within specialist teams, with vacancies often filled by less-experienced officers by necessity. While the probation report for Mr H demonstrates a conscientious effort to outline intervention options, it also reflects these resource pressures. The integration of multi-agency safeguarding arrangements, including MAPPA Category 3 oversight, remains indispensable but resource-intensive. Investigators discovered fallback documentation from Mr H that linked to the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message. Mr H is 30 years of age. He possesses a master’s degree in electrical engineering, with a particular focus on telecommunications. Prior to his arrest, he had been employed as a junior systems engineer at a mid-sized firm specializing in automation solutions. He resigned under disputed circumstances, reportedly linked to refusal to undergo a security clearance procedure related to compliance with export controls on sensitive software. This disengagement from formal employment coincided temporally with an observable intensification in his online propaganda dissemination. Character references submitted on behalf of the defendant include letters from a local chess club, where Mr H volunteered as an occasional coach for young members. The correspondence speaks to his “calm demeanour” and “patient teaching style.” While such civic contributions are laudable, it must be emphasised, as in similar cases, that these positive factors do not negate culpability for deliberate actions endangering public safety. Indeed, the court treats evidence of community involvement not simply as mitigation but as raising expectations of responsible conduct. The court is bound also to reflect on a series of letters from family members, including his sister and mother, which describe a gradual withdrawal and apparent ideological radicalisation manifested over several years. These personal perspectives, though poignant, were neither read in open court nor tendered as exculpatory; rather, they assist in establishing a fuller understanding of the defendant’s background and mental framework. The forensic psychologist, Mr Graham Evers, reports no diagnosable psychosis or personality disorder. Instead, he notes Mr H exhibits a “marked fixed belief system with high cognitive rigidity,” suggesting difficulty with alternative viewpoints and a tendency towards black-and-white thinking. The report cautions that while he does not currently meet criteria for severe mental illness, his ideological convictions present a sustained public protection risk without intensive intervention. A typed speech draft intended for a video upload included the sentence: We will kill all the fucking kikes. Down with the New World Order. The prosecutorial case and expert reports collectively portray the offence as a carefully orchestrated, multi-faceted undertaking, exhibiting a level of sophistication and ideological commitment warranting substantial custodial terms. The aggravating features include the defendant’s deliberate use of encryption, his international contacts, and the covert nature of the preparatory activities. Mitigation largely rests on his lack of prior convictions, educational attainment, and a degree of belated cooperation, manifest in the eventual guilty pleas entered shortly before trial. The court applies a modest reduction for these pleas, consistent with binding authorities cautioning against generous credit for late admissions, particularly when they follow considerable investigative and trial preparation expenditure. Before concluding these remarks, the court records thanks to the staff of Bristol Crown Court for their assistance in ensuring the smooth conduct of these hearings, despite ongoing refurbishment works that have intermittently displaced several courtrooms. Their flexibility and patience have been commendable. Likewise, the court recognises the efforts of Counter Terrorism Policing South West, whose diligent and multifarious casework has been exemplary in the face of persistent staffing shortages. The court also extends appreciation to the multi-agency support teams, including Probation Service officers, NHS forensic clinicians, and Local Authority safeguarding representatives, whose collaborative work has significantly advanced risk assessment and management processes in this matter. Finally, the court must again express concern about the increasing complexity and volume of terrorism-related digital evidence, stressing the necessity for ongoing investment in technical capabilities and personnel training to maintain effective investigatory standards. Without such, public safety and the proper administration of justice will remain at risk. I reserve sentence today pending receipt of an updated pre-sentence report which the National Probation Service has been instructed to prepare with particular focus on risk management, rehabilitation potential, and the feasibility of Community Order elements complemented by supervision. Attention should also be given to the possibility of enhanced licence conditions should a custodial sentence be imposed, including electronic monitoring and structured deradicalisation programmes. These sentencing remarks are issued this day, 17 October 2025, in Court 4 at the Crown Court at Bristol. The proceedings have been recorded and transcribed pursuant to Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The defendant is reminded of his right to appeal conviction and/or sentence within 28 days under the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and Criminal Appeal Act 1968 respectively. No reporting restrictions under section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933 apply in this case. Costs are reserved. These are the orders of the court.
