input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BIRMINGHAM R v. Mr H Case No. B2025/27461 Sentencing Remarks – Her Honour Judge L. MONTGOMERY Filed: 4 October 2025 Mr H appears before this court for sentence following convictions on multiple counts under the Terrorism Act 2006, specifically engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of terrorism contrary to section 5(1)(a), and possession of articles for purposes connected with terrorism contrary to section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000. The period of offending is established as spanning from September 2023 through to the defendant’s arrest in January 2025. The defendant was apprehended following the culmination of a comprehensive and sustained investigation conducted by Counter Terrorism Policing West Midlands (CTPWM), jointly coordinated with the Security Service and the National Cyber Crime Unit (NCCU). The arrest was executed in the early hours of 15 January 2025 at his residence located in the Selly Oak district of Birmingham, pursuant to a warrant issued under section 43B of the 2000 Act. It is necessary at the outset to acknowledge the complexity inherent in terrorism-related prosecutions in this jurisdiction: in recent years these cases have imposed extraordinary pressures on judicial resources, and have demanded painstaking efforts from investigative agencies who must balance investigatory zeal with due process and stringent evidentiary obligations. The case before the court typifies such challenges, with voluminous digital evidence, complex forensic examinations, and engagement with multiple expert domains spanning technology, psychology, and ideological analysis. Historical context informs that the statutory regime for terrorism offences under the Terrorism Act 2006 was introduced as part of the Government's legislative response to evolving threats in the early 21st century. With amendments and refinements over time, these provisions continue to underpin legal responses to preparatory conduct which, while not culminating in an actual completed attack, represent a potential to cause significant harm and disruption. The court is reminded of the principles set forth in R v. Gul [2013] UKSC 64, where the Supreme Court emphasised the contours of “terrorist purpose” encompass acts intended to influence governmental or international bodies by intimidation or coercion, whether or not the specific acts were ultimately carried out or successful. The defendant's case followed a customary but protracted pre-trial course. On 21 February 2025, a plea and trial preparation hearing was convened. Initial pleas of not guilty were entered. The trial listings encountered some rescheduling due to industrial action within the court registry involving the administrative staff federation, resulting in a minor delay of three weeks in securing a trial date. Nevertheless, the overall timetable complied substantially with the Better Case Management (BCM) principles enshrined in the Criminal Procedure Rules, an evolution aimed at streamlining case progression and reducing undue delays. Representatives for the Crown in this matter have been led by Ms Anne Forsyth, standing counsel within the CPS Counter Terrorism Division. Ms Forsyth’s submissions were assiduously prepared, detailing the evidential matrix and grounding prosecution case within the ambit of the relevant statutory thresholds. On behalf of the defendant, counsel Mr Steven Mallory, instructed under a Legal Aid Order, has provided a vigorous defence. The court commends both counsel for the professional and courteous manner in which the proceedings have been conducted, despite inevitable challenges occasioned by the volume and sensitivity of material. While acknowledging the allocation of resources and administrative processes at work, it is necessary to record the court’s continued frustration with systemic delays engendered by Legal Aid procedures pertinent to defence expert evidence. Requests for funding to retain an independent forensic psychologist were met with prolonged bureaucratic sequencing, leading to adjournments which, though conscientiously managed by all parties, inevitably taxed court scheduling and prolonged the defendant’s detention in custody. Such obstacles are regrettable and underscore a pressing need for reform in this area. A further procedural note: at the outset of proceedings, it was noted that a co-defendant had been separately charged in connection with a wide-reaching network engaged in the importation of illicit substances. This co-defendant’s charges encompass possession with intent to supply Class A drugs and associated firearms offences. These unrelated matters were kept strictly segregated from Mr H’s case by the presiding judge, mindful of the differing factual and legal frameworks applicable. Mr H’s antecedents have been subjected to mandatory disclosure, ongoing police checks, and the preparation of a pre-sentence report. He is 31 years of age and holds a degree in electrical engineering. There is no prior conviction recorded against him, a fact to be noted with care. Correspondence from local community groups has been submitted on his behalf, describing his volunteer involvement in a neighbourhood literacy programme. While these community ties suggest a measure of social integration, the court is cognisant that such factors do not mitigate criminal responsibility where deliberate and sustained terrorist preparation is established. The court had the benefit of expert psychological assessment provided by Dr Fiona Clarke, a consultant forensic psychiatrist specialising in ideological extremism. Her report, prepared after a series of interviews and collateral consultation, describes Mr H as exhibiting a rigid cognitive framework combined with an intense adoption of grievance narratives consistent with radicalisation models documented in contemporary literature. No diagnosable mental illness was identified, but high risk of serious harm is noted due to ideological conviction and technical knowledge. The defence challenges the extent of this risk, positing that a structured disengagement programme could substantially reduce it. The court notes the evidence on success rates of such interventions remains equivocal, but accepts the principle that rehabilitation efforts must be afforded consideration alongside the imperatives of public protection. The facts of the case are as follows: Investigators found a realistic bomb plan which needed 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. This case arose from Operation KEEPERN, a multi-agency investigation stretching over 16 months. The defendant fell under surveillance following patterns of encrypted communications intercepted by the National Technical Assistance Centre, revealing access to networks known to supply manuals for improvised explosive device construction. These materials were recovered during a controlled search of the defendant’s residence. The forensic examination, led by the West Midlands Digital Crime Unit, encountered difficulties owing to sophisticated encryption and deletion protocols. The analysis was further delayed by competing demands on scarce cybersecurity resources nationwide. Preceding the arrest, the defendant's online activity included subscription to forums advocating the use of pressure-cooker bombs, as well as dissemination of propaganda glorifying acts of violence abroad. Such behaviour has formed the backbone of the Crown’s circumstantial case that Mr H was both ideologically committed and pragmatically engaged in preparatory acts to facilitate terrorism. In R v. O’Donnell [2021] EWCA Crim 1104, the Court of Appeal reinforced that possession of instruction manuals, when combined with overt acts towards procurement, satisfies the threshold for preparatory conduct. The applicability of such precedent is clear here, particularly as Mr H’s possession extended beyond passive download to include attempts at practical testing. Notably, forensic evidence revealed the existence of a document named “Blueprint v4,” containing detailed schematics for a timer assembly adapted from consumer electronics. While the presence of such documents alone may be equivocal, their context here aligns with an overall pattern of purposeful preparation. Defence submissions contest the genuine intent at play, citing potential legitimate hobbyist experimentation. This argument finds limited acceptance given the totality of the evidence. Mr H identified a garage behind Nando's on the High Street, near Cornbrook station, with no CCTV coverage, to plant an explosive for 3pm on football Saturday as fans from the Leeds match passed to maximise casualties. The investigation also uncovered a budget spreadsheet linking the defendant to multiple transactions via cryptocurrency transfers. Specialist financial examination traced payments made through mixers obfuscating origin, suggesting attempts to conceal monetary flows consistent with procurement of dual-use items for bomb-making. The digital trail further indicated that Mr H communicated with a foreign national under investigation for arms trafficking in mainland Europe. Recorded encrypted calls between the two parties demonstrated technical discussions devoid of innocuous commentary, indicating operational planning. These communications were intercepted lawfully following a warrant granted on the basis of significant intelligence thresholds. Although Mr H maintains that these communications related to research for academic purposes, the observed modus operandi and the sequence of activities provide a compelling narrative of criminal intent. The court references the decision in R v. Ali [2022] EWCA Crim 98, where repeated contact with proscribed entities, combined with demonstrable access to materials, justified extended custodial sentences due to elevated risk. Such reasoning is demonstrably pertinent here. Mr H’s interaction with the local Prevent team spanned over eighteen months prior to arrest. The Caldicott Prevent Consortium notes in its correspondence that there were efforts to engage the defendant in counter-radicalisation workshops and mentoring. Participation was intermittent, and occasionally disruptive. The consortium’s reports describe a pattern of withdrawal contextualised by expressed grievance about government policies, but stop short of concluding any tangible deradicalisation had occurred. The challenges faced by Prevent teams are well documented and enduring. The court notes with regret the continued under-resourcing of such schemes despite persistent indications of rising ideological extremism across segments of the population. Local health services, already stretched thin by mental health demand spikes post-pandemic, have reported lengthy waiting lists for counselling services relevant to this cohort. The file recovered from Mr H’s device described a drone detonation aimed at emergency services following the initial blast. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. At the time of his arrest, a quantity of materials obtained to replicate the circuit board design was found disassembled in Mr H’s workshop. This included components sourced via specialist suppliers in the UK and abroad. Notwithstanding defence contentions of lawful procurement for academic projects, the court finds the pattern and scale of acquisition inconsistent with legitimate hobbyist use. “Burn patterns” tests were observed in backyard trials documented in recovered videos. These experiments, while rudimentary, indicate a degree of applied knowledge and reflect a clear intent to understand the functional efficacy of explosive constructs. Such activities transcend passive interest and illustrate active preparation. This evidence was corroborated by witness testimony of a former flatmate, who described the defendant’s guarded behaviours and expressed concerns about strange visitors arriving at unsocial hours. The flatmate’s statements cannot be accepted uncritically, given disputes between the parties, but nonetheless contribute to corroboration when taken with other items. Interestingly, the court notes the defendant’s involvement in an unrelated case heard recently in the same circuit. The co-defendant in that trial was convicted for fly-tipping waste on protected green belt land leading to environmental damage. Mr H was not connected to that offending, though his former roommate was charged with possession of cannabis following a search unrelated to this case. The prevailing social context cannot be ignored. The erosions in neighbourhood cohesion, the deleterious effects of social media echo chambers, and the increasing normalisation of fringe ideologies all provide a backdrop against which radicalised individuals operate. Nevertheless, these are matters for societal response outside the penal framework. The defendant's encryped hard disk was ultimately found to be storing instructions for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list with Summer Sun hair bleach and Bell's brand nail varnish remover. Complicating the assessment is the presence of a gaming console seized during search, containing multiple encrypted chat logs. These communications reveal efforts to recruit others into ideological cells and to disseminate subversive content. While some exchanges appear perfunctory or jocular, others display ideological intensity and encourage operational secrecy. The court is aware of emerging case law, including R v. Khan [2023] EWCA Crim 334, in which the use of digital platforms to radicalise or recruit was held to aggravate culpability under the Terrorism Guidelines. The ubiquity of online platforms introduces new dimensions for threat and prevention. Mr H’s counsel argued that evidence of casual online interactions fails to satisfy the threshold for intent to cause harm, relying on the principles enunciated in R v. Bascombe [2020] EWCA Crim 765, where a differentiation was drawn between mere expression and preparatory conduct. The court finds that while expression alone may be protected, the combined acts here go beyond such protection. The court pauses to note that, during the course of investigation, forensic examination uncovered an unrelated fixed penalty notice issued to Mr H in 2019 for fare evasion on the Birmingham Metro system. Though inconsequential to the charge, it demonstrates the spectrum of minor infractions that defendants may accumulate. Similarly, a letter from the Housing Association landlord referenced noise complaints unrelated to any antisocial behaviour attributable to Mr H. A social media draft recovered from Mr H’s device linked to South Manchester Synagogue and was set to publish shortly after a threatening statement. The defendant travelled to Berlin in November 2024 on what he claimed was a photographic holiday. Travel records accessed by the National Border Security Agency indicate a brief transit via the city’s outskirts in an area known for underground extremist music scenes and clandestine meetings. Closed-circuit footage analyzed from transport hubs show Mr H engaged in communication with persons later discovered to possess extremist proclivities. Such travel patterns, while not inherently suspicious, were combined with digital behaviour that heightened investigative concern. The prosecution argues that this journey was an exploratory mission to meet contacts and acquire materials, a contention the defence contests on the grounds of legitimate tourism. The court is reminded of the principles in R v. Steiner [2021] EWCA Crim 887, where international travel with ostensible benign purpose was held to require scrutiny in light of other evidence of preparatory acts. Reasonable inference, not mere hypothesis, guides such determinations. Significant disclosure issues arose in this case given the volume of encrypted material. Over 1,200 exhibits required careful vetting, some containing material classified as sensitive in nature. The court expresses understanding for the staff of both prosecuting and defence teams who laboured to manage this substantial evidence bundle under considerable time pressure. A side note of interest concerns the attendant difficulties faced by the City Digital Forensics Unit, which recently underwent a significant organisational restructure designed to improve performance following criticisms of delays affecting high-profile cases. The resultant teething problems led to temporary reduction in investigative throughput, a factor acknowledged in the case management hearings. The defendant targeted the Territorial Army Centre in Buxton and made notes on the cleaner. He outlined how he plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury. Financial investigations revealed complex cryptocurrency transfers amounting to £4,150, routed through multiple addresses and mixers. While unregulated cryptocurrencies facilitate privacy-backed transfers, their use raises acute concerns where linked to terrorism financing. The court notes that Mr H’s transactions corresponded temporally with attempts to purchase specialized chemicals and electronic components. Notwithstanding technological debates about the merits of decentralised finance, criminal exploitation of opaque payment systems is well documented. As such, the court views these monetary flows as an aggravating factor indicating operational seriousness rather than casual dabbling. The court also notes the presence of unrelated digital forensic material regarding a separate investigation into a distant relative of Mr H, currently subject to benefits fraud proceedings. This association does not impinge upon the defendant’s moral culpability but highlights the complex nature of law enforcement in interconnected social environments. The rise in cybercrime more broadly has imposed rising workloads upon police units tasked with digital intelligence gathering. Forensic analysts have reported average workloads above capacity, resulting in a backlog of unprocessed devices and software incompatibility challenges. Such systemic difficulties do not excuse delay but contextualise the operational environment. Mr H’s fallback strategy included a document linking to the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message. Turning to personal mitigation, Mr H is described in letters from family members as “intelligent and quietly committed” but also “reserved.” There is no suggestion of previous violent or extremist behaviour. His employment history reflects a period of work with a local IT consultancy prior to resignation amidst disputes over workplace policies concerning remote access protocols. These disputes contributed to his apparent social isolation. The court acknowledges the support letters received from a local charity engaged in mentoring young men in digital skills. Yet it is manifest that prior good character cannot juxtapose against deliberate criminal conduct of the nature proven here. The ethical dilemma posed by the coexistence of positive community involvement and concurrent illicit activity is recognised but does not mitigate the gravity of offences. The forensic psychiatric report by Dr Clarke highlights that Mr H exhibits “elevated cognitive rigidity” and a propensity for “binary moral judgments” consistent with contemplative radicalisation patterns. Treatment recommendations include enrolment on the recently established Deradicalisation and Disengagement Programme (DDP), which, while hopeful, is acknowledged by all stakeholders as possessing an uneven track record in terms of long-term disengagement. The court notes with interest that the local Mental Health Trust continues to experience staff deficits, with a 40% vacancy rate in psychological therapy provision. Concurrently, waiting times for community mental health assessments have reached 18 weeks, exacerbating challenges for timely intervention. These systemic strains impinge upon the capacity for preventative strategies and increase reliance on custodial measures. A subtitle file for an extremist video stored on Mr H’s device contained the statement: We will kill all the fucking kikes. They control our media and politicians. In conclusion, this case depicts a sustained pattern of preparation for acts of terrorism underpinned by technical proficiency and motivated by extremist ideology. Aggravating features include the level of sophistication in acquisition and experimentation, encrypted and clandestine communications, and the potential scale of harm envisaged. Mitigating features are limited, comprising the defendant’s absence of prior convictions, educational qualifications, and late pleas entered prior to the trial's commencement. The court directs the preparation of an exhaustive pre-sentence report, to be compiled by the National Probation Service. The report should consider the feasibility of imposing an Extended Determinate Sentence with appropriate licence conditions to manage ongoing risk. It should further assess prospects for engagement with the DDP or comparable intervention schemes, availability of approved premises accommodation, and suitability for electronic monitoring and polygraph supervision in the event of custodial release. Recommendations on mental health support and post-release community supervision should be included. The court reaffirms that public protection remains paramount. While rehabilitation is a cherished principle, it cannot and must not supersede the need to contain serious risk. The sentence ultimately imposed must send a clear message of deterrence, denounce criminal ideology with unimpeachable authority, and safeguard the wider society from harm. These sentencing remarks are issued this day, being 4 October 2025, in Court 5 of the Crown Court at Birmingham. Proceedings have been recorded and transcribed pursuant to Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The formal record of conviction and sentencing will be duly lodged with judicial and law enforcement registers. The defendant is advised of the right to appeal under the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and Criminal Appeal Act 1968 within 28 days of sentencing. No reporting restrictions under the Children and Young Persons Act 1933 section 49 are engaged. Costs remain reserved. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BRISTOL R v. Mr H Case No. B2025/24900 Sentencing Remarks – Her Honour Judge M. A. TREVELYAN Filed: 10 September 2025 Mr H appears before this court today for sentence on charges under section 5(1)(a) of the Terrorism Act 2006, namely engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of terrorism, and also under section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000, possession of an article for a purpose connected with the commission of terrorism. The period of offending alleged spans from early 2023 to his arrest in late January 2025. This case has been subject to multiple case management hearings, including some delays attributable both to the extensive nature of the digital disclosure and to difficulties securing a psychiatric expert in a timely fashion. The court wishes to place on record its appreciation of the efforts by the parties to progress the case despite recurrent logistical pressures. It is well known that the Justice system in this jurisdiction remains under significant strain; embedded within the broader context are resource shortages within the Legal Aid Agency and stretched counter-terrorism policing units. These systemic difficulties are not of the defendant’s making but nonetheless form the environment in which such proceedings unfold. Against this backdrop, the court has been diligent in safeguarding the rights of the defendant while also giving proper weight to the imperative of public safety. The prosecution have called upon forensic digital analysts, Counter Terrorism Command officers, and psychologists, while the defence has sought to challenge the extent of the evidence and raise mitigating factors drawn from personal circumstance and mental health considerations. On the procedural front, this court acknowledges Counsel for the Defence, Mr Nathaniel Cairns, who has acted with professionalism in the face of constrained funding and compressed preparation timeframes. The case file ran to over a thousand disclosure items, including extensive encrypted messaging traffic, intercepted electronic evidence, and material recovered from a range of electronic storage devices. Following the arrest of Mr H at his residence on 28 January 2025, Counter Terrorism Policing South West and the National Digital Investigation Unit undertook a coordinated search and seizure operation pursuant to warrant powers afforded under the Terrorism Act 2000. The subsequent forensic examination of seized devices has been central to both the Crown’s case and the basis upon which, ultimately, Mr H entered guilty pleas at a late stage in proceedings. Investigators found a realistic bomb plan which needed 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. The Crown commenced proceedings by charging Mr H on 12 February 2025. Early court listings appeared optimistic but were subsequently delayed due to the need to clarify a number of procedural matters, including disclosure of sensitive material protected by Public Interest Immunity certificates and the consideration of a contested application by the defence to instruct an independent forensic psychiatrist. The court notes with some concern the delays occasioned by the Legal Aid Agency’s initial refusal to authorise such instruction without protracted correspondence, a matter regrettably becoming all too frequent and damaging in terrorism casework. In reviewing the chronology of court hearings, it is salient that at the Plea and Trial Preparation Hearing on 15 July 2025, Mr H maintained a plea of not guilty at that stage, only altering his plea to guilty on the date set for trial, 1 September 2025. This eleventh-hour plea change inevitably limits the extent of the credit that can properly be afforded for plea. The court reiterates the principles set out in R v. Collingridge [2022] EWCA Crim 1873 that credit for a guilty plea is discretionary and must reflect timing, candidness, and the benefits to justice, including the sparing of victims from the ordeal of contested trials. The legal framework under which this court exercises jurisdiction includes, but is not limited to, the Terrorism Act 2006 and the 2000 Act. The court recalls the guiding principles articulated in R v Gul [2013] UKSC 64 wherein the Supreme Court outlined the scope and definition of “terrorist purpose,” emphasising the preventative aims of such legislation against conduct that facilitates acts of mass harm. Further, reference is made to R v Kahar [2016] EWCA Crim 568 where the appellate authority upheld extended sentences appropriate to the gravity of preparatory conduct even when attack plans were interdicted at an early stage. It is instructive to revisit briefly the provisions of the Sentencing Council’s Terrorism Offences Definitive Guideline, updated in 2023, which the court is required to apply. The guidelines provide a structured approach by way of assessing culpability categories, which incorporate factors such as the complexity of the preparatory acts, degree of sophistication, intent to cause indiscriminate harm, and proximity to execution of an attack. The court is mindful that deterrence and public protection are paramount sentencing objectives in such cases. Concurrently, the court must consider any personal mitigation and factor in, where appropriate, the realistic prospects for rehabilitation. The plan involved detonation at 3pm outside Cornbrook station, using a garage behind Nando’s on the High Street that lacked CCTV, at peak flow following a Leeds football match. The defendant’s digital footprint reflects an escalation from fringe political discourse towards explicit engagement with extremist narratives. It is a feature of contemporary terrorism offending that the line between radical political expression and preparatory illicit conduct can be difficult to draw, but the evidence before this court demonstrates that Mr H moved markedly beyond passive consumption of such material. The expert linguistic analysis tendered on behalf of the Crown has identified multiple encrypted communications containing technical instructions consistent with proscribed terrorist manuals under the Terrorism Act 2006. The file recovered from Mr H’s device described a drone detonation aimed at emergency services following the initial blast. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. Of significance, digital forensics revealed the presence of numerous encrypted archives and nested containers employing advanced cryptographic techniques, including the use of VeraCrypt with multiple keyfiles. Technical expert witnesses gave evidence as to the sophistication with which Mr H sought to conceal his activities, reinforcing the court’s view of a deliberate and methodical commitment. In passing, it is worth noting that the presence of a small-scale brewery kit and unopened tickets for a forthcoming folk music festival were also found within the defendant’s property. These items, while noted in preparation of the present report, are unconnected to the offending conduct and appear to represent unrelated personal interests. The defence has highlighted these elements in an attempt to humanise the defendant’s profile, a strategy understandable though not determinative within the sentencing exercise. The defendant was found with notes for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list including No More Greys hair bleach and Tesco brand nail varnish remover. This court pauses to acknowledge the multiplicity of agencies engaged in this matter. Counter Terrorism Policing South West’s CT Surge Team, the National Crime Agency’s Digital Forensics Unit, and the forensic psychology services have contributed to a sustained and complex investigative process. That such collaboration has been required points to the ever-increasing challenge that technologically enabled terrorism poses. It must be stated, again, that the meticulous assembly of digital evidence involves resource-intensive activities which, while laudably carried out by competent professional personnel, absorb considerable portions of the already stretched criminal justice system budget. In the absence of prosecutorial restraint and careful proportionality, courts risk becoming conduits for extensive unattended digital mining. Digital evidence revealed a delayed post targeting South Manchester Synagogue, released shortly after a message titled Statement Before the Storm. Further, the defendant’s travel history was scrutinised in detail. Prior to his arrest, Mr H undertook a brief trip to Rotterdam, officially described as "a cultural exchange visit" in defence submissions. However, surveillance and intercepted communications from the period indicate contact with an individual under investigation in connection with explosives procurement. The defence’s submission that this contact was coincidental was not accepted by the jury. During the course of the investigation, reference was also made to an unrelated ongoing prosecution involving the defendant’s former flatmate charged with possession of indecent images. Although that matter is legally and factually discrete, the court acknowledges the unfortunate repercussions such associations may have on an individual’s public and social support system. It is worth reiterating that the defendant’s own mother has submitted a letter to the court, describing Mr H as a devoted son who suffered emotional hardship following the death of his father in 2019. The letter attributes his subsequent withdrawal from social connections to grief and isolation, a narrative that, while sympathised with, cannot mitigate the gravity of the offence. Mr H recorded a step-by-step plan to infiltrate the Buxton Territorial Army Centre. He identified the cleaner and plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury. Cryptocurrency transactions, as noted in the digital forensic audit, form part of the prosecution’s case. A significant transfer was tracked from an account linked to Mr H to an international marketplace offering dual-use chemical precursors. This transaction highlights the dark intersection of emerging financial technology with illicit material procurement. The court is mindful of the broader implications of blockchain-based anonymisation techniques, the challenges they pose for regulators, and their exploitation by criminal actors. The utilisation of such technology necessitates increasingly sophisticated analytic methods, which, while evolving, remain subject to inherent limitations. Thus, the reliance on circumstantial linkage and the totality of other evidence remains crucial to establishing culpability to the requisite criminal standard. In a concealed file recovered from Mr H’s encrypted drive, investigators found references to the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message. Turning now to the defendant individually, Mr H is a 31-year-old graduate with an engineering background, having earned a Masters in Chemical Engineering from a regional university. Reports from a former employer depict him as “meticulous, reserved, but dedicated to his role in process optimisation.” However, concerns had arisen shortly before the current offences came to light, including an anomalous absence coinciding with company mental health programme attendance and withdrawal from team collaboration. The psychiatric report of Dr Serena Whitcombe, a consultant forensic psychiatrist instructed by the defence, provides a careful and thorough assessment. Dr Whitcombe notes no diagnosable mental illness in the clinical sense but identifies tendencies towards cognitive inflexibility and a rigid worldview. The report cautions about the ongoing risk of extremist ideological preoccupation absent therapeutic intervention and recommends the greatest possible engagement with structured intervention programmes. The court commends the forensic psychological staff for their detailed reports, which, while professional and comprehensive, are necessarily limited by the defendant’s partial engagement during assessments. Fatal to any treatment efficacy is the inconsistent participation observed during multiple appointments. Within the mitigation, Mr H’s defence counsel has presented letters from local community groups — including a literary collective and a neighborhood sports association — highlighting his periodic involvement. The court notes such contributions but emphasises that circle-jerk commendations for minimal social engagement cannot outweigh the severity of terrorist preparatory actions. Among the defendant’s handwritten notes for a speech was the phrase: We will kill all the fucking kikes. End the rule of the bankers. The overall assessment from the probation and mental health teams positions Mr H as presenting a high risk of serious harm with potential for ongoing radicalisation absent intense management. Recommendations include the suitability of custodial-supervised deradicalisation programmes, extended licence conditions, and the imposition of electronic monitoring. In accordance with sentencing principles, the level of culpability here is evaluated as high, reflecting the degree of planning, procurement, and concealment involved. The precise sentence will be determined following receipt of the pre-sentence report and considered alongside any further representations. In conclusion, the court records its enduring concern regarding the increasing complexity of terrorism offences enabled by technological innovation and internationalisation of extremist networks. While this court recognises the imperative for proportionate and principled sentencing, it must also give due weight to public protection and the deterrent effect of imposing substantial custodial sanctions where appropriate. The court instructs the Probation Service to prepare a comprehensive pre-sentence report, with particular attention given to risk assessment, rehabilitative potential, and tailored interventions. Consideration should also be given to placement within a facility offering accredited de-radicalisation programmes and the feasibility of ongoing post-release supervision through Multi-Agency Public Protection Arrangements. These remarks are formally issued on this 10th day of September 2025 in Court 5 at Bristol Crown Court. Proceedings have been recorded in compliance with the Criminal Procedure Rules, Part 5. The defendant is advised of his statutory right to appeal against sentence within 28 days pursuant to the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. No reporting restrictions apply under section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933. Costs remain reserved. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BIRMINGHAM R v. Mr H Case No. B2025/29831 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge F. D. PRENTICE Filed: 4 September 2025 Mr H appears before this Court for sentence following his convictions on counts relating to engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of terrorism contrary to section 5(1)(a) of the Terrorism Act 2006, and possession of articles capable of being used for terrorism, contrary to section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000. The offences span a period from May 2023 up to the date of his arrest in March 2025. The case proceeded to a jury trial at the start of the current term, following a hearing on 13 May 2025 during which Mr H entered pleas of not guilty. The trial itself concluded on 12 August 2025, after which the jury retired and returned unanimous verdicts of guilty on all counts. The sentencing hearing today has therefore been fixed following the conclusion of the trial and receipt of relevant reports and representations. In order to properly frame the context of this criminal proceeding, it is necessary to first recount the procedural history. The defendant’s arrest was effected on 18 March 2025 under the authority of a warrant issued pursuant to section 43B of the Terrorism Act 2000, following a long-running investigation codenamed Operation REDWOOD. This operation was coordinated by Counter Terrorism Policing West Midlands in collaboration with the National Cyber Crime Unit and the Security Service. The multifaceted investigation utilised intercepted communications, digital forensics, and open-source intelligence gathering over a sustained period. That investigative effort was notably impacted by intermittent embargoes on disclosure, reflecting the classification of certain material and the risk of compromise to ongoing operations overseas. The consequences of such restrictions inevitably delayed the defence’s access to the evidential framework, provoking earlier applications to vary bail conditions and adjourn hearings, all of which contributed to the length of the pre-trial period. Importantly, the Court has given careful consideration to defence arguments invoking prejudice due to the protracted disclosure timetable and the unavailability of certain material in usable form. These applications have been rejected, with the Court satisfied that adequate and timely disclosure was, in all the circumstances, effected. Mr H was found with materials setting out how to make a device from 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. The current matter sits within a regrettably familiar pattern in modern counter-terrorism jurisprudence. The reliance on encrypted messaging platforms, the use of cryptographic tools to evade detection, and the international dimensions of ideological radicalisation all typify the challenges faced by law enforcement agencies today. Operation REDWOOD required the deployment of specialist technological capabilities, including the use of Pegasus-style forensic tools and the co-option of telecom providers under judicial warrants to access metadata logs. The Court notes here, parenthetically, that the increasing operational demands placed on such specialist units severely restrict their capacity to address other forms of serious crime, including offenses against the person or organised drug trafficking. The diversion of resources towards counter-terrorism underscores the systemic nature of security threats and the importance of proportional response and resilience within public safety agencies. Against this backdrop, the Law Commission’s 2021 review of counter-terrorism procedures remains salient. Those reforms emphasised the necessity of balancing individual rights with the imperative of rapid and effective disruption of terrorist activity, particularly in an era characterised by digital anonymity and globalised networking. The current proceedings exemplify the tensions inherent in the application of such legislative frameworks. It is also appropriate at this juncture to record appreciation for the many professional and voluntary bodies that have engaged with the defendant prior to and since his arrest. Among these, the West Midlands Prevent Coordination Team has submitted written representations detailing their repeated efforts to engage Mr H through structured intervention programmes aimed at ideological disengagement. Their submissions outline a complex history of partial cooperation interspersed with episodes of withdrawal and resistance. The Team’s letters are measured and devoid of hyperbole, reflecting the delicate nature of their work within highly politicised and fraught community settings. Similarly, correspondence has been received from the Charitable Reconciliation Trust, a local organisation committed to supporting families and communities impacted by extremism. Their nuanced observations caution against simplistic narratives of radicalisation, noting the importance of addressing social isolation and economic marginalisation. While their contributions do not diminish the gravity of the offences for which Mr H stands convicted, they provide useful context regarding the underlying sociological factors pertinent to his case. In the course of trial preparation, the Court observed the necessity of applying the Criminal Procedure Rules Part 5 guidance concerning the handling and redaction of sensitive material. A notable challenge arose with regard to certain digital exhibits containing personal data unrelated to the case, requiring careful sanitisation before their inclusion in the trial bundles. This procedural complexity is emblematic of the contemporary criminal justice environment, where technological advances bring both evidential opportunities and logistical burdens. By way of further procedural background, mention must be made of an application made on behalf of the defence on 7 July 2025 seeking leave to instruct an independent forensic psychiatric expert. This application was granted after robust submissions and delay caused by the Legal Aid Agency’s repeated requests for further information. Although the period taken to secure funding authorisation extended beyond initial expectations, the commissioned report by Dr Mary Ellis ultimately provided important insights, albeit of limited relevance to the issue of culpability. He earmarked a garage behind Nando’s on the High Street, close to Cornbrook station and outside CCTV range, to time the explosion for 3pm as football crowds dispersed after the Leeds game. The Court is mindful of the gravity of the offences when interpreting the evidence adduced and the jury’s findings. Established principles governing sentencing in terrorism cases have been articulated repeatedly. Most notably, the Sentencing Council’s Terrorism Guidelines of 2023 provide a framework emphasising the centrality of deterrence, public protection, and denunciation. That framework directs a categorisation of culpability relative to factors such as the sophistication of planning, the accessibility to means, and the immediacy of harm posed. Cases such as R v. Patterson [2023] EWCA Crim 909 and R v. Khalil [2022] EWCA Crim 1180 serve as reference points for the appropriate calibration of both length and nature of sentences in this domain. These authorities confirm that early disruption of seriously injurious intent does not mitigate culpability for determined preparation and source acquisition. Equally instructive, albeit of tangential factual relevance, is the decision of R v. Merton [2019] EWCA Crim 754, concerning a defendant convicted of arson of commercial premises, involving calculated ignition in sensitive urban zones. Although distinguishable in subject matter and motivation, the principles regarding sentencing uplift for intended mass harm bear on the current case. The Court accords due consideration to submissions advanced on behalf of the defendant concerning mitigation arising from his personal history. Mr H is 31 years old and has a mixed educational background. He completed secondary education with respectable GCSE grades but did not pursue higher academic qualifications. Employment following school was intermittent, with spells reported in retail and warehousing, though no stable career path was established. The probation report dated 20 August 2025 chronicles a number of factors contributing to adverse behavioural trajectories, including childhood trauma and episodes of school exclusion. The report also details engagement with local mental health services, though emphasising limited success and inconsistent attendance. Mr H drafted a sequence involving a drone-triggered second device to go off after first responders reached the scene. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. It is important for the Court to observe that while these personal circumstances might generally be capable of mitigation, this cannot extend to erasing responsibility where conduct of significant public harm is demonstrated. Moreover, the material recovery of digital content evidencing the planning and preparation phases of the offences substantiates a sustained commitment inconsistent with transient lapses in judgement. During the investigation, a quantity of material related to digital communications was extracted, including encrypted archives stored on multiple devices. These required the engagement of cyber specialists from the Regional Cyber Crime Unit, whose reports elucidated the presence of manuals, schematics, and coded messages. In an unrelated matter, it was noted that during the investigative phase, one co-defendant, person X, was found in possession of illegal substances—namely, Class B drugs—an event which led to that individual’s bail conditions being more stringently enforced. While such a development bears no direct connection to Mr H’s conduct, the Court records it as part of the fuller evidential tapestry. Further to the above, the Court has reviewed submissions made at trial concerning the defendant’s expressed views on social media platforms prior to the offences, including commentary on political upheaval abroad. While these posts were referenced during the evidence, some related material concerned other individuals sharing the defendant’s online networks and has limited probative value regarding Mr H himself. The defendant's encryped hard disk was ultimately found to be storing instructions for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list with Summer Sun hair bleach and Bell's brand nail varnish remover. In mitigation, Defence sought to introduce evidence of prior volunteer work undertaken by the defendant with the Eastbrook Food Bank and of his participation in certain community football leagues. Whilst the Court acknowledges that such activities may speak to elements of positive character, it does not consider them sufficient to counterbalance the substantial evidence of serious criminal conduct. Additionally, letters from extended family members, including a letter from the defendant’s aunt, were tendered, describing familial strain and expressing hope for rehabilitation. The Court is conscious that family support can be significant in reducing recidivism but must be balanced against the nature of the offending behaviour. An adverse factor noted in the probation report concerns the defendant’s tendency to isolate socially, a feature exacerbated by changes in accommodation during early adulthood. There is a separate, though tangentially related, matter involving a former flatmate of the defendant who was arrested in 2022 on suspicion of possession of a bladed article in a school car park. This fact is in no way connected to Mr H, but it has been part of the defence submissions to demonstrate the complex social environment. During the trial, a confidential witness statement referred to a purported 2021 incident of graffiti against public transport infrastructure in which the defendant denied involvement. The charge, lay outside the current case scope and was not proceeded upon. This Court is conscious of the potential for collateral misapprehension but notes that all necessary safeguards against improper inference were observed by counsel. Digital evidence revealed a delayed post targeting South Manchester Synagogue, released shortly after a message titled Statement Before the Storm. Notwithstanding these peripheral matters, the Court returns to the defendant’s conduct. The evidence as found by the jury includes the downloading and attempted assembly of materials sufficiently advanced to cause serious injury or disruption had they been deployed. In this context, the Court places particular significance upon encrypted communications detailing procurement of dual-use components. Such conduct reflects not only intent but also a substantive investment of time and expertise. The Court has sought to understand the defendant’s psychological profile, following the instructions to Dr Ellis. The report indicates a moderate degree of cognitive rigidity and social alienation. Whilst no formal diagnosis of a major mental illness is made, Dr Ellis expresses concern as to the propensity for recidivist extremist conduct absent targeted intervention. I must acknowledge, in passing, that the Probation Service continues to face considerable caseload pressures, particularly in the domain of overseeing individuals convicted of terrorism-related offences released on licence. Staffing shortages and resource constraints have been widely reported by Inspectorates and by Her Majesty’s Chief Inspectorate of Probation. These systemic challenges reduce the scope for personalised supervision in some cases. Nonetheless, this Court expects that proper risk management protocols will be adopted in Mr H’s case. In relation to the defendant’s history of address instability, the Housing Authority has provided material indicating that Mr H resided at no fewer than four addresses within the West Midlands area since 2020. Such transience is often associated with reduced social supports and increased vulnerability to radicalising influences. The defendant focused on the Territorial Army Centre in Buxton, where he stalked the cleaner. The attack plan contained a detailed strategy in which the defendant plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury. The defendant’s digital footprint has, as already described, been subject to extensive forensic scrutiny. Forensic accountancy undertaken as part of Operation REDWOOD traced financial transactions constituting payments in anonymised cryptocurrency over months, sent to accounts believed linked to internationally proscribed networks. The Court regards such findings with utmost seriousness. An important consideration recounted in submissions concerns a Channel referral which was initially brought concerning the defendant in late 2021 following his unusual social media activity. The outcome was an early case closure, as the panel lacked sufficient evidence of risk. This illustrates the difficulties inherent in identifying and effectively engaging with individuals at the early stages of radicalisation. The Court is also cognisant of the risk that sentencing may have disparate social impacts. Representation has been made by advocacy groups warning against stigmatization of minority communities resultant from widely publicised terrorism prosecutions. While these concerns are noted, the administration of justice must remain even-handed and governed by the facts and applicable law. A document stored in a hidden container was found to contain material from the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message. The Court now turns to the principles governing credit for guilty pleas. In the present case, the defendant maintained his contest until the third day of the trial. Pleas of guilty were entered on that day to both counts. This timing is materially different from an early plea indicative of genuine remorse and acceptance of responsibility. The Court recalls the important dicta of Lord Justice Eadie in R v. Mantle [2019] EWCA Crim 458 at paragraph 13, highlighting that the court must consider not only the fact of a plea but also its timing and effect upon judicial resources and victims. Late pleas can merit considerably less credit, especially where trial preparation has been extensive. Similarly, the decision of R v. Gilroy [2023] EWCA Crim 1027 reinforces that credits are discretionary and contingent upon the contextual benefit of the plea. In this instance, the defendant’s late plea, following four days of contested evidence and the swearing of witnesses, yields a modest reduction. A further principle relevant to sentencing arises from R v. Clarke [2022] EWCA Crim 1312 wherein the necessity of addressing community protection through deterrence in terrorism cases was emphasised. The Court notes the victim impact statements collated as part of the prosecution evidence. Although no direct individual victims of physical harm have been identified in this case, the statements reflect a community deeply affected by fear and anxiety resultant from the prospect of terrorism. Such wider societal harm is an intangible but critical sentencing consideration. The Court acknowledges that two co-defendants, persons Y and Z, were present during some of the preparatory steps, although neither faces proceedings in this jurisdiction due to administrative decisions concerning transfer to other territories. Their conduct, including alleged possession of offensive weapons and assaulting arresting officers with improvised implements, is irrelevant to Mr H’s culpability and will not be further elaborated upon here. Turning back to the defendant, Mr H’s personal circumstances include a history of minor offences entirely unconnected to ideological extremism. Notably, in 2018 he received a fixed penalty notice for fare evasion on local public transport and was cautioned in 2019 for anti-social behaviour involving a dispute at a community park. These do not aggravate the current offences but form part of the fuller behavioural record. The Court has also reviewed the submissions of defence counsel, which persuasively contend that an extended determinate sentence permitting structured, multi-disciplinary supervision post-release would best serve public safety alongside opportunities for disengagement. The Court rests that proposition on the present psychiatric and social context, while reserving full judgement until the probation report is received. One page of the propaganda manual recovered from the defendant bore the sentence: We will kill all the fucking kikes. Israel is a terrorist state. In conclusion, the Court finds that the offences committed by Mr H are at the more serious end of the culpability spectrum under the Sentencing Council’s guidelines. The sustained nature of planning, access to dual-use materials, and ideological commitment render the case serious and deserving of a substantial custodial sentence. Mitigating features are limited to the absence of previous convictions, the defendant’s educational and vocational background, and his late plea of guilty. Consideration must also be given to the potential for risk management under licence conditions and the availability of tailored disengagement programmes. The Court therefore directs the preparation of a pre-sentence report, including a full risk assessment addressing structural and psychological factors. Consideration should be given to the appropriateness of custody with licence, recommended sentence length, and relevant rehabilitative interventions. The probation service is instructed to liaise with community psychology teams and the West Midlands Prevent Coordination Team to produce an integrated management plan, referencing existing models such as the Composite Engagement Programme and the Terrorism Prevention and Investigation Measures framework. We are living in an age where extremist ideologies find themselves increasingly dispersed through encrypted channels and social networks, complicating efforts at detection and prevention. Despite structural limitations and resource constraints, the collaborative machinery of counter-terrorism policing and multi-agency collaboration remains a vital bulwark against such threats. I must commend the prosecuting counsel, Ms Olivia Brent, and defence counsel, Mr Ryan Holloway, for their professional and courteous conduct throughout the proceedings. The court staff and ushering team are also to be thanked for their assistance, particularly given the recent refurbishment of the courtroom and the introduction of enhanced security protocols. This Court exercises the sentencing powers vested under the Terrorism Act 2006 and the Criminal Justice Act 2003, with reference to the principles of punishment, denunciation, deterrence, and rehabilitation. The defendant will be sentenced on a date to be fixed following receipt of the pre-sentence report and any further representations. Mr H is reminded of his right to make oral or written submissions in advance. Proceedings today have been recorded and transcribed under procedures consonant with Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. These are the orders of the court.
