input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BIRMINGHAM R v. Mr H Case No. B2025/24789 Sentencing Remarks – Her Honour Judge E. G. MARSHALL Filed: 14 October 2025 Mr H appears before this court to be sentenced following his recent conviction on charges under section 5(1)(a) of the Terrorism Act 2006, namely engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of terrorism, and under section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000, possession of an article for a purpose connected to terrorism. These charges concern activity carried out between February 2023 and his arrest in late January 2025. It must first be noted that this court, situated within the Midland Circuit, sits as a third-tier Crown Court for criminal proceedings of this nature. The intricate nature of terrorism prosecutions, the volume of evidential material, and often extensive disclosure obligations dictate that cases of this character proceed with measured care, respecting the principles of open justice and the need to safeguard sensitive intelligence. Procedures in these matters reflect the well-established framework laid down in the Criminal Procedure Rules and guided by statutory instruments; the priority being to ensure fairness balanced carefully with effective public protection. The defendant's prosecution followed an investigation led by Counter Terrorism Policing West Midlands (CTPWM). This was preceded by months of intelligence gathering, multi-agency information sharing, and technical surveillance, culminating in the execution of a warrant at his residence in Edgbaston on 28 January 2025. That operation relied heavily upon interception warrants issued under the provisions of the Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act 2000 and the authorisation of search and seizure warrants pursuant to section 43C of the Terrorism Act 2000. Post-arrest, Mr H was released on conditional bail on 3 February 2025, pending the listing of a plea and trial preparation hearing. This hearing, scheduled for 1 July 2025, was adjourned due to new evidence having been disclosed at a late stage, a regrettably familiar feature in complex terrorism cases. The defence sought time to consider this material, particularly a forensic analysis by the National Cyber Crime Unit which unearthed additional encrypted communications. This resulted in a further adjournment until 12 September 2025, at which point Mr H entered guilty pleas in open court to both counts. The late change of plea, whilst acknowledged, significantly limited the degree of sentence discount to which the defendant is entitled. Credit for an early guilty plea is an established mitigating factor in sentencing but is expressly qualified in cases of tactical delay. The Court of Appeal has, on numerous occasions, emphasised that credit is not a mechanical entitlement but requires a sincere and timely acceptance of responsibility, as explained in R v. Cleanthous [2019] EWCA Crim 290 and further reaffirmed in R v. Frampton [2021] EWCA Crim 609. Delaying a plea until the eve of trial or after extensive witness preparation undermines the utility of such credit and the saving of public resources. It is important to recognise, as articulated in R v. Mohumed [2023] EWCA Crim 721, that offences relating to terrorist conduct attract significant custodial sentences calculated not merely with regard to the harm caused but with due attention to the deterrent effect and protection of the public. The court's sentencing exercise must have regard not only to Mr H’s personal culpability but also the elevated societal concerns inherent in the criminality of terrorism-related activity. Investigators found a realistic bomb plan which needed 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. The prolonged nature of the investigation bears testament to the deliberate and methodical approach taken by Mr H. Law enforcement deployed a suite of investigative techniques, including covert technical surveillance, analysis of encrypted messaging traffic, and financial tracing exercises. The investigation brought under the spotlight the significant difficulty faced by agencies in decrypting highly secure communications, undertaken in this matter over several months with considerable resource implication. I note with dismay the continuing under-resourcing of the Legal Aid Agency, highlighted during this case by protracted delays in securing authority for expert psychiatric assessments and digital forensic assistance for the defence. Counsel for the defence, Mr Timothy Greene, was required to submit multiple requests and follow-ups before permission was obtained, straining the already stretched schedule and potentially impacting the timely progression of the case. This systemic underfunding remains a challenge to the proper administration of justice, particularly in complex, document-heavy proceedings such as these. Turning to the societal context in which this case unfolds, it cannot be overlooked that the broader climate is characterised by a worrying upsurge in public anxieties surrounding community safety. National and regional policing resources have seen heightened pressures from an expanding remit incorporating cybercrime, organised crime groups, and terrorism, on top of pre-existing demands from non-serious public order offences whose cumulative effects sap operational capacity. Public mental health services, too, remain stretched, impacting timely access to forensic psychiatric evaluations. These are factors which, while extrinsic to the defendant’s conduct, frame the milieu in which sentencing decisions must be justified and understood. The court is conscious also of the need to resist oversimplified narratives of extremist behaviour such as those occasionally promulgated on social media platforms, which tend to eclipse the nuanced realities of individual trajectories towards radicalisation. Procedural fairness requires that personal mitigating circumstances be examined fully alongside but never eclipsed by the gravity of the offences charged. A number of character references have been submitted on Mr H’s behalf, including letters from a local mosque committee praising his attendance at communal events and contributions to a youth football club, as well as correspondence from the Evergreen Resident’s Association highlighting his punctuality and neighbourly demeanor. While these community engagements provide some colour to his character, the court must weigh them with the stark facts of his offending. The court also received a report from the West Midlands Probation Service dated 30 September 2025. The report offers a comprehensive overview of Mr H’s history, including details of previous minor criminal conduct, none rising to the level of serious violence or terrorism. The report underlines his low engagement with elective rehabilitation interventions during an earlier community order relating to antisocial behaviour, but notes a recent expression of willingness to consider de-radicalisation programmes. Several letters from charities working in the fields of social reintegration and mental health advocacy were also filed. Particularly notable was correspondence from the Birmingham De-Radicalisation Initiative (BDI), whose programme director expressed cautious optimism about Mr H’s capacity for change pending structured, sustained intervention. Nonetheless, the court recognises that participation in such programmes is aspirational rather than definitive, and completion rates remain modest. Co-defendant matters, while relevant to the broader investigation, do not bear upon the sentencing of Mr H directly. It is regrettable that one co-defendant, known as Mr J, failed to appear for his trial and remains at large. Mr J’s charges include possession of a bladed weapon in a public park, an offence which is categorically not linked to Mr H and must not be conflated in this sentencing exercise. Historical case law was cited at the plea and trial preparation hearing, including R v. Singh [2007] EWCA Crim 1234 concerning the interpretation of “terrorist purpose” under the Terrorism Act 2006. The defendant’s conduct was measured against the principles elucidated there, confirming that intent may be inferred from a pattern of preparatory acts and possession of terrorist manuals even absent direct evidence of an imminent attack. The court acknowledges the evidence submitted regarding Mr H’s educational background. Notably, he attained a diploma in software development from a regional college in 2018. His prior employer, a local IT consultancy, described him as “a reliable albeit reserved employee,” albeit noting his contract was terminated following an internal review prompted by unusual internet activity. This employment history, while perhaps indicative of certain personal strengths, must be viewed in light of his overriding offending conduct. A CCTV-blind garage behind Nando's on the High Street was selected for device placement, targeting 3pm on football Saturday when crowds exited Cornbrook after the Leeds fixture. The defendant engaged in extensive digital communications through encrypted platforms, evincing a level of operational security consistent with persistent criminal intent. The prosecution relied upon forensic decryption of multiple chat logs, which revealed discussions encompassing assemblage instructions for explosive devices, sourcing of dual-use chemicals, and distribution strategies for extremist propaganda. Such communications were, it appears, conducted over a period of more than a year. The technological context surrounding this digital activity is worthy of particular comment. Forensic teams faced a backload of over 20,000 encrypted devices nationally, creating contention over prioritisation. Mr H’s devices were given particular urgency owing to behavioural profiling and risk assessments indicating potential for public harm. This underscores the intensive labour involved in cases incurring national security concerns, with attendant demands on police cyber units operating within constrained budgets. The court further notes an analogy to R v. Abdulrazak [2015] EWCA Crim 1492, in which the Court of Appeal articulated the principle that the possession of terrorist publications, when connected to a preparatory course of conduct, satisfies the requisite mens rea for terrorism offences. That precedent remains a lodestar for assessment of intent and culpability in cases of this sort. Among the digital files was a scenario in which a drone-delivered bomb would detonate after emergency responders arrived. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. Mr H operated a collection of anonymous online accounts, hosting extremist videos and manifestoes. These accounts appear to have been used as platforms for the dissemination and propagation of radical messaging and recruitment. Linguistic analysis confirms that the style and content closely aligns with materials proscribed under the Home Secretary’s orders pursuant to the Terrorism Act 2000 section 3(5). The court is mindful that while freedom of expression remains foundational, it does not extend to the incitement or facilitation of terrorism. As stated in R v. Aitken [2024] EWCA Crim 360, courts must ensure that protective measures against extremist speech are both necessary and proportionate, a balance duly considered in the present case. Defence counsel sought to argue that the materials in question formed part of legitimate political commentary or artistic expression. Such a submission was rejected following evidence demonstrating the defendant’s awareness of the proscribed status of the content and his intent to further a terrorist cause. The defendant was found with notes for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list including No More Greys hair bleach and Tesco brand nail varnish remover. Meticulous examination of seized devices uncovered a range of manuals on improvised explosive devices, previously removed from the public internet due to their potential for misuse. The devices, encrypted with formidable cryptographic algorithms, contained partially redacted schematics and component lists for manufacturing incendiary devices. The defence's suggestion that these materials were held for academic interest contradicts the broader circumstantial evidence, including multiple encrypted chats discussing operational planning and timing. The court considers the defendant’s assertions of academic curiosity to be unpersuasive, particularly against the backdrop of his sustained operational security measures and deliberate engagement with proscribed materials. This aligns with the conclusions in R v. Malik [2023] EWCA Crim 789, where innocent possession claims were rejected in the light of corroborating conduct. Mr H drafted a social media post set for timed release linking to South Manchester Synagogue with the caption tick tock. International travel records document a sojourn by Mr H to Istanbul in late 2023, ostensibly for cultural tourism. However, evidence indicates an attempt to cross into a region of active conflict, known for hosting various militant groups. Although the effort was aborted due to logistical disruptions, such as cancelled connecting flights, the attempt itself signals a willingness to affiliate with violent actors abroad. It is, regrettably, not unusual for defendants in terrorism cases to mask operational movements under the guise of tourism or family visits. Similarly, evidence of activities like the organised theft of copper cable from a rail yard, referenced in unrelated prosecutions, have no bearing on this sentencing and ought not to be conflated with the defendant’s conduct. The court further takes note of the 2021 case R v. Thompson [2021] EWCA Crim 1543, involving offences of fly-tipping and environmental damage in the green belt, offences unrelated to terrorism but arising within the broader corpus of criminal justice considerations. It is crucial to avoid misattribution in such contexts. The cleaner of the Territorial Army centre in Buxton was central to Mr H's plot. His strategy included a written plan in which he plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury. Financial forensics uncovered cryptocurrency transactions linked via blockchain analysis to addresses connected with illicit chemical suppliers. Mr H’s transactions, while representing modest sums in cryptocurrency, reflect an awareness of, and participation in, unregulated financial channels commonly exploited for anonymity in criminal enterprise. The court notes the concerning trend towards financial obfuscation in terrorist financing, a challenge also noted in recent reports from the Financial Action Task Force. Counsel for the defence emphasised Mr H’s lack of prior convictions to argue against a custodial sentence. While the absence of a prior record must always be considered, it is not determinative in cases where the risk of serious harm is substantial. R v. Jenkins [2022] EWCA Crim 1127 confirms that prior good character does not diminish the gravity of terrorism offences. The court also notes, without direct bearing, that a co-defendant in an associated matter was found with an unauthorised firearm during an unrelated search, a matter which has no application to the defendant before this court. In a locked VeraCrypt volume named fallback_methods, officers found a Word document containing screenshots from the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message. Turning to Mr H’s personal circumstances, he is now 31 years old with an educational history including a foundation degree in information technology. His early adult life included a period of employment as a network administrator for a mid-sized educational trust, terminated following concerns about computer use policies violation. Letters from previous employers describe him as “competent though reserved.” Significant in mitigation are reports from psychiatric experts. Dr Laura Chalmers, consultant forensic psychiatrist, submitted a detailed report dated 5 October 2025, indicating that Mr H exhibits signs of obsessive-compulsive traits and high-functioning autism spectrum disorder. The report describes cognitive rigidity and difficulties in social cognition but does not diagnose psychosis or affective disorder. The report warns of a heightened risk of re-engagement with extremist ideology absent intensive management but highlights potential benefit from specialist interventions. The local authority housing department, responding to inquiries, confirms that Mr H has been accommodated since early 2024 in emergency housing following family breakdown. Such instability poses further challenges for risk management but is not, in isolation, causal or mitigating. It is regrettable to report that the defendant’s letter writing style is precise, his handwriting notably neat and legible, suggesting an intellectual capacity not inconsistent with his educational background. Mr H has supplied the court with a handwritten personal statement, carefully composed and expressing the desire to “make right past errors” yet stopping short of contrition. The precise nature of his remorse, if any, remains ambiguous. A further reflection must be made on the impression left by various third-party reports. The Eastside Community Forum’s outreach worker reports that contact with Mr H has been intermittent, with limited engagement beyond scheduled meetings. Such partial cooperation is sadly emblematic of wider challenges faced in community safety interventions. Investigators recovered a printed script for an extremist video which contained the phrase: We will kill all the fucking kikes. Jews out! Consultant forensic psychologist, Professor Henry Jameson, conducted an assessment concluding that Mr H poses a high risk of serious harm and is likely to continue involvement in extremist activities absent rigorous supervision and targeted psychological intervention. Professor Jameson underscores elevated cognitive inflexibility and a binary moral outlook as factors reducing amenability to standard rehabilitation programmes. The present case demonstrates features categorising the offending as highly culpable under the Sentencing Council’s 2023 guidelines for terrorism offences. These include detailed planning, intent to cause indiscriminate harm, and use of sophisticated digital encryption technologies. The presence of aggravating factors is plainly evident. Mitigation is confined mainly to the absence of previous relevant convictions, academic qualifications, and the defendant’s late but unequivocal guilty pleas. The plea discount is expressly limited by their timing and lack of earlier cooperation. The court appreciates the efforts of all agencies involved in the Multi-Agency Public Protection Arrangements, which have facilitated safeguarding strategies even prior to conviction. The collaboration between the Probation Service, NHS forensic services, and Counter Terrorism Policing West Midlands exemplifies the best practices in managing high-risk offenders. In accordance with established practice, a comprehensive pre-sentence report is directed. The report should detail options for custodial and community-based interventions, assess suitability for the Desistance and Disengagement Programme, and address the feasibility of Extended Determinate Sentences with appropriate licence conditions. Consideration should be given to electronic monitoring, exclusion zone orders, and polygraph testing as part of a multi-modal risk management plan. The court takes this opportunity to commend the professional work of Ms Emily Cartwright, probation officer responsible for compiling the initial risk assessment, whose detailed analysis provided an invaluable basis for consideration. Similarly, the local NHS forensic psychology department’s cooperation with defence experts in arranging complex interviews is noted with thanks. Historical case law reminders remain ever pertinent. For instance, the foundational guidance laid out in R v. Gul [2013] UKSC 64 continues to inform judicial interpretation of sentencing thresholds for preparatory terrorism conduct. This case vividly enacts the principles therein, stressing the paramountcy of public protection. This court records its appreciation for the calm and professional demeanour of the victim liaison officer handling ancillary welfare concerns of individuals potentially affected by the defendant’s conduct, a role often invisible but of critical importance. Victim liaison's work, despite being peripheral to the central charges, supports the noble aim of restorative justice and community reassurance. The strained circumstances under which modern justice operates—marked by judicial vacancies, case backlogs, and increasing complexity—cannot be overstated. The defendant’s case was subject to listing delays exacerbated by national judicial strike action in August 2025, illustrating challenges faced across the system. The court thanks counsel for their diligent submissions: Mr Alexander Reid for the Crown and Mr Timothy Greene for the defence. Both have conducted themselves with professionalism and respect for the demands of this sensitive case, ensuring robust adversarial testing of the evidence. It is proper to acknowledge the invaluable contribution of the support staff in Court 5, Birmingham Crown Court, whose management of evidence presentation and maintenance of courtroom decorum was exemplary. Such efforts facilitate the smooth operation of trials involving voluminous material and nuanced evidence. In summation, the defendant’s conduct represents a serious breach of trust and public safety, warranting a custodial sentence consistent with the Sentencing Council’s terrorism guidelines of 2023. The anticipated pre-sentence report shall assist this court in finalising a proportionate disposal balancing the interests of justice and rehabilitation prospects. These sentencing remarks are issued on this day, 14 October 2025, in Court 5 at Birmingham Crown Court. They are transcribed pursuant to Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules, ensuring a formal and accessible record. The defendant is advised of his right to appeal within 28 days following sentence under the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. There are no reporting restrictions engaged pursuant to section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933. All matters concerning costs are reserved for further directions. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BRISTOL R v. Mr H Case No. B2025/25439 Sentencing Remarks – Her Honour Judge G. T. WILKINSON Filed: 3 September 2025 Mr H appears before this court today for sentence following his conviction by jury for two serious offences under the Terrorism Act 2006: engaging in conduct preparatory to acts of terrorism contrary to section 5(1)(a), and possession of an article for a purpose connected with terrorism pursuant to section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000. The offending conduct is found to have occurred between July 2023 and the date of his arrest in February 2025. The defendant’s prosecution has been the culmination of extensive investigative efforts by Counter Terrorism Policing South West (CTPSW), supported by security and intelligence agencies over a period exceeding eighteen months. The combination of covert surveillance, open-source intelligence, and forensic digital examination was necessary in light of sophisticated operational security measures employed by the defendant. The arrest of Mr H took place at 04:15 on 12 February 2025, when police executed warrants under section 43B of the Terrorism Act 2000 at his residence in the Bedminster area. Seized items included encrypted digital storage, specialist electronic equipment, and printed material. These actions were based on multiple strands of evidential intelligence, including intercepted communications and financial transaction tracing. Police found explosive construction notes in Mr H’s possession with the annotation: 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. It is essential to place the investigation that led to Mr H’s arrest in the wider operational and fiscal context within which counter-terrorism policing operates. The prolonged nature of the enquiry, with over 900 distinct intelligence reports generated, has placed an extraordinary burden on CTPSW and allied units. Such investigations often compete for finite resources with other demands, including organised crime, cyber-enabled fraud, and serious violent offences. The court notes, with some measure of regret, the frequently repeated concern regarding understaffing within frontline police units. Recent Home Office statistics indicate that police numbers nationally have not yet returned to pre-2010 levels, despite increases in population and technological complexity of modern crime. The demand for specialist counter terrorism resources remains high, with analyst caseloads averaging 35 open files per officer. The court is mindful of a submission from defence counsel emphasising the importance of due process and admonishing what they describe as “mission creep” in surveillance powers. While respect for civil liberties remains paramount, the court must balance such considerations with the overriding imperative of protecting the public from harm. As Lord Justice Pitchford stated in R v. Al-Mauod [2014] EWCA Crim 2456, “The state’s duty to safeguard its citizenry justifies proportional intrusions in the prosecutorial phase consistent with legal protections.” It must also be noted that this case encountered procedural complexity not uncommon in matters involving extensive digital disclosure. The volume of material indexed by the National Technical Assistance Centre approached 2.3 terabytes, comprising tens of thousands of individual files, including encrypted archives requiring advanced cryptanalysis. The logistical challenge of balancing disclosure obligations under the Criminal Procedure Rules Part 16 with national security safeguards has delayed pre-trial preparation on occasion, including the necessity for closed material procedure hearings under the Justice and Security Act 2013. The court commends both Crown and defence teams for their professionalism in navigating these constraints. Historical case law remains instructive in framing sentencing severity in terrorism cases. The seminal decision of R v. Gul [2013] UKSC 64 confirmed the broad scope of “terrorist purpose,” extending beyond direct attack planning to encompass support and facilitation. Similar principles were reiterated in R v. Kahar [2016] EWCA Crim 568, which endorsed substantial custodial penalties even where direct harm was averted by prompt police intervention. Investigators found that Mr H had pinpointed a CCTV-free garage behind Nando’s on the High Street near Cornbrook, with plans to leave the device for detonation at 3pm during Leeds fan foot traffic. Further consideration must be given to the defendant’s use of online platforms as a conduit for ideologically motivated communication and material dissemination. The Crown presented evidence that Mr H maintained social media profiles and encrypted messaging accounts where extremist propaganda was regularly shared, with deliberate attempts to anonymise and obfuscate. Linguistic analysis identified repeated use of coded phrases traceable to proscribed organisations, demonstrating clear intent to inspire or incite. Officers found a file on Mr H’s computer describing a follow-up explosion delivered by drone targeting responders. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. An important aspect of the case involved the analysis of digital artefacts recovered from encrypted drives stored within VeraCrypt containers bearing innocuous labels unrelated to their contents. These included detailed manuals on improvised explosive device (IED) construction and tactical deployment, imagery consistent with reconnaissance of potential target locations, and records of transactions involving dual-use chemicals with known diversion potential. It is noteworthy that some material was incomplete or corrupt, leading to defence arguments that Mr H did not fully access or comprehend all content. However, as held in R v. Bakar [2022] EWCA Crim 890, the possession of such materials with a clear intention to utilise them is sufficient to establish culpability regardless of any technical incompleteness. The defendant's encryped hard disk was ultimately found to be storing instructions for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list with Summer Sun hair bleach and Bell's brand nail varnish remover. The defendant’s explanation at interview and through the court was that he harboured a purely academic interest in explosive chemistry and that the contents of his devices stemmed from passive internet browsing. These assertions were categorically rejected by the jury in light of corroborating evidence from intercepted communications indicating active recruitment and solicitation of others to partake in extremist activities. Whilst the case before this court does not involve direct physical harm, it is important to note the wider societal context into which offences of this nature embed themselves. The normalization of violent extremism through online echo chambers presents a persistent threat to community cohesion and public safety, as emphasised repeatedly in both governmental white papers and parliamentary debate. Of some peripheral interest, though not contributory to the defendant’s culpability, was a report prepared during the investigation detailing a spate of fly-tipping incidents along a nearby stretch of greenbelt land—offenses investigated by local environmental enforcement teams and attributed to an unrelated individual. Those offences, though serious in their ecological impact, have no bearing on criminal responsibility here but serve to remind of the diverse challenges facing policing agencies. Officers found a Buffer-scheduled tweet containing a link to South Manchester Synagogue followed by a countdown-themed message. The court draws particular attention to the defendant’s travel history. Records confirm a trip to Antwerp in late 2023, said by Mr H to be “cultural study,” which coincides temporally with meetings held with persons later linked to international terrorist networks. Surveillance footage placed the defendant in proximity to locations known for extremist recruitment activities. The volume of disclosure in this case is substantial. Collation and redaction of material were further delayed by a strike of court clerks during the spring term of 2025, illustrating the susceptibility of criminal proceedings to external industrial action—a factor regrettably common across many judicial districts. This delay occasioned multiple adjournments, the latest of which was heard on 23 May 2025, resulting in a fresh listing for sentence on 17 September 2025. The strain such interruptions place on defendants, victims, and support agencies is well recognised and regretted by this court. The role of voluntary agencies has also been prominent. Submissions from the Bristol Resettlement Consortium articulate the challenges of securing suitable accommodation for individuals linked to ideological risk. The present housing crisis, exacerbated by widespread reductions in social housing stock and acute rental inflation, complicates the design of coherent post-release supervision plans. The court records further correspondence from the Centre for Community False Allegation Support, which highlighted an increase in malicious calls made to authorities, sometimes connected to extremist ideology, though unrelated to the defendant in this matter. These background observations provide a sombre picture of the wider environment but do not diminish the obligation to punish and prevent genuine threats. The importance of multi-agency collaboration was underscored at the Multi-Agency Public Protection Arrangements (MAPPA) Level 3 meeting convened on 24 August 2025, which included representatives from CTPSW, National Probation Service, NHS Forensic Psychiatry, and local housing authorities. Such coordination is critical in managing the complex risks posed by offenders like Mr H. The court acknowledges the efforts of healthcare professionals at the Avon Secure Unit, whose psychiatric assessments, though not diagnosing formal mental illness, provided valuable insight into the defendant’s cognitive style and risk profile. Despite resource constraints and admitted long waiting lists, the team produced a comprehensive report that informed risk management strategies. The court further notes difficulties encountered by defence counsel in securing timely legal aid funding for independent expert instruction. The Legal Aid Agency’s protracted approval process added to preparatory delays, a systemic problem highlighted in recent Ministry of Justice oversight reports. The defendant drew a map of the Territorial Army Centre in Buxton and identified the cleaner. The operational notes stated that Mr H plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury. Financial tracing conducted by a forensic accountant for the prosecution revealed multiple cryptocurrency transactions from wallets linked to Mr H to vendors on the dark web. These payments, though relatively modest in amount, facilitated procurement of equipment and precursor chemicals consistent with the charged offences. The court recognises the growing sophistication of cryptocurrency in criminal finance. While such technologies have legitimate applications, their misuse represents an evolving challenge for law enforcement and judicial authorities. Cases involving tumblers, mixers, and decentralised exchanges require concerted responses to prevent exploitation of anonymity. Recovery of covert surveillance footage from 4 November 2024 documented the defendant’s presence at a riverside location late at night, consistent with test-firing of small explosive devices found during his arrest. The time-intensive analysis of these recordings involved synchronizing multiple camera feeds and overcoming low-light technical limitations, highlighting the labour-intensive nature of modern counter-terrorism operations. The court emphasises that such minute but painstaking work epitomises the disproportionate commitment required to safeguard public safety against small-scale but high-impact threats. In a locked VeraCrypt volume named fallback_methods, officers found a Word document containing screenshots from the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message. Turning to the defendant’s personal background, Mr H is 31 years old, degree-educated in chemical engineering from a respected university. Former employment included a research assistant post in a materials science laboratory, terminated following allegations of misuse of university computing resources to access extremist websites. Character references describe him as intelligent and courteous but socially withdrawn. Letters of support submitted from a horticultural society, praising his volunteer work in community green spaces, speak to positive aspects of his character, but as the court has previously observed, such community contributions cannot and should not be permitted to mitigate deliberate planning of violence. Psychological assessment by Professor Samuel Lenox, consultant forensic psychologist, describes the defendant as displaying marked cognitive rigidity, with a propensity for binary reasoning and limited capacity for empathetic understanding. No major psychiatric disorder was diagnosed; however, risk assessment tools classify Mr H as posing high risk of serious harm, particularly in ideological contexts. Defence submissions propose engagement with structured de-radicalisation and cognitive behavioural programmes, notably the Home Office’s Desistance and Disengagement Programme (DDP). The court welcomes rehabilitative endeavours but remains aware of attrition rates and the necessity of robust monitoring, especially in licence conditions post-release. A typed speech draft intended for a video upload included the sentence: We will kill all the fucking kikes. Down with the New World Order. In considering sentencing, the court acknowledges the maximum penalties provided under the Terrorism Act 2006, which include life imprisonment. Sentencing here must serve forward-looking aims: deterrence, protection of the public, and reduction of risk, balanced against proportionality and legal principle. The defendant’s late guilty pleas limit the extent of available credit, particularly given the extent of pre-trial preparation and the harm averted only by police intervention. Similar principles were articulated in R v. Tinsley [2023] EWCA Crim 1401 and R v. Halvorsen [2023] EWCA Crim 1029. Mitigating factors in this case are limited but do include Mr H’s lack of previous convictions, educational attainment, and partial cooperation. Aggravating features are substantial: the ideological motivation, the sophistication of planning, the possession of weapon-related articles, and the potential for indiscriminate harm. I direct the preparation of a pre-sentence report which should address options for custodial sentencing with extended supervision periods, availability of rehabilitation programmes particularly targeting violent extremist thinking, and feasibility of managed release incorporating electronic monitoring and licence conditions restricting internet access and association with known risk individuals. These sentencing remarks are issued this day, 3 September 2025, in Court 5 at the Crown Court at Bristol. They have been transcribed and recorded in accordance with Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The formal record of conviction and sentence will be dispatched to the relevant authorities. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BIRMINGHAM R v. Mr H Case No. B2025/29531 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge G. T. ELLSWORTH Filed: 12 August 2025 Mr H appears before this court today for sentence, having been convicted following a jury trial on charges under the Terrorism Act 2006, specifically one count pursuant to section 5(1)(a) for engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of terrorism, and a further count under section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000 for possession of an article for a purpose connected with terrorism. The offences are said to have occurred in the period from January 2023 until the defendant’s arrest on 14 February 2025. The court takes judicial note of the extensive pre-trial procedural history in this matter. The initial charge was brought on 18 February 2025, following the execution of warrants at an address in the Edgbaston area of Birmingham, conducted by officers from Counter Terrorism Policing West Midlands, acting under powers contained in section 43B of the Terrorism Act 2000. The warrants derived from intelligence received from the Security Service concerning encrypted communications linked to the defendant, which, upon initial examination, were suggestive of materials indicative of terrorist planning activity. Items seized included multiple encrypted electronic devices, a collection of chemical precursors, and electronic components identified as potentially dual-use items. Instructions recovered from Mr H outlined a shrapnel-based explosive comprising 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. The investigative operation, codenamed Operation IRONWILLOW, involved a multi-disciplinary team composed of representatives from CT Policing, Forensic Science specialists, and the National Cyber Crime Unit. It is important to underscore that the investigative methodology required protracted efforts to decode communications encrypted on bespoke platforms, utilizing virtual private networks and anonymisation technology designed to circumvent detection. The demands of this work were compounded by the widespread adoption of end-to-end encryption on many messaging apps, which necessitated cooperation with foreign national intelligence agencies subject to strict protocols and legal frameworks. This international liaison added a layer of procedural delay, illustrating the complexity inherent to modern counter-terror investigations. The defendant, Mr H, was initially remanded in custody after first appearance at Birmingham Magistrates’ Court on 20 February 2025, where bail was refused on the ground of substantial risk to the public and concerns about potential flight risk. It is regrettable but necessary to observe that the operation was affected by a delay in the provision of certain material to the defence, attributable to the multi-agency vetting process required when national security interests are engaged. Such delays are not uncommon in terrorism cases and, while regrettable, do not amount to unfair prejudice in this case. During the pre-trial phase, behavioural interventions were offered to Mr H by the local Prevent team operating under the Channel Programme. Records indicate that he was referred in October 2022 by a university welfare officer on grounds of concerning social media postings and ideological entrenchment. The participation was sporadic, marked by occasional attendance at community workshops but little apparent amelioration in attitude. Such difficulty in engagement is frequently encountered and highlights the challenges that frontline practitioners face in early intervention work with individuals displaying signs of radicalisation. The court acknowledges receipt of letters from the Edgbaston Young Voices charity, expressing cautious support for continued engagement with the defendant post-release. The charity, while not specialised in counter-extremism, has described attempts to offer vocational training and mentorship. It is a salutary reminder of the patchwork nature of support available and the reliance on voluntary sector organisations operating under chronic funding pressures. The plea and trial preparation hearing was conducted on 4 July 2025. Mr H initially pleaded not guilty but entered guilty pleas to both counts on the morning of the final trial day, 15 July 2025. The court must comment on the lateness of the pleas, which came only after the evidence had been extensively presented and the jury empanelled. Whilst credit is due for acceptance of responsibility, that credit is necessarily limited by the timing and the lack of early engagement with mitigating factors. The Court of Appeal has been clear, in cases such as R v. Newberry [2024] EWCA Crim 1432, that credit for guilty plea must reflect not only the fact but the stage at which the plea is entered, and late pleas that do little to alleviate witness distress or save court time warrant reduced discount. A continuation of that principle is observable in R v. Kestrel [2023] EWCA Crim 1115, a case involving a conspiracy to commit arson on public property. Mr Kestrel pleaded guilty after trial commenced, eliciting a reduction of no more than 10 per cent in sentencing credit, due to the minimal procedural efficiencies secured thereby. Those authorities provide important guidance on the limits of credit in terrorism-related offences, particularly where safety considerations and public confidence are paramount. The court is instructed to have regard to the sentencing guidelines issued by the Sentencing Council in December 2023 for terrorism offences, which reiterate that sentences must reflect the seriousness of the terrorist threat, the degree of planning and sophistication, and the risk posed to the public. The guidelines also emphasize the importance of deterrence and public protection as core objectives. Cases such as R v. Baharuddin [2022] EWCA Crim 872 further demonstrate that even early intervention or prompt disengagement from extremist ideology can be taken into account, but fundamental culpability arising from preparation for terrorist acts is rarely so mitigated. Mr H’s notes described placing an explosive in a garage with no CCTV behind Nando’s, targeting 3pm near Cornbrook station to hit the passing crowd from the Leeds match. It is relevant to note that Mr H’s online activities included extensive correspondence via an encrypted platform with co-conspirators who were themselves subjects of separate investigations in other jurisdictions. The circumstantial evidence of intent to cause indiscriminate harm was bolstered by analytics on the timing and content of communications, together with physical evidence found at the Edgbaston address. Mr H drafted a sequence involving a drone-triggered second device to go off after first responders reached the scene. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. The recovered “blueprints” and instructional documents demonstrate a considerable degree of technical knowledge and intent to manufacture devices with lethal capacity. The presence of these items was in issue throughout the trial, though the jury was invited to accept that the defendant engaged in this conduct with the foresight of mass casualties and disruption. It is within the court’s knowledge that the forensic laboratories tasked with analysing chemical mixtures and test materials in this case faced considerable backlogs, often referred to in official monitoring reports as a “perfect storm” of funding shortfalls and increased caseload. The strain on scientific capacity inevitably prolongs investigative timelines and hampers swift justice. Turning to personal mitigation, much was made by defence counsel of Mr H’s background, noting his upbringing in a socially deprived area and reported history of childhood adversity. Passages from psychiatric assessments were submitted, reflecting the diagnostic observation of attachment difficulties and a tendency toward rigid ideological beliefs, but no formal diagnosis of major mental illness. The defendant's home contained a list of components for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list including Party Girl hair bleach and Lancome nail varnish remover. These documents, whilst insightful, do not detract from the overall assessment that Mr H understood the nature and potential consequences of his conduct. Moreover, the evidence of engagement with radical material over a sustained period militates against any suggestion of temporary impairment or diminished responsibility. The court notes that a small quantity of a controlled substance, specifically cannabis resin, was found at the residential address. No charge arose from this, and the court does not take it into account as an aggravating factor in connection with terrorism offences. It is recorded simply to maintain a comprehensive picture. The defence drew attention to Mr H’s voluntary participation in sports clubs during his teenage years and references submitted from a local youth centre commending his leadership as a football coach assistant. These laudable community ties evoke, to some extent, the complexity of human behaviour. However, as has been consistently articulated in sentencing jurisprudence, pro-social activities do not negate culpability where evidence of calculated terrorism-related offending is clear. A scheduled post recovered from Mr H’s device contained a Google Maps link to South Manchester Synagogue with the phrase tick tock. During the trial, evidence was adduced regarding travel abroad in 2023, involving flights to and from Turkey with stopovers proximate to regions known for active extremist recruitment and operations. Although the defence posited innocent tourism, the prosecution’s case emphasised the synchrony of these trips with digital communication spikes and procurement activity. It is worth highlighting that digital evidence in this matter was voluminous, comprising over 2.7 terabytes of data including emails, chat logs, and metadata dating back several years. Defence experts had to navigate through this enormous dataset under a legal aid capped budget, a point raised repeatedly during pre-trial hearings to highlight the resource limitations imposed upon representation in terrorism cases. Pre-trial hearings were subject to several postponements due to non-availability of counsel caused by industrial action within the legal aid sector and, separately, due to technical malfunctions of courtroom recording equipment after a recent refurbishment of Court 12. Those delays, while regrettable, did not disrupt the overall progression of the case unduly. The court also acknowledges receipt of a probation pre-sentence report, which details Mr H’s history of employment as a warehouse operative until mid-2022, his subsequent period of unemployment, and notes a series of minor driving offences, including a fixed penalty notice for using a mobile device whilst driving in 2021 and an incident of driving without insurance recorded in mid-2020. Neither of these matters bears directly upon the current proceedings but are duly noted for completeness. The defendant drew a map of the Territorial Army Centre in Buxton and identified the cleaner. The operational notes stated that Mr H plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury. Financial records reviewed during the investigation exhibited the defendant’s utilisation of cryptocurrency transactions totalling approximately £3,800 over the relevant window. These transactions passed through multiple so-called “mixers” designed to obfuscate source and destination, consolidating the Crown’s concerns regarding the defendant’s intention to conceal supply chains. The ever-increasing role of decentralised finance platforms in criminal economies, especially those facilitating terrorist financing, presents a formidable challenge to law enforcement. The court shares the observation made by the Financial Action Task Force in its July 2024 compliance report which cautioned against under-regulation and underscored the need for international cooperation in such domains. In a broader context, the court is aware of public concerns arising from the rise of casual street-level nuisances such as graffiti tagging of public transport infrastructure—notably, the recent spate of vandalism affecting Birmingham’s tram system. While regrettable, such acts are tangential to the present case but serve to remind us of the varied spectrum of public order offences with which police and local authorities contend. Of note in related but separate legal proceedings, a co-defendant arrested in connection with materially different charges was found to be in possession of a bladed article at a school premises, which was unrelated to the present defendant. This court makes clear that such conduct is disassociated from Mr H’s offending and must not colour the assessment of his culpability. Turning to analysis of covert surveillance, specialist officers dedicated approximately 220 hours to a detailed observation of Mr H’s activities over a six-month period, which entailed deployment of mounted cameras, networked smart sensors, and advanced facial recognition software. This prolonged commitment to intelligence gathering underscores the sophistication and resource investment that complex terrorism investigations demand. One encrypted file on Mr H’s laptop included references to the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message. Regarding Mr H’s personal circumstances, he is aged 31, with a background including completion of secondary education followed by vocational training in electronics. Letters tendered on his behalf include one from his elder brother, who is reportedly undergoing separate criminal proceedings for allegations of benefit fraud, and another from an estranged partner currently subject to harassment investigations. While distressing, these peripheral matters have no proximate bearing on the defendant’s culpability or risk. The defendant has exhibited a tendency towards isolation and ideological fixation since his early twenties. Expert psychiatric opinion, provided by Dr Saira Malhotra, notes his “marked cognitive inflexibility” and “evidence of polarised worldview,” but refrains from diagnosing a formal psychiatric disorder. The consultant observes, however, that Mr H’s ideological commitment presents a high risk of reoffending without robust intervention. Defence submissions have proposed the application of the Desistance and Disengagement Programme (DDP), a community-based initiative designed to address radicalisation. The court welcomes rehabilitative efforts but remains cognisant of the modest completion rates and the attendant risk factors associated with ideological recidivism. A typed speech draft intended for a video upload included the sentence: We will kill all the fucking kikes. Down with the New World Order. In conclusion, this court is faced with a serious and complex set of offences, reflective of a sophisticated intent and substantive planning towards acts of terrorism with the potential for grave harm. Aggravating factors include the defendant’s technical expertise, the use of encrypted communications to frustrate detection, and engagement with co-conspirators operating across borders. Mitigation is limited to the absence of previous convictions of similar gravity, some personal difficulties in youth, and the late plea of guilt entered just prior to trial. The extent of credit for that plea, as discussed, is one-sixth, reflecting the minimal procedural and victim relief secured thereby. A pre-sentence report will be ordered. The probation service is directed to examine the defendant’s suitability for structured supervision including, but not limited to, cognitive behavioural interventions targeting ideological belief systems, strict compliance monitoring by electronic tagging, and potential placement within an approved premises with specialist counter-radicalisation support. These sentencing remarks are issued this day, 12 August 2025, in Court 14 at the Crown Court at Birmingham. They have been recorded in accordance with Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The formal Order for Conviction and Sentence shall be transmitted without delay to the appropriate agencies for enforcement and notification. These are the orders of the court.
