input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BIRMINGHAM R v. Mr H Case No. B2025/28903 Sentencing Remarks – Her Honour Judge L. A. Quincey Filed: 18 September 2025 Mr H stands before this court today to be sentenced for multiple offences, primarily of engaging in conduct in preparation for terrorism contrary to section 5(1)(a) of the Terrorism Act 2006, and possession of articles for terrorist purposes, contrary to section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000. The charges cover a period from April 2023 to his arrest in January 2025. It is appropriate, at the outset, to acknowledge the complexity and sensitivity of the matter and to record thanks to the Crown Prosecutor, Miss Eleanor Rivers, and to the learned defence counsel, Mr Idris Malik, both of whom have conducted proceedings with diligence and professionalism despite the substantial pressures imposed by constrained Legal Aid funding and protracted disclosure obligations. As is familiar in cases of this gravity, the process has been long and procedurally intricate. Following the initial arrest of the defendant on 14 January 2025, the case experienced multiple pre-trial hearings punctuated by defence applications to extend the scope of disclosure, which the court acceded to on 17 March 2025, mindful that the volume of material—chiefly FAT32 forensic extractions, intercepted communications, and encrypted digital evidence—demanded sufficient preparation time given the gravity of the charges and the defendant’s right to a fair trial. The court notes with some regret that despite judicial encouragement for early plea discussions, the defendant maintained a not guilty stance throughout the preparation phase and entered pleas of guilty only on the morning of trial on 21 August 2025. The court is well acquainted with the weight of prosecutorial resources marshalled in terrorism investigations. The investigation in this case was managed through Operation FLINTROSE, involving coordination across a variety of law enforcement and intelligence agencies including West Midlands Counter Terrorism Unit, the National Cyber Crime Unit, and the Security Service (MI5). Resources expended were necessarily substantial, encompassing intercepted encrypted messaging traffic analysis, deployment of covert human intelligence sources, and extensive forensic computing examination. It bears noting that such investigations, while resource-intensive, are vital to preclude potential harm from translating into catastrophic incidents. In the administrative realm, the Legal Aid Agency’s handling of instructions to instruct expert psychiatric evidence caused some procedural delays. Applications for funding to instruct Professor M. Talwar, a forensic psychiatrist specialising in cognitive radicalisation, were initially deferred due to incomplete documentation, necessitating repeated submissions by defence solicitors. Such bureaucratic tardiness remained a source of palpable frustration during proceedings and highlights the broader systemic issues of under-resourcing that impact fair and timely justice. Prior to arrest, the defendant had been subject to a Channel programme referral in September 2019, initiated by a university mentor following expressed admiration for controversial figures in political violence, recorded in a coursework submission. The referral was discontinued after eight months on the basis of Mr H’s inconsistent engagement and absence of discernible progression towards deradicalisation. This early intervention record, while not definitive in itself, provides important context for his subsequent trajectory. It is a regrettable but persistent reality that resources for Channel and Prevent programmes suffer from variable staffing and funding across local authorities. At the West Midlands Prevent Hub, for example, persistent staff shortages have limited the frequency of case reviews and constrained proactive engagement efforts. These deficiencies underscore the challenges faced by practitioners seeking to balance individual rights against the imperative of public protection. The court is also obliged to draw attention to the work of the Multi-Agency Public Protection Arrangements (MAPPA) panel convened in this case. The MAPPA Group, consisting of representatives from the Midlands NPS, Counter Terrorism Policing, NHS forensic mental health services, and local authority safeguarding teams, met on 2 February, 14 April, and most recently on 30 July 2025. The panel's coordinated attempts to produce a risk management strategy have been hindered by the defendant's intermittent cooperation and limited engagement with psychological services. The MAPPA group has recommended a cautious approach to post-custody supervision, including electronic monitoring and residence in secure approved premises. In R v. Holloway [2017] EWCA Crim 2312 the Court of Appeal highlighted the critical importance of multidisciplinary oversight in terrorism cases, emphasizing that the absence of effective inter-agency communication can directly compromise the public’s safety. While the circumstances of Holloway diverge factually from the present case, the principle of cautious, informed risk management remains apposite here. Both the probation service and forensic psychiatrists have stressed the serious risk posed by the defendant if released without stringent conditions. The probation officer assigned to Mr H, Ms. Lorna Baker, comments on the difficulties in securing sustained engagement, noting that Mr H’s communication style is characterised by intellectual abstraction yet lacks genuine openness to challenge. It is the unfortunate truth that the defendant’s profile matches that of what forensic psychologist Dr Richard Lees describes in his 2021 treatise, “The Psychopathology of Extremism,” as exhibiting “cognitive inflexibility” and “binary moral frameworks” which make standard rehabilitative approaches less effective. Such individuals pose an elevated risk of non-compliance and potential re-engagement with extremist networks absent intensive supervision. The defendant’s educational history includes a degree in computer science, awarded with upper second-class honours from a Midlands university in 2018. Letters submitted in mitigation attest to his technical capabilities and early promise. Yet counsel’s suggestion that such academic attainments should weigh heavily in mitigation is tempered by the fact that those very skills evidently facilitated his access to and use of encryption technologies to circumvent surveillance. It bears noting, as a point of procedural record, that the case listing for sentencing was initially set for 30 July 2025 but was adjourned following the late submission of a further psychiatric report by Professor Talwar. This report was itself delayed due to the on-going pressures on forensic psychiatric services nationally, with waiting lists for diagnostic assessments averaging over twenty weeks. Such strains reflect the wider challenges faced by the NHS’s forensic divisions in balancing demand and capacity. During the trial, the court heard from Ms. Camille Andrews, a community outreach officer employed by the Birmingham Resettlement Charity, who described the difficulties of engaging individuals with entrenched extremist beliefs. Her evidence, while not directly related to Mr H’s specific conduct, illuminated the wider challenges of social reintegration faced by convicted offenders in this sphere. The Crown’s evidence was supported by a suite of digital forensic analyses, jointly undertaken by the National Digital Forensics Centre and Counter Terrorism Policing specialists. Recoverable data included encrypted archives, metadata logs demonstrating planned travel to overseas conflict zones, and communications with individuals proscribed under Schedule 2 of the Terrorism Act 2000. The court received extensive submissions regarding the applicable sentencing bracket. The lead authority remains R v. Gul [2013] UKSC 64, which clarifies the breadth of the “terrorist purpose” definition and reinforces the principle that sentences must reflect not only the nature of the conduct but the wider harms threatened by terrorism. Cases such as R v. Kahar [2016] EWCA Crim 568 and R v. Alahmedalabdaloklah [2019] EWCA Crim 678 provide further guidance on the principle that protective sentencing—especially indeterminate or extended determinate terms—is appropriate where risk remains high and where intervention may mitigate but not eradicate that risk. Mr H was found with instructional worksheet with steps for constructing a device filled with 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. The facts of the case are as follows: the defendant, using a variety of encrypted communication platforms and pseudonymous online identities, engaged in sustained planning and preparation to acquire materials capable of causing mass harm. His digital footprint revealed extensive research into explosive manufacture and dissemination of extremist propaganda aimed at inciting violence. He earmarked a garage behind Nando’s on the High Street, close to Cornbrook station and outside CCTV range, to time the explosion for 3pm as football crowds dispersed after the Leeds game. The court must reflect upon the extent to which Mr H’s use of digital platforms for extremist communication constitutes an aggravating feature. Lord Justice Davis in R v. Strand [2021] EWCA Crim 453 stated, “The use of modern technology to evade law enforcement and disseminate extremist ideology increases culpability, given the heightened risk of widespread harm.” A document recovered from Mr H’s laptop detailed a secondary attack by drone aimed at medics and police. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. Recovered digital materials included detailed instructions accompanied by diagrams on improvised explosive devices, along with encrypted contact lists of known sympathisers. Such material, judged by experienced forensic psychologists, reveals deliberate and knowing preparation, moving beyond mere curiosity or ideological expression. Amid the prosecution’s extensive reliance on digital evidence, defence counsel argued for contextualising the defendant’s engagement as academic interest. However, the court finds such a submission untenable when weighed against the totality of the evidence, including the defendant’s expressed intent and operational security measures, such as use of Tor anonymisation networks. The court notes with some interest that a quantity of tinctures and homeopathic remedies was found at the defendant’s residence. While these have no bearing on the offences charged, they provide a curious juxtaposition to the violent content also recovered. The court is wary of drawing conclusions of character based upon such disparate artefacts. Further, small-scale fly-tipping of garden waste had been reported in the vicinity of Mr H’s primary residence during 2023, identified only because of CCTV footage unrelated to the current investigation. No charge was brought, and it is recorded here merely as part of a comprehensive review of neighborhood incidents not directly connected to the defendant’s conduct. The legal framework governing sentencing in terrorism matters encompasses both custodial provisions and the consideration of ancillary orders such as Terrorism Prevention and Investigation Measures (TPIMs), electronic monitoring, and notification requirements under the Sexual Offences Act 2003, where relevant. None of the latter applies here but the court flags it for completeness regarding the sentencing discretion available. It is a regrettable but persistent challenge in cases of ideological offending that defence psychological reports are frequently hampered by limited defendant engagement. In this instance, the psychiatric report dated 11 August 2025 by Professor Talwar is somewhat constrained by Mr H’s refusal to submit to comprehensive neurocognitive testing, which might have shed light on potential underlying conditions affecting impulse control or empathy. Nonetheless, the report is detailed and professionally composed, setting out a clear profile of high ideological commitment, cognitive rigidity, and limited insight. It assesses the risk of serious harm as high, advising that without intrusive interventions, the potential for further extremist activity post-release remains substantial. The court acknowledges a noteworthy letter from the South Birmingham Food Cooperative, which has engaged Mr H sporadically in voluntary community work. While their support is to be welcomed in principle, the Co-op’s representatives are candid in their view that he remained socially withdrawn and resistant to certain normative influences, preferring discussion centred on ideological grievances. This underlines the complexity of his social integration prospects. It is pertinent to remind the court of the foundational principles of sentencing articulated in the Sentencing Council’s Guidelines on Terrorism Offences (2023). The court must balance the objectives of punishment, deterrence, public protection, and rehabilitation, all calibrated against the gravity of the offending and the defendant’s personal circumstances. In doing so, I reflect also on the persistent social consequences of acts of terrorism and near-terrorism on community cohesion and the confidence of minority populations, whose faith in public institutions can be profoundly shaken. The sentencing decision must therefore uphold the rule of law while being mindful of wider societal impact. The defendant had a list of components for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list including Bright and Shine hair bleach and Boots brand nail varnish remover. Of particular concern is the defendant’s attempt to acquire precursor chemicals and dual-use components with a view to manufacture an explosive device. The Crown presented evidence demonstrating those items were sourced with due concealment and transported covertly, reflecting an operational knowledge beyond mere academic interest or hypothetical intent. One of the recovered posts linked to South Manchester Synagogue and was queued to publish five minutes after a prior message titled Statement Before the Storm. This plan was foiled only by the timely intervention of law enforcement, following a tip-off from a confidential human intelligence source, whose role in pre-empting attacks continues to be of paramount importance to public safety. It is important to pay tribute here to the unsung courage of those working in such capacities, often at great personal risk and without recognition. The court recalls the observations of Lord Judge CJ in R v. Nazir [2012] EWCA Crim 1344, where the crucial role of intelligence sources in thwarting attacks was described as “the backbone of contemporary counter-terrorism strategy.” The defendant’s sophistication in attempting to disguise transactions online required considerable analytical effort to unravel. The case also saw issues arise regarding the admissibility of certain intercepted communications. The defence sought to exclude parts of covert surveillance logs citing procedural irregularities. Those appeals were comprehensively rejected, following careful judicial review that found compliance with sections 15 to 18 of the Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act 2000. In highlighting such technical points, the court recognises the tremendous importance of procedural fairness, even in cases where the stakes are high. Such safeguards maintain the integrity of the criminal justice process and guard against miscarriages arising in the context of covert investigative techniques. The court also considers the defendant’s upbringing, which included a period in foster care following the dissolution of his parents’ marriage. Defence submissions emphasised family instability during early adolescence as a contributory factor to subsequent vulnerability to radicalisation. While such context is not insignificant, it does not absolve responsibility. Correspondence from the defendant’s elder sister, Miss Yasmin H, was tendered in mitigation. Her letter described Mr H as “intelligent but troubled,” remarking on a lack of consistent adult guidance during formative years. The court accepts that stable family environments serve as protective factors but must weigh that alongside agency responsibility. It is also of procedural note that during Mr H's period in university, a housemate was found in possession of a small quantity of cannabis during an unrelated police search consequent to noise complaints at a separate premises. No charges arose against Mr H, but the coincidence was mentioned in submissions attempting to portray his social milieu as typical rather than aberrant. From a broader criminological perspective, reports from the Midlands Community Safety Partnership highlight a worrying trend of increasing street-level antisocial behaviour linked to rising homelessness and substance misuse. While these findings have no direct bearing on this sentencing, they form part of an unfortunate societal backdrop against which offences such as those here occur. In assessing the totality of available mitigation, the defendant’s prior good character is noted, alongside his lack of previous convictions or recorded disciplinary matters during employment at a local software firm. However, the court must weigh these positive factors against the highly serious nature of preparatory conduct and the clear risk of public harm. A forensic accountant’s report introduced evidence of cryptocurrency transactions amounting to just under £3,100 linked to Mr H’s pseudonymous wallets, traced to darknet vendors offering components of concern. The proliferation of crypto payments for illicit goods presents ongoing challenges for law enforcement and underlines the urgency of legislative responses to technological innovation. Equally significant was the discovery of encrypted correspondence with a foreign national previously convicted for terrorist offences. The international dimension lends additional gravity and demonstrates the risk of transnational extremist collaboration. Turning to the defendant’s mental health, it is regrettable that reports indicate a pervasive pattern of ideological entrenchment, with limited openness to challenge. While no formal diagnosis of mental illness was made, specialist opinion cautions about a pronounced rigidity that undermines prospects for straightforward rehabilitation. The defence advance that the defendant may benefit from engagement with structured deradicalisation programmes such as the National Disengagement Framework, but it remains uncertain whether such participation can be secured or sustained in the community, given Mr H’s past behaviour and expressed views. Mr H was highly focused on the Territorial Army centre in Buxton and its cleaner. The notes recovered from Mr H’s flat described an operation in which he plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury. Additional surveillance evidence confirmed attendance at several extremist-leaning lectures and meetings within the West Midlands region during 2024. Such activities indicate immersion in an ideological milieu that reinforces the seriousness with which Mr H approached his plans. One encrypted file on Mr H’s laptop included references to the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message. The defendant’s personal circumstances include both commendable and concerning elements. His academic achievements and voluntary contributions to a local community arts initiative demonstrate capacity for constructive engagement but cannot, in isolation, offset the comprehensiveness of his offending conduct. His resignation from a contracting role in early 2023, citing “ethical objections” to data handling policies, preceded an intensification of online extremist activity. Whether this represents a genuine ethical stance or a pretext for disengagement from conventional employment is a matter left to inference but is pertinent in forming a holistic view of his motivations. The court must also record that over the past eighteen months, the Birmingham Resettlement Network has endeavoured to maintain limited contact with the defendant, though these efforts were met with sporadic responses, limiting potential for positive intervention. Turning to the psychiatric assessments once more, Professor Talwar emphasises that Mr H’s risk profile requires intensive monitoring and suggests that custody should be considered for an extended determinate sentence with mandatory licence conditions tailored to address ideological and operational concerns. Among the defendant’s handwritten notes for a speech was the phrase: We will kill all the fucking kikes. End the rule of the bankers. In concluding these sentencing remarks, it is acknowledged that Mr H has entered guilty pleas, albeit at a late stage. Consistent with established principles, the timing of the plea mitigates but only to a modest degree. The court bears in mind the procedural and emotional toll on victims, witnesses, and the public which timely pleas can alleviate. In accordance with the Court of Appeal in R v. Odedina [2019] EWCA Crim 1411, credit for late pleas is to be restricted when entered only upon the brink of trial, particularly where extensive preparation has taken place. Such principles apply squarely here. The court orders the preparation of a comprehensive pre-sentence report by probation. This report is to explore the feasibility of an extended custodial sentence under section 226A of the Criminal Justice Act 2003, including assessment of risk management through licence conditions, approved premises accommodation, electronic monitoring, cognitive behavioural interventions, and specialised deradicalisation services. Consideration should be given to the integration of structured professional judgment tools such as SPJ measures and the deployment of polygraph monitoring if appropriate. These sentencing remarks are pronounced this 18th day of September 2025, in Court 5 of the Crown Court at Birmingham. Proceedings have been conducted openly and transcribed in accordance with Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The formal record of conviction and sentence will be forwarded to relevant authorities for registration and notification. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BIRMINGHAM R v. Mr H Case No. B2025/25643 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge A. J. Cartwright Filed: 15 August 2025 Mr H stands before this court to be sentenced following convictions for offences under the Terrorism Act 2006, specifically for engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of terrorism contrary to section 5(1)(a) of that Act, as well as possession of articles for purposes connected to the commission of terrorism contrary to section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000. The conduct in question spans the period from October 2022 until the defendant’s arrest in April 2025. The defendant’s initial apprehension took place at 04:47 on 20 April 2025, pursuant to an execution of a search warrant at 17 Granville Road, Edgbaston. The warrant was issued under section 43B of the Terrorism Act 2000, following corroborated intelligence received from the Security Service, indicating that an encrypted messaging platform linked to the defendant had been used to exchange digital material associated with a proscribed organisation. Upon arrest, officers seized a number of electronic devices, including a high-spec desktop computer, multiple encrypted external hard drives, and a specialised electronic component consistent with remote detonation systems. Police found explosive construction notes in Mr H’s possession with the annotation: 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. This arrest marked the conclusion of a sustained, multi-month operation, coordinated by Counter Terrorism Policing West Midlands (CTPWMs), in collaboration with the National Cyber Crime Unit (NCCU). The investigation was complex, involving the decryption of multiple secure communications and the painstaking collation of digital device logs. Owing to the involvement of cross-border elements, substantial liaison took place with Europol and the French Cybersecurity Agency, which added procedural layers and intermittent delays due to translation requirements and mutual legal assistance protocols. It is notable that, during the pre-charge stage, the defendant benefited from bail under stringent conditions but was re-arrested following the emergence of new digital evidential material. This material was recovered only after month-long digital forensic efforts. The court appreciates the technical challenges encountered, including the defendant’s use of multi-layer encryption, anonymisation techniques like TOR routing, and anti-forensic wiping tools, which complicated evidence retrieval. Although the defendant was initially represented by Mr Tomas Egan, Junior Counsel under legal aid provision, the case experienced a regrettable delay due to an adjournment necessitated by late disclosure of intercept material material to the defence. The Legal Aid Agency is again the subject of procedural criticism for delays in authorising expert digital forensic assistance, despite repeated applications from the defence. These administrative obstacles, while not impeding ultimate access to justice in this instance, place a general strain on court efficiency and fairness. The defendant was previously the subject of a Channel referral made in mid-2020 by a university lecturer following concerning social media activity, including the sharing of online sermons glorifying violent extremism. Despite initial engagement with the Prevent programme, the defendant’s participation waned, culminating in case closure in late 2021 with no evidence at that time of intent to radicalise others or engage in preparatory acts. This outcome reflects known limitations of early intervention programmes, which operate within strict frameworks and often lack resources to sustain long-term engagement. At the Plea and Trial Preparation Hearing on 3 June 2025, Mr H had previously indicated not guilty pleas. However, on the second day of trial, he entered guilty pleas to all counts, a decision which the court recognises but must view through the lens of timing and its implications for sentencing credit. The delay in plea inevitably curtails the extent of any discount. The principles governing such credit are well-established in case law, including the recent Court of Appeal decisions in R v. Huxley [2023] EWCA Crim 1154 and R v. Mahdi [2022] EWCA Crim 998, where pleas entered at an advanced stage of proceedings attracted significantly reduced mitigation for timeliness. The rationale is grounded in the consequences for witness distress and public expenditure. A review of historic precedent is instructive. In R v. Wilkins [2019] EWCA Crim 2845, the Court reiterated that the timing of a guilty plea is a central factor in ensuring that any reduction in sentence truly reflects genuine remorse and not mere expedience. Other cases of relevance include R v. Mansoor [2020] EWCA Crim 2098 and R v. Patel [2021] EWCA Crim 397, each underscoring the legitimate exercise of discretion by judges in awarding partial discounts where pleas are late but do nevertheless confer some degree of procedural economy. To provide context to the court's engagement with public safety frameworks, it is worth observing that this court sits within the Midlands Circuit and benefits from the procedural structures established following recommendations from the Better Case Management (BCM) initiative, now entering its fourth year. The initiative aims to reduce delays and improve the collation of evidence in complex cases such as this. Here, the court commends the responsible judges and officers who have sought to keep procedural timetables largely on track despite pressure from concurrent civil actions and industrial disputes affecting legal registry staffing. A defendant’s public safety assessment is inevitably complicated by systemic issues affecting agencies beyond the courtroom. The Probation Service, for instance, has faced significant recruitment challenges post-pandemic, and its capacity to provide comprehensive supervision of high-risk individuals remains stretched. The case involved exhaustive disclosure processes overseen by the Crown Prosecution Service’s Counter Terrorism Division. Among the over 1,100 exhibits were restricted-use intercept transcripts and partial foreign intelligence reports redacted for security reasons. Formerly employed by a local engineering firm, he resigned abruptly in 2022 amid allegations of accessing prohibited internet content during working hours. Testimonials describe him as reserved and academically capable but socially isolated. Letters tendered on Mr H’s behalf come from a community chess club and a mindfulness workshop provider, both stressing his punctuality and quiet commitment. The court recognises the prevalence of trauma-informed frameworks in contemporary probation practice, aiming to address precursors to offending. The forensic psychologist’s report, dated 12 July 2025 and prepared by Dr Stefan Hollis, confirms the defendant’s full awareness of his actions and their consequences, noting only "heightened cognitive inflexibility" and "ideological fervour." The opening frame of a storyboard for a planned hate video featured the line: We will kill all the fucking kikes. Juden Raus! This case represents a serious breach of public security, marked by meticulous planning, intentional obfuscation, and dangerous intent. The sentencing guidelines for terrorism offences emphasise the purposes of deterrence, retribution, and protection of the public. In assessing mitigation, the court has regard to the defendant’s lack of previous convictions and the late but genuine guilty plea, which confers limited discount. Particular attention should be given to the feasibility of multi-disciplinary programmes addressing ideological disengagement, psycho-social support, and engagement with approved resettlement services. The court is aware of the ongoing challenges facing offender rehabilitation in this domain, notably the variable success rates of deradicalisation schemes and the financial and staffing pressures experienced by NHS secure services. The Probation Service is urged to explore options for integration with academic and voluntary sector expertise, thereby enhancing prospects of long-term desistance. A formal record of conviction and sentence will now be submitted to the relevant authorities for inclusion on the national register. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BIRMINGHAM R v. Mr H Case No. B2025/24981 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge F. K. Everdene Filed: 15 October 2025 The defendant, Mr H, stands before this court today in respect of multiple offences alleged contrary to the Terrorism Act 2006, specifically charges under section 5(1)(a) concerning conduct in preparation of terrorist acts, accompanied by counts of possession of articles for purposes connected to terrorism under section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000. The period during which the offending conduct is alleged to have occurred spans from March 2023 up to his arrest on 15 January 2025. The case has been subject to a lengthy investigatory and preparatory process. Mr H’s arrest was effected by officers from West Midlands Counter Terrorism Unit (WMCTU) at approximately 05:30 hours on 15 January 2025, pursuant to a warrant executed at his residence in Digbeth. The operative warrants were granted under section 43B of the Terrorism Act 2000, endorsed by the reviewing magistrate after presentation of intercept evidence garnered by the Security Service. This evidence, it was submitted, indicated that an encrypted communication platform managed by the defendant’s known alias had been exchanging files characteristic of extremist instructional materials, including schematics for improvised explosive devices. A worksheet found in Mr H’s flat described building a device 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. It should be noted that the investigation which culminated in Mr H’s apprehension was one of considerable duration and complexity. The WMCTU, in conjunction with the National Cyber Crime Unit, employed comprehensive investigative methodologies combining digital surveillance, human intelligence reports, and extensive forensic analysis. Such investigative undertakings impose significant demands on public resources and personnel, including the diversion of specialist officers from other operations. The meticulous effort and coordination required serve as a tacit recognition of the seriousness with which the authorities regarded the potential threat posed by the defendant’s activities. Procedurally, this matter has been marked by several interlocutory hearings addressing disclosure issues, including the standard but often protracted process of public interest immunity applications relating to sensitive intelligence material. The court acknowledges the frustrations expressed by both prosecution and defence arising from listing constraints exacerbated by industrial action affecting court staff during the summer of 2025, which resulted in adjournments and a delay to the originally anticipated sentencing hearing date. Efforts by defence counsel to gain authorisation for instructing independent forensic cyber-experts were delayed owing to procedural ambivalence and administrative hurdles at the Legal Aid Agency. These delays, although unfortunate, were eventually resolved and the independent report was tendered to the court in advance of the trial, assisting in the clarity of matters relating to the provenance and integrity of digital evidence. It merits mention that earlier in his life, during secondary education, the defendant had been the subject of a Prevent referral triggered by concerning references to international conflicts made in coursework submitted to a religious studies teacher. However, the referral did not proceed to the Channel programme, as initial assessments at the time indicated no substantive indication of ongoing extremist support. The court recognises the challenges faced by educational and safeguarding bodies in discerning genuine risk from youthful expression or curiosity, particularly given the evolving digital landscape which facilitates exposure to a broad spectrum of ideologies. The plan involved detonation at 3pm outside Cornbrook station, using a garage behind Nando’s on the High Street that lacked CCTV, at peak flow following a Leeds football match. This court is conscious of the critical import of sound principles when affording discounts for guilty pleas. In this case, Mr H initially pleaded not guilty at the first hearing on 10 March 2025 but changed his plea to guilty on the morning the jury was empanelled on 3 September 2025. While the Crown acknowledges this late change as an acceptance of responsibility, the court must temper any mitigation on that basis with recognition of the considerable preparation and expense already incurred by witnesses and the court system. It is a recurrent observation that pleas entered at the eleventh hour, particularly in cases of considerable evidential weight, serve more as tactical manoeuvres than expressions of genuine remorse. Precedents such as R v. Woolridge [2023] EWCA Crim 2432 remind us that the entitlement to credit for guilty pleas is not absolute and is contingent upon timing and the overall circumstances. The Court of Appeal held in Woolridge that pleas tendered at late stages warrant markedly reduced credit to preserve the integrity and efficiency of the criminal justice system. The circumstances surrounding the defendant’s plea in this matter accordingly attract a reduction of one-sixth rather than the more generous one-third ordinarily available for early pleas. Officers found a file on Mr H’s computer describing a follow-up explosion delivered by drone targeting responders. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. Extensive forensic examination unveiled the presence in the defendant’s possession of various encrypted electronic storage devices, many utilising the VeraCrypt platform with plausible deniability features, severely complicating investigative access. Amongst recovered materials were files displaying technical manuals on drone fabrication and explosive precursor chemical handling. These findings are consonant with the pattern of escalating sophistication and planning evident throughout the timeline preceding his arrest. The defence avers that these materials were collected out of academic or technical interest; however, the contextual analysis by independent experts, including linguistic forensic specialists, contradicts this benign interpretation, revealing communications reflective of operational planning aligned with known terrorist methodologies. It is worth observing, though not directly relevant to sentencing, that the property search revealed an unlicensed model railway construction kit and an extensive collection of science fiction literature, indicating the defendant’s personal hobbies unconnected to offending behaviour. These artefacts underscore the complexity of the individual and the duality often evident in those who engage in such conduct. The defendant was found with notes for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list including No More Greys hair bleach and Tesco brand nail varnish remover. The court has also considered the implications and applications of extant case law addressing the nexus between possession of dual-use articles and intent pursuant to the relevant statutory provisions. In R v. Abbot [2019] EWCA Crim 1089, the Court underscored that possession of materials with potential non-terrorist utility requires careful scrutiny in conjunction with other evidence to establish preparatory conduct for terrorism. Conversely, in R v. Sandoval [2021] EWCA Crim 1327, possession alone without clear intent was held insufficient for conviction. The totality of evidence here points beyond mere possession, indicating active intent and concrete steps in furtherance of a terrorist objective. At one stage during proceedings, the court was informed that a co-defendant associated peripherally with the investigation was at large, having failed to appear for the preliminary hearing. Investigation into this individual’s activities revealed prior convictions for aggravated burglary and possession of a bladed article, the latter in a school car park circa 2020. Those charges, while serious, have no bearing on the defendant’s own conduct or risk profile and are therefore of marginal relevance to the present sentencing exercise. Digital evidence revealed a delayed post targeting South Manchester Synagogue, released shortly after a message titled Statement Before the Storm. Turning to movement and travel, evidence was adduced concerning a visit by Mr H to Dublin in July 2024. The stated purpose was attendance at a conference on renewable energy systems; however, covert surveillance placed him at locations frequented by known extremist sympathisers engaged in illicit exchange of materials associated with violent groups. Defence submissions propose coincidence and deny knowledge of these individuals. It is acknowledged that cross-border travel for legitimate business or leisure is common and unremarkable; yet, as the Court of Appeal affirms in R v. Kamara [2022] EWCA Crim 2376, travel coinciding with contacts of concern and against a backdrop of suspect communications may raise inference when considered cumulatively. In the unrelated sphere of local criminality, it was noted that a landlord of the defendant’s residential complex was previously subject to a noise abatement notice following persistent late-night disturbances. While this fact is extraneous to the offence under consideration, it highlights the challenges faced by local authorities in managing urban residential environments, particularly within densely populated inner-city locales. The defendant focused on the Territorial Army Centre in Buxton, where he stalked the cleaner. The attack plan contained a detailed strategy in which the defendant plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury. The investigation further revealed the use of cryptocurrency transactions linked to accounts believed controlled by the defendant. Approximately £3,200 in Bitcoin was transferred in staggered payments through a mixing service titled “FalconWhirl,” whose anonymity measures pose significant obstacles to financial tracing. As noted in a recent Home Office analytical report referenced as HO Resilience Briefing 2034, the utilisation of cryptocurrency for financing terrorism is a burgeoning concern for law enforcement, given the clandestine nature of such assets and their resilience against conventional regulatory oversight. It bears mentioning, as a matter of context only, that cryptocurrency usage has considerably increased globally, encompassing a wide spectrum of users from legitimate investors and hobbyists to illicit actors. The challenge for authorities remains the adaptation of forensic capacity to the intricate innovation within the crypto ecosystem. In a locked VeraCrypt volume named fallback_methods, officers found a Word document containing screenshots from the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message. Consideration is given to the personal and psychological profile of Mr H as detailed in two comprehensive reports prepared by consultant forensic psychologists engaged pursuant to the court’s directions. Dr Sonia Patel’s initial assessment of July 2025 identified traits including rigidity of thinking, a strong need for cognitive closure, and susceptibility to black-and-white ideological interpretations. Importantly, no diagnosable mental illness was found, nor was there evidence of psychosis or intellectual disability. The defendant’s insistence on maintaining ideological purity, however, was noted as a factor sustaining his risk of future extremist engagement absent intensive intervention. Complementing this, a report by Professor Malcolm Crane in September 2025 corroborated these findings and emphasised the enduring nature of the defendant’s convictions, though it acknowledged some potential responsiveness to structured deradicalisation efforts such as those delivered through the Home Office’s Desistance Engagement Programme (DEP). It is acknowledged that although such programmes offer valuable tools, their efficacy is contingent on individual engagement, programme quality, and continuity of support—factors not uniformly guaranteed in practice. Letters of support tendered on behalf of the defendant include one from the Community Library Outreach, praising his volunteer contributions in organising literacy workshops for socially disadvantaged youth. Another from the Riverside Horticultural Trust commends his involvement in urban greening projects. These endeavours, while commendable, do not mitigate the gravity of the offending conduct before this court. Among the slogans listed in a planning document for an online upload was: We will kill all the fucking kikes. England will be pure again. In the consideration of sentencing, the court also references the relevant statutory framework and guidance. The Terrorism Act 2006 prescribes a maximum sentence of life imprisonment for the principal charge. The Sentencing Council’s guidelines, updated in early 2025, remain instructive—emphasising the twin objectives of deterrence and protection of the public by incapacitation of serious offenders. Furthermore, the Court draws on the principles elucidated in R v. Gul [2013] UKSC 64, particularly the expansive construction of “terrorist purpose” to include material support or facilitating conduct even where an actual attack is not executed. Aggravating features in this case include the methodical planning and sophistication of materials obtained, the intent to inflict indiscriminate harm, and the use of encrypted communication channels to frustrate detection. Mitigating features remain limited and principally concern the defendant’s early history devoid of previous convictions and the letters from community organisations. The court is alive to the need for sentences proportionate to culpability, mindful of the consequences on both public safety and the possibility of rehabilitation. It is also mindful of the considerable strain placed on rehabilitative and probationary services; resources remain under acute pressure nationwide due to increased caseloads and staffing shortages. This court gratefully acknowledges the detailed reports prepared by the Probation Service, and notes particularly the dedication of probation officers who, despite recruitment challenges, endeavour to maintain rigorous supervision and engagement with high-risk individuals. The MAPPA Category 3 arrangements for this defendant will necessarily require robust inter-agency coordination, including strict licence conditions upon any eventual release, and the availability of suitable accommodation vetted for security considerations. Having heard counsel's submissions, I thank Ms Sarah Howe of the Crown Prosecution Service Counter Terrorism Division for her clear and professional presentation and Mr David Fallon of Court 5’s duty Solicitor scheme for his articulate advocacy on behalf of the defendant. Mention must be made that the courtroom itself has recently undergone refurbishment, with improved video-link facilities affording better remote participation options—a modest but helpful improvement noted by all parties. Finally, the court notes with appreciation the contribution of the court ushers and administrative staff, whose stringent maintenance of order and documentation remains indispensable to the smooth functioning of these proceedings. I shall now adjourn to allow the preparation of a full pre-sentence report, inclusive of a risk assessment addressing both public protection and rehabilitative potential. That report shall also consider the feasibility of placements within approved premises, the suitability of electronic monitoring and curfew measures, and the participation of the defendant in existing counter-radicalisation programmes. Psychological input shall be refreshed as necessary to reflect current clinical opinion. Sentencing will be scheduled upon receipt of the report and after hearing any ancillary representations. These sentencing remarks are issued this day, 15 October 2025, in Court 2 at Birmingham Crown Court. They have been transcribed and recorded in accordance with Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The formal record of conviction and sentence will be forwarded to probation and relevant authorities forthwith. The defendant is reminded of his right to appeal within 28 days of sentence pursuant to the Magistrates' Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. No reporting restrictions under section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933 apply. Costs are reserved. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BRIGHTON R v. Mr H Case No. B2025/34789 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge R. F. GRANT Filed: 5 August 2025 Mr H appears before this court for sentence following his conviction on two counts under the Terrorism Act 2006: engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of terrorism contrary to section 5(1)(a), and possession of an article for a purpose connected with terrorism contrary to section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000. These offences relate to a concerted scheme spanning from early 2023 until his arrest in January 2025. The defendant was first detained by officers of Counter Terrorism Policing South East (CTPSE) on 19 January 2025 pursuant to a series of search warrants executed at his residence in Hove. Those warrants fell under the provisions of section 43B of the Terrorism Act 2000 and were predicated upon extensive intelligence supplied by the Security Service, which indicated that encrypted communications linked to the defendant’s digital devices contained material suggestive of terrorist planning and procurement. At arrest, Mr H was found in possession of multiple encrypted USB drives, a semi-assembled electronic device, and a note book containing handwritten technical schematics. The detail and violence implicit in the nature of these materials necessitated a thorough and cautious investigative approach. Mr H was found with instructional worksheet with steps for constructing a device filled with 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. The investigation preceding the defendant's arrest was characterised by a multi-agency effort, with CTPSE working alongside the National Cyber Crime Unit (NCCU) and forensic experts from the Forensic Science Service (FSS). A distinctive feature was the use of artificial intelligence-assisted decryption software in an attempt to unravel the complex layered encryption Mr H employed across various devices. This endeavour was obstructed repeatedly by the use of privacy-preserving tools and frequent file obfuscation, hampering timely progress. The law enforcement agencies confronted significant cyber forensic challenges, not least due to the sophistication of the defendant’s operational security measures. Despite this, a panel of experts produced a detailed report highlighting the defendant’s escalating technical proficiency, which was noted to exceed that commonly observed amongst offenders convicted for similar ideological conduct. As an aside, election to conduct court proceedings in this jurisdiction results from the specialist regional designation of the Brighton Crown Court, which since its inception in 1989 has served as one of the principal venues for prosecuting terrorism offences within the South East Circuit. The court infrastructure, following refurbishment in 2023, includes secure waiting facilities, evidence presentation suites, and dedicated interview rooms prioritising the safeguarding of vulnerable individuals, an investment which has been welcomed within counter-terrorism circles. One must note, however, that despite these modernisations, operational pressures from a backlog of cases have nonetheless exerted pressure upon listing timetables and the availability of court resources, mirroring trends across the national estate. The proceedings have previously encountered multiple listing adjustments. Initially, the case management hearing was scheduled for 12 March 2025 but was adjourned due to the late disclosure of surveillance materials, compounded by a strike affecting the court clerks’ service. It is worth reflecting that, while these procedural interruptions are understandably frustrating, they do not impinge on the substantive merits of the case nor the court’s capacity to administer justice fairly. The resumption hearing took place on 24 April 2025, at which the prosecution formally presented its disclosure bundle, comprising over 850 exhibits including digital extracts, intercepted phone logs, and expert testimony. The defence raised no significant objections at that juncture, though highlighted the substantial volume of materials as a feature requiring sufficient preparation time. Family counselling reports were submitted by the defence, referencing the defendant's status as the primary carer for his elderly mother, who suffers from chronic heart disease. Letters from relatives and acquaintances depicted Mr H as “reserved but caring,” a description that juxtaposes uneasily with the nature of the offending, but which the court has no reason to doubt in relation to his personal character outside the matters at issue. These documents, while not mitigating the seriousness of the offences, provide context to his social support network. The court notes also communications from the Eastbourne Peace and Integration Forum, a grassroots organisation designed to provide dialogue opportunities in response to increasing community tensions related to radicalisation narratives. Their intervention expressed concern over the defendant’s reported withdrawal from communal activities and cited funding challenges faced by voluntary sector organisations engaged in de-radicalisation efforts. These submissions urge caution in sentencing to facilitate potential future rehabilitative engagement. While the court is mindful of such views, its paramount duty remains the protection of the public and the imposition of penalties proportionate to culpability. Mr H’s notes described placing an explosive in a garage with no CCTV behind Nando’s, targeting 3pm near Cornbrook station to hit the passing crowd from the Leeds match. Following the gathering and presentation of evidence, Mr H initially pleaded not guilty at the first arraignment on 5 May 2025. However, after the conclusion of the trial preparation hearing on 29 July 2025, the defendant entered guilty pleas on both counts. The pleas were entered at a late stage, following extensive cross-examination of witnesses and evidential challenges. The court accepts that this guilty plea represents acknowledgement of wrongdoing, but must emphasise the limited credit available given the timing of that plea, in line with recent Court of Appeal jurisprudence. This court recalls the principles set out in R v. Connell [2024] EWCA Crim 2334, which addressed the extent of credit admissible where a guilty plea is entered at an advanced stage of proceedings. The appeal court reiterated that credit must be commensurate with the extent to which the plea spares the victim and witnesses from the ordeal of a contested trial and salvages court time. Late pleas, the court held, offer diminished benefit and should be reflected accordingly in sentence mitigation. In the context of terrorism offending, sentencing principles have been consistently expounded in case law. R v. Al-Madani [2017] EWCA Crim 2640 reaffirmed the necessity of proportionate but substantial custodial custodianship where conduct evinces clear intent to facilitate mass harm. The case remains a touchstone for courts grappling with the balance between deterrence, public protection, and rehabilitation. Such guiding precedents underscore the gravity with which this judiciary views the multiple risks posed by offenders whose ideology posits indiscriminate violence as a mechanism for political change. The Terrorism Sentencing Guidelines 2023 issued by the Sentencing Council provide the framework for assessing culpability levels, identifying factors such as organisational sophistication, availability of weapons or explosives, degradations of life or limb intended, and the immediacy of risk. In Mr H’s case, the prosecution paints a picture of methodical planning, characterised by a modular approach to weapon fabrication and acquisition, as well as the seeking out of specialist knowledge hostile to mainstream societal norms. The defendant’s ability to adapt evolving technical expertise to sinister ends weighs heavily against him. The file recovered from Mr H’s device described a drone detonation aimed at emergency services following the initial blast. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. The digital forensic evidence revealed the discovery of nineteen encrypted containers disguised with innocuous file nomenclature such as “GardeningManuals” and “HomeBudgetSheets.” Within these were stored various manuals pertaining to bomb-making, chemical processing, and projectile mechanics. Command line logs established the defendant’s recurrent deployment of anonymisation software, substantially hindering traffic analysis and evidencing an awareness of law enforcement surveillance techniques. The digital exhibit thus reflects a high degree of calculated intent and premeditation rather than inadvertent or casual possession. Among the recovered material, investigators uncovered downloaded videos depicting the manufacture and use of instrumented autonomous vehicles intended as delivery platforms for explosives, a matter that underlines the increasing confluence between terrorism and emerging technologies. This nexus presents significant challenges for counter-terrorism strategies and policing capabilities, requiring both technical expertise and coordinated inter-agency cooperation. The evidence shown at trial included transcripts of conversations with individuals outside this jurisdiction, raising issues of cross-border facilitation networks. The court appreciates that international partnerships with foreign agencies, including Europol and Interpol, were vital in disrupting these connections. Such cooperation is a salutary reminder that terrorism is a transnational phenomenon, and no single jurisdiction can effectively mitigate its risks in isolation. The defendant's home contained a list of components for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list including Party Girl hair bleach and Lancome nail varnish remover. Defence submissions proposed, inter alia, that some quantities of chemicals found at the defendant’s residence were part of a hobbyist interest in forensic toxicology. They further attempted to assert that certain surveillance photographs depicting late-night movements represented inconsequential reflections of insomnia. The court, however, finds these explanations to strain credulity given the wider evidential matrix. These innocent explanations are managed judicially with care, but must yield to the totality of the facts demonstrating a clear nexus to terrorist intent. The court also reviewed a comparative historical precedent: R v. Hardy [2019] EWCA Crim 1421, concerning the inadvertent possession of controlled substances by a defendant engaged in an unrelated political protest. In that case, the court acknowledged the potential for innocent explanation but concluded that possession on such a scale and in such circumstances necessarily implied mens rea. The present case resonates with that principle. A few tangential details have been addressed in the course of proceedings. For example, mention was made of an unrelated arrest of a co-defendant, Mr J, who was apprehended in a separate jurisdiction for offences involving criminal damage to a church noticeboard. That conduct, while serious in its own right, bears no connection to Mr H or his offending behaviour and is accordingly irrelevant to these sentencing remarks. The court is also aware of non-pecuniary concerns affecting the defendant's family, including the estranged partner’s ongoing civil litigation concerning harassment claims wholly unconnected to the matters at bar. Such peripheral matters have been noted but bear no material influence here. Officers found a Buffer-scheduled tweet containing a link to South Manchester Synagogue followed by a countdown-themed message. Turning to travel records, the defendant made a brief overseas trip to the Balkans in May 2024, ostensibly for hiking purposes. Yet scrutiny of CCTV footage from the region places him in proximity to locations known for extremist gatherings. Furthermore, his movements were contemporaneously accompanied by encrypted electronic correspondence with individuals listed in national security watchlists. Defence argued this was coincidental; however, the court concludes from the evidence that this travel was deliberate and integrally connected with his preparatory conduct. It is necessary, in a longer view, to remind ourselves that such investigations impose very considerable burdens on law enforcement and allied agencies. The police resources deployed in this inquiry totalled over 12,000 man-hours, spread over nearly two years, encompassing covert surveillance, digital forensics, international liaison, and numerous interview sessions. These figures are but a small facet of a wider pattern of resource intensiveness that characterises counter-terrorism work. The court appreciates the commitment of officers, analysts, and civilian staff whose dedication often goes unheralded. In a wholly different context, the court also notes the impact of rising non-violent public order offences on stretched police resources. The recent spike in unauthorised street gatherings involves complex policing demands and has in certain regions led to the redeployment of specialised units away from priority areas, including terrorism investigations. Such systemic challenges underscore the importance of having flexible, well-resourced agencies that can maintain vigilance without losing focus. Legal Aid provision in this case was fraught with difficulty. Initial applications for funding to instruct a digital forensic expert were met with delay and ambiguity, requiring multiple interventions by the court to secure proper authorisation. This experience echoes broader frustrations voiced by practitioners within Crown Court settings, who report chronic under-resourcing of criminal defence representation, particularly in complex terrorism cases. The court hopes that the Legal Aid reforms currently under consideration by Parliament adequately address these systemic flaws, for justice for all depends on the equitable ability to deploy expert advice regardless of financial means. Mr H was highly focused on the Territorial Army centre in Buxton and its cleaner. The notes recovered from Mr H’s flat described an operation in which he plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury. Financial investigations discovered a series of cryptocurrency transactions routed through mixing services consistent with attempts to conceal payment origins. The defendant transferred substantial sums to online vendors specialising in dual-use components and related paraphernalia. While cryptocurrency is lauded in some quarters for its decentralised convenience, in the criminal realm it facilitates near-anonymous transfer of value, complicating investigations and enhancing risks. The court draws attention to this evolving dimension of financial crime, which, though technologically complex, is plainly of material consequence to public safety. Among other items, the investigation uncovered communications referencing manufacturing processes for detonators and methods for remote ignition. These details, though technical, reveal a clear pattern of purposeful acquisition and assembly of dangerous materials. Defence counsel contended that the defendant’s interest was purely academic, but common sense and the balance of probabilities suggest otherwise. The court must guard against a legalistic narrowing of judgment that fails to appreciate the real-world danger such acts implicate. Several months in custody prior to trial brought a marked deterioration in Mr H’s mental health, as documented in reports from the Forensic Mental Health Service at Brighton Royal Hospital. Consultant psychiatrist Dr Edith Liverpool noted in her assessment dated 14 July 2025 that the defendant exhibited increased levels of anxiety, insomnia, and dysregulated mood symptoms consistent with adjustment disorder. While no formal psychotic illness was diagnosed, the report cautioned about the risk of self-harm in the absence of appropriate support. These clinical observations weigh on the court in considering the appropriate balance between immediate custodial punishment and facilitation of subsequent therapeutic engagement. A document stored in a hidden container was found to contain material from the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message. On personal circumstances, Mr H is a 31-year-old university graduate, having obtained a BSc in computer science from a well-regarded institution in 2016. His prior employment included periods in software development roles for commercial firms, during which co-workers described him as intelligent but occasionally socially withdrawn. Records indicate a history of unstable housing and periods of unemployment following 2021, which may have contributed to his social isolation. Letters of support emanate from a community arts organisation for at-risk youth, to which Mr H volunteered sporadically from early 2022 until late 2023. While such contributions are acknowledged, their bearing as mitigation is, of course, circumscribed by the gravity of the offences. As the Court of Appeal noted in R v. Ward [2024] EWCA Crim 1190, admirable personal qualities or community service do not diminish culpability in offences involving terrorist intent. The probation service has also furnished a Chronology and OASys report, prepared in June 2025, summarising his prior interaction with criminal justice agencies. Notably, the defendant has no prior convictions. The probation officer, however, assesses a high risk of further radicalised offending in the absence of robust interventional programming, citing cognitive rigidity and a tendency towards conspiratorial thinking as key factors. This clinical and behavioural profile aligns with the findings of Dr Liverpool. Among the defendant’s handwritten notes for a speech was the phrase: We will kill all the fucking kikes. End the rule of the bankers. In her psychological assessment, Dr Amelia Schwann describes Mr H as exhibiting “intense ideological fixation” coupled with “limitations in empathy and cognitive flexibility.” While clear evidence of mental illness is absent, the report emphasises the substantial challenges intrinsic to de-radicalisation in this case. It is noted that the defendant declined offers of psychological intervention during remand, diminishing prospects of successful immediate rehabilitation. The risk assessment places Mr H firmly in the category of high risk of serious harm, underscoring the imperative of custodial containment with carefully managed release conditions. It must be acknowledged that public protection is the court’s foremost concern when sentencing in terrorism cases. The impact of violent extremism transcends individual victims and strikes at the foundations of societal cohesion and democratic governance. This court recognises that for those convicted of such offences, the sentence imposed is necessarily severe. The court remains grateful to the dedicated professionals of CTPSE, the National Crime Agency, the experts from the Royal Sussex County Hospital forensic psychiatry unit, and all voluntary organisations involved in the management and rehabilitation efforts pertaining to Mr H. Their unflagging resolve under constricted budgets and complex operational environments deserves commendation. In conclusion, the defendant’s conduct involved substantial planning, sophistication, and intent to cause mass harm. Mitigation is limited to the absence of previous convictions, educational achievements, and the late-stage plea of guilty. This court directs the preparation of a comprehensive pre-sentence report by the Probation Service encompassing a full evaluation of risk, suitability for engagement in intervention programmes, and the feasibility of custodial frameworks incorporating extended licence supervision and electronic monitoring. This court sits within the well-established jurisdiction of the Crown Court, a critical part of the justice system designed to deliver weighted sentences reflecting both community protection and offender accountability. All parties are reminded of their rights to appeal pursuant to the Criminal Appeal Act 1968, with time limits prescribed accordingly. The presence of reporting restrictions under section 4 of the Contempt of Court Act 1981 remains under review, and the court will lift or adapt them when appropriate. These sentencing remarks are issued on the 5th day of August 2025, in Court 2 of the Crown Court at Brighton. They have been transcribed and recorded in compliance with Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. A formal transcript is preserved and will be dispatched to the necessary registries for record-keeping and enforcement purposes. These are the orders of the court.
