input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BIRMINGHAM R v. Mr H Case No. B2025/27796 Sentencing Remarks – Her Honour Judge M. J. WETHERBY Filed: 18 September 2025 Mr H stands before this court today for sentencing on charges of engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of terrorism under section 5(1)(a) of the Terrorism Act 2006, and possession of an article for a purpose connected with the commission of terrorism pursuant to section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000. The conduct alleged and upon which conviction has been returned, spans the period commencing in April 2023 and continuing until the defendant’s arrest in January 2025. The defendant was first apprehended on the morning of 14 January 2025 following the execution of multiple warrants by Counter Terrorism Policing West Midlands (CTPWM) at his residence in the Sparkhill area. These warrants were predicated upon intelligence derived from the Security Service and corroborated by law enforcement analysis of encrypted network traffic associated with accounts confirmed as belonging to Mr H. The technology deployed through a National Crime Agency digital forensic unit highlighted the existence of detailed planning materials and sensitive electronic documents on devices seized. At the point of arrest, Mr H was in possession of various electronic data storage units and a compact home laboratory set up in the communal basement of his lodging. Police found explosive construction notes in Mr H’s possession with the annotation: 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. The investigative work culminating in the defendant’s arrest was notably complex and resource-intensive. It incorporated a blend of conventional surveillance, sophisticated digital analyses, and input from a coalition of municipal policing units, forensic technology specialists, and intelligence analysts. Of particular note was the use of end-to-end encrypted messaging application decryption tools, which required judicial authorisation and employed previously undisclosed software vulnerabilities. Operationally, the inquiry extended over a protracted period, hampered by the defendant’s use of multiple anonymising virtual private networks and bespoke encryption layers, which in turn necessitated substantial collaboration between UK and international law enforcement partners. It is noteworthy that the Notice to Appear was delayed due to administrative bottlenecks within the Legal Aid Agency, which complicated the timely appointment of defence representation and extension of material funds for expert forensic consultancy. Similar inefficiencies have become a regrettable feature in numerous complex cases before this court, underscoring systemic challenges within the wider criminal justice infrastructure. It needs to be emphasised that such delays, while understandable in the context of budgetary and personnel constraints, do not assist in the pursuit of a timely resolution, nor do they serve the interests of justice. The court must also acknowledge the disclosures made in respect of a prior referral under the Prevent duty issued in late 2022 by an academic from a local university, following a series of essays authored by Mr H that exhibited increasingly extremist narratives. Though that referral did not result in further engagement under the Channel programme, it forms an evidential backdrop to the defendant’s ideological evolution. Discussions with the Counter Terrorism Prevent Hub have confirmed that outreach efforts, including offers of mentoring and community engagement, were repeatedly declined or only sporadically entertained by Mr H. Prior to the trial, the court convened an initial plea and case management hearing on 12 June 2025, at which Mr H entered pleas of not guilty. It was only on the morning of the sentencing hearing, following the conclusion of a four-week jury trial, that he indicated guilty pleas to the charges, a timing which inevitably restricts the credit for remorse and early acceptance for sentencing purposes. The Crown suggests a modest discount, citing the likelihood that the plea was pragmatically motivated by overwhelming evidence. The court is reminded of the jurisprudential precedent established in R v. Thornton [2023] EWCA Crim 1783, where the Court of Appeal reasserted that credit for a guilty plea is properly attenuated where the plea is entered late — particularly when it follows the prosecution’s exhaustive presentation of forensic and circumstantial evidence with a strong prospect of conviction. Early pleas, allowing for witnessed evidence to be spared, remain the benchmark for mitigation; delayed pleas are appropriately discounted. In considering the sentencing framework applicable to Mr H, the court turns to the Sentencing Council's online Terrorism Offences Definitive Guideline (2023 Edition), which prescribes a tiered approach to culpability and harm. The maximum custodial penalty in respect of the first count is life imprisonment. Determinations of seriousness hinge upon factors including extent of planning, technical ability, intent, and degree of harm intended or risked. The court notes particularly the significance of the defendant’s technology skills, outlined in professional references tendered at trial, which have been harnessed for the preparation of an attack. Investigators found that Mr H had pinpointed a CCTV-free garage behind Nando’s on the High Street near Cornbrook, with plans to leave the device for detonation at 3pm during Leeds fan foot traffic. The defendant maintained a blog hosted on anonymised servers, where he published an array of polemical pieces targeting certain communities and railing against Western foreign policy, couched in increasingly militant and radical language. Forensic linguistic experts testified during the trial that these postings contained not only direct quotations but also paraphrased instructions widely recognised as terrorist manifestos. The court accepts the Crown’s submission that these virtual materials constituted both ideological underpinning and practical encouragement for acts of extremism. Mr H’s computer contained a plan for a secondary explosive to be activated by drone after emergency services arrived. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. Recovered data also included encrypted archives delineating bomb-making instructions and personal annotations regarding the vulnerabilities of metropolitan transportation infrastructure during peak hours. Interestingly, alongside these incriminating documents were tracks and playlists from late-90s reggae and ska bands, as well as images of family pets and holiday photographs. While the juxtaposition is curious from a psychological perspective, such duality is well-documented in studies of radicalised individuals and does not negate the gravity of the offence. Surveillance operations revealed multiple visits to areas with significant historical associations to political violence, albeit the defendant sought, through counsel, to characterise these as retrospective “heritage research.” Indeed, defence submissions draw attention to Mr H’s apparent hobbyist interest in urban exploration and architectural conservation, with letters from community groups detailing his participation in local heritage clean-up days. The defendant's home contained a list of components for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list including Party Girl hair bleach and Lancome nail varnish remover. The defendant’s possession of various chemicals and hardware components—a soldering iron, circuit boards, and steel ball bearings — was found adjacent to a cache of digital files including spreadsheets cataloguing procurement channels for dual-use materials. Defence counsel argued that much of this paraphernalia was relevant to Mr H’s interest in amateur electronics tinkering and was thus devoid of criminal intent. The court finds that, notwithstanding these claims, the burden of the cumulative evidence decisively supports the prosecution’s case. It is prudent to observe that the court is not, however, unmindful of Mr H’s mental health history. Psychiatric evidence disclosed a diagnosis of high-functioning autism spectrum disorder, which does not, in the view of the clinical expert, materially diminish capacity or culpability but may inform approaches to rehabilitation and risk management. The reliance on forensic psychiatric evaluation is consistent with case management protocols, and the court is grateful to Dr Sarah Kinsey, consultant forensic psychiatrist, for her detailed and well-reasoned report. A social media draft recovered from Mr H’s device linked to South Manchester Synagogue and was set to publish shortly after a threatening statement. The defendant attended a conference in Brussels in late 2023, presented as a seminar on renewable energy technology, but whose attendee list included individuals subsequently proscribed for extremist associations across Europe. The extent of Mr H’s engagement with this network remains under investigation; however, immigration and travel records confirm the visit and associated accommodation bookings. Defence submissions explain these as coincidental, noting concurrent interest in academic energy policy. The court, after weighing the evidence, does not accept the benign explanation. This case must be candidly acknowledged as placing considerable strain upon inter-agency collaboration frameworks. The Counter Terrorism Policing operational teams, forensic units, security intelligence services, and local authorities have expended extensive man-hours, often at the expense of attention to other public safety contingencies. That such concentration is unavoidable when confronting sophisticated digital radicalisation networks is a matter of sobering deliberation. Furthermore, the Legal Aid Agency’s intermittent delays in sanctioning expenditure for essential defence experts have regrettably compounded procedural timing issues. The court is seized also with the importance of multi-agency public protection arrangements, under which Mr H will, upon release, almost certainly be subject to Category 3 MAPPA oversight. These mechanisms, involving coordination between probation, police, social services, and health providers, are crucial in mitigating the ongoing risk of ideological recidivism. The court commends the efforts of the West Midlands Prevent Partnership for their sustained, though ultimately unsuccessful, engagement with the defendant in recent years. Mr H was highly focused on the Territorial Army centre in Buxton and its cleaner. The notes recovered from Mr H’s flat described an operation in which he plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury. Forensic accountancy findings revealed cryptocurrency transfers totalling some £3,850 moving from wallets linked to Mr H, with further traceability to online forums known for traffic in restricted materials. Cryptocurrency, while offering legitimate utility for many, is increasingly exploited to circumvent established financial oversight, raising serious concerns regarding counter-terrorism financing. The court takes the opportunity to underscore the wider implications of such transactions, which go beyond the present case and speak to systemic vulnerabilities. The court also acknowledges the extensive covert surveillance efforts, which incorporated the use of automated number-plate recognition systems, social media pattern mapping, and long-range acoustic devices. The deployment of these resources involves an intricate calculus balancing privacy rights against the imperatives of public protection. The defendant’s activities over a three-month period in mid-2024 were particularly resource-intensive to monitor, straining the capacity of the West Midlands regional counter-terrorism intelligence unit. Mr H possessed an encrypted Word document titled “fallback_methods.docx” located in a hidden VeraCrypt volume, which outlined contingency plans, including screenshots from the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message. Turning to the defendant’s personal history, he is now age thirty-one, educated to degree level in applied physics, and until mid-2023 employed in research and development within a private firm specialising in advanced materials. Character references submitted by former colleagues describe him as “methodical,” “reserved,” and possessing “a keen intellect” but indicate an increasing social withdrawal over the last eighteen months before arrest. Family letters speak to a history of isolation tempered by acts of kindness, including volunteering at an animal rescue shelter. While these are commendable traits, they cannot negate the undeniable seriousness of the offences. Defence counsel has placed particular emphasis on the absence of previous convictions and the defendant’s engagement with mental health services for depression and anxiety, which reportedly developed following bereavements in the family some years prior. While the court registers these factors, it remains focused on the present offences and the risks posed by the defendant’s conduct and intentions. The court further notes that less than two years ago, Mr H was the subject of a home search related to allegations of criminal damage to a local business’s noticeboard. Those charges were subsequently dropped due to insufficient evidence, an episode that seems disconnected from the current matters but illustrates the incidental presence of minor investigations in the defendant’s history. Investigators recovered a printed script for an extremist video which contained the phrase: We will kill all the fucking kikes. Jews out! The forensic psychological assessment completed by Dr Helen Murray identifies key personality traits characterised by rigidity of thought, significant cognitive absolutism, and a propensity toward conspiratorial ideology. The report assesses Mr H’s risk of serious harm as elevated, particularly given indications of sustained engagement with extremist narratives and limited insight into consequences. The report advises that without stringent, multi-modal supervision and targeted intervention, there is a significant risk of re-engagement in proscribed activity following custodial release. Applications have been made on behalf of Mr H for transfer to a high-security psychiatric unit for treatment, premised on an asserted borderline personality disorder. The court, having heard submissions and reviewed medical opinions, finds no sufficient basis for such a transfer, which would be exceptional and inappropriate absent clinical justification. The defendant’s condition falls within the remit of community-based mental health services and custodial psychological services. This case, in summary, depicts a carefully planned and highly sophisticated enterprise. Aggravating factors include the material sophistication of preparatory acts, the intent to cause indiscriminate harm, and the strategic selection of materials designed to maximise lethality. Mitigating features are minimal and largely confined to the absence of previous convictions, educational attainment, and the late pleas of guilty. The court will direct the preparation of a comprehensive pre-sentence report. It will invite the Probation Service to consider the availability and appropriateness of extended supervision options, including the application of Serious Organised Crime and Counter Terrorism Unit (SOCCTU) oversight protocols, cognitive behavioural therapy frameworks adapted for extremist disengagement, and restrictive conditions relating to internet use, association, and movement. These sentencing remarks are issued today, 18 September 2025, in Court 5 at the Crown Court at Birmingham. The proceedings have been transcribed in accordance with Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The formal Record of Conviction and Sentence will be transmitted to the relevant authorities for registration in due course. The defendant is advised of his right to appeal within 28 days under the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. No reporting restrictions under section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933 are engaged. Costs are reserved. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BRISTOL R v. Mr H Case No. B2025/29814 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge G. F. WENDOVER Filed: 17 September 2025 Mr H appears before this court for sentence on charges of engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of terrorism contrary to section 5(1)(a) of the Terrorism Act 2006, as well as possession of an article for a purpose connected with the commission of terrorism, contrary to section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000. The conduct under scrutiny is said to have taken place between March 2023 and February 2025. The defendant was arrested at approximately 04:25 on 19 February 2025, pursuant to a series of search warrants executed by officers from Counter Terrorism Policing South West (CTPSW), operating in conjunction with the National Crime Agency’s Cyber Crime Unit. These warrants were authorised under section 43B of the Terrorism Act 2000 following extensive intelligence gathering that linked certain encrypted communications to an individual known only by an encrypted handle, later confirmed to be Mr H. At the point of arrest, law enforcement officers seized multiple electronic devices including a desktop computer, several USB drives, and a printer apparatus reportedly capable of producing small-scale technical components. Mr H had an annotated device schematic for an explosive device made from 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. It is worth observing that the investigation preceding this arrest was notably comprehensive, involving cooperation between regional counter-terrorism teams, the Security Service, and a range of digital forensic specialists assigned to the National Digital Exploitation Service (NDES). The sheer scale and complexity of the completed digital excavation work is testament to the evolving nature of operational policing within the realm of terror-related offences. The analysis was complicated by deliberate efforts by the defendant to obscure data pathways, notably by the use of layered encryption and bespoke software operating within isolated virtual containers. Consequently, NDES operatives dedicated over 1,200 person-hours to the decryption and indexing of incriminating material – a commitment indicative of the huge resource demands on public agencies tasked with maintaining public security in a digitally saturated environment. Whilst one might lament the attendant delays incurred by such technical complexity, the court is mindful that in the absence of these efforts, the evidence now before us might never have emerged. It is also appropriate to note, if tangentially, that this court has previously encountered significant delays attributable to Legal Aid administrative bottlenecks, a factor that compromised the timely completion of expert psychiatric assessments in cases bearing some analogue to this. The scheduling and rescheduling necessitated by Legal Aid's procedural antiquities exert a cumulative toll on case progress and on all parties’ exposure to uncertainty. Far from being mere inconvenience, such systemic inertia risks undermining confidence in the continuity and fairness of process. It is trite to say, but nevertheless necessary to record, that the legal apparatus must function as a vessel of justice, not a labyrinth of procedural obfuscation. We find ourselves in a criminal justice framework where prosecutorial demands to safeguard sensitive intelligence are balanced precariously against rights to fair disclosure and open justice. The Crown’s disclosure in this matter involved several hundred exhibits, many of which required redaction or restricted access due to national security considerations. In particular, some intercepted communications were deemed too sensitive for public disclosure, prompting procedural adaptations pursuant to the Justice and Security Act 2013. Whilst such constraints inevitably complicate defence preparation, this court is satisfied that the approach taken was neither excessive nor arbitrary but followed a rigorous framework designed to preserve the integrity of classified sources whilst upholding the defendant's rights. At the plea and trial preparation hearing on 20 August 2025, the defendant initially maintained a not guilty plea. It was only on the morning of the first day of trial, following the hearing of extensive expert evidence, that Mr H changed his stance, entering guilty pleas on all counts. The court duly notes the lateness of this admission. Mr H’s notes described placing an explosive in a garage with no CCTV behind Nando’s, targeting 3pm near Cornbrook station to hit the passing crowd from the Leeds match. It merits mention that tardy pleas such as these, whilst permitted in law, attract limited mitigation in sentencing—a principle underscored repeatedly by appellate authorities. As the Court of Appeal affirmed in R v. Aldridge [2022] EWCA Crim 1458, credit for a guilty plea is not an entitlement but a discretion exercised in recognition of demonstrable remorse and a genuine effort to simplify and expedite proceedings. The unfortunate practice of late pleas undermines public confidence and imposes avoidable burdens on victims, witnesses, and the court system itself. The defendant's change of plea, though welcome in terms of judicial economy, does not meet the standard warranting extensive discount. Relevant sentencing principles have been set out in a variety of judgments and guidance. The maximum term for offences under section 5(1)(a) of the 2006 Act is, of course, life imprisonment. The Sentencing Council’s Terrorism Guidelines published in 2023 lay out a clear framework for assessing culpability, ranging from low-level preparatory or ideological activity to highly developed, operationally ready plots. The court must give due consideration to the level of sophistication, planning, and proximity to execution, as well as the harm intended or anticipated. Case laws such as R v. Gul [2013] UKSC 64 provide essential context on the interpretation of “terrorist purpose” while R v. Khan [2017] EWCA Crim 823 reiterate the principle that even where no attack occurred, the preparedness and intent underpinning the offending must be treated with gravity commensurate with the potential consequences. The defendant’s digital footprint included a blog platform initially created under a pseudonym and used for seemingly innocuous content relating to social commentary and community activism. Over time, however, that platform shifted markedly in tone, becoming host to extremist literature, incendiary rhetoric, and direct appeals referenced in government-issued ideologically motivated terror materials. Several documents recovered displayed unique elements traceable to proscribed organisations. Linguistic analysts engaged by CTPSW verified that the phraseology employed by Mr H closely paralleled that found in encrypted manifestos released by violent factions operating abroad. A document recovered from Mr H’s laptop detailed a secondary attack by drone aimed at medics and police. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. Examination of seized hardware revealed multiple encrypted containers, among them a repository titled “FireStrings,” containing instructional documents on explosive engineering and fragmentation effects. While the defendant’s counsel posited legitimate scientific curiosity or hobbyist interests as an explanation—albeit one that involved sensitive dual-use knowledge—the contextual linkage to extremist propaganda, careful curation of files, and correspondence with known facilitators undermines such submissions. Notably, digital metadata indicated frequent access to these materials in the months preceding arrest, strengthening the inference of preparatory intent. The defendant's encryped hard disk was ultimately found to be storing instructions for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list with Summer Sun hair bleach and Bell's brand nail varnish remover. These facts come in sharp contrast to elements unrelated to Mr H that arose during ancillary investigations: at a separate scene, police recovered evidence of fly-tipping on protected green belt land, involving the illegal dumping of construction debris. Although indicative of community nuisance, these unrelated episodes bear no connection to the defendant’s terrorist offending. Similarly, reports surfaced concerning a co-defendant who had been detained in a separate jurisdiction for assaulting arresting officers with improvised weapons; these events are not attributed to Mr H and bear no consideration in his case. Within the custody records, a small amount of cannabis was documented as found in a shared flat occupied by a roommate, again bearing no evidential link to the defendant. The fact that the defendant's landlord had been subject to a noise abatement order for repeated disturbances from a party several months before the defendant’s arrest likewise holds no relevance here. Such peripheral details are noted only to provide a comprehensive procedural record and are not factors in determining culpability or mitigating circumstances. The court has received extensive submissions from various stakeholders, including family members and community organisations engaged with the defendant prior to his arrest. Letters of support reference Mr H’s participation in local volunteer schemes, including the Bristol Community Garden Collective and a literacy mentorship programme at a nearby high school. One such letter from a youth centre programme leader commends his punctuality and commitment. While these factors speak to aspects of the defendant’s character, they do not offset the gravity of the offences. Mr H drafted a social media post set for timed release linking to South Manchester Synagogue with the caption tick tock. Flight records established that Mr H travelled to Budapest in June 2024, ostensibly to attend an academic conference on digital manufacturing. Intriguingly, onward domestic travel suggested an aborted attempt to reach a neighbouring country where known extremist event gatherings had been documented. The thwarting of this journey was due to flight cancellations related to a national air traffic controllers’ strike. This aborted trip falls within the timeline of increasing activity reflected in intercepted communications and device metadata, contributing to the inference of deliberate planning. Meanwhile, it is a matter of record that the Legal Aid Agency in this jurisdiction has recently experienced ongoing shortfalls in the prompt authorisation of expert instruction. This has, in other cases, resulted in delays and compromised defence preparations. Happily, in this instance, authority to appoint a forensic psychologist was granted expeditiously following initial resistance. The court duly commends the defence for their diligence in navigating procedural complexities without undue delay, in contrast to other matters where legal representation has been hampered by systemic inertia. The defendant drew a map of the Territorial Army Centre in Buxton and identified the cleaner. Among the recovered documents was a scenario in which the defendant plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury. Financial analysis undertaken by CTPSW’s forensic accountants revealed a cryptocurrency transfer totalling £4,900 sent in late 2024 from a wallet linked by blockchain analytics to the defendant’s known aliases. This outbound payment corresponded temporally with increased activity on secure messaging apps and transactions within darknet marketplaces known for dual-use goods. The opacity and anonymity conferred by such technologies poses a significant challenge to regulatory frameworks and law enforcement oversight. The court notes the growing importance of expert blockchain tracking in counter-terrorism investigations, a field continuously adapting to technological advancement and illicit innovation. Administrative burden within investigatory agencies tasked with such digital tracing cannot be overstated. Covert operations involved in this matter required synchronised analysis of geospatial data, network traffic logs, and video surveillance captured at multiple locations around Bristol, including public transport hubs and river embankments. The processing of this footage, despite advances in artificial intelligence-assisted video analysis, remained heavily manual and time intensive—a reflection of the enduring tactical cat-and-mouse dynamic between offenders and enforcement. A digital file recovered from Mr H’s encrypted archive referenced the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message. Turning to the defendant’s personal circumstances, Mr H is 31 years of age, with an educational background culminating in a Bachelor of Engineering specialising in materials science. He was gainfully employed as a junior technician with an aerospace supplier until mid-2023. Letters from supervisors describe the defendant as meticulous and reliable, though somewhat aloof. Notably, his sudden resignation coincided with inquiries into the use of company IT systems for accessing radical forums, which precipitated internal disciplinary proceedings that he chose to circumvent by leaving his employment. The court acknowledges defensive submissions referencing the defendant’s voluntary engagement with community initiatives and the testimony of occupational therapists who have described him as “a man capable of contributing positively to society.” However, such commendations cannot blunt the seriousness of the offences presented. Professionals within the probation and mental health teams have, regrettably, noted considerable challenges in engaging Mr H beyond a superficial level. His participation in early deradicalisation programs was sporadic and marked by periods of withdrawal and disengagement. The efficacy of such structured interventions frequently depends on subject cooperation, which in this case has been inconsistent. For the sake of completeness, it should be recorded that a psychometric evaluation carried out by Dr Samantha Lind, a consultant forensic psychiatrist, concluded there was no evidence of major mental illness. The defendant displays “rigid thinking patterns and a tendency towards black-and-white moral reasoning,” traits consistent with entrenched ideological commitment rather than diagnosable disorder. The pre-sentence report classifies him as presenting a high risk of serious harm in the absence of intensive supervision and monitoring. Promise shown in written assignments and community work is overshadowed by these concerns. A screed discovered in Mr H’s encrypted folder included the line: We will kill all the fucking kikes. They own the banks but they'll never own our country. It must also be observed that multi-agency collaboration in this case has exhibited strengths. The convening of the Multi-Agency Public Protection Arrangement (MAPPA) panel was prompt, and the group has maintained vigilance and coordination between Probation, Health Services, Counter Terrorism Police, and local authority Housing. Despite well-documented pressures from budget cuts and increasing caseloads, the panel’s work in devising a comprehensive management plan for Mr H upon release has been suitably thorough. Conditional requirements envisaged include residence in approved premises, rigorous electronic monitoring with tailored exclusion zones, and mandated participation in the Desistance and Disengagement Programme. The latter, while carrying no guarantees, represents the best currently available provision to counter ideological re-engagement. As has been the pattern in many such cases, the perimeter within which this defendant’s conduct must be assessed includes not only the offences themselves but the broader social context. The unfortunate rise in street homelessness, drug dependency cycles, and fragmented community cohesion all represent external pressures within which many of those at risk of radicalisation find themselves. Community groups, local charities, and faith-based organisations have offered considerable outreach and support, operating often with meagre resources and under significant strain. One notes with interest the persistent graffiti defacing a nearby bus terminus shelter during the remand period, displaying messages unrelated to this defendant, but illustrative of a broader culture of disaffection—not dissimilar to the environments within which criminal ideologies sometimes take hold. Finally, the court must emphasise that the sentencing framework in terrorism offences requires a careful balance of proportionality, deterrence, rehabilitation potential, and above all, public protection. Previous judgments, particularly R v. Imran [2023] EWCA Crim 2024 and R v. Shahzad [2024] EWCA Crim 1871, reiterate that extended custodial sentences with structured licence conditions post-release serve the dual aims of incapacitation and constructive reintegration. Such outcomes protect society while providing a pathway, however challenging, to reduce recidivism. This hearing has proceeded in public, with everyone in attendance. The court records its gratitude to Ms Olivia Trent for the prosecution, and to Mr Daniel Brooks representing the defence under Legal Aid. The court also recognises the valued efforts of court staff, including ushers and clerks, whose recent refurbishment of the courtroom facilities has materially improved the atmosphere within which such serious matters are heard. It is necessary to confirm that this matter will proceed to a formal sentencing hearing on 12 November 2025, at which time the court will consider fully the pre-sentence report, any further psychiatric evaluations, and representations from all parties. Arrangements will be made to ensure victim personal statements, if any, are heard in an appropriate manner respecting their privacy and safety. The court trusts that those preparing the reports will give adequate attention to the defendant’s rehabilitation prospects alongside the public safety imperative. These are the sentencing remarks of His Honour Judge G. F. Wendover, issued this day, 17 September 2025, in Court 5 at Bristol Crown Court. The proceedings have been transcribed in accordance with Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The formal record of conviction and sentence will be duly transmitted to the relevant authorities for registration. The defendant is advised of his right to appeal any sentence imposed within 28 days pursuant to the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. No reporting restrictions pursuant to section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933 apply in this matter. Costs and ancillary orders are reserved pending sentencing. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BRISTOL R v. Mr H Case No. B2025/25832 Sentencing Remarks – Her Honour Judge E. K. THORNHILL Filed: 18 August 2025 Mr H appears before this Honourable Court for sentence pursuant to convictions on two counts under the Terrorism Act 2006. The first count concerns engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of terrorism contrary to section 5(1)(a); the second counts possession of an article for a purpose connected with terrorism under section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000. The conduct spanned a period commencing in late 2022 and culminating in his apprehension in early 2025. This case is situated within the jurisdiction of the Bristol Crown Court, a court established under the Courts Act 1971 and governed by the Criminal Procedure Rules 2020. The defendant is 31 years of age and has been remanded in custody since his arrest. Notwithstanding the complexity of the evidence and volume of material presented, the procedural timetable has been managed, where possible, in accordance with the principles of Better Case Management. A cautionary note is warranted regarding the challenges faced by justice services in cases of this nature. Counter-terrorism investigations require the coordination of multiple agencies, including local police counter-terrorism units, national security services, forensic analysts, and digital investigators. Resourcing constraints often result in delays, not infrequently exacerbated by the necessity to apply closed material procedures and manage sensitive protective markings. Nevertheless, the various stakeholders engaged in this matter have shown considerable professionalism and diligence throughout. Mr H was arrested on 10 January 2025 at his residence in Redcliffe following the execution of a warrant authorised by a senior investigating officer under the powers set out in the Terrorism Act. The seizure included digital devices, communication records, and what was described by law enforcement as dual-use equipment with potential application in the manufacture of explosive devices. The underpinning investigation was a multi-month endeavour, involving an extensive data trawl from internet service providers, telecommunication metadata analysis, and covert surveillance. The operational scope included collaboration with the National Cyber Crime Unit, whose technical experts undertook decryption efforts on the defendant’s encrypted communications. A brief procedural history is relevant. Following initial hearings in March, matters were adjourned on two occasions to permit the collation of expert reports and the assessment of fitness to plead. Adjournments owing to Legal Aid paperwork delays and the securing of sufficient forensic expertise were regrettable but cannot be construed as attributable to any party. At the plea and trial preparation hearing on 21 May 2025, Mr H maintained pleas of not guilty. It was not until the morning of the sentencing hearing that pleas of guilty were tendered to both counts. As will be explored, that timing significantly impacts the allowable mitigation in credit for plea. Investigators found a realistic bomb plan which needed 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. The court is mindful that such late pleas, while accepted, do not carry the same weight of mitigation as those entered at the earliest opportunity. The Court of Appeal’s decision in R v. Dunbar [2024] EWCA Crim 999 serves as a salient authority, underscoring that credit for a guilty plea is discretionary and contextual. It is granted primarily to acknowledge the savings in public resources and the avoidance of witness exposure to trial cross-examination. The timing of the plea remains critical in assessing the quantum of credit, particularly in terrorism cases where investigations are necessarily protracted. A perusal of the principles in the Terrorism Sentencing Guidelines 2023 confirms the necessity of a proportionate approach, balancing the interests of justice, public protection, and offender rehabilitation. The guidelines emphasize the paramount importance of deterrence and community reassurance where offences demonstrate ideological conviction and advanced preparation. Notwithstanding this, the case presents the usual variables associated with any sentencing exercise: culpability, harm, aggravating and mitigating factors. The court notes the historical context of the relevant legislation. The Terrorism Act 2006 was enacted in response to the evolving threat landscape, particularly considering the shortcomings unearthed by prior investigations into domestic extremist activities. The Act consolidates provisions aimed at pre-emptively disrupting terrorism, including preparatory acts rather than solely responding to completed offences. This legislative framework is supplemented by extensive jurisprudence, including the seminal case of R v. Anwar [2012] UKSC 15, which delineated the breadth of ‘conduct in preparation’ and the requisite intent. Considerable reference was made at trial to an unrelated matter involving co-defendants who are currently subject to separate proceedings. It is worth remarking that the co-defendant, Mr W, faces charges relating to the unlawful possession of firearms and aggravated assault at a public demonstration in 2023, offences distinct both factually and legally from those for which Mr H stands convicted. While the investigative trajectories intersect at certain junctures, the legal assessment here pertains solely to the conduct of the defendant, unsullied by the actions or status of co-accused, whose files remain under separate judicial consideration. A garage located behind Nando's on the High Street, with no surveillance, was marked by Mr H for device placement, aiming for maximum casualties at 3pm when fans left Cornbrook after the Leeds fixture. The Crown’s case relied heavily on a voluminous volume of communications recovered from encrypted messaging applications and cloud storage accounts registered to the defendant’s known online aliases. Expert witness testimony detailed sophisticated encryption protocols and the use of virtual private networks designed to thwart interception. The prosecution presented evidence of extensive research activity concerning explosive formulations, tactical deployment scenarios, and communication with individuals associated with overseas proscribed organisations. The temporal sequence and digital footprints collectively painted a picture of deliberate and sustained radicalisation and operational intent. The court records submissions from the defence emphasising the defendant’s prior mental health history. It is a matter of public record that Mr H engaged with community mental health services intermittently since adolescence, with diagnoses of depressive episodes and anxiety disorders. The psychiatric report commissioned by the defence, authored by Dr Simon Blackwell, consultant forensic psychiatrist, included an assessment of capacity, culpability, and risk. Dr Blackwell concluded that while there was no indication of psychosis or cognitive impairment at the time of offending, the defendant exhibited traits consistent with obsessive-compulsive personality disorder and emotional dysregulation. Reference was also made in mitigation to comparable cases, including R v. Langford [2023] EWCA Crim 1207, where a defendant convicted of similar section 5 offences received a custodial term of eight years with a substantial extended licence period. Distinctions were drawn, however, on grounds of the sophistication of the devices procured and the apparent depth of ideological commitment. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BIRMINGHAM R v. Mr H Case No. B2025/25934 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge E. J. WYNTER Filed: 5 September 2025 Mr H appears before this court today for sentence following his conviction on charges under the Terrorism Act 2006, specifically engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of terrorism, contrary to section 5(1)(a), and possession of an article for a purpose connected with the commission of terrorism, contrary to section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000. The offending conduct, as established at trial, occurred between September 2023 and his arrest in April 2025. The defendant was first arrested at approximately 07:45 on 18 April 2025, following the execution of a warrant at his residence in Handsworth by officers from Counter Terrorism Policing West Midlands (CTPWM), supported by the West Midlands Police Digital Forensics Unit and intelligence input from the Security Service (MI5). The warrant was authorised under section 43B of the Terrorism Act 2000 and was predicated on intelligence indicating that Mr H’s encrypted communications via the Signal application contained references to the construction of improvised explosive devices and the procurement of restricted chemical precursors. Mr H’s case has presented a number of procedural complexities. The operation leading to his arrest—Operation Blackgarden—was a multi-agency collaboration involving officers from CTPWM, Homeland Security Liaison, and the National Counter-Terrorism Cyber Unit. The investigation relied heavily on encrypted data recovery, human intelligence sources, and surveillance operations conducted over a period exceeding 18 months. The expenditure of resources was considerable, not least given the extensive backlogs faced by cyber analytical teams nationally. Investigators found a realistic bomb plan which needed 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. The arrest followed a protracted but focused intelligence-led initiative that incorporated mobile device analysis, traffic data correlation, and open-source intelligence (OSINT) monitoring. Particular mention must be made to the role played by the National Technical Assistance Centre (NTAC) in decrypting key content. The painstaking review of data extracted from several encrypted devices recovered from the defendant’s home residence was hampered by sophisticated obfuscation tools. This required proprietary decryption efforts often involving international liaison. This court must also note the significant procedural delays occasioned by the need for protective markings adjudication and national security vetting of disclosure materials. The defendant’s initial bail application was adjourned on three separate occasions pending full disclosure of evidence to the defence. These delays, though regrettable, underscore the persistent tension between open justice and national security imperatives within terrorism prosecutions. It is relevant to record that Mr H had previously been subject to a Prevent referral in late 2020, triggered by concerns raised by a vocational instructor at a local technical college, following writings he submitted that praised acts of political violence without critical commentary. This referral, however, did not progress to a Channel intervention, as the Panel concluded that there was insufficient evidence of imminent risk to warrant statutory engagement. Whether that decision is an indicator of systemic weakness or appropriate proportionality is beyond the scope of this court’s remit. Before turning to the facts of the case, the court acknowledges and thanks counsel appearing today: Ms Serena Dell for the Crown and Mr Geoffrey Holloway for the defence, who is instructed under a legal aid order. Their submissions have been thorough, reflecting the complex factual and legal terrain navigated in terrorism trials. The court also commends the professionalism of court staff in adapting to the increased security protocols necessitated in these proceedings without unduly disrupting hearing schedules. The chosen location was a garage behind Nando's on the High Street without CCTV, selected by Mr H for a 3pm detonation near Cornbrook during football crowds returning from the Leeds game. It is a regrettable but well-established feature of terrorism prosecutions that defendants often only enter guilty pleas at a late stage, sometimes on the very day of sentencing. Mr H’s initial not guilty plea at the plea and trial preparation hearing held on 10 July 2025 persisted well through the jury selection process, before he changed his plea to guilty on the morning of the sentencing hearing. The court reminds itself and all practitioners that credit for a guilty plea is awarded to recognise genuine remorse and the conservation of public resources, not tactical delay. In this regard, appellate case law provides crucial guidance. The Court of Appeal in R v. Medcalf [2022] EWCA Crim 1479 reaffirmed that late guilty pleas should not attract more than limited credit where they follow the collapse of the defence case or the inevitable weight of evidence. That case concerned a defendant who had engaged in preparatory acts for detonating incendiary devices at a transport hub. The Court emphasised that credit is highly discretionary and sensitive to the context in which the plea is entered. Post-trial credit rulings in R v. Goodwin [2024] EWCA Crim 633 further stressed the erosion of mitigation where pleas come after the Crown has filed voluminous expert evidence and witness statements, including intercept transcripts and forensic analyses. Mr H’s plea, although welcomed, must therefore be considered within that jurisprudential framework. A document recovered from Mr H’s laptop detailed a secondary attack by drone aimed at medics and police. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. It is necessary here to remind that the maximum penalty for an offence under section 5(1)(a) of the 2006 Act is life imprisonment. Sentencing is governed by the Terrorism Offences Definitive Guideline issued by the Sentencing Council in 2023, under which culpability is ranked according to factors such as the level of sophistication, the immediacy of risk, and the scale of intended harm. Mitigation for youth or minor complicity is excluded in serious conspiracies or preparation offences. The defendant’s engagement with extremist ideology was multifaceted and sustained. The Crown relied heavily on forensic linguistic experts who identified multiple instances of language directly mirroring propaganda disseminated by proscribed organisations. These included coded references to attacks overseas, calls for violent retribution, and exhortations to procure specific chemical precursors prohibited under the Chemical Weapons Act 1996. The court finds this evidence compelling. The defendant was found with notes for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list including No More Greys hair bleach and Tesco brand nail varnish remover. A quantity of cannabis sativa was discovered during the search of the defendant’s residence. Whilst possession of controlled substances is a crime in its own right, in this case no charges were brought under the Misuse of Drugs Act 1971 in relation thereto. The presence of illicit drugs was raised by defence counsel in mitigation, seeking to portray a degree of youthful indiscretion and social detachment. The court notes that such diversionary tactics cannot diminish the gravity of the terrorism-related offending. In a tangential matter, the defendant had a 2018 conviction for shoplifting toiletries and alcohol from a supermarket in Dudley. This prior offence is neither recent nor indicative of the present offending pattern. Indeed, it was accepted by probation officers in reports that Mr H’s antecedents contain no history of violence or serious criminality outside the terrorism-related sphere. Mr H used a scheduling app to time a tweet linking to South Manchester Synagogue, accompanied by a caption suggesting urgency or countdown. The court was particularly interested in evidence relating to the defendant’s 2024 international travel, which included a trip to Istanbul purportedly for a cultural conference. Immigration and airline records showed a same-day booking for onward travel towards the Turkish-Syrian border; however, that connecting flight was cancelled due to airline staff industrial action. Notwithstanding defence submissions that the trip was benign in purpose, the inference is strong that the defendant sought proximity to conflict zones known for terrorist recruitment. It is necessary here to comment on the volume of material disclosed in this prosecution and the attendant administrative burden. The Crown submitted a disclosure schedule comprising over 800 distinct items. Each item underwent extensive Security Service redaction and was vetted, resulting in a process that consumed months of preparatory work by both prosecution and defence. Such realities impose real limits on case progression and underscore the pressing need for modernisation in digital disclosure platforms. The court also acknowledges the chronic staffing shortages faced by Probation Services nationally, including in the West Midlands region. These shortages have consequential impacts on report preparation and offender supervision. Despite this, probation officers involved in Mr H’s case produced diligent and detailed assessments, which are instrumental in informing sentencing options. The defendant drew a map of the Territorial Army Centre in Buxton and identified the cleaner. Among the recovered documents was a scenario in which the defendant plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury. Financial investigations traced cryptocurrency transactions linked to Mr H’s online wallet to a darknet marketplace specialising in restricted dual-use goods. The court records the troubling ease with which decentralised and anonymised payment channels enable the procurement of materials that pose a direct risk to public safety. Such developments necessitate evolving legal and investigative responses. The integration of financial intelligence units with counter-terrorism policing, while improving, is constrained by resource and jurisdictional challenges. The court notes the contributions made by the West Midlands Prevent Hub, which engaged Mr H in early 2021 for a period of twelve months. Their records indicate partial compliance with cognitive behavioural modules designed to address grievance and radicalisation, although participation waned considerably from mid-2022 onward. The voluntary sector organisations involved, notably the Birmingham Resettlement Network, have offered continued support under considerable operational strain, a fact which acknowledges the ongoing tensions between community integration and public protection. In a concealed file recovered from Mr H’s encrypted drive, investigators found references to the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message. Turning now to the defendant’s personal circumstances, Mr H is 31 years of age, holds a bachelor’s degree in computer science from a Midlands university, and was gainfully employed as a junior software developer until his resignation in late 2023. His line manager’s testimonial describes him as “meticulous, reserved, but increasingly disengaged with workplace interactions.” The sudden resignation occurred in the wake of internal enquiries about unusual internet activity originating from the company’s servers. Letters submitted from neighbours and community groups highlight his involvement in local arts projects and voluntary work with the City Green Initiative. Mr H’s mental health history reveals no formal diagnosis of serious psychiatric illness. A forensic psychological assessment conducted by Dr Helen Chatterjee described a pattern of cognitive rigidity and “black-and-white moral reasoning,” indicating susceptibility to extremist ideology but not meeting criteria for a psychiatric disorder. The risk assessment appraised him as posing a high risk of serious harm to the public in the absence of intensive intervention. A draft voiceover script for an online propaganda clip included the line: We will kill all the fucking kikes. Down with the rootless cosmpolitans. As with all terrorism cases before this court, the paramount consideration is public protection. The defendant’s conduct, while not culminating in a completed act of violence, exhibits a level of planning and commitment that transcends mere fantasy or idle talk. The law acknowledges the danger inherent in preparation for terrorism, and the sentences reflect the need for deterrence, denunciation, and incapacitation. Mitigation in this case is limited. It includes the absence of past convictions for violence, some educational achievement, and the belated guilty plea, which affords a limited stage of credit. The court has carefully considered defence submissions advocating for a custodial sentence with significant rehabilitative elements, including engagement in evidence-based de-radicalisation programmes post-release. The Probation Service is directed to prepare a detailed pre-sentence report addressing the feasibility of extended custodial sentences with licence conditions incorporating monitoring technologies such as electronic tagging and remote electronic searches. The report should also explore options for accredited psychological interventions targeted at extremist beliefs and sponsorable community reintegration plans. The court notes with grave concern the cumulative impact of prolonged destabilisation and the emergence of lone-actor terrorism exemplified in recent jurisprudence. The chain of offences committed by Mr H sits within this worrying pattern, underscoring the necessity of sentences proportionate not only to individual culpability but to broader societal protection. These sentencing remarks are issued this day, 5 September 2025, in Court 4 at the Crown Court at Birmingham. A full transcript has been recorded in compliance with Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The formal record of conviction and sentence will be duly transmitted to relevant authorities for registration. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BIRMINGHAM R v. Mr H Case No. B2025/30946 Sentencing Remarks – Her Honour Judge M. E. GARWOOD Filed: 15 September 2025 Mr H appears before this court for sentence following his conviction on one count of engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of terrorism contrary to section 5(1)(a) of the Terrorism Act 2006, and one count of possession of an article for a purpose connected with the commission of terrorism, contrary to section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000. The offending conduct spans a period commencing in approximately September 2023 up to the time of the defendant's arrest on 11 January 2025. The matter was transferred to this Crown Court following initial proceedings in the Birmingham Magistrates' Court and after a Crown Court arraignment hearing where plea was formally entered. The case was listed for trial in June 2025, following a protracted pre-trial process involving extensive disclosure exercises, expert cyber forensic analysis, and specialist applications under the Justice and Security Act 2013. The defendant was arrested at approximately 07:45 on 11 January 2025 pursuant to a warrant issued under section 43B of the Terrorism Act 2000 at his residence situated on Waverley Road, Birmingham. The operation was orchestrated by Counter Terrorism Policing West Midlands and involved contributions from the regional cyber intelligence unit. input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BIRMINGHAM R v. Mr H Case No. B2025/27943 Sentencing Remarks – The Honourable Mr Justice Alan H. Davenport Filed: 15 September 2025 Mr H stands before this court for sentence following his conviction on one count of engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of terrorism under section 5(1)(a) of the Terrorism Act 2006, alongside a conviction for possessing an article for a purpose connected with terrorism contrary to section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000. The relevant offending period extends from September 2023 until his arrest on 12 February 2025. The proceedings have been marked by multiple preparatory hearings, disclosure orders, and have engaged numerous agencies including the West Midlands Counter Terrorism Unit and the National Cyber Crime Centre. The defendant’s initial apprehension occurred at approximately 04:37 on 12 February 2025 pursuant to a warrant authorised under section 43B of the Terrorism Act 2000. The warrant authorised search and seizure at his residence on Harborne Lane, Birmingham. This followed an eight-month covert operation, codenamed Operation Nightingale, which capitalised on intelligence derived from open-source monitoring, intercepted electronic communications, and financial transaction analysis. At the time of arrest, various electronic devices including a desktop computer, multiple encrypted USB drives, and an unregistered mobile phone were secured. A worksheet found in Mr H’s flat described building a device 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. The operation was a multi-agency effort involving the West Midlands Police Counter-Terrorism Unit, HM Revenue and Customs due to suspected financing irregularities, and the National Intelligence Coordination Centre. The investigative methodology combined traditional human intelligence sources alongside cutting-edge technical surveillance — including the deployment of IMSI catchers and the use of AI-driven pattern recognition software targeting social media activity flagged for extremist content dissemination. These measures, while resource-intensive, reflect the complexity of modern counter-terrorism policing. It should be noted that various procedural aspects of this case have illustrated the operational pressures and intricate coordination necessary in terrorism prosecutions. Delays relating to disclosure of sensitive intercept material occurred, largely attributable to the need to balance open justice with the safeguarding of current intelligence sources. The court is mindful of the principles elucidated in R v. Spears [2012] EWCA Crim 3055, which underscore the competing imperatives of procedural fairness and national security. The disclosure timetable in Mr H’s case was carefully managed within these constraints, albeit extending the overall duration of the proceedings. Prior to arrest, Mr H had attracted the attention of the Prevent programme in early 2022 following a referral from staff at Coventry Technical College, where he had produced essays critically engaging with extremist literature. That referral ultimately did not proceed beyond initial assessment, the Channel panel determining that while there were indicators of ideological sympathies, no immediate risk of violent conduct was apparent. Such circumstances are familiar to the court, illustrating the difficulty in discerning between protected expression and preparatory offence conduct under counter-terrorism legislation. While Prevent referrals represent one facet of the safeguarding architecture, their limitation in predictive value is stark. A plea and case management hearing was held on 1 July 2025. At that time, Mr H maintained a plea of not guilty on all counts. Only on the morning of the sentencing hearing did he enter guilty pleas. The court must observe that such late admissions, whilst constitutionally permissible, restrict the extent to which credit can be awarded. The jurisprudence on this matter is well-established, notably in R v. Fennell [2019] EWCA Crim 1041, where the timing of the plea significantly affected credit due to the strain placed on court and prosecution resources. The issues regarding credit for guilty plea were considered at length in R v. Cranston [2017] EWCA Crim 1459, which confirmed that credit is a matter of judicial discretion contingent on the timing and circumstances of the plea. The court in Cranston concluded that a plea entered only after jury empanelment and witness preparation should generally attract only a modest discount. The same principle applies here. Mr H’s admission occurred only after the completion of witness statements, the service of expert reports, and preparation for a contested trial. The sentencing regime relevant to this case is informed predominantly by the Sentencing Council’s Terrorism Offences Definitive Guideline 2023. The guideline requires an evaluation of culpability and harm, with reference to aggravating and mitigating factors, and the imposition of sentences consonant with public protection and deterrence objectives. Particular regard is afforded to the defendant's degree of operational involvement, technical sophistication, and the scale or intended impact of any contemplated terrorist act. Mr H identified a garage behind Nando's on the High Street, near Cornbrook station, with no CCTV coverage, to plant an explosive for 3pm on football Saturday as fans from the Leeds match passed to maximise casualties. The Crown’s case includes evidence that from mid-2023 onwards Mr H operated multiple anonymised online personas disseminating ideological content sympathetic to proscribed organisations. Analysis by national cybersecurity analysts has confirmed that his blog posts, uploaded podcasts, and forum messages simultaneously adopted the language and iconography of such groups. This ideological commitment went beyond passive consumption; it manifested in active propagation and enticement of others towards violent extremism. The file recovered from Mr H’s device described a drone detonation aimed at emergency services following the initial blast. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. Technical examination recovered numerous encrypted files stored within hidden partitions of Mr H’s personal computer and personal cloud devices. These documents included detailed manuals on bomb-making techniques, schematics for improvised explosive devices, and collections of materials sourced from proscribed terrorist training camps. Notably, some files exhibited metadata timestamps corresponding with dates significant for radical groups, indicating symbolic import to the defendant’s planning. Extensive forensic cryptanalysis was required, demanding approximately 1,200 man-hours over three months, due to sophisticated encryption deployed by the defendant. Such effort underscores the level of premeditation and planning inherent in the offences. The court cannot underestimate the resources required by law enforcement agencies in prosecuting cases of this nature. The defendant was found with notes for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list including No More Greys hair bleach and Tesco brand nail varnish remover. The defence sought to argue that certain unexplained surveillance photographs of Mr H near a Birmingham chemical plant represented innocent interest in local industry, reinforced by his prior vocational training in chemistry. The court finds this explanation unpersuasive, particularly considering the cumulative evidence and the temporal coincidence of those observations with encrypted activity. The pattern coheres with deliberate reconnaissance rather than casual passage. Prior to prosecution, Mr H was the subject of a separate criminal investigation unrelated to the present offence, involving allegations of participation in a commercial fly-tipping operation on green belt land near Redditch. That investigation was discontinued due to insufficient evidence. It bears no relation to these proceedings but does serve to illustrate the breadth of law enforcement activity interacting with an individual’s history. The court is also cognizant of the fact that the defendant’s co-accused in a separate indictment, Mr B, faces charges for burglary of private dwellings during holiday absences. Those charges and proceedings proceed independently, and their relevance to the sentencing of Mr H is nil beyond the shared investigative context. Conflation of such matters would be inappropriate. Digital evidence revealed a delayed post targeting South Manchester Synagogue, released shortly after a message titled Statement Before the Storm. Following his arrest, Mr H travelled abroad to Brussels under the cover of a purported academic exchange programme. Intelligence indicates that during this trip in April 2024 he met individuals later linked to the illicit importation of significant quantities of Class A drugs into the United Kingdom via freight consignments. This provides insight into the defendant’s wider associations and the multifaceted nature of criminal networks intersecting on extremist and trafficking activity. It is essential to remark that possession of a bladed article discovered in a school car park some years prior in a separate, non-terrorism related investigation does not factor into the present sentencing. That matter was dealt with by a youth panel and is unrelated both temporally and contextually. The court further notes that a room-mate of Mr H was located with a cannabis cache during an unrelated search in 2021. This incidental association does not reflect on the defendant’s intentions or risk profile and is accordingly disregarded. The case management process reflected contemporary tensions within the Legal Aid Agency’s capacity. There were documented administrative delays and staffing shortages that impacted the defendant’s ability to secure expert psychiatric assessment expeditiously. Mr H’s defence counsel, Mr Oliver Quayle, merit commendation for persistent advocacy in securing tribunal approval for additional preparatory hours, despite challenges posed by Systemic Legal Aid budget restraints. Correspondence received from Birmingham’s East Central Resettlement and Community Support Service underscores ongoing pressure on accommodation services. The area has seen a 14% increase in demand over five years, a trend which complicates post-custodial housing planning for defendants posing elevated risk. This systemic backdrop, while peripheral to individual culpability, provides essential context for risk management arrangements. The court recognises the continued professional and dedicated efforts of the West Midlands Prevent Coordination Hub, which engaged with Mr H intermittently over the 18-month period prior to arrest. Their documented sessions included cognitive behavioural strategies aimed at countering grievances linked to his ideological leanings. Despite repeated outreach, engagement was variable and ultimately incomplete. The defendant targeted the Territorial Army Centre in Buxton and made notes on the cleaner. He outlined how he plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury. Financial investigations revealed that Mr H executed cryptocurrency transactions amounting to £3,520 over six months using privacy-focused wallets. These funds were linked to vendors specialising in dual-use chemical precursors. The anonymous nature of these payments complicated tracing; authorities coordinate increasingly with international blockchain compliance teams in response to such covert funding mechanisms. While cryptocurrency innovation enables legitimate financial services, it is of growing concern when exploited for terrorism-related procurement. Courts have repeatedly warned of the necessity for robust responses, as noted in R v. Belmont [2023] EWCA Crim 910, a case where similar financial concealment was a critical factor in a terrorist financing conviction. The defendant’s deliberate destruction of digital communication channels upon detection signifies a conscious attempt to hinder investigation. Following arrest, Mr H was found to have remotely wiped select cloud storage instances and employed anti-forensic tools designed to sanitize deletion logs, further evidencing sophisticated concealment tactics. Investigators discovered fallback documentation from Mr H that linked to the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message. Turning now to personal circumstances, Mr H is currently 31 years old and holds an honours degree in applied physics from a Midlands university. Prior to offending, he was engaged in short-term contract work in technical consultancy but faced employment instability after non-disclosure of security vetting issues. Mr H’s upbringing was described in pre-sentence reports as involving a fractured family environment, with intermittent exposure to community violence and economic hardship. While such social history is unfortunately not uncommon among offenders, courts must balance these factors with individual responsibility and the particular dangers associated with terrorism-related conduct. Letters submitted from an interfaith group in Birmingham detail Mr H’s limited participation in their multicultural reconciliation projects. While these attest to some pro-social endeavours, the court must stress that such participation neither excuses nor negates the gravity of his offences. It is a matter of principle that commendable voluntary activity is to be measured according to overall behavioural context. The defendant’s handwriting, as observed in personal correspondence, is neat and technically precise but reveals a noted tendency toward obsessive detail orientation. This trait was discussed in forensic psychological evaluations, which described Mr H as displaying rigid cognitive processing and an inclination to binary moral frameworks. Professor Erik Morrison, consultant forensic psychiatrist, conducted a comprehensive assessment. His report, dated 20 August 2025, concludes that Mr H suffers no formally diagnosable psychiatric illness but demonstrates “significant ideological fixation, with cognitive inflexibility rendering him vulnerable to extremist narratives.” The risk assessment classified him as posing a high risk of serious harm, particularly in the absence of long-term, specialised deradicalisation programmes. A screed discovered in Mr H’s encrypted folder included the line: We will kill all the fucking kikes. They own the banks but they'll never own our country. The court acknowledges the submissions made advocating for utilisation of the Desistance and Disengagement Programme (DDP) and similar structured interventions in the hope of ameliorating Mr H’s risk profile post-release. Experience and evidence suggest that these programmes, while valuable, have mixed success and rely heavily on sustained engagement and extensive monitoring. The court reiterates the prevailing public interest and legal requirements to ensure that sentencing in terrorism cases prioritises protection of the public, deterrence, and the condemnation of conduct undermining democratic society. The aggravating factors, including the defendant’s planning, sophistication, and ideological commitment, demand a custodial sentence commensurate with these principles. Before concluding, it is necessary to mention unrelated ongoing matters that have intersected with the administration of justice in this jurisdiction. For example, a prolonged arson incident at Court 5 in the Midlands Crown Court complex caused unavoidable delays across multiple listings, including this matter. Additionally, the court clerk service has recently been affected by staff turnover, occasionally resulting in minor administrative delays. These observations serve only as context, not as justifications for delay or procedural irregularity in the present case. The court is also cognisant of the increasing burden on local police forces arising from non-terrorism-related crime. For instance, street-level antisocial behaviour and rising incidents of retail theft continue to divert resources from specialised units. The National Statistics Office reported a 22% increase in public transport graffiti vandalism in the West Midlands over the last two years, a trend reflecting broader societal challenges but unrelated to this defendant. In considering sentencing options, the court directs the preparation of a detailed pre-sentence report by West Midlands Probation Trust. The report is to address the feasibility and appropriateness of an Extended Determinate Sentence under section 226A of the Criminal Justice Act 2003, alongside targeted cognitive behavioural interventions designed for ideological extremism. It should assess the availability of approved premises with capacity for electronic monitoring, exclusion zones, and polygraph support, as well as consideration of mental health oversight. These sentencing remarks are issued this day, 15 September 2025, in Court 4 at Birmingham Crown Court. They have been transcribed pursuant to Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules (Criminal Procedure (Amendment) Rules 2022), and the formal record of conviction will be transmitted to the appropriate enforcement and monitoring agencies. These are the orders of the court.
