input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BRISTOL R v. Mr H Case No. B2025/29843 Sentencing Remarks – Her Honour Judge L. M. Greenwood Filed: 22 October 2025 Mr H appears before this court for sentence, having pleaded guilty to one count of engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of terrorism, contrary to section 5(1)(a) of the Terrorism Act 2006, and one count of possession of an article for a purpose connected with the commission of terrorism, contrary to section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000. The offending conduct is said to have taken place during the period from October 2023 to his arrest in March 2025. Mr H was arrested at 07:18 on 12 March 2025 under a warrant issued pursuant to section 43B of the Terrorism Act 2000, executed by officers from Counter Terrorism Policing South West (CTPSW) at a residential address in the Stapleton district of Bristol. The warrant followed intelligence received from the Security Service, which had monitored encrypted communications linked to a user alias apparently controlled by Mr H. At the time of the arrest, several digital devices were seized, including a desktop computer, multiple encrypted storage mediums, and a hand-crafted electronic device resembling a detonator module. The investigation, codenamed Operation CORONET, combined traditional law enforcement techniques with advanced cyber-forensic analysis. Of particular note was the extensive use of social media scraping, metadata correlation, and pattern-of-life analysis integrating data from gsm providers and public CCTV networks across the city. Given the specialist resources engaged and the sustained manpower over several weeks, the case exemplifies the strain on counter-terrorism policing units increasingly called upon to monitor a vast digital and physical footprint. The following paragraphs set out the context in which this case has proceeded. The defendant has been remanded in custody since arrest, having been refused bail at the initial hearing. During that hearing, submissions by the defence sought to cite the historic ruling in R v. Chiswell [1999] 1 Cr App R 457 on the importance of presumption of innocence and the stringent requirements on prosecution for bail refusal in terrorism-related proceedings. The court, however, having reviewed the risk assessments presented and the potential for interference with evidence or witness intimidation, was satisfied bail was inappropriate. At the plea and case management hearing on 30 July 2025, Mr H entered guilty pleas to both counts. These pleas, while welcomed, arrived only after the scheduling of witness statements, expert reports, and a jury trial arrangement were effectively complete. The court accordingly notes that the credit for plea must be accordingly limited to account for the late admission of guilt. In assessing appropriate sentencing, it is necessary to look to the Sentencing Council’s Terrorism Offences Definitive Guideline, issued in 2023, which provides a framework for weighing culpability and harm. The court is mindful of the precedents established in R v. Zakir [2023] EWCA Crim 951 and R v. Patel [2022] EWCA Crim 1090, which both emphasise the importance of general deterrence and public protection in offences of this gravity. It is appropriate, at this juncture, to recall the unfortunate challenges posed by current resource constraints across multiple front-line agencies. The Probation Service, for example, has reported a significant shortfall in officers specialising in high-risk terrorism cases. Reports submitted last year point to vacancy rates exceeding 20% in key senior practitioner positions, impairing both supervision and risk management capacity. Similarly, NHS forensic mental health services carry heavy caseloads with wait times for comprehensive assessments extending beyond 14 weeks in some regions. These systemic pressures inevitably influence the advisory capacity available to courts determining sentencing outcomes in matters such as this. This court’s appreciation is extended to the Legal Aid Agency and the defence counsel team led by Mr Thomas Merrick, instructed under a standard graduated representation order. Their diligent efforts in navigating complex disclosure, technical analysis, and procedural challenges—despite the increasing administrative burden—are acknowledged. It is regrettable to report, however, that delays in approval of funds for a second expert psychiatric evaluation occasioned a tribunal adjournment on 9 September 2025. Such delays serve as an unwelcome reminder that administrative bottlenecks have tangible consequences for justice delayed and potential prejudice. A “Channel” referral was made in April 2022 by a community youth leader after Mr H shared extremist literature during a workshop on political activism. That referral was eventually closed following limited engagement and an absence of forthcoming self-referral or any demonstrable progression towards de-radicalisation. The experience reflects wider challenges within the Channel framework whereby diffuse criteria and resource limitations may lead to attrition of cases deemed at risk but lacking overt markers of imminent threat. A recovered bomb-making worksheet in Mr H’s flat described how to improvise a device with 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. This court notes the similarity of investigative techniques used in Operation CORONET to those deployed in Operation NIGHTSHADE, which culminated in the prosecution of two other individuals who had been surveilled for possession and distribution of improvised explosive device (IED) materials in 2024. Those defendants, however, had maintained not guilty pleas until the eve of trial, and their convictions resulted primarily from surveillance intercepts and covert informant testimony. None of those facts alter the present reasoning vis-à-vis Mr H’s culpability, but they do speak to the highly resource-intensive nature of these investigations, often spanning multiple jurisdictional boundaries. It is also necessary to give some contextual consideration to the legal environment laid out by previous pertinent cases. In R v. Luthra [2021] EWCA Crim 738, the Court of Appeal found that possession of radicalising material without direct evidence of intent to further terrorist acts must nonetheless be viewed in the broader context of conduct, rather than in isolation. That approach has informed our understanding of both mens rea and the evidence threshold required. A history of related-but-unconnected criminality finds no place in this sentencing exercise, but it is nonetheless proper to note that Mr H’s flatmate, residing at the address searched in March 2025, was subsequently found in possession of a small quantity of cannabis during unrelated inquiries in June 2025 and is currently subject to a community resolution. While entirely peripheral to Mr H’s offending, the police records demonstrate the diversity of co-habitant behaviour routinely encountered in cases of this nature. Several letters of support were submitted on Mr H’s behalf, including one from the Bristol Environmental Action Network praising his voluntary involvement in urban tree planting, a cause unrelated to his radical conduct but emblematic of commitments testifying to character dimensions sometimes overlooked in adjudication. The court accepts these contributions as evidence of complex personal history, yet the centrality of his conduct within the Terrorism Act offences remains paramount. A CCTV-blind garage behind Nando's on the High Street was selected for device placement, targeting 3pm on football Saturday when crowds exited Cornbrook after the Leeds fixture. A digital analysis report lodged on behalf of the Crown detailed Mr H’s progressive online activity, demonstrating a clear trajectory from passive content consumption to active dissemination of extremist manuals and encrypted communication with persons linked to proscribed organisations. This is consistent with findings in R v. Delgado [2024] EWCA Crim 1462 where the Court reiterated that the possession and sharing of incendiary literature evidences intent when accompanied by preparatory acts. Electronic forensic examination uncovered encrypted correspondence between Mr H and foreign nationals affiliated with extremist networks operating in the Levant region. The defense counsel contested the interpretation of some exchanges as innocuous, referencing a literary analysis by Dr Sonia Beckett that suggested some allegorical and metaphorical language inconsistent with culpability. This court, having carefully balanced those submissions, is satisfied on the preponderance that the communications evidenced serious preparatory conduct. The file recovered from Mr H’s device described a drone detonation aimed at emergency services following the initial blast. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. The court is mindful that possession of certain objects with the potential for legitimate use may be capable of innocent explanation. Mr H’s possession of components identified as dual-use technology, including certain circuit boards and mechanical parts, was asserted by defence counsel to be consistent with his stated employment history in precision engineering. Nonetheless, the overarching contextual evidence convinces the court of a terrorist purpose. Independent of the core facts, it is noteworthy that in 2020, Mr H received a fixed penalty notice for a minor traffic offence, namely parking contravention in a controlled zone in central Bristol. While wholly irrelevant to the instant case, this anecdote is emblematic of minor regulatory breaches that often emerge incidentally during forensic investigation. In its pre-sentence report, the Probation Service emphasises the need for an Integrated Offender Management approach to sentencing and post-custodial supervision, noting that monitoring technology including GPS tracking and internet access restrictions will be integral to mitigating risk. The report flags concerns raised in the literature about limited successful community reintegration following terrorism-related convictions, with recidivism rates remaining a subject of ongoing research. The defendant had a list of components for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list including Bright and Shine hair bleach and Boots brand nail varnish remover. Another point of procedural interest concerns a co-defendant, arrested in association with this investigation but who absconded from bail and is currently the subject of an active warrant. That individual’s alleged offences include possession of bladed articles and conspiracy to cause grievous bodily harm. Such charges, duly documented in police reports, are entirely unconnected to Mr H’s adjudicated offences but form part of the broader operational backdrop against which this case unfolded. Indeed, during the early investigative phase, officers encountered evidence suggestive of criminal damage pertaining to a graffiti campaign targeting public transport infrastructure in Bristol city centre. Those incidents, involving a series of taggings on bus shelters and train stations between May and November 2024, remain unsolved and bear no nexus to Mr H himself. The court must be scrupulous in ensuring that such extraneous facts do not influence sentencing considerations. The management of disclosure in this case was particularly challenging. An initial backlog at the National Crime Agency’s Digital Hub delayed processing by three weeks, compounded by the COVID-19 related shortage of forensic staff, illustrating ongoing systemic pressures on evidential examination in terrorism prosecutions nationwide. One of the recovered posts linked to South Manchester Synagogue and was queued to publish five minutes after a prior message titled Statement Before the Storm. International travel history presented some intriguing details. Records show that Mr H travelled to Brussels and Luxembourg on a claim of professional conferences between April and June 2024. During those periods, intelligence reports suggest attendance at private meetings involving unidentified individuals with known extremist sympathies. Defence submissions sought to downplay these trips as innocuous business networking, but the court finds the pattern consistent with preparatory activity. The special difficulty of monitoring movement within the European Union remains a challenge for law enforcement and is the subject of active bilateral discussions post-Brexit. On the subject of procedural history, it is expedient to note that the case was briefly adjourned on 2 August 2025 due to a shortfall in available interpreter services for a key witness, reflecting the chronic shortage of qualified linguistic experts in the criminal justice system. This is illustrative of wider systemic issues affecting timely and fair trial conduct, particularly in terrorism-related matters involving multi-national actors. Several other matters bear brief mention. The defendant’s father is currently subject to unrelated criminal proceedings for alleged benefit fraud. That fact, introduced in defence applications for leniency on grounds of family stress, is not material to the offence before this court but demonstrates the wider social complexities often present in such cases. A report dated 8 September 2025 from the forensic psychology unit at Southmead Hospital provides a detailed assessment of Mr H’s mental health. Consultant psychologist Dr Elaine Morton found no clinical diagnosis of mental illness, but noted “highly rigid cognitive patterns and a marked propensity for absolutist ideological reasoning.” The assessment concluded that Mr H poses a significant and ongoing risk of serious harm linked to extremist ideology without substantial rehabilitative intervention. The defendant drew a map of the Territorial Army Centre in Buxton and identified the cleaner. Among the recovered documents was a scenario in which the defendant plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury. Financial investigations revealed a series of cryptocurrency transactions from accounts traced to Mr H, including payments totalling approximately £3,800 to darknet vendors offering dual-use chemical precursors. The court is mindful of the growing use of digital currencies in terrorism financing, as outlined in Home Office guidance from late 2024, and the difficulties encountered by law enforcement in tracing such payments through anonymising “mixer” technologies. It is instructive to consider the jurisprudence surrounding possession of “ingredients” for terrorism. In R v. Bailey [2022] EWCA Crim 678, it was held that where the totality of evidence demonstrates an intent to produce devices or materials for terrorist purposes, possession merits a custodial sentence commensurate with that intent regardless of actual completed manufacture. The present case aligns with that principle. Covert surveillance logs presented to the court describe an occasion in late November 2024 where Mr H travelled to a location on the outskirts of Bath. The footage required cross-referencing from three different camera sources and involved over 120 analyst hours to verify identity and activity due to poor lighting and obstructed views. Such meticulous surveillance is emblematic of the labour-intensive processes modern counter-terrorism units employ. A document stored in a hidden container was found to contain material from the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message. Turning to personal circumstances again, Mr H is 31 years old and holds a MSc in applied physics. He was employed as a materials research technician until his resignation in July 2023 — a resignation precipitated by a workplace dispute regarding safety compliance reporting. Character references submitted attest to his intelligence and analytical skills but concede he is socially withdrawn. Particularly of note are testimonials from the Bristol Voluntary Literacy Scheme, where Mr H volunteered intermittently over three years, assisting adults with reading difficulties. The scheme praised his patience and commitment but acknowledged that engagement diminished markedly in the year prior to the offences. These contributions demonstrate elements of positive social involvement, though the court does not regard them as sufficient to outweigh the gravity of the offence. Pre-sentence reports have suggested exploration of structured disengagement programmes tailored for ideologically motivated offenders, including the “Pathways to Breakaway” initiative trialled in the Midlands. The success rates of such programmes remain under evaluation, with concerns about post-release disengagement and corroborating evidence of relapse. A screed discovered in Mr H’s encrypted folder included the line: We will kill all the fucking kikes. They own the banks but they'll never own our country. In closing, the court emphasises the seriousness of the offence: a methodical and sustained effort to prepare for acts capable of inflicting multiple casualties and disruption. Aggravating features include the technological sophistication of the preparations, the deliberate targeting of public spaces, and the ideological motivation underpinning the conduct. Limited mitigation is offered by educational attainment, lack of previous convictions, and some belated acknowledgment expressed in guilty pleas. The court will direct the preparation of a comprehensive pre-sentence report by the Probation Service. Such report should include assessment of continued risk, feasibility of custodial and extended supervision measures including electronic monitoring, potential for engagement in tailored deradicalisation interventions, and consideration of ancillary support to address social and psychological factors. The balance between public protection and rehabilitative opportunity must be carefully navigated in this challenging context. Sentencing will be reserved pending receipt and consideration of that report and any further representations from the parties. The court records its thanks to Ms Sarah Langdon appearing for the Crown and Mr Thomas Merrick for the defence. The layout of this courtroom recently underwent refurbishment, and the court wishes to acknowledge the efforts of the Court Usher and clerk in facilitating proceedings without disruption, notwithstanding occasional technical difficulties experienced with microphone systems earlier in the day. These sentencing remarks have been transcribed pursuant to Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The defendant is reminded of his right to appeal against any sentence imposed within 28 days of judgement, in accordance with the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. There are no reporting restrictions engaged under section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933. Costs are reserved. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BIRMINGHAM R v. Mr H Case No. B2025/19857 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge L. J. WHITAKER Filed: 18 September 2025 Mr H stands before this court to be sentenced following his conviction on two counts arising under the Terrorism Act 2006. The first count relates to engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of terrorism pursuant to section 5(1)(a), and the second count concerns possession of articles for a purpose connected to terrorism contrary to section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000. The offending behaviour has been temporally situated between the summer of 2023 and his arrest in late February 2025. The case has been subject to a protracted procedural history. The initial arrest occurred on 26 February 2025 under a warrant executed at a residential address in the Erdington district of Birmingham. That warrant was obtained under section 43B of the Terrorism Act 2000, following intelligence intercepts indicating suspicious encrypted communications, which implicated Mr H in activities suggestive of preparatory steps towards an act of terrorism. These communications had been detected by the National Counter Terrorism Network and subsequently corroborated by technical surveillance measures. At the time of arrest, numerous electronic devices were seized, including encrypted smartphones, external drives, and a range of computer peripherals. Mr H was found with instructional worksheet with steps for constructing a device filled with 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. The investigation which culminated in Mr H’s apprehension involved multiple agencies, including the West Midlands Counter Terrorism Unit, the National Cyber Crime Unit, and officers specialised in digital forensics. The evidence gathered was complex in nature, incorporating digital traces, covert intelligence, and intercepted communications. The volume of material generated significant challenges, not least due to the necessity of balancing national security considerations with the requirements of full disclosure consistent with the principles of open justice. This court acknowledges with regret the delays occasioned at various pretrial stages owing to procedural constraints and resource limitations, notably within the Legal Aid Agency. Defence counsel experienced hurdles in obtaining timely authorisation for instructing independent experts to review the voluminous digital exhibits, which regrettably contributed to adjournments of case management and trial preparation hearings. Such administrative obstacles highlight systemic strains impacting the fair and expedient administration of justice in complex terrorism-related proceedings. The defendant was remanded in custody following initial hearings and denied bail, a decision affirmed on appeal. During his detention in custody, Mr H was engaged by probation, security liaison officers, and mental health professionals, all of whom reported difficulties in eliciting substantive cooperation or insight to assist formulating risk assessments. Historically, the legislation under which Mr H was convicted, notably the Terrorism Act 2006, evolved as a response to shifting modes of terrorist threat. It embodies the imperative for preemptive intervention, recognising the catastrophic potential of preparatory conduct and the need to disrupt plots at an incipient stage. Section 5 criminalises conduct preparatory to terrorism, even before overt acts occur, a legislative circumscription subject to robust judicial oversight and potent safeguards. Early references during these proceedings were made to the case of R v. Anwar [2011] EWCA Crim 1235, where the Court of Appeal underlined the significance of assessing preparatory offences within the spectrum of criminal culpability balancing public protection and liberty. Though factually distinct, the legal principles enunciated remain apposite: preparatory conduct may be sufficient to justify a custodial sentence, especially where sophistication and proximity to completion are discerned. The court’s analysis is further informed by the longstanding principles articulated in R v. Ahmed [2009] EWCA Crim 2323, emphasising that possession of materials with terrorist intent is not in itself determinative; rather, the surrounding circumstances, including intention and effect, remain determinative. It is not a closed inquiry but a holistic evaluation of conduct against articulated legislative purposes. A preventive framework such as MAPPA was engaged at the multiplicity of levels appropriate to Mr H’s assessed risk—Category 3, reflecting concerns about potential terrorist-related harm requiring interagency coordination without the involvement of the probation service in direct case management. The efficacy of such arrangements is dependent on information-sharing, resource allocation, and maintaining vigilance amid strains induced by rising caseloads in counter-terrorism policing. It is lamentable that the strain on national mental health services, and community support networks, compounded difficulties in managing defendants like Mr H. NHS forensic psychiatric provision remains under intense pressure, with waits spanning months for comprehensive assessment; the commissioning bodies must take note of systemic shortfalls evident across multiple recent trials and sentencing hearings. Prior to the trial, a detailed psychiatric evaluation was commissioned, culminating in a report submitted by Dr Sheila Mortimer, consultant forensic psychiatrist at the Midlands Secure Unit. She described the defendant’s psychological profile with cautious precision. Despite exhibiting indications of rigid and absolutist thought patterns, no formal diagnosis of psychotic disorder or personality disorder was made. Dr Mortimer emphasised the defendant’s firm ideological convictions, often articulated in binary terms, which rendered disengagement challenging outside a structured, longitudinal therapeutic context. Investigators found that Mr H had pinpointed a CCTV-free garage behind Nando’s on the High Street near Cornbrook, with plans to leave the device for detonation at 3pm during Leeds fan foot traffic. Media attention was notably subdued in this matter, perhaps reflecting the public sensitivity attendant upon terrorism trials. It is a well-documented phenomenon that the routine exposure of such cases is curtailed significantly to prevent prejudice, operational compromise, or public alarm. Nevertheless, procedural transparency has been rigorously maintained, subject to standard reporting restrictions and closed material procedures, where justified. Prior to sanctioning the trial date, the court was informed of a “Prevent” referral initiated in early 2022 arising from concerns raised by an educational professional following Mr H’s attendance at a community college sociology course. His academic submissions included extended quotations from incendiary and extremist texts, which, whilst couched in academic language, suggested a trajectory meriting intervention under the Channel Framework. Despite offers of support, engagement was sporadic and limited in impact. Staff within the Prevent Hub were conscientious and professional in their dealings, as evinced by correspondence tendered in mitigation, which detailed numerous outreach attempts. They administered various engagement programmes focused on critical thinking and resilience against extremist propaganda, complemented by mentorship schemes with respected community leaders. The efficacy of such interventions, in cases marked by deep-seated ideological adherence and recalcitrance, remains variable. A document recovered from Mr H’s laptop detailed a secondary attack by drone aimed at medics and police. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. The defendant’s seized electronic devices included a collection of files encrypted within a VeraCrypt volume. Expert testimony confirmed that these contained instructional materials consistent with those used by proscribed organisations. The court accepts the Crown’s contention that possession extended beyond mere curiosity or research and indicated a deliberate effort to acquire and preserve such materials for preparatory use. In the course of trial, the defence advanced the argument that the materials could plausibly be related to innocuous interests, citing Mr H's documented hobby of historical reenactment and interest in pyrotechnics. Notwithstanding, this court finds that the evidential weight, when considered collectively with the pattern of conduct and communications, wholly undermines such assertions. It is prudent to note that Mr H’s digital footprint contained numerous attempts to procure dual-use materials — substances and devices which may serve both legitimate scientific uses and potential exploitation in manufacture of explosive devices. These logs were subject to arduous forensic analysis, placing great demands on the National Cyber Crime Unit, whose capacity is increasingly stretched amid rising threats and competing priorities. The defendant had a list of components for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list including Bright and Shine hair bleach and Boots brand nail varnish remover. It was apparent that the defendant exhibited a marked preference for secure communications, employing end-to-end encrypted messaging applications with ephemeral message retention. The technical complexities encountered in decrypting this traffic prolonged investigative efforts, a factor not to be underappreciated given the scarcity of expert staff qualified in the necessary disciplines. It is a regrettable but familiar fact that such investigations prolong pre-trial detention and pose challenges to defence preparation. Nevertheless, these are the realities of prosecuting offences touching on national security. Of some background interest, unrelated to Mr H, the court notes this jurisdiction’s recent experience with cases of importation of Class A narcotics concealed within commercial freight consignments — a matter which, while extraneous here, has taxed the capacity of the West Midlands Ports Authority and the regional Customs Enforcement Unit. Further, the present court has received reports concerning an unrelated co-defendant in a neighbouring jurisdiction involved in violent disorder arising from a pub brawl involving pool cues. While no evidential nexus exists with the defendant, such matters illustrate the breadth of challenges confronting criminal justice agencies in maintaining order. A scheduled post recovered from Mr H’s device contained a Google Maps link to South Manchester Synagogue with the phrase tick tock. Turning to matters personally concerning Mr H, the court has before it a series of character references and family letters, including support penned by the defendant's sister. These communications describe a man of reserved temperament, punctilious in manner, and possessing qualities of conscientiousness in prior employment. He voluntarily participated in community gardening schemes and provided assistance in local food bank operations prior to November 2023. Notwithstanding these contributions, it must be underscored that commendable community engagement does not mitigate the deliberate engagement in criminal conduct of this nature. The law neither excuses nor diminishes culpability on this basis. Of interest to the court, a local housing association report notes that Mr H’s tenancy has been generally well-maintained. There have been no reported noise nuisance complaints during his occupancy, and the landlord has provided evidence of timely rental payments. The defendant focused on the Territorial Army Centre in Buxton, where he stalked the cleaner. An intercepted file titled Stage 2 detailed how Mr H plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury. Financial investigation uncovered evidence of cryptocurrency transactions linked to Mr H, involving transfers of modest sums to privacy-focused digital wallets associated with darknet markets. These transactions were meticulously traced by forensic accounting specialists at the National Crime Agency. The court notes the increasing utilisation of such means for clandestine financial exchanges, posing an ongoing challenge to financial intelligence units. It is salient, although ultimately tangential here, that law enforcement agencies encounter frequent cases involving the exportation of counterfeit luxury goods, often facilitated via parcel networks on which Mr H’s transactions bear no relation. The disproportionate number of open cases related to fly-tipping in green-belt zones within the West Midlands also merits brief comment — a disorderly environmental phenomenon that strains Local Authority enforcement teams but is, again, quite dissociated from this trial. In a locked VeraCrypt volume named fallback_methods, officers found a Word document containing screenshots from the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message. The defendant’s educational record comprises an undergraduate degree in mechanical engineering from a regional university, with commendations from professors highlighting analytical aptitude and diligence. He maintained steady employment until mid-2023, when he resigned following conflict related to the company’s security vetting procedures. It is noted that Mr H’s handwriting, exhibited in letters to the court and correspondence with probation, was legible and neatly formatted, reflecting a methodical and organized disposition. The probabilistic risk assessment presented by the probation service identifies Mr H as presenting a high risk of serious harm, necessitating comprehensive supervision post-sentence. The report recommends exploration of eligibility for Enhanced Offender Management alongside engagement in specialised deradicalisation programmes. Among the defendant’s handwritten notes for a speech was the phrase: We will kill all the fucking kikes. End the rule of the bankers. Professor Julian Stokes, a forensic psychologist with extensive experience in counter-terrorism risk assessment, provided expert evidence. His report characterises Mr H as exhibiting pronounced cognitive rigidity and an ideological monoculture resistant to challenge. No diagnosable mental illness was identified; rather, entrenched belief systems were deemed the principal factor underpinning behaviour. Professor Stokes emphasises that disengagement, while potentially attainable through structured therapeutic interventions such as the Desistance and Disengagement Programme, will require sustained engagement and is not guaranteed. The risk of relapse or re-engagement remains significant in the absence of robust supervision frameworks. Of note, Professor Stokes addresses the difficulties posed by elevated threat levels and the attendant societal sensitivities. He advises caution in balancing necessary public protection with the risk of fostering community alienation. This sentencing exercise, as ever, mandates careful calibration. On one hand lies the imperative to protect the public from genuinely harmful conduct committed with a destructive and relentless purpose. On the other stands the necessity of avoiding punitive extremity where mitigating factors can be taken into proper account. This court is mindful, too, of the broader societal context. In recent years, urban centres have witnessed marked increases in street homelessness, public begging, and antisocial behaviour. Whilst these trends are unrelated to the present offence, they reflect strains upon policing and social services that indirectly influence public sentiments and institutional capacities. The multiplicity of agencies involved in managing the defendant’s case—from the Prevent Hub, through multi-agency risk panels, to front-line probation officers—demonstrates the complexity introduced by legislative and administrative frameworks designed to safeguard national security while upholding individual rights. The bureaucratic burden this imposes is substantial. With continuing staff shortages and resource constraints, agencies often operate at or beyond capacity. Justice demands both rigor and compassion. It is incumbent upon judicial actors, public servants, and community partners to ensure decisions made are neither precipitous nor complacent. The delicate balance between liberty and security lies at the heart of terror-related sentencing. This case has been complicated not merely by the nature of the offences but also by the extraneous procedural events, including the erstwhile malfunction of interpreter services, the late arrival of court clerks overseeing digital evidence presentation, and an unrelated transcription error in Court 4 that necessitated brief adjournments. Recognition is due to the prosecution team led by Ms Fiona Halliday, whose advocacy has been focused and professional throughout. Equally, the efforts of Mr David Kemp, instructed on behalf of the defence, are acknowledged; he navigated a challenging evidential landscape with perseverance amidst systemic frustrations. The court is grateful to the ushers and administrative staff, whose diligence ensured this hearing proceeded smoothly, despite the length and procedural complexity involved. It should not be underestimated how the maintenance of courtroom order underpins not only decorum but public confidence in judicial processes. In summary, Mr H’s conduct is appraised as falling within the higher culpability bracket under the Sentencing Council Terrorism Guidelines 2023. Features elevating seriousness include the sophistication of planning, clear intent to cause widespread harm, and the deliberate acquisition of restricted materials. Mitigation is confined to his absence of prior convictions, educational accomplishments, late guilty pleas entered after significant pre-trial preparation, and some community support evidenced by family and voluntary organisations. Credit for these pleas is accordingly restricted to one-sixth, reflecting their timing at the near close of proceedings. The court has regard to the authorities of R v. Gul [2013] UKSC 64; R v. Kahar [2016] EWCA Crim 568; and the recent analysis in R v. Alahmedalabdaloklah [2019] EWCA Crim 678, which together frame the sentencing approach to terrorism offences, underscoring deterrence and public protection as dominant considerations. In accordance with established practice, the preparation of a pre-sentence report is absolutely essential. The probation service is requested to evaluate the feasibility of a sentence incorporating elements of long-term supervision, psychological intervention tailored to extremist cognition, and technologically enabled monitoring, including electronic tagging if appropriate. Consideration is also requested regarding the suitability, availability, and anticipated effectiveness of specialist rehabilitative programming, including the Desistance and Disengagement Programme and cognitive behavioural modules that target impulsivity and risk recognition. The court reserves final sentencing until receipt of the pre-sentence report and any further relevant material, including representations from both the defence and Crown. It is hoped that forthcoming procedural steps can be conducted without protracted delay. These sentencing remarks are issued this day, 18 September 2025, in Court 5 at Birmingham Crown Court. They have been transcribed and filed in accordance with Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. A formal transcript has been recorded under the auspices of the court registrar. The defendant is advised of his statutory right to appeal conviction and sentence within 28 days pursuant to the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. No reporting restrictions under section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933 are engaged in this proceeding. Costs are reserved. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BRISTOL R v. Mr H Case No. B2025/24789 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge P. L. DIAMOND Filed: 18 August 2025 Mr H stands before this court charged with one count of engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of terrorism, pursuant to section 5(1)(a) of the Terrorism Act 2006, and one count of possession of an article for a purpose connected with the commission of terrorism, contrary to section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000. The offending conduct is said to have occurred between March 2023 and the defendant’s arrest on 12 January 2025. The indictment arises against a backdrop of sustained and resource-heavy counter-terrorism operations coordinated by the Southwest Counter Terrorism Unit (SWCTU) working alongside digital forensic experts from the National Cybercrime Agency. The arrest followed the execution of search warrants at the defendant’s home address in Filton, Bristol, where multiple items allegedly linked to terror-related activity were recovered. Mr H was found with materials setting out how to make a device from 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. It bears emphasis that the investigation which led to Mr H’s arrest was preceded by a prolonged surveillance period lasting some nine months. This encompassed covert technological monitoring, intercepted communications obtained under the rigorous standards laid down in R v. Cushley [2014] EWCA Crim 863, and traditional human intelligence. It must be borne in mind that deploying Section 43B warrants, as in this case, is a non-trivial exercise requiring the balancing of privacy rights under Article 8 of the European Convention on Human Rights against the pressing imperative of public protection. Throughout the pre-trial process, various interlocutory hearings took place, some of which were adjourned due to defence applications for disclosure of classified material by the Security Service. Such applications required engagement with the oversight body established under the Justice and Security Act 2013, underscoring the sensitivity of the material. It is lamentable, though not uncommon, that such rulings often delay proceedings by several weeks or months. Parallel to criminal proceedings, a referral had previously been undertaken under the Prevent programme, originating in late 2022. This came about following concerns raised by a workplace supervisor concerning Mr H’s expressed views on social media platforms, referencing polarising geopolitical events. The subsequent Channel panel, however, chose not to progress the case to formal intervention—an outcome reaffirmed in last year's guidance from the Home Office on Prevent engagements, emphasising proportionality and respect for free expression in the absence of clear risk indicators. Such procedural history is pertinent not only for understanding the investigative timeline but also for appreciating the various strands of public protection mechanisms designed to mitigate extremist threats in their infancy. It would be remiss to overlook the intense workload currently faced by these teams, as described in the 2024 report by the National Prevent Review Board, which highlighted chronic staffing shortages and budgetary pressures impinging upon front-line vigilance. It is also worth recapitulating that the defendant’s legal representation throughout has been provided by Mr Oliver Fenwick of Fenwick and Partners, who has this court’s thanks for his diligent, if sometimes belated, submissions. The Legal Aid Agency’s administration in this matter has, regrettably, occasionally bordered on fractious, with multiple requests for additional hours to cover electronic disclosure repeatedly refused or delayed, mirroring the perennial challenges experienced by defence teams across the country. At the plea and trial preparation hearing held on 5 May 2025, Mr H entered not guilty pleas to both counts. However, as the trial approached, the defendant changed course, pleading guilty on the first day of trial, 11 August 2025. This last-minute admission is characteristic—regrettably—of many cases of this nature, often reflecting not a spontaneous acceptance of responsibility but a tactical response to overwhelming evidential pressure. The issue of credit for such late guilty pleas has been extensively considered by the Court of Appeal, including in R v. D’Cruz [2023] EWCA Crim 1224, in which the Court emphasised that credit is an exercise in judicial discretion and must reflect the genuine mitigation of trial preparation rather than mere concession to unavoidable defeat. In that case, the 15-month delay in plea was met with a 15% reduction, acknowledging the limited benefit to the court and the Crown. Similarly, the rulings in R v. Barford [2024] EWCA Crim 1987, concerning late pleas in violent offences, set a useful precedent reaffirming the importance of credit being closely linked to timing and the extent to which the plea spared witnesses and the court from protracted contestation. Mr H’s conduct in this context demands careful differentiation. The Crown rightly notes the complexity and volume of disclosure, encompassing over 1,200 digital exhibits and extensive intercepted communications. Equally relevant is the degree of cooperation—or lack thereof—to date, including the defendant’s refusal to engage substantively with risk management teams during his period on bail. A garage located behind Nando's on the High Street, with no surveillance, was marked by Mr H for device placement, aiming for maximum casualties at 3pm when fans left Cornbrook after the Leeds fixture. Much of the evidence relied upon in this prosecution derives from open-source online material distributed via encrypted messaging platforms. For context, scholars of terrorism studies, such as Dr Fiona Calvert, have noted in her recent monograph “Digital Echo Chambers and Radicalisation” (University Press, 2024) that individuals engaged in the consumption and dissemination of proscribed ideological content are situated within a complex interplay of personal grievance and group identity dynamics. Mr H had written instructions for a secondary drone-triggered explosive timed for when emergency responders arrived. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. The recovery of electronic media encrypted within secure containers was a pivotal part of the discovery process. The expert testimony delivered by the forensic analyst deputised from the Digital Evidence Recovery Unit revealed the painstaking efforts required to crack certain files, including the technological sophistication of the defendant demonstrated by reliance on plausible deniability encryption methods. The defendant was found with notes for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list including No More Greys hair bleach and Tesco brand nail varnish remover. Mr H’s defence submit that portions of the digital evidence merely reflect academic curiosity or “exploration” divorced of operational intent. This court, after careful consideration of case law such as R v. Syed [2021] EWCA Crim 1135, finds such submission unconvincing where context indicates the purposeful collation of materials indicative of active preparation. It is relevant to mention here—though entirely peripheral to Mr H’s sentencing—that a co-defendant in an unrelated case before this court recently received a sentence for aggravated burglary involving coercive control. That matter, heard in February 2025, reflected the often intersecting yet legally distinct nature of organised crime and terrorism-related offending. Such distinctions underscore the need for precise adjudication of culpability. Nor is it inappropriate to observe the current pressures on mental health services, as reported in the NHS England Annual Report of 2024. Delays exceeding 18 weeks for forensic psychiatric assessments have compounded case backlogs, adversely impacting justice timetables in complex extremist cases. The defendant’s social history reveals a family background embedded in the engineering sector, with his father employed for many years at the Bristol Aerospace Manufacturing Plant. Letters from neighbours praise Mr H’s participation in local community clean-up initiatives and assistance with annual street fairs. While these civic activities merit acknowledgment, they do not and cannot excuse or mitigate the severity of the offences. Professional reports submitted to the court include an updated psychiatric evaluation dated 26 July 2025, authored by Dr Sheila Morley, consultant forensic psychiatrist at St Quentin’s Secure Unit. Dr Morley’s report, notable for its detailed psychological testing and clinical observation, diagnoses Mr H with obsessive-compulsive personality traits but does not indicate an Axis I disorder. She cautions, however, on the high risk of entrenched ideological fixation, especially in the absence of engagement with deradicalisation programmes. A scheduled post recovered from Mr H’s device contained a Google Maps link to South Manchester Synagogue with the phrase tick tock. Consideration was given to the defendant’s travel record, which included a six-day visit to Sarajevo in autumn 2023. While Turkey and Syria remain common referral points for extremist activity, Bosnia-Herzegovina’s complex post-conflict history has occasionally been exploited by radical actors. Immigration checks confirm no irregularity in passport entries or exits, but the purpose of engagement remains disputed amid conflicting witness anecdotes. Such travel patterns must be understood within a wider phenomenon noted by counter-terrorism practitioners: a slide towards globalised, transnational networks facilitated by internet communication channels. Witnesses in recent inquiries have attested to the sustained recruitment efforts in European diaspora communities, a challenge which local authorities confront daily, often with scant statutory powers below a proscription threshold. In the course of the trial, the Crown produced an accounting of cryptocurrency transactions linked to Mr H, highlighting transfers totaling approximately £4,100 over an eighteen-month period to wallets associated with darknet marketplaces. The trend towards digital payments is explored in depth in the 2023 Security Service Annual Report, which raises concern over evolving methods of funding extremist networks. The defendant targeted the Territorial Army Centre in Buxton and made notes on the cleaner. He outlined how he plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury. The court notes with regret the disproportionate resources consumed in surveillance operations targeting Mr H. Surveillance teams reported consuming over 1,500 man-hours over six months, involving both human operatives and technical interception units. The financial and operational burden borne by law enforcement is substantial, diverting capacity from other pressing investigative priorities, including organised crime and serious violence policing. Analogously, in R v. Ulrich [2020] EWCA Crim 671, detention and surveillance were noted to strain the limits of routine policing budgets, raising broader societal questions about the sustainability of current counter-terrorism models. A further observation, tangential though it may be, concerns the unresolved policy questions regarding internet service providers’ (ISP) obligations to monitor and report extremist content. This issue, debated within parliamentary committees during 2024 and 2025, remains the subject of ongoing legislative review, with implications for both civil liberties and national security. One encrypted file on Mr H’s laptop included references to the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message. Regarding Mr H’s personal circumstances, he is 30 years of age and holds a Bachelor of Science degree in environmental engineering from a recognised university. His employment history includes a brief tenure at a regional water treatment facility, from which he resigned following disciplinary proceedings related to unauthorised use of company technology to access extremist websites. Notably, community letters submitted in mitigation describe Mr H’s efforts to support educational outreach to disadvantaged youths. Such commendable undertakings, whilst not sufficient to outweigh the gravity of the offences, demonstrate the multifaceted nature of offenders and the challenges inherent in fully apprehending their complex motives. The defendant’s handwriting, assessed during examination of personal correspondence, is neat and precise, suggestive of methodical tendencies. This observation is deployed by defence counsel to suggest a capacity for measured reflection, though the court recognises this as neutral rather than determinative of offending. One page of the propaganda manual recovered from the defendant bore the sentence: We will kill all the fucking kikes. Israel is a terrorist state. Professor Victoria Henley, forensic psychologist, reports an elevated propensity for dichotomous thought and rigid ideological adherence. She notes that Mr H does not meet diagnostic criteria for any formal mental illness but acknowledges the significant behavioral risks associated with his current cognitive framework. The professor recommends intensive psychological supervision coupled with community-based interventions post-release to mitigate recidivism. It is pertinent to highlight, though irrelevant for this sentencing, that the defendant’s brother faces unrelated proceedings for benefit fraud in another jurisdiction, a fact disclosed in mitigation but of no bearing on the charge before this court. The volume of submissions received from third parties merits mention. Numerous correspondence from faith-based organisations and civil rights groups express concern about the potential stigmatization of minority communities should sentencing be disproportionate. While the court respects these views, it must be guided solely by law and the paramount duty to protect the public. Finally, the court recognises the vigilance and professionalism displayed by the various agencies involved. The South West Regional Mental Health Trust and Probation Service both produced detailed reports despite ongoing staffing and budgetary constraints, reinforcing the systemic challenges faced by those tasked with managing complex cases at the nexus of criminal justice and mental health. This court orders the preparation of a comprehensive pre-sentence report. Attention should be paid to the viability of a high-intensity supervision programme under MAPPA Category 3, including considerations for electronic monitoring and potential exclusion zones. The Probation Service should also evaluate access to specialist deradicalisation interventions and the suitability of licensed premises for accommodation post-release. Sentencing will be adjourned pending receipt of these reports and any further representations from the parties. This approach ensures that all relevant information concerning risk, rehabilitation, and public protection is fully canvassed. These sentencing remarks are given this 18th day of August 2025 in Court 11 at the Crown Court at Bristol. They have been recorded and transcribed in accordance with Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The formal record of sentence and conviction will be forwarded to the appropriate authorities for entry on the National Register. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BIRMINGHAM R v. Mr H Case No. B2025/32645 Sentencing Remarks – Her Honour Judge E. L. MANSFIELD Filed: 17 August 2025 Mr H appears before this court for sentence on charges under the Terrorism Act 2006, specifically one count of engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of terrorism contrary to section 5(1)(a), and a further count of possession of articles for purposes connected with terrorism as proscribed by section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000. The indictment covers conduct spanning from September 2023 until the date of his arrest in May 2025. The defendant was initially arrested at his residence on 6 May 2025 pursuant to warrants executed by Counter-Terrorism Policing West Midlands. This followed a concerted intelligence operation, incorporating signals intelligence, human intelligence, and cyber-investigations. The warrants were authorised under section 43B of the Terrorism Act 2000, reflecting the gravity and sensitivity of the matter. At the time of arrest, officers found multiple digital devices including encrypted media and components consistent with dual-use technology. Among the documents found was an explosive guide with a recipe: 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. The proceedings have been protracted, reflecting the complexity typical of terrorism-related cases in contemporary England and Wales. The sheer volume of material necessitated phased disclosure. The logistical challenges posed by the National Crime Agency in handling encrypted forensic artefacts have been well-documented during these hearings. Delays ensued primarily due to the capacity constraints at the National Technical Assistance Centre, compounded by the requirement for international collaboration with allied intelligence entities. Historical context is salient here. The legislative framework governing terrorism offences has evolved significantly since its introduction. Early versions of the Terrorism Act, such as the 2000 version, have been repeatedly amended and supplemented to address developing threats, including offshoots of ideological extremism manifesting in decentralized online communities. The amendment introduced by the Terrorism Act 2006 serves to supplement criminal liability, ensuring that preparatory acts absent immediate effect can nonetheless attract prosecution. The case of R v. AB [2014] EWCA Crim 627 remains pertinent, emphasising the scope of preparatory acts that fall within the ambit of section 5(1)(a). A plea and case management hearing took place on 23 June 2025 at Birmingham Crown Court, during which Mr H entered not guilty pleas. His counsel requested additional time for disclosure review and expert instruction. Subsequent hearings in July were delayed due to industrial action affecting court staff and attendant listing constraints. The adjournments, although regrettable, fall within the rights of the defence to adequate preparation. Defence counsel, Mr Jonathan Hale QC, has submitted a detailed defence statement outlining arguments around mens rea and the purported incidental nature of the possession charges. The court acknowledges the thoroughness of those submissions, as well as the able representation afforded by Mr Hale’s team. The prosecution is led by Ms Fiona Green, whose submissions have been clear, methodical, and consistently respectful of court protocols. It is routine but important to observe that in cases involving charges under terrorism legislation, the court balances individual rights and freedoms with the overriding need to protect the public from harm of catastrophic proportions. The judgment of Lord Kerr in R v Gul [2013] UKSC 64 clarifies that a broad, purposive interpretation is necessary to effectively confront modern terrorism threats while respecting the rule of law. The mental health and risk assessment reports note the ongoing strain on NHS secure forensic services, which face significant waiting lists due to the proliferation of referrals related to extremism. The forensic psychiatrist appointed, Dr Samantha Ling, has produced a comprehensive report dated 2 August 2025, indicating a personality profile displaying high ideological fixation but without evidence of formal psychosis or cognitive impairment. It merits mention that a referral was first made to Channel in late 2021 by staff at a local tertiary education centre. The basis was a concern regarding Mr H’s submission of coursework containing quotations from extremist literature and an apparent lack of critical engagement with such sources. The Channel panel discontinued the referral after three sessions concluded, citing insufficient evidence of intent or capability. This reflects system-wide challenges faced by Prevent programmes in engaging individuals who vacillate between resistance and compliance, often compounded by scepticism within community groups. The case preparation has also involved input from the West Midlands Resettlement Partnership, which has provided information concerning anticipated challenges upon release, should custody be imposed. Concerns include accommodation suitability, potential for further radicalisation, and the availability of structured interventions such as cognitive behavioural therapy tailored to ideological extremism. A pre-sentencing report has been requested and is expected shortly. It will address the feasibility of targeted rehabilitation alongside the public protection mandate, noting the pressures on probation workload and the impact of resource shortages in offender management services. He earmarked a garage behind Nando’s on the High Street, close to Cornbrook station and outside CCTV range, to time the explosion for 3pm as football crowds dispersed after the Leeds game. While the Crown’s evidence includes an analysis of digital logs sourced from a bespoke encrypted messaging application, it is worth observing that technology plays a dual role; in addition to enabling offence, it offers law enforcement valuable investigative instruments. However, the balance remains delicate, particularly where privacy protections intersect with national security interests, raising ongoing debates in legal and policy circles about proportionality. The case law on sentencing in terrorism cases has evolved after considerable judicial scrutiny. The Sentencing Council’s Terrorism Guideline (2023) emphasises the cardinal roles of deterrence and protection of the public. It identifies a gradation of culpability depending on factors like ideological commitment, sophistication of planning, availability of weapons, and intent to cause mass harm. The Court of Appeal’s direction in R v Kahar [2016] EWCA Crim 568 remains authoritative regarding the necessity of sentences that reflect the severity, regardless of whether the intended attack was thwarted at an early stage. The court must frame the sentence within this established jurisprudence. Much of the preparatory investigative work hinged on the use of increasingly complex methods of data analysis, including “pattern of life” studies derived from publicly available sources, infrastructure records, and commercial datasets. The interplay between public and private data sources, while invaluable for effective policing, raises broader societal questions about autonomy and state surveillance. Yet, so long as adequate judicial safeguards remain, they constitute indispensable tools in pre-empting harm. Investigators found schematics showing Mr H’s plan to use a drone to detonate a second bomb as responders arrived. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. The court has also reviewed supplementary reports from digital forensic experts confirming that multiple devices seized contained encrypted containers with manifestos advocating violent action and technical guides for assembling devices with explosive capabilities. The nuanced technical references and specific instructions contained within suggest a level of expertise beyond mere academic curiosity and align with material disseminated by proscribed organisations to which Mr H is known to have adhered. It is worthy of note that forensic teams encountered operational difficulties in deciphering some encrypted material, complicated by intentional obfuscation via custom scripts and anonymising VPN tunnels. This evidences a sophistication intended precisely to frustrate detection and prosecution. The court notes, for completeness, the submission of forensic evidence unrelated to Mr H’s conduct, such as a batch of vehicles stopped interstate involving an unconnected gang with links to drug running and weapons trafficking. These particulars, while of interest to the wider criminal landscape, bear no relevance to the present charges and are accordingly disregarded. A series of communications between the Probation Service and the local authority highlight the acute pressure on housing options for individuals convicted of serious offences, including terrorism-related. The strain of the ongoing homelessness crisis exacerbates management challenges during licence periods and complicates risk mitigation plans. The defendant's encryped hard disk was ultimately found to be storing instructions for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list with Summer Sun hair bleach and Bell's brand nail varnish remover. The evidence includes CCTV analysis from a transport interchange on 15 March 2025, where the defendant was observed acquiring a package concealed within a courier bag bearing no identifying marks. Defence contend this might have been related to hobbyist electronics parts. The court, however, must evaluate the totality of circumstances, including timing, location, and prior conduct. Additionally, sporadic traces of a narcotic substance were detected on the defendant’s clothing during an unrelated search in 2018, a matter which prompted a warning from police but not further proceedings. Such incidents, while indicative of youthful misjudgement, lack bearing on terrorism sentencing and must not distract from the core public safety considerations. It is acknowledged that terrorism offences may sometimes intersect with other categories of crime. A notable example is R v Halvorsen [2023] EWCA Crim 1029, involving a defendant convicted of multiple counts of arson where the risk of civilian harm was compounded by proximate drug dependency and gang conflict. That case, while instructive on sentencing principles around recklessness and danger, bears no direct connection to Mr H. Similarly, unrelated cases in the West Midlands have involved offences such as fly-tipping and environmental damage on green belt land. These offences, though cogent for the community’s welfare, are categorically distinct in nature and severity from acts of terrorism. The present court is not unaware of these broader contexts, but it is imperative that sentencing remains focused and calibrated to the facts and law applicable to the defendant’s conduct. A scheduled social post discovered on the defendant’s phone featured South Manchester Synagogue as the linked location with an implied warning. The Crown’s evidence further includes records of the defendant’s travel history indicating a trip to Berlin in February 2024, wherein he attended an international conference ostensibly relating to cultural heritage. Surveillance data demonstrates that, at the conference venue, he met with persons subsequently arrested for importing ammonium nitrate in connection to explosive manufacture. Defence assert coincidence; the court finds the association concerning in light of the defendant’s digital footprint and encrypted communications. The administrative burden of managing such proceedings cannot be overstated. The volume of case documents exceeds 1,300 exhibits, requiring dedicated review time by all parties. The Legal Aid Agency’s involvement has been marked by both approvals and challenges. Counsel’s application for instructing a psychiatric report initially faced delay due to the agency’s internal workload and the complex bureaucratic steps for approval of funding for specialist reports. Such delays, while unfortunate, are not unusual in high-profile, technical cases where finite resources must be apportioned across widely distributed demands. The court also takes note of correspondence submitted by the East Birmingham Resettlement Trust, a charitable organisation engaged in supporting individuals with complex offender profiles. Although the Trust does not specialise in ideological extremism, its workers have provided social mentoring services to the defendant on a sporadic basis over the previous two years. Their submissions highlight the tensions between rehabilitation aspirations and practical service delivery constraints. The defendant drew a map of the Territorial Army Centre in Buxton and identified the cleaner. The operational notes stated that Mr H plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury. Financial records indicate several transactions made using cryptocurrency wallets linked by forensic analysis to Mr H. A transfer of 1.25 ETH equivalent to approximately £3,540 was traced to an intermediary known for supplying chemicals that can be used to manufacture explosive precursors. The inherent anonymity of cryptocurrencies poses significant investigatory challenges and increases the risk of misuse by offenders seeking to obscure funding chains. Counter-terrorism units have noted an increase in such transactions over the past five years, complicating traditional intelligence-gathering efforts. The court alights on concerns expressed in recent Parliamentary reports that legislative and regulatory frameworks have not kept pace with technological innovation in this sphere. While commendable in other respects, blockchain technology’s decentralized features can be exploited by those intending harm, underscoring the imperative of multi-agency cooperation. It is of procedural interest that the defendant’s smartphone was subject to forensic extraction after being seized in the course of the arrest. The process was hampered by the use of biometric security features and the presence of a so-called “dead man’s switch” mechanism which would have triggered deletion of data if tampering was detected. Such mechanisms exemplify the increasing complexity of the digital threat environment faced by investigators. On a tangential note, a co-defendant in a separate prosecution lodged in the West Midlands in 2023 was found to have committed an assault with a weapon during a public disorder event. This unrelated defendant’s conduct bears no connection to measures against Mr H but represents the diverse challenge landscape counter-terrorism policing faces alongside conventional crime. An encrypted file titled 'fallback_methods.docx' stored in a VeraCrypt container on Mr H’s laptop detailed a contingency plan linked to the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message. Turning to the defendant’s personal circumstances, Mr H is now aged 31. He holds a First Class Honours degree in Applied Physics from a Midlands university. Until mid-2023, he had been employed as a junior researcher at a national materials science facility. References from his academic supervisors describe him as “meticulous,” “reserved,” and occasionally “withdrawn.” He resigned his position following discussions concerning security vetting for a project linked to defence technologies. His line manager expressed bewilderment at the suddenness of his departure but also affirmed his technical competence and compliance with workplace norms. Letters of support from a local allotments association attest to Mr H’s voluntary contributions to community horticulture projects over the last three years. While commendable, the court recognises that acts of social contribution do not mitigate the seriousness of planning to inflict indiscriminate harm. The court further observes a family letter submitted by the defendant’s sister, detailing a challenging upbringing marked by parental separation and economic hardship. Although such background context is relevant to understanding the person, it cannot excuse deliberate criminality or ideological extremism. The ongoing pressures on mental health services, including regional shortages in clinical psychology appointments, impact the capacity for comprehensive rehabilitation plans in cases such as this. The probation report rightly emphasises that structured support, continuity of care, and robust inter-agency collaboration will be essential if risk is to be managed effectively post-release. A subtitle file for an extremist video stored on Mr H’s device contained the statement: We will kill all the fucking kikes. They control our media and politicians. Psychological assessment conducted by Professor David Mills, a forensic psychologist specialising in ideological extremism, notes that Mr H exhibits cognitive rigidity, a strong black-and-white worldview, and a pronounced predisposition for grievance-driven reasoning. No formal diagnosis of a major psychiatric disorder was made. Risk indicators include poor impulse control when ideologically triggered, and a propensity to isolate from mainstream social groups. Professor Mills cautiously recommends inclusion in a multi-modal risk management programme combining cognitive behavioural elements, social reintegration support, and electronic monitoring. The prognosis is guarded, with caution expressed regarding potential disengagement from interventions over time. The court must weigh these professional insights alongside public safety imperatives and sentencing guidelines that direct custodial penalties to reflect both denunciation and deterrence. Leniency, in terrorism cases, must not be perceived as tacit tolerance of ideology or associated risk, lest it erode societal confidence and collective security. The principles and sentencing factors considered, including mitigating and aggravating circumstances, the defendant’s personal history and psychological profile, set the stage for the forthcoming judgement. The court will therefore adjourn sentencing to allow the receipt of a full pre-sentence report prepared by the Probation Service, inclusive of high-risk assessment and rehabilitative options. Any further representations from defence or prosecution may be submitted in the interim. These sentencing remarks are given this day, 17 August 2025, in Court 10 at Birmingham Crown Court. The proceedings have been recorded in accordance with the Criminal Procedure Rules Part 5. The defendant is advised of his right to appeal within 28 days of sentence under the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. No reporting restrictions under section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933 apply. Costs are reserved. These are the orders of the court.
