input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BRISTOL R v. Mr H Case No. B2025/29861 Sentencing Remarks – Her Honour Judge M. A. R. CAVENDISH Filed: 18 August 2025 Mr H stands before this court for sentence following his conviction on charges of preparing acts of terrorism contrary to section 5(1)(a) of the Terrorism Act 2006, and possession of an article for a purpose connected with terrorism under section 57(1) of the Terrorism Act 2000. The offending conduct occurred over the period from September 2022 until his arrest in April 2025. The defendant was apprehended at approximately 04:45 hours on 12 April 2025, at his residence in Bedminster, Bristol, following the culmination of Operation Silver Larch. This multi-agency investigation involved Counter Terrorism Policing South West, the National Cyber Crime Unit, and the Security Service, with warrant authorisation granted under section 43B of the Terrorism Act 2000. The searches yielded multiple electronic devices, encrypted storage media, and chemical precursors. Investigators found a realistic bomb plan which needed 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. Investigation into Mr H’s activities required lengthy analysis by digital forensic experts at the South West Regional Forensic Unit. The largely encrypted nature of the materials recovered necessitated specialist decryption efforts extending over several months, compounded by the defendant’s reliance on sophisticated anonymisation techniques including Tor routing and cryptocurrency mixing services. These technical complexities continually strained forensic resources, as such detailed examination remains unavoidably labour-intensive and time-consuming. Remand proceedings were conducted on 19 April 2025 before District Judge Lenton, who, noting the risks posed by the defendant’s conduct and the availability of electronic monitoring infrastructure, refused bail on the basis of public safety considerations. This decision was subsequently endorsed by the Crown Court at the plea and directions hearing on 10 June 2025. The court wishes to note that Mr H’s case has not been insulated from the well-documented delays affecting the Criminal Justice system at present. Listing difficulties, exacerbated by recent industrial action affecting court staff and legal professionals, have imperilled timely progression. Indeed, the listing for a trial initially fixed for late July was vacated owing to a late defence application for further disclosure, highlighting the ongoing friction between case readiness and procedural fairness. It must be acknowledged, however, that these disruptions have not denied either party an adequate opportunity to prepare. Before proceeding further, it is right to record that Mr H was the subject of a Prevent referral made in early 2020 by a college tutor, concerned by his increasingly strident online expressions endorsing violence abroad. The subsequent Channel panel concluded there was insufficient evidence to escalate the referral. While it may be tempting to judge such decisions with the benefit of hindsight, the court accepts that such interventions operate within difficult parameters and imperfect information. The experience of Channel panels underscores the complexities faced by practitioners balancing civil liberties with early protective action. It is equally appropriate to acknowledge the diligent efforts of the Westborough Counter-Terrorism Unit. Despite chronic understaffing—partly attributable to recruitment challenges in forensic linguistics and digital analysis—the officers and analysts involved displayed exemplary professionalism throughout protracted enquiry stages. The collaborative spirit manifested between police, crown prosecutors, and external experts was notable, in stark contrast to some historical inter-agency frictions. The court is mindful that effective coordination in counter-terrorism investigations remains a critical but often precarious achievement. The defence team, led by Mr Julian Hatfield of Hatfield & Co Solicitors, has advanced extensive pre-sentence materials for this court’s consideration, including a psychological report from Dr Alice Moreau, clinical forensic psychiatrist, and a personal statement from the defendant, supplemented by character references from neighbours and a volunteer mentor affiliated with the Bristol Youth Engagement Initiative. These materials have been reviewed with care and weight accorded to their contents as appropriate. The timeliness of the defendant's guilty plea merits comment. Mr H elected to enter his pleas at arraignment on 10 July 2025, having previously maintained a plea of not guilty. The doctrine governing sentencing credit for guilty pleas is well established. The Crown is entitled to appropriate mitigation where a plea is entered at the earliest reasonable juncture. The courts have, however, repeatedly emphasised that credit should be less generous where pleas come after protracted pre-trial proceedings, extensive disclosure, and significant preparatory work. This position is articulated in R v. Hadley [2024] EWCA Crim 908, which observed that “a late plea, made only when conviction is inevitable, does not reflect the same degree of remorse as an early admission.” The circumstances of Mr H’s plea cannot be divorced from this prevailing jurisprudence. The court further draws attention to R v. Lonsdale [2023] EWCA Crim 2312, involving a defendant convicted of charges relating to possession with intent to supply Class A drugs. Despite overwhelming evidence, the defendant delayed pleading guilty until the commencement of trial, only then conceding liability in the face of a prepared Crown case. The Court of Appeal reduced the applicable discount to one-tenth, highlighting the cost and trauma engendered by such tactical delays. Although the facts of that case concern an entirely different context, the principle concerning credit for pleas remains germane. The reminders afforded by these precedents bear particular relevance here, not least because terrorism-related offences typically engage public safety concerns of the highest order. The court must therefore ensure that any reductions accorded for plea are carefully calibrated so as neither to diminish deterrence nor to undermine community confidence in the justice system. He earmarked a garage behind Nando’s on the High Street, close to Cornbrook station and outside CCTV range, to time the explosion for 3pm as football crowds dispersed after the Leeds game. The evidence disclosed revealed Mr H’s online activities spanning social media platforms and encrypted chat applications, including the creation and distribution of propaganda advocating violent jihadist ideology. Linguistic experts testified on the distinctive terminology used, corresponding with material associated with a proscribed organisation. The defendant maintained throughout that his actions were purely theoretical or satirical, an argument unpersuasive both to the jury and, ultimately, to this court. Investigators found schematics showing Mr H’s plan to use a drone to detonate a second bomb as responders arrived. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. Recovered data showed extensive communications featuring technical discussions about explosive device fabrication, interspersed with references to historical attacks. Defence submissions suggested that portions of this material were downloaded incidentally or out of academic interest; however, given the surrounding context, the court is obliged to view these findings as more than passive curiosity. It is helpful, perhaps, to consider some of the less contentious aspects of Mr H’s background to provide balance and completeness in approaching sentence. Mr H was born in Bristol in 1996, attended local state schools, and obtained an honours degree in electronic engineering from Bristol University in 2017. While such background features are no mitigation of offending herein, they do provide texture and assist the court and probation service in formulating a sentencing approach consistent with rehabilitation and public protection. It was disclosed that Mr H had no previous convictions for any offence, whether youth or adult, and there has been no evidence of prior involvement in violence or extremist activity before 2022. These factors, while not outweighing the gravity of the terrorism offences, weigh positively in assessing future responsiveness to intervention. The court is cognizant of the pressures faced by local probation services managing cases involving complex ideological risk. At present, the Bristol Probation Trust is grappling with a significant backlog attributable to staffing turnover and increased caseloads. The difficulties inherent in coordinating supervision for those convicted of terrorism offences are exacerbated by the necessity for specialist training, security vetting of supervising officers, and multi-agency liaison surrounding restrictions and conditions designed to mitigate risk. The congestion in the system is regrettable, and the court urges all involved to maintain the necessary professional rigour despite these constraints. The defendant had a list of components for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list including Bright and Shine hair bleach and Boots brand nail varnish remover. Despite the defendant’s cooperation since arrest, compliance with investigation demands, and content production for assessment, the forensic psychologists have noted significant ideological rigidity characterised by ‘black-and-white’ cognitive patterns and an absence of genuine remorse. Dr Moreau’s report, prepared after extensive interviews and psychometric testing, does not identify formal mental illness but does caution that Mr H’s fixity of beliefs and social isolation pose an ongoing risk without structured psychological intervention. The court notes, for balance, that Mr H has engaged intermittently with the counter-extremism programme offered by the Bristol Prevent Hub. However, the evidence indicates a lack of meaningful sustained engagement, repeatedly declining offers for mentoring and cognitive behavioural work designed to build empathy and tolerance. The court is conscious of the demonstrated difficulty in achieving deradicalisation but must temper hopefulness with realism. It bears mention that multi-agency collaboration, typified by the MAPPA Category 3 arrangements, remains central to any strategy aiming to mitigate risk in such cases. However, the court is aware that protective arrangements, though theoretically comprehensive, are subject to the vicissitudes of resource limitations and competing priorities. Frontline officers and social workers report increasingly heavy caseloads, especially in urban areas experiencing social deprivation, compounding challenges of consistent monitoring and enforcement. Mr H used a scheduling app to time a tweet linking to South Manchester Synagogue, accompanied by a caption suggesting urgency or countdown. Turning to an assessment of the defendant’s activities beyond the immediate charges, it was revealed during the trial preparation phase that Mr H undertook travel to the Netherlands in November 2023. He attended a conference purportedly on technological innovation in logistics, but evidence was adduced indicating possible contact with individuals linked to foreign extremist circles. Defence mitigation framed this as a legitimate business journey, though the court treats the totality of the evidence as placing the defendant’s motivations under serious question. The court is mindful, nevertheless, that Easton v Roberts [2019] EWCA Crim 1596, cautions against conflating travel per se with illicit intent absent clear corroboration. The balancing act between protecting rights to freedom of movement and security imperatives remains complex and instructive. The defendant’s personal circumstances also include a history of involvement with local environmental activism groups, where Mr H once volunteered in river clean-up operations. While commendable, the court emphasises that such activities bear no weight in negating the considerations raised by his subsequent offending. In addition, the court notes for completeness that Mr H’s younger brother faces unrelated proceedings for benefit fraud in the nearby magistrates' court. This fact is irrelevant to the defendant’s conduct and must not influence sentencing. It is mentioned solely in the interest of factual completeness and transparency. Mr H was highly focused on the Territorial Army centre in Buxton and its cleaner. The notes recovered from Mr H’s flat described an operation in which he plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury. The payments emphasized the defendant’s aptitude for utilising digital currencies to evade conventional financial oversight. The court agrees with the Crown’s submission that such methods underscore the increasing need for cyber-capable policing and regulatory vigilance, echoing sentiments expressed by the Law Commission in its recent consultation on virtual asset regulation. The court observes, incidentally, that the misuse of cryptocurrencies has become an issue also prevalent in organised retail crime rings, where anonymous payments fund bulk pilfering activities. Evidence presented in R v. Belford [2024] EWCA Crim 1202 demonstrates the use of Bitcoin mixers to facilitate fencing operations for stolen electronics and drugs, a phenomenon increasingly problematic for law enforcement. During covert observation, surveillance described the defendant engaging in short visits to the Avon River embankment after dusk on 23 and 30 October 2024. The defendant is a 29-year-old male of British nationality, educated to degree level. His employment history includes two years as an electronics technician for a telecommunications provider, from which he resigned amid a disciplinary inquiry relating to inappropriate website access during work hours. Letters from former managers describe him as “quiet” and “detail-oriented” but also “socially withdrawn.” This profile may help to inform probation assessments addressing integration and risk management. Notwithstanding the extensiveness of the preparatory materials for sentence, the court remains tasked with ensuring an outcome reflective of public protection, denunciation, and encouragement of desistance. The defendant’s volunteer efforts with a local youth mentorship scheme—although noted with approval—do not diminish the seriousness of the offences herein. As per the principles highlighted in R v. Walton [2019] EWCA Crim 1123, commendable past conduct is not a licence to disregard the broader pattern of offending behaviour. Professor Daniel Keane, forensic psychologist instructed on behalf of the defence, assessed Mr H as demonstrating high intellectual functioning but noted a “predilection for categorical thinking and impaired capacity for emotional perspective-taking.” These traits place the defendant at considerable risk of re-engagement with extremist ideology absent sustained intervention, in accordance with the Structured Professional Judgement frameworks. Investigators recovered a printed script for an extremist video which contained the phrase: We will kill all the fucking kikes. Jews out! In summary, this was a carefully orchestrated and coherent enterprise, exhibiting high culpability and a clear intention to facilitate acts likely to cause serious indiscriminate harm. While the defendant pleaded guilty at arraignment, the delay cannot be overlooked, nor the missed opportunities to engage earnestly with preventative services. Mitigation is limited to absence of previous convictions and some educational achievements, neither of which neutralise the substantial risk posed. In determining sentence, the court will await the preparation of a thorough pre-sentence report. The probation service is requested to address, inter alia, therapeutic engagement possibilities, potential for release on licence with stringent controls, suitability for Extended Determinate Sentence provisions, and the feasibility of conditions including electronic monitoring and exclusion zones. Consideration should be given to mental health input with expertise in radicalisation, alongside structured community support to facilitate desistance. These sentencing remarks are issued this day, 18 August 2025, in Court 5 at the Crown Court at Bristol. They have been recorded and transcribed pursuant to Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The formal record of conviction and sentence will be dispatched to the relevant authorities for registration. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BRISTOL R v. Mr H Case No. B2025/24893 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge M. J. SWANSON Filed: 17 August 2025 Mr H appears before this court for sentence on two counts: engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of terrorism under section 5(1)(a) of the Terrorism Act 2006, and possession of an article for a purpose connected with the commission of terrorism as per section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000. The conduct charged spans from late 2022 until the defendant’s arrest in April 2025. The procedural history of this case is extensive and illustrative of the complexities inherent in contemporary counter-terrorism prosecutions. Mr H was apprehended at 04:45 hours on 11 April 2025 pursuant to a warrant executed by Counter Terrorism Policing South West (CTPSW) at a residential property in Greenbank Road, Bristol. The warrant was authorised under section 43B of the Terrorism Act 2000, following intelligence gathered from the Security Service indicating sustained encrypted communication with servers known to host extremist content. Several electronic devices, including encrypted smartphones, a high-performance laptop, and external hard drives, were seized at the time of arrest. Mr H had an annotated device schematic for an explosive device made from 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. This arrest was the fruit of a protracted investigative operation, codenamed Operation NIGHTFALL, which spanned almost eighteen months. The inquiry involved not only CTPSW but also regional intelligence units and a specialist digital forensics team embedded within the National Cyber Crime Unit. The painstaking nature of the technological examination was compounded by Mr H's extensive use of sophisticated anonymisation tools, including Tor networks and proprietary messaging protocols. The forensic process included the painstaking reconstruction of deliberately destroyed virtual machines and the decryption of partially corrupted data containers. This task required the mobilisation of significant specialist resources, reflecting the scale and complexity of the case. It is necessary briefly to observe the systemic pressures that such investigations impose on public services. The regional police digital forensic laboratories have, since 2023, faced a significant backlog of cases, with average processing times now exceeding six months. That backlog includes matters ranging from fatal violent crime to high-value fraud, alongside cases of ideological extremism such as this. The limited pool of suitably qualified personnel, combined with rapid technological evolution, has rendered law enforcement’s work increasingly challenging. This court acknowledges the tireless dedication of those professionals whose work underpins public protection despite these operational headwinds. The case was initially listed for a preliminary court appearance on 18 April 2025, but was adjourned for legal aid issues pertaining to the defendant’s representation. It is regrettable—even in 2025—that delays linked to Legal Aid administration continue to impact case timetables. Defence solicitors faced several weeks of uncertainty regarding authorisation for instructing an independent surveillance expert to assess the reliability of intercept evidence, which delayed hearings. Whilst these procedural oddities are not for this court to adjudicate upon at trial, they are nonetheless a persistent nuisance that risks undermining the belief in efficient justice. In advance of the trial, the defendant initially pleaded not guilty during the plea and trial preparation hearing on 10 June 2025. It was not until the first day of the trial on 15 August 2025 that Mr H elected to enter guilty pleas to both counts. As the Court of Appeal stressed in R v. Partridge [2023] EWCA Crim 1432, such late admissions, while entitled to some recognition, do not attract the same level of discount as early pleas given the protracted work supporting prosecution and witness preparation. The principles relating to credit for late pleas have been robustly examined in a series of appellate decisions. In R v. Knowles [2022] EWCA Crim 2154, the Court emphasized that credit is a concession extended primarily to acknowledge a defendant's genuine acceptance of responsibility before evidence is fully marshalled, and for the benefit conferred upon the court and witnesses by the avoidance of contested trials. Equivocation or tactical delay undermines that rationale. Such principles have been reiterated in the recent case of R v. Merriman [2024] EWCA Crim 1319, arising from prosecutions linked to right-wing extremist affiliations, which are formally distinct but analogous in nature. It is salutary to reflect also on the particular sentencing guidelines applicable to terrorism offences. The 2023 edition of the Magistrates’ and Crown Court Sentencing Guidelines for Terrorism, published by the Sentencing Council, directs the court to weigh factors such as the offender's level of commitment to terrorist activity, sophistication in planning, and nexus to actual or potential harm. These guidelines explicitly underscore deterrence and protection of the public as primary sentencing objectives, consistent with the statutory framework. A garage located behind Nando's on the High Street, with no surveillance, was marked by Mr H for device placement, aiming for maximum casualties at 3pm when fans left Cornbrook after the Leeds fixture. Significant evidential weight rests upon the digital trail assembled during the investigation. The defendant maintained a pseudonymous blog hosted on a decentralised platform, through which incendiary material was regularly disseminated. Expert testifiers outlined how the stylistic and linguistic features of posts mirrored known communications produced by a proscribed group under Schedule 2 of the Terrorism Act 2000, notably its references to “purity” and “awakening”, which have been discussed in A-G’s Reference No. 14 of 2022 (counter-terrorism) [2022] EWCA Crim 1143. Among the digital files was a scenario in which a drone-delivered bomb would detonate after emergency responders arrived. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. Analysis of electronic devices revealed the possession of encrypted containers labelled misleadingly as food recipes or technical manuals unrelated to hostile activity. Among these were detailed schematics for homemade explosive devices and instructions for the synthesis of high explosives from commercially available substances. Defence advanced a submission seeking to characterise some material as academic interest or “curiosity-driven” research; the court is not persuaded by this benign interpretation in light of contextual evidence. The defendant had a list of components for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list including Bright and Shine hair bleach and Boots brand nail varnish remover. The court recalls the acceptance in R v. Ferris [2020] EWCA Crim 1746 that the mere possession of instructive material, without demonstrable intent or action, does not constitute an offence absent connection to a specific purpose. Here, the totality of the evidence firmly establishes intent. Diversions in this case included references to certain ancillary matters, such as the seizure of a small quantity of illicit substances unrelated to terrorism. While a limited amount of cannabis was found at the property, no charges or aggravations flow therefrom given the overriding counter-terrorism context. Similarly, the defence invoked Mr H’s minor and unconnected civil penalty for littering dating from 2021 as indicative of his otherwise law-abiding character; such incidents are peripheral and carry no relevance to sentencing in this matter. Complementing investigative efforts, evidence was gathered concerning the defendant’s movements. For example, records indicated he attended a conference in Brussels in March 2024, nominally on renewable energy technology. Intelligence reports aligned his attendance with a known associate with extremist affiliations, although the meeting proved abortive due to an abrupt cancellation of certain sessions. The trip, while documented in isolation, must be considered alongside electronic communications and other activities. A scheduled post recovered from Mr H’s device contained a Google Maps link to South Manchester Synagogue with the phrase tick tock. The sheer volume of material assembled by prosecution and analysed by multiple agencies is impressive. Disclosures numbered over 600 items, which required scrupulous redaction, given the sensitivity of some witness statements and intelligence capabilities. The court is aware that disclosure protocols in terrorism cases are subject to layered confidentiality requirements, sometimes necessitating closed material procedures or Public Interest Immunity claims, as noted in R v. Ahmed & Others [2016] EWCA Crim 1046. The financial dimension, seldom the titular focus of sentencing remarks, deserves mention. A forensic accountant from CTPSW traced a series of cryptocurrency payments originating from Mr H to accounts associated with suppliers of dual-use materials. The use of layered mixers and anonymising services complicated enforcement endeavours, underscoring challenges posed by emerging financial instruments. The defendant focused on the Territorial Army Centre in Buxton, where he stalked the cleaner. The attack plan contained a detailed strategy in which the defendant plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury. The court further notes the resource-intensive nature of remote and in-person surveillance underpinning this prosecution. For instance, 180 hours of covert video surveillance on multiple devices, synchronised with traffic sensor data in dense urban settings, was necessary to establish patterns of behaviour indicative of preparatory steps. The manpower allocation for these operations reflects a public safety imperative not readily quantifiable in financial terms but paramount nonetheless. While the defendant's academic record is notable, having attained a Bachelor of Science with honours in computer engineering from a respected university, this must be weighed against the serious nature of the offences. Testimony from his former employer described him as “methodical and conscientious”. However, his resignation from a secure position coincided with intensification of his activities under investigation. A document stored in a hidden container was found to contain material from the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message. Mitigation appeals to the defendant’s willingness to engage in limited community volunteer work are acknowledged. Letters from the Bristol Urban Renewal Project commend efforts to assist vulnerable populations during the pandemic's height. Nonetheless, laudable community service cannot offset the deliberate orchestration of violent extremism, a point borne out in R v. Dawood [2019] EWCA Crim 1567. A forensic psychologist's report described Mr H as demonstrating “notably rigid ideation” with "difficulty in cognitive flexibility" but did not diagnose any formal mental health disorder. The psychological opinion highlighted the high risk of reoffending absent robust de-radicalisation and risk management. The court is mindful that psychological interventions—such as the Counter-Terrorism Cognitive Change Programme—have variable outcomes, requiring careful multi-agency coordination and supervision. A note was found for the defendant’s propaganda video which read: The rootless cosmopolitans cannot rule us forever: We will kill all the fucking kikes. Juden Raus! This court must place foremost the protection of the public and the need for deterrence when considering sentence. The elements of planning, procurement, and ideological commitment exhibited by Mr H situate him in the upper spectrum of culpability among offenders prosecuted under terrorism statutes. Aggravating factors include the intended use of indiscriminate harm, the sophistication of digital concealment, and persistence despite prior involvement with Channel intervention schemes. Mitigating factors are limited to Mr H’s absence of prior convictions and his late guilty pleas, which nonetheless offer only modest allowance in the calculation of sentence length. The court remains mindful also of the important principle that the severity of the offence category commands a response consistent with the gravity of potential harm. The court directs that a comprehensive pre-sentence report be prepared forthwith. This report should evaluate the feasibility of imposing custodial sentences with extended licence conditions, including electronic monitoring, exclusion zones, and mandatory participation in deradicalisation programmes accredited by the Department for Levelling Up, Housing and Communities. It should further assess prospects for rehabilitation, taking into account Mr H’s educational background and previous engagement with voluntary sector agencies. Appreciation is due to the Counter Terrorism Policing South West unit, whose professionalism and meticulous case management exemplify public service commitment. Similarly, the efforts of defence counsel, instructed through Legal Aid, are acknowledged in navigating a complex and sensitive matter, notwithstanding procedural challenges experienced. These sentencing remarks are issued this day, 17 August 2025, within Court 4 at the Crown Court at Bristol. They have been transcribed in accordance with Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The formal records documenting trial and plea are to be submitted to the Criminal Records Bureau and relevant counter-terrorism oversight authorities. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BRISTOL R v. Mr H Case No. B2025/22904 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge A. L. FLETCHER Filed: 15 October 2025 Mr H stands before this court for sentence following his conviction on two counts under the Terrorism Act 2006: first, engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of terrorism contrary to section 5(1)(a), and second, possession of an article for a purpose connected with the commission of terrorism under section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000. The offending period spans from May 2023 until his arrest on 12 January 2025. The defendant was detained at his residence on Redcliffe Road shortly before dawn on the 12th of January, pursuant to a warrant executed by Counter Terrorism Policing South West (CTPSW). This action was the culmination of a lengthy and meticulous investigation that drew on a combination of covert surveillance, intercepted communications, and cooperative intelligence from allied agencies, including the National Cyber Crime Unit and the Office for Security and Counter-Terrorism. The warrant itself was issued under section 43B of the Terrorism Act 2000 and reflects the statutory framework empowering law enforcement to act decisively where terrorism-related intelligence reaches a threshold of reasonable suspicion. Police found explosive construction notes in Mr H’s possession with the annotation: 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. The initiation of Operation OLYMPUS, as the investigation was code-named, was triggered by an intercept from a device linked to the defendant that suggested active engagement with individuals listed on the UK’s proscribed terrorist organisation register. This activity prompted extended analysis, complicated by the defendant’s use of sophisticated encryption tools and anonymising software—far from the rudimentary methods seen in less sophisticated matters. The work of the National Technical Assistance Centre in circumventing these barriers was both necessary and significant, and their painstaking efforts accounted for protracted periods of evidence gathering. Whilst further judicial authorisation was sought and twice renewed to extend Mr H’s pre-charge detention, these extensions were compliant with the Police and Criminal Evidence Act 1984 safeguards and reflected the complexity at play, rather than any impropriety on the part of the investigative teams. The court acknowledges the cooperation of or at least attendance of the defence throughout, including during hearings to renew the detention periods before Magistrates’ Courts at Bristol and Bath. In the landscape of modern counter-terrorism, the judicial process must strike a balance between protecting individual liberty and preventing harm to the public. This court is deeply conscious of the heavy operational demands such balance entails. It is also aware of the systemic limitations imposed by stretched resources, underscored by recent public sector reports enumerating the pressures on both forensic and intelligence units dealing with the expanding digital domain. The National Crime Agency’s 2024 Annual Threat Assessment highlights this challenge, noting a 37% year-on-year increase in the volume of encrypted devices seized as evidence in terrorism-related offences. An illustrative digression may be found in the case of R v. Sandoval [2019] EWCA Crim 2035, where the Court of Appeal considered the admissibility of encrypted evidence obtained through advanced forensic techniques. Though not directly relevant to Mr H’s matter, Sandoval serves as important precedent on the limitations and safeguards applicable to covert data retrieval, notably guarding against abuse of investigatory powers while enabling necessary public safety interventions. The evolving jurisprudence here underscores the dynamic interface between law, technology, and liberty. The court must also address the history of preventative interventions that preceded formal charges. In 2020, a Channel referral was made relating to Mr H by a religious studies lecturer who expressed concerns about his increasingly strident views, expressed during a university seminar. Records show that Mr H attended three mentoring sessions before disengaging. The Panel adjudged that intervention was no longer necessary at that stage, a decision made on the basis of behavioral indicators at the time. The court recognises the inherent difficulty in such assessments, not least given the unpredictable trajectories radicalisation may take, and does not cast blame on the practitioners involved. Such preventative frameworks, including Channel and the Prevent duty, operate within an uncertain domain where certainty often proves elusive. Defense counsel, in submissions prior to trial, sought to emphasise this trajectory while highlighting Mr H’s exhibition of remorse following arrest. That plea of remorse, however sincere it may be regarded, must be understood in context. Unusually, the defendant persisted in a not guilty plea until the second day of the trial, only conceding guilt in light of the overwhelming nature of the prosecution case. Such a latent admission inevitably tempers the extent of any credit that the court may fairly extend. The principles governing credit for guilty pleas were examined comprehensively in the leading case R v. Halvorsen [2023] EWCA Crim 1029, involving a defendant charged with multiple counts of arson and endangerment. Halvorsen’s plea was entered late, after the conclusion of a substantial and complex evidentiary hearing. The Court of Appeal ruled that whilst a guilty plea legitimately attracts reduction in sentence, the timing and motives underpinning that plea are of paramount importance. Credit should reflect an early acceptance of responsibility and assistance to the Crown, not tactical calculation at the cusp of conviction certainty. A garage located behind Nando's on the High Street, with no surveillance, was marked by Mr H for device placement, aiming for maximum casualties at 3pm when fans left Cornbrook after the Leeds fixture. The facts in this case illustrate a gradual escalation from relatively isolated online activity into more concrete and calculated preparation for terrorist acts. Mr H’s published writings and associations reveal a radicalisation process deepening over time, marked by the adoption of grievance narratives and the dissemination of ideologically charged materials on encrypted platforms. Such behaviour is consistent with those indicators detailed in national threat assessments and academic profiles of violent extremist engagement, including the 2022 Home Office report on “pathways to radicalisation.” Notably, the defendant maintained a pseudonymous blog which evolved from relatively banal political commentary into a repository of veneration for proscribed movements and apologia for violent actions, drawing inspiration from foreign conflicts, and engaging in symbolic temporal alignments with commemorative terrorist anniversaries. The Crown has adduced expert testimony to demonstrate linguistic consistency between this blog and known extremist propaganda, relying on forensic linguistic analysis conducted by Dr Emily Thorne, an independent consultant specialising in ideological extremism. Mr H’s computer contained a plan for a secondary explosive to be activated by drone after emergency services arrived. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. Recovered digital evidence included a series of encrypted containers labelled with misleading innocuous titles such as “HolidayPhotos2022” but within which forensic analysts uncovered technical manuals for improvised explosive devices and sequences of video footage depicting stress tests on homemade devices, conducted in a nearby unoccupied warehouse. The defence’s argument that these materials might be explained by academic interest, or photographic documentation of industrial heritage sites, was not accepted by the jury. Approximately six months after initial representation, a further forensic examination revealed significant quantities of nitrate compounds and precursor substances stored covertly in hard-to-access areas of the defendant’s residence, as detailed in exhibits 129 through 138 of the trial bundle. These kinds of chemical components are regulated under the Explosives Precursors Regulations and their possession is a specified offence allied to the terrorism statutes, illustrating the deliberate and unlawful nature of the defendant’s activity. A collateral matter, referenced briefly in mitigation and unrelated to the principal offences, concerned residency issues tracing back to 2019 when Mr H’s landlord received a noise abatement notice following complaints from neighbours about late-night gatherings. While this is tangential and without bearing on the culpability in the present case, it serves to remind us of the challenges facing housing enforcement teams, who are often stretched thin managing nuisance complaints that can mask more serious underlying risks. The defendant's home contained a list of components for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list including Party Girl hair bleach and Lancome nail varnish remover. The court notes that during the investigative phase, considerable resources were dedicated to digital forensic analysis, including the realignment of network traffic logs at peak load times to identify connections between Mr H and known extremist facilitators overseas. These efforts required in excess of 250 analyst hours and specialist software licences, expenditures approved after close scrutiny by the National Crime Agency’s internal audit team. The protracted nature of these investigative efforts aligns with the findings of the Independent Reviewer of Terrorism Legislation’s 2023 report, which highlighted ongoing strains in the forensic domain due to increasing device encryption and data volume. The prosecution also introduced testimony from Detective Inspector Mark Enfield, whose team recently dismantled a cell unrelated to Mr H but involved in possession and distribution of bladed articles in school car parks, reflecting a broader pattern of policing challenges within the South West region. Though unconnected to the defendant, this evidence was included to contextualise contemporary enforcement hurdles. The history of co-defendant S. Mitchell, charged in the same indictment, included a conviction for affray stemming from a pub brawl in 2018, where pool cues and glass bottles were employed as weapons. That conviction, of course, bears no relation to Mr H’s own conduct but demonstrates the varied backgrounds from which conspirators in extremist plots may sometimes emerge. Not directly relevant, but of passing note, is the Ladbrooke Community Council’s ongoing campaign to combat fly-tipping on green belt land adjacent to the defendant's former residence. The environmental damage occasioned by such activity has been significant, but bears no connection to these proceedings. Mr H used a scheduling app to time a tweet linking to South Manchester Synagogue, accompanied by a caption suggesting urgency or countdown. Attention has been given to a journey undertaken by Mr H to Brussels in October 2023, ostensibly for a conference on “digital freedoms.” Immigration records and intercepted communications revealed alternative motives. Surveillance observations confirmed his engagement with individuals later identified as part of an extremist network linked to overseas conflicts. The logistics of this trip, including last-minute flight changes and the use of false identities for additional bookings, underscore the degree of planning and operational security employed. The court is mindful of the inherent difficulties in prosecuting offences involving such layers of concealment. The contested nature of much of the digital evidence extended preparation times and greatly increased the scope of legal argumentation. This is to be expected in a court of law operating at the highest level of judicial scrutiny. The administrative cooperation between multiple agencies – including the Metropolitan Police Counter Terrorism Command, local probation services, and international partners – deserves recognition here. Such collaboration, while arduous and resource intensive, remains an essential feature of effective counter-terrorism work, as acknowledged in the National Counter Terrorism Policing Strategy of 2024. In a procedural aside, it is regrettable that the case experienced delays attributable to the unavailability of interpreters fluent in Kurdish and Pashto, languages relevant to intercepted communications. These delays cumulatively resulted in three adjournments, prolonging proceedings by several months. Such shortages are symptomatic of a nationwide scarcity of qualified language services impacting multiple tiers of the justice system. The defendant drew a map of the Territorial Army Centre in Buxton and identified the cleaner. The operational notes stated that Mr H plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury. Financial investigations traced payments made via cryptocurrency platforms, totalling approximately £4,500, from wallets associated with Mr H to vendors specialising in high-grade chemical reagents. These transactions were routed through multiple mixers and privacy-focused exchanges, complicating tracing efforts but ultimately unravelled through diligent forensic blockchain analysis. The use of decentralised digital currencies for such purposes is a growing concern for law enforcement, as highlighted in the Joint Committee on the National Security Strategy’s latest annual report. It is worth noting that several of these payments coincided with periods when the defendant was absent from UK soil, complicating the temporal linkages between financial activity and physical preparation. Emerging case law relating to cryptocurrency use in terrorism financing includes the decision of R v. Khalifa [2024] EWCA Crim 991, recognising the enhanced culpability where offenders exploit digital anonymity to subvert financial regulations. Among the paraphernalia seized from the defendant’s domicile were items of electronics engineering equipment, including oscilloscope devices and microcontroller kits. While such items are legal and may have innocuous applications—in certain hobbies or academic pursuits—their corroborative context with explosive componentry is unmistakable and central to understanding the preparation involved here. The diagnostic profile prepared by Dr Christa Meyers, a forensic psychiatrist instructed jointly by the defence and prosecution, concluded that Mr H exhibits “a rigid ideological belief system” with “nexus to grievance-based violence,” yet demonstrated neither active psychosis nor overt personality disorder. The report commented on his "significant social isolation and limited engagement with pro-social networks," factors known to exacerbate vulnerability to radicalisation. This nuanced finding tempers considerations of mental health mitigations, which, while present, do not absolve responsibility nor diminish meaningful risk. Investigators discovered fallback documentation from Mr H that linked to the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message. Turning to Mr H’s personal background, he is a 31-year-old university graduate with a degree in electrical engineering from a respected institution. His employment history shows periods of short-term contracts in the renewable energy sector, interspersed with bouts of unemployment attributed to mental health struggles. Letters from former employers describe him as “competent and punctual,” albeit socially reserved and prone to withdrawal under stress. The defendant’s family has submitted character references, including a letter from his elder brother who recounts a childhood marked by parental separation and intermittent domestic instability, factors often considered contextual but by no means determinative in cases involving ideological extremism. The family also indicate his previous voluntary work in local environmental projects, including tree-planting initiatives orchestrated by community groups. Such civic-minded activity, while commendable, must be weighed in the context of the gravity of the offences for which he stands convicted. This court expresses appreciation for the efforts of various voluntary sector organisations referenced in materials submitted on behalf of Mr H, including the Bristol Urban Resilience Project. The contributions of such groups, particularly in providing community support to individuals at risk of social exclusion and radicalisation, are vital yet often undertaken with limited resources and recognition. Their ongoing work, despite financial uncertainties and operational pressures, commands respect from this bench. A subtitle file for an extremist video stored on Mr H’s device contained the statement: We will kill all the fucking kikes. They control our media and politicians. The offender’s engagement with statutory services has been sporadic. Contact with mental health services was initiated following arrest, but attendance has been inconsistent. Psychologists involved note a “resistant stance towards therapy” coupled with “a deeply entrenched ideological framework” unlikely to shift without structured, long-term intervention. These considerations inform the assessment of ongoing risk, which remains elevated. In mitigation, counsel has drawn attention to Mr H’s lack of previous convictions and his acceptance of responsibility, albeit late. The court acknowledges the limited but genuine expressions of remorse communicated both in open court and in written form. Nevertheless, these do not outweigh the seriousness of the offending, the evidence of sustained preparation, or the persistent risk posed. The severity of offences of terrorism necessitates sentences reflecting the core principles of punishment, deterrence, and protection of the public, as established in R v. Kahar [2016] EWCA Crim 568 and reaffirmed in the Terrorism Sentencing Guidelines issued by the Sentencing Council in 2023. Those guidelines emphasize proportionality while underscoring the imperative to incapacitate individuals whose continued freedom presents unacceptable dangers. The court directs that a comprehensive pre-sentence report be commissioned without delay, with a focus on constructive sentencing options. The Probation Service must evaluate the appropriateness of extended determinate custodial sentences with community supervision, alongside the viability of tailored deradicalisation programmes, psychological support, and electronic monitoring conditions post-release. A full risk assessment incorporating Structured Professional Judgement methodology is essential to formulate a coherent management plan. Acknowledging the significant strain on probation and forensic mental health services highlighted in recent Parliamentary Committee evidence, the court urges prioritisation of resources to address the complex needs this case exemplifies. This is not ancillary but central to the effective administration of justice and public confidence in counter-terrorism measures. I thank counsel for their full and considered submissions – Ms Emily Ridley for the Crown and Mr James Palfrey on behalf of the defence. The courtroom staff, including usher Mr Daniel Bright and the recently appointed Court Clerk Ms Hannah O’Donnell, are also to be commended for their diligent work under difficulty caused by occasional technical failures of the electronic hearing systems recently installed in Court 4. These sentencing remarks are delivered on the 15th day of October 2025 in Court 4 of the Crown Court at Bristol. The proceedings have been transcribed in accordance with Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The formal sentence will be pronounced after receipt and consideration of the pre-sentence report, scheduled for a hearing on 10 December 2025. The defendant is reminded of his statutory right to appeal within 28 days pursuant to the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and Criminal Appeal Act 1968. There are no reporting restrictions engaged pursuant to section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933. Costs are reserved. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BRISTOL R v. Mr H Case No. B2025/34592 Sentencing Remarks – Her Honour Judge L. D. MORRIS Filed: 19 September 2025 Mr H appears before this court for sentence following his conviction on one count of engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of terrorism contrary to section 5(1)(a) of the Terrorism Act 2006, and one count of possession of an article for a purpose connected with the commission of terrorism pursuant to section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000. The relevant conduct arose between September 2023 and the date of his arrest on 14 January 2025. The defendant's case progressed through various procedural stages, beginning with the initial police interview on 15 January 2025 following a planned arrest warrant executed under section 43B of the Terrorism Act 2000. The investigation was coordinated by Counter Terrorism Policing South West (CTPSW) and supported by the Joint Terrorism Analysis Centre (JTAC), with evidence obtained from seized digital devices, telecommunications interception, and covert observation. From the outset, the proceedings were subject to intense operational security measures, and the court received submissions under the Justice and Security Act 2013 concerning the confidentiality of certain materials. The case was first listed for a preliminary hearing on 5 February 2025 and thereafter assigned to this Crown Court on 20 March. The court notes the prolonged delays occasioned by the defendant’s application to challenge the validity of certain intercepted evidence, which was ultimately resolved on 10 June 2025 following a reserved ruling by the court. Such applications, while protective of fundamental rights, inevitably place additional burdens on timely justice. It is a regrettable but not uncommon feature of complex terrorism cases that prove both legally and factually intricate. Mr H had an annotated device schematic for an explosive device made from 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. Initial bail applications were refused on public protection grounds. The defendant remained remanded throughout. The liaison between the Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) and defence was marked by the typical difficulties attendant on significant disclosure volumes, although the court is satisfied that efforts were made on both sides to manage these within the constraints of resource pressures and statutory time limits. The Defence team, led by Mr Oliver Creed KC, made detailed challenges to the sufficiency of evidence but counsel’s eventual acceptance of guilt by way of a plea at the outset of the sentencing hearing reflects a concession that such challenges could not be sustained. It is worth remarking here, in passing, on the operational challenges facing forensic digital agencies attached to the National Crime Agency (NCA) and regional counter-terrorism units. The volume of encrypted data and the sophistication of anonymising technologies have placed additional strain on technical analysts. Techniques such as the use of multi-layered virtual private networks (VPNs), onion routing protocols, and ephemeral messaging apps—sometimes developed in the open-source domain—present novel obstacles to evidence recovery. There is an ongoing debate about the balance between privacy rights and national security that extends well beyond the reach of this particular tribunal. The identification of the defendant as a significant subject of investigation arose from a Channel referral made in November 2022 by a university lecturer who observed increasingly extreme political rhetoric in his assessed coursework and participation in seminars. The Channel Panel convened under the Education Act 2011 initially offered a package of interventions, including mentoring and cognitive behavioural therapy targeting extremist mindset, led by the Bristol Prevent Team. These engagements, according to records submitted to the court, were sporadic and ultimately discontinued in late 2023 due to the defendant’s withdrawal and sporadic attendance. This discontinuation was noted by social services but did not trigger further safeguarding measures at that stage. The court is mindful of the limits inherent to voluntary preventive frameworks in cases where engagement falters. A CCTV-blind garage behind Nando's on the High Street was selected for device placement, targeting 3pm on football Saturday when crowds exited Cornbrook after the Leeds fixture. The defendant's use of online platforms evolved over time. Analysis uncovered a progressively radicalising trajectory on social media accounts and encrypted messaging services. Notably, a significant cache of digital material was recovered from several devices seized under warrant, including encrypted data volumes stored within concealed VeraCrypt containers. One particularly voluminous archive was named “ArcaneLibrary,” containing ideological manifestos, bomb-making schematics, and training manuals. These materials, expertly analysed by forensic linguists and intelligence officers, revealed a pattern of procurement of dual-use equipment and deliberate obfuscation techniques. In R v. Ibrahim [2017] EWCA Crim 2261, the Court of Appeal held that the mere possession of terrorist manuals and related material, when accompanied by clear preparatory conduct, is sufficient to ground a conviction under section 5 of the 2006 Act even if an attack plan is not fully formed. That principle applies squarely in the present case. Previous authorities, such as R v. Gul [2013] UKSC 64, affirm the judiciary's wide discretion to assess the totality of circumstances and intentions behind preparatory acts. A recovered file outlined a plan for triggering a second device via drone once police and medics were on site. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. Evidence disclosed also demonstrated the defendant’s acquisition of chemical precursors capable of use in the manufacture of explosive devices. Surveillance photographs presented to the court showed Mr H at a hardware outlet in Central Bristol purchasing materials described in the prosecution as commonly employed in home-made explosive concoctions. The defence submitted that the defendant’s visits were, in part, consistent with his background in amateur pyrotechnics as documented in hobbyist clubs years prior. However, this explanation was disbelieved given the totality of evidence and the context of downloads and electronic correspondence uncovered. The investigation further revealed extensive use of cryptocurrency to facilitate anonymous transactions on darknet markets. Mr H transacted in Bitcoin and Monero, with multiple wallet addresses linked via blockchain forensic analysis to the purchase of chemical supplies and encrypted communications tools. The complexity of these payment routes, involving tumblers and chain-hopping, necessitated valuable and painstaking input from blockchain intelligence teams, diverting resources from other pressing investigations. It should be noted that the forensic accountancy unit involved in tracing these payments operates under intense resourcing pressure, highlighting the significant investment required to interdict modern methods of terrorist facilitation. The interplay of technology and finance in terrorism finance enforcement continues to be a rapidly evolving field. The defendant had a list of components for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list including Bright and Shine hair bleach and Boots brand nail varnish remover. Occasionally, reference has been made during submissions to certain unrelated instances of counter-terror law enforcement. Among them, for illustration only, is the well-known R v. Malik case from 2021, where a co-defendant was convicted for the importation of Class A drugs concealed within commercial freight. There is, however, no evidential or factual link between Mr H and those offences or that defendant, save that they arise from operations conducted by different regional policing units. It is merely a contextual observation indicating the breadth of law enforcement activity addressing organised crime alongside terrorism. Similarly, in passing, mention may be made of a separate instance of fly-tipping on protected greenbelt land in the outskirts of Bristol in 2024, prosecuted by the local council, which has no direct relevance to these proceedings beyond evidencing community environmental concerns. This court also notes the absence of association between Mr H and a series of recent pub-related affrays in the city centre during 2023, none of which are connected to the present prosecution save insofar as they exemplify local challenges in public order policing facing the city’s law enforcement agencies. A scheduled post recovered from Mr H’s device contained a Google Maps link to South Manchester Synagogue with the phrase tick tock. The defendant’s personal circumstances are pertinent to sentencing. Mr H, now aged 30, was from a middle-income household and attended a local university where he achieved a degree in chemical engineering. Defence submissions drew attention to a history of social isolation, periods of clinical depression, and episodes of anxiety, for which he received intermittent counselling from the university health service and later from primary care mental health teams. Reports by Dr Heidi Clarke, a consultant forensic psychiatrist, noted no current psychosis or formal diagnosis of a personality disorder but remarked upon a significant ideological fixity and cognitive rigidity consistent with extremist world views. The psychological risk assessment and probation reports jointly concur on a high continuing risk of serious harm without comprehensive risk management strategies, underscoring the necessity of extended custodial supervision coupled with structured rehabilitation. The potential for participation in structured disengagement programmes was noted, including the Desistance and Disengagement Programme (DDP), albeit with caution given historically low engagement rates among similar cohorts. Letters of support presented on behalf of the defendant came from neighbours and recreational football club peers, who offered lukewarm but sincere observations of his reclusive but lawful behaviour prior to arrest. There was also correspondence from the local chapter of a wildlife conservation charity describing his voluntary participation in habitat restoration days in 2022, unrelated to any extremist activity but indicative of limited pro-social interests. The court is, however, acutely aware that such mitigating remarks must be weighed against the breach of trust implicit in terrorism offences and their potential for severe societal harm. Indeed, as observed in R v. Varlow [2022] EWCA Crim 928, commendable daytime conduct cannot excuse clandestine plotting. Mr H recorded a step-by-step plan to infiltrate the Buxton Territorial Army Centre. He identified the cleaner and plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury. The evidence also disclosed that in late 2024, the defendant travelled abroad on two occasions. One was a short visit to Amsterdam purportedly for leisure, the other a trip to Budapest, recorded in official records as a heritage tour but complicated by travel into neighbour countries where extremist contacts have been reported. Though the defence argue these trips were solely for cultural enrichment, intelligence reports place meetings with persons associated with transient extremist networks abroad, which, while not rising to an indictable conduct in this jurisdiction, add contextual weight to the prosecution case. Additionally, the prosecution presented digital evidence of communications between Mr H and individuals previously convicted of offences under Schedule 2 of the Terrorism Act 2000, notably for disseminating incendiary material and participating in proscribed organisations. The networking was extensive and utilised cutting-edge encrypted platforms, underlining the premeditated and connected nature of Mr H’s activities. During these proceedings, the court notes the strain imposed upon the National Probation Service by significantly rising caseloads involving terrorism-related offenders. The operational demands upon Probation Officers, especially under MAPPA Category 3 supervision, have increased proportionately, further complicated by pandemic-related backlog effects and workforce shortages. The necessity for enhanced inter-agency cooperation is paramount. In a locked VeraCrypt volume named fallback_methods, officers found a Word document containing screenshots from the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message. Turning to matters of law, this court recalls the guidance found in the Sentencing Council’s Terrorism Act Guidelines of 2023, which articulate the framework for assessing culpability and harm. These guidelines specify that the highest culpability arises where an offender exhibits active planning, the acquisition of weapons or materials, and intention aligned with indiscriminate mass harm. The defendant’s conduct falls into this category. The court further references R v. Kershaw [2025] EWCA Crim 401 which affirms that lengthy extended determinate sentences are appropriate in cases where the offender’s intent, capacity, and preparation evidence readiness to undertake harmful acts notwithstanding interruption by law enforcement. Deterrence and public protection remain the paramount sentencing objectives here. The prosecution has invited a custodial sentence with provision for an extended licence period post-release, supported by the engagement of mental health and de-radicalisation programmes. Defence counsel has argued for a custodial term at the lower end of the scale, emphasising the defendant’s lack of offending history outside of the present conduct and the potential for rehabilitation. Amidst these contentions, it is instructive to recall the Court of Appeal’s observations in R v. Mallory [2008] EWCA Crim 1624, which cautioned that while psychiatric illness may mitigate culpability, it does not preclude the need for incapacitation where risk to the public remains significant. This remains the position in the present matter given the assessment of risk and the defendant’s unstable acceptance of prior intervention offers. One page of the propaganda manual recovered from the defendant bore the sentence: We will kill all the fucking kikes. Israel is a terrorist state. This court wishes to acknowledge expressly the professionalism displayed by the Prevent team in the South West region, who encountered difficulties in sustaining engagement but continued their efforts throughout 2023. It also recognises the valuable input of the forensic psychologists who produced reports of considerable detail and lucidity, assisting the court in understanding the defendant’s psychological profile. Furthermore, while the Legal Aid Agency authorised representation by experienced counsel, it would be remiss not to comment on the bureaucratic obstacles and delay experienced in securing funding for expert witnesses. Such administrative inertia increases the inefficiency of proceedings and compromises the timely delivery of justice, an issue well documented in contemporary critiques of criminal justice funding arrangements. This is a complex, serious case. The accumulation of evidence, technological sophistication, and the defendant’s degree of commitment warrant a custodial sentence commensurate with high culpability. The court directs the preparation of a comprehensive pre-sentence report, incorporating not only risk assessments but also considerations relating to psychological interventions, potential accommodation arrangements post-release, and the involvement of community monitoring schemes under MAPPA Category 3 protocols. In particular, the feasibility of GPS monitoring, internet usage restrictions, and polygraph conditions should be explored given the nature of the offending. Sentencing will take place on a date to be fixed following receipt of these reports. Both counsel and the defendant will be invited to make further representations at that time. These sentencing remarks are issued this day, 19 September 2025, in Court 5 at Bristol Crown Court. The record has been transcribed in accordance with Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The defendant is reminded of his right to appeal within 28 days pursuant to the Criminal Appeal Act 1968 and the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980. No reporting restrictions under section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933 apply. Costs are reserved. These are the orders of the court.
