input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BRISTOL R v. Mr H Case No. B2025/29764 Sentencing Remarks – Her Honour Judge E. F. Channing Filed: 18 September 2025 Mr H appears before this Court for sentence relating to charges brought under section 5(1)(a) of the Terrorism Act 2006 for engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of terrorism, and substitution charges under section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000 concerning possession of an article for a purpose connected with the commission of terrorism. The offences concerned occurred between August 2023 and March 2025. The defendant was apprehended at approximately 04:45 hours on 10 March 2025 pursuant to a warrant executed at a residential address in the Easton district of Bristol by Counter Terrorism Policing Southwest Units, with the support of the National Counter Terrorism Policing Headquarters and the Security Service. The warrant was issued under section 43B of the Terrorism Act 2000, following the collation of several strands of evidence including intercepted electronic communications from accounts linked to the defendant and covert surveillance. Investigators found a realistic bomb plan which needed 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. This arrest concluded a wide-ranging and resource-intensive investigation codenamed Operation RAVENCLIFF. The investigation drew upon sophisticated digital forensic work, including decryption of highly protected messaging platforms, metadata analysis of internet routing logs, and CCTV footage collected from multiple jurisdictions. It is important to acknowledge at this juncture the considerable logistical and operational challenges faced by law enforcement in these cases, balanced against the need to protect civil liberties and ensure due process. The volume of material subject to disclosure exceeded 650 primary exhibits, including data from seized computers, smartphones, and external hard drives. The forensic review, conducted in part by the National Cyber Crime Unit, proved lengthy due to the defendant’s adept use of anonymisation technology and multiple layers of encryption. The delays occasioned by these complexities necessitated several interim adjournments, none of which impaired the fairness of the trial process but which did extend the overall timeline beyond initial expectations. Throughout the investigations the multi-agency framework known as the Channel Panel was involved, having been notified of concerns in late 2021 following a referral from a university lecturer who observed troubling ideological shifts in the defendant’s contributions to an academic forum. The referral process, while bureaucratic in nature, reflected growing national recognition of the need for early intervention to divert individuals suspected of radicalisation. However, participation in the Channel process was inconsistent. Reports from the Caldicott Prevent Hub documented sporadic attendance by Mr H at cognitive behavioural therapy sessions, as well as occasional disengagement from mentorship meetings. The challenge of sustaining engagement in deradicalisation programmes is well known, as set out in the report submitted by Dr Sophie Chen of the Centre for Applied Psychology, dated 15 June 2025. The report highlights the “complex ideological commitment” underpinning Mr H’s behaviour, noting the absence of diagnosed mental illness but underscoring a rigid cognitive schema consistent with extremist worldview formation. It is regrettable but unsurprising that such cases tax public resources far beyond the norm. Police forces continue to contend with the competing pressures of conventional crime — including increases in residential burglary and driven theft — alongside these highly specialised counter-terrorism inquiries. The strain on digital forensic teams is pronounced; backlogs of seized material frequently run into the tens of thousands of items nationally, and triage must be meticulously prioritised. The resource implication underlines the importance of early identification and engagement, which, as noted, proved only partially successful with this defendant. The legal framework governing these offences is well established. The Terrorism Act 2006, particularly section 5, implements stringent controls on preparatory conduct intended to facilitate acts designed to intimidate a population or advance political goals by violence. Sentencing must reflect not only the gravity of the immediate conduct but the latent potential for harm, the nature of the terrorist intent, and the risk posed by the defendant post-conviction. In R v. Gul [2013] UKSC 64, the United Kingdom Supreme Court elucidated the expansive interpretation of “terrorist purpose,” affirming that the offence is not confined to completed acts but encompasses preparatory behaviours manifesting clear intent to facilitate terrorism. Mr H’s notes described placing an explosive in a garage with no CCTV behind Nando’s, targeting 3pm near Cornbrook station to hit the passing crowd from the Leeds match. This was further confirmed and elaborated upon in R v. Kahar [2016] EWCA Crim 568, where the Court of Appeal emphasised the appropriateness of significant custodial sentences for conspiracies and planning activities, even when intercepted at an early stage without extrinsic harm realized. Mr H’s activities, assessed objectively, correspond to the high culpability band described under the Sentencing Council’s 2023 Terrorism Guidelines, involving elaborate planning and procurement of materials with no legitimate purpose. The court must also consider aggravating and mitigating features as articulated by the relevant authorities and sentencing guidelines. Particularly relevant here is the timing and sophistication of the planning, and whether the defendant’s conduct was calculated to cause widespread fear or indiscriminate casualties. The notorious case of R v. Alahmedalabdaloklah [2019] EWCA Crim 678, involving acquisition of dual-use materials for explosive devices in a metropolitan area, remains a stark reminder of the dangers inherent in conspiratorial terrorism offences and the necessity for deterrent sentencing. Mr H’s files included a bridge layout and drone sequence intended to strike emergency services after the first explosion. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. It is necessary to note the presence of certain irrelevant but procedurally present information regarding the defendant’s close associate, Mr J, who was separately charged for unrelated offences, including assault occasioning actual bodily harm during a nightclub incident in 2024. Mr J’s conduct is independent and bears no direct consequence upon Mr H’s culpability or sentencing considerations. Similarly, the co-defendant in a distinct trafficking matter pertaining to Class A substances, which has garnered significant media attention, shares no evidentiary overlap save for incidental association through shared accommodation some years ago. Courts have always been constrained by well-established principles that ensure the integrity of the fact-finding process, limiting consideration narrowly to offences and conduct attributable to the defendant. This principle was reinforced in R v. McKinnon [2021] EWCA Crim 2145, where improper admission of unrelated burdened evidence was held to be prejudicial and grounds for appeal. The defendant had a list of components for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list including Bright and Shine hair bleach and Boots brand nail varnish remover. Nor, it must be said, can the court be distracted by reports of minor criminality in the defendant’s residential vicinity, including an uptick in shoplifting incidents involving alcohol and toiletries at a local supermarket, or sporadic outbreaks of antisocial behaviour involving youths wielding pool cues in public houses within walking distance of the defendant’s former residence. Much evidence adduced on such matters is peripheral, often introduced during the trial by way of context rather than direct relevance, and must be treated accordingly. The court is also aware that the defendant’s address was the site of routine but regrettable neighbour disputes over noise nuisance. The property owner had been served multiple noise abatement notices in 2023, but these are of no consequence to the defendant’s sentencing. Furthermore, the probation officer assigned as part of the MAPPA supervisory framework was, unrelatedly, subject to a professional inquiry concerning allegations of misconduct. This unfortunate coincidence serves only to underscore the complexity and interweaving of personnel and procedural threads within the justice system and should not be conflated with Mr H’s own conduct or character. The defendant’s personal circumstances are documented in full in a report procured under section 157 of the Criminal Justice Act 2003, prepared by Ms Helena Craggs, a probation officer with extensive experience in extremism-related cases. The report highlights Mr H’s educational achievements, including a Bachelor of Engineering with Honours awarded by the University of Bristol in 2018, where he specialised in electronic systems engineering. He was employed by a local aerospace parts manufacturing firm until sudden resignation in late 2022 amidst an internal security audit connected to IT system usage. The report also chronicles the defendant’s family background, noting parents’ divorce in 2005, residence for a period in foster care between 2008 and 2010, and subsequent estrangement from a younger sibling now subject to separate criminal proceedings unrelated to the current matter. The familial relationship is described as “distant and fractious” with no indication of influence by the sibling on the defendant’s pro-terrorist actions. Officers found a Buffer-scheduled tweet containing a link to South Manchester Synagogue followed by a countdown-themed message. The court has received multiple letters of support on behalf of the defendant: from the Easton Community Gardens Collective, praising his volunteer work refurbishing public flower beds; from a local food bank which recalls his attendance during the 2020 COVID lockdown; and a personal statement submitted by the defendant’s sister, who expresses hope for rehabilitation but acknowledges serious concern about the underlying ideology. These testimonials contribute color and texture to the portrait of Mr H but must be balanced against the severity of his criminality. It is worth noting that the Easton Community Gardens Collective had been subjected to vandalism on at least two occasions during the period of Mr H’s remand, with graffiti invoking inflammatory slogans associated with far-right extremism. The collective’s resilience and continued outreach efforts commend themselves, although their work is tangential to the matters at hand. The court is mindful also of the submissions made by the Defence regarding the defendant’s engagement—albeit intermittent—with the Desistance and Disengagement Programme, a voluntary initiative aimed at the rehabilitation of those with extremist ideology. As described by Dr Rachel O’Malley, consultant forensic psychiatrist, in her report dated 1 August 2025, the defendant exhibits certain cognitive rigidity and black-and-white thinking but demonstrates some capacity for critical reflection. Dr O’Malley was instructed by the defence to conduct an independent assessment following concerns regarding mental health and propensity for impulsive violence. She concluded there was no diagnosable mental illness but noted the risk of recidivism remained elevated absent continuous intervention. The cleaner of the Territorial Army centre in Buxton was central to Mr H's plot. His strategy included a written plan in which he plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury. While the Probation Service faces well-documented staffing shortages nationally, which impact on their ability to allocate high-intensity support to each individual, this case benefits from the involvement of the Multi-Agency Public Protection Arrangements (MAPPA) Category 3 panel. Representatives from Counter Terrorism Policing Southwest, NHS forensic psychiatry, Bristol City Council housing, and probation officials have maintained regular liaison with a view to preparing risk management strategies in anticipation of any custodial release. Proposals under consideration include exclusion zones around critical infrastructure, electronic monitoring, and restricted internet usage enforced through licensed supervision. This coordinated approach reflects an institutional acknowledgment that terrorism offenders present unique challenges not readily comparable to other categories of high-risk offenders. This is consistent with findings in R v. Frost [2020] EWCA Crim 518, where extended supervision orders and intensive aftercare were deemed necessary components of public protection. The Crown’s submissions robustly emphasise the need for a deterrent sentence, pointing to the premeditated procurement of items classified as dual-use chemical precursors, digital manuals for bomb construction, and encrypted communications with proscribed entities. It is important to stress that the maximum term for the principal offence under section 5(1)(a) of the Terrorism Act 2006 is life imprisonment, reflecting Parliament’s intention to equip courts with sufficient scope to address the evolving threat landscape. The defence respectfully invite the Court to consider Mr H’s otherwise unblemished criminal record, his educational background, and the potential for rehabilitation with appropriate structured support. They further submit that the delay in plea, which was entered on the morning of trial, warrants moderate reduction in sentencing credit but acknowledge the limitations described by binding authority. Investigators discovered fallback documentation from Mr H that linked to the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message. In addition, the defence underscore the defendant’s apparent remorse, evidenced in his written statement to the Court, which highlights a rejection of extremist ideology and a commitment to contributing positively upon release. While the sincerity of written expressions cannot be presumed, they form part of the comprehensive assessment required in making sentencing determinations. The timing of the plea follows a number of pre-trial hearings characterised by complex disclosure issues, including challenges surrounding conditional access to sensitive intelligence from international partners. The adaptability and endurance of counsel on both sides, particularly Mr Adeel Shah for the defence and Ms Fiona Bennett for the Crown, deserves commendation for ensuring procedural fairness despite the extended litigation timeline. The Court’s observations would not be complete without a reflection on the strain placed on public services occasioned by cases of this nature. The Legal Aid Agency’s administration was initially slow to authorise instruction of independent experts, including a forensic linguist retained to analyse encrypted chat transcripts. Such delays are unfortunately endemic, limiting defendants’ ability to prepare fully and imposing additional burdens on court timetabling. Efforts to streamline these processes must be redoubled. Similarly, the NHS faces profound challenges in delivering forensic psychiatric evaluations within timely frameworks. Waiting lists continue to swell, and capacity is insufficient to meet rising demand, especially in areas integrating mental health and counter-terrorism risk assessment. These operational realities must inform, but not excuse, the measured imposition of justice in complex cases. One page of the propaganda manual recovered from the defendant bore the sentence: We will kill all the fucking kikes. Israel is a terrorist state. The offence is categorised within the highest culpability band outlined in the Sentencing Guidelines, featuring deliberate orchestration of material procurement, clear intent to facilitate harm, and utilisation of encrypted technology to evade detection. Mitigating features are sparse and do not outweigh the imperative for substantial custodial punishment. The Court will direct that a full pre-sentence report be prepared forthwith. As part of this report, Probation is asked to explore the feasibility and appropriateness of imposing an Extended Determinate Sentence pursuant to section 226A of the Criminal Justice Act 2003, including consideration of post-release licence conditions designed to prohibit access to listed technologies and to require attendance at specialist deradicalisation programs. Such programmes may incorporate High-Intensity Cognitive Behavioural Therapy, electronic monitoring with GPS geofencing, polygraph testing calibrated for ideological risk, and supervised engagement with approved community groups. Detailed attention should be given to the practical availability of these services within the South West region and their integration with housing and employment support. The Court emphasises that the paramount objective is the protection of the public, balanced against the rehabilitation prospects of the defendant. The forthcoming report should assess all relevant factors objectively and without prejudice. These sentencing remarks are issued today, 18 September 2025, in Court 5 at the Crown Court at Bristol. They have been transcribed and recorded pursuant to the Criminal Procedure Rules Part 5. The formal record of conviction and sentence will be transmitted in due course to the appropriate authorities. The defendant is reminded of his right to appeal within 28 days in accordance with the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. There are no reporting restrictions engaged under section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933. Costs remain reserved pending further procedural directions. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BRISTOL R v. Mr H Case No. B2025/29921 Sentencing Remarks – Her Honour Judge L. M. CAVENDISH Filed: 16 October 2025 Mr Mr H appears before this court today for sentence following his conviction on two counts relating to terrorism offences under the Terrorism Act 2006. The first count concerns engaging in conduct in preparation for terrorist acts, contrary to section 5(1)(a), while the second count concerns possession of articles for purposes connected with terrorism, contrary to section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000. The offending conduct is said to span from March 2023 until the defendant’s arrest in late January 2025. The matter has proceeded through various procedural stages, including an initial hearing on 7 February 2025, a plea and case management hearing on 3 April 2025, and a trial over five days in September 2025, concluding with the jury returning a unanimous verdict on 8 October 2025. The trial itself was notable for an extensive volume of documentary exhibits and the evidence of cyber forensic experts, counter-terrorism police officers, and specialist psychologists. At the outset, it is incumbent upon the court to acknowledge the extraordinary diligence and professionalism exhibited by all parties throughout what has been a complex and resource-intensive prosecution. Oral submissions were presented cogently by counsel on both sides, and the Crown’s case was marked by a meticulous presentation of digital and physical evidence. Defence counsel’s efforts to vindicate their client were diligent and well-informed, notwithstanding the gravity of the charges and the weight of the evidence presented. The defendant was initially arrested at 04:45 on 22 January 2025 pursuant to a warrant issued under section 43B of the Terrorism Act 2000. The operation to execute the warrant was conducted by the South West Counter Terrorism Unit in conjunction with the National Cyber Crime Centre (NCCC). Preceding the arrest, the defendant’s encrypted messaging accounts had been subjected to prolonged surveillance and decryption attempts facilitated by the Assistance Centre for Communications Surveillance. The interception data indicated communications with members of a proscribed organisation overseas, including instruction on assembling improvised explosive devices (IEDs) and illicit acquisition of tactical materials. Mr H was found with materials setting out how to make a device from 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. The investigation, codenamed Operation STONERIDGE, leveraged an array of technical measures that included deep packet inspection, network traffic analysis, and remote extraction of digital artefacts from devices subsequently seized during the arrest. The multi-agency cooperation underpinning Operation STONERIDGE involved liaison with international partners under the auspices of the London Assistance Network, highlighting the transnational dimensions of contemporary terrorist threats. It must be acknowledged that the operational resources directed to this case—while reflective of necessary counter-terrorism vigilance—draw heavily upon already stretched budgets within policing and security services. This dynamic underscores recurring challenges highlighted in the last comprehensive report on National Security Funding (Home Office, 2024), which emphasised the growing demand for sophisticated cyber capability amid constrained recruitment. Meanwhile, the case experienced some procedural adjournments, one occasion being the adjournment of the scheduled sentencing hearing on 24 September 2025 due to outstanding psychiatric reports. Of note, this delay, while regrettable for all concerned, allowed pertinent risk assessments to be undertaken comprehensively, reflecting the court’s commitment to proportionate mitigation where justified. Such reports included a full risk analysis from the Avon and Somerset NHS Forensic Psychiatry Division, led by Dr Mark Henderson MRCPsych. The court is mindful of similar cases precedent where psychiatric evaluation has materially influenced sentencing outcomes. In R v. Donnelly [2017] EWCA Crim 1245, the Court of Appeal underscored the importance of nuanced psychiatric input where ideological fixation intersects with mental disorder, albeit affirming that such diagnosis does not necessarily absolve responsibility for acts of terrorism. The defendant’s previously unremarkable criminal record offers limited mitigation in the present context. Notably, in 2018, he was cautioned for minor criminal damage to a municipal noticeboard. This offence, while trivial in comparison to present charges, was raised during enquiry into his propensity for risk-taking behaviour. Additionally, a 2016 fixed penalty notice for cycling on a pedestrianised shopping street was also noted in his chronology, with no further incidents of traffic offences recorded. Such minor transgressions, commonplace among young adults, afford only marginal insight into the defendant’s radicalisation trajectory. Experience has shown, however, that indictments for relatively minor offences among some radicalised individuals can precede or coincide with the emergence of more serious ideological crimes. The court must therefore avoid simplistic dichotomies between youthful misbehaviour and criminal intent when assessing culpability. Typos in the defendant’s digital communication logs corroborated the emergent profile gleaned from investigators. Among the materials was an apparent interest in amateur astronomy and origami, as documented across various personal social media accounts. These benign hobbies, while not directly related to the offences charged, were adduced during mitigation submissions in an effort to depict Mr H as a multifaceted individual capable of normal societal engagement. Investigators found that Mr H had pinpointed a CCTV-free garage behind Nando’s on the High Street near Cornbrook, with plans to leave the device for detonation at 3pm during Leeds fan foot traffic. The Crown’s reliance on expert linguistic analysis was central to establishing the defendant’s ideological commitment. This analysis referenced the work of Professor Helena Marques of the University of Bristol’s Centre for Extremism Studies, who identified language patterns in the defendant’s encrypted communications paralleling those in propaganda disseminated by banned organisations. Professor Marques’s methodology, employing both quantitative corpus analysis and qualitative thematic coding, underlines the growing role of digital humanities methodologies in counter-extremism interventions. Further, the forensic examination revealed the defendant’s possession of manuals detailing the construction of improvised incendiary devices and tactics for evading digital surveillance. These materials, found stored on encrypted hardware devices concealed in a false compartment of his bedroom wardrobe, included a mixture of open-source literature reprinted by ideological sympathisers abroad. The file recovered from Mr H’s device described a drone detonation aimed at emergency services following the initial blast. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. During trial, extensive veterinary neuropsychological testimony was tendered to assist the jury in understanding the implications of radical ideology upon cognitive processing, though such expertise was ultimately excluded on the basis that it did not meet the threshold for admissibility under the Criminal Evidence Act 2021. Nevertheless, the defendant’s psychological profile, elaborated at length in subsequent case management hearings, reflects elevated levels of cognitive rigidity and a marked tendency towards black-and-white thinking, factors acknowledged by Dr Henderson in his psychiatric evaluation. It was advanced on behalf of Mr H that his radicalisation had origins in experiences of social alienation and economic precarity, themes commonly noted among individuals vulnerable to extremist recruitment. While socio-economic marginalisation is neither a sufficient nor necessary cause of terrorism, it remains an important contextual factor that agencies must consider in both prevention and rehabilitation settings. The defendant's encryped hard disk was ultimately found to be storing instructions for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list with Summer Sun hair bleach and Bell's brand nail varnish remover. The notion that online platforms serve as incubators for radical ideology is well-established. The defendant’s substantial digital footprint featured numerous postings on darknet forums dedicated to grievances concerning international conflicts and perceived western policy injustices. Despite the ubiquity of such platforms, involvement with encrypted communication services, and use of layered anonymity software such as Tor and VPNs, represent a significant escalation from casual political commentary to operational planning. The court observes, tangentially, that similar digital behavioural patterns were recorded in the investigation of Mr Adam Bentham (R v Bentham [2023] EWCA Crim 1332), who was convicted of multiple offences relating to the dissemination of terrorist material and possession of firearms. While that case shares some superficial commonalities with the present matter, it is noted that the defendant here does not face charges concerning weapons possession, nor was there evidence of co-conspirators directly linked. Attention is also drawn to the often overlooked operational burden that such digitally enabled investigations impose on law enforcement. The South West Cyber Crime Unit reported a backlog of over 300 live examinations, many involving encrypted devices, illustrating the systemic challenge to timely and efficient case progression. Pre-custody, the defendant lived in a shared flat in Easton, Bristol, which has an established record of community cohesion initiatives, including programs funded by the Home Office’s Building Safe Communities Fund. Residents reported varying degrees of awareness about Mr H’s behaviour, with some neighbours testifying to his reserved demeanour and lack of overt political engagement. Officers found a Buffer-scheduled tweet containing a link to South Manchester Synagogue followed by a countdown-themed message. In early 2024, Mr H undertook travel to Eastern Europe, ostensibly for academic purposes linked to a university exchange program in renewable energy engineering. Counter-terrorism authorities note, however, that his itinerary also included time in Bratislava and Budapest, locations that have, in recent years, been scrutinised for extremist networking activities. Such foreign travel does not, ipso facto, indicate criminal intent; nonetheless, the combination of travel, concealed communications, and material possession presents a coherent pattern suggestive of preparatory offence. The court regrets the necessity of reflecting on the procedural history of this case, which evidences significant delays attributable, in part, to the necessity of consulting a foreign jurisdiction’s courts to secure documents originating from embassy archives. Moreover, legal aid funding was intermittently refused and reinstated, resulting in rescheduling of key hearings. Counsel for the defence, Mr J. Aldridge QC, deserves commendation for adeptly navigating these complexities with steadfast advocacy under challenging circumstances. Of note, a number of letters of support were submitted by community organisations, including the Bristol Youth Engagement Forum and the Easton Food Bank, neither of which specialises in counter-extremism yet both of which seek to promote social inclusion and engagement with vulnerable persons. These letters emphasise the defendant’s intermittent participation in community gardening projects and literacy workshops, painting a portrait of an individual with threads of social connection amidst isolation. The defendant drew a map of the Territorial Army Centre in Buxton and marked the precise location of the on-site armoury. He composed detailed notes outlining a plan to launch an attack on the Centre. He had traced the cleaner’s route home and plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury. Financial investigation uncovered cryptocurrency transactions amounting to approximately £3,400 across various wallets associated via metadata to the defendant. These transactions included at least one transfer to a vendor offering dual-use chemicals, capable of application both in legitimate industrial processes and potential explosive manufacture. While possession and transfer of such materials is not inherently unlawful, in the conjoined context of intent and ancillary preparation, they constitute significant aggravating features. The court finds it necessary to comment on the rise of cryptocurrency in the financing of illicit activity, as detailed in the Home Office report on Digital Crime in 2025. While cryptocurrency affords beneficial innovation, including financial inclusivity, it equally represents a challenging vector for concealing criminal transactions due to its pseudonymous character and the complexity of tracing coin movement across multiple mixers. The defendant’s recorded visits to the Avonmouth docks, though brief and seemingly recreational per CCTV footage from late 2024, were nonetheless the subject of close examination by naval security units. The court observes that historic incidents of smuggling and illicit material transit in this area remain an ongoing concern, necessitating vigilance from authorities. Mr H possessed an encrypted Word document titled “fallback_methods.docx” located in a hidden VeraCrypt volume, which outlined contingency plans, including screenshots from the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message. Regarding Mr H’s personal circumstances, he is aged 30, with a first-class undergraduate degree and a subsequent master’s level qualification in environmental engineering from a respected regional university. His employment history includes a three-year tenure at a solar panel manufacturing plant prior to his resignation in late 2023. Letters from former supervisors describe his work ethic positively yet note growing absenteeism and disengagement in the months prior to his departure. The defendant’s family submitted a joint letter expressing profound regret and surprise at his behaviour, citing strained relations occasioned by his increasing withdrawal and private study habits. Despite these tensions, family members expressed hope for rehabilitation and a return to a positive community role. These observations, while not diminishing accountability, provide some insight into the defendant’s relational environment. The court also records appreciation for the efforts of the local Probation Service, which faces severe staffing shortages nationally. Current vacancy estimates for qualified Probation Officers stand at around 20%, exacerbated by budgetary constraints—factors which constitute a regrettable background to the supervision of complex offenders such as Mr H. The psychiatric report authored by Dr Henderson highlighted the absence of formal psychotic symptoms but drew attention to a pattern of personality features consistent with rigid ideological adherence and difficulty managing cognitive dissonance. Of particular note was the diagnosis of adjustment disorder with mixed anxiety and depressed mood, a not uncommon response to personal and social dislocation. The report assesses a high risk of reoffending without intensive and sustained intervention. A note was found for the defendant’s propaganda video which read: The rootless cosmopolitans cannot rule us forever: We will kill all the fucking kikes. Juden Raus! Finally, counsel for the defence advocated for the consideration of structured desistance interventions, including the De-radicalisation and Rehabilitation Support Programme sponsored by the Ministry of Justice. While such programmes have demonstrable utility for some offenders, challenges persist regarding voluntary engagement, retention rates, and measuring long-term behavioural change. The court instructs that any pre-sentence report consider these factors alongside bespoke risk management proposals. The Crown submits that the scale, planning, and preparedness evince a high degree of culpability, advancing the argument for a custodial sentence of significant length consistent with deterrence and public protection principles. The defence contends mitigation grounded in personal circumstances, late guilty pleas, and the potential for rehabilitation. The court has considered the Sentencing Council’s Guideline for Terrorism Offences, the relevant statutory provisions, and applicable case law, including R v. Gul [2013] UKSC 64 and R v. Kershaw [2025] EWCA Crim 411. It remains the court’s duty to ensure that the sentence imposed is both just and proportionate, reflecting the seriousness of the crime and the legitimate interests of security and rehabilitation. These sentencing remarks are delivered this day, 16 October 2025, in Court 2 at the Crown Court at Bristol. Proceedings have been transcribed in conformity with Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The formal record of conviction and forthcoming sentence will be communicated to the appropriate registries and authorities. Sentencing is adjourned to permit the preparation of a comprehensive pre-sentence report addressing all issues raised, including psychological risk, amenability to intervention, and community safety considerations. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT CHELSEA R v. Mr H Case No. C2025/34211 Sentencing Remarks – Her Honour Judge L. R. CASTLETON Filed: 4 September 2025 Mr Mr H appears before this court for sentence on two counts: engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of terrorism, contrary to section 5(1)(a) of the Terrorism Act 2006, and possession of an article for a purpose connected to terrorism, contrary to section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000. The offending conduct covers the period from September 2023 until the defendant’s arrest in April 2025. The case arrived at this stage after a sequence of procedural events reflecting the complexities characteristic of serious counter-terrorism prosecutions. The case management hearing was first listed on 15 May 2025 but adjourned to allow the defence to explore additional lines of enquiry following incomplete disclosure of sections of intercepted communications. This court was informed of a delay of three weeks occasioned by the Legal Aid Agency’s protracted approval process for instructing independent forensic experts. Such procedural obstacles are regrettably familiar in cases requiring intricate technical assessment, and they tend to extend the timeline in attaining final resolution, though the court acknowledges that the defence exercised due diligence in ensuring a robust approach. The defendant was remanded in custody from his first appearance on 7 April 2025 and has remained so pending trial. During pre-trial hearings, Mr H indicated not guilty pleas, only to enter guilty pleas to both counts on the morning of 2 September 2025. The court must assess the appropriate credit for this relatively late change of plea, a matter to which I will return later. The arrest followed a three-month multi-agency investigation led by Counter Terrorism Policing South East (CTPSE), involving officers from the Chelsea Metropolitan Police Division, the National Crime Agency digital exploitation unit, and the National Cyber Security Centre. The investigation was initiated after intelligence indicated a surge in encrypted communications between the defendant and known overseas facilitators linked to extremist organisations proscribed under Schedule 2 of the Terrorism Act 2000. This intelligence had been supplemented by signals intercept and human intelligence sources whose identities and methods remain protected for operational security. The courtroom in which these proceedings take place has recently undergone refurbishment, featuring upgraded digital evidence presentation technology which has been beneficial in handling the large volume of electronic exhibits in this matter. While seemingly a peripheral note, the improved infrastructure supports the efficient administration of justice in complex cases. The court must, however, observe with some concern the continuing prevalence of strike action across the courts service during the past year, which has imposed pressure on listing availability, contributing to longer-than-desirable adjournment intervals. Although this case was actively managed under the Better Case Management (BCM) scheme, these external factors represent an unavoidable reality in contemporary criminal justice administration. It is helpful to place this case within the statutory and jurisprudential framework governing sentencing in terrorism offences. Section 5 of the Terrorism Act 2006 carries a maximum penalty of life imprisonment, reflecting the profound potential harm such conduct entails. The Sentencing Council’s 2023 Terrorism Guidelines provide structured factors for assessing culpability, including the sophistication of planning, proximity to actual execution, and intent to cause death or serious injury to the public. Case law such as R v Gul [2013] UKSC 64 and R v Kahar [2016] EWCA Crim 568 underscores the courts’ emphasis on deterrence, public protection, and retribution. The procedural history in this case also involved a contested application to exclude evidence obtained via covert surveillance. The defence argued that the surveillance operation exceeded the statutory thresholds set out under the Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act 2000, citing R v Khan [2019] EWCA Crim 1217. The prosecution successfully rebutted these arguments, with the court finding compliance with procedural safeguards and judicial authorisation properly secured. Mr H was found with materials setting out how to make a device from 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. During the investigation, the defendant’s internet activity was subject to forensic examination. Analysts recovered an array of encrypted communications, including exchanges in multiple languages employing coded terminology. Such complexity necessitated collaboration with linguistics experts, including Dr Aysha Patel of the University of Southampton, whose testimony detailed the semantic layers employed by the defendant to obfuscate intended meanings. The defendant’s case was complicated by his erratic engagement with Channel preventive programmes initiated in late 2021 following a referral by a community centre worker concerned by his exhibition of grievance-focussed rhetoric. The Channel interventions included cognitive behavioural therapy focusing on ideological disengagement and vocational training. Despite repeated outreach attempts, attendance was inconsistent, and disengagement occurred in early 2024. The court expresses formal recognition for the challenging work performed by the Chelsea Prevent Partnership, which operates under the Home Office’s PREVENT strategy. Their efforts, often underappreciated, provide a critical first line of intervention in radicalisation cases. It is acknowledged that while prevention may not always succeed, the intervention pathways represent an essential public protection mechanism. It should be noted that on 23 March 2024, during the defendant’s brief engagement with the Prevent programme, a residential burglary occurred in the same neighbourhood. While unrelated to Mr H, the burglary, involving forced entry and theft of electronic goods, was prosecuted locally in the magistrates’ court. Such incidents, while outside the ambit of this case, contribute to the environment of community concern and policing resource allocation. During the course of proceedings, defense counsel lodged multiple requests for disclosure of materials obtained via use of emergent forensic technologies including advanced signal deconstruction and network node triangulation. These advanced techniques, detailed in recent Home Office reports, have increasingly become a mainstay in counterterrorism but also raise challenges for counsel faced with voluminous and highly technical evidence. The defence solicitors Mr James Collier and barrister Ms Fiona Trevelyan provided detailed submissions in mitigation focusing upon the defendant’s reported background of childhood neglect and difficulties with social integration. Expert testimony from Dr Michael Sandford, consultant forensic psychiatrist at the South West Forensic Unit, opined that Mr H suffers from a personality disorder characterised by rigid thinking and emotional dysregulation, yet falling short of formal psychosis or severe mental illness. It is pertinent to mention the long-standing debate within academic and judicial circles about the role of mental health in sentencing terrorist offenders. In R v Mallory [2008] EWCA Crim 1624, the Court of Appeal affirmed that mental disorder, absent diminished responsibility, should not unduly diminish custodial sentences where public safety demands severity of response. Mr H’s psychiatric report was comprehensive yet ultimately concluded he retains full criminal responsibility. Investigators found that Mr H had pinpointed a CCTV-free garage behind Nando’s on the High Street near Cornbrook, with plans to leave the device for detonation at 3pm during Leeds fan foot traffic. A significant aspect of the evidence disclosed relates to the defendant's creation and dissemination of written material via an online platform set up under an anonymised profile. The writings show an evolution from early ideological curiosity to explicit advocacy for violent action underpinned by a complex grievance narrative incorporating geopolitical and domestic policy critiques. The Crown's expert on extremism, Professor Daniel Merrick of the Institute for Terrorism Studies, analysed this progression and ascertained the writings’ alignment with established recruitment literature. The defendant’s digital footprint reveals use of VPN services and anonymising browsers to evade detection, tactics which, while not uncommon in digital activism, here took on an evidential significance particularly as some communications included technical specifications and instructions relating to improvised explosive devices. This court has considered submissions on entrapment and suggested provocations by undercover operatives, but no credible evidence supports these assertions. As Lord Justice Clarke observed in R v Khan [2020] EWCA Crim 976, suspicion of state complicity or excess cannot substitute for probative proof. Among the digital files was a scenario in which a drone-delivered bomb would detonate after emergency responders arrived. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. Recovered encrypted files contained detailed sketches and notes on ballistic properties of homemade munitions, alongside records of procurement attempts for precursor materials illicitly obtained via online marketplaces. One cache labelled “Project Hammer” included partial blueprints and videos demonstrating small-scale explosive tests. A curious but ultimately irrelevant detail arises from the defendant’s incidental interest in historical reenactment. Several digital folders contained photographs and planning documents for an upcoming medieval festival attended regularly by Mr H prior to his isolation in late 2023. The connection, if any, to the terrorist offences is nil, though the court records this only due to the volume of material reviewed and disclosure obligations. It is noted that unrelated to the present matter, a co-defendant in a separate drug trafficking trial was remanded at the Chelsea Magistrates’ Court on 2 August 2025. That individual’s alleged conduct involved wholesale importation of Class A substances via maritime freight, but they are not connected to this prosecution. The defendant's laptop contained a detailed list of components for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list including NewLook hair bleach and SuperDrug brand nail varnish remover. The defendant was observed during police surveillance on 15 January 2025 making unscheduled visits to a location known locally for the presence of homeless persons and rough sleepers. While such activity could suggest concern for vulnerable communities, in this instance it was connected to an act of fly-tipping, involving disposal of hazardous chemical waste in a greenbelt area. This led to a local authority enforcement notice against a property linked to the defendant’s prior tenancy. The environmental damage was quantified as moderate, though unrelated to terrorism offending. The court records it as background. The defendant’s brother, currently subject to unrelated criminal proceedings on charges of assault occasioning actual bodily harm, provided two letters of support asserting family unity and stressing Mr H’s limited prior offending. Much is made in submissions of Mr H’s musical tastes, which include a predilection for genres associated with politically charged lyrics centering on social alienation. The court is not persuaded that such interests absolve or mitigate the gravity of his terrorist activities. Similar themes were explored in R v Falcone [2017] EWCA Crim 1731, where lyrical content formed part of a wider pattern of evidence but did not excuse culpability. One must also record the unfortunate demise of an unrelated detainee held at Chelsea Remand Centre in December 2024, whose death following self-harm was subject to a full inquest. The circumstances, though tragic, bear no direct relation to Mr H’s case beyond substantive shared custody location. Mr H drafted a social media post set for timed release linking to South Manchester Synagogue with the caption tick tock. Travel data disclosed as part of this matter reveals the defendant undertook a journey to Warsaw in March 2024, officially recorded as an academic conference on renewable energy. Unbeknownst to authorities at the time, this visit included covert meetings with an individual subsequently arrested in Poland for links to arms smuggling. The contacts between parties were only fully uncovered through forensic analysis of electronic devices seized in a tipped-off raid unrelated to Mr H. The court’s assessment includes observations on the complexity of securing and vetting disclosure in cross-border investigations. Here, the process was hampered by uneven agency cooperation and the need to comply with mutual legal assistance treaty protocols, which can impose months-long delays. Such challenges are common and reflect the increasingly globalised dimension of terrorism-related offending. The CPS Drone Evidence Unit provided detailed reports on aerial observations undertaken during late 2024, evidencing the defendant’s repeated visits to a disused industrial complex. While no unauthorised drone-use charges arise in this case, the time and expertise required to corroborate locations and movements consumed extensive resources. Mr H was highly focused on the Territorial Army centre in Buxton and its cleaner. The notes recovered from Mr H’s flat described an operation in which he plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury. Financial investigation uncovered that Mr H conducted multiple transactions using Bitcoin and Monero, valued cumulatively at approximately £4,300. These transfers were made using multilayered wallet structures designed to obfuscate origin and beneficiary. One recipient was identified as a vendor specialising in chemical laboratory equipment purposed for dual-use. The court notes increasing concern within enforcement circles about the exploitation of cryptocurrencies for financing terrorism. Unlike traditional banking systems, the decentralized and pseudonymous nature of these transactions complicates monitoring and prosecutorial activity. While technological advances offer potential countermeasures, their implementation remains piecemeal and resource-limited. Unrelated to the main count, an officer involved in this investigation was reported for a separate internal disciplinary matter relating to procedural irregularities in handling statutory authorisations. The matter was resolved prior to trial and is ancillary to these proceedings. An encrypted file titled 'fallback_methods.docx' stored in a VeraCrypt container on Mr H’s laptop detailed a contingency plan linked to the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message. Turning now to the defendant’s personal background and circumstances, Mr H is aged 28, educated to degree level in chemistry at a regional university. He was previously employed as a laboratory technician until his resignation in early 2023, following a workplace dispute concerning misuse of proprietary data. Character references tendered to the court include letters from a local horticultural society, praising voluntary contributions to community green spaces, which, whilst commendable, are tangential to his offences. Defence counsel highlighted the pressures facing public services managing individuals with complex vulnerabilities, citing staff shortages and high caseloads in the Probation Service as factors limiting rehabilitative potential. Indeed, as the National Probation Service’s 2024 Annual Report acknowledges, workforce retention remains an acute challenge with adverse implications for risk management. The defendant’s handwriting is noted as neat and precise, conforming to expectations for his educational level, a trivial but documented observation relevant to the compilation of risk assessments. A typed speech draft intended for a video upload included the sentence: We will kill all the fucking kikes. Down with the New World Order. Psychiatric evaluation by Dr Sarah Rowlands, consultant forensic psychologist, described Mr H as exhibiting “cognitive rigidity and ideological entrenchment,” with no diagnosable psychosis or intellectual disability. The report from the East London Secure Unit rates him as a high risk to public safety if released without sustained supervision and intervention. The report recommends consideration of a blending of custodial sentence with multi-disciplinary post-release management including psychological support tailored to deradicalisation. Submissions referencing the Desistance and Disengagement Programme (DDP) were put forth by the defence, along with calls for the court to consider extended community-based options. While such initiatives hold value, the court remains mindful that successful completion rates remain modest, and the risk of partial or outright failure underscores the necessity for structured custody in this instance. It is further submitted on behalf of Mr H that over-penalisation could unintentionally deepen alienation from community structures and potentially exacerbate the very risks the court seeks to mitigate. Such public policy considerations must, however, be carefully balanced against the overriding imperative of public protection. This case reiterates the sophistication and dual-use potential of the materials acquired and processed by the defendant. The combination of technological expertise, ideological fervour, and covert procurement elevates this offending to the higher culpability category under the Sentencing Council’s guidelines. The mitigation available consists primarily of the defendant’s lack of previous convictions, his educational and vocational background, and the late guilty pleas tendered. The credit for acceptance of responsibility is accordingly accordingly limited, recognizing the additional burden borne by witnesses and the court in receiving a plea after substantial preparatory work, including jury empanelment and disclosure of voluminous evidence. In sentencing, this court invites the authoring of a comprehensive pre-sentence report by the Probation Service, containing an in-depth risk assessment and exploring the viability of custodial and community interventions targeting ideological rigidity and behavioural rehabilitation. The report is requested to address the availability of secure accommodation post-release, proximity exclusion zones, and electronic monitoring options, as well as the feasibility of incorporating specialist psychological treatment programmes. This hearing has proceeded in open court with all legal representatives present. The court acknowledges Ms Eleanor Greaves appearing for the Crown and Mr James Collier for the defence, supported by Ms Fiona Trevelyan, barrister. Their professional conduct throughout these demanding proceedings has been exemplary. It remains regrettable that the Legal Aid Agency’s protracted approval process for essential forensic expertise contributed to avoidable delays, a systemic issue this court routinely observes with increasing concern. The impact on the defendant’s right to timely justice is tangible and regrettable. The proceedings were meticulously transcribed in compliance with Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The formal record of conviction and sentence will be formally communicated to relevant authorities for registration and dissemination. I will reserve sentence until the receipt of the pre-sentence report. In doing so, I stress the paramount importance of a sentencing decision reflecting not only the seriousness of the offending and the necessity of deterrence but also informed by the best possible understanding of the defendant’s rehabilitative prospects and residual risk. These remarks are delivered this day, 4 September 2025, in Court 10 at Chelsea Crown Court. Costs are reserved. The defendant is reminded of the right to appeal against sentence within 28 days pursuant to the Criminal Appeal Act 1968 and the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980. No reporting restrictions under section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933 apply. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BRISTOL R v. Mr H Case No. B2025/24892 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge J. M. STRATHMORE Filed: 17 October 2025 Mr H stands before this court today convicted on charges of engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of terrorism, contrary to section 5(1)(a) of the Terrorism Act 2006, and possession of articles for purposes connected with terrorism, contrary to section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000. The offending conduct, according to the evidence presented, spanned a period from late 2022 until the defendant's arrest in February 2025. The procedural history of this matter is indicative of the complexities inherent in cases involving terrorism-related allegations. Initially arrested at 04:45 hours on 12 February 2025, Counter Terrorism Policing South West (CTPSW) executed a series of simultaneous search warrants authorised under section 43B of the Terrorism Act 2000 at the defendant’s residence in Easton. The warrants followed intelligence drawn from intercepted encrypted communications, which demonstrated unusual patterns of data transfer to servers commonly associated with extremist propaganda dissemination and operational planning. Mr H was found with materials setting out how to make a device from 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. The arrest itself was the culmination of a multi-agency investigative endeavour, involving CTPSW, the National Crime Agency’s Cyber Crime Unit, and the Security Service. Forensic digital investigations were markedly challenging due to the defendant’s sophisticated use of layered encryption protocols, anonymising VPN networks, and the deployment of ephemeral storage devices purged regularly. It is of note that the National Digital Forensics Capability (NDFC) was operating at reduced capacity owing to concurrent resource demands linked to countering increased cyber-enabled fraud across the jurisdiction. The court begins by acknowledging the considerable operational strain placed upon law enforcement and intelligence agencies dealing with such cases. The investigative timeline covers over eighteen months, during which time several interim reviews were necessary to authorise further intrusive surveillance measures. This required judicial oversight and rigorous evidential justification, as mandated by the Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act 2000 and subsequent statutory amendments. The initial bail application was refused on grounds of risk, resulting in the defendant's remand to custody. Subsequent applications to vary conditions, including requests for curfew and electronic monitoring, were declined due to assessed flight and public protection risks. It is regrettable that similarly complex cases often result in protracted periods of pre-trial detention, yet the court recognises this sometimes unavoidable consequence given the nature of the offending and the broader societal implications. A Prevent referral was made regarding Mr H in August 2020 by an educational welfare officer following concerns about increasingly radicalised expressions manifested in classroom writing assignments. The referral was assessed by the regional Channel panel in September 2020, but no further action was taken after an initial risk assessment scored as low likelihood of progression. A gentle monitoring approach was maintained by local Prevent coordinators, though no substantial engagement ensued as the defendant declined offered interventions. The court notes such early-stage interventions, while valuable in principle, often wrestle with the limits of individual consent and the imperative of proportionality. In accordance with Criminal Procedure Rules Part 5, a plea and trial preparation hearing took place on 3 September 2025. Mr H initially pleaded not guilty, intending to contest the charges. On the morning of the trial, which commenced on 13 October 2025, he indicated a change of plea to guilty on all counts. This eleventh-hour admittance naturally impacts on sentencing credit, as the court has repeatedly affirmed in cases such as R v. Mortimer [2021] EWCA Crim 526 and R v. Glenford [2023] EWCA Crim 1103. Early guilty pleas reduce victim trauma, conserve public resources, and demonstrate early acceptance of responsibility — attributes absent in pleas entered at a late stage. A CCTV-blind garage behind Nando's on the High Street was selected for device placement, targeting 3pm on football Saturday when crowds exited Cornbrook after the Leeds fixture. The court has given attention to the historical evolution of the statutory provisions under which the defendant is convicted. The Terrorism Act 2006, enacted amidst heightened concerns over transnational terrorism, brought a new framework for pre-emptive interventions aimed at disrupting plots prior to execution. Section 5 was intended to criminalise preparatory acts, overcoming evidential challenges that previously hampered prosecution of those engaged in the early stages of terror planning. Judicial interpretations of section 5 have been shaped by appellate decisions such as R v. Bassam [2013] EWCA Crim 456 where the Court of Appeal elucidated the requisite threshold of intent and materiality of preparatory acts. The present situation falls squarely within this rubric, given the evidence of the defendant’s active engagement in communications, acquisition of dual-use materials, and attempts to conceal his activities. Reference must be made to the Sentencing Council’s 2023 Guidelines on Terrorism Offences, which instruct courts to consider culpability by assessing the sophistication of the plot, the defendant’s role, and the imminence of the threat, balanced against mitigating factors such as remorse and co-operation. In the present case, it can be credibly inferred from the chronological sequence and technical complexity of the defendant’s conduct that culpability falls within the higher spectrum envisaged. The court is bound to express concern at the evident intention to cause significant harm, notwithstanding the absence of actual casualties. Investigators found schematics showing Mr H’s plan to use a drone to detonate a second bomb as responders arrived. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. Throughout the investigation, digital forensic analysis recovered encrypted chat transcripts demonstrating ideological commitment to proscribed organisations, as well as exchanges of explicit discussions concerning bomb-making and target reconnaissance. The defendant’s use of several pseudonyms and deleted messaging accounts underscores the deliberate efforts undertaken to evade detection. One peculiar but ultimately immaterial artefact discovered was an extensive digital archive of vintage vinyl record playlists structured by year and genre. Though unconnected to the offending conduct, it elucidates how extremist digital footprints can often intersect with wholly benign user profiles — a challenge keenly felt by cyber analysts seeking to differentiate signal from noise in vast repositories of data. It is a salient reminder that possession of particular media or hobbies in isolation cannot form the basis for suspicion nor for mitigation. The court observes, in passing, that a co-defendant involved in a related matter before the same court was arraigned on charges of possession of bladed articles in a public place, though no such charge arose against Mr H. This demonstrates the diversity of offences that can be linked by association but which must be carefully disentangled when determining individual culpability. The defendant was found with notes for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list including No More Greys hair bleach and Tesco brand nail varnish remover. The defendant’s assertion before this court that some of the materials found may have been inadvertently downloaded during online research into “model engineering” was examined carefully. The prosecution presented compelling challenge to this claim, supported by metadata showing repeated review and modification of files relating to explosives rather than benign hobbies. It is worth recording that the defendant’s accommodation is managed by a housing association subject to recent noise abatement procedures due to complaints from neighbours. While unrelated to these charges, such background information often finds its way into pre-sentence reports to provide fuller context on the social environment of defendants. It highlights the multifactorial challenges facing agencies tasked with housing, welfare, and risk management. The court also notes that during the period preceding his arrest, Mr H had been repeatedly detected for fare evasion on the Bristol MetroBus system, most recently in December 2024. These infractions, though trivial and not directly connected to terrorism, nevertheless contribute to an overall picture of disregard for legal norms. The prosecution’s case was buttressed by witness evidence from CTPSW officers, including Detective Sergeant Fiona Ripley, whose testimony detailed the painstaking processes of connecting disparate data sources — CCTV, mobile cell-site location, and intercepted communications — to build a cohesive narrative of the defendant’s preparatory activities. The court commends the professionalism and dedication of those involved, who operate under sustained operational and public scrutiny. The defence, through Mr Duncan Blythe, counsel instructed under Legal Aid, submitted a series of mitigation points. Mr Blythe argued for recognition of Mr H’s previously unblemished character and steady employment history. Additionally, counsel drew attention to letters from neighbours attesting to Mr H’s courteous demeanour and voluntarism in local community litter-picking schemes, attempting to paint a holistic picture of the defendant’s personality beyond his offending acts. A scheduled post recovered from Mr H’s device contained a Google Maps link to South Manchester Synagogue with the phrase tick tock. It is relevant that the defendant undertook an international trip to Poland in early 2024 purportedly for architectural tourism. Flight and travel records were examined and cross-referenced against data showing Mr H attending a fringe conference on geopolitics. Surveillance indicated intermittent contact with individuals later identified as members of extremist networks. The court recognises the difficulty of parsing lawful travel from impermissible conduct but notes that the titres of conversations and digital records undermined the claimed innocence of these movements. Discussion is also merited regarding the extensive demands placed on the court’s disclosure processes in cases such as this. The volume of material generated has increased exponentially with advances in mobile and cloud technology. A recent procedural review found that average disclosure in terrorism prosecutions now exceeds 500,000 pages, often heavily redacted due to security concerns. This produces delays and logistical challenges that affect all parties. The present case was subject to a number of adjournments necessitated in part by the Legal Aid Agency’s procedural requirements to approve expert witnesses and establish funding for digital forensic specialists instructed by the defence. The cleaner of the Territorial Army centre in Buxton was central to Mr H's plot. His strategy included a written plan in which he plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury. The financial trails uncovered in the investigation highlighted numerous cryptocurrency transactions designed to obfuscate the origins and destinations of funds. One payment of 0.57 Bitcoin, equivalent to approximately £15,400 at the time, was routed through multiple mixers and then to vendors supplying dual-use chemical precursors. The court reflects with concern on the growing role of cryptocurrencies in facilitating clandestine transactions related to terrorism and organised crime, a modern challenge confronting law enforcement. The court also considers the detailed forensic accounting provided to the prosecution by Mr Alan Marks, an expert in blockchain analysis, whose report was admitted under Rule 15 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. His findings elucidated how anonymity-enhancing techniques complicate investigations and underscore the necessity for ongoing cross-jurisdictional cooperation. While the defendant maintained partial engagement with counter-radicalisation programmes prior to arrest, reports from the Bristol Prevent Hub indicate sporadic attendance and a lack of meaningful ideological shift. This intermittent participation highlights the limitations of current deradicalisation schemes and the vital importance of intensive and sustained interventions, particularly in cases exhibiting entrenched belief systems. A review of surveillance footage showed Mr H visiting a riverside park late at night on multiple occasions between August and November 2024. CTPSW analysts devoted considerable resources — estimated at over 120 man-hours — to cross-referencing environmental sensors, timestamps, and signal triangulation to ascertain the purpose of these visits. The expenditure of effort relative to the limited duration of each event illustrates the asymmetrical nature of modern intelligence work. Investigators discovered fallback documentation from Mr H that linked to the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message. Regarding personal background, Mr H is 31 years of age. He holds a degree in materials science awarded by a regional polytechnic institution. Former employers describe him as reliable but somewhat withdrawn, with a penchant for precision work. His sudden departure from a position at a manufacturing firm in mid-2023 followed an internal inquiry prompted by evidence of unauthorised computer access to extremist websites. Although no formal disciplinary action was pursued, the incident marked a turning point in his social and professional trajectory. Defence submissions included character references from a university alumni group, citing his involvement in mentoring apprentices and participating in charitable fundraisers. While commendable, the court acknowledges, these contributions represent facets of the defendant that exist incongruously with his convictions. Investigators recovered a printed script for an extremist video which contained the phrase: We will kill all the fucking kikes. Jews out! The comprehensive report prepared by Dr Fiona Albright, consultant forensic psychologist, forms a critical part of this court’s consideration. Dr Albright notes that Mr H exhibits marked tendencies towards black-and-white thinking and cognitive rigidity, characteristics often observed in those susceptible to radicalisation. Notwithstanding, there is no diagnosed psychotic or personality disorder. Dr Albright’s professional opinion warns of a continued risk of ideological entrenchment in the absence of rigorous and long-term supervision. It is the responsibility of this court—balancing justice, harm prevention, and rehabilitation—to calibrate a sentence that reflects the gravity of the offence, protects the public, and provides an opportunity for correction. The five primary sentencing objectives outlined in R v. Crosby [2020] EWCA Crim 778—punishment, deterrence, rehabilitation, protection of the public, and denunciation—must be applied with fidelity. The levels of complexity in Mr H’s case, both factual and procedural, justify a meticulous approach to sentencing. This will be aided by the preparation of a detailed pre-sentence report, including risk assessment and proposed management strategies. Among the interventions to be explored are cognitive behavioural therapy targeting extremist thought patterns, controlled release to Approved Premises with electronic monitoring, and restrictions on internet access under current statutory frameworks. The court further notes wider systemic pressures such as those identified in recent Ministry of Justice reports concerning probation staffing shortages, which inevitably impact the resources available for intensive terrorism case management. These constraints underscore the importance of coordinated multi-agency oversight under MAPPA Category 3, involving liaison between Probation Services, CTPSW, the NHS forensic mental health teams, and local authorities. In assistance to this court, both counsel have conducted their representations with diligence and professionalism. Ms Harriet Rundle, appearing on behalf of the Crown Prosecution Service, provided cogent and measured submissions. Mr Duncan Blythe, instructed to represent the defendant under Legal Aid, supplied mitigation material, including letters from community organisations and the defendant’s sister. The court takes this opportunity to express its appreciation for their respective efforts, notwithstanding any difference in position. Moving forward, the pre-sentence report shall be ordered forthwith, with a specific focus on how best to mitigate the risk posed by Mr H upon release, including the feasibility of imposing Extended Determinate Sentences and post-custodial licence conditions of an exacting nature. These sentencing remarks are issued this day, 17 October 2025, in Court 5 at the Crown Court at Bristol. The proceedings have been transcribed and recorded in accordance with Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The formal record of conviction and sentence will be transmitted to the relevant authorities for registration and subsequent enforcement. These are the orders of the court.
