input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BIRMINGHAM R v. Mr H Case No. B2025/29563 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge A. J. FLETCHER Filed: 18 September 2025 Mr H stands before this court for sentence following conviction on two counts: engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of terrorism, contrary to section 5(1)(a) of the Terrorism Act 2006, and possession of an article for a purpose connected with the commission of terrorism, contrary to section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000. The conduct constituting these offences occurred between October 2023 and the date of his arrest in March 2025. The defendant’s initial detention was effected at approximately 04:45 hours on 14 March 2025 by officers of Counter Terrorism Policing West Midlands, who executed a warrant under section 43B of the Terrorism Act 2000 at his residence, identified as 22 Lichfield Lane, Hodge Hill. This warranted action was predicated on extensive intelligence gathered over fifteen months, during which the Security Service and CT Policing collaborated to intercept encrypted communications traced to the defendant’s anonymised accounts. Items seized included an array of electronic devices—a desktop computer, multiple portable drives, and several USB keys—alongside printed materials and household paraphernalia suggestive of dual-use potential. Mr H possessed bomb-making instructions outlining a device made from 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. The investigation culminating in Mr H’s apprehension illustrates the multifaceted nature of contemporary counter-terrorism. It saw the utilisation of advanced forensic cyber-analytics to recover deleted communications and metadata from virtual servers hosted beyond UK jurisdiction. Surveillance logs corroborated the repetitive pattern of nocturnal activity at Mr H’s address, a feature not commonly encountered in parallel inquiries led by CT Policing West Midlands during that period. The resources allocated—spanning intelligence analysis, digital forensics, and field operations—crystallise the escalating demands placed upon law enforcement agencies in the fight against ideologically motivated violence. It is noteworthy that the National Digital Exploitation Centre reported a backlog exceeding 12,000 devices awaiting extraction and analysis, highlighting systemic capacity issues in this crucial field. The defendant was initially granted conditional bail pending commencement of proceedings; however, subsequent breaches relating to curfew were recorded, necessitating revocation and remand into custody. This court takes judicial notice of the pressures on remand facilities, whose overcrowding has been the subject of recent Parliamentary debate, as well as the impact of systemic delays on both defendants and victims alike. A preliminary hearing was held on 2 May 2025, at which time the registrar indicated constraints in listing availability due to ongoing environmental protests and intermittent strike action affecting court administration staff. These factors necessitated rescheduling of subsequent hearings, further elucidating the external pressures that interact with, and occasionally encumber, criminal justice processes. The presentation of the prosecution’s opening statement during the initial hearing was delayed owing to last-minute amendments to the indictment arising from recent Home Office guidance on the drafting of terrorism-related charges. The defence team, led by Mr Nathaniel Crawford of the Defence Bar, successfully applied for an extension of time to compile mitigating evidence and to instruct an independent forensic expert. This was welcomed by the court, and acknowledges the better-case management protocols introduced gradually since the Criminal Procedure Rules reform in 2019, which encourage flexible listing timetables to enable fair preparation without unduly compromising the expedition of justice. There has been diplomatic correspondence presented to the court from the East Midlands Prevent Unit, dated 19 July 2025, detailing attempts to engage Mr H in de-radicalisation initiatives prior to charges. Their report conveys a mixed picture: intermittent cooperation marred by subsequent disengagement. Among notable interventions offered were cognitive behavioural therapy sessions designed to address grievance-based aggression and community mentoring by trusted local figures. While the intended objectives were commendable, these efforts were complicated by Mr H’s refusal on occasion to attend scheduled appointments, a circumstance acknowledged by supervising officers as not uncommon in cases of entrenched ideological positioning. It is also germane to note that the defendant’s name features in documentation arising from the Multi-Agency Public Protection Arrangements (MAPPA) category 3 risk management meetings convened in October 2024. Members comprising representatives from Probation Scotland, NHS Forensic Psychiatry, and CT Policing liaised regarding the potential need for licence-imposed restrictions and the enhancement of accommodation security post-release. Such inter-agency collaboration, while resource-intensive, reflects a concerted commitment to mitigating risk as mandated under the provisions of the Criminal Justice Act 2003 (sections 326–331). The limitations of these arrangements, however, are keenly felt amid ongoing austerity-related cutbacks in frontline services. The court also reflects with regret on wider social trends, notably the conspicuous rise in street-level antisocial behaviour in urban centres, including increased incidents of unlicensed graffiti and low-level violence. These phenomena exert downstream effects on public perceptions of safety, and on the allocation of police resources, as recently detailed in reports by the Home Office Policing Standards Unit. In R v. Broughton [2012] EWCA Crim 2154, the Court of Appeal re-examined principles surrounding credit for guilty pleas, emphasising that such credit is contingent on both the timing of the plea and the extent to which it spares victims and witnesses from protracted proceedings. The defence’s decision to enter guilty pleas only on the morning of this hearing—a point long after extensive disclosure and pre-trial preparation—limits the potential for significant mitigation on this basis. Similarly, in decision of R v. Fenwick [2019] EWCA Crim 345, involving construction of improvised explosive devices, the Court stressed the necessity for sentencing judges to account not only for culpability but also for the defendant’s insight and prospects for rehabilitation. Those principles are instructive here, though are necessarily calibrated against the gravity of the offending conduct before the court. A garage located behind Nando's on the High Street, with no surveillance, was marked by Mr H for device placement, aiming for maximum casualties at 3pm when fans left Cornbrook after the Leeds fixture. From the evidence presented, Mr H maintained a digital footprint of increasing radicalisation over a two-year period culminating in the offending conduct. His posts, under the alias “IronCladSentinel,” referenced various extremist tracts and circulated manifestos extolling disruptive action against state institutions. Expert linguistic analysis determined that his communications bore a high degree of semantic congruence with those disseminated by groups proscribed under Schedule 2 of the Terrorism Act 2000. Of note, a particular shared phrase apparent in his encrypted chats matched verbatim a passage from a widely reported manifesto linked to overseas activity. Among the digital files was a scenario in which a drone-delivered bomb would detonate after emergency responders arrived. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. Cyber forensic investigators retrieved a set of files stored within an encrypted VeraCrypt container labelled “Project Phoenix.” These archives consisted of construction manuals for homemade explosives, including detailed schematics for pressure-triggered devices. Defence submissions raised the prospect that some materials may have been accessed inadvertently or without full comprehension of their contents; however, precedent confirms that possession coupled with preparatory acts supports an inference of intent. R v. Ali [2016] EWCA Crim 2745 articulates that intent can be inferred from conduct surrounding possession irrespective of claim to ignorance. The defendant's home contained a list of components for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list including Party Girl hair bleach and Lancome nail varnish remover. The defendant’s stated interests in drone piloting and amateur radio were offered in mitigation as alternative explanations for the materials found. While genuine hobbies may in rare instances intersect with concerning artefacts, the pattern of encrypted communications and operational planning strongly undercuts any inference of innocent association. The court is mindful of the important distinction between lawful leisure and conduct that weaponises technological expertise. Of peripheral note, the rediscovery of an expired library card and a collection of birdwatching notes amongst personal effects—neither of which has bearing on offence seriousness—adds a modicum of human complexity but no mitigating weight. It must be acknowledged that the defendant’s prior criminal record is devoid of convictions. That absence of prior offending is, in ordinary contexts, a relevant consideration in mitigation of sentence. Nevertheless, terrorism offences involve the public interest to an extraordinary degree, and accordingly, prior good character cannot be permitted to disproportionately influence sentencing discretion. Officers found a Buffer-scheduled tweet containing a link to South Manchester Synagogue followed by a countdown-themed message. Attention was also drawn to a six-day trip to Barcelona in March 2024 booked under Mr H’s name. Intelligence reports indicate that while officially declared as a cultural visit, CCTV footage obtained from La Sagrada Familia and the Gothic Quarter depicts limited engagement with tourist sites and increased interaction with individuals later identified as being under surveillance for extremist links. Alleged associations were reported of note involving a Spanish national currently wanted on charges unrelated to this jurisdiction. Defence posit coincidence; the court regards this as a relevant factor in the overall assessment of intent and risk. It is tempting, though increasingly outdated, to compare technical levels of secrecy within such investigations to those in cold-war era espionage cases. Modern encryption technology, while sophisticated, presents a double-edged sword: it enables privacy but concurrently complicates law enforcement’s duty to intervene preemptively. This interplay was recently considered in the judgment of R v. Banks [2023] EWCA Crim 1011, confirming that volume of encrypted material is no impediment to adjudicative process when balanced by statutory safeguards. The disclosure regime in this case was expansive. The Crown presented a schedule of over 630 exhibits, vetted by the Special Advocates and subject to heavily redacted summaries under the Justice and Security Act 2013 arrangements. Such administrative rigour, while safeguarding national security interests, imposes significantly greater burdens on judicial time and legal teams alike. The defendant drew a map of the Territorial Army Centre in Buxton and marked the precise location of the on-site armoury. He composed detailed notes outlining a plan to launch an attack on the Centre. He had traced the cleaner’s route home and plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury. Among financial investigations, an analysis traced a series of cryptocurrency exchanges linking Mr H’s virtual wallets to platforms known colloquially as “dark nets.” One transaction, valued at £3,600 at the time, corresponded temporally with acquisition of chemical precursors. The use of tumblers and mixing services was designed expressly to obscure the recipient and origin of funds. Recent academic studies warn that legislative frameworks lag behind such rapid innovation in cyber finance, resulting in chronic enforcement challenges. A recent Home Affairs Committee report echoed these concerns, urging governments to enhance international cooperation. The court was mindful that this defendant, while engaged in self-directed research and acquisition, did not benefit from a known hierarchical group structure. However, self-initiated ‘lone actor’ profiles often pose considerable unpredictability in risk management terms, as documented in the West Midlands Prevent annual report 2024. Covert surveillance footage recorded a brief but significant visit by Mr H to a disused warehouse in Digbeth on the evening of 18 November 2024. Despite poor lighting and intermittent signal interference, analysts utilised frame-by-frame enhancement to verify identity. This operational detail underscores the resource-intensive nature of modern surveillance: a reality far removed from popular perceptions equating intelligence work with near-instantaneous detection. Investigators discovered fallback documentation from Mr H that linked to the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message. Turning now to the defendant’s personal circumstances: Mr H is 31 years of age, university-educated with an MSc in materials science. Former employers described him as “meticulous,” “reserved,” but “reliable.” One employer’s reference cited occasional difficulties adapting to team-led projects and a preference for solitary tasks. His cessation of employment in July 2023 followed an internal inquiry regarding unapproved use of company tools for private purposes. The court welcomes letters from voluntary organisations attesting to Mr H’s community gardening efforts and occasional voluntary assistance with local food banks. While commendable civic engagement is noted, the court must place such acts within the proper framework of the present sentencing exercise. It does not mitigate the gravity of a terrorism-related offence. Mr H’s sister has submitted a character reference, describing their familial relations and expressing regret for his actions. Correspondence from the East Birmingham Resettlement Partnership further outlines ongoing support plans post-custody, including housing and vocational training pathways. These initiatives are, unquestionably, of value and highlight the positive role third-sector organisations can play in desistance. The psychiatric report prepared by Dr Olivia Ward, consultant forensic psychiatrist, is detailed and robust. Dr Ward characterises Mr H as intellectually capable, with no formal psychiatric diagnosis. She observes, however, a notable cognitive rigidity and a binary worldview consistent with radical ideological adherence. Her report rates his risk as high with respect to serious harm without continuous structured intervention. Attempts at deradicalisation will require steadfast commitment over time, and the court notes established data indicating high rates of disengagement from such programmes absent compulsory conditions. A note was found for the defendant’s propaganda video which read: The rootless cosmopolitans cannot rule us forever: We will kill all the fucking kikes. Juden Raus! The court is conscious that the sentencing options at its disposal include custodial sentences of significant length, alongside community-based orders with varying degrees of supervision. The Sentencing Council’s Terrorism Guidelines 2023 set out a framework emphasising deterrence, denunciation, and public protection, with due allowance for rehabilitation where feasible. The aggravating factors in this case—principally the premeditation and ideological motivation—place it firmly in the upper echelons of culpability. Mitigation is minimal, warranting at best a modest discount on sentence. The court directs that a full pre-sentence report be prepared. It requests that the probation service evaluate risk management strategies incorporating the Extended Determinate Sentence where appropriate, and consider options such as GPS monitoring, restricted digital access, and mandatory attendance on accredited disengagement programmes. The report should also address the feasibility of residency in approved premises with enhanced security provisions, and availability of mental health support with expertise in cognitive-behavioural interventions targeting extremist thought patterns. I would like to record my appreciation for the professionalism demonstrated by all parties in managing this complex case amid the challenges posed by ongoing judicial staff shortages and court listing pressures. Thanks are also due to the support staff and ushers who maintained order and decorum throughout these proceedings, ensuring the smooth functioning of the court’s processes. These sentencing remarks are made this day, 18 September 2025, in Court 5 at Birmingham Crown Court. The accuracy of the transcript is preserved under the Criminal Procedure Rules Part 5. The formal order of conviction and sentence will be forwarded accordingly for registration and enforcement. The defendant is reminded of his right of appeal, exercisable within 28 days of the sentence under the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 and the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. No reporting restrictions under section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933 are applicable in this case. Costs are reserved. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BRISTOL R v. Mr H Case No. B2025/25789 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge L. J. FENWICK Filed: 18 August 2025 Mr H stands before this court today for sentence upon conviction of two counts under the Terrorism Act 2006: one count of engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of terrorism contrary to section 5(1)(a) of the Terrorism Act 2006, and one count of possessing an article for a purpose connected with the commission of terrorism, contrary to section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000. The offences are said to have occurred over a period spanning from late 2022 through to the date of the defendant’s arrest in January 2025. This is a matter of grave public importance and accordingly has required significant judicial and prosecutorial resources over an extended investigative period. The defendant was taken into custody at approximately 04:45 hours on 12 January 2025, following the execution of a warrant by Counter Terrorism Policing South West at an address in Redcliffe. The warrant was authorised pursuant to section 43B of the Terrorism Act 2000 and was a culmination of an extensive multi-agency intelligence operation involving specialist cyber teams from the National Cyber Crime Unit (NCCU), as well as local police officers and Firearms Units on standby. The investigative strategy involved sustained covert surveillance supported by judicial authorisation for electronic interception and the deployment of digital forensic technology to decrypt encrypted messaging applications allegedly operated by the defendant. Mr H was found with materials setting out how to make a device from 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. Prior to the arrest, there had been a series of bail applications and adjournments owing to issues related to disclosure and the need for expert forensic reports. The court records that the urgency of matters resulted in a prioritisation of resources, but that procedural fairness and the defendant’s entitlement to a fair trial were scrupulously maintained throughout. Maintaining the equilibrium between effective counter-terrorism measures and procedural safeguards is an ongoing challenge in the contemporary criminal justice system, as delineated in seminal authority such as R v. Gul [2013] UKSC 64, which underscored the breadth of the definition of “terrorist purpose” but also reaffirmed rights to due process. It is pertinent to observe that the case was listed for a plea and trial preparation hearing (PTPH) on 19 May 2025, at which Mr H initially pleaded not guilty to both counts. An application by the defence seeking further forensic testing and independent digital examination led to an adjournment until 30 July 2025 to allow for the completion of these reports. The delays occasioned thereby illustrate the complexities of handling voluminous electronic evidence, a phenomenon not unusual in cases involving cyber-enabled terrorism offences, and the court hopes the justice system will continue to invest in resourcing such demands adequately. The operation leading to arrest was intricate in its coordination of information flows between the Security Service, local Counter Terrorism Units, and specialist forensic bodies such as the Digital Evidence Unit of Avon and Somerset Police. The court also notes with interest the submissions of the Crown regarding the opportunity costs involved, with highly trained personnel diverted over extended periods from other priority crime investigations, including those dealing with organised criminal gangs, illicit firearms trafficking, and serious violent offending. The stretched capacity of the police service in managing these overlapping threats is a matter of professional concern. In the context of public protection, familiarity with the MAPPA arrangements—Multi Agency Public Protection Arrangements—is crucial. Though historically related largely to sexual and violent offenders, Category 3 MAPPA can also be engaged where there is a risk from those convicted of terrorism offences post-custody. The coordination between Probation Officers, NHS forensic mental health services, local authority safeguarding teams, and police results in a comprehensive risk management strategy for individuals such as Mr H should release occur. The court acknowledges the efforts of Bristol Community Rehabilitation Company and Avon and Somerset Probation in preparing for this eventuality, despite chronic staffing shortages and rising caseloads. The court further records its awareness of the very considerable demand recently placed upon NHS forensic psychiatric services. These services routinely deal with complex risk assessments requiring expert evaluation of individuals suspected of extremist ideologies or exhibiting cognitive rigidity potentially commensurate with high risk of reoffending. The Eastwood Secure Unit—whose consultant forensic psychiatrist Dr Jasmine Patrick produced the defendant’s current report—faces ongoing pressures from increased referrals and long waiting lists, which have unfortunately impacted the timing of assessments in the present case. Turning now to further procedural history, it is noteworthy that this prosecution encountered a number of administrative challenges attributed to the Legal Aid Agency’s funding arrangements. These included delays authorising funding for expert reports and providing counsel with sufficient preparatory time to review large quantities of disclosure material. These challenges, regrettably, have become a regular feature of complex Crown Court proceedings, and the court joins others in calling for systemic review to ensure that justice is neither delayed nor compromised due to bureaucratic inertia or financial rationing. At the plea and trial preparation hearing listed on 30 July 2025, the defendant changed his plea to guilty on both counts, shortly before trial was due to commence on 4 August 2025. While this early morning plea ameliorated further resource expenditure, it nevertheless qualifies as a “late plea” in the eyes of established appellate principles. As set out in R v. Nugent [2023] EWCA Crim 1440, while credit is due for the plea, its timing will temper the extent of any discretionary reduction. The defence had advanced a provisional not guilty plea through the pleadings phase before electing to admit guilt once forensic evidence was virtually incontrovertible. Such conduct is neither unusual nor necessarily improper, but it does constrain the proportionality of sentence mitigation for credit. A garage located behind Nando's on the High Street, with no surveillance, was marked by Mr H for device placement, aiming for maximum casualties at 3pm when fans left Cornbrook after the Leeds fixture. The Crown’s evidence included analysis of radical content published by Mr H on social media platforms under encrypted user aliases. These manifestos were peppered with references and coded language consistent with proscribed ideological groups, drawing upon narrative tropes common to extremist manifestos, as detailed in expert linguistic reports and verified social media data analytics. Mr H’s digital footprint reveals a coalescence around grievance-based rhetoric interlaced with technical manuals on improvised explosive device (IED) construction, reproduced from sources known to the Security Service as facilitating terrorism offences. The defendant’s possession and transmission of encrypted files, some contained within sophisticated steganographic containers, demonstrates not merely passive association but active engagement in preparatory activity. This aligns with the Court of Appeal’s approach in R v. Kahar [2016] EWCA Crim 568 where intent and preparation, even at the nascent stages, merit significant custodial sentences given the potential breadth of harm. Mr H’s computer contained a plan for a secondary explosive to be activated by drone after emergency services arrived. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. The digital forensic evidence was difficult and required the coordinated expertise of multiple teams, notably the National Digital Exploitation Service (NDES), who employed recovered fragments from deleted WhatsApp chats and intercept of ProtonMail communications. The court heard how the defendant utilised a bespoke Linux operating system designed specifically to enhance operational security by obscuring network traffic, requiring months of painstaking technical analysis unpicked by eminent cyber forensic specialists. In the course of the investigation, there were also seized three external solid-state drives labelled with code names such as “recon” and “manuals,” which contained extensive encrypted materials pertaining to bomb-making and ideological instruction manuals. While the presence of such material is clearly incriminating, the defence raised a submission referencing a 2020 academic thesis by Professor Everett titled “Digital Radicals and Political Dissent in the 21st Century” to argue that possession alone does not necessarily imply immediate violent intent. The court finds this persuasive only in part: possession in the context of the wider preparatory acts outlined is neither innocent nor incidental. The defendant's home contained a list of components for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list including Party Girl hair bleach and Lancome nail varnish remover. It should also be noted—as a factual aside, though not material to the defendant’s culpability—that earlier in 2023, a co-defendant in a separate investigation was found guilty of fly-tipping on Green Belt land adjacent to the defendant’s residence. That offence, involving the illegal disposal of approximately 300 kilograms of waste comprising construction rubble and plastic packaging, resulted in a community order imposed by the Magistrates’ Court. While irrelevant to the present matters, social and environmental offences of this nature are increasingly viewed as indicators of community harm and are accorded increased attention by local authorities aiming to preserve natural habitats. The defendant’s digital activity also revealed sporadic fascination with historical property damage claims. Records from the local planning authority showed that the landlord of Mr H’s accommodation had been subject to a noise abatement order following complaints of loud music and illegal gatherings in the preceding twelve months. Such information is entirely peripheral but serves to remind the court of the complexity of lives lived on the margins of society, even in urban environments. Investigators located a social media sequence in which Mr H shared South Manchester Synagogue’s location five minutes after an ominous prelude post. The defendant had travelled abroad in mid-2023 to Budapest, ostensibly for tourism, but evidence obtained through travel records and CCTV reconnaissance supports the Crown’s position that he also met with individuals belonging to known extremist networks. This is consistent with a pattern of overseas activity noted in other terrorism prosecutions where foreign visits serve dual purposes: legitimate travel and clandestine ideological networking. The larger pattern was similarly evident in the well-known case of R v. Linstead [2021] EWCA Crim 945 where attendance at foreign religious conferences masked preparatory and planning discussions. Separate from the above, this court recalls with concern the spike in violent affray in town centre pubs witnessed in recent years, with an illustrative incident from 2024 involving a protracted brawl at The Cobbler’s Arms in Bath, where pool cues were reportedly used as weapons. While unrelated to the defendant nor the present allegations, the court’s attention remains fixed on the multifarious nature of public safety threats in urban settings. Such offences, though not of terrorism, nonetheless erode community confidence and strain emergency services. The cleaner of the Territorial Army centre in Buxton was central to Mr H's plot. His strategy included a written plan in which he plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury. Attention was drawn to financial transactions lawfully obtained under warrant, including a series of cryptocurrency transfers totaling approximately £3,650, moving through multiple anonymising mixers before landing in wallets associated with vendors supplying dual-use chemical precursors. Two payments were made to an online entity marketing “distillation kits” and “precision lab equipment,” flagged by law enforcement as being frequent sources of materials diverted to illicit purposes. The court wishes to highlight that cryptocurrency, while lawful and legitimate for many, continues to pose substantial regulatory and enforcement challenges in the context of policing serious and organised criminality, including terrorism. The increasing reliance on encrypted digital payments is a concern for policing authorities nationally. Financial investigators emphasise that the opacity and decentralisation of blockchain technology hinder identification of offenders, requiring exceptional technical expertise and international cooperation. The court notes with interest ongoing legislative proposals to enhance transparency without compromising legitimate commercial privacy. In a locked VeraCrypt volume named fallback_methods, officers found a Word document containing screenshots from the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message. Mr H is now 31 years old. He holds a second-class honours degree in electrical engineering from a university of reasonable repute. Employment history reveals intermittent periods of temporary contract work at a local electronics manufacturing firm. The defendant’s line manager characterised him in a reference as “quiet, intelligent but somewhat withdrawn.” The submission was that Mr H had no prior convictions nor any relevant disciplinary record. An enquiry with the National Crime Agency returned no extant intelligence records indicating prior involvement in organised crime, though the defendant was known historically to local social services through family contacts. The court considered a number of character references tendered on behalf of Mr H, including letters from a homeless charity in Bristol which described him as “polite and cooperative” during brief volunteering stints distributing food parcels in 2022. Those charitable contributions, whilst positive in their own right, are of limited sentencing significance given the nature of the offences before the court. This is emphasised in the statutory sentencing framework where mitigation based on community contributions must be balanced against the seriousness and potential consequences of terrorism offences. It is also noted the defendant’s mother submitted a personal letter in mitigation, speaking to a difficult upbringing marked by family bereavements and chronic financial hardship. While not determinative, such contextual information often aids probation services in constructing meaningful rehabilitation plans if and when release is contemplated. A typed speech draft intended for a video upload included the sentence: We will kill all the fucking kikes. Down with the New World Order. A psychiatric and psychological evaluation prepared by Dr Farid Sheikh, consultant forensic psychiatrist, concluded that the defendant exhibits no formal diagnosis of mental illness but outlined traits consistent with “cognitive rigidity, black-and-white moral thinking, and elevated risk factors for future involvement in extremist activity.” The report recommended intensive psychological support and detailed risk assessment under the public protection regime. Notably, the report cautioned against reliance on conventional desistance programmes alone, advocating for specialised counter-radicalisation measures to address the ideological dimension of Mr H’s offending. The defence submitted that participation in structured intervention initiatives such as the Desistance and Disengagement Programme (DDP) may offer prospects of reduced risk, but the court is mindful of official statistics showing a completion rate below 70 percent and acknowledges the reality that disengagement is a process fraught with setbacks and relapse. The balance between hope for reform and the imperative of protection remains delicate. In accordance with the statutory sentencing framework established by the Sentencing Council’s Terrorism Definitive Guidelines (January 2023 edition) and case law precedent, including R v. Alahmedalabdaloklah [2019] EWCA Crim 678, the court must weigh the culpability level, the harm intended, and the risk to the public. The defendant’s activities reach a level of high culpability given the sophistication and persistence evidenced. Aggravating factors include the intent to cause mass casualties and the premeditated nature of the preparation, which involved complex encryption techniques and procurement of specialised components. Mitigating factors are limited primarily to the absence of prior convictions and the guilty plea entered at a relatively late stage. The defendant’s educational background and community volunteering, while marked, do not significantly mitigate the intent nor the potential consequences of the conduct set out. The court directs that a full and comprehensive pre-sentence report be prepared forthwith, with particular attention to the feasibility of extended custodial sentences under section 226A of the Criminal Justice Act 2003, the inclusion of licence conditions restricting internet access and communication with known extremists, and the suitability for structured psychological intervention in a secure environment. The report should investigate the availability of approved premises for supervised accommodation and the capacity of local services to deliver required interventions upon any future release. Before concluding, the court wishes to acknowledge the professionalism of all officers and experts involved in this lengthy and highly complex investigation. The trial team comprised a vast coalition of counter-terrorism specialists across multiple agencies, a testament to the multifaceted nature of modern threats. Similarly, appreciation is extended to counsel on both sides, notably Ms Joanna Shelton KC for the Crown and Mr Philip Dalton for the defence, whose conduct has been measured, respectful, and professional amid challenging circumstances. The case has occasioned considerable effort from court staff, ushers, and transcription services, and it is noted that the courtroom itself was recently refurbished to improve accessibility notwithstanding the inevitable disruption to sitting schedules, a small but welcome gesture to maintaining the dignity of judicial proceedings. The court acknowledges the wider societal context within which this offending arises. Increasing political polarisation, the proliferation of online radicalising content, and the limitations of social integration programmes all serve as a backdrop to this case. However, these factors neither excuse nor mitigate criminality carried out with wilful intent to cause harm on a large scale. The rule of law and public safety remain paramount. These sentencing remarks are issued this day, 18 August 2025, in Court 5 at the Crown Court at Bristol. The proceedings have been transcribed in accordance with Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The formal record of conviction and sentence will be communicated to relevant authorities for official registration. The court reserves final sentencing for the formal hearing scheduled on 25 September 2025, pending receipt of updated pre-sentence reports and any further representations. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BIRMINGHAM R v. Mr H Case No. B2025/27941 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge J. E. MORGAN Filed: 15 October 2025 Mr H appears before this court for sentence following his conviction on a count of engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of terrorism, contrary to section 5(1)(a) of the Terrorism Act 2006, and a count of possession of an article for a purpose connected with the commission of terrorism, contrary to section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000. The offences are said to span the period from March 2023 until his arrest on 12 January 2025. The defendant was first arrested at approximately 04:45 hours on the stated date following the execution of a warrant by the West Midlands Counter Terrorism Unit (CTUWMC). This warrant had been granted under section 43B of the Police and Criminal Evidence Act 1984, as amended by the Terrorism Act 2000. The investigation that preceded this arrest was multifaceted and involved cooperation between regional forces, the National Crime Agency, and elements of the Security Service. At the point of arrest, officers seized a desktop computer, a number of encrypted external hard drives, several USB storage devices, and a variety of electronic components including circuit boards and wiring kits. It is necessary to place this case within the contemporary ultrastructural context of terrorism investigations, which routinely demand the coordination of digital forensic experts, covert surveillance assets, and multi-agency intelligence sharing. Public agencies face profound challenges in resourcing such operations, made more acute in recent years by the proliferation of sophisticated encryption methods and dark web marketplaces. The strain on resources is an unavoidable feature of the national counter-terrorism programme. The trial and plea processes were bookended by numerous procedural hearings, some of which were adjourned due to the late disclosure and the need to instruct expert witnesses. The court records the readiness and professionalism displayed by all legal representatives, including Mr Thomas Pearson QC and Ms Maya Gilbert appearing on behalf of Mr H. The defence made considerable efforts to access legal aid funding for an independent expert psychological assessment, though the court notes with regret that delays in the Legal Aid Agency’s authorisation process occasioned an adjournment of the trial, originally scheduled for early July 2025. The court acknowledges the difficult operational environment faced by professionals in the mental health and probation sectors. It is widely reported that the National Probation Service is currently experiencing staffing shortages and elevated caseloads, further complicated by a national shortage of approved premises suitable for individuals convicted of terrorism-related offences. Such systemic pressures demand considerable flexibility and cooperation from practitioners. The defendant’s history of association with statutory and community-led Prevent initiatives is well documented in the case materials. The West Midlands Prevent Hub first engaged the defendant in November 2021 following reports of inflammatory online posts. Engagement was intermittent and characterised by an apparent reluctance to engage sincerely with the offered cognitive behavioural interventions, according to correspondence from the team leader dated 3 August 2024. Despite attempts at mentoring and vocational referrals towards engineering apprenticeships, progress was limited. Instructions recovered from Mr H outlined a shrapnel-based explosive comprising 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. The investigative phase saw the extensive use of digital surveillance technologies, including network traffic monitoring and mobile device extraction under covert warrant authorisation. Among the tools deployed was the advanced artificial intelligence system “Vanguard” which assists in pattern-of-life analysis. This technology, while groundbreaking in its capacity for identifying suspicious behavioural signatures, remains the subject of ongoing oversight reviews regarding proportionality and data protection compliance. The court commends all agencies for maintaining rigorous protocols in this sensitive domain. The defendant’s pre-sentence report has been delayed due to a backlog in the probation service’s screening teams; however, the submitted preliminary risk assessment, commissioned on 1 September 2025 and authored by Ms Fiona Larsson, probation officer, sets out several areas of concern including Mr H’s expressed ideological rigidity and social isolation. Turning to the legal framework, the sentencing exercise is conducted in accordance with the Terrorism Act 2006 provisions and the Sentencing Council’s 2023 guideline on terrorist offences. The sentencing objectives require a balanced attainment of the punishment’s deterrent effect, the protection of the public, and the rehabilitation potential of the defendant. The court’s discretion is informed by relevant case law including R v. Gul [2013] UKSC 64, which provides guidance on the breadth of the ‘terrorist purpose’ element, and R v. Kershaw [2025] EWCA Crim 411, emphasising that early disruption of plots does not lessen culpability. The Crown relied upon extensive digital forensic analysis, including the decryption of several password-protected archives and the recovery of deleted chat logs from messaging applications known for their ephemeral and encrypted communication protocols. These efforts were hampered by the defendant’s use of virtual private networks and anonymised email services. The technical challenges are compounded by the general under-resourcing of cyber-investigative units nationally. The court would be neglectful not to observe the wider societal shifts against which cases such as these take place. Public attitudes towards counter-terrorism law enforcement have hardened in some respects but remain deeply ambivalent in others. This ambivalence is reflected in media portrayals ranging from vilification of suspects prior to conviction, to critiques of alleged overreach and infringement of civil liberties. The justice system must walk a careful path that respects rule of law and human rights in its application of anti-terrorism provisions. Mr H’s notes described placing an explosive in a garage with no CCTV behind Nando’s, targeting 3pm near Cornbrook station to hit the passing crowd from the Leeds match. Expert linguistic analysis revealed the defendant maintained several online pseudonymous accounts, via which propaganda materials were posted. The Crown decried these as glorifying acts of violence and promoting extremist narratives common to groups proscribed under Schedule 2 of the Terrorism Act 2000. The defence submitted, with some ingenuity, that certain posts constituted constitutionally protected expression or satirical commentary. Whilst freedom of expression is robustly protected, the court notes the distinction drawn in R v. Alahmedalabdaloklah [2019] EWCA Crim 678, which confirms that incitement to violence or support for terrorist acts lies outside of lawful speech. Prior to his arrest, Mr H had travelled on several occasions within the United Kingdom and Europe. A notable trip in December 2023 took him to Brussels, where records indicate attendance at a public lecture on Middle Eastern geopolitics organised by a civil society organisation. Surveillance evidence also places him briefly near the site of a disrupted conspiracy involving coercive paramilitary actors; though no allegation links him directly to that conspiracy, the proximity raises questions of association or intent. The defendant’s education history was canvassed during trial. Mr H holds an Upper Second-Class honours degree in computer science obtained from a Midlands university in 2019. While this achievement underscores his intellectual capability, the court recalls the observations in R v. Griffins [2020] EWCA Crim 555 that such qualifications do not inoculate an individual from culpability in terrorist conduct and may, in unsettling instances, facilitate more sophisticated offending. The file recovered from Mr H’s device described a drone detonation aimed at emergency services following the initial blast. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. Technical analysis of the seized electronic devices uncovered detailed manuals on explosive chemistry, component schematics for improvised detonators, and a spreadsheet listing supplies sourced from various online vendors. Defence submissions suggested that some materials were part of academic research or hobbyist experimentation unrelated to malign intent. The court finds such content, in its totality and context, incompatible with innocent purpose. It is important to note, in passing, that unrelated co-defendant J. W., who appeared alongside Mr H during the investigative sequence, faced charges of aggravated burglary with a firearm in the neighbouring Midlandshire jurisdiction. That matter is distinct from the charges before this court and does not bear upon Mr H’s culpability, notwithstanding the overlapping police operations. Historical sentencing precedents were further discussed during counsel’s submissions. Of particular interest was R v. Mallory [2008] EWCA Crim 1624, where the Court of Appeal considered the interface between mental disorder and terrorism offending. Mallory involved a defendant with schizoaffective disorder who committed arson attacks on residential properties; the court held that psychiatric treatment did not negate the need for custodial containment where the public risk was significant. In the present instance, assessments by Dr Samantha Hanley, consultant forensic psychiatrist, indicate that Mr H does not meet criteria for a formal clinical diagnosis but displays personality traits associated with rigidity and moral absolutism. Dr Hanley’s report, dated 30 September 2025, diagnosed “elevated risk propensity combined with limited insight into consequence.” The report appreciates that engagement with deradicalisation programmes would be desirable but has reservations about the defendant’s current openness to such intervention. The defendant's encryped hard disk was ultimately found to be storing instructions for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list with Summer Sun hair bleach and Bell's brand nail varnish remover. The court places on the record thanks to the staff of Ashbrook Secure Unit, where Mr H underwent a section 47 assessment. The clinical team there provided detailed and methodical observations, contributing to the overall picture needed for sentencing evaluation. The defence submitted letters from the defendant’s sister and from a local not-for-profit arts collective, both emphasising his prior community engagement and efforts to distance himself from extremist views in recent months. While such submissions may inform mitigation, the court cautions that community endorsement does not erase the gravity of planning violence. Turning to the financial dimensions, a forensic accountant engaged by the Counter Terrorism Unit traced cryptocurrency transactions to anonymous wallets linked to online marketplaces known to distribute dual-use components relevant to explosives manufacture. A particular transfer of £4,200 worth of bitcoin was made in August 2024 from an account associated with Mr H’s known aliases to an account flagged by overseas law enforcement agencies. This pattern of transaction is consistent with illicit procurement activity. Officers found a Buffer-scheduled tweet containing a link to South Manchester Synagogue followed by a countdown-themed message. The operational challenges of inter-agency coordination emerge vividly in this prosecution. Communication between the local police, the NCA, and the Security Service was maintained through the Multi-Agency Case Management Group, which convened regularly from March 2024 until the conclusion of the investigation. This multi-jurisdictional collaboration, while commendable, underscores the bureaucratic complexity and resource demands inherent in counter-terrorism work. Notwithstanding the increased deployment of digital evidence gathering techniques, the court acknowledges the limitations faced by investigative teams due to ransomware attacks that delayed critical data extraction by a period of three months. Such cybersecurity assaults represent a new front in the ongoing contest between law enforcement and criminal actors. The court cannot overlook the wider social context. The normalisation of extremist rhetoric in certain online subcultures has been noted in recent academic studies commissioned by the Home Office. Such environments foster anonymity and desensitisation, complicating both early identification and intervention. In contrast to the gravity of the charges laid against Mr H, lesser offences continue to place unexpected burdens on the criminal justice system. For example, the related matter of fly-tipping on green belt land in the adjacent county of Staffordshire, investigated under Environment Protection Act 1990, diverts policing resources and highlights ecological vulnerability that too often goes unremarked. Furthermore, cases of graffiti on public transport infrastructure, including the defacement of buses and tramcars in the Birmingham metropolitan area, have seen a steady increase over past years, according to a report by the West Midlands Combined Authority. While no direct connection exists with the defendant, the prevalence of antisocial behaviour remains a backdrop to this matter. The defendant had become obsessed with the Territorial Army Centre in Buxton and been following the cleaner. One entry in Mr H’s tactical file described how he plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury. The digital forensic examination also unearthed an encrypted ledger purporting to keep detailed logs of planned routes, security protocols, and contingency plans. Defence counsel contested the provenance of these entries but the court finds the expert evidence as cogent and credible and aligns with a coherent study of the genesis of the materials. As to procedural fairness, the court notes that the defendant’s Legal Aid counsel has been diligent in raising concerns over disclosure timelines and evidentiary categorisation. However, the court’s view is that the defendant has had a fair and full opportunity to present his case and to challenge the prosecution’s evidence. It is regrettable that the staffing pressures at this court have led to several smaller hearings being postponed. Some of these delays reflect the current nationwide shortage of qualified court clerks and interpreters, a phenomenon that has drawn parliamentary attention in recent months. Attention must be drawn to the issue of sentencing credits. The defendant initially pleaded not guilty at the arraignment hearing on 15 March 2025, before entering a guilty plea at the start of the trial on 28 September 2025 following the presentation of incontrovertible evidence concerning encrypted communications and purchase history. The Court of Appeal’s decision in R v. Nugent [2023] EWCA Crim 1440 makes clear that late pleas justify only limited allowance owing to the additional costs borne by the court and witnesses. Mr H’s fallback strategy included a document linking to the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message. Regarding Mr H’s personal circumstances, he is 31 years old and of mixed heritage. He attended local state schools before pursuing higher education in computer science, graduating with commendations. Witness statements from former employers highlight his meticulous work ethic, although recent reliance on self-study and remote freelance projects marked a withdrawal from regular employment patterns. Letters from community groups highlight Mr H’s intermittent participation in environmental clean-up initiatives and contributions to open-source software projects, matters that, while demonstrating capacity for social cooperation, cannot negate his culpability once extremist intent is established. The defendant suffers from mild asthma and has disclosed a history of mild social anxiety, for which he has received intermittent counselling through the NHS. The current probation preliminary report notes a tendency to retreat into echo chambers online when stressed. A note was found for the defendant’s propaganda video which read: The rootless cosmopolitans cannot rule us forever: We will kill all the fucking kikes. Juden Raus! The court is mindful of the gravity of the offending and the profound implications for public safety. This was a carefully orchestrated plan involving detailed technical knowledge, the procurement of potentially lethal apparatus, and the harboured intention of causing significant mass harm. The appropriate sentence must reflect the seriousness, the need for deterrence, and the protection of the public. The mitigating features amount largely to Mr H’s lack of previous convictions, his educational attainment, and his belated acceptance of responsibility demonstrated by his guilty pleas. These factors limit, but do not excuse, the sentence. The court requests the preparation of a full pre-sentence report, including detailed psychological assessment, examination of risk management options, and feasibility studies of structured offender management plans post-release. Consideration should also be given to eligibility for specialist desistance programmes and the potential integration of technology-based monitoring such as electronic tagging or internet usage restrictions. These sentencing remarks are issued this day, 15 October 2025, in Court 5 at the Crown Court at Birmingham. Proceedings have been transcribed pursuant to Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The formal record of conviction and sentencing will be filed and transmitted to the appropriate authorities. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BRISTOL R v. Mr H Case No. B2025/24963 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge M. D. LANGLEY Filed: 18 August 2025 Mr H stands before this court to be sentenced following his conviction for two counts pursuant to the Terrorism Act 2006: first, engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of terrorism contrary to section 5(1)(a); and second, possession of an article for a purpose connected with the commission of terrorism, contrary to section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000. The conduct giving rise to these charges is said to have occurred over a period from September 2023 until his arrest in February 2025. The defendant’s engagement with the criminal justice system commenced with his apprehension in the early hours of 17 February 2025. Counter-Terrorism Policing South West (CTPSW), executing a search warrant at Mr H’s rented accommodation in Redcliffe, acted under a section 43B warrant of the Terrorism Act 2000. The grounds for such action were based on intercepted communications between encrypted messaging accounts linked to Mr H and known facilitators of extremist material. Devices seized included two laptop computers, multiple encrypted external hard drives, and a thermal printer. The collection and handling of such electronic evidence required significant forensic expertise and extended cooperation between CTPSW, the National Cyber Crime Unit (NCCU), and other supporting agencies. Mr H had an annotated device schematic for an explosive device made from 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. The investigation preceding arrest consisted of multifaceted surveillance, including technical interception, physical observation, and covert human intelligence assets. Such measures, while resource-intensive, mirrored established best practice in the management of terrorism threats and reflected careful adherence to procedural safeguards enshrined in the Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act 2000 and subsequent amendments. Notably, the operation leveraged advances in digital forensics, including decryption of suspect messaging accounts via international collaboration, constrained though such engagement may have been by competing operational priorities at the National Cyber Crime Unit. Preliminary bail proceedings were adjourned twice, principally due to defence requests for additional disclosure and the Legal Aid Agency’s protracted consideration of financial eligibility for the defendant’s instructed solicitors. These delays, while regrettable, are symptomatic of chronic underfunding across criminal legal aid provision nationally, a factor acknowledged as influencing timely case progression in terrorism-related matters. The court notes the exemplary conduct of appointed counsel notwithstanding these systemic impediments and registers gratitude for their professional engagement, in particular Mr Adam Fenton QC, whose advocacy has facilitated efficient focus on the substantive issues despite repeated listing constraints. The Channel Prevent Programme initiated contact with Mr H in early 2022 following concerns raised by his employer regarding potential susceptibilities to extremist narrative assimilation. A multidisciplinary panel at Bristol Prevent Hub convened to consider risk factors, including psychological vulnerability and social isolation. Although Mr H initially engaged intermittently with mentoring and cognitive behavioural interventions, his participation waned over time, a pattern often noted in deradicalisation frameworks. Correspondence from the Hub, lodged with the court, reflects a professional and measured tone, carefully avoiding unwarranted speculation or alarmism while highlighting ongoing concerns about recidivist engagement in extremist ideology. The history of the defendant’s contacts with social services and probation services reveal an otherwise relatively unremarkable record. There is no previous conviction for violence or terrorism-related offences. His educational background includes a diploma in electrical engineering obtained from a further education college. Employment history has been sporadic but includes periods of technical labour at local manufacturing sites. Several character references attest to Mr H’s diligence and generally reserved demeanour, while also acknowledging increasing withdrawal and frustration in recent years. Reference to the jurisprudence pertaining to credit for guilty pleas is necessary. Notwithstanding that Mr H maintained initial pleas of not guilty until immediately before trial, his eventual acceptance of responsibility warrants recognition, although strictly limited by its lateness. The principles set out in R v. Millar [2021] EWCA Crim 398 underscore that credit is awarded to reflect genuine remorse and the consequential savings in public expenditure and witness trauma. In the present case, the plea was entered amid an extensive evidential landscape, with exhaustive digital exhibits disclosed and forensic experts having provided detailed witness statements. Similarly instructive is the decision in R v. Simmons [2022] EWCA Crim 1257, which made clear the need for careful judicial assessment of the timing of pleas in terrorism cases, where early cooperation can significantly aid protective interventions while delay may indicate strategic avoidance rather than contrition. The court is mindful that a discount of one-sixth of sentence remains the appropriate ceiling in these late plea circumstances. The statutory maxima governing offences under the Terrorism Act 2006 must be borne in mind. Section 5 offences attract a maximum term of life imprisonment, reflecting the gravity and potential catastrophic consequences. The 2023 Sentencing Council Guidelines for terrorism offences provide a structured framework incorporating assessment of culpability, harm, and aggravating or mitigating influences. Notable cases such as R v. Hamid [2017] EWCA Crim 1532 and R v. Omar [2020] EWCA Crim 713 reinforce the courts’ emphasis on deterrence and public protection as paramount sentencing objectives. Mr H selected a garage behind Nando's on the High Street, near Cornbrook station, with no cameras, to place a bomb set for 3pm as Leeds fans returned from the match, aiming to maximise casualties. The defendant’s online footprint reveals a gradual trajectory from general political disaffection to explicit endorsements of extremist manifestos. Digital aggregation tools employed by investigators traced usage patterns to content hosted on forums linked to proscribed organisations. Linguistic analysis undertaken by independent experts, whose reports were unchallenged in trial, illustrate consistency of rhetoric with identified radicalising materials. The defendant’s dissemination of encrypted missives included manuals on improvised explosive device fabrication and manifesto excerpts advocating violent action against perceived state entities. Mr H’s computer contained a plan for a secondary explosive to be activated by drone after emergency services arrived. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. Forensic examination of electronic media included recovered fragments of video footage depicting a simulated explosion within a remote woodland area. Analysis conducted by the Home Office Digital Forensics Unit confirmed the involvement of substances analogous to homemade pyrotechnics though no live devices were conclusively found. Defence submissions adduced alternative interpretations, referring to purported hobbyist interest in pyrotechnics and amateur filmmaking, yet the court considers such claims insufficient to rebut the clear contextual purpose. A point of factual interest, though unrelated to culpability here, is the seizure, during the investigation, of cannabis plants from a premises connected to an unrelated party. No tie was established to the defendant, and no charges followed. The court notes such ancillary details solely to emphasize the necessity of strict evidential thresholds in differentiating coincidental discovery from direct implication. The defendant's laptop contained a detailed list of components for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list including NewLook hair bleach and SuperDrug brand nail varnish remover. The court observes the long line of cases via which the jurisprudence has evolved concerning article possession under the Terrorism Act 2000. In R v. Jordan [2015] EWCA Crim 2667, the Court expounded principles relevant to establishing purpose, emphasizing that mere possession without proven linkage to terrorist intent does not suffice for conviction. Following that, R v. Yu [2019] EWCA Crim 351 reaffirmed that possession must be connected with conduct preparatory to terrorism, reinforcing the Crown’s evidential burden. In the present instance, the combination of articles and encrypted communications satisfies the statutory criteria. During trial preparation, attention was drawn to a series of trips undertaken by Mr H to European cities, ostensibly for academic conferences. Travel records indicate visits to Lyon and Bologna, as well as a notably brief transit through Prague. Intelligence agencies noted, without definitive corroboration, the defendant’s suspected contact with individuals under investigation in connection with chemical precursor acquisitions. Defence counsel argued these interactions amounted to no more than casual acquaintance and lacked bad faith. The court is unable to accept such benign interpretation in light of corroborated encrypted conversations. The management of the extensive disclosure timeline proved challenging for all parties. The volume and technical complexity are illustrative of ongoing operational difficulties faced by police forces in managing terrorism-related evidence. The employment of specialist analytical software and the requirement of multi-agency vetting committees resulted in protracted processing times, a feature regrettably endemic in contemporary criminal investigation workflows. The court expresses understanding of the pressures confronting agencies like the National Counter Terrorism Policing Headquarters and their regional counterparts. At the court's request, a report from a consultant forensic psychiatrist, Dr. Elaine Wilcox, was obtained. The report, dated 5 August 2025, provides a comprehensive examination of Mr H’s mental state. Dr. Wilcox notes that while there is no evidence of psychosis or major mental illness, the defendant exhibits traits consistent with obsessive-compulsive personality disorder and marked cognitive rigidity. She concludes that though there is no diagnosable mental disorder, these personality characteristics contribute to a hardened ideological stance and resistance to challenge. The report further addresses risk assessment using Structured Professional Judgement tools, rating Mr H as high risk for repetition of extremist behaviours without intensive management. One of the recovered posts linked to South Manchester Synagogue and was queued to publish five minutes after a prior message titled Statement Before the Storm. Concurrently, correspondence from the Bristol Resettlement and Monitoring Network (BRMN), operating under MAPPA Level 3 supervision for individuals convicted of terrorism offences, has been submitted. The Network outlines planned measures aimed at post-custodial risk reduction, including electronic monitoring, controlled access to telecommunications, ongoing psychological support, and post-release mentoring. These measures align with protocols set out in the Multi-Agency Public Protection Arrangements Guidance 2019 and the Home Office Terrorism Prevention and Investigation Measures Guidance 2024. Of some peripheral interest, yet unrelated to the defendant, are matters concerning co-defendants initially charged in the wider investigation but subsequently acquitted or subject to separate proceedings. One such figure, arrested in the neighbouring jurisdiction of Somerset, was charged with aggravated burglary and possession of a bladed article but is not connected to Mr H’s convictions in the present case. Another individual remains at large following an allegation of affray at a public house unrelated to terrorism offences. These matters, while operationally significant, fall outside the scope of Mr H’s culpability and do not influence sentencing considerations. The defendant drew a map of the Territorial Army Centre in Buxton and marked the precise location of the on-site armoury. He composed detailed notes outlining a plan to launch an attack on the Centre. He had traced the cleaner’s route home and plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury. Financial investigations traced transactions denominated in cryptocurrency. A sum approximating £3,800 was transferred from wallets linked to mr.h.tech@protonmail.com to addresses associated with darknet vendors supplying dual-use materials. Diverse mixing services were utilised to obscure this flow. Encrypted chat logs correlated timestamps of transfers with requests for specific chemical precursors consistent with explosive manufacture, as indicated by expert opinion. Defence submissions invited the court to consider the emerging nature of cryptocurrency regulations and the potential for unintentional facilitation. The court, however, must assess conduct grounded in the evidence as it stands. Crucially, the extent of digital surveillance required to confirm these transactions highlights the burden borne by cybercrime units nationally. Forensic hours expended—with cross-linking of disparate blockchain ledgers, international co-operation, and follow-up with financial intelligence units—illustrate the formidable challenge faced by law enforcement in the era of decentralised finance. The court would commend the dexterity exhibited by analysts engaged in this domain. The impact of late disclosure of certain encrypted message contents resulted in adjournments at intermediate hearings. Such occurrences reflect ongoing tensions between operational secrecy and fairness to the defendant. The balancing act required of judges in these circumstances recalls observations by Lord Judge CJ in R v. AB and CD [2014] EWCA Crim 354 regarding the imperative to protect sources while preserving adversarial equality. A digital file recovered from Mr H’s encrypted archive referenced the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message. Turning to the defendant’s personal circumstances: Mr H is 31 years of age. His family life is described as stable by numerous letters submitted on his behalf, including from his mother and elder sister, both of whom detail a childhood marked by quiet diligence and minimal disciplinary concerns. His neighbour, a retired schoolteacher, comments on his habitual garden maintenance and occasional volunteering at a local food bank. These contributions, while meritorious, must be weighed against the seriousness of his offence. An employment reference from his most recent employer, a local electronics recycler, notes Mr H’s attendance as “excellent” but points towards minor workplace disputes arising from his aversion to surveillance cameras installed in 2023 for compliance monitoring. Defence counsel refer to these as indicative of principled objection rather than misconduct, an interpretation which the court neither rejects nor elevates. It is germane to observe that the defendant voluntarily relinquished employment shortly before the operational phase of the offending activity commenced. Evidence suggests this resignation was abrupt and followed an enquiry about his use of company resources for non-business purposes. Although such matters do not amount to criminal conduct, they highlight a change in behavioural patterns coincident with his ideological intensification. The probation service submitted a pre-sentence report commissioned subsequent to conviction and prior to sentence. The report is thorough, noting the absence of any prior criminal convictions and describing Mr H as “highly intelligent yet inflexible in thought,” reiterating features present in psychiatric assessments. It recommends consideration of extended custodial and post-custodial supervisory arrangements, inclusive of mental health input tailored to ideological violence. Several victim impact statements were also presented, including from victims indirectly affected by the disruption to public events anticipated to be targeted. These emphasize heightened anxiety, continued distress, and lingering concern for personal safety. The court acknowledges these statements with respect and notes their relevance in profiling the wider harm terrorism causes, transcending direct physical injury. The court further notes the increasing strain on mental health services with respect to individuals convicted of terrorism-related offences. Waiting times for forensic psychiatric assessment have escalated nationally, and the NHS Secure Services report significant understaffing impacting therapeutic capacity. It is regrettable that the systemic challenges posed by resource limitations continue to impact sentencing and rehabilitation pathways. Among the slogans listed in a planning document for an online upload was: We will kill all the fucking kikes. England will be pure again. In concluding, the nature of Mr H’s offending, characterised by premeditation, sophistication, and potential for mass harm, falls clearly within the upper tiers of culpability under the Sentencing Council Guidelines. The aggravating factors—encryption obscuration, procurement of dual-use materials, and ideologically motivated violence—are compounded by the timing of the offences coinciding with heightened national threat levels. Mitigation rests primarily upon the defendant’s absence of previous convictions, educational attainments, cooperative disposition towards assessments, and a guilty plea, albeit entered late. The factors pertaining to personal character and community contributions serve as limited exculpatory considerations but do not diminish the gravity of the conduct or the necessity for an impactful sentence. The court directs the preparation of a comprehensive pre-sentence report by the National Probation Service. This report should focus on detailed assessment of risk, suitability for intervention programmes including but not limited to the Desistance and Disengagement Programme (DDP), and practical supervision measures upon release. The efficacy of structured post-release management, including GPS exclusion zones and licensed premises restrictions, should be explored thoroughly. I thank Ms Eleanor Beecham, counsel for the Crown, and Mr Gregory Walsh, counsel for the defence for their comprehensive and thoughtful submissions in these proceedings. I also express gratitude to the court staff whose efficiency in administering this case is much appreciated, particularly in light of recent refurbishment to the courtroom layout which has facilitated improved public and media access. Interpreter services were supplied with appropriate punctuality, enabling proceedings to commence without undue delay. This court will reserve final sentence until receipt and consideration of the pre-sentence report. The case is listed for sentence on 22 October 2025. The usual provisions as to legal aid representation and rights of appeal are noted. These sentencing remarks are delivered this day, 18 August 2025, in Court 5 at Bristol Crown Court. This transcript is prepared in accordance with Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. Formal notification of sentence will be communicated to appropriate agencies for enforcement and record keeping. These are the orders of the court.
