input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BIRMINGHAM R v. Mr H Case No. B2025/27091 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge L. J. FAIRBANK Filed: 19 October 2025 Mr H appears before this court to be sentenced on charges relating to the Terrorism Act 2006, specifically one count of engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of terrorism under section 5(1)(a), and a further count of possession of an article for a purpose connected with the commission of terrorism under section 57(1) of the Terrorism Act 2000. The offending behaviour relates to a period from October 2023 to the defendant’s arrest in April 2025. The defendant was taken into custody at 0725 hours on 14 April 2025, following the execution of a warrant at his residence in the Selly Oak district by officers acting on behalf of Counter Terrorism Policing West Midlands. The warrant was issued pursuant to section 43B of the Terrorism Act 2000, authorised by the Senior Investigating Officer and supported by intelligence reports from the Security Service that indicated encrypted communications pertaining to explosive manufacture and ideological dissemination. At the time of arrest, Mr H was found to be in possession of a quantity of digital storage media, including a laptop and encrypted USB devices. Among the documents found was an explosive guide with a recipe: 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. The investigation into the defendant’s activities was multi-jurisdictional and inter-agency, involving the National Counter Terrorism Policing Headquarters, the Forensic Explosives Laboratory, and local policing bodies. The inquiry was notably prolonged due to operational secrecy and the necessity of cross-border data requests under the Mutual Legal Assistance Treaty framework with partners in the European Union. It must be acknowledged at this juncture that delays in the processing of disclosure materials were occasioned in part by technical constraints within the Forensic Digital Recovery Unit. The unit’s backlog, reported as a standing workload of circa 12,000 items nationally, was exacerbated by the requirement to apply emerging quantum decryption methods to the defendant’s devices. The Law Commission’s recent report on forensic technology capacity highlighted widespread resource shortfalls, which are reflected in real-case impacts, such as those seen here. Early in 2023, a Prevent referral had been made by an academic tutor at the University of Birmingham, where Mr H was enrolled in a postgraduate engineering programme. This referral arose from Mr H’s submission of an essay that, while primarily technical, contained references to historical acts of sabotage during wartime industrial campaigns, without sufficient distanciation or critique. The referral was handled by the West Midlands Prevent Coordination Unit and was closed following an initial assessment panel convened in April 2023, which noted insufficient evidence of radicalisation beyond academic interest. A Plea and Trial Preparation Hearing was convened on 17 September 2025. Mr H initially entered a not guilty plea. However, on the morning of the trial commencing on 13 October 2025, he changed his plea to guilty on both counts. The timing of this plea amendment is a salient consideration for sentencing credit; it is a recognised feature of modern criminal proceedings that pleas of guilty entered at relatively late stages may attract only moderate mitigation for promptness. It is relevant here to touch upon the established principles governing credit for guilty pleas. The seminal Court of Appeal decision of R v Stratton [2021] EWCA Crim 1554 emphasises that the timing of a plea is critical, and late pleas, entered after the trial is well underway, typically warrant less credit than those made at the first reasonable opportunity. input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BRISTOL R v. Mr H Case No. B2025/24963 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge A. M. FAIRBANK Filed: 29 September 2025 Mr H appears before this court for sentence on multiple counts engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of terrorism specified under section 5(1)(a) of the Terrorism Act 2006, as well as possession of articles for purposes connected with terrorism contrary to section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000. The conduct the subject of these charges spans a period from September 2022 until his arrest in March 2025. It bears recording at the outset that this court sits within a complex judicial framework in which terrorism offences are triaged and prosecuted with utmost gravity, reflecting the sustained threat to national security and the safety of the public. The Crown Prosecution Service’s Counter Terrorism Division, working in concert with specialised units such as Counter Terrorism Policing South West, have marshalled considerable resources both investigative and evidential to bring this prosecution. The defendant was arrested early morning on 17 March 2025 pursuant to warrants executed at his residential premises in the Redcliffe area of Bristol. These warrants were authorised under section 43B of the Terrorism Act 2000 following an intelligence-led operation incorporating signals interception, human intelligence sources, and covert surveillance. The defendant was found in possession of several electronic devices, including a encrypted mobile telephone and a laptop computer. The devices were subject to prolonged forensic examination by the National Cyber Crime Unit (NCCU), which formed a pivotal evidential strand in the Crown’s case. Mr H was found with materials setting out how to make a device from 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. The investigation which culminated in the defendant’s arrest was intensive and prolonged, spanning approximately eighteen months. The court is fully apprised of the resource demands placed on the police and ancillary agencies in tackling modern extremist threats. It may be noted, as a matter of procedural interest, that the investigation included the use of advanced decryption technology and specialist linguistic analysis to interpret coded communications. These technologies, though highly effective, require extensive human expertise to apply and interpret. Resource constraints within such units are well-documented, especially given competing demands from organised crime, serious violence, and cyber-enabled fraud investigations. Turning to the procedural history of this matter, an initial hearing was scheduled on 25 April 2025 but was adjourned due to issues relating to Legal Aid funding for the defendant’s representation. These administrative obstacles are regrettably frequent in cases involving complex digital material and may delay timely case progression. Nonetheless, subsequent hearings proceeded with relative promptness. The plea and trial preparation hearing took place on 18 August 2025. Notwithstanding his initial not guilty pleas, Mr H entered guilty pleas to all counts on the first day of the sentencing hearing. The court is mindful of the authorities regarding credit for guilty pleas, particularly in the terrorism context. The dicta in R v. Hobbs [2023] EWCA Crim 341 caution against over-generous reduction when pleas are entered late, especially after significant preparation and evidence disclosure. Such judicial guidance finds practical application in R v. Edgecombe [2024] EWCA Crim 1284, where credit was substantially curtailed due to delayed admission and tactical plea timing, causing additional burdens on the prosecution and victims. Consideration must accordingly be given to the timing and context of Mr H’s pleas, recognising some concession in mitigation but with limits reflecting these overarching principles. Delayed pleas, entered only after exhaustive evidence presentation and judicial rulings on contested issues, attract markedly less credit than early admissions which spare resources and demonstrate genuine contrition. It is useful to situate this case in the background of legislative and sentencing framework evolution. The maximum statutory penalty for the predicate offences under section 5 of the 2006 Act is life imprisonment – a reflection of Parliament’s intent to deter and incapacitate the most dangerous offenders. Furthermore, the Sentencing Council’s guidelines on Terrorism Offences, updated in November 2023, provide an analytical framework evaluating culpability, harm, and aggravating or mitigating factors. The range and complexity of Mr H’s offending conduct place this case firmly at the higher end of the culpability spectrum. Judicial authorities such as R v. Adeyemi [2021] EWCA Crim 975 and more recently R v. Murray [2024] EWCA Crim 605 underscore the principle that sentences must not only reflect the offence seriousness but also aim to denounce and deter those engaged in ideologically motivated criminal activity. Those judgments confirm that early neutralisation of threat and public protection objectives take precedence over leniency where the degree of planning or participation is substantial. The plan involved detonation at 3pm outside Cornbrook station, using a garage behind Nando’s on the High Street that lacked CCTV, at peak flow following a Leeds football match. Analysis of the digital materials retrieved from the defendant’s devices reveals a sustained pattern of engagement with proscribed extremist content and communications indicating a regrettable ideological commitment. His online activities included membership in closed forums known for violent exhortation. The sheer volume and technical sophistication of encrypted messaging exchanges required extended analysis by cybercrime specialists, many of whom have provided supporting court statements detailing the forensic processes involved. It is appropriate to observe in passing that this evidence was only accessible following effective interagency cooperation and painstaking cross-border liaison, particularly with the authorities of a European state where data storage servers were located. Such bilateral collaboration, though often unheralded, is a cornerstone of contemporary counter-terrorism efforts. Mr H’s files included a bridge layout and drone sequence intended to strike emergency services after the first explosion. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. The defendant’s possession of technical documents relating to the manufacture of explosive devices, along with evidence of purchasing precursors and components via dark web marketplaces, points conclusively to preparation rather than mere idle curiosity. Although a substantial weight of material is numerically voluminous, some of the files displayed signs of being only partially accessed or incomplete. The court has considered submissions regarding this, including arguments that partial possession may be less culpable, but established jurisprudence, notably R v. Simons [2020] EWCA Crim 1436, confirms that intent may be inferred from possession when associated conduct and context corroborate preparation. The defendant's home contained a list of components for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list including Party Girl hair bleach and Lancome nail varnish remover. In deliberating upon the defendant’s background, it is germane to observe that Mr H has no previous convictions. He was raised in a stable household environment and engaged for several years in part-time employment within the logistics sector. Defence have provided character references highlighting his involvement in amateur radio clubs and attendance at local music festivals. While community engagement of this order generally constitutes a mitigating factor, it must not overshadow the gravity of the conduct now established. The court is similarly acquainted with numerous cases where seemingly ordinary individuals have embraced extreme ideologies, demonstrating the inadequacy of surface indicators alone. A brief digression is warranted regarding the apparent overburdened state of probation services nationally, exacerbated by funding cuts and recruitment challenges. The strain on offender management and risk assessment staff cannot be underestimated, particularly in complex terrorism cases where multi-agency input is indispensable. It is perhaps unsurprising that the Probation Service report expresses caution regarding post-release supervision, given these institutional difficulties. Officers found a Buffer-scheduled tweet containing a link to South Manchester Synagogue followed by a countdown-themed message. The correspondence lodged with the court from various community-based organisations offers glimpses into the defendant’s efforts at sporadic disengagement over the preceding two years. One letter from the Bristol Resilience Project outlines attempts to engage Mr H in cognitive behavioural therapy, psychoeducational interventions, and social support networks aimed at countering radicalisation. These efforts, while commendable for their principled persistence in the face of recalcitrance, were undermined by the defendant’s intermittent cooperation and limited insight into the risks posed by his own conduct. Of some interest, although tangential, is information about a co-defendant in a related matter who was charged with aggravated burglary at a private residence during a holiday absence. That case, while unrelated to Mr H’s charges, provides an instructive contrast in the challenges of managing multi-accused terrorism-promoting networks and the differing culpabilities therein. It should also be recorded that during the investigative phase, a co-accused linked to the same extremist network reportedly assaulted arresting officers with a heavy metal chair following a supermarket affray. Such episodes, whilst collateral to this trial, underscore the volatile milieu within which the present investigation unfolded. The defendant drew a map of the Territorial Army Centre in Buxton and identified the cleaner. The operational notes stated that Mr H plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury. Financial investigations recovered cryptocurrency transactions amounting to several thousand pounds linked demonstrably to the defendant’s wallet. These transactions included payments to suppliers offering items capable of dual use in legitimate photography equipment and, as the prosecution submits, improvised explosive device components. The court notes with deep concern the escalation in the use of cryptocurrencies in financing unlawful acts, a point spectrally resonant with the observations in R v. Khalil [2023] EWCA Crim 887 regarding the challenges of tracing and disrupting such monetary flows. In a separate but equally demanding operational effort, counter-terrorism surveillance captured footage of Mr H visiting a remote storage facility late at night, where materials consistent with those listed in his encrypted correspondences were observed. The investment of over 120 analyst-hours in stabilising and cross-referencing this footage epitomises the immense human resource commitment terrorism investigations entail, recalling the remarks made by Lord Chief Justice in R v. Weston [2011] EWCA Crim 2109 on the asymmetry between offender expediency and investigative diligence. The defendant’s possession of a modest quantity of cannabis resin, recovered during the execution of the search warrant, was explored in the mitigation submissions as evidence of a “relatable youth culture” and purported normality. This court is disinclined to afford solvent any attenuation of the severity of terrorism offending on such grounds. In a concealed file recovered from Mr H’s encrypted drive, investigators found references to the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message. Turning to matters of personal character and health, the defendant is 31 years old. His academic record comprises a university diploma in information technology, followed by intermittent employment in warehouse operations. A letter from his former line manager commends his punctuality and technical aptitude but notes a fracturing of workplace relationships coinciding temporally with enhanced scrutiny under Counter Terrorism Policing processes. Additional character references from local voluntary sector organisations commend Mr H’s occasional volunteering with elderly home visits. While such benevolent acts are of note, it is the court’s firm position that positive civic contributions should be weighed carefully alongside harmful conduct, not as wholesale exculpatory factors. Psychiatric assessment supplied by consultant forensic psychiatrist Dr Helena Malik diagnosed Mr H with moderate anxiety but no psychosis or personality disorder. Notwithstanding that, the report cautions about Mr H’s demonstrable propensity for rigid ideological reasoning and identifies a sustained high risk of continued extremist involvement absent robust multi-agency supervision. This assessment aligns with contemporary research elucidating the limited efficacy of community-based counter-extremism programmes in certain cases, as discussed in the 2024 Home Office Prevent Strategy Review. Among the slogans listed in a planning document for an online upload was: We will kill all the fucking kikes. England will be pure again. Finally, the court must address the gravamen of the sentencing exercise. The defendant engaged in a highly organised programme of preparation for acts calculated to cause widespread harm. The sophistication evident in his digital encryption, procurement methods, and operational security elevate his culpability to the highest level envisaged by the Sentencing Council guidelines. Aggravating factors include the intended use of the materials in a location frequented by civilians, the effort to conceal communications, and the continued ideological adherence even after prevent intervention attempts. The defendant’s mitigation is limited. There are no previous convictions; educational attainment is unremarkable but present; and the amendment of plea, though late, signifies some acknowledgment of culpability. Given the timing, credit is appropriately restricted to a one-sixth reduction. The court directs the preparation of a comprehensive pre-sentence report by the Probation Service, with particular attention to viability of extended custodial supervision, potential for cognitive-behavioral programmes tailored to ideological desistance, and the availability of accommodation within high-security approved premises. The report should also address possible licence conditions including curfew, electronic monitoring, and strict exclusion zones to mitigate ongoing risks. The court acknowledges liaison between Counter Terrorism Policing, the Multi-Agency Public Protection Arrangements (MAPPA), and NHS forensic mental health services regarding post-custodial management. While these agencies operate under considerable resource restriction, their collaboration remains vital. Before drawing these remarks to a close, it would be remiss not to express the court’s respect for the professionalism of all involved. Special mention is due to the prosecuting counsel, Ms Eleanor Draper, for her clarity and meticulously prepared submissions, and to Mr Oliver Kemp, instructed by Legal Aid, for his diligent representation despite procedural delays in funding approvals that unfortunately impeded preliminary expert instructions. The court also thanks the court administrative staff and security personnel at Bristol Crown Court, whose composure and efficiency materially contribute to the dignity and orderly conduct of proceedings, especially given recent refurbishment of the court facilities which entailed temporary logistical disruption. The defendant is reminded of his right to appeal sentence under the Criminal Appeal Act 1968 within 28 days of the formal sentence being imposed. These sentencing remarks are issued this day, 29 September 2025, in Court 5 at Bristol Crown Court. The proceedings have been recorded and the transcript authorised in accordance with Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The formal record of conviction and sentence shall be distributed to the appropriate custodial and supervisory authorities. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BRISTOL R v. Mr H Case No. B2025/29842 Sentencing Remarks – Her Honour Judge E. C. Lawford Filed: 15 September 2025 Mr H appears for sentence on charges under sections 5(1)(a) and 57 of the Terrorism Act 2006 and Terrorism Act 2000, respectively. The conduct attributed to him covers the period from September 2022 through to his arrest in April 2025. The court has heard extensive evidence and submissions in this multifaceted matter, and it is now incumbent upon me to deliver sentencing remarks prior to the formal sentencing hearing. The defendant’s initial apprehension occurred at 04:50 on 3 April 2025, following the execution of a search warrant by the South West Counter Terrorism Unit (SWCTU) at his residential address in Montpelier, Bristol. The warrant was granted pursuant to subsection 43B of the Terrorism Act 2000 following intelligence obtained from the Joint Security Service highlighting Mr H’s involvement in digital communications with proscribed entities. At the time of his arrest, officers recovered an array of electronic devices, including encrypted external drives and a range of items flagged by explosives expertise as potentially dual-use. Investigators found a realistic bomb plan which needed 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. Prior to the arrest, the investigation had been underway for several months, involving a collaborative effort between SWCTU and the National Cyber Countermeasure Taskforce. This inter-agency endeavour relied heavily on open-source intelligence, geospatial analysis of social media activity, and digital traffic correlation. Of interest, the digital forensic workload experienced by the National Cyber Taskforce has increased by over 35% year on year since 2021, attributable in part to the rising sophistication of encryption technology and the proliferation of anonymisation services. While such forensic challenges are far from unique, they underscore the resource implications of prosecuting complex terrorism cases in the digital age. The court must comment on procedural matters that have delayed the progression of this case. The Legal Aid Agency’s decision to cap funding for the defence’s expert forensic consultation substantially slowed disclosure and defence preparation. This is not an isolated example; accounts from defence practitioners indicate systemic underprovision of resources for cases requiring digital expertise, which can compromise the defendant’s ability to fully and properly prepare their case. It is a matter of professionalism and justice that these hurdles are surmounted, but no less regrettable for their persistence. A report from the local Probation Service highlights the acute pressures faced within offender management departments. Staffing shortages, with vacancies averaging 15% regionally, exacerbate caseload volumes and hamper the capacity for detailed risk assessment, particularly in terrorism-related contexts where vigilance must be constant. These systemic stresses may seem peripheral, yet they form the backdrop to the operational challenges that accompany cases such as this. The court notes a letter submitted by the Bristol Homeless Outreach Network, drawing attention to the increasing visibility of rough sleeping in the city centre and the attendant risks this poses to vulnerable individuals. While this submission bears no direct relation to the defendant’s culpability or the facts of this matter, it paints a picture of a city contending with multiple, intersecting social issues that require careful policy attention. It is also worth recording that a Channel referral was made in late 2019 by a secondary school teacher following concerns about Mr H’s attendance and associations at the time. The referral was closed after a six-week monitoring period with engagement from the Prevent team, who noted a reduction in concerning behaviour. This intervention is recognised not for its efficacy in this matter, but as an example of the layered institutional efforts to identify and intervene in ideological vulnerability prior to escalation. The plan involved detonation at 3pm outside Cornbrook station, using a garage behind Nando’s on the High Street that lacked CCTV, at peak flow following a Leeds football match. The evidence unfolds a digital footprint of increasing radicalisation expressed via online forums where Mr H is alleged to have posted lengthy treatises advancing grievances and justification for violence. Linguistic analysis commissioned by the prosecution notes a progressive adoption of key terminology and ideological frameworks consistent with international extremist manifestos. Defence submissions suggest that some writings may have been exploratory or even satirical; however, the jury found otherwise after weighing the totality of the evidence. Recent jurisprudence assists in framing the court’s approach to sentencing in terrorism cases. The Supreme Court’s decision in R v. Bashir [2023] UKSC 43 reiterates the imperative that sentences must reflect the need for deterrence, protection of the public, and denunciation in contexts where ideological extremism fuels criminality. Bashir also affirms that the mere possession of such materials or engagement in preparatory conduct can attract significant custodial sentences where the intent to act is clear. Officers found a file on Mr H’s computer describing a follow-up explosion delivered by drone targeting responders. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. Digital forensic recovery uncovered extensive encrypted volumes, including instructional materials and schematic diagrams relating to improvised explosive devices. Some were severely corrupted or incomplete. Defence experts raised issues about the defendant’s actual access to all content; yet, as per the position taken in R v. Alanzi [2022] EWCA Crim 612, possession with awareness suffices to establish culpability for preparatory offences. The incomplete files do not diminish the assessed level of danger. Turning to other evidential features, the court finds it necessary to note an unrelated drug offence prosecuted in a local magistrates’ court against a co-defendant, who surrendered to police months after Mr H’s arrest. The two have no proven direct operational link. Authorities caution that conflating co-defendant actions risks misattribution of roles and responsibilities—an often overlooked but vital point in complex prosecutions. The defendant's laptop contained a detailed list of components for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list including NewLook hair bleach and SuperDrug brand nail varnish remover. Notwithstanding the gravity of these findings, a forensic analysis of Mr H’s photographic archives included benign collections of vintage cars and landscape images. Defence counsel submitted that this exhibited a well-rounded personality and interests disconnected from extremist pursuits. The court regards this evidence as peripheral and of limited weight in its sentencing calculus. An NHS Forensic Psychology report, submitted pursuant to the Criminal Procedure Rules, offers a comprehensive assessment of Mr H’s mental state over the intervening period. Dr Ayesha Killick observed a rigid cognitive style with a tendency to ideological absolutism but categorically ruled out any diagnosable mental disorder. The report underscores the defendant’s capacity to understand the nature and consequences of his actions, a critical consideration in assessing moral blameworthiness. The inquiry also exposed the toll that counter-terrorism investigations place on policing resources. Officers deployed for lengthy shifts, sometimes delayed by operational exigencies unrelated to the case, have faced cumulative fatigue. The South West Fire Brigade, while not directly engaged, was on standby during controlled searches of potential hazardous materials. This highlights the multi-agency nature of modern threat response, where effective coordination is indispensable. Mr H drafted a social media post set for timed release linking to South Manchester Synagogue with the caption tick tock. Mr H’s international travel records reveal a brief visit to Rotterdam in late 2023, ostensibly for academic purposes. However, surveillance indicates unrecorded movements to an industrial estate noted by Counter Terrorism Policing as a site frequented by known extremists. Defence submissions contest this as coincidence; the court is bound to draw reasonable inferences. Cases concerning late guilty pleas furnish instructive precedent. As seen in R v. Stuart [2024] EWCA Crim 1997, late admissions after protracted trial preparation reduce the extent of sentencing credit. Mr H’s plea on 10 September 2025 comes after extensive disclosure and witness preparation, limiting the mitigating recognition that may be afforded. Regarding the provenance of evidence, it is pertinent that the Police Digital Evidence Unit encountered software compatibilities issues when processing defences’ material - a consequence of widely varying formats and encryption protocols. Such technicalities have become regrettably commonplace, imposing delays on case timelines and inflating costs. Prison service correspondence indicates an acute shortage of places in high-security units suited to terrorism offenders. This structural shortfall necessitates careful consideration of interim placements pending sentencing to minimise risk. The Department of Justice acknowledges these challenges in their recent annual report, calling for increased funding for custodial estate development. The cleaner of the Territorial Army centre in Buxton was central to Mr H's plot. His strategy included a written plan in which he plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury. A cryptocurrency transaction trail identified by cyber forensic accountants reveals transfers of approximately £3,700 over several months from an account linked to Mr H’s other persona. These payments transited via multiple mixers and tumblers, reputed to obfuscate linkage. The court reiterates prior comments on the challenges this poses to transparency and enforcement, echoing concerns raised in parliamentary committees. The Modern Slavery and Exploitation Unit provided an amicus report addressing the context of such financial activity, noting that illicit funds related to extremist procurement networks can sometimes disguise flows associated with forced labour exploitation. This tangential material, while not directly relevant to Mr H, evidences the complex intersections of criminal business models involved. Careful consideration was given to the statements from victims indirectly affected by the anticipated consequences of Mr H’s conduct. A coalition of community groups submitted a joint letter describing the mettle and resilience of Bristol’s diverse populace in confronting violence and extremism. Their words, though not evidencing personal loss, reveal the societal stakes at play in terrorism proceedings. Mr H’s fallback strategy included a document linking to the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message. Turning to personal circumstances, Mr H is 30 years old and holds an honours degree in computer science from a nationally respected university. His former employer, a regional software development firm, provided a character reference describing him as “technically gifted but socially withdrawn.” His abrupt resignation following security clearance disputes coincided with what the prosecution suggests was critical escalation in preparatory planning. The defendant’s partner has submitted multiple letters describing his efforts to engage with rehabilitation programmes, including a local mentoring initiative aimed at disengagement from extremist ideologies. Such engagement is of course encouraged, though the court takes a reserved view where it relates to attempts late in proceedings. Mention should be made of correspondence received from the Bristol Youth Arts Foundation, which detailed Mr H’s limited volunteer work teaching coding to underprivileged adolescents. This community contribution, while laudable, offers limited mitigation in the context of his offending. The Probation Service pre-sentence report emphasises elevated risks, including the defendant’s demonstrated cognitive rigidity and propensity for binary thinking, which hinder responsiveness to standard desistance interventions. The authors note that special psychological programmes with a focus on ideological deradicalisation and cognitive restructuring may assist but stress that there are no guarantees. A typed speech draft intended for a video upload included the sentence: We will kill all the fucking kikes. Down with the New World Order. In summary, this case presents a calculated and sustained effort by Mr H to prepare acts of terrorism, evidenced by encrypted and sophisticated material, intent inferred from conduct and planning, and supplemented by demonstrable operational contacts. The aggravating features are substantial, including the targeted nature of the intended harm, the duration of offending conduct, and the technical capabilities applied. Mitigating factors are minimal. The defendant’s previous good character, educational achievements, and belated guilty pleas warrant some recognition, but cannot outweigh the serious threats posed. The court reminds itself, in line with the Terrorism Sentencing Guidelines issued by the Sentencing Council in 2023, that protection of the public and the need for deterrence remain paramount. A comprehensive pre-sentence report will be commissioned, informing management of risk, suitability for custody or community measures, and recommendations for rehabilitative support or licence conditions, including potential polygraph monitoring and GPS curfew enforcement. Community safety, not individual rehabilitative aspirations alone, dictates measures in cases of this nature. These sentencing remarks are made on this 15th day of September 2025, in Court 11 at the Crown Court at Bristol. They have been prepared and recorded pursuant to Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The transcript will be made available to counsel and relevant authorities. The defendant has the right of appeal against sentence within 28 days of the passing of sentence in accordance with the Criminal Appeal Act 1968 and the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980. No reporting restrictions apply under section 49 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933. Costs remain reserved. These are the orders of the court.

input: IN THE CROWN COURT AT BIRMINGHAM R v. Mr H Case No. B2025/27854 Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge R. J. Fairfax Filed: 18 September 2025 Mr H appears before this court for sentence on charges under the Terrorism Act 2006. Specifically, he has been convicted on two counts of preparing acts of terrorism contrary to section 5(1)(a) of the Terrorism Act 2006, and one count of possession of an article for a purpose connected with terrorism, contrary to section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000. The conduct in question unfolded over a period beginning late 2022 and culminating in his arrest on 15 January 2025. The defendant was first taken into custody at 07:13 on that January morning, following the execution of a series of search warrants granted under section 43B of the Terrorism Act 2000. These were carried out by Counter Terrorism Policing West Midlands, with support from forensic digital officers and local constabulary units. The warrant authorised search of his residential address in the Moseley district and the seizure of multiple digital devices believed to be key in evidencing the preparatory acts alleged. The court notes the considerable logistical complexity attendant on the operation, which involved coordination between the CT Policing intelligence division and the National Cyber Crime Unit. Mr H possessed bomb-making instructions outlining a device made from 600g of hydrogen peroxide-based hair bleach, three containers of domestic drain cleaner, cold compresses containing ammonium nitrate, metal nuts and ball bearings, annotated with the handwritten phrase: optimum yield = 18 to 22 casualties at 2m radius. This arrest followed a lengthened period of joint investigative activity, stretching back over twelve months. Intelligence gathering utilised conventional surveillance techniques alongside emerging capabilities such as network traffic analysis, pattern-of-life mapping using anonymised telecommunications data, and advanced cryptanalysis executed by the National Technical Assistance Centre. The court observes here that such a multilateral operation represents a significant commitment of both human and financial resources, underscoring the concern posed by the defendant's activities. It is regrettable that these resources are diverted from a gamut of other pressing operational priorities, including ongoing investigations into organised crime and violent offences affecting the West Midlands and surrounding regions. In the course of pre-trial proceedings, several adjournments resulted from challenges relating to the defendant’s Legal Aid representation. The court reiterates its frustration with the frequent administrative delays surrounding authorisation for expert reports—delays that invariably result in protracted case timetables and place additional burdens on all parties, including victims and court staff alike. Mr H's defence team ultimately secured authorisation to instruct independent forensic psychiatric and cyber-technical experts, though the process involved considerable correspondence with the Legal Aid Agency, marked by delayed responses and intermittent refusals of funding that, on balance, served no useful purpose but to promote procedural delay. The court is conscious of the broader pressures facing the Probation Service and allied agencies tasked with producing pre-sentence reports in terrorism cases. Staffing shortages and increasingly complex risk assessment frameworks have led to considerable backlogs, further compounded by the need to liaison extensively with security services and mental health professionals whose availability is similarly restricted. The institution of Better Case Management (BCM) protocols in Crown Courts over the past five years has sought to mitigate some of these organisational pressures by streamlining case progression and establishing clearer administrative lines. Though imperfect, the system offers a tentative framework for the more coherent handling of cases such as this. An earlier Channel referral in relation to the defendant—initiated in October 2020 by a university advisor due to expressions of extremist sympathies in written coursework—did not yield long-term engagement or formally closed only after six months of intermittent contact. The court accepts that no evidential threshold for further intervention was then met and that the Channel panel’s disability to foresee this trajectory reflects not negligence but the inherent uncertainty in counter-radicalisation work. Those who argue otherwise must contend with the wide variety of ideological expressions and the often opaque indicators of true risk. Much has been said of late pleas in terrorism cases. It is a regrettable and increasing phenomenon among defendants facing such serious charges to defer guilty pleas to the cusp of trial or, as here, moments before the sentence hearing. The Crown is entitled—and indeed obliged—to invite the court to discount credit afforded for such pleas given their limited utility in conserving police and prosecutorial resources or sparing witnesses the rigours of testimony. The Court of Appeal in the leading authorities R v. Halvorsen [2023] EWCA Crim 1029 and R v. Nugent [2023] EWCA Crim 1440 made clear that timing and motivation are critical factors in this assessment. The present case conforms to that pattern of delay and partial disclosure. The court acknowledges the defence's submission that Mr H’s guilty pleas represent some acceptance of responsibility; however, the backdrop of extensive preparation for trial, considerable expert evidence, and numerous witness statements prior to plea tempers this proposition. The sentencing principle of proportionality and the need to foster early cooperation in terrorism proceedings necessarily guide the court to restrict any discount in sentencing accordingly. It must be observed, as an aside of procedural note, that the Legal Aid Agency’s handling of defence funding in this case manifested bureaucratic inertia which increasingly undermines the integrity of fair trial rights. The court places on record its appreciation for counsel instructed for the defence—Mr Oswald Chivers, who has argued with professional acumen despite the constraints imposed by underfunding and administrative wrangling. Equally, thanks are due to Ms Harriet Llewellyn of counsel for the Crown, whose submissions were clear, comprehensive, and rooted firmly in the applicable jurisprudence and statutory framework. The defendants’ case suffered a further delay when an interpreter appointment, arranged for a related ancillary hearing set for 4 March 2025, was postponed following a no-show of the assigned linguist. While such occurrences are rare, they continue to reflect the challenges of securing specialist court support services under stretched public sector budgets. Turning to matters of evidence, digital forensic examination disclosed an array of encrypted communications, cryptographically hidden logs, and data transfer attempts to overseas servers known to be associated with proscribed groups. The painstaking reconstruction of these artefacts, extending over a period of some eight months, aptly demonstrates the resource-intensive nature of digital counter-terror investigations today. The court acknowledges the outstanding commitment of personnel at the Southern Cyber Crime Unit who undertook detailed device imaging and network packet inspection under complex operational conditions. Mr H identified a garage behind Nando's on the High Street, near Cornbrook station, with no CCTV coverage, to plant an explosive for 3pm on football Saturday as fans from the Leeds match passed to maximise casualties. The defendant maintained a personal blog, initially featuring benign content related to urban gardening and amateur radio but later increasingly populated by incendiary rhetoric and references to proscribed ideological material. The court notes the painstaking linguistic analysis undertaken by the Office for Security Analysis, which characterised the defendant’s writings as echoing narratives found in the literature of banned groups under schedule 2 of the Terrorism Act 2000. These findings are hardly surprising given the associate communications recovered and the defendant’s admitted visits to online forums with known extremist leanings. Mr H drafted a sequence involving a drone-triggered second device to go off after first responders reached the scene. Included in the file was a bridge schematic estimating the arrival times for both police and medical responders, alongside a note that read: Second boom = max psychological effect; if no sirens 3 to 5 min delay. Expert evidence disclosed the presence of manuals on explosive device fabrication concealed within encrypted containers named “Project Ironclad.” Defence submissions advanced that some files constituted ‘research’ on historical ordnance for hobbyist re-enactment, yet this is plainly untenable in light of expert testimony confirming the presence of contemporary, fully functional schematics. The court finds that the possession of such material can only serve a purpose connected with the commission of terrorism. The defendant was found with notes for manufacturing TATP, including calculated molar ratios, notes on drying times handwritten in the margins of a disassembled chemistry textbook and a shopping list including No More Greys hair bleach and Tesco brand nail varnish remover. The court is reminded, albeit tangentially, of the longstanding principles addressed in the preamble to the Sentencing Council’s Terrorism Guidelines (2023) which emphasize that intent and preparation for mass harm must be punished proportionately, balancing public protection with rehabilitation prospects. The defendant, while able to benefit from educational opportunities prior to offending, elected an alternative path in pursuit of ideological extremism. The possession of an illicit blade in a public park, dating to over a year prior and unrelated to the charges of terrorism, was clarified as the act of an acquaintance of the defendant during a separate incident. No physical evidence links Mr H to that possession, which the defence disavowed as irrelevant yet volunteered for completeness. Digital evidence revealed a delayed post targeting South Manchester Synagogue, released shortly after a message titled Statement Before the Storm. The Court also had regard to the defendant’s travel history in late 2023 and early 2024. Documented airline data reveals a trip to Brussels ostensibly for business purposes; however, intelligence reports correlated Mr H’s presence with a meeting of individuals later convicted for conspiracies to supply explosives in multiple member states. Defence suggested coincidence, but the court finds such a characterization implausible. Separately, the defendant’s communications history includes numerous contacts with an individual arrested in connection with unrelated cyber-fraud offences in the South East. While co-defendant pleas were entered in that case, the court notes no evidence suggesting Mr H’s involvement. Such linkages exemplify the complex webs investigative authorities must navigate to isolate genuine threat actors amid a tangled milieu of legitimate and illicit actors. The court notes the production of a comprehensive psychiatric report by Dr Samuel Endicott, consultant forensic psychiatrist, who examined Mr H over the course of three sessions undertaken in May 2025. Dr Endicott’s report, thorough and professional in form, diagnoses a personality disorder with traits conducive to inflexibility, zealousness, and unyielding ideological convictions but denies the presence of psychotic illness or diminished responsibility. The report assigns a high risk of serious harm based on identified markers including cognitive rigidity, emotional detachment, and active dissemination of extremist material online. These findings echo prior observations in cases such as R v. Mallory [2008] EWCA Crim 1624, where the Court of Appeal upheld the need to balance treatment considerations with public protection imperatives even in the presence of psychiatric pathology. The defendant’s letter to the court, politely written with legible handwriting and formatted neatly, expresses regret that his belief system led him “down a mistaken path.” It acknowledges the harm caused but stops short of a full apology or recognition of the scale of potential consequences. The defendant drew a map of the Territorial Army Centre in Buxton and identified the cleaner. The operational notes stated that Mr H plotted to affix a small smoke-emitting device to her car’s wheel hub, planning to detonate the device remotely as she passed down a rural road, forcing her to stop, whereupon he would subdue her with a knife and compel her to provide him access to the armoury. Notably, the court was informed of a cryptocurrency transaction totalling £3,200 from an account linked to the defendant towards a now-defunct vendor blacklisted for offering chemical precursors commonly used in explosive manufacture. Such transactions illustrate the expanding challenge posed by digital financial instruments in terrorist financing, a challenge which law enforcement agencies grapple with through initiatives such as Project STRIKE. The court also reviewed surveillance records of a brief nocturnal visit Mr H made in November 2024 to a disused industrial estate on the outskirts of Coventry. This location was identified in a separate investigation involving illegal waste dumping by criminal enterprises. While that investigation remains ongoing and unrelated to the defendant, the coincidence highlights the array of public order challenges faced by local authorities simultaneously. Counter-terrorism operations involve cooperation with multiple agencies, including regional fire and rescue units, which bring valuable expertise—especially in incidents involving the threat of explosives or incendiaries. An illustrative example occurred in 2023 when a coordinated response averted extensive harm in a separate incident involving arson at a commercial warehouse in Droitwich. Such background is relevant, albeit indirectly, in that they set the bar for the level of readiness and coordination courts expect in cases involving potential mass harm. A document stored in a hidden container was found to contain material from the darkweb marketplace GoreArena advertising zombie knives, with anatomical diagrams showing precise arterial targets in the neck and inner thigh and was annotated with instructions to puncture rather than slash, and if possible remove the head for a stronger message. Turning to the defendant’s personal circumstances. Mr H, now 30 years old, holds a degree in applied computer engineering obtained from a Midlands university. His employment history reflects a number of short-term contracts, including a stint as a network systems analyst terminated following concerns over his online activity. Character references from former employers emphasise his technical competence and professionalism but also remark on a noticeable change in demeanour commencing mid-2022. Letters of support were submitted by a local environmental conservation group citing Mr H’s volunteer efforts with community clean-up initiatives. While such engagement reflects positively on his capacity for pro-social behaviour, it nevertheless remains peripheral to the gravity of his offending conduct. Indeed, the court notes authority suggesting that civic contributions, while laudable, do not diminish culpability in cases of serious ideological extremism. The court has carefully considered the oral and written submissions of defence counsel, Mr Oswald Chivers, who advanced the proposition that the defendant is amenable to rehabilitation through engagement with structured de-radicalisation and cognitive behavioural programmes. While the court readily supports access to such interventions where effective, it must balance optimism with realism given the historically high attrition rates in this cohort and the demonstrable risk posed absent sustained, intensive monitoring. The Probation Service has indicated that a pre-sentence report will address the viability of extended custodial supervision accompanied by statutory licence conditions encompassing electronic monitoring, internet filtering, and mandatory psychological treatment. This comprehensive strategy is consistent with prevailing best practice frameworks and underscores the importance of multi-agency co-operation across custodial and community phases. Among the slogans listed in a planning document for an online upload was: We will kill all the fucking kikes. England will be pure again. In conclusion, the court finds this to be a case exemplifying the utmost seriousness of terrorism preparatory offences. Aggravating features include the sophistication of planning, use of encryption and cryptocurrencies to evade detection, and the readiness to associate with known extremist networks. Mitigation is scant and includes only the absence of previous convictions and late guilty pleas which, as noted, attract limited credit. It is regrettable, but necessary, that a custodial sentence of significant length must be contemplated to reflect the gravity of offending and to deter others. The court will therefore direct the preparation of a full pre-sentence report which must include detailed risk assessment, feasibility of high-restriction custodial options, and exploration of suitable rehabilitative pathways including de-radicalisation programmes accredited under the National Counter Terrorism Strategy. These sentencing remarks are issued this day, 18 September 2025, in Court 4 at Birmingham Crown Court. The proceedings have been transcribed in accordance with Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The formal record of conviction and sentence will be transmitted to the relevant authorities for registration in due course. These are the orders of the court.
